When my father asked me for help with his life insurance, I naïvely assumed it would be a straightforward matter of dollars and cents.
Whether it is consumer prices, raw material costs or the fines levied on miscreant corporations, all signs pointed up this week.
Babel was re-enacted in three fascinating and substantial pieces played by David Robertson and the Zankel Band at Zankel Hall on Thursday night.

The Roots proved that they were the best backing band in hip-hop on Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall.

Billy Connolly, the Scottish comedian, will draw from his more than 35 years of comedy routines for his stint at the Arts complex in Manhattan, which runs through June 17.
This year's winners are young women who were 18 when their plays were submitted. All three have a lot to say, some of it funny, poignant, brutal and at times confusing — like life.
"The Necklace," the loony new show by the Talking Band theater company, lovingly revives an old and beloved form, the serial.
Dominic Dromgoole's background in what he calls "writers' theater" will likely play a part in his first season as the Globe's new artistic director.
"In the Continuum," which tells the story of two women — one in Los Angeles and one in Zimbabwe — infected with H.I.V., was a big hit at the Harare International Arts Festival last month.

Indian retailers are frantically expanding in an effort to gain a substantial lead before foreign competitors are allowed to enter the market.
For all the improvements in computer security, using the Internet is growing only more dangerous — both at home and at work.
Sharon Lockhart introduced yet another combination to her multilayered "Pine Flat" narratives when she asked the Los Angeles architecture firm Escher GuneWardena to design her series of exhibitions.

"Invitation to the Voyage," performed on Thursday evening at Immanuel Lutheran Church on the Upper East Side, represented less a foray into new territory than business as usual.

Ron Hutchinson's witty, poignant one-act play "Beau Brummell," tosses out grand observations while conveying the quiet agonies of a ruined man trying not to see through his delusions.

The world's most successful single-session charity bridge event had its 43rd running on Tuesday evening at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, with virtually all of the top New York-area players competing.
If the housing boom is finally nearing an end, it is clear from regional activity in both apartment and single-family home construction, that it was an unusual boom.
Yi Seok has led perhaps the most checkered life, from his birth and fall as a royal prince.
For the good of the sport, horses should match up in all three Triple Crown races. In an ideal world, a horse's presence in all three races should be mandated.

A Reuters article on May 8 about maneuvering by Italy's incoming governing coalition of Prime Minister Romano Prodi to choose a new president misstated the president's term of office. It is seven years, not two.

A front-page article on Thursday about a federal plan to use contractors to help secure the borders of the United States misstated the amount that Lockheed Martin made in federal government sales in 2005. Of $37.2 billion in sales, more than $31 billion, not $6 billion, was in sales to the government.

FALLOUT OF LAWSUIT -- The attorney general of Ohio, Jim Petro, dismissed the law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad & Shulman as his special counsel yesterday, one day after the firm was indicted on charges of paying more than $11 million in kickbacks to clients. Mr. Petro also removed Milberg Weiss from representing the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority, the state's college savings plan, in lawsuits against Putnam American Government Income Fund, which is run by Putnam Investments. The 300 suits claim Putnam and other mutual fund companies engaged in improper trading. A spokeswoman for the firm, Marina Ein, said in a statement that ''Milberg Weiss regrets that the attorney general of Ohio has asked the firm to withdraw as counsel for the Ohio Tuition Trust Authority.'' (BLOOMBERG NEWS) IN-FLIGHT INTERNET SERVICE -- Three more companies -- Unison Spectrum, AMTS Consortium and Intelligent Transportation and Monitoring Wireless -- have dropped out of an auction for licenses to provide in-flight Internet services. With offers now at more than $28 million for the larger of two licenses, Unison and the other two firms are reaching their limits. Verizon Airfone, a unit of Verizon Communications, dropped out of the auction earlier this week. There are now four eligible participants. Most recently, the bidding was led by AC BidCo, which is associated with Ripplewood Holdings, a private-equity fund. AC BidCo had offered $28.4 million for one license, while LiveTV, a unit of the JetBlue Airways Corporation, had offered $615,000 for a smaller amount of spectrum. (DOW JONES) NEW CHIEF AT TYSON -- The world's largest meat processor, Tyson Foods, promoted its president, Richard L. Bond, to chief executive, succeeding John H. Tyson. Mr. Tyson, 52, will remain chairman, focusing on strategy and supervising the chief financial officer, general counsel and senior vice president for external affairs. He had been chief executive since October 2001. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) SUPPORT FOR AOL -- Time Warner, the media conglomerate, is committed to turning around its AOL Internet business even as the unit loses customers at a faster-than-expected pace, the chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, below, said. AOL's dial-up subscribers have been defecting to high-speed services largely provided by cable and phone companies as it works to revamp its business as an online provider of entertainment and other services supported by advertising revenue. Mr. Parsons said AOL ''is in a space that the marketplace thinks is contracting and needs to migrate its business to another part of the Internet landscape where the market is growing,'' referring to efforts to move AOL from a subscription model to an advertising-supported operation. (REUTERS) HEWLETT DIRECTOR QUITS -- Thomas J. Perkins has resigned as a director of Hewlett-Packard, the computer equipment company. Mr. Perkins, a founder of the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, rejoined the board in February 2005, having served after the buyout of Compaq Computer in May 2002. Before starting the venture firm in 1972, Mr. Perkins led Hewlett-Packard's early computer operations. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) ANHEUSER ACQUIRES ROLLING ROCK -- The Anheuser-Busch Companies agreed yesterday to buy the lager-style beer Rolling Rock from InBev of the Netherlands for $82 million. The acquisition will bring Rolling Rock to more consumers beyond the Northeast, where the brand is strongest, Anheuser-Busch said. Rolling Rock's volume has fallen 25 percent in the last two years, an analyst at UBS Securities, Caroline Levy, said in research note. Anheuser-Busch wants Rolling Rock because it sells for about $19 a case, or 16 percent more than Budweiser and Bud Light. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) EXXON PROXY FIGHT -- The Institutional Shareholder Services Inc. called on shareholders of the Exxon Mobil Corporation to withhold votes from four of the five members of the compensation committee after the former chairman, Lee R. Raymond, received a $98.4 million retirement payment. I.S.S. said shareholders should withhold votes from the directors James R. Houghton, William R. Howell, Reatha Clark King and Walter V. Shipley. Mr. Raymond, who retired in January, received a $357 million retirement package. Exxon Mobil said I.S.S. misinterpreted the company's compensation formula, according to a letter sent to shareholders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) STRONG QUARTER FOR RETAILER -- The AnnTaylor Stores Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter profit more than doubled on stronger demand for its women's suits, dresses and casual wear. The company, which owns the Ann Taylor and Loft apparel chains, had earnings of $39 million, or 53 cents a share, for the first quarter ended April 29, from $17 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Estimates had expected earnings of 40 cents a share. Sales jumped almost 17 percent, to $556.2 million. (REUTERS) RECORD FOR FRENCH BANK -- BNP Paribas became the latest French bank to report a record first-quarter profit as higher revenue at its investment banking division drove a surge in earnings that beat forecasts. The bank said net profit rose 17 percent from a year ago, to 2.01 billion euros ($2.57 billion). Revenue rose 22 percent, to 6.82 billion euros. BNP's first quarter net profit was the highest among banks in the euro zone. Its results beat the first-quarter net profit of 1.49 billion euros at Spanish lender Santander. BNP Paribas said all its main activities contributed to its growth, although its corporate and investment banking units led the way with a 49 percent rise in profit. (REUTERS)

REISLER--Harriet. On May 18th, 2006. Beloved wife of the late New York Supreme Court Justice Ray Reisler, Loving mother of Raymond Frank and Nancy, proud grandmother of Karen, Zachary and Michael and greatgrandmother of Samantha and Allison. Master's degree in English from Adelphi University With a seminal thesis on Walt Whitman. A gracious, elegant woman who treated everyone with a friendliness and kindness that reflected her joie de vivre.
To the Editor: Re ''British Union Weighs Boycott of Teachers From Israel'' (news article, May 15):

David Wright did his best impersonation of Carlton Fisk last night, hopping up the first-base line until his deep fly ball found a safe landing place. Wright used every inflection of body language, not to curl the ball around a foul pole, but to push it over the head of Yankees' center fielder Johnny Damon. When the ball bounced against the warning track, Wright celebrated as if he had just won Game 6 of the 1975 World Series.

''The only thing that today's New York has in common with New York City at the beginning of the 20th century is its location.'' MICHAEL L. DOLFMAN, the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics' regional commissioner. [B4]

Elvis Presley, right, the possibly deceased king of rock 'n' roll, is going on tour again. CKX Inc., which owns a controlling interest in Presley's name, has announced an arrangement with Cirque du Soleil to create a series of touring and permanent shows based on his life and music, and multimedia installations featuring, among other things, virtual tours of Graceland. The partners, which are splitting the costs and profits of the project, are planning at least one touring show and one installation somewhere outside the United States in 2008, with a new show to open up each year for the next six years, and then every two years until 2021. Cirque du Soleil recently announced a show revolving around the Beatles. ''This would be the next generation of that,'' Robert F. X. Sillerman, the chief executive of CKX, said in an interview. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

To the Editor: As a liberal woman who was a big fan of Hillary Rodham Clinton, I say no, she cannot win. Formerly a strong, independent woman, Mrs. Clinton has become mired in the game of politics, working so hard to be both dove and hawk, playing all the party strategies, that we don't know what she stands for or believes.

To the Editor: ''Still Here? Rumors May Fly, but Treasury Chief Hangs On'' (front page, May 13) gave voice to the worst of Washington rumor-mongering. As Treasury secretary, John W. Snow has worked tirelessly as a steady and strong proponent of the economic interests of the American people.
To the Editor: Re ''The Day an Immigrant Refugee Can Say, 'I'm an American' '' (Editorial Observer, May 19):

Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, 11:15 AM Sunday, May 21. Memorial contributions may be made to NY Section, National Council of Jewish Women or your favorite charity. $(6$)KAPNER--Doris. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. INTERNATIONAL A2-8 U.N. Criticizes Guantánamo While Prisoners Riot Inside A United Nations panel criticized the United States for its treatment of terror suspects and called for the closing of its detention camp at Guantánamo Bay. The panel's criticism came as military officials at Guantánamo disclosed the most serious disturbances by prisoners there since the camp opened. A1 Chávez Methods Irk Neighbors As Venezuela's president, Hugo Chávez, insinuates himself deeper in the politics of his region, some neighbors have expressed impatience at what they see as his meddling. A1 Prominent Priest Disciplined The Vatican announced that it had disciplined the most prominent priest to be accused of sexual abuse, taking a step that Pope John Paul II had long resisted. A6 U.S. and Europe Divided on Iran The United States and Europe are split over negotiating strategies on Iran, with the Bush administration resisting an offer that includes a plan for a Middle East security framework for Iran if it gives up its nuclear activities, diplomats said. A4 Hamas Leader Smuggled Cash A spokesman for Hamas was caught trying to smuggle $815,000 into Gaza in what he said was an effort to circumvent the economic blockade on the Palestinian Authority. A3 Warning on Darfur Relief Effort A United Nations aid official told the Security Council that conditions in Darfur had deteriorated so drastically that the international assistance effort there could collapse. A7 NATIONAL A8-11 Coast Guard Tips Off Ships To Searches, Officials Say Under intense pressure from shipping companies concerned about costly delays, the Coast Guard is tipping off some large commercial ships about security searches that had been intended as a surprise, several high-ranking Coast Guard officials said. A1 Hospices Broaden Services Inspired by research on the end of life, hospices are broadening their range of therapeutic services. More are encouraging the use of music, meditation, aromatherapy and massage for patients. Some are training so-called 11th hour companions to assist the dying and their families. A1 Senate Moves on Immigration In the days since President Bush endorsed comprehensive changes in immigration law in a nationally televised speech, Senate backers of that approach have prevailed on the crucial votes, clearing the way for likely Senate approval of major immigration legislation next week. A10 New Orleans to Choose Mayor With the future of New Orleans on the line, there is great suspense about the outcome of the mayoral election today. The large number of evacuees, voting by absentee ballot, have made surveys unreliable. But everyone in the city believes that the contest will be close. A9 Indictments in Ski Resort Fire A federal grand jury has indicted four people on arson charges for the devastating fires at the Vail Mountain resort in 1998 that drew attention to the shadowy realm of environmental extremism. A10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 City Families Faring Better, A New Federal Study Shows New York City's economy has been transformed in almost every measurable way from its bleak state at the start of the 20th century, a new federal study that compares the city with the rest of the nation shows. Families, on average, became smaller, wealthier and better fed, and devoted less of their income to alcohol and tobacco. A1 Students Heckle McCain The jeers, boos and insults flew as soon as Senator John McCain, the keynote speaker at the New School University graduation, and possible 2008 presidential candidate, was introduced at the commencement at Madison Square Garden. B1 Music Brings Brief Harmony There is a short musical performance before each meeting of the bitterly divided Ulster County Legislature in upstate New York, by top student groups in the county, in an attempt to silence their chronic political bickering, however briefly. B1 Seeking Driver in Hit-Run Even as a family grieved for Vanessa Montes, 5, and her brother, Hector, 2, the Union County prosecutor in New Jersey told the public to be on the lookout for a white car last seen near the scene of the hit-and-run accident that killed the two children. B1 OBITUARIES D8 R. Bruce Merrifield A chemist who won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry, he was 84. D8 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Drug Industry and Doctors Three pharmaceutical companies donated $700,000 that helped wine and dine doctors last year across the country and brief them on news about high blood pressure. These gifts reflect a growing unease that drug industry money is influencing scientific discourse. A1 Insurers Forgo the Coasts As a result of Hurricane Katrina, home insurers are wooing customers with lower premiums in the heartland of America, where hurricanes rarely tread, and are abandoning customers on the southern coast. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Gambling on a weaker dollar; press one for English; prison-based gerrymandering; royalties on r.b.i.'s? Columns: Maureen Dowd, John Tierney. Bridge B15 Crossword B15 TV Listings B17 Weather D7

The Churn column on the Street Scene page of Business Day yesterday misstated the given name of the executive hired by Barclays Capital to head United States distressed debt trading. He is Drew Doscher, not Andrew.
CAPELLUTO - Alexander. We deeply mourn the tragic death of our dear friend Alex. Karen, Jacques & Katherine, our thoughts and sympathies are with you. Ellen, Jeffrey, Kara and Jesse Oppenheim
FRIEDMAN--Marian. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Sr. Rabbi Jerome Seiler, MD, President

RETTINO--Anthony A., 69. Of Huntington Bay, passed away peacefully on May 18, 2006. Beloved husband of MaryAnn. Loving father of Marie Giammarino, Anthony, Augustino and Lucille. Adored grandfather of Nicholas, Marc and Isabel. Devoted son of the late Augustino and Louise. Cherished brother of Frances Usefof and Rosalie Santacroce; predeceased by his brothers Louis, Augustino and Thomas. Noted NY City Restauranteur and Business Consultant. Generous throughout his life; in his memory, he asked that people do a kindness for someone less fortunate. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at the M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington Station. Mass Monday, 10 A.M., Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Centerport. Contributions celebrating his life can be made to fight ALS and kidney disease.

A front-page article yesterday about a House vote to pressure oil and gas drillers to give up billions of dollars in government incentives misstated the number of Republicans who voted for the provision. Sixty-seven Republicans voted in favor, not 85. (The overall vote total was correct: 252 to 165.)

ETTELSON - Andrew. Be loved son of our very dear friends, Sandy and Bill. He was a terrific brother and brother-in-law to Amy and Bob, and to Linda and Alan. A loving uncle to Cary, Jeff, Emily, Dana, and Jay. Our love and deepest sympathy to all of the family. Nancy, Bob, Diane and Rob

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Iran's decision to cut back international inspectors' access to its nuclear program incorrectly described negotiations between Tehran and the West that collapsed last year. The talks were about the fate of the Iranian program, not about inspections. Also because of an editing error, the article mischaracterized new openness accords that the Iranians adopted in 2003. Tehran agreed to two separate voluntary measures, not one -- the Additional Protocol, which let inspectors explore more of Iran's nuclear infrastructure, and so-called transparency measures, which let them visit military sites and interview atomic scientists.

MARKHAM - Beatrice. Be loved wife of the late Dr. Mark Markham. Devoted mother of Dan, Jay and the late Carol. Loving grandmother of five. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY.

A headline on Thursday about criticism of a decision by the Dutch immigration minister to withdraw citizenship from a Somali-born lawmaker who has criticized militant Islam and the abuse of Muslim women misstated the lawmaker's religious affiliation. She is not a Muslim, but is a former Muslim.

To the Editor: As ''Ideology Only'' (editorial, May 13) aptly points out, Congress and the administration have made an unprecedented commitment to fighting AIDS in Africa and beyond. But given that there's no one-size-fits-all approach to H.I.V. prevention, a policy adjustment is needed to get the job done right.

BITENSKY--Samson. Died on May 17, 2006 in the late afternoon at the age of 86. He is survived by his love, best friend and wife of 56 years, Halina. He was the devoted father of Beth and Steven Myers of Kings Point & Susan and Peter Lerner of Sands Point and the adoring grandfather of Jessica, Allison and Benjamin. A visionary in the world of American textile manufacturing, a philanthropist and a wonderful person who touched people from all walks of life, he always strove to make the world a much better place. A brilliant and incisive thinker to the end. Funeral services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Pl, Great Neck, NY on Sunday, May 21 at 12 P.M. $(6$)BITENSKY--Samson. We mourn the loss our our founder, friend and mentor, Samson Bitensky, former President, Chief Executive Officer and Director of Fab Industries, Inc. Your total dedication to excellence, to our well being, your leadership and brilliance, were an inspiration to all who had the privilege of being members of your Fab family. Each day with you was a special gift that we will always cherish and now sorely miss. The Employees of Fab Industries Corp Steven Myers, President $(6$)BITENSKY -- Samson. The Board of Directors of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research and staff mourn the passing of our longtime Trustee, friend and distinguished colleague, whose commitment to preserving Yidishkeyt was unparalleled. He will be sorely missed. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife Halina and the entire family. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Carl J. Rheins, Exec. Dir. $(6$)BITENSKY -- Samson. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Samson Bitensky. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Halina, and their family. Allan Greenblatt, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary $(6$)BITENSKY -- Samson. Intel ligent, learned, philanthropic, a giant amongst his peers. We join Halina and all the family in mourning the passing of Samson and offer our sincerest condolences. Muriel & Howard Weingrow

BECKER--Gloria, known professionally as Gloria Spitz, died peacefully May 18, 2006 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in NYC. Devoted wife of over fifty years to Abraham Becker, beloved mother of Richard & Steven Becker, loving mother-in-law of Carri Joy Becker & Emily Mitchell Becker & cherished grandmother (Nana) of James, Lily, Ian, Charles & Scott Becker. Sister of Bernice Gibber. Born in Bronx, NY, Gloria graduated from Abraham Lincoln High School & Cornell University. Gloria served on the Board of Directors of the Gerber Baby Foods Company for 18 years, until its acquisition by Sandoz (now known as Novartis). During her tenure, Gloria rotated on all Board committees and chaired the Management and Development and Compensation Committees. Gloria ended her illustrious public relations career as a Senior Vice President at BursonMarsteller. Among other positions, Gloria served as Editor-in-Chief of Forecast Magazine and edited the Food and Appliance section of the magazine, Living for Young Homemakers. Funeral Sunday, May 21, at 11 AM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91 Street). In lieu of flowers, donations may be mailed to the ''Gloria Spitz Becker Memorial Fund'' at Cornell University Development, 130 East Seneca Street, Suite 400, Ithaca, New York 14850. $(6$)BECKER--Gloria. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherish member, Gloria Becker. To her family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Secretary
QUIGLEY - Howard. Our adored Grandpa Quig. You gave yourself completely to your beloved Clarice and to us. We will love you forever. Diana, Scott, Alexandra and Matthew

''Will & Grace'' and ''That 70's Show'' rode into the televised sunset on Thursday, and though their ratings have withered in recent years, both shows drew significant audiences to their finales. On NBC, a one-hour ''Will & Grace'' retrospective (drawing what Nielsen estimated at 12.7 million viewers) led into the final episode at 9 p.m. (18.1 million) of the show, featuring Debra Messing, left; its strong performance helped the season finale of ''ER'' (16.7 million) at 10. On Fox, the end of ''That 70's Show'' offered the return of Topher Grace and Ashton Kutcher, and delivered 9.8 million viewers. That led into the season finale of the sinking ''O.C.'' (6.4 million), which featured the death of Marissa Cooper (Mischa Barton) in a car accident. CBS fared well against all this competition, though the season finales of its ''CSI'' (25.1 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (19.5 million) were down in comparison with their conclusions last year. CBS had the most viewers in total, while NBC was No. 1 among the 18-to-49 demographic; Fox was a distant third in both counts. KATE AURTHUR

THE scoreboard said ''Yankees-Mets,'' but the scorecard didn't. With all their injuries, it's as if the two New York baseball teams were the two New York football teams. The Yankees' lineup for last night's opener of the three-game interleague party at Shea Stadium had no Hideki Matsui (out until at least September with a broken wrist), and no Gary Sheffield and no Bubba Crosby (both also on the disabled list). Another absentee, the right-hander Carl Pavano, who hasn't pitched for the Yankees this season, won't pitch this season. He needs bone-chip surgery above the elbow.

7 P.M. (FX) NEXTEL CUP: ALL-STAR CHALLENGE -- Kurt and Kyle Busch, Dale Earnhardt Jr., Tony Stewart, Jeff Gordon, Kasey Kahne, Bobby Labonte and nearly a dozen more of Nascar's top speed demons will burn rubber in this 22nd annual event, covering 90 laps in three parts on the 1.5-mile Lowe's Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C. The incentive: more than $1 million in prize money for the winning driver and $70,000 for the winning pit crew (Mr. Stewart's crew is shown at work above). And, in a Nascar first, the Red Hot Chili Peppers will perform, attired in customized fire-resistant race suits, between the first and second segments. 2 P.M. (MTV) ALL YOU'VE GOT -- It's a crosscourt attack in this teen flick from Neeme Barnette when three upper-crust volleyball players relocate to enemy territory at a school in the barrio -- gasp! -- after their fancy-shmancy campus burns down. Ciara, the Grammy-winning R&B singer, and Sarah Mason of ''The Loop'' play the mean girls. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) MISSION GIANT OTTER -- Some people are more dedicated than others, and Diane McTurk is one of them. This special follows Ms. McTurk on just another day in her calling for the past 20 years: rescuing orphaned otter pups (right), rearing them herself and reintroducing them back into the wild. 8 P.M. (Fox) COPS -- Only in California. In this ''Palm Springs Weekend Special,'' a nude driver leads the police on a high-speed chase, and suspicious smoke comes out of a parked car. In the series's 650th episode, at 8:30, the police respond to a burglary -- and find the robber in a bubble bath. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) ABOMINABLE -- Bigfoot is on a killing spree in California. As we said above. . . . 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICA'S MOST WANTED: AMERICA FIGHTS BACK -- ''Child Predator Special Edition No. 3.'' Two years after John Walsh and other children's advocates began an aggressive campaign, Mr. Walsh, the show's host, discusses the recent passage of the Children's Safety Act, which toughens sex-offender registries and increases criminal penalties. 11 P.M. (Fox) MAD TV -- Season finale. The misunderstood Bae Sung (Bobby Lee) works for the Chinese mafia as a translator in a meeting with Tony Soprano. It doesn't go well. 11:30 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE -- Faster than a speeding bullet, Kevin Spacey (left), soon to be seen as the nefarious Lex Luthor in ''Superman Returns,'' closes out the ''SNL'' season as host. Nelly Furtado, promoting her soon-to-be-released album ''Loose,'' is the musical guest. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Vatican Disciplines Order's Founder in Abuse Case The Vatican announced that it had disciplined the founder of the conservative Legionaries of Christ, the most prominent priest to be accused of sexual abuse. It was a step that Pope John Paul II had long resisted. PAGE A6 Western Powers Disagree On How to Reach Iran Deal Security? Sanctions? The United States and Europe are divided over proposed incentives in the latest phase of their negotiating strategy on Iran's nuclear program. Add Russia's objections to the mix, and the prospect of a quick and straightforward resolution is growing even dimmer. PAGE A4 Down by 4, Mets Come Back The Mets completed their comeback from an early four-run deficit against the Yankees last night when David Wright drove in the winning run against Mariano Rivera in the bottom of the ninth inning. SPORTSSATURDAY, PAGE D1 Odets in Color Forty watercolors by the playwright Clifford Odets, who in the early 1940's began to express himself by painting, are on display in New York. PAGE A13 THIS WEEKEND Choosing the Best Fiction What is the best work of American fiction published in the last 25 years? Prominent writers, critics and editors were asked to choose the single best work -- no second or third choices, just one book. BOOK REVIEW T: Travel The New York Times Style Magazine explores the world: from a river expedition in Suriname to a bucolic, undiscovered part of Tuscany to a surprising surfing safari in Maine. The Day the Musical Died What was once a lively art on Broadway has turned into the McMusical, a development the Tony nominations underscored, Ben Brantley writes. ARTS & LEISURE

MARGULIES--Charles, 91. On May 18, 2006 in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Husband of Helene. Father of Amy Berman & husband Stephen & Liza Margulies. Grandfather of Julie and Cheryl. He will be greatly missed. Graveside service, Sunday, 10:00 A.M. Mt. Eden cemetery. Shiva will be held Sunday, 4:00-8:00 P.M. at the home of Amy and Stephen Berman. $(6$)MARGULIES--Charles. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Charles Margulies, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Charles J. Block, President

To the Editor: Bob Herbert and others are overly concerned with ''the all-important matter of electability'' for judging potential Democratic presidential candidates. It seemed that many in the Democratic Party and in the media concluded in 2004 that John Kerry was much more ''electable'' than Howard Dean. I would argue that hindsight has shown that those two candidates had equal amounts of presidential electability: zero.

The Palestinian head of intelligence was badly wounded today in a well-planned but unclaimed explosion at his heavily guarded headquarters in Gaza City. The intelligence chief, Maj. Gen. Tareq Abu Rajab, is a senior member of Fatah and an ally of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas. The explosion occurred as he entered an elevator with his aides and bodyguards. One bodyguard, a nephew of Mr. Rajab, was killed and Mr. Rajab and five others with him were wounded, plus another three employees nearby.

RIECK--James C., 69. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, formerly of New York City passed away on May 13, 2006. Before retiring, he was an English teacher at Bergenfield High School in New Jersey. Jim's life partner, Theodore F. Schultz of Fort Lauderdale, and two sisters, Faith Minshull of Margate, FL, and Joy Carter of Ocean City, NJ survive him.

An article yesterday about a sperm donor in Michigan who passed on a genetic disease to five children in four different families mischaracterized the actions of the sperm bank involved in the case. The bank, which was not named in the article, supplied sperm samples from the donor to a university laboratory for genetic testing; it did not refuse to provide a sample. (The tests were not completed because a university ethics panel said they could not be done without the donor's permission.) The bank says it is unable to get in touch with the donor because it no longer knows his whereabouts. It did not tell him he could no longer be a sperm donor or refuse to seek his permission for the testing.

RUDIN--Min. Dear Sondra, your loss is our loss. Your mother was an incredibly kind and caring person and she will be missed by all of us. May she rest in peace. With our personal condolences, Freddie, Tami, Jason and Hailey $(6$)RUDIN--Minnie. We express deep sorrow at the passing of Minnie Rudin, beloved mother of our dear friends Sondra and David Mack. Our condolences to the entire family. Gloria and Jesse Gottlieb

A picture caption in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday misidentified the site of a performance in New York City by the hip-hop duo Gnarls Barkley on Monday night. It is Webster Hall, not the World Financial Center.

To the Editor: Gen. Michael V. Hayden, as a serving officer, is subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice, and so long as he remains in uniform will be a subordinate to the secretary of defense. If this gentleman wishes to pursue a civilian job he should retire and join the civilian ranks.

JOHNSON--J. Stewart. With great sadness, the staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art notes the passing of Stewart Johnson, a long time colleague and friend, who for 14 years was Consultant for Design and Architecture in the Department of Modern Art until his retirement in 2004. A connoisseur and scholar, he curated many exhibitions, including retrospectives of the designers Charles Rennie Mackintosh and Emile Jacques Ruhlmann, and under his guidance the Met's collection of design and architecture was significantly enhanced. The 2005-6 exhibition ''A Curator's Eye'' paid tribute to the many acquisitions Stewart brought into the Museum, which will reside here to educate and enlighten for generations to come. Philippe de Montebello, Dir Emily K. Rafferty, President Gary Tinterow, Engelhardt Curator in Charge Dept. of 19th Century Modern & Contemporary Art

An obituary on Thursday about the theatrical producer Cy Feuer misstated the site of the Roxy Theater, where he landed a job playing the trumpet as a teenager. It was on West 50th Street, not West 47th Street.

STRAUSS--Libby. Of Miami Beach, FL., died Wednesday after a short illness. Libby led many lives in her 80 years-as an activist for a multitude of social and political causes, a food columnist for the Miami Herald, and a development officer for the Brandeis University National Women's Committee. She was married to her beloved Harold ''Ocky'' Strauss, a University of Miami Business professor, for 52 event-filled years and together they experienced life with a remarkable group of family and friends who maintained an unusually close bond. Libby was the best cook and hostess anywhere, enjoyed music, reading, traveling, keeping up with the news, but most of all she loved her six grandchildren: Benjamin, Matthew, Alexa, Madelyn, Rebecca and Adam. Her daughters and their husbands Charlotte and Michael Zinder, Valerie Strauss and Marc Levy, and Andrea and Mark Dettelbach, her sister Debby Israel, her many nieces and nephews, and her devoted friends will miss her great hospitality, wisdom and powerful spirit. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Harold Strauss Endowed Scholarship Fund, University of Miami School of Business, POB 248032, Coral Cables, FL 33124-6521 or Brandeis University National Women's Committee, POB 549110, Waltham, MA 02454

Prime Minister Romano Prodi survived the first of two required confidence votes in Parliament, winning the approval of the Senate with the votes of all seven of the body's unelected honorary members. ''It couldn't have gone better than that,'' said Mr. Prodi. The 165-to-155 vote was a crucial test for Mr. Prodi and his new center-left government, given that he holds only a slim two-seat majority in the Senate among the regular elected members. But Silvio Berlusconi, the ousted prime minister, called the vote ''profoundly immoral'' because honorary senators do not normally take part in confidence votes. Next week, Mr. Prodi will face a vote in the lower house, the Chamber of Deputies. IAN FISHER (NYT)

To the Editor: Verlyn Klinkenborg's May 18 Editorial Observer, ''Renewing America's Commitment to Research in High-Energy Physics,'' is exhilarating. In our present darkness, it is hard to see which particular imprisonment is the most paralyzing: our indifference to international cooperation, our marginalization of mathematically gifted students or our sensate craving for immediate satisfactions.

In a significant but controversial moment of baseball history, Barry Bonds matched Babe Ruths regular-season career total of 714 home runs Saturday afternoon with a solo blast off the left-handed pitcher Brad Halsey of the Oakland Athletics in the second inning of an interleague game at McAfee Coliseum. Batting in the cleanup spot as designated hitter because the game was played under American League rules, Bonds normally the left-fielder of the San Francisco Giants hit a 1-1 pitch into the right-field stands while leading off the second inning and tying the score, 1-1.

An article in Science Times on May 9 in the form of a conversation with Representative Sherwood Boehlert of New York, the departing chairman of the House Science Committee, included an incorrect figure from him for the annual payment from oil royalties that the State of Alaska awards to each citizen. In 2005, it was $845.76 per person, or $3,383 (not $10,000) for a family of four. (The highest payment, in 2000, was $1,963.86 per person.)
To the Editor: Re ''C.I.A. Choice Says He's Independent of the Pentagon'' (front page, May 19):

India's largest bank, the State Bank of India, said yesterday that its profit fell 20 percent in the fourth quarter as interest income declined and the value of its bond investment portfolio fell. The bank, which is government-owned, said its net profit fell to 8.53 billion rupees ($188 million) in the quarter, which ended in March, from 10.65 billion rupees a year earlier. Net interest income fell 10 percent despite the growth of loans. The bank said it expects loans to grow 23 percent this year from financing projects to upgrade India's infrastructure. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

An article and picture caption on April 5 about a tax preparation workshop for workers in the sex industry in New York misstated the filing history of one participant, Sarah Patterson, a foot fetish model. She said she was filing for the earned income tax credit for the first time, not reporting her income to the government for the first time. A letter from a sponsor of the workshop pointing out the error was misdirected at The Times, and this correction was further delayed by difficulty in contacting Ms. Patterson.

To the Editor: In ''Hillary Can Run, but Can She Win?'' (column, May 18), Bob Herbert raises an important issue about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's potential run for the presidency -- her gender. While Mr. Herbert claims that it will be difficult for a woman to get elected in the United States, recent evidence proves otherwise.

To the Editor: Bob Herbert strongly questions Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's ability to be elected president, believing that current poll numbers ''are a recipe for anxiety.'' As a college student from New York, I believe we must shrug off this defeatist attitude.

And if San Francisco liberals are not behind her -- who then?

IF the new theater at the Pulse Performing Arts Studio in Bedford Hills looks familiar, there is a good reason. Much of the interior, including the stage, curtains, chairs, risers and lights, came from the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts in Mount Kisco, which folded last fall after failing to close a $400,000 budget gap. To the Editor: In ''Treading Lightly On the Road to Mandalay'' (May 7), Joshua Kurlantzick acknowledges the controversy regarding tourism in Myanmar, but he also offers ''several strategies'' for people who choose to visit but ''want to give as little money as possible to the Myanmar government.'' And on his last night in Mandalay, he went to see the Moustache Brothers comedy troupe, who ''have paid a steep price for their laughs,'' in the form of arrest and imprisonment, and whom the regime now allows to perform only for tourists. The suspicion inevitably arises, however, that the only reason the Moustache Brothers are allowed to perform for tourists is that they are being required to kick back some (and likely most) of the precious foreign currency they earn to the regime.

Bobby Fisher Photographing a trip through a remote area of the Amazon could prove disastrous for someone who has never ridden rapids in a folding canoe before. But Bobby Fisher, who has seen his fair share of adventure, was not intimidated. Fisher -- an accomplished surfer since his childhood (shown far right with his brother) who has also motorcycled down the Ho Chi Minh Trail and trekked the eastern Arctic -- was still not prepared for capturing the pleasures and challenges of Suriname during his ''Tumble in the Jungle'' (Page 116). The piranha-packed Lucie River destroyed his boat and nearly swallowed all of his equipment, though his beloved sketchbook survived (center). In addition to his adventure travel photography, he regularly tackles another type of wildlife -- shooting celebrities for magazines like In Style.

ON a recent Wednesday night at the Cool Beanz Coffeehouse in St. James, the singer and songwriter Martha Trachtenberg sipped a latte as she waited for her turn at the microphone. In a few minutes, she would be performing. Until then, she was a member of the audience. The young man standing on the small stage, John-Flor Sisante of Hauppauge, was strumming his Martin guitar and introducing a song he just wrote. ''It's called 'A Letter to Britney Spears From a Young Man,' '' he said. ''I think she's getting a raw deal from the press.''
A restaurant review of Tombolino, in Yonkers, on April 30 misstated the number of bottles in its wine cellar. It has about 13,000 bottles, not 1,300.

To the Editor: On the front page of your May 14 Long Island section, there was a photo of a ballot on a voting machine to be used later that week for the budget vote for the Bethpage Schools. Although this most likely was intended to convey to voters that they have the choice of pressing the ''yes'' or ''no'' levers when they go out to vote on school budget and other propositions, the photo appears directly above a headline that reads, ''For School Budgets, the New Word Is No.''

To the Editor: Regarding Rachel Donadio's essay (''The Party's Over,'' April 23) about the demise of the book party in New York, we would respectfully suggest that she visit New Hampshire, where the book party is alive and well. All of the debauchery she craves is here by the bushel. Last year we held a party in celebration of the first book in the Motorcycleman series. The event was held at a local doughnut shop, where patrons were serenaded by an Elvis impersonator accompanied by an accordionist. The liquor was free- flowing and everybody understood the ''no glass'' policy. The cuisine was Chinese takeout and hot glazed doughnuts. There were no arrests or fistfights, but we did witness one divorce and two marriage proposals (one same sex). We expect our next party, for ''Voodoo Moon'' (the second book in that series) to be even louder and more obnoxious than the first. The party will have a Dixie theme, complete with a Louisiana funeral jazz band, hurricanes and a Truman Capote look-alike reading from a selection of our titles. As you see, then, rumors of the death of book parties are highly exaggerated! One just needs to know where to find them. Jeremy Townsend Phil Englehardt Exeter, N.H. Jeremy Townsend is the publisher of PublishingWorks. Phil Englehardt is the marketing director of Revolution Booksellers.
SERMAN - Michael. Six years. Missed and loved throughout eternity. Your Family

For most jet-setters, sleeping in a mud hut without electricity hardly sounds appealing. But there's something about the Adrere Amellal in Siwa, Egypt, that makes up for the Captain Caveman lodgings. Maybe it's the regal Berber men in turbans and robes who glide about waiting on guests hand and foot. Or the perpetual open bar, dune surfing at sunset or perching -- cocktails in hand -- on the stone bar chairs submerged near the shore. Whatever the case, this remote eco-hotel, on a silent oasis in the Sahara, is a destination for royals and sybarites alike. After a night or two, most guests go local and trade in their Gucci for a djellaba -- more comfortable in the desert heat, yes, but also easier to don by candlelight. Double occupancy, $400 a night, includes meals and excursions. www.adrereamellal.net. CATOR SPARKS

Pierre-Jean Baudouard, a radiologist from Le Havre, France, with his 6-year-old son, Paul. ''Every year, I go on vacation with my nephew, my sister and my wife, but we had a baby girl this year, and my wife couldn't come along. So this was a trip just for the guys, and the first for my son, Paul. We decided to go with my nephew, Thomas, to Crete, because we felt sure to find some history, the beach and also a bit of adventure for Paul. We rented a 4x4, and every day we took off into the mountains -- with Paul as the copilot holding the map, which made him very happy.'' As told to Austin Considine

The prolific RICHARD GREENBERG -- whose new play ''THE HOUSE IN TOWN,'' about a wealthy Manhattan couple in the late 1920's, starts performances this week -- is in a serious slump and badly in need of a hit, to use a baseball metaphor, which is something he has been known to do. In September his cotton-candy-light ''Naked Girl on the Appian Way'' received a critical drubbing that seemed particularly harsh, until the revival of his drama ''Three Days of Rain'' opened on Broadway in April, and the critics really went to work. Granted, Julia Roberts took the brunt of the assault, but few would argue that the production did any favors for Mr. Greenberg's reputation. He has had better receptions with world premieres in Washington and Chicago, but only slightly. The Washington Post critic Peter Marks dismissively likened Mr. Greenberg's ''Bal Masque,'' which opened at Theater J, to a Neil Simon comedy, and Charles Isherwood of The New York Times said that ''The Well-Appointed Room,'' which opened at the Steppenwolf Theater, was infected with the ''glib nihilism'' of NEIL LaBUTE. Sheesh. ''House,'' directed by DOUG HUGHES, could still be the kind of success that redeems the season, but if it isn't, hey, there's always next year. ''The House in Town'' starts previews Wednesday at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 279-4200; $70 until June 18, then $75. Speaking of Mr. LaBute, his new play, ''SOME GIRL(S),'' began previews last week at the Lucille Lortel Theater, and it reunites the devilish playwright with the director JO BONNEY, who successfully staged his hit version of ''Fat Pig.'' In this relationship drama, a fiancé, played by DAVID SCHWIMMER in Chicago and ERIC McCORMACK here, visits four ex-girlfriends before getting hitched. I can't imagine what could possibly go wrong. ''Some Girl(s)'' is now in previews. 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200; $65 and $75.

To the Editor: It is distressing to read that the dispute between DeCamp Bus Lines and New Jersey Transit has not been resolved (''Tug of War Over Commuters,'' May 14). Yes, commuting on the bus can be difficult. I've heard people complain about the service on New Jersey Transit, too. My experiences, however, are always good. I am handicapped, and walk, slowly, with a cane. The DeCamp drivers are unfailingly thoughtful: in-bound drivers will let me get seated before pulling away, and the drivers coming home will try to pull close to the curb so that I can more easily ''debus.'' Loss of DeCamp would force me to consider the train, which is not a realistic option for the handicapped.

RUBINSTEIN--Eli A. Eli A. Rubinstein, Ph.D., a scientist who was an authority on the effects of TV violence on children, was born in New York City on April 27, 1919. He died at Carolina Meadows in Chapel Hill, NC on May 15, 2006, at age 87. His last formal position was as Adjunct Research Professor of Mass Communications, School of Journalism, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC from 1971 to 1978, he was Professor of Psychiatry and Psychology at the Health Sciences Center, State University of New York at Stony Brook, New York. He received his Ph.D. in psychology at the Catholic University of America in 1950. He served for twenty years in various senior research and administrative positions in federal agencies in Washington, D.C.; in the Veterans Administration, from 1950 to 1958, and then at the National Institute of Mental Health, from 1958 through 1971. At the time he left federal service, he was the Assistant Director for Extramural Programs and Behavioral Sciences at NIMH and the highest ranked psychologist at that Institute. One of the last major responsibilities he had in that federal position was the coordination of a three-year national program of research on television and social behavior. The results of that research program were summarized, in 1972, in a comprehensive report by the Surgeon General's Scientific Advisory Committee on Television and Social Behavior, assessing the effects of televised violence on the behavior of children. Dr. Rubinstein served as Vice-Chairman and project leader for that Committee, representing the Surgeon General. Five volumes of technical reports, published under Dr. Rubinstein's guidance, served as scientific documentation for the Committee report. Subsequently, Dr. Rubinstein was a senior advisor and contributor to the tenyear update of the Surgeon General's report, published in 1982. Over his entire scientific career, Dr. Rubinstein published more than 100 articles and books on such diverse topics as: research in psychotherapy, the status of mental health manpower, the qualities of science administration, and developments in the behavioral sciences, in addition to his editing of the original five volumes of technical reports on television and social behavior. His major publications since 1975 were on policy issues relating to findings on the effects of television on the viewer. He was the co-editor of a book, published in 1985, on ''The Media, Social Science and Social Policy for Children.'' He was coeditor of ''Big World, Small Screen,'' a book published in 1992, which examined the research and scientific conclusions on the effects of television viewing on various segments of the viewing public. He testified before various congressional committees on the effects of televised violence and on policy issues related to that public problem. On the less serious side of his career, Dr. Rubinstein prided himself on having been the master of ceremonies at many retirement parties at the NIMH. His doggerel and sharp comments at these events were always enjoyed by the audience. At his own retirement party from the NIMH in 1971, he was given a plaque naming him ''Poet Laureate Emeritus.'' His federal career was distinguished by the fact that he began in 1940 as the lowest grade clerk, working in the 1940 decennial census. Through a series of promotions and advances because of his graduate work, he ended his federal service, thirty years later, at the highest grade level, GS18, one of only a handful of federal civil service employees to have ever accomplished that feat. Dr. Rubinstein was a Fellow of the American Psychological Association. He had been a consultant to many private and federal agencies concerned with research in the behavioral sciences. He was also a consulting editor for various scientific journals. In 1967-1968, he was a Fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Stanford, CA. Dr. Rubinstein is survived by three children; two sons, Dr. Lawrence V. Rubinstein of Rockville, MD, and Dr. Donald H. Rubinstein of Guam and one daughter, Betsy Rubinstein of Chevy Chase, MD and three grandchildren.

Ron Stephens refuses to fill prescriptions for emergency contraceptives on the grounds that he believes them to be immoral. Why stop there? Will we soon see the day when a pharmacist can refuse to fill Prozac prescriptions because of a belief that those suffering from depression are better treated by therapy and willpower alone? Allowing a pharmacist to determine which prescriptions are ''moral'' or ''immoral'' opens the door to very dangerous territory indeed. Dina A. Gamboni Santa Cruz, Calif.

THE plastic martini glass industry must have rejoiced at a recent Craigslist posting: an ''incredible new upscale venue'' in Midtown Manhattan with a ''magnificently landscaped 14,000 square foot'' penthouse garden, needed bartenders. Lots of them. Up to 22 at a time, 15 working the rooftop. With the opening of the bar, 230 Fifth, on May 4, Manhattan's rooftop bar season unofficially kicked off, with more than 25 high-altitude places in the city where the air is fresh (except for the cigarettes), the views are (often) stunning, and the drinks are (almost always) served in lightweight plastic, presumably to save pedestrians far below from potential injury, if not cranberry juice stains.

THE New York Legislature is debating whether to approve a sex offender civil commitment law. The law would allow the attorney general to confine sex offenders in secure hospitals indefinitely after they have served their prison sentences. This is a bad idea. More than a dozen states have tried this novel strategy for preventing sexual recidivism. Their experiences clearly show that these laws waste taxpayer dollars and embroil state agencies in endless litigation. Instead of warehousing a small percentage of sex offenders, states should use the money on cost-effective strategies like community supervision combined with mandatory treatment that would reach many more released convicts.

Wet / (wet) / adj. / Covered or soaked with a liquid, like water; [idiomatic] used to describe someone who's a bore, a drip, as in, ' ''He's such a wet noodle to travel with -- he'll stay only at hotels with infinity pools''; an emerging trend, as the travel industry is deluged with water-themed adventures, e.g., ' ''I want to do something wet and wild this weekend -- surfing in Maine? Or maybe kayaking in Suriname?''

SALGAR--Dr. Alberto. Died Tuesday in Greenwich, CT. A giant of a man in stature and grace, Dr. Salgar was born in Bogota, Colombia in 1934. He served in the US Army in Vietnam and practiced pathology for 20 years in New York State. His family and countless friends bid a heartfelt farewell to a legend.

In the continuing Left Bank-ification of the globe, Stockholm's Hornstull neighborhood is the latest industrial precinct to metamorphose into a hipster paradise. Artists have fertilized, cafes have been colonized, and the area is now entering its golden age -- that period just before real estate prices skyrocket and the early adapters are priced out. Go now, before Starbucks arrives. CHRISTOPHER ISENBERG
To the Editor: Re ''O Brother, Here Art Thou (Where Have You Been?)'' by Jon Pareles [May 14]:

IT could have been a keg party or a hipper-than-usual church social: As 80 guests parked bumper to bumper along the main drag of tiny Haddam, one Saturday night last month, couples clambered out of cars carrying covered potluck dishes and six-packs. Some congregated around cars while they sipped from plastic cups, while others followed a flashlight-waving attendant toward the back door of a 19th-century church. Once inside, they handed their casserole dishes to the evening's gray-haired but youthful host, John Friedlander, a real estate agent.

Putting on the Ritz to eat catfish fritters and baby back ribs seems as counterintuitive as wearing a ball gown to a ballgame. Even so, you'll want to wriggle into your starchy Sunday best for Freshwaters. If the ''Proper Attire Required'' sign at the door isn't incentive enough, there is always Sharon Freshwater herself, her hair swept into an elaborate wave, to shame you: At a recent Sunday supper, which started at 1 p.m., the hostess/chef/proprietress (with her husband, Clifton Freshwater) was wearing pumps and sparkling jewels as she greeted a steady stream of smart-looking guests.

To the Editor: I attended New York University, graduating in 1973. It was the same N.Y.U. described by Michael J. Agovino (''Pomp and Altered Circumstances,'' May 14), only more so. Those were great times at a fine university.
An article on April 23, about Amazing Hot Dog in Verona, misstated the hometown of Matt Applebaum, one of the restaurant's owners. He is from Springfield, N.J., not Jersey City.

MAKING art and making a living are often mutually exclusive. For every professional artist who is successful enough to survive by selling work, there are thousands who have to find another job that pays the bills. Predictably, creative people find creative ways of balancing two professions. Teaching is a time-honored way for an artist to keep the wolf from the door. It is, in fact, the most common alternative profession listed on applications for financial support at the Pollock-Krasner Foundation in Manhattan, according to Caroline Black, its program officer. The foundation, established in 1985, gives grants that enable artists to take time off from their day jobs and concentrate on their own work.

To the Editor: I must register a protest concerning David Gilmour's review of my book, ''The Terror'' (May 7). In it he casually assimilates my analysis of the September Massacres of 1792 to an entirely unnecessary, and insulting, association with belittling the Holocaust, and a diminution of the impact of 9/11 on America. If I may be allowed to quote myself in my own defense, these are some of my concluding remarks on the topic in the book: After discussing the fact that many potential victims were spared by the ''tribunals'' set up in the prisons, I note that: ''In all the horror of massacre, it is perhaps here that we find the greatest apparent incomprehensibility. . . . It is easy to come to terms with the idea of irrational carnage carried out by sadistic mobs: such acts fit neatly into the concept of a radically 'different,' almost subhuman crowd, safely distanced from the self-image of the observer. Far less comfortable is the realization that bloody murder could be committed by upright citizens in the name of their country's freedom.'' I am trying here, as an unprejudiced observer will note, to retrieve the Massacres for understanding. I should have thought it clear that I do not use words like ''horror'' and ''bloody murder'' about acts of which I approve, or the significance of which I wish to diminish in any way. I had hoped it was possible to write about these events at a distance of more than 200 years without being forced to defend myself against charges of unreasonable sympathy. It would appear, however, that the French Revolution remains capable of stirring ire, even across the wide Atlantic. David Andress Portsmouth, England

PINCOVER--Kate. We offer our Kos Tanchumim to Edward Pincover and Ruth Moss on the loss of his beloved mother and her cherished sister. A Diamond Founder, Mrs. Pincover was a gracious, kind and modest woman who made caring for the medical needs of the people of Jerusalem a priority. It could truly be said that her heart beat to the pulse of this holy city. May Edward and Mrs. Moss be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

WHEN THE WALL CAME DOWN, by Serge Schmemann. (Kingfisher. $15.95; ages 12 and up.) Could it be that Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, the former Enron chief executive, was watching ''Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King'' during his recovery from heart surgery? ''There may be a jury that yields to unpopularity, but it's not this jury!'' Mr. Ramsey said in his closing argument on Tuesday at the Enron trial, after missing more than a month because of health problems. ''There may come a day when an American jury yields to a media mob, but it's not this date!''

BEYOND BLACK, by Hilary Mantel. (Picador, $14.) This darkly comic novel explores spiritualism through the story of a woman coming to terms with her disturbing past. Mantel's fat, middle-aged English heroine, Alison Hart, is a professional medium and clairvoyant -- a ''sensitive'' -- who depends on the help of a grizzled ''spirit guide'' named Morris. Just as Alison has begun to dictate her autobiography to her no-nonsense assistant, Colette, her consciousness comes under attack from Morris and a crew of villainous apparitions. Our reviewer, Terrence Rafferty, said ''Beyond Black'' feels like ''a great, gleeful binge, a wallow in the not-good-for-you riches of this writer's extraordinarily vivid, violent imagination.''
LYLE PUENTE composed a song in a parking lot while waiting to pick up his children from school. Dave Nichols wrote one sitting in his car outside a McDonald's.

CARLICK--Jane. Of New York. Died May 10, 2006. Honest, hard worker, loyal friend who will be remembered by all who loved her. A memorial will be held on May 28, 3-5 PM, at Telephone Bar & Grill, 149 Second Ave. Contributions in remembrance of Jane can be made to the American Cancer Society.

PLANNING a family hiking trip through Europe can be daunting, especially with children of varying ages and needs. Butterfield & Robinson's Bespoke program (www.butterfield.com/bespoke, 800-387-1147) will customize a family-friendly version of any of its adult hiking packages. Options include Krakow to Budapest, Barcelona to Aragón and walking tours through Scotland and Ireland.

''WATER for the City,'' an exhibition at the Southeast Museum in the Village of Brewster, focuses on the creation of the Croton Reservoir system, particularly the four reservoirs built in the Town of Southeast. ''We are trying to talk about the reason for the reservoirs -- the quality of water for the city and the need for pressurized water,'' said Amy E. Campanaro, executive director of the museum. ''Even though people in Brewster don't get water from the reservoir system, we wanted to discuss the need for being good stewards of the water supply that supplies eight million people in New York City and one million elsewhere in the state.''

DARCY--Natalie. July 29, 1909-May 18, 2006. Dr. Darcy, the only girl of thirteen children born to Maud Horgan Darcy and Michael Darcy, was a psychologist and teacher at Brooklyn College and Fordham University for many years before retirement in 1972. She was a devoted parishoner and first chair person of the Parish Council at St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village, was a member of the Third Order of St. Francis, and of the Ladies of the Holy Sepulcher. Her body will lie in state at St. Joseph's Church, 371 6th Ave., between 8th St. and Waverly Place on Monday evening at 7PM, May 22, 2006. There will be a Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's on Tuesday, May 23 at 10AM followed by burial in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to St. Joseph's Church in her memory.

To the Editor: Re ''This Summer, One Formula Fits All'' by Christopher Noxon [May 14]: How ironic that a cover story explores Hollywood's quest for the perfect film that will play to '' 'all four quadrants': that is, across the age spectrum'' when on the Week Ahead page of the same section, Nathan Lee laments the case of ''Duma,'' Carroll Ballard's critically celebrated film, and its doomed theatrical release.

It's easy to forget that three of America's most famous contemporary painters are Southern. Robert Rauschenberg (Texas), Jasper Johns (South Carolina) and Cy Twombly (Virginia) may have begun their careers in Manhattan, but the next generation of Southern talent is sticking to their roots. Two years ago, Chloë Seymore and her husband, Harrison Haynes, a painter, opened the Branch Gallery in a former mill house in Carrboro, N.C., as a pipeline between New York and the Southeast. With 18 shows under their belts, they have already shown at the Cologne art fair and recently moved toa larger space, an old car dealership in Durham. 401C Foster Street; (919)918-1116. Hunter Kennedy

NEVER have so few drunk so much as in Beth Henley's new play ''Ridiculous Fraud,'' commissioned by McCarter Theater Center and receiving a splendidly acted and directed world premiere here at the Berlind Theater. Set in the New Orleans Garden District, the surrounding Louisiana backwoods and the above-ground tombs of a local cemetery (Michael Yeargan's design, beautifully lighted by Peter Kaczorowski, is strikingly handsome), in a time described as ''five years before Hurricane Katrina,'' this raucous, blackly tinted romp finds most of Henley's dysfunctional losers wetting the whistle at every opportunity. Be it Jack Daniel's, Wild Turkey or good, old-fashioned Coca-Cola, the Clays and Chrystals rarely stop drinking as they scramble to ''find the courage to be honest and true,'' to quote Andrew Clay (Reg Rogers), the family's oldest brother, self-anointed savior and would-be state auditor.

LEVY--Maurice, 75, a truly heroic and inspirational man, on Friday May 19, 2006. Devoted husband of Herma of nearly 50 years, beloved father of Alan Levy and Beth Krol, loving father-in-law to Jane Levy and Joe Krol, loving brother to Eleanor, cherished grandfather to Neil, Rachel and Hanna. Services are today, 11 AM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ. $(6$)LEVY--Maurice. A man of dignity and courage. Heartfelt sympathy to Herma and family. Don & Gertrude Katz

To the Editor: We are longtime admirers of Philip Roth's fiction and appreciative of the depth and complexity in his latest book, ''Everyman,'' reviewed by Nadine Gordimer (May 7). Nonetheless, as social scientists, we feel compelled to comment on its thrust. Our research intimately following the lives of middle-class Americans who are currently in their 70's shows that only a small minority ''worry about oblivion,'' in Roth's phrasing. Most believe, as the gravedigger encountered by the protagonist puts it, that ''You gotta do what you gotta do,'' and they get on with it. They accept their lives -- including illness, loss, and their many past misdeeds and mistakes -- and purposefully engage with the present. Unlike Roth's protagonist, many older Americans are well buffered by family, faith and friends. Some despair, but they tend to be the same people who were also despairing in young and middle adulthood. With the aging of the baby boomers upon us, we share this note lest too many aging Americans take permission from Roth to dwell in the past and fear the future rather than seize the present. Michele Dillon Paul Wink Wellesley, Mass. Michele Dillon is professor of sociology at the University of New Hampshire. Paul Wink is professor of psychology at Wellesley College.
DAVIDSON--Nathan J. May 21, 1999. Thank you, God, for the gift of his life--a joy to so many, an inestimable treasure to me. KMD
To the Editor: Re ''Rising Diabetes Threat Meets a Falling Budget'' (''Cost and Effect'' series, front page, May 16):

MAURER--Allan, 88, May 17, 2006, Providence, RI. Beloved husband of the late Rhoda; devoted father of Amy and Bruce, and Howard; proud grandfather of Evan & Ilana. A memorial celebration of his life to be held in NY in June.

ROSEMARY PALLADINO of Yonkers recently had to give up her beloved BMW sports car for a Toyota 4Runner. Why? Because she is a band mom -- and her son, Raff Ferraioli, 15, is a drummer, requiring a tremendous amount of equipment when he plays. ''I always have to be available because the drums have to be transported,'' Mrs. Palladino said. ''I loved my BMW, but he really did need the room.''

COTTINGHAM--Betty J. Died at the age of 82, in her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, on May 19, 2006. Born and raised in Syracuse, NY, Betty Comiez volunteered as a nurse's aide during World War II. She moved to New York City in 1949, married Robert Cottingham in 1951, and gave birth to their son Stuart in 1964. Betty lived a full and active life as a bookkeeper, wife, widow, mother, sister, aunt, friend, neighbor, retiree, Democrat, avid theater goer, movie buff and die-hard Yankees fan. Service at 9:30 AM, on Monday, May 22, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

JOY--Eileen C. Suddenly on May 17, 2006. Beloved daughter of the late Catherine and James F. Joy. A lifelong New Yorker who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Tuesday May 23rd 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial WedMay 24, 11 AM, Holy Family Church, 315 E. 47 St. NYC.
SIMMONS--Marshall Jay. June 27, 1922--May 22, 1993 Love never ends. Your daughter, Cathy

Your article quotes ''some commentators'' who say the ''dark side'' of widespread contraceptive use is declining birth rates. In fact, slowing population growth, and even declining populations, are things to be celebrated, not feared. Smaller families, especially in crowded places like Europe and Japan, are a sensible and rational response to overcrowding. Grace Pritchard Burson Konstanz, Germany

TWENTY years ago, Long Island had a thriving stand-up comedy scene, one so hip and dynamic that fans didn't need to trek into Manhattan. But in the comedic landscape where Eddie Murphy, Jerry Seinfeld, Rosie O'Donnell, Ray Romano and Kevin James all had their start, today there is only one major full-time comedy club, Governor's in Levittown. Long Island comedians, a proud group with a distinct storytelling tradition, have survived by any means possible, short of standing on a street corner and yelling their routines at passing motorists.

CAMP--Orton P., 83, formerly of Waterbury, died at his home in Bethany, CT May 11, 2006. Mr. Camps education included The Fessenden School in West Newton, MA. The Taft School in Watertown, CT and Yale University. His senior year at Yale was interrupted by service in WW II. AS an army officer, he participated in the initial invasion of France and later served as an Aide to General Mark Clark in the European Theater. After his army service, he returned to Yale, graduating in 1947 as a member of the class of 1945. He later served in the military in Korea. He was president of the Patent Button Company, later Dot Fasteners in Waterbury and Cheshire, CT. He also served as Chairman of the familyowned Platt Brothers Company. His many civic interests included 2 terms as president of the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury with which he remained closely alive most of his life. Mr. Camp is survived by two sisters, Nancy Camp, of Middlebury, CT and Mimi Neiderman, of Bethany, CT and four nieces and nephews. He also leaves his longtime companion Roger Roby of Bethany. Memorial donations may be made to CT Hospice.

To the Editor: Thanks to Mr. Kurlantzick for laying out the arguments for and against tourist travel to Myanmar, given its poor human rights record. Although he did mention Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, he didn't say that she won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991 and is now the only imprisoned Nobel Laureate. We also think it would have been worth noting that the ''at least hundreds of other political prisoners'' live under inhumane conditions merely for exercising their right to express divergent political opinions. They never received fair trials; just harsh and sometimes absurdly long sentences.

The chief executive is not always the highest-paid employee of his company, but last year Eric F. Billings was not even the highest-paid employee of his company in his own family. Mr. Billings, who runs the Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group, an investment bank, received $480,000 in salary, $1.6 million in stock and no bonus -- a total of $2.1 million -- after the company lost $170 million in 2005. His brother Jonathan, an executive vice president, received a $2.65 million bonus on top of his $250,000 salary. But Eric got a head start on his sibling in March, when the company's directors doubled his salary, to $960,000 a year. PATRICK McGEEHAN

To the Editor: Tell a 3-year-old with Type 1 diabetes and his parents that the child will need at least five insulin injections and five finger sticks for blood a day, and must measure every morsel of food he eats, exercise and avoid sweets.

An article last Sunday about ''After All,'' a play by Gina Barnett that ended its run at the Woodward Hall Theater in Briarcliff Manor on May 13, omitted the name of the production company. It was the Hudson Stage Company.
GORCHOFF--Nora. At home on May 13. She worked in the research division of the NY Public Library and was active in her local community board. Survived by her husband George of Laguna, Woods CA.

STRAUSS--Libby. Of Miami Beach, FL., died Wednesday after a short illness. Libby led many lives in her 80 years-as an activist for a multitude of social and political causes, a food columnist for the Miami Herald, and a development officer for the Brandeis University National Women's Committee. She was married to her beloved Harold ''Ocky'' Strauss, a University of Miami Business professor, for 52 event-filled years and together they experienced life with a remarkable group of family and friends who maintained an unusually close bond. Libby was the best cook and hostess anywhere, enjoyed music, reading, traveling, keeping up with the news, but most of all she loved her six grandchildren: Benjamin, Matthew, Alexa, Madelyn, Rebecca and Adam. Her daughters and their husbands Charlotte and Michael Zinder, Valerie Strauss and Marc Levy, and Andrea and Mark Dettelbach, her sister Debby Israel, her many nieces and nephews, and her devoted friends will miss her great hospitality, wisdom and powerful spirit. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Harold Strauss Endowed Scholarship Fund, University of Miami School of Business, POB 248032, Coral Cables, FL 33124-6521 or Brandeis University National Women's Committee, POB 549110, Waltham, MA 02454.

Though Galadriel Mattei named her Hollywood clothing boutique, Ylem, after an obscure scientific term for the primordial fabric of the universe, the merchandise is more down to earth. Mattei (top, center), a Los Angeles designer and stylist, stocks her own line as well as a mix of cherry-picked vintage -- a hooded, iridescent silk Krizia jacket from the 1980's, say, or John Paul Gaultier's iconic early-90's elephant leg trousers. Although she welcomes walk-ins at her shop (6353 Yucca Street; 310-403-7753), most of her business is by appointment. Mattei keeps size charts of her regular clients in case that dream item -- like a Zandra Rhodes white chiffon gown she recently scored -- should appear. STEFFIE NELSON

CAPELLUTO -- Alexander James. ''Like the sun, he brought warmth, brilliance and illumination to everything that he did and touched ...a star has vanished from our midst...we are heartbroken.'' The Horace Mann community is in deep shock and mourning over the tragic death of our cherished alumnus, Alexander Capelluto, HM 2004. Alexander's extraordinary intelligence and goodness, his indomitable spirit and fortitude, and his wonderful sense of humor touched all. Graduating as Valedictorian of his class, he was recognized in many ways for his distinguished work and valuable contributions to the daily life of the school...elected to the Cum Laude Society, he graduated with honors in Mathematics, History, English and Science. He was the recipient of the Joseph Chase Award in Mathematics and was a National Merit Scholarship awardee. He received Jazz Band and Chamber Wind Band awards, and was awarded the Scholarship for Academic Excellence provided by the State of New York. He was a remarkable individual whose imprint was everywhere...class president, a Governing Council representative, Model UN member, president of the Jazz Ensemble, ad hoc reporter for The Record, a cross-country runner and an avid basketball player. He was elected by his classmates to deliver their valedictory in June 2004. His death is a tragic loss. We are anguished by his passing and extend our most heartfelt condolences to his parents, Jacques and Karen Capelluto, and his sister Katherine, HM 2000. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly Head of School Robert J. Katz, HM 1965 Chair, Board of Trustees $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander, from the beginning a blend of brilliance, sweetness and spirit. He was our daughter's first playdate and will always be ''Zander to our Gingey.'' The memories and images are full in our hearts. With love and sympathy, Kevin, Lindsay, Lexi and Matti Brine $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander. Each of us mourns the tragic death of Alexander, age 20. His compassion, prodigious intellect and multiple talents awed and inspired all who knew him. Our loving thoughts are with his family. Donald, Julie, Joshua and Zoe Marcuse $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander. Beloved son of Jacques and Karen, loving brother of Katherine. Services 12 noon, Monday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue. No flowers. $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander. We deeply mourn the tragic death of our dear friend Alex. Karen, Jacques & Katherine, our thoughts and sympathies are with you. Ellen, Jeffrey, Kara and Jesse Oppenheim $(6$)CAPELLUTO--Alexander. You were the epitome of character and leadership. You will be missed. Shelley, Jeffrey, Jared and Adam
Buys you beach sounds better than the inside of a seashell. Sonic Impact i-Fusion speakers help your iPod work like a boombox in the sand (www.si-technologies.com). PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

STEP outdoors one spring night soon -- after midnight would be best -- and you just may hear them. Just above the rustle of leaves and the hushed splashing of lawn sprinklers, you may hear guitars strum and voices murmur as sophisticated recording equipment hums. They are 21st-century Dickinsons and Whitmans with names like Boxcar Nancy and East River Pipe making music that will go straight to the Web or eventually appear on self-produced CD's. All they need is one small, quiet room and their dreams to lose themselves in the obsessive world of what has become known as bedroom pop, bloglike music that tries to make the world a better place through a perfect homemade song.

To the Editor: If the effects of inhaling World Trade Center dust are debilitating but treatable for firefighters, as a recent health study suggests (''Firefighters' Lung Capacity Suffered After 9/11 Work,'' news article, May 16), New York's public health authorities ought to do two things.
