A bartender becomes an unwitting accomplice in choosing a serial killer's next victim. 3 1 BROKEN PREY, by John Sandford. (Berkley, $9.99.) Lucas Davenport, working for the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, searches for a serial killer. 4 137 ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Pocket, $9.99 and $7.99.) A scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society. 5 2 A GOOD YARN, by Debbie Macomber. (Mira, $7.99.) The lives and loves of a group of women who meet at a knitting class in Seattle. 6 4 TRUE BELIEVER, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $12.95.) WILLIAMS--Ray. Died May 14 at NYU Medical Center which was a part of most of his life. Ray was the Administrator of the Department of Surgery under Frank Spencer, MD. About 40 years ago when his son Shawn had to tell his classmates what his father's work was, he said, ''My Dad tells doctors what to do.'' Well, that somewhat overstates it, but all at NYU who had contact with him knew he could things done and was so highly regarded for his ability as a facilitator. The general word was ''Go see Ray.'' Ray was born in Atlanta, GA and a graduate of Grady High School and Georgia Tech. He was enormously popular as a young man and was relied upon to be the organizer. This ability continued throughout his life. He organized numerous cruise trips among so many other activities for multiple friends. Ray was also a generous contributor to all equality causes. Ray is survived by his life partner of 40 years, Frank Folisi, his son, Shawn, daughter-in-law, Jasmine, and their children, David and Jennifer, and a brother, Graybill, of Orlando, FL.

Russell Shorto's article was illuminating and unbiased. He raised legitimate questions, followed by concrete summations of responses from prominent sectors of church and state. His article acknowledges the links between contraception and abortion and keeps the main points in focus, while respectfully noting the divergent interpretations. The Rev. James Diluzio Paulist Fathers New York
An article on May 7 about the actor Rip Torn misstated the surname of one of his former wives and misspelled her given name. She is Ann Wedgeworth, not Anne Wedgewood.

COLLEGE campuses can be good neighbors. At their best they are cultural beacons in the suburbs, a place where the arts flourish in communities that otherwise may not be able to support them. The visual arts are a prime example. There are more than two dozen galleries and museums tucked away on campuses in the New York suburbs. They are a varied lot, characterized partly by the wealth of the school and the generosity of alumni and partly by the kind of art they display.

Thinking about the health and future of Long Island Sound calls to mind an old ''Far Side'' cartoon, the one where a dentist, having filled a patient's gaping jaws with a steely forest of braces, clamps, screws and straps, announces that he wants to insert a tennis ball, too, just to see if he can. About 20 million people live within 50 miles of the Sound, and it seems sometimes as if all of them at once are either putting something into it (sewage, fertilizer, pesticides, natural gas platforms) or taking something out (striped bass, flounder, clams, lobsters). Left to itself, the Sound would surely regain its footing as a stable, healthy ecosystem.

Love soccer (or at least soccer players)? The FIFA World Cup is a punter's Mecca, and this quadrennial tournament kicks off in Germany next month. If you go, you may want to visit Puma SoundTrip (www.soundtrip.puma.com), which includes sport-friendly audio guides and maps of the host cities. But even if you just plan to record the games on your DVR, you can still step up your wardrobe. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

To the Editor: Your May 7 editorial ''Getting Governors Island Right'' got it exactly right. The island will be a spectacular new destination for New York and its visitors if the mayor and the governor follow through on their commitments to put preservation, education and open spaces first.

To the Editor: There is no doubt that Camden is a struggling city. As you point out in ''Camden Still Finds Itself Treading Water'' (April 30), redevelopment focused on waterfront attractions has been slower than anyone hoped. Still, investments being made in Camden, spurred by the Economic Recovery Board, are making a real difference in the lives of residents.

HALPERN--Shelly. Ph.D, educator, writer, photographer, historian, died suddenly on April 28, 2006 from complications following surgery. She was 69 years old. An independent, forthright, incisive thinker of great integrity, she worked closely with Dr. Kenneth Clark, taught at the university level and in New York City high schools for many years rescuing scores of students out of poverty, designed and developed educational and testing programs. Very concerned with the oppressed, she gave generously of time and money to numerous organizations including those in her Lower East Side neighborhood of Gouverneur Gardens. Dr. Halpern graduated from CCNY in 1958 Phi Beta Kappa, earned an MA in English from Cornell, a Ph.D from Fordham and was a Post Doctoral Fellow at Columbia. She was a generous philanthropist of the arts and education, more recently researching the history of immigrants and immigration. The daughter of Max J. Halpern and Luba Chusid Halpern, immigrants from Poland and Russia, she is survived and beloved by her twin sister, Dr. Lenore Migdal, niece Laura Migdal, brother-in-law Dr. William Lloyd and many loving cousins and dear friends. A private memorial service will be held. Donations in her name can be sent to The City College Fund, The City College, 139 St. and Convent Ave, N.Y., N.Y. 10031. She is, and will be deeply missed.

LIBYA The News -- The United States renewed diplomatic relations with Libya, ending more than a quarter-century of estrangement. Behind the News -- The two countries' relationship has come a long way since 1979, when the United States severed relations, and particularly since 1988, when Libyan agents blew up Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland, killing 270. Libya did its part by abandoning unconventional weapons and renouncing terrorism. But in some ways the world has also passed Libya by, and with Iraq, Afghanistan, Al Qaeda and now Iran, the United States has bigger fish to fry. IRAQ The News -- A panel of judges in the trial of Saddam Hussein approved formal charges of crimes against humanity in the case. Behind the News -- The ruling means that Mr. Hussein and seven co-defendants would almost certainly face the death penalty if convicted. Mr. Hussein and the others are on trial in connection with the execution of 148 Shiites in 1982. Convictions would not come anytime soon, however. The trial has already gone on for more than seven months -- the judges' ruling came after the prosecution presented its evidence -- and is expected to continue into the fall. WASHINGTON The News -- Less than a day after the deadline for enrollment in the Medicare prescription drug program, a bipartisan group of senators pushed to eliminate the penalty for people who missed it. Behind the News -- The administration had defended the penalty -- an increase on future premiums -- as a stick to encourage people to sign up for the program, which subsidizes drug coverage. But the senators, uneasy about upsetting the electorate in an election year, said the program was difficult to understand. Waiving the fee would cost an estimated $1.7 billion over five years. RHODE ISLAND The News -- A judge in Rhode Island sentenced the onetime reality TV star Richard Hatch to 51 months in prison for tax evasion. Behind the News -- The sentence was at least 10 months longer than expected, and the judge said he opted for the longer term because it was clear to him that Mr. Hatch had lied during the trial. Mr. Hatch denied that he had been less than truthful, but fans of reality television could believe the judge's comments, given that Mr. Hatch connived his way to winning the CBS reality show ''Survivor'' in 2000. TEXAS The News -- The Texas Department of Transportation said it would consider raising the speed limit to 80 miles per hour on parts of two Interstate highways. Behind the News -- By making the proposal, the department seemed to thumb its nose at those who argue that Americans need to conserve gasoline. And traffic safety experts said that raising the limit would make the highways, in rural parts of West Texas, less safe. But officials said that if they raised the limit, they would just be acknowledging the obvious: that motorists drive that fast already.

ON weekdays, Julie Kroloff sets the coffee maker for 5:45 a.m., then speeds through her kitchen in Hopewell Junction, N.Y., and grabs a cup to fortify herself for the long drive ahead. If Ms. Kroloff, a self-employed consultant, is on time, she backs out of the garage just before 6 and makes the trip from Dutchess County to her office in Midtown Manhattan in just under two hours. If traffic is heavy, Ms. Kroloff's 54-mile commute can take two and a half hours or more. About the same time, in Burlington, N.J., south of Trenton, Ronny Byrd, a vault custodian for the Bank of New York, boards a bus bound for Wall Street. If the New Jersey Turnpike and the Holland Tunnel are not backed up, Mr. Byrd will reach his destination in two hours.

Sweeps month rolls on. NBC's ''10.5: APOCALYPSE'' (Sunday and Tuesday nights at 9) is a sequel to a 2004 disaster film in which the West Coast was devastated by an earthquake that surely qualified as ''the big one.'' But my oh my, now there's an even worse earthquake coming. One seismologist (FRANK LANGELLA) has predicted that it could create a continental divide right down the middle of the United States. BEAU BRIDGES is the president, KIM DELANEY a determined seismologist, DAVID CUBITT her ex-boyfriend and GARCELLE BEAUVAIS-NILON the FEMA boss. When Stephen King thinks about the apocalypse, he heads for Nevada (at least Las Vegas was the Antichrist's headquarters in ''The Stand''). The title of ''STEPHEN KING'S DESPERATION'' (ABC, Tuesday night at 8), a three-hour movie, refers to Desperation, Nev., where hapless motorists are stopped by a local lawman (RON PERLMAN), framed for marijuana possession and thrown in jail. The scary part is that dead people are lying all over town, and the cop is possessed by something evil. TOM SKERRITT, ANNABETH GISH, MATT FREWER and CHARLES DURNING are among the inmates. It's highly self-referential. (Yes, that's ''redrum'' written on a wall.) One more time, it's the ''AMERICAN IDOL'' season finale on Fox. CHRIS DAUGHTRY, who even the notoriously demanding SIMON COWELL predicted would win, is gone. On Tuesday night at 8 the two finalists perform. Then the producers stretch out Wednesday night's show (also at 8), when the winner is announced, to two hours. That includes a reunion of the Top 12, but some people will still watch only the last 10 minutes. For those not swept up so much by sweeps, ''JIM HENSON'S THE STORYTELLER'' comes out as a two-disc DVD set (Sony Pictures, $19.94) on Tuesday. That means nine fairy tales (including one that asks whether a king will marry his beautiful daughter off to a hedgehog) and four Greek myths with decidedly uncuddly puppets.

R. Albert Mohler Jr., president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, says that students on his campus are ''intensely concerned'' about the morality of contraception. Students can have the luxury of intense concern. The true test will come in 10 or 15 years, when those students have a spouse and children to support on a minister's salary. When the rubber of ideals meets the road of financial reality, I wonder if their consciences will manage to accommodate contraception. Angela Stockton Clermont, Fla.

IN the mid-1900's, Eugene I. Meyer Jr., financier, federal government official and later the owner of The Washington Post, entertained in grand style at his Georgian-style mansion overlooking Byram Lake in northern Westchester. The stately home, where Katharine Graham, Meyer's daughter, the longtime publisher of The Post, was raised, was renowned for its orangery -- a separate glass and stone building where the family grew citrus fruit in the winter and held parties -- and a bowling alley in the basement.

As an advocate for reproductive rights and health, I applaud Shorto for clearly exhibiting the archaic quality of the socially conservative position on sexuality and sexual health. However, his failure to even once mention women's rights in an article explicitly focused on the politics of women's health disturbed me. Instead of quoting the English writer Daniel Defoe, Shorto might have cited the United States Supreme Court, which in 1908 ruled that the state could regulate a woman's workday because it had an interest in ''protecting'' her reproductive capacity for ''the well-being of the race.'' How is it that now, despite the fact that this case was long since implicitly overturned, this country is still run by people who believe that womanhood is inextricable from motherhood? Diana Price New York
To the Editor: Re ''A Parisian Impressionist Jewel Reopens, Polished'' (Arts pages, May 16):
To the Editor: I found it curious that you ran a banner headline, ''For School Budgets, the New Word Is No,'' only two days before Super Tuesday, leaving no opportunity to respond.

The quest for the perfect nude beach is a high-risk proposition. The upside is undeniably sweet: the sun on your buttocks and the perfect sneak peek at unsuspecting, perfectly bronzed nubiles. But whether you are truly a tan-line eliminator or a peeping Tom, you need to choose your beach wisely or suffer the unsightly consequences.

TIME was when the theater at the Showboat Casino Hotel at the north end of the Boardwalk strip had the look and charm of a junior high school cafeteria. Showgoers checking out Don Rickles or Frank Sinatra Jr. would have to sit at long tables on a flat floor. These days, the Showboat's showroom is the place to see acts like Eminem, Government Mule and even the saucy comic Margaret Cho -- and the floor actually has a tilt to it now. The House of Blues chain took over the main entertainment room in the Showboat last year and transformed it.

To the Editor: What was your headline writer thinking when he or she wrote ''For School Budgets, the New Word Is No'' (May 14)? That is the message that probably resonated with the uninformed, the uncommitted and the wavering who walked into voting booths on May 16. And yet your article indicates that it is hardly a majority that is voting down the budgets. You note that one-third of budgets in 2004 and 2005 were rejected. That leaves a resounding two-thirds that were passed.

In the final reckoning, the pianist PAUL BLEY's influence over the last 50 years of jazz -- and it continues -- will be enormous. It includes figures as major as Keith Jarrett and Pat Metheny, and endless numbers of musicians who are still learning. Deeply original and aesthetically aggressive, Mr. Bley long ago found a way to express his long, elegant, voluminous thoughts in a manner that implies complete autonomy from its given setting but isn't quite free jazz. The music runs on a mixture of deep historical knowledge and its own inviolable principles. On Monday he plays a duo concert with one of the younger pianists who has absorbed him most deeply, FRANK KIMBROUGH. The admiration runs both ways, but that doesn't mean they'll go easy on each other. One might expect thorough, almost forensic examinations of standards, as well as their own music. 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330; $35. DUCK BAKER, a resourceful and knowledgeable acoustic fingerpicking guitarist, has waded deeply into all kinds of American repertories, from ragtime, blues and gospel music to the harmonically intricate jazz compositions of Herbie Nichols. Mr. Baker plays three times this week: first at the tiny Lower East Side club the Stone, probably joined by some other guitarists, during the special month the club has prepared in homage to the guitarist Derek Bailey, who died in December; then outdoors at Green-Wood Cemetery, playing old-time music; and finally at the Brooklyn Lyceum, playing what he describes as modern jazz. Tuesday at 8 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, www.thestonenyc.com; $10. Thursday at 8 p.m., Green-Wood Cemetery, 500-25th Street, Brooklyn, $10. Friday at 10:30 p.m., Brooklyn Lyceum, 227 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, $10. Information on the Brooklyn shows: (718) 857-4816 or www.gowanus.com.
To the Editor: Re ''Richest Kids on the Block Find That Money May Talk but Money Can't Dance'' by Roslyn Sulcas [May 14]:

To the Editor: I'd like to start a petition to name Walter Kirn the United States Book Reviewer Laureate. No matter what he's writing about, Kirn's reviews are consistently insightful, profoundly articulate and uniquely illuminating. From the first Kirn review I'm conscious of having read (of Rick Moody's ''Demonology,'' in February 2001), which set forth a generous and dynamic way to read and interrogate collections of short fiction, to his recent brilliantly comic manifesto against ''Manliness'' (March 19), and his inventive, cinematic and virtually acrobatic review of A. M. Homes's ''This Book Will Save Your Life'' (May 7), I dig into every Walter Kirn review for The Times with the kind of anticipation and relish I once reserved for Anthony Lane's film critiques in The New Yorker. Maybe I should just register this as my first official book-critic crush? Thisbe Nissen Iowa City Thisbe Nissen is the author of two novels and a story collection.

Fashion, as colorful as a circus, is mixed together by a few talented wearers, left and right, with the sensitivity of artists or the innocence of children holding balloons. They add a joyous exuberance to the popular style spectrum of neutral colorings.
To the Editor: Re ''Turkey, Armenia and Denial'' (editorial, May 16):

Although he's best known for helping people build their dream houses, the home improvement expert Bob Vila also helps filmmakers make their dream movies. Interviewed at a party recently at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which is the host this month for programs with the Sundance Institute, Mr. Vila talked about why the Fledgling Fund, a foundation that he and his family established that focuses on improving health care for poor families, was giving grants to filmmakers. The reasoning, he said, was that films deliver messages with the power to influence policy and public opinion, so he likes to finance film projects that could have a salubrious effect on health care policy.

Boston Red Sox Manager Terry Francona made an interesting choice on April 25. With his team leading Cleveland, 5-4, he chose to send the 39-year-old Curt Schilling to the mound for the seventh inning, even though Schilling had already thrown 110 pitches. What unfolded was something rare in the current era of closely managed pitch counts. Schilling threw 23 more pitches, surrendering the lead and being relieved with two outs and 133 pitches thrown. For perspective, Schilling's 133-pitch total has been the most by a starter this season; in the past five-plus seasons, that total has been exceeded only 28 times.

Brother-inlaw of Gloria Kreizel. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett LI, at 10 AM, Friday.

Jazz From a Harp Back in the day, classical music was plentiful on the airwaves, and major networks had their own symphony orchestras. ''There were concerts all the time on radio and TV,'' said Ruth Berman Harris of White Plains, who was a freelance harpist with those orchestras and other groups for 48 years and played under the legendary conductor Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony.

To the Editor: Re ''Someone Has to Pay for TV. But Who? And How?'' (Digital Domain, May 7), which described how technology might someday immobilize the remote control during commercials: Go ahead -- take away my remote and develop TV sets that will not let me choose what to see and when to see it. But have those who would take this course of action considered the possible consequences?
Grab a beer and the baby oil!

For all the talk about the ''culture of life'' and poetic pontifications on matrimonial sex, this looks like thinly veiled misogyny to me. Now, if the same parties who put forth such a strong rationale for limiting (women's) access to contraceptives started to clamor for legislative protection for pharmacists who refused to fill Viagra prescriptions for male clients who will not certify that they will use the drug only in the context of connubial, procreative sex, one might begin to take their philosophical/moral/ethical concerns seriously. Kyle Brown, M.D. Iowa City

To the Editor: Congratulations for a clear and concise portrayal of the Turkish denial of the 1915 genocide of the Armenian people. Your editorial will greatly contribute to helping Turkey finally come to grips with its treatment of the Armenian minority living within Ottoman Turkey during World War I.

I see the value of combating a hypersexualized culture, but I question the methods of the abstinence-only camp. With its ''purity balls'' and ''purity rings,'' it sends the message that abstinence is more important for girls. Telling girls that their value is tied to their virginity sets them up for a lifetime of using sex as currency in the search for acceptance. There are better ways to promote sexual responsibility. Jenny Knopinski Bethesda, Md.

As the daughter of a diplomat and a flight attendant, the L.A. artist Zoe Crosher is obsessed with transience. For her new book, ''Out the Window (LAX)'' (LA Forum), Crosher explored the limbo of life at the airport, photographing planes coming in for landing through the windows of the surrounding hotels and motels. In her images, the planes are incidental to the parking lots, empty balconies and cheap carpeting and curtains that make up the local accommodations. Crosher says she doesn't find these spaces depressing, but still, she's in no hurry to get back to LAX: ''These days I'm trying to book everything out of Burbank.'' STEFFIE NELSON

Oh, those celebrities and their wacky tuxedo fashion antics. Perhaps in certain circles, a double-breasted satin dinner jacket and a mile-long ascot do look elegant with Converse sneakers. But for un-Hollywood types who aren't burning to stand out clownishly in a sea of black tie, a simple black tuxedo should do the trick. To take some of the stress out of prom and wedding season, J. Crew has added just such a tuxedo to its men's line. The single-breasted, one-button jacket ($550) has the nice detail of a necktie-silk-lined collar; the pants are flat-front and have a silk-lined waistband ($225 at J. Crew stores). Wear it with a plain white evening shirt and a spare black Jack Spade bow tie, and you instantly rise above the faddish fray.

THE New York Legislature is debating whether to approve a sex offender civil commitment law. The law would allow the attorney general to confine sex offenders in secure hospitals indefinitely after they have served their prison sentences. This is a bad idea. More than a dozen states have tried this novel strategy for preventing sexual recidivism. Their experiences clearly show that these laws waste taxpayer dollars and embroil state agencies in endless litigation. Instead of warehousing a small percentage of sex offenders, states should use the money on cost-effective strategies like community supervision combined with mandatory treatment that would reach many more released convicts.

David Letterman The Tony nominations are out. The Oprah thing, ''The Color Purple,'' has been nominated for 12 Tonys. I'm thrilled. It's nice to see something finally going Oprah's way. Speaking of Tonys, a new musical is opening up about Vice President Cheney. It's called ''Cheney Get Your Gun.'' ''How many folks saw the President's address about immigration last night? President Bush feels that it's time we do something special about illegal immigration. And I'm thinking, well, by gosh, he nipped that in the bud.'' Jay Leno President Bush said last night that we do not yet have full control of the border. Full control? If we had any less control there would be an E-ZPass lane. President Bush said that these troops will be at the border temporarily. You know, just until Mexico is ready to govern itself. Sound familiar? Barry Bonds is still one home run away from tying Babe Ruth's record. He's still in a home run slump. You know what I think the problem is? Since he's stopped using steroids, his hat is falling over his eyes. I think his head has shrunk. Conan O'Brien Senator Hillary Clinton is being criticized because she recently called today's college kids lazy and uninformed. A spokesperson for college kids said, ''Whatever lady from TV.'' Cuban dictator Fidel Castro is furious about a Forbes magazine story that says he is worth $900 million and says he will step down if they can prove it. Castro's exact quote was, ''If I had that kind of money I'd be living in Miami.''

To the Sports Editor: I just read Joe Drape's smart and insightful article (''Thinking Triple Crown Before the First Race Was Run,'' May 14) about Michael Matz, trainer of the Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro, and the comparatively unconventional route they took to Louisville.

An article last Sunday about the renovation of Greenwood Gardens in Short Hills referred incorrectly to the population of New Jersey. It is the most densely populated state in the country, not the most populous.

Grandfather of Julie, Cheryl, Sarah, Alex, Becky, Jake, and Zoe. He will be greatly missed. Graveside service, Sunday, 10:00 A.M. Mt. Eden Cemetery. PART 5

Hundreds of immigrants and their supporters marched down Madison Avenue yesterday, calling on the United States Senate to pass legislation this week that would offer millions of illegal immigrants the chance to become American citizens. The march was far smaller than an April 10 demonstration that drew thousands to City Hall Park. The atmosphere was festive as Koreans, South Asians, Hispanics, Haitians and others beat bongo drums, blew whistles and waved signs reading, ''I Love Immigrant New York.''

JOE ORTON has received a lot of attention recently, largely because of Alec Baldwin's turn in ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane'' at the Roundabout Theater in Manhattan. The Two River Theater Company here boasts no movie stars in its Orton comedy, ''What the Butler Saw,'' but it shares Roundabout's challenge to successfully bring British humor to an American audience. The most striking element of the Two River production is Jeremy Doucette's set. As soon as the curtain rose on opening night, the audience applauded the sprawling psychiatric clinic, painted in robin's-egg blue with cream-colored wainscoting. The costumes by Deborah J. Caney are exactly late 1960's London, from the bobby's blue cap to the secretary's pink high heels. But while the production is lovely to look at, it is not as delightful to hold.

What if the slowly emerging opposition to contraception is much more than an effort to inhibit promiscuity, promote youthful abstinence or contend that contraception is really a type of abortion? What if it is ultimately an effort to condemn any action intended to prevent procreation? We may be dealing with a mind-set aimed at eventually controlling private marital behavior. I suspect most people are critical of Iranian mullahs, who control dress codes and the public behavior of unmarried people. Are we quietly edging toward a similar effort to impose state control over the desire of people, unmarried or married, to decide whether they wish to procreate? Jerry Sheinbach Lutherville, Md.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Summer Stages list of festivals misidentified the site of a concert in the San Luis Obispo Mozart Festival. It was Chapel Hill, a private chapel in Shandon, Calif., built in the mission style, not an 18th-century Spanish mission.

FROM now through the fall, the county's calendar is chockablock with art, music and cultural festivals. Have you ever wondered what it takes to get one on the map in a community? Those who have done so cite several key factors: a strong idea, a core group of dedicated volunteers and advance planning of up to a year. According to Ron Aja, outreach events director of the 40-year-old Clearwater Festival, which is scheduled for June 17 and 18 at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson: ''If you're just starting out, you need either a lot of money or a lot of time. If you don't have money, you need a lot of time to put all the pieces together in a way you can afford.'' And keep expectations low, he advises -- at least at the beginning. ''There's a growth process. Unless you can afford big names, you need to let the festival grow organically.''

Some United States officials said they feared the naming of Iraq's new government may be the last chance to save the American enterprise in Iraq from a descent into chaos and civil war. News Analysis, Page 18.

Having mastered the grape, Australians are tackling the coffee bean. A visit to Campos, a coffee bar in Sydney, or to Batch Espresso, in Melbourne, is worth the 22-hour flight from New York -- not to mention a great way to kick the jet lag. Order a ''short black,'' Aussie for espresso, or a ''flat white,'' a sort of macho cappuccino, devoid of froth. In no time, you'll discover why baristas have replaced pub owners as the anchors of many communities. How did this former British colony steeped in tea drinking succumb to coffee mania? It started in Italy in 1947, when Achilles Gaggia perfected the spresso machine -- right on cue for the post-World War II migration to Australia from southern Europe. Italians arrived en masse in the 50's and early 60's, and a generation later, espresso had seeped into the mainstream. About 10,000 cafes dot the country, so competition is fierce. At least one leading newspaper gives a barista-of-the-year award. ''Coffee Guide ... Sydney'' rates 120 of the city's top cafes. Baristas even distinguish their drinks with latte art -- motifs like roses and fern leaves. The craft has become so popular, technical colleges now give classes. IAN KELDOULIS

To the Editor: Re ''Is Lefty Finally Showing Up?'' [April 23]: Charles Isherwood astutely observes that there is a renewed interest in unionism, exemplified by revivals of ''The Pajama Game'' and ''Awake and Sing.'' The producers he cites are not-for-profit institutions, however. Meanwhile, in Broadway's commercial sector, producers and theater owners are banding together to try to weaken if not eliminate theatrical unions: each week 10 cents of every paid admission is diverted to a strike fund for this very purpose. (The contract of Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, the stagehands' union, is up for renegotiation in 2007.)

HELPING a friend with her tag sale in the Hamptons, while trying to get rid of a few of my own accumulated possessions, was not only an exhausting ordeal but a mind opener. Who ever needed any of this stuff? I vow to live only with more than what is absolutely necessary -- an unrealistic concept for anyone except the die-hard minimalist (hardly me). Yet having much less stuff around is a cleansing thought.

To the Editor: ''Odd Math for 'Best High Schools' List,'' by Michael Winerip (On Education column, May 17), exposes the major flaw in Newsweek's list of America's Best High Schools: that it is based on the percentage of students taking Advanced Placement tests, without regard to how many do well on the tests.
To the Sports Editor: Re Harvey Araton's column, ''Federer-Nadal Is Starting to Have That Frazier-Ali Ring'' (May 16): This rivalry is truly one of the most exciting stories in sports right now.

To the Editor: When are we going to stop blaming people for their suffering and simply commit ourselves to alleviating it (''Beyond 'I'm a Diabetic,' Little Common Ground,'' ''Cost and Effect'' series, front page, May 17)?

A theater entry today in the Week Ahead report on Page 4 of Arts & Leisure misstates the city where David Schwimmer appeared in the play ''Some Girl(s).'' It was London, not Chicago. In addition, the entry misstates the top ticket price in New York. It is $70, not $75.

''OUR top-of-the-line pool is the Johnny Weismuller over here,'' Corey Bullock says, leading the way. For eight years, he has been a salesman at Harrow's, a hangarlike pool and spa store with inflated duckies dangling from the rafters. Certain phrases -- ''extruded aluminum'' and ''optional decking feature,'' for example -- have become part of his everyday vocabulary.

RYAN--Angela Shen, Ph.D., 77. Died on May 18, 2006 after a long illness. She was a beloved wife, mother and grandmother as well as an esteemed professor of social work. Her loss is deeply felt. A service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave. on Tuesday, May 23, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, send donations in her name to the Hunter School of Social Work, 129 E. 79th St., NYC 10021, attn: Dean's Office.

Architecture fosters more controversy than perhaps any of the other arts. From Beijing to Biloxi, it's the vehicle for heated debates about aesthetics, politics and the uses of public space. Here's why.

While fancy liquid soaps may be a dime a dozen these days, C. O. Bigelow's Lemon Hand Wash seems to have struck a chord with shoppers who are snapping up bottles of the citrusy stuff and making it the latest ablutionary accessory. The hand wash made its debut this spring and swiftly sold out.

To the Editor: Michael J. Agovino hit the nail on the head in his article about New York University. I was a member of the same endangered species: local, subway-riding students. In the late 60's I was in one of the last classes in the evening division at N.Y.U. Law School before that division was shut down -- largely, we suspected, because the Harvards, Yales and Columbias do not run evening divisions for less desirable people like me. I sometimes dream of Harvard Law School recognizing its obligations to the local community and opening up an evening division. Should that ever happen, I would not be surprised to see N.Y.U. fall over itself to backtrack. Brian A. Jones Brooklyn Heights

To the Editor: Re ''Way North of the Border'' (April 30): Immigrants here legally are O.K. But illegal immigrants have with deliberate forethought violated our borders and laws. Deport them. If there is no one to care for their children, born here, give them a choice. Take the children with them, and we will give the kids United States passports. Or put the children in the care of the state child welfare agencies.

Anyone who has a problem with contraception should spend a few days in a country where women spend their entire adult lives bearing and raising children. We have increasing problems with street kids, rampant crime of all types, malnutrition, illiteracy and low status of women, just to start. How could someone who is ''pro-life'' wish this on anyone? Peter Mildner Papua New Guinea

ARBEENY--Emily. The entire Long Island College Hospital (LICH) family is saddened by the passing of Emily Arbeeny, longtime member of the LICH Board of Regents. Her lifelong commitment to community health greatly benefited Brooklyn residents and Long Island College Hospital. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. We extend deepest sympathies to her family. John Wren, Chairman of the Board of Regents, LICH Morton P. Hyman, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Continuum Health Partners Rita Battles, President and CEO, LICH
From Mustique to the Mediterranean to Manhattan, T offers plenty of tips for an endless summer (bikini optional).

FOR cinema lovers, a July bonanza awaits. Long Island film festivals are becoming showcases for new work, offering a chance to see hundreds of lovingly made films, many of which may never find mainstream distribution. Nearly all the films scheduled to come to the Island via festivals are independent, a slippery label generally meaning that they were not produced by major studios and do not have built-in distribution deals. With finished films in hand, filmmakers hunger for audiences. For the burgeoning number of independent filmmakers around the world, film festivals are the brightest hope for finding distributors.

Joe Torre's first words after the Yankees' 11-inning comeback victory yesterday spoke a lot about what is on his mind. ''It was an ugly game for a long time,'' he said. Torre, the Yankees' manager, is concerned about his team's defense. The Yankees have committed at least one error in each of their past eight games, surviving four errors yesterday to beat the Mets, 5-4.

KATHLEEN KORES, a k a Leila Dal, her pumpkin-colored hair flowing over a blazing red velour blouse, moved along the floor of her studio in Glastonbury the way a snake moves in the grass, smoothly and silently. Then, in a split-second maneuver, she bent a knee and threw a hip to one side like a weapon. Her class tried to follow suit, but that smoothness eluded them. ''No bouncing!'' Ms. Kores admonished.

No longer a cow town, Bozeman -- in Big Sky Country, Montana -- has been nicknamed Boz Angeles because of an influx of Californians and celebrities. This has resulted in ranchers cashing out and Wal-Mart moving in, although downtown Bozeman still has plenty of charm, along with mountain views. And while it has been known to snow in August, on most weekends you'll find the whole town -- and its many dogs -- floating down the Madison and Yellowstone Rivers on inner tubes.

Weak demand for some European sailings is leading to some deep discounts for summer cruises in the Mediterranean and Northern Europe. Earlier this month, Holland America Line, which has five ships in Europe this year, one more than in 2005, cut prices by 30 percent or more off brochure rates on four Baltic cruises departing May through September. For example, most of its 12-day Best of the Baltic voyage on the Rotterdam, right, sailing from London to Copenhagen in June and July, now start at $1,499 a person based on double occupancy, down from $2,349. Information: 877-724-5425; www.hollandamerica.com.

ASHLEY KAHN was in one of those sublime yet ridiculous situations a few years ago when he stumbled upon his writerly epiphany. He had spent most of the previous dozen years as a road or tour manager for rock acts and he happened to be in Memphis helping run a tour for Britney Spears. ''I had taken some of the dancers over to Graceland for a tour during the afternoon and, at the same time, I was editing a piece on the 40th anniversary of 'Kind of Blue,' one of Miles Davis's masterpieces,'' he said. ''So there I was on the cellphone on a bench at Graceland trying to explain modal jazz to an editor while Britney's dancers were, I don't know, crying at Elvis's grave. It was pretty funny.''
SPITZ--Gloria, also known as Gloria Becker, died peacefully on May 18, 2006. See obituary under BECKER--Gloria.

To the Editor: Carole Getzoff (''The Demon Shopper of Fordham Road,'' May 14) pulled me back in time to similar childhood memories. I, too, grew up in the Northeast Bronx -- not Pelham Bay but Parkchester -- and Alexander's on Fordham Road was the change-of-season mecca of shopping. The paired shoes, the success of the hunt, the whining (me) when my mother picked out serviceable but not necessarily stylish clothing. The hours (or so it seemed) of measuring, nipping, tucking, all while rotating so slowly on the stepstool. All this done while my brother was allowed, most unfairly, to watch TV or go ''down'' to play!
An entry last Sunday in the Summer Stages list for SPF: Summer Play Festival in New York misstated the phone number for tickets. It is (212) 279-4200.

ANDREASIAN--Edgar Diran. 80, of Great Neck, NY, died at home on May 19, 2006. Born and raised in New York City, he is survived by his former wife Zepure Andreasian, his daughter Marguerite White, sons Peter and Theodore, and granddaughters Arax and Amelia. Friends may visit at the Edward D. Jamie Jr. Funeral Chapel, 208-17 Northern Blvd., Bayside, NY, on Monday, between the hours of 3 to 5, and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Holy Martyrs Armenian Church, 209-15 Horace Harding Blvd., Bayside, NY, on Tuesday, May 23, at 12 noon. His wit and wisdom will be sorely missed.
Dry off, lie down, be happy.

IT could have been a keg party or a hipper-than-usual church social: As 80 guests parked bumper to bumper along the main drag of tiny Haddam, Conn., one Saturday night last month, couples clambered out of cars carrying covered potluck dishes and six-packs. Some congregated around cars while they sipped from plastic cups, while others followed a flashlight-waving attendant toward the back door of a 19th-century church. Once inside, they handed their casserole dishes to the evening's gray-haired but youthful host, John Friedlander, a real estate agent.

Paramount Classics is pulling out the political stops to pump its documentary about global warming, ''AN INCONVENIENT TRUTH,'' which arrives just at the moment when the broader culture seems ready to pay attention. The film had its premiere at Sundance but, oddly, did not make a big splash there. It features former Vice President AL GORE as he travels from place to place ringing alarm bells (which is not the same as being alarmist) about global warming; it also intersperses science with Mr. Gore's personal journey into activism. The studio has tapped into political grass-roots groups to promote the film, but you needn't be an activist to find this either interesting or relevant. Opens Wednesday at Sunshine Cinema, 143 East Houston Street, (212) 330-8182, and AMC Loews Lincoln Square, 1998 Broadway, (212) 505-6397; and at the Arclight Hollywood in Los Angeles, (323) 464-4226, and the Monica in Santa Monica, (310) 394-9741. If you're into dark Gothic tales with more than a hint of forbidden sex, see ''THE KING,'' which opened on Friday in Manhattan and expands to five more cities on June 9. The gifted GAEL GARCÍA BERNAL plays a young dreamer just out of the Navy who travels to Corpus Christi, Tex., to find his father, played by WILLIAM HURT. But the father, now a pastor, would rather forget this reminder of a sinning past. As the young man continues to insinuate himself into the family's life, and that of his half-sister, the stage is set for violence and, ultimately, tragedy. MILO ADDICA, whose credits include ''Monster's Ball'' and ''Birth,'' wrote the screenplay with JAMES MARSH, who directed. Sunshine Cinema, 143 East Houston Street, (212) 330-8182.

QUAYTMAN--Wilfred, Ph.D. Died on April 1, 2006 at age 92 in NYC. He was a noted psychologist in the NYC area for 55 years, co-founder of the Long Island Consultation Center mental health clinic in 1953, founder of the Long Island Institute for Mental Health psychotherapy training institute in 1960, and founding editor of the Journal of Contemporary Psychotherapy. He will be missed by his Wife Harriet, two stepdaughters, six grandchildren and all his friends and colleagues. Contributions to honor his memory may be made to the Glaucoma Foundation, 80 Maiden Lane, Suite 1206, New York, NY 10038.

With gas prices soaring, a number of hotel chains are rolling out gas-related discounts. Through Sept. 10, Gaylord Hotels, which has resorts in Dallas, Nashville and Kissimmee, Fla., is offering $25 a day to guests who stay a minimum of two nights. About a dozen Best Western hotels in California are giving gas credits. They include properties in Pacifica (www.bestwesternlighthouse.com), Half Moon Bay (www.halfmoonbaylodge.com) and San Diego (www.bestwestern-bluesea.com) offering $50 gas cards to guests who stay three or more nights by May 25 and use promotion code Gas50 when booking online.

The Hong Kong fashion company Shanghai Tang has taken a great leap forward in recent years, thanks to Joanne Ooi, its creative director since late 2001. ''We've transformed the brand from a high-end, touristic Chinese emporium into modern clothes with a Chinese touch,'' said Ms. Ooi, a native of Singapore. ''I get my ideas from China. I don't read fashion magazines or go to runway shows for inspiration. I prefer to visit a province in China to see how a certain ethnic group dresses or to read a biography of the Empress Dowager.'' Ms. Ooi, 38, said she considered wearing all black to be ''a cop-out, a form of laziness,'' and described her own aesthetic as ''powerful femininity.'' She explained: ''I never dress in girlie clothes, I don't wear ruffles. During that big Victorian lace moment I bought a token shirt on a whim, and I never wore it.'' Her favorite designers are the flounce-free Azzedine Alaïa, Helmut Lang, Junya Watanabe and Missoni.

The final scene of the final episode of ''Sex and the City'' offered viewers a glimpse of a New York institution. But the backdrop to Sarah Jessica Parker's last stroll was not Central Park or the Empire State Building or the New York Public Library.

Melky Cabrera's confidence is written in red and blue ink on his right shoulder blade. It was there, five months ago, that Cabrera had a tattoo artist draw a Major League Baseball logo. At the time, Cabrera had played in only six games, none very well. Somehow, he must have known there was more to come. Cabrera is not supposed to be playing for the Yankees now, but there he was in the ninth inning at Shea Stadium yesterday, down two strikes to the Mets' star closer, Billy Wagner.

Book now! CHRISTOPHER ISENBERG

EVERY day, thousands of students stroll by ''Plain and Painted Parts,'' a mixed-media artwork that soars 65 feet high into the foyer connecting the three sections of the University of Connecticut's chemistry building. For many, the piece has come to blend into the scenery, the way a shrub or a streetlight can. Some people are paying attention, though. Steven L. Suib, the head of the university's department of chemistry, said he studies ''Plain and Painted Parts'' every day. He looks at the beakers, the spectrographs and the other scientific instruments incorporated into the work by the artist, Robert Cumming. Professor Suib, whose grandfather was a painter and sculptor, likes to view ''Plain and Painted Parts'' from various perches on the building's staircase, often spotting an element he previously missed.

JOE LOVANO is a jazz saxophonist at the peak of his powers. Seasoned enough at age 53 to have won a bucketful of awards, yet vigorous enough to be blowing as hard as ever, he spends most of the year performing in premier concert halls and clubs around the world and in the mecca of jazz, New York City. But come summer, Mr. Lovano puts on another hat: artistic director of the Caramoor Jazz Festival, a two-day event on a former estate in the Westchester village of Katonah. The festival is one of dozens of outdoor summer jazz events now dotting the New York suburbs that attract top players and programmers.

Because of a production error, an article on Page 68 of The Times Magazine today, about architecture in China, omits the last word. The last sentence should read, ''Maybe we will use it somewhere else.''

BITENSKY--Samson. My beloved Samson, my husband of 56 years. Guided by your wisdom, we embarked on a journey filled with accomplishments, success, and love. Not only were you my partner, but my best friend. I will always be your beautiful wife, and you will always be my handsome husband. You will always be in my heart, Halina $(6$)BITENSKY -- Samson. The Board of Trustees of Continuum Health Partners join with the medical staff and administration of Beth Israel Medical Center in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our beloved colleague, Samson Bitensky. In the 30 years that Samson served on the Beth Israel Board, he was a devoted supporter of many of the hospital's programs including cardiology, cancer, integrative medicine and ethics conferences. He also served with great distinction as Chair of the Finance Committee of the Board for many years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Halina, and their family and loved ones. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum David J. Shulkin, MD President and CEO Beth Israel $(6$)BITENSKY--Samson. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with sadness the passing of Samson Bitensky, an esteemed business leader and treasured friend. Samson, together with his beloved wife Halina, shared a deep commitment to humanitarian causes, enriching millions of lives through their generosity and dedication. That benevolence was also expressed through Samson's profound devotion to the Long Island Jewish community, where he served with distinction. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Halina; to their children: Beth, and her husband, Steven Myers; Susan, and her husband, Peter Lerner; to their grandchildren, and to their entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. $(6$)BITENSKY -- Samson. The Board, Associate Board, League, Administration and Staff of Parker Jewish Institute mourn the passing of Trustee Samson Bitensky. A renowned business leader and philanthropist, Samson Bitensky will always be remembered as an individual dedicated to improving the quality of later life. We offer our heartfelt condolences to wife, Halina, and the entire Bitensky family. Jerry Landsberg, Chairman of the Board Michael N. Rosenblut, President & CEO $(6$)BITENSKY -- Samson. Dear friend, gentleman, golfing companion. We will miss him. Our condolences to his wife, Halina, daughters Beth and Susan and their families. Cynthia and Bernie Mollod $(6$)BITENSKY--Samson. We remember a good friend over many years and mourn his passing. Richard Netter, President Thanks To Scandinavia

IN 1971 Marvin Stamm was, by his own admission, ''the most famous unknown trumpet player in America.'' ''Uncle Albert/Admiral Halsey,'' a song on the Paul and Linda McCartney album ''Ram,'' was No. 1 on the pop charts, with a brief memorable trumpet solo emanating from Mr. Stamm's horn. Indeed, the familiar riff (''da-rum-pum-pum-pah, rum-pum-pum-pah '') was heard so often then that few baby boomers would have trouble recognizing it today.

To the Editor: ''Adding More Urban to Suburbia'' (May 14) and other articles discuss problems that the Brooklyn-based developer Forest City Ratner is having imposing two ambitious proposals on well-organized communities in Brooklyn and Yonkers. In both cases, the people who will be most directly affected by the developer's proposals are demanding the right to shape the future of their neighborhoods and are mobilizing in creative ways to make their voices heard.

Thinking about the health and future of Long Island Sound calls to mind an old ''Far Side'' cartoon, the one where a dentist, having filled a patient's gaping jaws with a steely forest of braces, clamps, screws and straps, announces that he wants to insert a tennis ball, too, just to see if he can. About 20 million people live within 50 miles of the Sound, and it seems sometimes as if all of them at once are either putting something into it (sewage, fertilizer, pesticides, natural gas platforms) or taking something out (striped bass, flounder, clams, lobsters). Left to itself, the Sound would surely regain its footing as a stable, healthy ecosystem.

Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas casino impresario, and his wife, Elaine, may have the most expensive rent-stabilized home in the country. Wynn Las Vegas, the casino company that Mr. Wynn runs as chairman, decided this month not to raise the rent on the couple's ''villa suite'' at the resort for two more years, according to company filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Since July, the company has been charging them $580,000 a year, or almost $1,600 a day, for the suite, which overlooks the 18th hole of the resort's golf course. PATRICK McGEEHAN

JOE LOVANO is a jazz saxophonist at the peak of his powers. Seasoned enough at age 53 to boast a bucketful of awards, yet vigorous enough to be blowing as hard as ever, he spends most of the year performing in premier concert halls and clubs around the world and in the mecca of jazz, New York City. But come summer, Mr. Lovano puts on another hat: artistic director of the Caramoor Jazz Festival, a two-day event on a former estate in the village of Katonah, N.Y., in Westchester. The festival is one of dozens of outdoor summer jazz events now dotting the New York suburbs that attract top players and programmers.

IN a back room of a storage building at the Ballard Institute and Museum of Puppetry, dozens of puppets wrapped in white cloth bags hang from wooden rods in the dark. Surely, this is what the inside of a child's mind looks like. The Ballard museum is filled with all sorts of hidden treasures like that quiet back room, and because it has only five small rooms and a lobby for exhibitions, many of the Ballard's puppets remain hidden most of the time. But many of the finest and funniest puppets in the collection are on display in a 10th anniversary exhibition, ''Bits and Pieces.''

I am told that the Star Alliance has great deals on round-the-world fares. How can I get information on this? -- Y. J. Kim, Toms River, N.J. The three main airline alliances -- Star Alliance (www.staralliance.com, with 18 carriers, including United, Singapore, Lufthansa, Air New Zealand), Oneworld (www.oneworld.com, with 8 carriers, including American, British Airways and Qantas) and Skyteam.com (10 carriers, including Continental, Delta, Air France, KLM and Alitalia) -- offer round-the-world opportunities with a raft of options, based on the number of continents visited or miles traveled. Prices depend on itinerary (a Northern Hemisphere routing traveling east or west taking in Hong Kong, Singapore, Bangkok or Tokyo will cost about 30 percent less than a southern routing via Australia or the South Pacific) and the number of stopovers.

Chelsea Studio $549,000 MANHATTAN: 148 West 23rd Street (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), #4D A one-bath co-op. Richard Hamilton, Halstead Property (212) 381-6548; www.halstead.com MAINTENANCE: $976.74 a month PROS: The attractive sleeping nook of this approximately 520-square-foot co-op is a minimalist white box that is slightly raised above the floor and is open to the rest of the living space on one side. Sarah Joanna Mahurin and Gregory Clifton Padgett were married yesterday at the Club at Olde Stone, a private club in Bowling Green, Ky. The Rev. Jerry Patton, a Baptist minister, officiated. Mr. and Mrs. Padgett, both 26, are graduate students. She is a doctoral candidate in English and American literature at Yale and he recently completed his second year at Columbia law school. This month, he is to become a summer associate at Covington & Burling, the Washington law firm. The couple met during their last semester at Harvard, from which both graduated, she magna cum laude, he cum laude.

BRENT R. WILKES is quickly becoming a household name. Mr. Wilkes, a successful California defense contractor, is at the hub of corruption investigations stretching from Congress to the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Wilkes first emerged when he was identified as a co-conspirator in the case of Randy Cunningham, the former California Republican congressman who pleaded guilty to bribery. Prosecutors said Mr. Wilkes gave bribes for Mr. Cunningham's help in gaining federal contracts. Mr. Wilkes denies wrongdoing and has not been charged with any crimes.

ON a Saturday night last month, the producing director of the Fairfield Theater Company Stage One, Miles Marek, walked onstage before the group Professor Louie and the Crowmatix performed, and, as he usually does, asked the audience who was visiting the theater for the first time. About half of the nearly sold-out audience raised their hands. It was a pleasing response for Mr. Marek, a veteran actor and theatrical producer who is working to establish the 200-seat theater across from the Fairfield train station as a cultural center for Fairfield County.
A picture caption today with the Playlist column of CD reviews on Page 32 of Arts & Leisure misstates the surname of a performer. He is Johnny (Guitar) Watson, not Wilson.

SINGER--Paul. President and Chief Executive Officer of Paragon Honda, Paragon Acura, and White Plains Honda died quietly with his family at his side, on May 10, 2006, in Westchester, NY. Mr. Singer died from complications due to cancer; he was 72 years of age. As a devoted husband, father and grandfather he leaves behind a legacy of accomplishments and achievements earned with an unparallel combination of dignity, drive and respect for all of those around him. Mr. Singer was a Holocaust survivor, a veteran of the Korean War, an entrepreneur, a marathon runner, and a collector of antique automobiles; his son said appropriately, at his father's funeral service, ''My Father embodied the American Dream.'' His eloquent speech, his elegant touch, mixed with his iron willed determination earned him the nickname the ''silk hammer.'' Perhaps his greatest gift of all was his ability to cause ordinary people to conduct themselves in extraordinary ways, using encouragement, thoughtfulness, and selflessness as his tools. Mr Singer is survived by his wife Edith, two daughters, Michelle and Karen and his son Cory. Other surviving family members include his sisters Susan and Katherine, and his six grandchildren Anna, Lauren, Danielle, Julian, Isaac, and Samuel.

Jesse James knows a nice ride. His company, West Coast Choppers, makes stylized motorcycles for those who can afford them. James's renegade style and expertise (which no doubt attracted his wife, Sandra Bullock) are the focus of the television show ''Monster Garage.'' His biker clothing lines, L.A. burger joint and Memorial Day TV special -- he rebuilds a Hummer with American troops in Iraq -- suggest a life at full throttle. So how many vehicles do you have? Between 30 and 50. The best ride you ever took? 2,700 miles across Mexico. We started in El Paso and went down through Chihuahua and Hermosillo. Most important thing to pack? Your cellphone. That's all you need. Where would you like to travel next? Home today in my '54 Chevy. Sounds weird and unspectacular, but I just dig riding one of my cars or bikes along the beach. Madhu Puri

France and China will be dancing partners when the New York City Ballet presents the premiere of JEAN-PIERRE BONNEFOUX's ''TWO BIRDS WITH THE WINGS OF ONE'' on Thursday night (repeated on Saturday night) as part of its Diamond Project festival of new works. Mr. Bonnefoux, a French-born former principal dancer with the company, has chosen two other French-born dancers, SOFIANE SYLVE and SÉBASTIEN MARCOVICI, to lead an ensemble of six men and six women. But Mr. Bonnefoux is setting everyone dancing to scores by a Chinese-born composer, BRIGHT SHENG: ''Two Songs From the Sung Dynasty,'' to be performed in Chinese by the soprano LAUREN FLANAGAN, and an instrumental piece, ''Chi Lin's Dance.'' Mr. Sheng was recently appointed the troupe's first resident composer, and this will be an opportunity to get to know his music. At 8, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500 or www.nycballet.com; $20 to $86.. Africa will also be dancing in Brooklyn. DANCEAFRICA, the annual festival that is always one of spring's brightest events, opens Friday night with an African bazaar in the street and lots of vibrant dancing onstage. Four groups exemplify how African traditions spread throughout the world. PERÚ NEGRO features the dance and music of black Peru, including pieces for percussion instruments that evolved from the wooden crates that slaves once used to preserve their outlawed rhythms. The UNIVERSAL AFRICAN DANCE AND DRUM ENSEMBLE offers acrobatic and martial-arts pieces. The BAM/RESTORATION DANCEAFRICA ENSEMBLE allows young people to participate in the preservation of the African heritage. And the CREATIVE OUTLET DANCE THEATER OF BROOKLYN combines dance and poetry. Friday at 7:30 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., May 28 at 3 p.m., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100 or www.bam.org; $20 to $45 (half price for children 16 and under).

HERLES--Jeffrey Joseph, 46. Passed away May 7 in Santa Fe, NM. Survived by parents Anthony and Barbara, brothers Chris and Andrew, friends and family who loved him. Financier, composer, vocalist, raconteur, wit, Jeff's interests and talents were many. A memorial concert of his music is planned for a later date.

No, that isn't the sun glinting off Mariah Carey's toe ring. It's the sparkling Carrara marble powder that stands in for sand at the Monte-Carlo Beach Hotel and Club. Forty tons of the sugary white stuff is trucked in from Italy in April and then raked until it looks as if it could be sniffed by confused jet-setters. ''You don't see beaches made of marble powder very often; it's too expensive,'' says Danièle Siri, the general manager. Which probably explains why luxury lovers like Tara Reid and Paris Hilton have lounged there, sipping the club cocktail: a mojito hybrid made with (what else?) Champagne. SANDRA BALLENTINE

IT could have been a keg party or a hipper-than-usual church social: As 80 guests parked bumper to bumper along the main drag of tiny Haddam, Conn., one Saturday night last month, couples clambered out of cars carrying covered potluck dishes and six-packs. Some congregated around cars while they sipped from plastic cups, while others followed a flashlight-waving attendant toward the back door of a 19th-century church. Once inside, they handed their casserole dishes to the evening's gray-haired but youthful host, John Friedlander, a real estate agent.

Thank you for Russell Shorto's great article (May 7). As an 18-year-old, I have gone through three years of sex education in high school -- everything from condoms to abstinence. As a pro-lifer, I have never felt offended by anything taught in the class. The point is, we are getting the information we need to make an informed decision. I see nothing wrong with the safe-sex and no-sex choices being taught in the same presentation. I felt physically sick when I readKimberly Zenarolla's comment that ''by using contraception, they [the couple] are not allowing the fullness of their expression of love.'' Take this comment and insert the words: ''By wearing a seat belt, the experience of driving is lessened.'' Doesn't make much sense, does it? Rachel Zsamboky Washington, Pa.

RIORDAN--Robert E., 76. Died on May 12, 2006 of a heart attack near his home in Lighthouse Point, Florida. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Mary Anne, their three children, Kathleen, Timothy and Robert Jr., ten grandchildren, and his sister, Nancy Riordan. After graduating college, traveling the world on a Merchant Marine ship, and serving in the United States Army Intelligence, Mr. Riordan had a long and successful career in the magazine publishing industry. He began as a copywriter in the circulation department of Gentleman's Quarterly Magazine and stayed with the magazine when it was purchased by Conde Nast. He later moved to the circulation department at Newsweek Magazine where he rose to VP/Circulation. He left Newsweek to form his own publishing consulting firm and subsequently started Family Media, Inc., a magazine publishing company that, at its peak, published 12 consumer titles including Ladies' Home Journal, Savvy, World Tennis, Discover, and 1,001 Home Ideas. An avid runner, Mr. Riordan ran five marathons during his lifetime with his first in 1981 at the age of 51. His personal best in the New York Marathon was a finish time of 2:57:56. He will be missed and will be remembered as a man with huge ideas and a huge heart. A Mass celebrating his life will be held on Friday, May 26, 2006 at the Church of St. John & St. Mary in Chappaqua, NY at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

A lot of executives love their BlackBerries, but Bill McDermott seems to have taken this devotion to a new level. For Mr. McDermott, the president and chief executive of SAP Americas, the business software provider, leaving his BlackBerry at the office is out of the question. ''I never throw the BlackBerry away,'' said Mr. McDermott, 44. ''I would be more stressed if I didn't use it.''

The exhibition no modern art fan should miss this summer opens on Friday at the Guggenheim Museum. ''NO LIMITS, JUST EDGES: JACKSON POLLOCK PAINTINGS ON PAPER'' will present almost 70 of the approximately 700 works on paper produced by this pioneering Abstract Expressionist. The show tracks the evolution of Pollock's art from drawings and paintings of human and imaginary beings in the middle to late 30's, through increasingly abstract symbolic works in the 40's, to the totally nonrepresentational paintings made by dripping, pouring and splattering. 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Sept. 29. Meanwhile a major exhibition of new paintings by the German Neo-Expressionist ANSELM KIEFER opens on Saturday at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. In keeping with Mr. Kiefer's penchant for the big statement, the show is titled ''VELIMIR CHLEBNIKOV'' after a visionary leader and thinker of the pre-World War II Russian avant-garde, and it consists of a suite of 30 paintings displayed in an outdoor steel pavilion designed by Mr. Kiefer. 258 Main Street, Ridgefield, Conn., (203) 438-4519, through Oct. 1. For something on the lighter side consider the eccentrically humorous drawings and watercolors by the musician and actor JOHN LURIE at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center. Made in a sophisticated, faux-primitive style, Mr. Lurie's creations in ''Works on Paper'' are like pages from a demented children's book in which dark, angry, often sexual adult preoccupations leak through the charmingly juvenile and often richly sensuous surfaces. Many are laugh-out-loud funny, like the one in which a dog tells his master, ''I am your dog, but I am not your friend.'' 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, through Aug. 14.

To the Editor: ''In Case of Disaster, Have a Backup for Your PC'' (May 14) was an important reminder of the dangers of not saving data in a separate place. Clearly, external hard drives are attractive because of their capacity and recently reduced prices, while CD's and DVD's are easy to burn and transport and are relatively inexpensive. I also use a laptop to keep a current mirror of the PC that contains most of my data. (And don't forget that the database in a hand-held wireless device can be a backup, too.)

COLLEGE campuses can be good neighbors. At their best they are cultural beacons in the suburbs, a place where the arts flourish in communities that otherwise may not be able to support them. The visual arts are a prime example. There are more than two dozen galleries and museums tucked away on campuses in the New York suburbs. They are a varied lot, characterized partly by the wealth of the school and the generosity of alumni and partly by the kind of art they display.

The Mets have called up reliever Anderson Garcia from Class AAA Norfolk, but that move will not help fill the void in their starting rotation. Willie Randolph, the Mets' manager, indicated yesterday that the club is leaning toward promoting Alay Soler from Class AA Binghamton to replace starting pitcher José Lima, who was designated for assignment Friday night.

If you build it, they will eat it. But in the case of some of the most impressive -- and even basic -- dishes, the architecture is flimsy at best. Among the most feared kitchen failures are fallen soufflés, broken sauces, polarized vinaigrettes and molten baked Alaskas. All are items that require a solid foundation, a meticulously followed blueprint and dogged optimism -- or an unshakable ego. But do try them at home. The building blocks to the shakiest classics follow. The ego is up to you.

For those who wish to declare themselves fashion winners, Jessica Grindstaff's witty prize-ribbon brooches add a stylish touch to any lapel, shoulder, belt loop or pocketbook strap. The classic satin rosettes with dangling ribbon tails ($154 to $220 at www.ravinstyle.com) are made from vintage satin ribbons and come in an assortment of colors and sizes from a 2-inch rosette with a 3-inch tail to a giant 5-inch rosette with a 7-inch tail. The difference lies dead center, where Ms. Grindstaff attaches whimsical gold or silver charms of creatures like a dog, a bee, a loping horse or a coiled snake.

To the Editor: It has been clearly established that Type 2 diabetes is a lifestyle disease. Sedentary lifestyle and poor nutritional choices, grounded in an excess intake of saturated fats, refined carbohydrates and fast foods, are clearly the major contributing factors.

To the Editor: In ''Bratislava: Discovering Time Travel in Slovakia's Capital'' (Next Stop, May 7), Andrew Ferren overlooks a pertinent fact. Until territorial rearrangements were made after World War I, the city was an important urban center of the Kingdom of Hungary, respectively called Pozsony and Pressburg by its Hungarian and German-speaking population. Examples of Bratislava's Hungarian past -- from the Middle Ages to the turn of the 20th century -- abound. St. Martin's Cathedral, for example, became Hungary's coronation church during the Ottoman occupation of Budapest. A replica of the Crown of St. Steven, Hungary's first king, graces the spire. Eleven Hapsburg monarchs were crowned there as kings, or queen in the case of Maria Theresa of Hungary.

Because of an editing error, the Jersey column last Sunday about the expanding role of supermarkets gave an incorrect location for a ShopRite with a beauty salon and a liquor store. It is in Oakland, N.J., not Oakland, Calif.

To the Sports Editor: Alan Schwarz's ''The Weather Was Fine, and the Homers Were Easy'' (May 14) provided some scientific perspective on the spate of home runs in the major leagues during April. Perhaps the article grants us some perspective on larger issues as well. If a team of meteorologists, ecologists and sports statisticians were to bend their talents to the task, we might find that Barry Bonds's remarkable achievements at the plate were not about performance-enhancing drugs, but rather an indirect result of global warming. William Bennett Foster City, Calif.
Being seen reading one of these glossies at the beach or on the jitney is the equivalent of posting a really intriguing Nerve.com profile. CHRISTOPHER ISENBERG
The Market Week column on May 7 misstated the effect of a weakening dollar on the price of imports. They tend to become more expensive for American shoppers, not cheaper.

COHEN--Edith. Formerly of Manhattan, NY, died in New London, CT. Born May 27, 1921 to Charles and Dorothy Ehrlich Cohen of Brooklyn, predeceased by a sister Helen Coburne. She was a career special education teacher at PS 121 Manhattan, and a summer counselor at Camp Waterford in Quaker Hill, CT. Contributions may be made to Waterford Country School, 78 Hunts Brook Rd, Quaker Hill, CT 06375. Neilan Funeral Home of New London, CT.
PALTER--Richard D. Born October 17, 1927. Died May 13, 2006. Dick, your voyage is over. The last years were rough, but the Lord will give you peace and no pain forever more. Godspeed. Buddy

To the Editor: In her review of ''Death in the Haymarket,'' by James Green (May 7), Louise W. Knight says that ''this stunning historical event . . . has been relatively neglected by historians,'' and notes that only three full-length histories have been written on the subject. She might also have mentioned ''Haymarket: A Novel,'' a remarkable book by Martin Duberman, a distinguished professor at the graduate center of the City University of New York, which was published in 2004. Martha Crotty Cincinnati

BECKER--Gloria, known professionally as Gloria Spitz, died peacefully May 18, 2006 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in NYC. Devoted wife of over fifty years to Abraham Becker, beloved mother of Richard & Steven Becker, loving mother-in-law of Carri Joy Becker & Emily Mitchell Becker & cherished grandmother (Nana) of James, Lily, Ian, Charles & Scott Becker. Sister of Bernice Gibber. Born in Bronx, NY, Gloria graduated from Abraham Lincoln High School & Cornell University. Gloria served on the Board of Directors of the Gerber Baby Foods Company for 18 years, until its acquisition by Sandoz (now known as Novartis). During her tenure, Gloria rotated on all Board committees and chaired the Management and Development and Compensation Committees. Gloria ended her illustrious public relations career as a Senior Vice President at BursonMarsteller. Among other positions, Gloria served as Editor-in-Chief of Forecast Magazine and edited the Food and Appliance section of the magazine, Living for Young Homemakers. Funeral Sunday, May 21, at 11 AM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (at 91 Street). In lieu of flowers, donations may be mailed to the ''Gloria Spitz Becker Memorial Fund'' at Cornell University Development, 130 East Seneca Street, Suite 400, Ithaca, New York 14850.

WEINREB--Sylvia. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed colleague and friend Rabbi Dr. Tzvi Hersh Weinreb, Executive VP of The UOJCA. May the Weinreb family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Harold Tanner, Chairman and Malcolm Hoenlein Executive Vice-Chairmen

Where: Leksand, Sweden. What: Midsummer festival, celebrating the longest day in sun-starved Sweden. Leksanders put up a 25-meter (roughly 82-foot) maypole and perform steps like the ''small frogs'' dance, and fiddlers play traditional music. When: June 23. The vibe: ''Dancing Queen'' meets paganism. Before you go: Study the words to the Swedish national anthem, ''Du gamla, Du fria''; you'll sing it when the maypole is raised. Where to stay: Akerblads Hotell och Gastgiveri in Tallberg boasts of a very un-Ikea traditional feel. Go to www.akerblads-tallberg.se. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

Getting to the beach can be a pedestrian affair, but a great car will get you there in style. Don't want to spend a fortune? No problem -- these rental companies let you drive some of the world's most expensive cars for a nice price. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

COLLEGE campuses can be good neighbors. At their best they are cultural beacons in the suburbs, a place where the arts flourish in communities that otherwise may not be able to support them. The visual arts are a prime example. There are more than two dozen galleries and museums tucked away on campuses in the New York suburbs. They are a varied lot, characterized partly by the wealth of the school and the generosity of alumni and partly by the kind of art they display.

Venetian mosaics decorate the walls and ceilings of countless churches and palazzi -- and now the guest rooms of the tiny Domus Orsoni hotel, located in the Orsoni family's villa and workshop in Venice's Cannaregio district. With only five rooms, it was opened two years ago by Lucio Orsoni, whose relatives have been making tile for more than a century; their mosaics decorate Sacré Coeur in Paris and the Sagrada Familia Church by Gaudi in Barcelona. Guests can tour the foundry or immerse themselves in one- or two-week classes. You can sign up with Giovanni Cucco, who has been overseeing mosaic restoration at the Basilica for 27 years and leads private tours DEGEN PENER

Bombing in Gaza Wounds Palestinian Official The Palestinian intelligence chief, Maj. Gen. Tareq Abu Rajab, was badly wounded in a bombing in Gaza City that killed his nephew and wounded eight other people. Later in Gaza, the Israeli military fired missiles that killed a commander of the Islamic Jihad and three other Palestinians.
