To the Sports Editor: There are safe ski resorts all over the world, but some of us seek a high from putting ourselves in places man should not be. This is what keeps us sane. We live only when we are going to the mountains, when we are in the mountains or when we are planning to go to the mountains.

There were so many issues raised in Russell Shorto's article that I almost don't know where to begin. Your recent article on the criminalization of abortion in El Salvador was so disturbing. But to think that someday soon that might be happening in the United States is just something I cannot fathom. What I find particularly frightening about this is the politicizing of what are deeply personal issues. Fran Schreiber Brooklyn Heights

The American orchestral scene has seemed volatile of late, with lots of changings of the guard: new music directors, departing general managers and so on. The PITTSBURGH SYMPHONY was part of this trend last season, when it announced the replacement of its music director, Mariss Jansons, with a triumvirate (Andrew Davis, Yan Pascal Tortelier and Marek Janowski). For its Carnegie concert this week, however, the orchestra is going with the tried and true: the star conductor CHRISTOPH VON DOHNANYI, who has served as music director in Cleveland but never in Pittsburgh. Mr. Dohnanyi's acute, precise music making may be a contrast to Mr. Jansons's more expressive approach, but it's like comparing different kinds of caviar. The program includes Bartok, Haydn and Tchaikovsky's ''Pathétique.'' Tuesday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $26 to $89. One keeps coming back to the Metropolitan Museum's interesting ''PIANO FORTE'' series, featuring strong pianists in a rather intricately conceived group of concerts involving three different pianos and three different pairings of composers. Finishing off the season is Bach and Brahms in the capable hands of FREDERIC CHIU, who offers a kind of understated virtuosity that serves the music more than the performer (a good thing), and whose Bach is particularly fine. Thursday at 8 p.m., (212) 570-3939; $40. Left to my own devices, I might check out the EDGAR MEYER YOUNG ARTISTS CONCERT to hear what Mr. Meyer, the versatile classical-bluegrass bass player and composer, can achieve with a group of young fiddlers, classical violinists, cellists and even a dobro player. Sunday at 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall; $15. Or, expanding my horizons still further, I might take in the final concert of the ''NEW SOUNDS LIVE'' series at Merkin Concert Hall, which has covered everything from Meredith Monk to Bang on a Can, and which this week presents two new-music groups the series calls ''post-rock,'' RACHEL'S and CLOGS. Thursday at 8 p.m., 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 501-3330; $20.

JOE LOVANO is a jazz saxophonist at the peak of his powers. Seasoned enough at age 53 to boast a bucketful of awards, yet vigorous enough to be blowing as hard as ever, he spends most of the year performing in premier concert halls and clubs around the world and in the mecca of jazz, New York City. But come summer, Mr. Lovano puts on another hat: artistic director of the Caramoor Jazz Festival, a two-day event on a former estate in the village of Katonah. The festival is one of dozens of outdoor summer jazz events now dotting the New York suburbs that attract top players and programmers.

Kristen Shay Hogan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Hogan of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Geoffrey Brian Doyle, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Doyle of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. Daniel O'Reilly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection. The couple met at Columbia, from which each received an M.B.A.

A listing on Page 16 of the Book Review today includes an incomplete name for an author and historian who was a judge in an informal survey to name the single best work of American fiction published in the last 25 years. He is Richard Gid Powers. (The novelist Richard Powers was not among the judges.)

Could Joe Lieberman lose to netroots candidate Ned Lamont in Connecticut's Aug. 8 Democratic primary? The Hotline On Call blog says it's possible: Capturing one-third of the delegates at the state party convention last week means that Lamont's run will mean "a real primary race for Joe Lieberman, one that he might lose, against a[sic] extremely well-funded, ideologically dedicated challenger."

Investors and analysts on Monday seemed to take a cautious -- bordering on skeptical -- stance toward the New York Stock Exchange's $10.2 billion offer to buy its European counterpart Euronext on Monday. The extent of the deal's benefits for the N.Y.S.E. was not completely clear, but the potential risks to N.Y.S.E.'s rivals seemed obvious enough.

The half-hour speech included references to the Beverly Hillbillies, Shakespeare and Yogi Berra as well as dozens of statistics. And Mr. Paterson, who is legally blind, did it all by memory.

Stock options awarded to top executives at five companies, including KLA-Tencor and Boston Communications, showed an unusual tendency of being granted just before a runup in the underlying stock, according to an analysis by The Wall Street Journal published on Monday. The findings follow up on a similar analysis conducted by the Journal in March. That research identified six companies, all of which now face government investigations.
Colin South recently raised $4 million in funding for his sapling company, Mascoma, which is developing a system to liquefy plants and trees into ethanol.

BankAtlantic Bancorp expects to begin a share buyback plan in the next month, Chairman and C.E.O. Alan Levan said. The Fort Lauderdale-based company on May 3 announced a plan to repurchase up to 6 million of its 57 million shares of Class A common stock.

Rosneft's I.P.O., which could come as early as July, has been billed by the company and the Russian government as the deal of the century. The sale of 49 percent of Rosneft's shares is expected to raise as much as $20 billion.

William Dean Singleton, the maverick chief executive of the MediaNews Group, is thought of as something of a magician in the newspaper world - having transformed himself from the son of a ranch hand in a tiny town in Texas to a media baron who now controls a newspaper empire that sprawls from coast to coast. He has, in a manner of speaking, sawed many of his competitors in half, only to have them hop off the table and become his partners.
Wachovia Securities has hired two former J.P. Morgan Chase executives to direct the company's media and communications investment-banking group.
WashingtonFirst Bank, taking an aggressive expansion step just two years after it was founded, agreed to purchase First Liberty Bank yesterday.

Alexander Vik, the rebel shareholder in Vivendi, has approached Vodafone, the British mobile phone giant, and Lagardère, the French media group, to try to persuade them join his audacious attempt to break up the 35 billion euro ($44.6 billion) French telecoms and media conglomerate.

Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Saturday, 22 May 1784: 29 8/10; 63, 66 1/2; NE, SE. Cloudless, sun & gale, golden evening. Columbines, & Monkshood blow. Lapwings on the down. Began to tack up the vine-shoots. Men bring-up peat from the forest. The sycamores, & maples in bloom scent the air with a honeyed smell. Lily of the valley blows.

Fourteen people were injured after a fire broke out on the second floor of a six-story apartment building early yesterday. Three people were in critical condition at Jacobi Medical Center with injuries from smoke inhalation. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries. The fire, at 1181 East Tremont Avenue, started about 1 a.m. and was brought under control 45 minutes later. Angela Vitalo, 36, who lives in an apartment on the third floor, said her father, Ernesto Hernandez, 75, had collapsed in the stairwell when trying to return there for some clothing. Firefighters carried him out, and he was in a coma yesterday afternoon. Ercida Guerrero, 67, and her granddaughter, Mary Suarez, 14, were also in critical condition, according to a hospital spokesman. A 2-year-old child was in fair condition, the police said. Ms. Guerrero's son, William Guerrero, 38, said they had been trapped behind the press of people trying to go down the stairs. Firefighters helped other elderly residents and a 6-year-old boy escape.

A 19-year-old man was fatally shot shortly after midnight yesterday after a dispute in Hamilton Heights, the police said. There were no arrests. The shooting occurred in front of 104 West 144th Street, the police said, and the victim, Kelly Rush of West 143rd Street, was taken to Harlem Hospital Center and pronounced dead about 2 a.m. Mr. Rush was the youngest of eight children, said his father, David Parks, 73.

The size of classes in the city's public schools should not be an issue put on the ballot in November, a judge ruled on Friday in State Supreme Court. In upholding a decision by the city's corporation counsel, Justice Lewis Bart Stone found that the city's voters lacked the power under state law to force Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to allocate money to reducing the size of classes. A group known as New Yorkers for Smaller Classes had challenged the city's decision and started a campaign to build public support for smaller class sizes. The group said it would appeal the latest ruling. The mayor has supported reducing class sizes, but he said last July,

The police are seeking a man who has been robbing restaurant delivery workers at knifepoint. In four robberies in Manhattan, The New York Post reported, the man has ordered food and then asked for change for a $100 bill. In the first three, the robber lured deliverymen into vacant apartments. In the most recent case, the he met a deliveryman in the lobby of 115 West 85th Street about 8:50 p.m. on Saturday, took him to the basement and robbed him at knifepoint, the police said.

A Bronx man was charged yesterday after a car chase Saturday on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive that included a collision with a patrol car, the police said. The defendant, Thomas Mathurin, 24, of Boynton Avenue, was charged with attempted murder and vehicular assault, the police said. After the police stopped him near East 44th Street about 11:10 a.m. on Saturday, the police said, Mr. Mathurin made a U-turn and drove north in the southbound lanes. One officer fired at the car, which continued north until it stopped at East 74th Street after colliding with a police car, the police said.
Dr. Lee Jong Wook had a blood clot on the brain known as a subdural hematoma removed and will be hospitalized "for some time."

VERDICT WATCH Jurors in the criminal trial of Enron's former chief executives, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, began deliberations last week and are to resume them today. The jurors are reviewing 28 charges of fraud, conspiracy and insider trading against Mr. Skilling and 6 charges of fraud and conspiracy against Mr. Lay. The two men face decades in prison if convicted on all charges.

BENTELE--Max. Age 97, died May 19, 2006. A pioneer of the jet age, Dr. Bentele made major contributions to the development of reciprocating, rotary and gas turbine engines, including the Wankel engine. He will be long remembered for advancing the status of engineers and promoting innovation in engine design. He is survived by three daughters, Rose-Marie Klipstein of Rochester, NY, Ursula Tenny and Brigitte Bentele, both of NYC, five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the First Presbyterian Church of Fairfield, 2475 Easton Turnpike, Fairfield, CT 06432.
To the Editor: As an undergraduate, I see fellow students cheating all the time, often without any remorse at all.

TURCHIANO--Frank. Nearly 90. On May 20, 2006, at home in Port Washington, NY. My father, a man of ceaseless curiosity, perseverance, and accomplishment, triumphed over severe adversity and went on to make many people happy, including himself. A memorial service will be held soon at the Congregational Church of Manhasset. Please call for details, 516627-4911. Francesca Turchiano, Always a Daddy's Girl

In his newest film, ''Climates,'' a portrait of a man profoundly out of touch with his innermost self, the Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan has made one of the finest films to play the festival in competition. (His last film at Cannes, ''Distant,'' won the grand prize in 2003.) The exquisitely observed story opens with a man and a woman just minutes away from a brutal breakup, only to shift focus to the man, a professor played by the director himself. Using a minimum of naturalistic dialogue and breathtaking compositions, and featuring a rollicking sex scene that kept the press audience in rapt silence, Mr. Ceylan renders a psychological portrait from the outside in, slowly, slowly, digging his way into a heart of stone. MANOHLA DARGIS

Sometimes I don't get Ray Nagin, so it's all right.'' MAYOR C. RAY NAGIN, of New Orleans, asked what he would say to those who were surprised at his re-election on Saturday. [A18]

RIORDAN--Robert E., 76. Died on May 12, 2006 of a heart attack near his home in Lighthouse Point, Florida. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Mary Anne, their three children, Kathleen, Timothy and Robert Jr., ten grandchildren, and his sister, Nancy Riordan. After graduating college, traveling the world on a Merchant Marine ship, and serving in the United States Army Intelligence, Mr. Riordan had a long and successful career in the magazine publishing industry. He began as a copywriter in the circulation department of Gentleman's Quarterly Magazine and stayed with the magazine when it was purchased by Conde Nast. He later moved to the circulation department at Newsweek Magazine where he rose to VP/Circulation. He left Newsweek to form his own publishing consulting firm and subsequently started Family Media, Inc., a magazine publishing company that, at its peak, published 12 consumer titles including Ladies' Home Journal, Savvy, World Tennis, Discover, and 1,001 Home Ideas. An avid runner, Mr. Riordan ran five marathons during his lifetime with his first in 1981 at the age of 51. His personal best in the New York Marathon was a finish time of 2:57:56. He will be missed and will be remembered as a man with huge ideas and a huge heart. A Mass celebrating his life will be held on Friday, May 26, 2006 at the Church of St. John & St. Mary in Chappaqua, NY at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

SORRENTINO--Gilbert. Died on May 18, in Brooklyn, at 77, of cancer. Novelist, poet, critic, and teacher, husband of Victoria, father of Jesse, Christopher, and the late Delia, grandfather of James, Violet & Penelope. A memorial service will be held later this year. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the PEN Writers' Fund.

Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, who is heading the national Democratic effort to capture the United States Senate this year, has signed a book deal, the senator's office announced on Sunday. Mr. Schumer said he was writing about what he contends is the failure by both Republicans and Democrats to articulate a vision of government that addresses contemporary concerns.

''Why is sex on film necessarily pornographic?'' wondered John Cameron Mitchell (best known for directing and starring in ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch''). He was sitting on the terrace of the Hotel Majestic just after his new film, ''Shortbus,'' had been screened for the press. It had achieved a certain notoriety in the indie film world before it was even cast, and Mr. Mitchell had long since tired of hearing it referred to, leeringly, as his ''porno movie.''

The United States will hold a joint military exercise using naval, army and air forces with Turkey next week aimed at demonstrating a determination to stop missile and nuclear technology from reaching Iran and other countries, Bush administration officials said Sunday. The officials said the exercise was part of a three-year effort known as the Proliferation Security Initiative, under which the United States and cooperating countries carry out military and naval exercises to interdict nuclear materials and contraband.

CRAWFORD -- John Hum phrey III. Died on May 16th of complications from ALS. Originally from Short Hills, New Jersey, ''Tex'' graduated from the Pingry School and Lehigh, and received an MBA from NYU. He was an officer in the Marine Corps and served in Vietnam. He is survived by his beloved Jane Matilda Pflug, his two children, John H. Crawford IV ''Scott'' of Eugene, Oregon and Lynne Adair Crawford of Portsmouth, New Hampshire, as well as his sister, Allyson Crawford Louthan of Kewswick, Virginia. ''Tex'' was an enthusiastic member of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the ALS Association, Greater New York Chapter, 116 John Street, Suite 1304, New York, New York 10038.

Expedia, Seattle, the travel Web site operator, placed its account in review after working for seven years with the Marina del Rey, Calif., office of Deutsch, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Spending last year was estimated at $170 million. Deutsch, which has handled the account since Expedia began, said it would not take part in the review. Harvard Business School named MMB, Boston, to help market its executive education and alumni relations programs. Spending has not been determined. The school had worked with various agencies on a project basis.

KRACH--William Robert. 83. A man of integrity and humor. Bill died peacefully at home with his Ellie by his side on May 20. Bill was a singer, vocal coach, and performed in many original Broadway productions including ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' ''My Fair Lady,'' and ''High Spirits.'' He leaves his loving and devoted companion of 35 years, Elinor Weiler Krach, stepdaughters, Ellen McCoy and Mary Wright, and stepson Roger Schachtel. He was a friend of Bill W. Funeral private; however, a gathering to honor Bill's life will be held Wednesday, May 24, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, from 6-8 pm. In lieu of flowers contributions to Bide-a-Wee Animal Shelter, 410 E. 38 St, NYC 10016.

Scott Walker ''The Drift'' (4AD) Scott Walker has a voice made for drama: a long-breathed baritone with a cultivated vibrato that sounds both virile and ghostly. It made him a pop star when he proclaimed a monumentally orchestrated despair in the 1966 Walker Brothers hit ''The Sun Ain't Gonna Shine Anymore.'' He moved from Los Angeles to London, where the Walker Brothers -- not his brothers and not his last name, Engel -- became pop idols for a few years. There he embarked on his own increasingly idiosyncratic songwriting career: from pop-rock to singing Jacques Brel to what can only, and incompletely, be called art songs.

Growing up poor, I saw my mother skip meals. I saw my father pawn everything he loved. I saw our cars repossessed. I never saw France or London. I didn't even see an airplane up close until I was a senior in high school and won an Al Neuharth-sponsored trip. The older I get, though, the more I appreciate not having money. Working as a journalist in Mississippi for a handful of years, I found my past connected me to so many people. Crafting racially charged stories, I saw myself in the eyes of interviewed after interviewed. No, I didn't know what it was like to be perceived as scary because my melanin shaded me darker. But I knew what it was like to wear out-of-style clothes and want the shoes and cooler lunches that others had. As a lesbian, I knew what it was like to feel out of place.

CBS won the concluding Friday of the official television season in Nielsen's estimates. Its season finale of ''Numbers'' (12.49 million) was the night's most-watched show. Another returning CBS crime show, ''Close to Home'' (9.64 million), also ended its season. For the week that ended on May 14, USA Network's ''WWE Monday Night Raw'' topped the list of the most-watched shows on basic cable, with 5.42 million viewers. But TNT's playoff basketball coverage put that channel in first place in prime time overall among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. In that age group, wrestling and basketball, also on ESPN, occupied 8 of the top 10 slots for the week. The two entertainment shows that nudged their way in were the May 9 ''Real World'' (1.83 million 18-to-49-year-olds) on MTV and the Discovery Channel's ''Deadliest Catch'' (1.61 million 18-to-49-year-olds), also on May 9. KATE AURTHUR

To the Editor: In my 35 years as a teacher at both an Ivy League and a public college, I caught many plagiarists and reported them to the authorities. As far as I know, not one of these students was ever seriously sanctioned.

Yo Gotti ''Back 2 da Basics'' (TVT Records) Yo Gotti is a shiny-toothed, crime-obsessed Southern rapper who has yet to score a big hit. But he does have a rabid local fan base in Memphis, along with one of hip-hop's richest drawls. His sing-song rhymes tumble out in a lispy blur of squelched consonants, shape-shifting vowels and agile rhythms.
To the Editor: Re ''Colleges Chase as Cheats Shift to Higher Tech'' (front page, May 18):

To the Editor: ''Judges Should Police Themselves'' (editorial, May 18) is right. A judicial inspector general to investigate sitting federal judges, an idea being considered by Congress, would threaten judicial independence.

Pedro Almodóvar's new film, ''Volver'' -- in English the title means ''To Return'' -- is aptly titled, since in recent years this director has been a regular visitor to Cannes. Filmmakers are frequently venerated here, but Mr. Almodóvar, 55, inspires a special kind of affection. His shock of vertical hair is mostly gray, and he retains a boyish sweetness and openness of spirit, delighting in the warm response of the audience and the critics, who were themselves mainly delighted with ''Volver.'' (If the festival ended today, and there were a democratic election rather than a jury trial, he would be a shoo-in for the Palme d'Or).
To the Editor: Re ''As Death Stalks Iraq, Middle-Class Exodus Begins'' (front page, May 19):

An article in Business Day on Friday about Dell's quarterly earnings referred imprecisely to a preliminary statement by the company on May 8. While Dell said in the statement that its earnings this quarter would be 33 cents a share, it did not announce the profit figure, $762 million, until Thursday.

To the Editor: Why are students taking tests in which cheating is even relevant? In today's information age, where a body of information in all but the narrowest of fields is beyond anyone's ability to master, why aren't colleges teaching students how to research, organize and evaluate the information that is out there?
To the Editor: Re ''Conservative Christians Warn Republicans Against Inaction'' (front page, May 15):
If I was on a trip with Nicholas Kristof, the first day might look like this: Kigali, Rwanda-

I'm the kid that's not supposed to get this. This is a shot in the dark that I'm hoping will yield results. Then again, that is sort of how I live my life. Let me explain. Anyone who knows me, knows that I go big or I go home. It's sort of the mantra of my life. For example, I stumbled into stand up comedy earlier last year and decided to test the waters. I skipped the open mics at the hole in the wall bars; I skipped practicing my routine in front of familiar friends and faces. Instead, I flew to LA and hit the stage at the Improv and The Laugh Factory. My friends couldn't believe that I had the wherewithal to get on stage at such renowned comedy institutions and contend with the professionals. I have to admit, sashaying past pictures of comedic geniuses such as Robin Williams, Tim Allen, and Jay Leno made me a little nervous. As I attempted to steady my heart before the host said my name, I scribbled a reminder at the top of my notes that a mentor had said along the way, "Never be afraid to succeed." With that, I jumped on stage. I was swimming with the big fishes and I had a blast doing it. If you're looking for someone to make you laugh, don't pick me, it didn't go very well. Just kidding, it went great.

Johnny Cash ''Personal File'' (Columbia/Legacy) At various times from 1973 to 1982 Johnny Cash recorded favorite songs in his studio, singing alone with his guitar. A clutch of these, the earliest, were conceived as a proper record, but he couldn't find a label to release it.

9 P.M. (VH1) HEAVY: THE STORY OF METAL -- It's loud. It's ugly. And for millions of hearing-impaired fans, it still thrills. This four-part series traces the four-decade evolution of heavy metal -- skintight jeans, luxuriant tresses, eyeliner, smashed guitars and all (as seen on Mötley Crüe, above). 8 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS -- Season finale. Carrie predicts a retirement home in Arthur's future after he sets the basement on fire. 8 P.M. (Fox) 24 -- ''Day 5: 5:00AM-6:00AM/6:00AM-7:00AM.'' As the day wanes in this two-hour season finale, Jack faces his biggest opponent yet. But in the end, who will rule? 8 P.M. (ABC) OPRAH WINFREY'S LEGENDS BALL -- After being bumped by the president's speech on May 15, this two-hour special rehashes the glam moments of the May 2005 weekend-long festivities with which Ms. Winfrey honored 25 of her personal heroes, in case your invitation never arrived. 8:30 P.M. (CBS) THE NEW ADVENTURES OF OLD CHRISTINE -- Those soccer moms can be so harsh. Christine gets relief from her outcast status when she finds another working mother at her son's snobby school. That is, until she discovers where she works. In the season finale, at 9:30, after ''Two and a Half Men,'' Christine is secretly pleased when she realizes that the attractive man those nasties are cooing over is an ex-boyfriend. That is, until she discovers she still has feelings. 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE MAN BEHIND HITLER -- He was perhaps the original spin doctor, a brilliant but disturbed propagandist without whom Hitler -- and the Nazi Party -- might have been almost nothing. This ''American Experience'' documentary traverses the life of Joseph Goebbels (above right), the second most powerful member of the Third Reich, by letting him speak for himself through his own diary entries, read by the actor Kenneth Branagh. 9 P.M. (CBS) TWO AND A HALF MEN -- Season finale. Charlie and Mia plan their wedding, with their families weighing in. 9 P.M. (ABC) ALIAS -- When will it all be over? Just as soon as Sydney can stop the cartel of evildoers from fulfilling Rambaldi's deadly plan in this two-hour series finale. 10 P.M. (NBC) MEDIUM -- Season finale. Allison (Patricia Arquette, left) has visions of what her life would have been if she'd become a high-powered lawyer and married another man, and they aren't all that scary. 10 P.M. (MTV) PUNK'D -- Series finale. Ashton Kutcher puts an end to his tomfoolery, and Hollywood can sleep more soundly now. Unless, of course, we're being punk'd. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

DARCY--Natalie. July 29, 1909-May 18, 2006. Dr. Darcy, the only girl of thirteen children born to Maud Horgan Darcy and Michael Darcy, was a psychologist and teacher at Brooklyn College and Fordham University for many years before retirement in 1972. She was a devoted parishoner and first chair person of the Parish Council at St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village, was a member of the Third Order of St. Francis, and of the Ladies of the Holy Sepulcher. Her body will lie in state at St. Joseph's Church, 371 6th Ave., between 8th St. and Waverly Place on Monday evening at 7PM, May 22, 2006. There will be a Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's on Tuesday, May 23 at 10AM followed by burial in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to St. Joseph's Church in her memory.
To the Editor: Re your May 18 editorial ''Water Hazard,'' about the floods in New England:

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.81 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 4.98 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.74 percent.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 European Banks Curb Activities in Iran Under prodding from the United States, some European banks have started curbing their activities in Iran, even in the absence of a Security Council resolution imposing economic sanctions on Iran for its suspected nuclear arms program. A1 Iran has become an increasing focus of interest in a three-year-old effort known as the Proliferation Security Initiative, under which the United States and cooperating countries carry out military and naval exercises aimed at stopping nuclear materials and contraband. A8 Rogues Hurt Iraq Police An American effort to rebuild the Iraqi police, undermanned and slow to get started, has become overwhelmed by corruption, political vengeance and lawlessness as rogue police units and other government security forces are accused of carrying out massacres and violence on behalf of political or tribal groups. A1 Iraq's new prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, used his first full day on the job to promise ''maximum levels of force in confronting terrorists and killers,'' but the deaths of at least 20 people in Baghdad were a measure of the uphill struggle in pulling Iraq back from the brink of civil war. A10 The Lazim family lost all four of its men when a man walked up to them as they got out of their pickup truck and sprayed them with gunfire. In the patterns of violence in Baghdad, sectarian killings like this one -- the Lazims are Shiites and blame Sunni insurgents for the murders -- have become routine. A10 U.S. Site to Stop Iran Missiles The Bush administration is moving to establish a new antimissile site in Europe that is designed to stop attacks by Iran against the United States and its European allies. A1 Palestinian and Israeli Meet The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, and Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni of Israel met in Egypt in the highest-level contacts between the sides since Hamas, the radical Islamic faction, won the Palestinian elections in January. A4 Kuwait's Parliament Dissolved Kuwait's emir, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, dissolved the country's 50-member Parliament, ending a weeklong battle over a proposed redistricting law that paralyzed the government and threatened to cause a constitutional crisis. A6 Montenegro Splits From Serbia According to projections, voters in the small Balkan state of Montenegro decided in a referendum to end their union with Serbia, breaking up all that remained of the Communist-era Yugoslavia. A3 W.H.O. Leader Hospitalized The director general of the World Health Organization underwent emergency brain surgery in Geneva and will be unable to participate in the agency's annual meeting, which will focus on preventing and preparing for any pandemic of influenza. A3 NATIONAL A14-19 New Orleans Mayor Vote Shows Power of Incumbent The extraordinary circumstances stacked against Mayor C. Ray Nagin by Hurricane Katrina could not finally trump a cardinal force of New Orleans politics, the power of incumbency. By a margin of four percentage points, voters re-elected Mr Nagin to guide the city through the next four years of rebuilding. A1 Mr. Nagin was as unruffled in his victory as he has been facing defeat, better-funded opponents, a cataclysmic flood, and the defection of one-time supporters. A18 Levees Flawed, Report Says A new report says that major breaches in the New Orleans levee system during Hurricane Katrina were caused by flaws in design, construction and maintenance and that parts of the system can still be dangerous even after the current round of repairs. A19 F.B.I. Accuses Lawmaker The Federal Bureau of Investigation charged that Representative William J. Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat, was paid hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes by a Kentucky businessman and stashed $90,000 in his home freezer in Washington. A1 Corruption Trial to Begin A former White House budget official is scheduled to go on trial this week, the first defendant to face a jury in the corruption scandal centered on the lobbyist Jack Abramoff. A17 Gonzales on Journalists The government has the legal authority to prosecute journalists for publishing classified information, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales said. A14 5 Dead After Church Shooting A man opened fire inside the Ministry of Jesus Christ Church in Baton Rouge, killing four people and wounding another, before kidnapping and later killing his wife, law enforcement officials said. A19 Caribbean Coral Threatened For the first time, two species of Caribbean coral were added to the list of threatened species under the federal Endangered Species Act. A14 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Effort to Save Racehorse Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro's racing career is over, but a valiant and costly effort was made Sunday to repair the right hind leg of the horse that sustained a catastrophic ankle break before an audience of millions early in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. A1 The pall that was cast over Pimlico Race Course the moment Barbaro took his first awkward steps in the Preakness had not lifted. The usually busting backstretch was eerily quiet, the visitors still seemed oblivious to the terrific race Bernardini had run in victory. D7 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 More Young Principals As System Is Revamped More than half the principals in the New York City public school system have left the job over the past five years, opening the way for an influx of newcomers, some in their 20's and 30's with impressive credentials but little teaching experience. The transformation is occurring at the very moment Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein is seeking to give principals more authority. A1 NYC TV Is a Big Success NYC TV, the city's official television outlet whose bread and butter used to be City Hall hearings, has soared in the ratings to 100,000 viewers for its most popular shows. The station's programming is so successful that its shows are starting to get picked up by stations from East Hampton to Los Angeles. B1 Plight of 9/11 Workers Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's decision to intervene in the case of a former deputy mayor who believes that he became severely ill from working around ground zero after the Sept. 11 attacks has cast unwanted attention on the city's handling of 9/11 workers' compensation cases. B1 ARTS E1-10 Controversy Over Auction In a decision that is stirring wide debate in Chinese Internet chat rooms, a Chinese-American collector plans to sell a renowned official portrait of Mao at auction in Beijing on June 3. Some argue that the 1950 portrait should go to a national museum. E3 Bill Maher on Amazon.com Bill Maher, the comedian, who since losing his ''Politically Incorrect'' perch on ABC in the wake of 9/11, has been reborn on HBO, will begin a new talk show on June 1 on Amazon.com. Its stated purpose is to steer clear of controversy and sell books and music for the Web site. E3 OBITUARIES B6 Robert Heinecken An artist and teacher whose challenging work radically expanded the range of possibilites for photography as a form of art, he was 74. B6 BUSINESS DAY C1-20 Assessing Clinical Trials The announcement by medical experts that new data from Merck indicated that Vioxx's risks started to emerge after only four months of use is the latest illustration of how widely open to interpretation the results of clinical trials can be -- even when conducted under carefully designed research conditions and reported in a leading medical journal. C1 NYSE May Acquire Euronext The board of the NYSE Group, operator of the New York Stock Exchange, agreed this weekend to make an offer to acquire Euronext, the pan-European exchange, a deal that would create the first trans-Atlantic market, with a combined market capitalization of more than $21 billion. C1 Criticism for Bausch & Lomb Singapore officials are openly critical of Bausch & Lomb for not acting faster when a connection was made between Bausch & Lomb's ReNu With MoistureLoc cleaner and Fusarium eye fungus infections. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: Promises? What promises?; corn laws for the 21st century; a better Javits all around; our hidden history. Columns: Bob Herbert and Paul Krugman. Bridge E4 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather B7

SCHACHAT - Robert. Of Greenwich, CT, on May 20, after a valiant struggle. Born August 3, 1947, graduate of NYU and Ph.D in social psychology from University of Connecticut. Bob was a management consultant, a professor at Mercy College, an actor in local theatre and gifted cabaret singer. Beloved father of Arielle. Dearest brother of Joan Goldman and brothers-in-law Hank Goldman and Bob and Gina Hoffman. Devoted uncle to David and Jennifer Goldman, Jeff Wetzler, Sam Hoffman and grand-nephew Jacob. His wife Shelley predeceased him. He will be greatly missed by his family and his many friends, whom he loved. Services on Monday, May 22, 12:30, Temple Shalom, Greenwich, CT.

RAISLER -- Jeanne, CNM, DrPH. Died May 19, Ann Arbor, MI, age 59. Beloved wife to Jonathan Cohn, mother to Josina and Josh, daughter-inlaw of Pauline Cohn and daughter of the late Harold Raisler and Mary Kutz. Born in New York City, Jeanne received her MSN in Midwifery from Columbia University, MPH from the University of California, Berkeley, and DrPH in Maternal and Child Health from Johns Hopkins University. For the past 10 years Jeanne worked in the School of Nursing at the University of Michigan, receiving her promotion to Clinical Associate Professor in her final days. During her 30 years as a Nurse-Midwife, Jeanne contributed as an educator, mentor, caregiver, writer and editor. She was an accomplished breastfeeding researcher and advocate, received the Regional Award for Excellence from and was inducted as a Fellow by the American College of NurseMidwives. In recent years Jeanne devoted herself to promoting the role of nurses in HIV/AIDS care in Africa. Jeanne's commitment to social justice began as a tutor in Spanish Harlem in her high school years and continued as an antiwar activist and promoter of quality healthcare for poor women throughout her life. Jeanne will be greatly missed by her family, friends and colleagues, and will be remembered as an inspiration and visionary by all those whose lives she touched. Gifts in her memory may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union or the Association of Nurses in AIDS Care/Global HIV Nursing Specialty Committee.

VERDICT WATCH -- Jurors in the criminal trial of Enron's former chief executives, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, began deliberations last week and are to resume them today. The jurors are reviewing 28 charges of fraud, conspiracy and insider trading against Mr. Skilling and 6 charges of fraud and conspiracy against Mr. Lay. The two men face decades in prison if convicted on all charges. BOX-OFFICE BUZZ -- May has been an uneven month at the Hollywood box office. ''Mission: Impossible III'' and ''Poseidon'' each sold fewer tickets in their opening weekends than Hollywood had expected. ''The Da Vinci Code'' had a big opening last weekend. Will the release on Friday of ''X-Men: The Last Stand,'' whose stars include Halle Berry, above, keep the box office humming for the extended Memorial Day holiday weekend? THE BIG 3 OF FINANCE -- Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve; John W. Snow, the Treasury secretary; and Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, are scheduled to appear on Wednesday before the Senate Banking Committee to speak about improving financial literacy in the United States. A COOL-DOWN? -- Reports of new home sales for April, on Wednesday, and existing home sales for April, on Thursday, will give an updated look at the housing market. I.P.O. WATCH -- A couple of high-profile public offerings are scheduled for this week. MasterCard, the credit card company, is planning a $2.5 billion offering, and Vonage, the provider of phone service over the Internet, has a $500 million offering planned. HOLIDAY BREAK -- The bond market will close early on Friday ahead of the Memorial Day weekend. ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- Durable goods orders for April on Wednesday; annualized total output and personal consumption for the first quarter and weekly jobless claims on Thursday; personal income and personal spending on Friday.

''The Da Vinci Code,'' with Audrey Tautou and Tom Hanks (above), didn't crack the top 10 list of biggest weekend openers. Still, it earned a respectable $77 million, which places it at No. 23 on the list of the top 100 openers, tied with ''Finding Nemo'' (2003). Movies which open with a built-in audience of 5- to 15-year-olds occupy a disproportionate number of the top 100 slots, more than 30. In addition to the Harry Potter series, they include ''The Incredibles'' ($75 million), ''Monsters, Inc.'' ($71 million) and ''Toy Story 2'' ($69 million). SHELLY FREIERMAN
To the Editor: I teach history at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Rather than try to combat cheating, I encourage it.

ANDREASIAN--Edgar Diran. 80, of Great Neck, NY, died at home on May 19, 2006. Born and raised in New York City, he is survived by his former wife Zepure Andreasian, his daughter Marguerite White, sons Peter and Theodore, and granddaughters Arax and Amelia. Friends may visit at the Edward D. Jamie Jr. Funeral Chapel, 208-17 Northern Blvd., Bayside, NY, on Monday, between the hours of 3 to 5, and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Holy Martyrs Armenian Church, 209-15 Horace Harding Blvd., Bayside, NY, on Tuesday, May 23, at 12 noon. His wit and wisdom will be sorely missed.

CAPELLUTO - Alexander. Beloved son of Jacques and Karen, loving brother of Katherine. Services 12:30, Monday, at Congregation Bnai Jeshurun, 257 West 88th St. No flowers. $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander. You were a true inspiration to both Horace Mann students and parents alike. From Nursery Years to the Grasshopper of Lower School to Middle School to your leadership in the Upper School, you excelled in every way. You taught us how to love, to learn and live life to the fullest. As Valedictorian in June, 2004, you said to us ''Live for this moment; the past is present now.'' Alex, you will always be in our present--today and forever. Our hearts are with Karen, Jacques and Katherine. The Bernstein Family The Frankel Family The Fleder Family The Glusband Family The Kasner Family The Lowe Family The Minsk Family The Olanoff Family The Tabak Family The Taber Family Debra and Schuster Tanger $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander, from the beginning a blend of brilliance, sweetness and spirit. He was our daughter's first playdate and will always be ''Zander to our Gingey.'' The memories and images are full in our hearts. With love and sympathy, Kevin, Lindsay, Lexi and Matti Brine $(6$)CAPELLUTO -- Alexander. Alexander, we mourn deeply for you. You were unique and special. Your potential was limitless. You were a very special friend to us and we will always remember you. Michael, Nedra, Matthew, Brett and Alyssa
To the Editor: Re ''Inflation Rising, Markets Tumble'' (front page, May 18):

So, ''The Da Vinci Code,'' Ron Howard's critically skewered and roasted film adaptation of the Dan Brown book took in, according to a news release put out by Sony on Sunday, an estimated ''$224 million in worldwide box office receipts during its first three days of theatrical release'' and delivered ''$77 million in U.S. ticket sales,'' thereby giving the company its ''biggest worldwide opening ever.'' Does this mean that critics are out of touch with the public? Maybe, but really, who cares? All that box office doesn't make it a good movie. Here's hoping that this extra lucre means that Sony Pictures Classics, can go on a shopping spree at Cannes. MANOHLA DARGIS

To the Editor: Simply raising the fuel economy standards for cars would not fix a flawed decades-old program (editorial, May 15). As the National Academy of Sciences has reported, raising fuel economy standards without improving the program would do more to endanger motorists and threaten American jobs than it would to help end our addiction to oil.

Because of an editing error, a brief sports article on Wednesday about Franco Pellizotti's victory in the 10th stage of the Giro d'Italia misstated the given name of another cyclist. He is Axel Merckx, not Alex.

5 Dead After Church Shooting in Louisiana A man opened fire inside the Ministry of Jesus Christ Church in Baton Rouge at a morning service, killing four people and wounding another before kidnapping his wife and killing her, law enforcement officials said. RUDIN--Min. Dear Sondra, your loss is our loss. Your mother was an incredibly kind and caring person and she will be missed by all of us. May she rest in peace. With our personal condolences, Freddie, Tami, Jason and Hailey

Eoghan O'Connell had to wait an hour during a lightning delay yesterday before making a par 3 on the 18th hole to defeat John McClure, 1 up, to win the Travis Memorial Tournament at Garden City Golf Club in Garden City, N.Y. ''The horn went off as I was about to play and it was a little nerve-racking during the delay,'' O'Connell said. ''However, I was fine when play resumed and had no trouble sinking my putt.'' BERNIE BEGLANE

You can hear the stars arrive well before you see them from inside the news conference room at the Cannes Film Festival headquarters, since their entrance is broadcast by photographers shouting just outside the entrance. On Sunday afternoon the yells were for ''Sarah! Sarah! Sarah!'' and ''Rock! Rock! Rock!'' meaning Sarah Michelle Gellar and Dwayne Johnson, two of the stars of Richard Kelly's new film, ''Southland Tales.'' This noisy reception was in stark contrast to the welcome that Mr. Kelly's long-anticipated follow-up to his 2001 cult favorite, ''Donnie Darko,'' received during is first screening before a palpably hostile press.

STERN--Harriet May, of Rye, NY, on May 19th. Beloved wife of Bill Stern, the late sportscaster, loving mother of Peter Stern of NY, Mary Wiehe of Citrus Springs, FL, and Patricia Mulcahy of La Mesa, CA. She is also survived by a brother Richard May of Tucson, AZ, seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Graveside service Monday, 2 PM, at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

A man died yesterday after he was found on a Chelsea street with head injuries about 4 a.m., the police said. Thomas White Jr., 24, of Hoboken, N.J., was picked up on Sixth Avenue between 19th and 20th Streets by an Emergency Medical Services vehicle that was flagged down by a pedestrian who said someone had been stabbed. Mr. White was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he died about 5:30 p.m. Mr. White studied business at the University of Delaware, said James Moretti, a neighbor in Howell, N.J., where Mr. White grew up. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

RICH--Milton. 92, passed away peacefully on May20, 2006, with his beloved wife of 67 years, Adele, and daughter, Meredith, at his side. Veteran publicist, uncle, greatuncle and friend. Burial private. Details of a memorial service to follow.

Nancy Hill joined Lowe Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group, as chief executive for North America. She assumes some duties from Susan Cantor, chief executive for the New York office, who left. Ms. Hill had most recently been executive vice president and managing director on the Visa account at BBDO Worldwide, New York, part of the Omnicom Group. Andy Sims joined ZenithOptimedia USA, San Francisco, as senior vice president and interactive director, part of a reorganization of digital media operations. He succeeds Brenda Goodman, who is leaving, the agency said. Mr. Sims had been senior vice president and director for interactive services at SF Interactive, San Francisco, part of Butler, Shine, Stern & Partners. ZenithOptimedia USA is part of the ZenithOptimedia Group division of the Publicis Groupe.

RYAN--Angela Shen, Ph.D., 77. Died on May 18, 2006 after a long illness. She was a beloved wife, mother and grandmother as well as an esteemed professor of social work. Her loss is deeply felt. A service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave. on Tuesday, May 23, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, send donations in her name to the Hunter School of Social Work, 129 E. 79th St., NYC 10021, attn: Dean's Office.
The Times's C.J. Chivers reports on the revival of a dance ritual among  Chechnya's Sufi Muslims, a sect that is also erecting the region's largest mosque.    Producer: Adam B. Ellick
The Times' David Carr talks with reknowned restaurateur Sirio Maccioni and distinguished guests at the opening party of Le Cirque on 58th Street. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

I've had some indignant comments from applicants to my "win-a-trip" contest who say that actually their essays were much better than Casey Parks' essay. And Harvard students are peeved that they got shut out among the finalists.
Eliot Spitzer's most recent campaign ad.

So, does State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, one of the most powerful Republicans in the state, think that his party and the Senate Republicans would be better off with William F. Weld running at the top of the ticket in the fall? Maybe maybe not.
It was my second week as the globe-trotting Frugal Traveler, and I was beginning to wonder if I had made a wrong turn. Bealo, for all its rustic charms, is not easy to reach without a car.

The race to decide whether Al Gore or George Bush is the Newest Nixon appears to be as close as the historic 2000 presidential campaign. Will the Supreme Court break the impasse? Will Gore win his home state of Tennessee? Will confused opinion-makers in Palm Beach County accidentally make the case for Pat Buchanan?
Publishing company McClatchy said Tuesday it has agreed to sell two Philadephia newspapers to an investor group led by advertising executive Brian Tierney.

OMV AG and Verbund, the Austrian energy companies that announced plans to merge in a 13.1 billion-euro ($16.7 billion) accord earlier this month, scrapped the deal because of mounting political opposition, the government said.

The field of candidates to succeed Representative Major Owens of Brooklyn narrowed today: Assemblyman N. Nick Perry told The Empire Zone that he was withdrawing from that race and running instead for re-election.

Whirlpool has sifted through the assets of recently acquired Maytag and decided to divest several business lines that it picked up in the deal. Among the brands slated for sale are Hoover, which makes vacuum cleaners, as well as Amana and Jade, both of which make commercial appliances, Whirlpool said Tuesday in a press release.

EMI Group on Tuesday vowed to continue pursuing an acquisition of United States-based rival Warner Music Group. The statement came as EMI of Britain reported a 20 percent increase in profit for the fiscal year.
It looks like CNBC anchor Maria Bartiromo may have had her first, last and only private chat with Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke.
On Friday night, my wife and I had a date night in New York City. But then we saw the mobs standing in line for the grand opening of Apple's new flagship store.
A hearty welcome to those of you just joining us at The Empire Zone, a news blog about New York politics from The New York Times.

Claiming there was a "systematic effort by senior management to manipulate accounting, reap financial rewards and prevent the rest of the world from knowing about it," federal regulators on Tuesday announced a settlement with Fannie Mae that included a $400 million penalty for the mortgage lending giant.
Weld-Faso has ended at Building Congress. Weld was funny and a bit windy, and Faso sounded smart about state government - like, budget-director smart. Some highlights:

A flood of stories in recent days have questioned whether Internet telephone service Vonage can pull off its proposed initial public offering in the face of mounting competition. Deep in Vonage's recent regulatory filings, however, the company revealed a different potential problem related to its roughly $500 million offering.

Hedge fund manager Nelson Peltz wants to more than double the stock price of H.J. Heinz to as much as $81 a share. Toward that end, on Tuesday he released a position paper calling for Heinz to sell assets and boost its dividend payout ratio.

They say nobody doesn't like Sara Lee, but plenty of people don't like its poison-pill takeover defense. The company's shareholders approved a non-binding resolution to dissolve the poison-pill provision in October, and Sara Lee management responded on Monday by meeting them halfway, the Chicago Tribune reported.

Investment bank Lehman Brothers Holdings has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle charges that it filed inaccurate short-interest reports between January 2001 and May 2004, the enforcement and regulation unit of NYSE Group said on Tuesday.
Swedish lockmaker Assa Abloy agreed to buy Minnesota-based Fargo Electronics for $300 million to gain access to its growing market for security cards and holographic badges.
There have been only a few times in my life as a physician when I've been able to say (at least to myself), "This is truly big news."
Paul Farrell over at MarketWatch notes the confusion over the real estate market and even mentions one of my favorite indicators, magazine covers.
Avanir Pharmaceuticals on Tuesday said it agreed to buy a privately owned drugj company, Alamo Pharmaceuticals, for about $29 million in cash and notes.

Citing regulatory delays, satellite radio provider XM ended its $196 million bid for WCS Wireless late Monday. The 10-month-old bid, in which XM said it would issue 5.5 million shares to buy closely held WCS, would have provided the embattled radio provider with spectrum to expand its land-based radio services and extra features like video.

John Faso, at Building Congress, just made his pitch for Mayor Mike Bloomberg's endorsement. Mr. Faso said the mayor had done a "sterling" job managing city schools and was especially impressive at providing "adult supervision - especially over that City Council."

The business software maker Oracle Corporation said on Tuesday that is had extended its tender offer for all shares of Portal Software through June 6. Oracle bid $220 million, or $4.90 a share, last month for Portal, which provides billing and revenue management software to communications and media companies.

An Activision subsidiary, Activision Publishing, said on Tuesday it had signed a multiyear agreement giving it exclusive worldwide distribution rights to new video games based on Mattel's Barbie brand.
At the NY Building Congress forum now, featuring Republican candidates for governor John Faso and Bill Weld. Bonhomie is breaking out.

Shareholders of the European stock exchange operator Euronext rejected a proposal Tuesday to declare a merger with the Deutsche Börse in the company's best interest, rather than a rival bid by the New York Stock Exchange.

The New York Conservative Party holds its convention in Manhattan this afternoon to select a nominee for governor -- former Assembly leader John Faso -- and for the U.S. Senate race against Hillary Rodham Clinton -- former Yonkers mayor John Spencer.
South Korea's antitrust watchdog has rejected an objection lodged by Microsoft over a ruling that the company should unbundle its media player and messaging service from Windows software.

The former chief executive of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay, acknowledged on Monday that he or his staff might have violated a federal law governing the use of personal bank loans to buy stocks, but he said that he never intended to defraud the banks or lie to them.

A Los Angeles lawyer pleaded guilty on Monday to a tax charge related to claims that he funneled money to a client of Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, the law firm indicted last week on chargest it paid more than $11 million in kickbacks.

Lance K. Poulsen, former chairman of National Century Financial Enterprises, and six other former executives were indicted on charges of plotting to defraud investors in the company, a health care finance concern that is now bankrupt.
A former broker with Merrill Lynch who gave day traders access to the firm's internal communication system was banned from the industry under a settlement with federal regulators Monday.

How lucky is William McGuire, wonders Bloomberg News columnist Graef Crystal, suggesting that the answer to that question is related to the $2.1 billion in options he amassed in the last 12 years as head of UnitedHealth.

Thomas H. Lee Partners, the private equity group, is in advanced talks to recoup tens of millions of dollars it lost in the collapse of Refco as part of a wider settlement between United States authorities and Bawag, the Austrian bank linked to the bankrupt brokerage.

The flotation of Bank of China, the world's biggest share listing for six years, is attracting a large amount of demand from retail investors, despite the recent declines in the Hong Kong stock market.
Juniper Networks joined a growing list of companies under scrutiny over allegations they engaged in questionable practices involving the grant of stock options to top executives.
Securities regulators sanctioned Los Angeles-based investment firm Crowell, Weedon, saying it violated customer identification requirements mandated by the Patriot Act.

Perhaps looking to build on prior success in the waste services industry, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners said it has agreed to buy United Site Services, a provider of portable restrooms and services at sports stadiums, construction sites and other locations, from Odyssey Investment Partners.
Water Street Capital Partners has purchased a majority stake in lab test company Lakewood Pathology Associates, its first deal since the firm formed last year.

The focus on fine cheese is intensifying as U.S. consumers gravitate toward high-quality food in general, and as retailers such as Whole Foods Market and Trader Joe's work to set themselves apart by the breadth of their cheese sections. The traditional product is becoming a bigger business.

Red Diamond Capital agreed to buy Avon Automotive for $118.9 million and said it was aiming to leverage its ties with Mitsubishi International to create a rubber auto parts platform out of the company.
Market10, a provider of job listings on the Internet, raised $13 million in a second round that founder and C.E.O. Rob McGovern will use to take on his first creation, CareerBuilder.
Apollo Management, the New York-based private equity firm, is raising a $1.5 billion publicly traded private equity vehicle similar to the one raised on May 3 by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

Merrill Lynch's Asian operations have more than doubled in two years, having increased its personnel by more than 10 percent in each of the past two years, Asian chief Damian Chunilal said in an interview with FinanceAsia.com.
Britain's Rexam, the world's largest drinks can maker, on Tuesday declared its 146 million euro ($188 million) bid made on February 22 for Amsterdam-listed Airspray, a foam pump maker, unconditional.

Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage buyer, is expected to pay more than $400 million today as part of a settlement to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses, The New York Times reported.
A slew of large takeovers in fixed-line telecoms saw the value of deals in the sector almost treble to 125 billion pounds ($235 billion) last year, according City law firm Eversheds.
Newspaper publisher and broadcaster Tribune said that its Tribune Interactive subsidiary has acquired ForSaleByOwner.com, a national real-estate Web site, for an undisclosed amount.

U.S. pipeline giant Kinder Morgan has closed the sale of its Terasen water and utility services business for $124 million to a group that includes the Vancouver company's management and a major British Columbia pension fund.
PT Unilever Indonesia, the nation's biggest consumer goods maker, has acquired an appetite for vanilla tea.

One day after The New York Stock Exchange launched a $10.2 billion offer for Euronext, Deutsche Börse fought back with a bid valued at $11.1 billion, as it seeks to create Europe's biggest stock market and expand in derivatives.
Hellman & Friedman, a buyout firm with a specialty in financial services, may buy London-based Gartmore Investment Management, which oversees $78 billion, Bloomberg News reported.
American Express weighed in Monday with a $10 billion stock buyback program and boosted its quarterly dividend by 25 percent as the Dow component puts its cash to work.

Citibank, the retail banking arm of Citigroup, is exploring ways to return to Saudi Arabia and is open to acquisitions in the Middle East and North Africa as part of aggressive regional expansion plans, William Rhodes, Citibank chairman, said on Monday.

Thanks to its relentless marketing and low prices, Vonage has quickly become synonymous with phone service over the Internet. But when Brandon Sehlke and his wife, Jennifer, moved into a new home in San Antonio two weeks ago, they chose a new Internet phone service from Time Warner Cable, not Vonage or AT&T, his old provider.
Swedish firm Bonnier Magazine Group has taken on the American magazine market by grabbing a stake in World Publications, owners of Saveur, Garden Design, Caribbean Travel & Life and Water Skiing.
Royal Philips Electronics agreed to buy the U.K.'s Avent Holdings for 460 million pounds ($868 million) to add baby soothers and bottle warmers to the appliances division.
First Republic Bank agreed to buy BWC Financial, the parent of Bank of Walnut Creek, for $177 million in stock.

Eircom, Ireland's dominant telecommunications company, is set to be taken private for the second time in five years after it on Tuesday recommended a 2.36 billion euros takeover offer led by Babcock & Brown, the Australian financial services company.

Federated Department Stores has completed the first of two sales of credit-card receivables it picked up in the acquisition of May Department Stores. Terms of the sale to Citigroup were undisclosed. More than 40 percent of the May's credit-card portfolio has been converted through the completion of the transaction.
A team led by Goldman Sachs Group raised its bid for Associated British Ports Holdings, the biggest U.K. ports company, by 11 percent to 2.4 billion pounds ($4.5 billion).
9 Days, 42 Stops, 3,650 Miles, 10 Favorites.

French buyout shop PAI Partners has agreed to buy French energy and rail industry services group Amec Spie from British construction and infrastructure management company Amec for 1.04 billion euros ($1.33 billion), beating both two other private equity bidders and construction group Vinci.

J.P. Morgan's team of Internet analysts has issued a report speculating on a number of potential mergers or partnerships among the largest Web companies -- it's an interesting read brought to our attention by PaidContent.org. Of all the possible pairings, the combination that the report deems "most strategically feasible" is a union between Yahoo and eBay.
The German media conglomerate Bertelsmann said that it might buy out a minority shareholder, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, and avoid the need for an initial public offering.

Many of the nation's next crop of M.B.A. holders have studied their last case study and taken their last final exam, putting us firmly in commencement season. Although it may not help them land a better job or higher pay, a big-name commencement speaker could give certain members of the class of 2006 their first post-M.B.A. coup: bragging rights at graduation barbecues.

A Bronx man has been indicted in the shooting of a Mount Vernon police detective during questioning at the police station last month, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Michael J. Mitchell, 33, of Bruckner Boulevard, was charged with attempted murder, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said Mr. Mitchell tried to take a gun away from Detective Matthew Frank during questioning about the shooting death of a local businessman on April 19. During the struggle, she said, Mr. Mitchell shot the detective in the foot before being subdued.
John Faso, a Republican candidate for governor, is expected to choose C. Scott Vanderhoef, the Rockland County executive, as his running mate today, two Republican consultants said yesterday.

<subhead>CONNECTICUT</subhead><leadin>SUFFIELD: GUARDS INJURED IN ATTACK</LEADIN> Two prison guards were injured Sunday night in an attack by two inmates at the MacDougall-Walker Correctional Institution, the state police said yesterday. The inmates, whose names were not released, were serving sentences for conspiracy to commit murder, the state police said. One guard was admitted to Hartford Hospital, and the other was treated and released. The prison, which holds about 2,100 inmates, was in lockdown yesterday as the state police investigated the attack.

A federal grand jury indicted John A. Gotti, left, on new charges yesterday as the government positions itself for the July 5 start of Mr. Gotti's third trial on racketeering charges. Juries deadlocked in two previous trials in the last year. Yesterday's indictment, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, accused Mr. Gotti of tampering with a witness last summer and of using money earned illegally to operate holding companies used to buy real estate and collect rents. Charles Carnesi, Mr. Gotti's lawyer, did not immediately return telephone messages for comment.

The new chairman of the state commission that polices the ethics of New York judges has resigned from the commission because of a complaint that involves members of his Binghamton law firm. The former chairman, Alan Pope, took office April 1 and had been a member of the Commission of Judicial Conduct since 1997, according to the commission's Web site. A statement on the site said the commission had received a complaint against a judge that involved members of Mr. Pope's firm on May 9, and Mr. Pope resigned last Tuesday to avoid an appearance of a conflict of interest. The vice chairman, Raoul Felder, will serve as acting chairman.

As a hate-crime trial opened in Queens yesterday, jurors heard two very different versions of a high-profile showdown between two groups of young men — one white and one black — in Howard Beach last summer.

The government said politically motivated crimes in the country increased sharply from 2004 to 2005, especially attacks carried out by the far right. The number of crimes committed by the far right increased by 27 percent and the number of violent attacks carried out by the group rose by 23 percent. The total number of politically motivated violent crimes came to 2,448 in 2005, according to the annual report. Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra will formally take back the reins of power today by leading a cabinet meeting almost two months after announcing he was taking a political break, officials said. After weeks of mass protests in the capital, Bangkok, calling on him to resign, Mr. Thaksin called for a national election in April and then transferred his main duties to his deputy. Last month, the Constitutional Court annulled the national election because an opposition boycott left seats in Parliament unfilled. The government has not set a new election date, although the Election Commission has proposed that it be held in late October.

Foreign Minister Abdallah bin Zayid al-Nuhayyan of the United Arab Emirates said Persian Gulf countries, most of them close allies of the United States, planned to hold talks with Iran over concerns that Iran's nuclear program could pose an environmental threat to them. The gulf states rely on seawater desalination plants for drinking water.

Two neighborhoods in the capital, Bucharest, were off-limits as the authorities worked to contain bird flu outbreaks, officials said. The authorities began setting up disinfection points and culling poultry after suspicious poultry deaths. No human infections were reported.

A court sentenced eight senior Culture Ministry officials to 10 years in prison each for negligence in a theater fire that killed 50 people last September. A judge found them guilty of negligence in applying fire codes and safety measures at the theater, in Beni Suef, about 60 miles south of Cairo. The highest-ranking defendant was Mustafa Alwy, who was chairman of the Culture Palaces Authority, which ran the theater. On Sept. 5, more than 150 people were watching a play inside the theater when an actor knocked over a candle being used as a prop, igniting the set and setting off a stampede of people struggling to escape through the only available exit. Sixty people were injured.

Prosecutors were seeking a charge of attempted murder against a man being held in a knife attack on Park Geun Hye, the chairwoman of South Korea's main opposition party, the Grand National Party. The attack on Ms. Park took place in Seoul on Saturday as she was attending a party rally for the country's local elections this month. She suffered a four-inch cut along the face that required 60 stitches and will prevent her from talking normally for weeks, a hospital spokesman said. Ms. Park, 54, is widely expected to be a candidate for president next year. Her father, Park Chung Hee, was a president from 1961 to 1979, when he was assassinated. Her mother had been killed five years earlier by a bullet that missed her father. The police said that the suspect in Ms. Park's attack had served 14 years in prison on charges including assault and that he had told them he was

Managers dismissed warnings about water leaks in a coal mine in northern Shanxi Province just days before a flood trapped 57 miners, state media said as relatives awaited news after the biggest accident this year in China's chaotic mines. An 800-member rescue team searched for the miners, but there was no word on whether any of them was believed to be alive, four days after the mine flooded with water on Thursday.
The Jets signed punter Ben Graham, a former Australian Rules football player, to a six year contract extension Monday.
Tennessee will pay Pat Summitt $1.125 million for next season, making her the first millionaire coach in women's basketball.

Hicham el-Guerrouj of Morocco, who holds the world records for the mile and the 1,500 meters, announced his retirement Monday.

In a vote of confidence from Wall Street, one of the three major bond-rating agencies upgraded its rating of New York City's debt yesterday, citing surging tax revenues, a commitment from Albany to finance school construction projects and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's decision to create a $2 billion trust fund to pay for the health care expenses of retired city workers.
Teresa Janoras is one of 150,000 people who scavenge or recycle the garbage in Manila. On her best days she can earn a bit more than $3.

The Supreme Court yesterday put off deciding whether to hear an appeal from four reporters who have been held in contempt of court for refusing to disclose confidential sources. The justices' move was apparently prompted by a letter saying the underlying case might soon be settled.
Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson each left Arizona seeking championships. Schilling helped the Red Sox win the World Series in 2004. Johnson has become a Yankees enigma.

Nearly a third of Chicago's public schools will be restructured because they have failed to improve test scores under the No Child Left Behind Act, the school district said. The plan for 185 of the district's 600-plus schools includes curriculum changes, fewer grades per school and staffing changes. Officials have already announced that a handful of schools have closed or will close. The district will present its proposal to the Chicago Board of Education at a meeting tomorrow. The Illinois State Board of Education also must approve the plan.

Five people face criminal charges after a weekend confrontation with members of a Kansas group that pickets military funerals and believes that American casualties in Iraq are God's retribution for America's embrace of homosexuality, the authorities said. Members of Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka, Kan., were met at Seaford by about 1,000 angry counterdemonstrators. The authorities said David Jones, 29, of Bridgeville broke through a police line and began assaulting two of the Westboro protesters. He was charged with two counts of third-degree assault and one count of disorderly conduct. A 16-year-old Seaford youth was charged with criminal mischief and disorderly conduct after a tire on the Westboro group's van was slashed. Christopher Daudt, 19, Stephen Carson, 19, and Allen Dunn, 56, all of Seaford, were also charged with criminal mischief and disorderly conduct. Church members plan to return to Seaford on Wednesday to picket another funeral.

The Dutch police have detained a man on suspicion of participating in the disappearance of Natalee Holloway last year in Aruba, the man's lawyer said. The lawyer, Gerard Spong, said his client, whose name was not disclosed, was suspected of "assisting in the murder" of Ms. Holloway, an Alabama high school senior. The man was arrested Wednesday and is being questioned in the city of Utrecht, Mr. Spong said. He has not been formally charged. Mr. Spong said the suspect was a friend of Joran van der Sloot, the last person known to have seen Ms. Holloway alive, and had been questioned three times in Aruba shortly after the disappearance.

A 15-year-old girl in Latta led a small protest march of about a dozen people over her high school's ban on clothing featuring the Confederate flag. The girl, Candice Hardwick, marched a few blocks to her high school wearing a Confederate belt buckle and button. Ms. Hardwick, who is also challenging the ban in court, says she wants to wear the emblem to pay tribute to ancestors who fought on the Confederate side of the Civil War.

A mistrial was declared after all but 1 of 12 jurors told a federal judge that they were unable to reach a unanimous verdict on any of the 24 felony charges of public corruption against Robert E. Vigil, who is accused of extorting kickbacks from investment counselors while he served as state treasurer from 2003 to 2005. After Judge James A. Parker of Federal District Court in Albuquerque rejected a request by prosecutors for the jury to continue deliberating, they said they would try Mr. Vigil again. Michael A. Montoya, Mr. Vigil's predecessor, pleaded guilty in 2005 to extortion in a similar case.

A woman who the authorities said was fatally shot by her husband after he killed four of her relatives at a church service in Baton Rouge received a temporary restraining order against him last year. The woman, Erica Bell, 24, filed her request in December, saying her husband, Anthony Bell, sometimes beat her and once gave her a black eye. But at her request, the restraining order was dismissed Jan. 3, court records show. Mr. Bell, 25, of Baton Rouge, was charged with murder, attempted murder and kidnapping in the attack on Sunday. He was being held without bail.

AIRPORT CROWDS Domestic airports are more crowded than ever, so book early and arrive early as the peak summer travel season approaches. More than 1.52 billion passengers traveled through airports in North America in 2005, according to the Airports Council International-North America; that number is an increase of 4.3 percent from 2004. The busiest airport was Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International (85.9 million passengers). Next in the top 5 were Chicago O'Hare (76.5 million); Los Angeles International (61.5 million); Dallas/Fort Worth International (59.2 million); and McCarran International in Las Vegas (44 million). Passenger traffic is defined as the total of arriving and departing passengers, though connecting passengers are counted only once. Meanwhile, airlines have fewer employees to handle the crush. Domestic airlines had 5.4 percent fewer workers in March of this year than in March 2005. It was the 15th consecutive month that airline employment levels fell compared with the month in the previous year, the Bureau of Transportation Statistics of the Transportation Department said.

(CBS) THE 41ST ANNUAL ACADEMY OF COUNTRY MUSIC AWARDS -- ''Country Music's Biggest Party'' just got bigger with a move to MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, which holds 17,157 and was patterned after Madison Square Garden. The bright-eyed Reba McEntire, in her eighth turn as host, will introduce performers including Rascal Flatts, Kenney Chesney, Big & Rich, Martina McBride and two ''American Idol'' winners: Kelly Clarkson, who earned two Grammys in February but neglected to thank the show that gave her a jumpstart, and Carrie Underwood (above), a contender tonight with four nominations. Wonder what she'll say. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- Blood may be spilled on this Night of Nights, when Taylor Hicks pits his gravelly funk against Katharine McPhee's saccharine crooning in what ultimately boils down to a gladiator-like battle of the overheated voters. 8 P.M. (ABC) STEPHEN KING'S DESPERATION -- Something wicked -- and very, very determined to keep a secret -- this way comes in this three-hour made-for-television movie, set in a remote Nevada mining town named Desperation. Tom Skerritt, Steven Weber, Annabeth Gish, Henry Thomas, Matt Frewer and Charles Durning portray some of the town's reluctant heroes. Ron Perlman (above) plays Sheriff Collie Entragian, who isn't feeling much like his old self these days. 9 P.M. (NBC) 10.5: APOCALYPSE -- Part 2 of 2. The big one has hit, and all of North America continues to shake, rattle and roll. 9 P.M. (Fox) HOUSE -- Season finale. We know his bedside manner has all the subtlety of a sledgehammer. But when a disgruntled former patient (Elias Koteas) walks into the office of Gregory House M.D., and shoots him, well, that's going a bit far, isn't it? Imagine, then, when House has to share his hospital room with this wacko. And now imagine when he can walk without his cane. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) JAMIE KENNEDY'S BLOWIN' UP -- Mr. Kennedy, in his somewhat misguided quest to become a hip-hop superstar, accepts a cameo on ''Law & Order: SVU.'' Anything to meet Ice T. 11:35 P.M.
