OFFER FOR EUROPEAN MARKETS -- The New York Stock Exchange's parent took a big step toward the creation of a global marketplace by offering to acquire Euronext, the operator of five European stock and futures exchanges, for $10.2 billion in cash and shares. [Page A1.] THE STOCK SLUMP -- A three-year bull run in stocks has lost strength in recent weeks as concerns mount about higher inflation and slower growth. Shares fell again yesterday after sharp declines in Asia and Europe, especially on emerging markets. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.73 points, to 11,125.33. Market Place [C1.] GAS PRICE INQUIRY -- Despite suspicions among consumers about rapidly rising gasoline prices and record oil industry profits, a federal investigation has concluded that the jump at the pump over the last year has not been a result of unlawful price manipulation. [C1.] UNEASY TIES -- The State Department's decision to keep personal computers made by Lenovo of China off its networks that handle classified government messages and documents points to how much relations between the United States and China have become a tangled web of political, trade and security issues. [C1.] GOOGLE VIDEO ADS -- Google is taking its first steps to go after the huge market for television advertising with a new service that will place video commercials on the many Web sites on which it sells advertising. For now, Google isn't placing video advertising on Google.com or the other sites it runs, but it says it is considering doing so in the future. Advertising. [C3.] RIVALS GAIN ON VONAGE -- Vonage, which is expected to go public this week, has become synonymous with phone service over the Internet thanks to relentless marketing and low prices. But others are rapidly catching up. [C1.] IMMIGRATION REVISITED -- As the immigration debate boils, the halls of Congress are haunted by the failed amnesty legislation of 1986. Senators who hope to put the nation's illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship say they have learned from the past. But some members of Congress and former immigration officials fear history will repeat itself. [A20.] LAY TAKES STAND -- The former chief executive of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay, took the witness stand in a trial in Houston. Meanwhile, a jury from an earlier case against Mr. Lay and his co-defendant Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, deliberated for a second full day. [C3.] SINGAPORE CASINOS -- Next month, Singapore's government -- which under Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, left, has lifted a ban against casinos -- is due to choose a company to build the first of two planned resorts. The list includes some of the biggest names in Las Vegas. [C1.] OPTIONS INQUIRY GROWS -- Juniper Networks, F5 Networks, Openwave Systems and Brooks Automation said they were contacted by the authorities as an inquiry into executive stock option grants widened. [C7.] WIRELESS NETWORK -- In an ambitious proposal, a Silicon Valley company, M2Z Networks, has asked the government to give it a band of radio spectrum for a free high-speed wireless Internet network that would cover most of the country and be supported by advertising. [C3.] HOLLYWOOD LAW -- Three months after the indictment of Anthony Pellicano, the private eye who prosecutors say routinely wiretapped enemies of the rich and famous, the high-priced lawyers who do Hollywood's business are waking to a grim truth: the government believes they are the problem. [E1.] WAL-MART EXITS KOREA -- Wal-Mart Stores agreed to sell its 16 South Korean outlets to Shinsegae, a local retailer, for $882 million, becoming the latest global brand to flounder in an economy with some of the most demanding consumers. [C5.] EX-EXECUTIVES INDICTED -- Lance K. Poulsen, former chairman of National Century Financial Enterprises, and six other former executives were indicted on charges of plotting to defraud investors in the company, a health care finance concern that is now bankrupt. [C9.] LOWE'S CUTS FORECAST -- The Lowe's Companies, the home-improvement retailer, said first-quarter profit rose 44 percent on higher sales of appliances and lawn mowers, but the company cut its annual revenue forecast. Net income climbed to $841 million from $586 million in the period a year earlier. [C9.] ONLINE A DO-IT-HERSELF TREND -- In 2003, a purchaser of a kitchen cabinet was far more likely to be a man, but in 2005, such a buyer was almost as likely to be a woman. A report is at nytimes.com/business. THE CLASSICS -- Previous columns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/pages/timesselect. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.

To the Editor: Re ''Press One for English'' (editorial, May 20): Senator James Inhofe's ''English only'' amendment to the immigration bill is a punitive response to a genuine need. Immigrants cannot simply be mandated to speak and write English. They need teachers and tutors to help them do so.

While speaking about owners and coaches who criticize the officiating, N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern said yesterday that Washington Coach Eddie Jordan had been fined $25,000 for suggesting that the referees favored Cleveland's LeBron James and that James had traveled at the end of Game 3 in the teams' first-round series. LIZ ROBBINS (NYT)

An article on Friday about the Senate confirmation hearing for Gen. Michael V. Hayden rendered a phrase incorrectly in a quotation in which he suggested that he would share intelligence information with Congress. Invoking what he called a ''crude airman's metaphor,'' General Hayden said, ''If you want people at the crash, you've got to put them on the manifest.'' He did not say, ''If you want people with the craft.''
To the Editor: It's precisely because Americans are fed up because they have to ''press one for English'' that the Senate voted for English to be the national language.

GOODMAN--Anthony R. Beloved husband of Zmira Goodman for almost 52 years, on May 20, 2006 at The Mount Sinai Hospital after a long and valiant battle with heart disease and cancer. A perceptive and talented individual of great integrity and outstanding wit, Tony was born in London and educated at Oxford University where he received his degrees with Honors in Politics, Philosophy and Economics in 1953. Singled out as one of three promising young students at Oxford, he was selected to join Reuters upon graduation, and Fleet Street immediately became his home. Tony was a respected journalist whose career with Reuters spanned over four decades, twenty years of which were at the U.N. His in-depth and incisive reporting, particulary on topics concerning sensitive regions around the world, earned him wide esteem in the international community. He covered a variety of assignments around the world, among them a stint in Iran after the takeover of the U.S. Embassy. In addition to his devoted wife Zmira, he is survived by an extended family of cousins in England and Canada, and by scores of friends and colleagues who will miss him dearly. Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on Wednesday, May 24 at 11:15AM. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in care of Valentin Fuster, M.D., at The Cardiovascular Institute of Mount Sinai Medical Center. $(6$)GOODMAN--Anthony. Beloved husband of our dear friend, Zmira Goodman, we will always cherish Tony's keen insight, great charm and incomparable sense of humor. Heartfelt condolences. Hank and Irma Damhuis

To the Editor: The tragedy of Barbaro raises the issue of breeding pressures for racehorses: they must be both light of bone, and strong. Does this create creatures whose bones cannot withstand the force of their stride?

An article on Saturday about the heckling of Senator John McCain before his speech to graduates of the New School in Manhattan referred incorrectly in some copies to a student selected by university deans to speak. She is Jean Sara Rohe, not Sara Jean Rohe.

DAVIS--Lewis, 80. Died May 21, 2006. He is survived by Anne, his wife of 30 years, four children, Steven, Michael, Peter and Ariel, and five grandchildren, Emily, Nicholas, Alexander, Zachary and Nina. He founded the architectural firm Davis, Brody and Associates with his partner and best friend Samuel Brody, and leaves a legacy fueled by a passion for architecture, people and the city of New York. His love, humor and stewardship were a gift to us all and he was adored by so many in return. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service at the New York Public Library on June 20. Gifts may be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, NYC Chapter, 733 Third Avenue, NYC, 10017 or the Mt. Sinai Palliative Care Program, P.O. Box 1070, New York City 10029. $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis, FAIA. The partners, retired partner Alan Schwartzman, and staff of Davis Brody Bond Architects and Planners, deeply mourn the passing of the firm's founder, Lewis Davis, FAIA. Lew, together with his friend and partner, Sam Brody, created a practice dedicated to the highest values of the architectural profession. Lew's body of work was characterized by a unique fusion of design excellence with social purpose, firmly believing in the power of architecture and its ability to enrich people's lives. Through his innovative urban housing to his public work at Lincoln Center and The New York Public Library, Lew touched the lives of countless New Yorkers. As a colleague and mentor, Lew was both a role model and a friend. His tutelage, both in the office and his teaching at Cooper Union, Yale University and at his alma mater, The University of Pennsylvania, influenced generations of architects. Through lifelong friendships with artists, writers and others in the public realm, Lew brought a true collaborative spirit to his work. Lew's contributions to architecture, the arts and to New York City were repeatedly honored through awards from professional, cultural and public institutions, including the American Institute of Architects Firm Award, the Thomas Jefferson Award for Public Architecture and the American Institute of Arts and Letters Arnold W. Brunner Prize. To all of us who knew Lew for so many years, we know we will never live up to his standards, yet we will never stop trying. Davis Brody Bond $(6$)DAVIS -- Lewis. Architect, mentor, neighbor and friend. Founder and heart of Davis Brody Bond LLP. For over 40 years, developed his firm to be one of the leading architectural firms in the industry. He is responsible for great housing, schools and industrial installations. He was a mentor and teacher to generations of young architects. We will miss him. Marvin A. Mass and Partners of Cosentini Associates $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis. You were my role model, my inspiration and my good friend. I owe my professional life to you through the knowledge, guidance and friendship offered to me as a young professional. To your dear wife, Anne and family, I send my deepest condolences. You will be sorely missed. Costas Kondylis Costas Kondylis and Partners $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis. You were always a true inspiration to me for all the long years we worked together. I will miss dearly your enthusiasm and friendship, your knowledge and support. I join your beloved wife Anne, your daughter, sons and grandchildren in mourning your loss. Marta Rudzki Costas Kondylis and Partners $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of Lewis Davis. A great designer and residential architect, he left a lasting mark on our profession and on the city in which we live through his generosity of spirit and leadership. Costas Kondylis and Partners, Architects $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis. The Waterside community mourns the passing of Lewis Davis, FAIA, the creative genius responsible for Waterside Plaza's award-winning architecture.

To the Editor: As an immigration lawyer who speaks four languages and is a former French and Spanish teacher, I resent the implication that because I support Senator James Inhofe's amendment declaring English to be the official language of this country, I am a xenophobe.

Dr. Lee Jong Wook, who led the World Health Organization as its director general as it struggled to cope with the spread of SARS, avian flu and other public health menaces, died yesterday in Geneva, where he was to attend the organization's annual meeting. He was 61. Spain's minister of health, Elena Salgado, announced Dr. Lee's death minutes before he was to have spoken to representatives of the agency's 192 member countries at the opening session of its weeklong meeting, known as the World Health Assembly. The organization, based in Geneva, is overseen by the United Nations.

Damien Hirst's Skull and Bones For Damien Hirst, sharks and cows pickled in formaldehyde are out. What's in are a platinum skull encased in diamonds and the latest rendering of ''The Virgin Mother,'' his 35-foot-tall, 13.5-ton bronze statue exposing the bones, muscle tissue and fetus of a hugely pregnant woman. First the skull, which Mr. Hirst, right, described in an interview with The Observer of London as ''certainly the biggest single undertaking by a jeweler since the crown jewels,'' Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Hirst said the work, titled ''For the Love of God,'' will consist of a human skull, cast in platinum and covered in 8,500 diamonds at a cost of $15 million to $18.8 million. ''The biggest expense will be the 50-carat beauty that will sit on the forehead,'' he said, adding: ''The only part of the original skull that will remain will be the teeth. You need that grotesque element for it to work as a piece of art.'' Explaining the artistic impulse, Mr. Hirst said: ''I just want to celebrate life by saying to hell with death. What better way of saying that than by taking the ultimate symbol of death and covering it in the ultimate symbol of luxury, desire and decadence?'' ''The Virgin Mother'' went on view yesterday in the courtyard outside the Royal Academy of Arts in London, the BBC reported. An earlier rendering was installed in 2005 outside Lever House in Manhattan. Madonna With Mirrors Religion and entertainment don't intersect only in ''The Da Vinci Code.'' Now the world has Madonna wearing a crown of thorns and suspended from a giant mirrored cross while she sings the ballad ''Live to Tell'' and video screens flash images of third-world poverty and grim statistics. This performance was seen in Los Angeles on Sunday, when Madonna began her first world tour in two years. Promoting her new album, ''Confessions on a Dance Floor'' (Warner Brothers), before an audience that included her kabbalah instructor, Rabbi Yehuda Berg, as well as Nicole Richie and Rosie O'Donnell, Madonna was 50 minutes late when she started the show by popping out of a mirrored ball in sadomasochistic riding gear (with whip), singing ''Future Lovers'' while four bare-chested male dancers writhed with ball gags in their mouths. Her tour will continue in North America for two months and begin a five-week European leg in Wales on July 30. Mariah Carey will tour for the first time in more than three years, beginning on Aug. 5 in Miami, Billboard reported. She will appear on Aug. 23 and Aug. 29 at Madison Square Garden, on Aug. 25 at the Mohegan Sun Arena in Uncasville, Conn., and on Aug. 27 in East Rutherford, N.J. Ticket sales for the tour, promoting her hit album ''The Emancipation of Mimi'' (Island/Def Jam), begin on June 2.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Iraqi Charities Bringing A Divided Land Together The Iraqi government has registered 5,000 private organizations, including charities and human rights groups. Officials estimate that another 7,000 groups exist unofficially. The efforts show that even as sectarian violence tears Iraq's cities apart, a growing number of Iraqis are trying to bring them together. A1 Only 48 hours after Iraq's new government took office, the British prime minister, Tony Blair, flew to Baghdad to discuss an issue crucial to Iraq, as well as to the politics of the war in London and Washington: when British and American troops can start to withdraw. A14 Underdog Surges in Mexico In the race for presidency of Mexico, Felipe Calderón, fond of portraying himself as the underdog, has surged past the front-runner, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, with a stream of advertisements portraying Mr. López Obrador as a dangerous, violent leftist who will bankrupt the country. A1 U.S. Jets Kill Afghan Civilians American military planes in pursuit of suspected Taliban fighters bombed a village in southern Afghanistan, killing 16 civilians and wounding 15, among them women and children, the local governor and villagers said. A10 New Ways to Recall Holocaust Israel, 58 years after the Holocaust, is trying to cope with the fading of history. As the number of survivors and perpetrators dwindles, Israel has been exploring ways of preserving the memory of the Holocaust, including trips to former concentration camps and bringing Israeli youth together with survivors. A8 A Redrawing of Balkan Borders Fifteen years after ethnic conflict broke out in the western Balkans, Montenegro appears to have voted by a bare margin to separate from Serbia. The move may be the last phase in redefining borders of the region, possibly leaving Serbia as the only remaining republic of the six that once formed Yugoslavia. A10 Debate on Aid to India's Castes As India prospers it faces a polarizing totem of public policy: a government proposal to extend quotas for admission to some of the country's prestigious federally financed universities for the lowest castes on the Hindu social ladder and indigenous tribes. A3 Former Opposites Unite in Syria Abdel Halim Khaddam, Syria's former vice president, and Ali Sadreddin al-Bayanouni, the leader of the Muslim Brotherhood in Syria, have formed the National Salvation Front, an alliance with the dual goals of unifying Syria's opposition and reassuring insiders fearful of change. A12 Paisley Rejects Leader's Role Ian Paisley, Northern Ireland's Protestant leader of the Democratic Unionist party, rejected a proposal by Sinn Fein, the largest Roman Catholic party, that he should lead a power-sharing executive body to revive the province's peace effort. A5 NATIONAL A16-23 Vast Data Cache On Veterans Stolen Personal electronic data on up to 26.5 million military veterans, including their Social Security numbers and birth dates, were stolen from the home of a Department of Veterans Affairs employee who had taken the information home without authorization, the agency said. A1 Democrats Try to Blunt Scandal Democrats' plans to make Republican corruption a central theme of their election strategy this year were complicated by accusations of wrongdoing in their own ranks, leading them to try to blunt the political effects of the unfolding case against Representative William J. Jefferson. A18 Challenging Schwarzenegger Two fixtures of Democratic politics in California -- Phil Angelides, the state treasurer who made a fortune as a real estate developer, and Steve Westly, the controller who made even more money as a founder of eBay -- are in a battle to take on Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, in November. A16 Congress Looks Back to 1986 As the debate on immigration reaches a boil, Congress is haunted by Senate Bill 1200, the failed amnesty legislation of 1986. Today, senators who favor a path to citizenship say they have learned from the past. A20 Disorder in the Courts In the nine months since Hurricane Katrina, more than a thousand defendants have languished in jail without access to lawyers. The New Orleans public defender system is desperately short of money and manpower, says Judge Arthur L. Hunter Jr. A1 Busy Hurricane Season Seen Forecasters predict that 13 to 16 tropical storms will form in the Atlantic during the six-month hurricane season that begins June 1. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Clintons Display Unity In Separate Public Lives Since leaving the White House, Bill and Hillary Clinton have built largely separate lives -- partly because of the demands of their distinct career paths and partly as a result of political calculations, according to interviews and a review of their activities. A1 New Trial in Subway Murder The mentally ill man who pushed a 32-year-old journalist and photographer to her death in front of a speeding subway train after he stopped taking his antipsychotic medication will get a new trial after the U.S. Supreme Court declined to consider an appeal from New York State. B1 Ex-Governor's Memoir Former Gov. James E. McGreevey, who resigned in 2004 after declaring that he was gay and that he had had an extramarital affair, was so determined to climb New Jersey's political ladder that he hid the fact that he was gay by masquerading as a womanizer, according to his memoir. B2 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Poet Inspires 'Seeing Machine' A poet and artist has enlisted the help of scientists and engineering students to create a ''seeing machine'' that may eventually help people like her, with severely impaired vision, to read. F5 Health & Fitness F5 OBITUARIES B7-8 Katherine Dunham The dancer, choreographer, teacher and anthropologist whose pioneering work introduced much of the black heritage in dance to the stage, she was 96. Yet to many investors, the slump only confirms that an earlier rally may have been hollow to begin with. To the Editor: Re ''Frankencotton, the Shirt'': Although your article on the use of recombinant DNA technology to genetically alter cotton was informative and witty, it truly does a disservice by using the prefix ''franken,'' further perpetuating the myth that somehow these transgenic plants are ''Frankenstein'' creations.

To the Editor: Re ''We Care. But Why Do We Care So Much?,'' by Jane Schwartz (Essay, SportsMonday, May 22): It's not because horses are childlike, requiring our constant care. We care so much because all of us from the ignorant to the aficionado can appreciate the grace and beauty that mark the horse's every move.

The executive producers of the Tony Awards ceremony have put an end to one of the richest topics of Broadway speculation in the last few weeks: Julia Roberts, right, whose theater-packing performance in ''Three Days of Rain'' was generally dismissed by critics and snubbed by the Tony nominators, will appear as a presenter. The speculation was fueled in part because last year other Hollywood actors who were not nominated for their stage work -- Denzel Washington and Jessica Lange, for example -- were not part of the ceremony. The other presenters announced yesterday were Ralph Fiennes, a nominee in the acting category for ''Faith Healer,'' and Cynthia Nixon, nominated in the same category for ''Rabbit Hole''; Martin Short, whose show ''Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me'' will open on Broadway in August; Alfre Woodard, who was on Broadway in 2004 and has had a recurring role this year on ''Desperate Housewives''; Eric McCormack, from ''Will & Grace,'' currently in previews for Neil LaBute's ''Some Girl(s)'' at the MCC Theater off Broadway; and Anna Paquin, an Academy Award winner who has been in several Off Broadway plays. The 60th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be broadcast on CBS June 11. As of yesterday, no host had been named. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

There are several South Korean films at Cannes this year, including ''The Unforgiven,'' an impressive first feature from Yoon Jong-bin. The film, which is screening out of the main competition in a section called Un Certain Regard, follows a sensitive young man (he listens to Belle and Sebastian) through the brutalizing first years of his military service. The film's complex narrative structure cost it some viewers during its first press screening (the scandalously bad projection didn't help), but those who stuck with it were rewarded by a film that, much like Roman Polanski's ''Pianist,'' shows how individuals can be broken by systems of power bit by soul-crushing bit. Mr. Yoon also wrote the script and plays one of the two pivotal supporting roles, as yet another young man who slips under the boot. Another offering from South Korea -- and the best film I've seen to date at this year's festival -- is ''The Host,'' which for some reason is screening outside the main festival program in a parallel section called the Directors' Fortnight. Directed by Bong Joon-ho, who made the policier ''Memories of Murder,'' this terrific hybrid-genre fantasy about a mutant creature with a lotuslike mouth and a steady appetite has been alternately described as a monster movie and a science fiction thriller, but is also a comedy, a family drama, a political critique and, at times, a seriously scary freak-out. Mr. Bong can shift moods and tones on a dime, and when the loudly appreciative audience wasn't laughing at the witty dialogue it was shrieking at tensely wound scenes as effective as any in Steven Spielberg's ''War of the Worlds.'' MANOHLA DARGIS

A classical music review in The Arts yesterday, about the Metropolitan Opera gala on Saturday evening commemorating the retirement of Joseph Volpe as the Met's general manager, referred incorrectly to the company's music director, James Levine. Although he did not appear onstage during the performance, Mr. Levine did attend; he was not absent.

To the Editor: Re ''Hello, My Name Is '' (Observatory, May 16): Today's scientists need to reacquaint themselves with a little word called ''anthropomorphizing.'' Giving animals human attributes used to be a taboo among scientists, but now it's done with reckless abandon: rats laugh, prairie dogs have language, monkeys are concerned with injustice, and dolphins play the name game.

GRAZIO--Alan Roy. On May 16, 2006, after a courageous fight against lung cancer, Alan Grazio, aged 66, passed away peacefully in his home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Everyone who knew Alan knew him to be kind and giving with a great sense of humor and an infectious laugh. He enjoyed life to the fullest and his passing will leave a large void in the hearts of the family members and friends whose lives he touched. Alan's memory will be long cherished by his wife Joan, his mother Sue, his daughter Lisa & her husband John, his daughter Diana, his grandchildren Evan and Alexandra, his sister Cecily, his niece and nephews, aunts and uncles, cousins and many friends. A memorial service celebrating Alan's life will be held at 11:00 AM, on Wednesday, June 7, 2006, at Saint Matthew the Apostle Parish, 335 Dover Chester Road, Randolph, NJ 07869, 973584-1101. Those unable to attend may send condolences to the grazios@adelphia.net to be shared with the rest of Alan's family. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation to Hospice of Palm Beach County or to The Sylvester Cancer Center at the University of Miami. For more information contact Aycock Funeral Home 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, Florida 561-746-5124.

To the Editor: Jane Schwartz asks why those of us not directly connected to a racehorse might care so much about its well-being. It may very well be because of the undeniable beauty of these majestic animals as they race around the track. But I believe in another aspect of the human emotional spectrum: guilt.

Abbreviated sneak peeks of studio movies are a publicity ritual at Cannes, and this year is no different. Last week, Paramount showed 20 minutes of one of its end-of-the-year great hopes, Bill Condon's ''Dreamgirls,'' and on Sunday it unveiled 20 minutes of Oliver Stone's ''World Trade Center,'' about two Port Authority police trapped under the rubble of the World Trade Center. (The film is to open in August.) The excerpt was shown before a screening of Mr. Stone's ''Platoon,'' his 1986 drama about the Vietnam War, showing here in the Cannes Classics section. After taking the stage with the three stars of ''Platoon'' -- Willem Dafoe, Tom Berenger and Charlie Sheen -- Mr. Stone spoke very briefly, in French, about what he called his ''work in progress.'' He noted that the special effects looked like something out of a Japanese science fiction film (they didn't) and that ''the truth must exist in some way to confront power and extremism.'' These words were followed by 20 unnerving minutes in which we follow a Port Authority officer, played by Nicolas Cage, from his predawn rise to when the second tower collapses on him. It would be both impossible and unfair to say more, other than that the footage looked good and was very upsetting to watch, primarily because it includes images of the actual burning towers. (That said, Mr. Cage's mustache does elicit concern since bad hair sometimes portends a bad film; witness Mr. Stone's ''Alexander.'') Like ''United 93,'' this clip made me wonder why Hollywood seems so eager to turn this raw national wound into entertainment. MANOHLA DARGIS

BROWN -- Joseph S., 89. Passed away peacefully surrounded by family Saturday, May 20, 2006, in Somers, NY. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 64 years, Shirley, daughters Regina (Mark) and Marilyn (Meredith), sister Lillian Lublang, and many nieces, nephews, relatives and friends who loved and adored him. He was a veteran of the Second World War where he taught celestial navigation in the Air Force, and was a member of the Counterintelligence Corps. He was a top notch printing salesman, former National Vice President of Bnai Zion, former President of the American Zionist Federation of Long Island, and an active supporter of Israel, an adventurer, sailor, and one of a kind individual. He kept his sense of humor until the end. ''How in heaven are you, Joe Brown?''

In an ambitious proposal, a Silicon Valley company has asked the government to give it a band of radio spectrum for a free high-speed wireless Internet network that would cover most of the country and be supported by advertising. The idea is to create something like an Internet version of broadcast television, using local and national sponsors to pay for what its promoters say would be near-ubiquitous high-speed access.

Q. Why don't the pictures taken from orbiting spacecraft, on the Moon, etc., show any stars in the background? A. Some such pictures do show stars, and NASA offers a Web link to one that does: eol.jsc.nasa.gov/Images/STS039-342-25.jpg. For the most part, however, pictures taken by astronauts are in the nature of snapshots, intended to capture some well-lighted object in the foreground, like Earth or another astronaut.

Though the women of Wisteria Lane are not the ratings draw they once were, the season finales of ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' helped ABC flatten the Sunday competition. ''Housewives'' (with Brenda Strong, below) delivered 23.96 million viewers to a two-hour episode that included ''Lost''-like flashbacks to the early days of the neighbors' lives. (Last May's finale brought in more than 30 million viewers, and a much higher rating in the 18-to-49 demographic.) Earlier, ''Home Edition'' was broadcast in two parts. The 7 p.m. episode drew 8.25 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates, and the one at 8 p.m. brought in a more robust 13.59 million, opposite CBS's season finale of ''Cold Case'' (13.1 million). Fox's season-enders of ''The Simpsons'' (8.23 million) and ''Family Guy'' (8.07 million) put the network in second place for the night among adults 18 to 49. NBC's earthquake-hysteria television movie ''10.5: Apocalypse'' (8.3 million), and before it an earthquake-hysteria ''Dateline'' (6.85 million) featuring a news report that spelled doom for San Francisco and most other places, succeeded in placing only fourth among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds. The series finale of ''Charmed'' on WB attracted an audience of 4.23 million. KATE AURTHUR

VAN DEN HEUVEL--Stanley. The Board of Directors of Goodwill Industries of Greater New York and Northern New Jersey, Inc. note with sadness the passing of our longtime board member, tireless supporter and valued friend, Stanley van den Heuvel. He joined the Goodwill board in 1962 and was an active champion of Goodwill's mission -to help people achieve dignity through the power of work. A graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School, after serving in WWII he joined Hanover Bank in 1955. He retired in 1982 from Manufacturer's Hanover, having become senior vice president and corporate secretary. Stanley, who always had a pleasant word for everyone, was made Director Emeritus in 2004 to recognize his outstanding service to Goodwill and the community. The Goodwill family deeply mourns his passing.

To the Editor: Re ''An Immigration Bottom Line'' (editorial, May 21): Achieving consensus for immigration policies is proving even more intractable than was true for campaign finance reforms. In both cases, most people believe that new legislation will be circumvented no matter what Congress does.

RUBINSTEIN-WEBER--Ruth, 86. Died on Monday, May 22, 2006 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Norman Rubinstein & the late Jack Weber, sister of Doris Selub and the late Norman Burtman, devoted mother of William S. Rubinstein (Sheryl) & Alan F. Rubinstein (Susan), grandmother of Mark, Andrew, Michael and Natasha, and great-grandmother of Emily and Nicholas. Funeral service on Wednesday, May 24, at 11 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Gifts in her memory may be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 8th Ave., 6th Flr., New York, New York 10001.
''Remember that it only takes one hurricane in your neighborhood to make it a bad season.'' CONRAD C. LAUTENBACHER JR., administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. [A16]

Aaron Copland and Igor Stravinsky, meet Chick Corea and David Benoit. Boosey & Hawkes, the London-based publisher of classical and contemporary music, which represents the works of Rachmaninoff, Steve Reich and Prokofiev, is getting into the jazz business. The company has acquired the rights to music since 1995 by Mr. Corea, below, who has a piano concerto coming this summer, and new pieces by Mr. Benoit, whose recent compositions include ''Kobe'' for orchestra and ''Peanuts'' specials for CBS. The company has also acquired the Second Floor Music catalog, which includes 3,500 pieces by the likes of Ray Bryant (''Cubano Chant''), Kenny Dorham (''Blue Bossa''), Bobby Timmons (''Moanin' ''), J. J. Johnson and Hank Mobley. ''Boosey's Jazz Initiative is a natural progression of our mission to publish the leading creative lights in music of our time,'' Jenny Bilfield, the president of the company's New York office, said in a statement. BEN SISARIO

Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a sharp cut in tolls paid by the more than 100,000 commuters who use the New York Thruway as part of a reorganization of the Thruway Authority. Under the plan, which requires the Legislature's approval, the Canal Corporation would become an independent public benefit corporation, and its money would come directly from the state's general fund. The plan would save the Thruway Authority $305 million over six years, with $110 million used to reduce tolls paid by people who buy monthly commuter passes. The rest would go to capital investments, customer service improvements and debt reduction. DANNY HAKIM (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''Make Poetry, Not War'' (column, May 20):

To the Editor: Re ''Learning to Live With Your Pet (and Breathe, Too)'' (Personal Health, May 16): Here's an appropriate song, to the tune of ''I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face'': I've grown allergic to my cats My sneezes make my day begin I've grown allergic to their paws, their whiskers and their claws Their tails, their fur, their meows, their purrs Are just like ragweed to me now From breathing out, and breathing in They run around all day quite happ'ly, shedding fur where'er they go; The furniture's quite covered now, my sneezes tell me so I've grown allergic to the bed Allergic to the couch Allergic to my cats. Carol Svolos Omaha

An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about plans by New York City officials to redevelop the Willets Point section of Queens, possibly through the use of eminent domain, misstated the date of the United States Supreme Court's ruling in an eminent domain case involving New London, Conn. It was June 2005, not July.
To the Editor: Re ''Rage Is Afoot in New York, or Should Be,'' by Clyde Haberman (NYC column, May 19):

MERRIFIELD--Bruce. The Rockefeller University community mourns with deep sadness the loss of our beloved colleague and friend, Bruce Merrifield, a biochemist whose research greatly advanced the understanding of the relationship between the chemical structures of proteins and their physical and biological properties. A Nobel laureate, Dr. Merrifield served the university with distinction for nearly 60 years. World-renowned for his development of a rapid, automated procedure for synthesizing peptides, Dr. Merrifield has been credited with making possible the systematic exploration of the structural basis of the activity of enzymes, hormones and antibodies. He trained generations of peptide chemists and his impact on the field is immeasurable. Dr. Merrifield was passionate about research and he was active at the lab bench into his 80's. He was truly one of the seminal figures in biological chemistry of the 20th century. He will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Libby Merrifield, a beloved member of our community who worked in his lab for 23 years, his children, and grandchildren. Paul Nurse, President David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Joshua Lederberg, Frederick Seitz, and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti
To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof complains about the trans fats in Girl Scout cookies (''Killer Girl Scouts,'' column, May 21).

MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL National League METS--Recalled RHP Alay Soler from Binghamton of the Eastern League. Optioned RHP Anderson Garcia to Norfolk of the IL. MILWAUKEE BREWERS--Recalled RHP Carlos Villanueva from Huntsville of the Texas League. N.B.A. MINNESOTA TIMBERWOLVES--Named Randy Wittman assistant coach. N.F.L. DETROIT LIONS--Released DT Dan Wilkinson. Re-signed LB James Davis to a one-year contract. JACKSONVILLE JAGUARS--Claimed OT Wayne Hunter off waivers from Seattle. Signed P Tony Gowin. BAKER--KeoraP. 85, Educator. Beloved wife of Dr. Elmer E. Baker Jr. for more than 60 years. Died on May 21, 2006 at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. Private services at Frank E. Campbell followed by intombment at Trinity Church Mausoleum. Donations in her memory may be made to The Lotos Club Foundation, 5 East 66th St. NY, NY 10021

Two ''Companys'' are a crowd, or so decided the New York Philharmonic, which has canceled its semi-staged concert performances of the 1970 musical by Stephen Sondheim and George Furth. The performances, scheduled for March 7 to 10, 2007, at Avery Fisher Hall, were to be directed by Lonny Price, with Paul Gemignani conducting. But then the Routh/Frankel/Viertel/Baruch Group announced that it was bringing a production of ''Company'' to Broadway in November -- this one reimagined by John Doyle, above, who has been nominated for a Tony Award for his direction of this season's ''Sweeney Todd.'' ''We have decided to put our production aside in deference to this wonderful production,'' said Eric Latzky, a spokesman for the Philharmonic. Another musical theater production to take its place will be announced by early summer, Mr. Latzky added. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

To the Editor: Re ''Link Is Cited Between Smell and Sexuality'' (May 16): My experience in years as a fragrance artist supports and adds an interesting nuance to the finding of a ''lesbian olfactory link.''

CHAIFETZ--Charlotte. Mom, 21 years ago you left us. Although the years have passed the memory of your love and devotion are with us everyday. Rest in peace. Sons, Barry and Alan Daughters-in-law, Maureen and Lynn

An article in Business Day yesterday about the response by health officials in Singapore to reports of eye infections linked to Bausch & Lomb's ReNu With MoistureLoc solution misstated the total number of infections uncovered by Singaporean investigators by early February. It was 19, not 17.

An article on Sunday about native West Virginians returning to their home state after time away misidentified the state that had the smallest growth in population from 2000 to 2005. It was North Dakota, not South Dakota. (West Virginia ranks 49th.)

Parents often fail to perceive when their child is overweight. In a recent study, parents were asked to describe their child's weight in words. They were then presented with a series of sketches, below, and asked to choose the drawing that most closely resembled their child. Graph tracks whether the child was: not overweight Overweight At risk for overweight And compared those answers to according to whether the parents said the children were: Overweight About right A little overweight A little underweight underweight Of the children who were actually overweight or at risk to be overweight, only 36 percent of parents described them that way. But 70 percent of those parents selected one of the heavier images when choosing a sketch. Graph tracks whether the child was: not overweight Overweight At risk for overweight Graph also compared how parents (looked at images below and) said their child was... Average Lighter Combined in chart Heavier Diagram/Chart shows sketches of children (boys and girls) ages 2-5, 6-9, and 10-13 who would be considered lighter, average, and heavier body types. Note: The body mass index (BMI) was used to determine if each child was overweight. A percentile of 95 or higher was considered overweight (85-94 considered at risk for overweight). (Sources by Dr. Helen J. Binns, Northwestern University; Pediatrics)

At first glance, it would be hard to imagine a movie more immediately topical than ''The Caiman,'' Nanni Moretti's new film about Silvio Berlusconi, the media tycoon turned politician who has dominated Italian public life for at least a decade. Indeed, ''The Caiman,'' which was released in Italy a few weeks before the recent Italian elections and which screened for the press here Monday morning, may risk pushing timeliness to the point of obsolescence, given Mr. Berlusconi's narrowly achieved and grudgingly conceded defeat last month by a center-left coalition led by Romano Prodi. It was therefore perhaps inevitable that the first question asked of Mr. Moretti at the post-screening news conference was whether the election had changed his perception of the movie -- which some in Italy believe may have influenced the outcome -- and its political message.

To the Editor: Senator John McCain's comments about the New School student protests were just as canned as his commencement speech: ''I feel sorry for people living in a dull world where they can't listen to the views of others.''

Two construction workers were injured by falling planks at an Upper East Side building site yesterday, the Fire Department said. One was treated for minor injuries at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Hospital, and the other suffered serious injuries, city building officials said. Ilyse Fink, a spokeswoman for the Buildings Department, said the accident occurred at 10:42 a.m. when a crane lifted a bundle of metal bars, which banged into wooden planks and knocked them loose from the 10th floor. The planks fell to the eighth floor, striking the workers, she said. The building is on East End Avenue between 87th and 88th Streets, opposite Gracie Mansion. The condition of the workers, who were not identified by city officials, was unknown yesterday afternoon. COLIN MOYNIHAN (NYT)
Apple's new, 13-inch, low-cost laptop, the MacBook, is a very sweet laptop that's gained more than it's lost.

I've been traveling in the American Corn Belt this past week, and wherever I go, people are talking about the promise of ethanol. Corn-distillation plants are popping up across the country like dandelions, and local ethanol boosters in Minnesota, Illinois, Iowa and even Washington State (where Bill Gates is jumping into the business) are giddy at the prospect of supplanting OPEC with a homegrown, America-first corn cartel. But as much as I'd like to have a greener fuel to power my car, I'm afraid corn-based ethanol is not that fuel.
The Times's Bill Hamilton visits the International Contemporary Furniture Fair. Producer: Craig Duff

Having set a personal record after lunch of walking from beyond the Casino square down to the paddock along the Monaco streets that will be used as the track - I did it in a little over 10 minutes, and it must be a couple of kilometers and the sun beat down hard - I arrived at my destination in a sweat. At my destination lay a typical Wednesday-in-Monaco-sponsor-presentation. Steinmetz, the diamond company, was showing off a couple of diamond steering wheels they made for the McLaren-Mercedes cars. But they had also commissioned the creation of a full-size replica of this year's McLaren, made out of two tons of ice.
So the comments to the Zone have been a real eye-opener over its first 36 hours. Ditto the comments about it, some of which have been a riot.

The first of 5,300 new army homes in Hawaii was unveiled this week. The homes, at Schofield Barracks in Oahu, all have at least three bedrooms and will "feature lanais in keeping with the indigenous architecture of the region." The houses are largely solar-powered, too.

The Bank of China's massive $9.7 billion initial public offering apparently did not quench the desire for shares in the country's flagship lender. Even as the bank was completing its offering -- the world's biggest I.P.O. in six years -- a group led by Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday offered to pay $2 billion dollars for a 2.7 percent stake in the company, Bloomberg News reported.
So how long can Mr. Outsider remain Mr. Outsider and still make his way inside?
Inspired by the recent pickup in bank mergers, analysts at Citigroup issued a 21-page report this week handicapping which banks might be in play - and which might be the players.
A June 7 fundraiser at Ditka's Restaurant in Chicago for David McSweeney, a Republican congressional candidate in a high-priority race for the national party.

A British engineering firm, Invensys, said on Wednesday that it had sold its building management systems operations in the United States and Asia Pacific to Schneider Electric of France for $296 million in cash.

As Enron's former chief executives await a jury verdict in their criminal fraud trial, Enron's former shareholders got a piece of good news (but a small one, in the scheme of things). A judge on Wednesday approved a $6.6 billion settlement with three banks -- Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, J.P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup -- that would resolve a civil lawsuit alleging they helped Enron mask its losses before it went bankrupt.

One prominent Republican who won't be at the party's state convention next week is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Asked today if he would attend, he replied, "I didn't plan to, no." He did not address his plans for the Democratic convention.
The Hansen Natural Corporation, a distributor of fruit juices and other beverages, could be open to being acquired if the right offer were made, its chief executive said on Wednesday.

L-3 Communications Holdings, which makes flight recorders and wireless telecom equipment, said Wednesday it had agreed to acquire the Crestview Aerospace Corporation, a manufacturer of aircraft components, for $135 million.
Free phone calls! Free phone calls!
"I was having to learn how to run and chew gum at the same time. Lucky I'm not a Republican." - William F. Weld.
Now you can make free calls from your computer to any telephone number in the U.S., courtesy of Skype. Don't say I never did anything for you.
"Indian Idol" offers marginal, small-town India the chance to rally around its own by rooting and voting for local contestants.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

John Spencer, the former mayor of Yonkers, was working the halls of the Capitol this morning, making his pitch to Senate Republicans that they should unite behind him in the challenge to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and skip having a primary.
Readers respond to Thomas Friedman's May 24 column, "A Million Manhattan Projects"

Shares of the Internet phone service provider Vonage Holdings dropped as much as 14.7 percent on Wednesday amid mounting skepticism about its closely watched initial public offering. The stock priced at $17 late Tuesday -- the middle of the expected range -- but traded as low as $14.50 early in Wednesday's session.

The entertaining bidding war for casino owner Aztar appears to be over, but TransMontaigne has stepped in to fill the void. Transmontaigne, an oil products marketing company, announced Wednesday that it has accepted a revised $11.25-a-share cash bid from pipelines partnership SemGroup. The latest offer tops Morgan Stanley's most recent bid of $11 a share.

Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq in 2001 turned out to be the biggest flop this side of Time Warner and America Online, right? Wrong, writes Alan Murray in a commentary in The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday.

Dissenting from the chorus of "who cares?" liberal-blog criticism of Tuesday's front-page story in The New York Times on the state of the Clintons' marriage, David Corn, Washington editor of The Nation, suggests on his personal blog that the subject is a valid one for voters to consider when they cast their ballots, particularly when the presidency is at stake. "Democrats ought to keep in mind that when many people vote for president they are voting to choose a leader not a representative, policy expert or manager," Corn writes. "For many, psychology - more than policy - drives the decision. They vote for personal attributes - not positions on health care savings account and trade disputes."

In what would be the largest overseas acquisition by a Chinese company, China Mobile is close to an agreement to buy Luxembourg-based Millicom International Cellular for $5.3 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, citing unnamed sources.

Speculation continues that Western Digital, a maker of computer hard drives, is a strong candidate to be acquired. The Washington Post on Wednesday cited a recent report from analysts at Bear Stearns asserting that a foreign firm -- perhaps Hitachi or Toshiba -- might buy the company, which has a market capitalization of nearly $4.5 billion. A Western Digital spokesman would not comment on the report.

On Tuesday Bill Weld called himself a "bomb-throwing, iconoclastic governor" during his years in Massachusetts. Given his panning of the 9/11 memorial design, which the tabs aren't letting him forget this morning, one wonders if his loose and unpredictable style -- which made him personally popular in Massachusetts - will come off as glib or just plain weird as he runs for the Republican nomination for governor this year.
Fifty years on, the Eameses' heirs get real at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair.
Trolling the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, visitors found wares from around the globe, many retaining the mark of its maker's hand.
Finns warm up to wood, a kaleidoscope you turn your head to see, an upscale chair downsized for a tiny market and more.

The Sara Lee Corporation said Wednesday it expects to complete the spinoff of Hanesbrands, the owner of clothing brands including Hanes, Playtex and Wonderbra, by September. The split is part of a plan, which Sara Lee announced last year, to focus on its food, beverage, household and body-care products.
MasterCard, the world's second-largest credit-card brand, will end four decades as a private entity tomorrow when it begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Pierre Danon is to enter talks with the Irish government about a break-up of the country's former phone monopoly, Eircom, once his backers complete a 2.42 billion euro ($3.11 billion) takeover of the company.
Eurotunnel has signed a preliminary binding restructuring agreement over 6 billion pounds of debt with its major creditors and will present the plan to other debt holders in coming weeks.
A trustee in Calpine's bankruptcy case has sued a financing arm of Philip Morris's parent the Altria Group, to recover $363.5 million and control of two idled power plants, court papers show.

Every October, some 50 former Home Depot managers, calling themselves the Former Orange-Blooded Executives, after the home-improvement chain's trademark bright orange color, gather in Atlanta to reminisce, chat about new jobs and pass around pictures of their children.

General Motors is asking a New York bankruptcy court judge to adjourn hearings for as long as two months to give the company and its largest supplier, the Delphi Corporation, more time to negotiate a union agreement and avert a strike.

A senator plans hearings on the defense-contracting practices that led the Boeing Company to agree to pay $615 million to end a Justice Department investigation. Senator John Warner, a Republican from Virginia, said his Armed Services Committee would not limit itself to Chicago-based Boeing, the nation's second-largest defense contractor, and would look into other aerospace contracts with the government.
The firm behind Morpheus online file-swapping software is suing eBay and 21 other defendants in a dispute over the right to technology used to make telephone calls over the Internet.

the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, announced settlements with the Fidelity National Title Group and First American, the number one and number two title insurers in the nation, resolving a two-year probe into illegal payments to agents and favored customers.

An investor group led by the Boston buyout house Bain Capital is engineering a dividend recapitalization of Bombardier Recreational Products of Canada that could more than repay the investors' original investment in the company, which makes snowmobiles and outboard motors, after just two and a half years.
Crispin Odey, one of the grandees of the London hedge fund world, warned that the industry could be doomed, likening it to a disaster at the Lloyd's of London insurance market in the 1980's.
William Spiegel, Cypress Group's president since 2004, has resigned and will join a startup investment firm headed by Howard Newman, a former partner at Warburg Pincus, The Deal.com reported.
AnchorFree has raised a $6 million Series A round to help it pull other free WiFi providers into a unified marketing and advertising system.
ArchPro Design Automation raised $4.5 million in its second round of venture funding. Investors include Intel Capital, the investment unit of Intel, and Santa Clara-based Entrepia Ventures.
Mechanology has raised $6 million to support what it calls the first major innovation in compressor technology in the last 30 years.
Sequel Venture Partners, an early-stage Colorado-focused firm, has added a sixth partner as it heads out for a new fund targeting $200 million.
Inrix, the first of what is expected to be a reliable flow of technology spinoffs from Microsoft, raised $10 million in a second round of venture capital led by Boston's Bain Capital Ventures.
Nordstrom told shareholders at their annual meeting in Seattle that it plans to repurchase $1 billion of its shares.

There has been a significant correction in global stock markets and China has just flagged another round of measures to prevent its property market from overheating. However, that has not stopped four mainland property developers from readying to tap the I.P.O. market. Collectively they are looking to raise up to $2.4 billion over the next month or so.

A former economic adviser to Russian president Vladimir Putin has warned that the planned flotation of the state-owned oil giant Rosneft would see "the London Stock Exchange being used to distribute stolen assets," the Telegraph reported.

Citigroup is in talks with China Life and other Chinese companies about joining its bid for a controlling stake in the Guangdong Development Bank, after the central government refused to relax foreign investment rules for the sale.
The bookseller Ottakar's is hoping for a swift conclusion to takeover talks with HMV, owner of the rival Waterstone's chain.
CBS is mulling the sale of radio stations in 10 of its smaller markets as the company works to streamline itself in the aftermath of its split from Viacom.

Stark Investments, a hedge fund with a sizeable investment in Mills, the troubled mall developer, has increased its stake in the company. Stark has purchased 720,000 shares in the company since late March and now controls 4.95 million shares, or 8.7 percent of Mills's stock.

The business models associating with open source software - code that is open to developers and freely distributed - are rapidly evolving, but still nascent. Recent events show one thing clearly: there is money to be made in open source. Not content to rest on their laurels while smaller open source players garner market share and revenue, both Oracle and Red Hat recently struck deals that have thus far proven to be wise.
Aleris International has agreed to buy Corus Group's downstream aluminum business for about 700 million euros ($894 million) in cash.

Reynolds and Reynolds has agreed to buy a software provider, DCS Group for 21.7 million pounds, or about $41 million including net debt of about 10.8 million pounds. DCS shareholders would receive 31.5 pence for each DCS share.

Deutsche Börse has no choice but to increase its bid for Euronext after Ejuronext's shareholders voted against a proposal that a merger with Deutsche Börse was in the best interests of shareholders and called for higher offers from both the New York Stock Exchange and the German exchange. The Telegraph believes Deutsche Börse is on the verge of going one step further in the bidding war with the N.Y.S.E.
Viacom, struggling to grow on its own, wants to build its international business through acquisitions and joint ventures, a company official told a media conference on Tuesday.
What kind of man is Kenneth L. Lay?
James Packer's Publishing & Broadcasting and Melco International Development are planning to sell $1 billion of shares in an initial public offering of their Macau casino venture, Bloomberg reported.
Citigroup's Smith Barney brokerage unit has agreed to pay $98 million to settle claims that thousands of current and former brokers are owed overtime pay and other reimbursements.
The Bank of China Ltd. raised 75.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($9.73 billion) in the world's biggest initial public offering in six years, despite a rocky time for Asian stock markets.

Northgate Minerals has begun a $435-million all-share bid for a smaller rival, Aurizon Mines, a move that analysts said would help Northgate tackle its growth problems but that left the door open to competing bids.
China is considering rules that would allow companies to use their own equity for acquisitions to increase the number of takeovers, according to a draft released Tuesday.
Companies are transforming the properties of backcountry clothing so that hikers and campers can live in the same outfits for days without any telltale smudges.

At more than $11 billion, last year's acquisition of SunGard Data Systems was, and still is, the largest technology buyout ever. But the deal may look relatively modest in hindsight, if Tuesday's predictions by some leading private equity executives are any indication.
At the Nuyorican Poets Cafe is a colorful gathering of seminary students, artists, actors, scholars and exuberant gawkers.

Vonage Holdings and its underwriters on Wednesday succeeded in staging an initial public offering for the Internet telephone pioneer. It was an important milestone for the company, which will need the funds to fend of increasing competition in a field it helped to create.
Apple's new, 13-inch, low-cost laptop, the MacBook, is a very sweet laptop that's gained more than it's lost.
Davis Guggenheim's necessary documentary about the dangers of climate change features Al Gore as the surprisingly engaging vehicle for some very disturbing information.
This sketchy documentary portrait of a summer camp for teenagers with Broadway stars in their eyes remains a cool distance from its subject.
Emmanuel Carrère's psychological mystery is a surreal reflection on perception, reality and memory.
North Fork Table and Inn opens on Long Island's East End, The Laundry reopens on Friday in East Hampton and 'Witchcraft comes to East Eighth Street.
In its first day of trading, shares in Vonage fell nearly 13 percent below its initial offering price.
The falling scores appeared certain to increase anxiety about America's academic competitiveness.
A Pakistani immigrant was convicted today of plotting to blow up the Herald Square subway station in 2004.
The detentions followed an elaborate series of raids involving 500 police officers across England, the authorities said.
A team of World Health Organization experts has been deployed to help investigate the cluster of cases in northern Indonesia.
An Israeli undercover arrest operation turned into a chaotic gun battle today, leaving four Palestinians dead and about 50 injured.
The head of the Veterans Affairs Department expressed outrage today over being kept in the dark about the theft.
Economists expected a decline in sales, reflecting the fact that mortgage rates have been climbing.
A deadly wave of racism has resulted in at least 48 murders and scores of assaults across the country in the last year and a half alone.
Israel's new prime minister sought support today for his plan to unilaterally set his country's borders.
The Canary Islands are suddenly the outpost of Europe most at risk of experiencing an infusion of refugees from Africa, and the European Union is reacting with alarm.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made his most scathing attack to date on legislation working its way through Congress.
The cloture vote makes it likely that the bill, which would provide a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants, will pass.

A court in Tashkent conditionally freed Nodira G. Khidoyatova, a leader of the Sunshine Uzbekistan coalition, a small opposition group that has criticized President Islam A. Karimov. She was sentenced in March to 10 years in prison on embezzlement and tax evasion charges her supporters say were politically motivated. Yesterday, the court ordered that she serve a seven-year suspended sentence instead, because she has two young children. She has reportedly paid $100,000 of the $230,000 back taxes companies controlled by her were judged to have evaded.

ALBANY, May 23 — The state's budget may have passed on time this year, but the process "has never been in worse shape," according to a bleak new report by State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi that faulted the Pataki administration for inflating its estimate of the Legislature's budget by $3 billion.

The Bloomberg administration has overstated its projected deficits for the 2008 to 2010 fiscal years by $1 billion a year, according to an analysis released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office. The analysis also found that the city will end the current fiscal year on June 30 with a surplus of $3.5 billion, slightly greater than Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has projected, and should expect a surplus of $400 million in the 2007 fiscal year, which starts July 1. The future deficits will not be as severe as Mr. Bloomberg has projected because some of the rise in property values has not yet been reflected in tax receipts, according to the report, which, however, also noted risks from rising interest rates, higher oil prices and a slowing housing market.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, said yesterday that they hoped to add 254 energy-saving taxis to the city's fleet, and an additional 204 that are wheelchair accessible. The City Council was to vote today on the mayor's proposal to designate an auction of 308 medallions in June for special-use taxis: 254 for alternative fuel or hybrid vehicles and 54 for wheelchair-accessible vehicles. Pending approval of the State Legislature, an additional 150 medallions would be sold later this year for wheelchair-accessible vehicles.
The court-authorized search of the Congressional office of Representative William Jefferson by federal agents was as unprecedented in the history of Congress as it was alarming.

The body of a 25-year-old woman was found inside her Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning after her 6-year-old son ran into the street for help, the police said. The victim, Patricia Torres, was found lying in her home at 2166 East 26th Street in Sheepshead Bay about 11 a.m., the police said, adding that they were seeking to speak with Ms. Torres's boyfriend. Officers had gone to the house about 11 p.m. Monday night after a 911 call reporting a domestic dispute, but the officers who responded were told that everything was fine.

The editor of an Internet newspaper faces prosecution for publishing a satirical article mocking President Vladimir V. Putin's recent proposal to address Russia's demographic crisis by encouraging families to have more children, news agencies reported. Vladimir Rakhmankov, editor of the Web site Cursive in the Ivanovo region northeast of Moscow, said his article, published May 18, contrasted Mr. Putin's proposal with an announcement that animals in the local zoo were mating at a high rate. Prime Minister Romano Prodi moved quickly to head off a dispute with the Vatican and publicly reprimanded his new health minister, Livia Turco, left, for supporting trials of the abortion pill known as RU-486, and his new minister for the family, Rosy Bindi, for defending proposed legislation to grant legal recognition to same-sex unions.
Kenneth L. Lay faces four charges of fraud and lying to banks, which will be decided by Judge Simeon T. Lake III and announced after the jury rules in the Enron trial.

The police dismantled a long-running antiwar protest across the street from Parliament in a middle-of-the-night operation, carting away dozens of banners and placards, some showing graphic images from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Brian Haw, left, who has held the five-year antiwar protest alone, was not evicted but was left with just one poster. He vowed to continue. This month, he lost a protracted legal battle against a new law that bars protests within a half-mile of the Parliament building.

North Korea said today that it would postpone groundbreaking test runs of trains across the DMZ. The runs scheduled for Thursday along rebuilt railroads would have been the first time trains crossed the border since June 1951, and were a high-profile part of detente efforts between North and South Korea since a pivotal summit meeting of their leaders in 2000. The official Korean Central News Agency blamed the postponement on the failure of the two Koreas to reach a military agreement on operation of the trains.

Support for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the detained opposition leader, has faded and her release from house arrest in Yangon is unlikely to pose a threat to political stability, the country's police chief said. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has spent about 10 of the last 17 years in detention, mostly under house arrest. Her latest detention is set to expire on Saturday, but Myanmar's junta has not said whether it will be extended. The police chief, Maj. Gen. Khin Yi, said she was unlikely to be able to draw large gatherings because her support had dwindled over the years.

Greek and Turkish F-16 fighter jets crashed into the Aegean Sea after colliding in disputed airspace over the sea at midday. The Turkish pilot ejected and was rescued by a merchant ship in international waters between Greece and Turkey about an hour later. It was not known if the Greek pilot had managed to eject, and Greek helicopters and navy vessels were still searching for him last night.
The grief-stricken team confronted high winds and rough seas and sailed with sail trimmer and friend, Hans Horrevoets's body, until it was retrieved by the Dutch Navy.

Eddie D'Hondt was fired as general manager of Robert Yates Racing in a shake-up of the struggling team. D'Hondt joined the team in late 2003 and helped guide Elliott Sadler into the inaugural Chase for the championship the next season. But Dale Jarrett and Sadler missed out on the playoffs last year and are currently 12th and 15th in the Nextel Cup standings.

A Roman Catholic priest in suburban Chicago who was planning to celebrate his 25th anniversary in the ministry last week has voluntarily stepped down amid accusations involving the sexual abuse of minors more than 20 years ago. The Archdiocese of Chicago confirmed that it had started an investigation into the priest, Robert Stepek, at St. Albert the Great Parish in Burbank. The archdiocese said it had reported the accusations to the Cook County state's attorney's office and the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services.
High school students in Libertyville, a northern suburb of Chicago, are going to be held accountable for what they post on blogs and on social-networking Web sites like MySpace.com.

The Texas Supreme Court justice who publicly supported his close friend Harriet E. Miers for the United States Supreme Court last year has been admonished by the state judicial conduct commission as using his office to promote her nomination. By telling White House staff members to send news media inquiries about Ms. Miers's career and religious background to him and discussing her qualifications in dozens of interviews, the justice, Nathan L. Hecht, left, improperly used his position to support her for the federal bench, the Commission on Judicial Conduct found. Justice Hecht, a Republican, said the ruling restricted his right to free speech. He hired Chip Babcock of Houston, a prominent First Amendment lawyer, to challenge it.
A man ran over three toddlers and two women with his car outside a McDonald's in Covington, southeast of Atlanta, the police said. The man, Lanny Barnes, 36, was in custody, and charges were pending.

A former Department of Homeland Security press aide from Silver Spring, Md., has pleaded not guilty to charges of sexually preying on a detective who was posing as a teenage girl on the Internet. The former aide, Brian Doyle, 55, submitted his plea in writing and was not required to appear at his arraignment in Polk County. Mr. Doyle, who resigned from his job after the arrest, faces 23 felony charges, including 16 counts of sending pornographic movie clips to a minor. Mr. Doyle was extradited from Maryland, where he had been held since his arrest on April 4. He is free on bail.
The Federal Communications Commission will not pursue complaints about the National Security Agency's access to telephone records because it cannot obtain classified material.

A state political advocate is betting that a proposal to pay one lucky voter $1 million will drive people to the polls. The advocate, Mark Osterloh, a Tucson ophthalmologist who has run unsuccessfully for governor and the Legislature, filed paperwork to put the idea before voters.

A man arrested in the Netherlands in connection with the disappearance of an Alabama teenager on the Dutch Caribbean island of Aruba was released from custody, a court official said. The release of the man, identified only as Guido W. because of Dutch privacy laws, means that he will not be transferred to Aruba, said the court official, Martine de Bruijn. The man's lawyer, Gerard Sprong, told Dutch television that there was not enough evidence to hold his client. The suspect was arrested last Wednesday. He was a dealer at the casino in the Holiday Inn where the teenager, Natalee Holloway, was staying when she disappeared during a trip a year ago.
