BAKER--Keora P., 85, Educator. Beloved wife of Dr. Elmer E. Baker Jr. for more than 60 years. Died on May 21, 2006 at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. Private services at Frank E. Campbell followed by entombment at Trinity Church Mausoleum. Donations in her memory may be made to The Lotos Club Foundation, 5 East 66th St. NY, NY 10021

To the Editor: Buying an energy-efficient light bulb or driving a hybrid car won't solve our climate problems. But these actions, done collectively, can be part of a team effort that allows Americans to be part of the solution. Katherine Ellison, instead of criticizing Al Gore and Environmental Defense for not being daring enough, would be wise to consider what place their actions hold in the overall climate change movement.

JOSEPHSON--Anne, 95. Died peacefully in her sleep Monday. She was a retired speech therapist, an avid reader and bridge player. She was the wife of the late Abe Josephson and the sister of the late Becky Goldspinner and Dr. Morton Polokoff. She is survived by her loving children and their spouses, Dr. Barry Josephson and his wife Dixie Roberts Josephson, Harriet Josephson and her husband Jack Sachs. She was the proud grandmother of her two grandsons and their spouses, Mark Josephson and Megan Josephson and Dr. Braden Josephson and his wife Dr. Sarah Church. She was the delighted greatgrandmother of Henry, Eliza and Theodore Josephson. She will always remain in the hearts of those who loved her. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 24 at 11:30AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York. Shiva will be observed at her daughter's home on Thursday and Friday from 3-6 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Women and Infants Hospital, Office of Development, The Program in Woman's Oncology, 101 Dudley Street, Providence, RI 02905.

An article in The Arts yesterday about possible repercussions for Hollywood lawyers in the government's case against Anthony Pellicano, a private detective, misstated the age of Daniel A. Saunders, the assistant United States attorney prosecuting the case. He is 43, not 42.

An obituary on May 17 of Lew Anderson, the last actor to play Clarabell the Clown on ''The Howdy Doody Show,'' omitted two surviving stepdaughters. They are Lorie George of Danbury, Conn., and Halley Leffler of Sandusky, Ohio.

To the Editor: ''Tension and disappointment'' in a marriage? They're not always together? There are good times and bad times? Wow, what a revelation! I've been married for 10 years, and much of what you describe in the article about the Clintons' marriage is true for almost every marriage I've ever seen, including my own.

KEYES--Marie A. (Bonanno). Of Bayside, NY, Saturday, May 20. Loving mother of Louise Rutkay & Gregory Isola. Cherished grandmother of Andrew Isola, David, Scott and Caitlin Rutkay. Mrs. Keyes worked for the NYC Board of Education for 25 years. Upon retirement, she volunteered at Old Westbury Gardens, and was Treasurer of the NY Microscopical Society. Memorial celebration to be announced. Condolences to Louise, 973-379-3259 or Gregory, 973-283-2650.

To the Editor: I know it's naïve, but I couldn't help thinking that the logical conclusion of Katherine Ellison's article isn't her submitting to the lack of leadership on global warming but her inspiring a concerted effort among mothers to do more than buy fluorescent light bulbs. With their children's and grandchildren's futures at stake, they could, starting tomorrow, build a culture of conservation, lower their thermostats, get rid of their S.U.V.'s, teach their kids restraint in energy use, and force companies, through sheer economic power, to confront the degradation of our planet.

TROLL--Walter Ph.D. Professor at NYU Medical Center for many years died May 21 due to complications of multiple sclerosis. He is survived by his wife, Elaine, sons Mark and Victor, daughters-in-law Lalli and Nell and grandchildren, Emily, Phoebe, Miya and Rajan. Memorial service will be scheduled.

Jason Giambi did not really need a day off Tuesday, he said, but he was not too upset about getting one. The opposing pitcher was the Boston Red Sox knuckleballer Tim Wakefield, who baffles Giambi. ''I stink against him,'' Giambi said.

AHRENS--Peter. We mourn his passing on May 22,2006.Peter was a successful broker and money manager.Until his death he was a vice president at Ladenburg Thalmann.In the 60s Peter ran the Champagne Gallery in Greenwich Village. Performers including Richard Pryor,BarbraStreisand and Woody Allen appeared at the club during his tenure. During the 70s Peter entered the broadcast business representing many radio properties across the U.S.Peter was an avid skier and enjoyed his country home in Stanfordville. He will be greatly missed by family,friends and business associates. Donations can be made to, Calvary Fund Inc. Calvary Hospital 1740 Eastchester Rd,Bronx,NY 10461-9955

To the Editor: Re ''For Clintons, Delicate Dance of Married and Public Lives'' (front page, May 23): I'm not quite sure what to make of your report about Bill and Hillary Clinton's marriage as provided by anonymous experts. What I do know is that I'll be looking forward to the same thorough reporting into the marriages of other presidential hopefuls, like John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani, including ''interviews with some 50 people and a review of their respective activities.''
A picture credit on Friday with an obituary of the poet and conservative scholar Peter Viereck misstated the date of the photograph. It was taken in 1997, not 1977.

GOODMAN--Anthony R. Beloved husband of Zmira Goodman for almost 52 years, on May 20, 2006 at The Mount Sinai Hospital after a long and valiant battle with heart disease and cancer. A perceptive and talented individual of great integrity and outstanding wit, Tony was born in London and educated at Oxford University where he received his degrees with Honors in Politics, Philosophy and Economics in 1953. Singled out as one of three promising young students at Oxford, he was selected to join Reuters upon graduation, and Fleet Street immediately became his home. Tony was a respected journalist whose career with Reuters spanned over four decades, twenty years of which were at the U.N. His in-depth and incisive reporting, particulary on topics concerning sensitive regions around the world, earned him wide esteem in the international community. He covered a variety of assignments around the world, among them a stint in Iran after the takeover of the U.S. Embassy. In addition to his devoted wife Zmira, he is survived by an extended family of cousins in England and Canada, and by scores of friends and colleagues who will miss him dearly. Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on Wednesday, May 24 at 11:15AM. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in care of Valentin Fuster, M.D., at The Cardiovascular Institute of Mount Sinai Medical Center. $(6$)GOODMAN--Anthony R. The Faculty and Staff of the Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Anthony R. Goodman, an award-winning journalist and news editor for Reuters and the devoted husband of Zmira Goodman, a driving force behind the establishment of the Cardiovascular Institute. We extend our deepest sympathy to Zmira and to the entire family. Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D. Director, Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute and The Marie-Josee and Henry R. Kravis Center for Cardiovascular Health $(6$)GOODMAN--Anthony. The Board of Directors of Americans for Oxford, Inc. (AFO), and the entire Oxford University community mourn the loss of Tony, a distinguished journalist and devoted husband to AFO Board member, Zmira Goodman. Tony was an Oxford man whose great wit, loyalty, humor, humility and humanity will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Zmira and her family. Paul M. Dodyk, Esquire, Chairman, AFO Michael G. Cunningham, Director, Oxford NA Office $(6$)GOODMAN--Anthony. We mourn and miss our dear friend, Tony, erudite and elegant, and extend sympathy and affection to his esteemed wife, Zmira. Joanna and Allan, Judy and Mickey

To the Editor: Katherine Ellison is indignant about the ineffectiveness of the political establishment in mitigating global warming. But her endorsement of the Clean Energy Transition, with its narrow emphasis upon currently deployable renewable technologies, is also equally ineffective, because these technologies are now too small in output or too localized, and are often not competitive in today's energy markets without subsidy. The Clean Energy Transition agenda is a positive step, but it seriously underestimates the scale and types of changes needed.

ERICKSON--Rodney, 89. Died on May 22, 2006, at his home in Pound Ridge, NY. Born July 9, 1916, in Chicago. BA dramatic arts, University of Iowa, 1938. Began his career in radio in New York and went on to be VP in charge of television sales for Warner Bros. President of Filmways Production. VP and Manager of the TV department of Young & Rubicam before retiring to his gardens. He leaves his wife of 50 years Jean, a sister Dorothy Kennedy, five children and two grandchildren.

To the Editor: It is our position that unlike the Holocaust, the Armenian allegations of genocide have never been historically or legally substantiated (editorial, May 16). Genocide is a crime defined by international law. As such, it must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt, not by, as you suggest, a ''preponderance of serious scholarship.''

There's not much to Bealo, a tiny village in Galicia in Spain's verdant northwest. Just a few hundred people live here on a mountainous peninsula that juts into the Atlantic. Their houses are simple white stone, with grapevine-covered trellises out front and small fields out back. Virtually every home has an horreo, a corn shed that looks like a miniature stone cathedral. Otherwise, the rocky hills are dotted with white and yellow flowers and quiet stands of pine and eucalyptus. It was my second week as the globe-trotting Frugal Traveler, and I was beginning to wonder if I had made a wrong turn. Bealo, for all its rustic charms, is not easy to reach without a car. From Porto, Portugal, I made my way north using the region's network of inexpensive buses and trains, dropping 9 euros here, 2.50 euros there. But none of the buses actually went to Bealo proper. About nine miles from Bealo, I finally got off the bus and called Miguel, a person I'd never met, who'd been text messaging me all day with offers to pick me up.

INTERNATIONAL A3-19 A Galaxy of Armed Groups Propel Iraq Towards Chaos The effort to arm Iraqi soldiers and officers, coupled with a failure to curb militia gunmen, has created a galaxy of armed groups, each with its own loyalty and agenda, which American and Iraqi officials fear is accelerating the country's slide into chaos. A16 Fear of a Nurse Exodus As the United States runs short of nurses, Senators are inserting a little noticed provision in an immigration bill that would lift the limit on the number of nurses who can come to the United States and, some fear, drain nurses from the world's poorest countries. May Block Criticism The American Civil Liberties Union is considering standards that would discourage its board members from publicly criticizing the organization's policies and administration. But civic groups argue that the reforms contain a loophole that will allow lobbyists to continue drawing on matching funds as they seek to influence officeholders. A Chevron television advertisement broadcast in Russia whimsically pokes fun at Europe's efforts to diversify its sources of energy away from fossil fuels. A breeze picks up on the streets of Paris, scattering leaves and newspapers and blowing a man's bowler hat down a boulevard in a mighty gust. A voice-over explains: ''As a source of energy wind power alone cannot do it all. Just to power a city like Paris would need 20,000 wind turbines.'' The camera pans up to show the Eiffel Tower converted into a huge lumbering windmill.

Lidia: Italy at Home is Lidia Bastianich's new magazine, which has just the right combination of authority and homey warmth, Ms. Bastianich's trademarks on television and in her books. The focus of the magazine is beautifully photographed Italian dishes presented with lots of tips. For example, she suggests never discarding the pasta water until you are ready to serve the dish, in case a little more liquid is needed. The first issue focuses on pasta, herbs and leftover bread; there is a guide to balsamic vinegar and Italian coffees. It is $5.99 on newsstands and in bookstores until late August. Imbibe is a new magazine devoted to drinks, alcoholic and non, hot and cold. It covers drink culture around the world, ingredients, gadgets, bars and news. Karen Foley, the publisher and editor, started Imbibe to fill a void. She could not find a comprehensive magazine about drinks. It is $4.95 a copy in bookstores, coffee shops and wine shops; $15.95 for an annual subscription of six issues at imbibemagazine.com

To the Editor: Re ''Turned Off by Global Warming'' (Op-Ed, May 20): While Katherine Ellison, a mother of two young boys concerned for their future, advocates for personal virtues like energy conservation, she suggests that a lack of leadership from both politicians and some environmental advocacy groups is the main setback for global climate-change solutions. Let's take her point further.

The body of a 25-year-old woman was found inside her Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning after her 6-year-old son ran into the street for help, the police said. The victim, Patricia Torres, was found lying in her home at 2166 East 26th Street in Sheepshead Bay about 11 a.m., the police said, adding that they were seeking to speak with Ms. Torres's boyfriend. Officers had gone to the house about 11 p.m. Monday night after a 911 call reporting a domestic dispute, but the officers who responded were told that everything was fine. AL BAKER (NYT)

To the Editor: I am a 9-year-old girl who goes to Girl Scouts, and I was insulted by Nicholas D. Kristof's May 21 column. When I sell Girl Scout cookies, many people ask if there are any fat-free cookies. We say yes and point out which are fat-free. If they choose ones with fat, it is not our fault.

A brief art review in Weekend on May 12 about ''Cady Noland Approximately'' at the Triple Candie gallery in Harlem referred incorrectly to the genesis of that exhibition and of an earlier one, ''David Hammons: The Unauthorized Retrospective,'' both of which exhibited copies instead of original artworks. Mr. Hammons did not respond to the gallery's efforts to contact him about exhibiting there, and no effort was made to contact Ms. Noland; neither artist rejected an invitation to exhibit at the gallery.

The editor of an Internet newspaper faces prosecution for publishing a satirical article mocking President Vladimir V. Putin's recent proposal to address Russia's demographic crisis by encouraging families to have more children, news agencies reported. Vladimir Rakhmankov, editor of the Web site Cursive in the Ivanovo region northeast of Moscow, said his article, published May 18, contrasted Mr. Putin's proposal with an announcement that animals in the local zoo were mating at a high rate. He called Mr. Putin ''Russia's phallic symbol.'' Prosecutors questioned him the next day and shuttered his office the day after that. The Web site was also closed. Mr. Rakhmankov faces a fine and up to a year in prison for violating an article of the criminal code that prohibits insulting public officials. ''It was a light article, not even satire,'' Mr. Rakhmankov said in telephone interview. ''I saw it as funny.'' STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)
Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the referendum on independence for Montenegro referred incorrectly to its status from 1878 to 1918. It was a monarchy, not a republic.

Prime Minister Romano Prodi moved quickly to head off a dispute with the Vatican and publicly reprimanded his new health minister, Livia Turco, left, for supporting trials of the abortion pill known as RU-486, and his new minister for the family, Rosy Bindi, for defending proposed legislation to grant legal recognition to same-sex unions. ''Ministers cannot express their opinions,'' Mr. Prodi said. ''They must speak about decisions, their consequences and their implementation.'' The rebuke came just before the lower house of Parliament gave Mr. Prodi's government a required vote of confidence by a margin of 344 to 268. The Senate approved Mr. Prodi's coalition last week. PETER KIEFER (NYT)

WHEN fresh basil hits the market, as it has in recent weeks, everything changes. It's not summer, but from a cooking perspective it may as well be. When I get a whiff of it in the supermarket, or when a plate of pasta with pesto makes its way into my vicinity as it did this week, I want to grab a bunch and start cooking. When I was learning how to cook, fresh basil (I grew up with dried, a substance that we could all do without) meant pesto, and pesto meant pasta. But just as we've learned further roles for basil (including, yes, ice cream), we now know all that pesto can do, from serving as a sauce for grilled food to being the base for salad dressing.

About 90 minutes into the 8:30 a.m. press screening of Alejandro González Iñárritu's ''Babel'' on Tuesday, something strange happened. There had already been plenty of startling images and scenes in the movie, which, like Mr. González Iñárritu's previous films ''Amores Perros'' and ''21 Grams,'' splinters time and leaps across space as it tells four parallel yet connected stories. But at this moment the audience was thrown jarringly backward, as a scene we had witnessed some time earlier seemed to be occurring all over again. Was this another example of Mr. González Iñárritu playing with chronology? No, it was something much more shocking and, at the same time, fairly banal. At a festival that prides itself on fastidious attention to technical detail, someone in the projection booth had mixed up the reels. The lapse was soon noticed, the audience began to make noise, and the house lights came up briefly before the movie resumed, in proper sequence.

This postseason may be a television turning point for the National Basketball Association, which for the past four years has focused on its cable coverage. TNT, ESPN and ABC are showing substantial ratings increases caused by a potent mixture of stars and close games. A record nine games went into overtime and 14 were decided by 2 points or fewer. And three of the four conference semifinal series went to seven games. ''I think this is a watershed year, and you'll see this as a continuing process as long as teams stay competitive,'' said David Levy, the president of Turner Sports, whose TNT has carried 39 playoff games. ''I think the N.B.A. is on the rebound here.''

Greek and Turkish F-16 fighter jets crashed into the Aegean Sea after colliding in disputed airspace over the sea at midday. The Turkish pilot ejected and was rescued by a merchant ship in international waters between Greece and Turkey about an hour later. It was not known if the Greek pilot had managed to eject, and Greek helicopters and navy vessels were still searching for him last night. ''There was no dogfight, no shadowing'' said Yannis Papageorgiou, a spokesman for the Greek Air Force. ''We sent up our aircraft to simply identify the intruding aircraft, not to intercept it.'' The countries have a long-standing territorial dispute over the Aegean and often engage in mock dogfights. Turkish military officials offered no immediate details on the collision. ANTHEE CARASSAVA (NYT)

Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland, below, center) brought down the corrupt American president on Monday night's ''24'' but ended up being arrested -- or rather, tortured -- by the Chinese government, which was still mad at him for breaking into its consulate the season before. The two-hour season finale of ''24'' brought Fox 13.52 million viewers and a victory among adults 18 to 49 in Nielsen's estimates. Fox was a close second to CBS among total viewers, as that network's night of finales was less even. CBS's schedule featured ''King of Queens'' (8.4 million), ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' (7.53 million), ''Two and a Half Men'' (15.7 million), another episode of ''Christine'' (13.28 million) and ''CSI: Miami'' (19.41 million). NBC was No. 3, with ''Deal or No Deal'' (13.99 million), ''The Apprentice'' (10.14 million) and the season finale of ''Medium'' (9.87 million). And ABC finished fourth, as the two-hour ''Alias'' series finale drew little attention. Jack (Victor Garber) and Irina (Lena Olin) both died, and Sydney (Jennifer Garner) saved the world (again) before a mere 6.52 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

To the Editor: You write, ''Many of those interviewed were granted anonymity to discuss a relationship for which the Clintons have long sought a zone of privacy.'' Nice job in going ahead and invading their privacy anyway.

Consider the strange case of Bruno Dumont. In 1997 Cannes showed that French filmmaker's feature debut, ''Life of Jesus,'' outside the main selection in the parallel program, Directors' Fortnight. The film, which follows a group of unemployed young people in a desolate town in Normandy, received a special mention and subsequently hit the festival rounds. Like critics, festival programmers tend to have a proprietary relationship with directors they feel they have had a hand in discovering, so when Mr. Dumont was invited back to Cannes two years later with his second film, ''Humanity,'' it was no surprise that this time he was welcomed into the main competition. During its first press screening ''Humanity'' suffered a fair share of critical derision, telegraphed with choruses of giggles, but nonetheless picked up three major awards. Cannes understandably passed on Mr. Dumont's follow-up film, ''Twentynine Palms,'' a violent folly about two Europeans tooling around the California desert in a symbolically overloaded Hummer. Now Mr. Dumont is back in competition at Cannes with ''Flandres,'' about a young French farmer named Demester who goes off to fight in some unnamed war in an unspecified Arab country. Once again, the filmmaker's favorite themes and tropes are mostly present, notably the narcoleptic pacing, human faces as cragged as landscapes, ritualistic rutting and, regrettably, allusions to Robert Bresson, one of the art's holy men.

To the Editor: Katherine Ellison is right in saying we are living through an extraordinary failure to respond to the danger of human-caused global warming, which every year is less looming and more actually upon us. The grip of torpor, denial and inertia is worldwide, but is strongest of all in the United States.

A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with a theater review of ''Hamlet,'' at Theater Five on West 43rd Street, misidentified the character played by George Ashiotis in the scene shown. It was the ghost of Hamlet's father, not Claudius -- a role also played by Mr. Ashiotis.

HOLLANDER--Wilbur (Bill). A copy editor at the New York Times for 40 years until his retirement in 2001, died May 14 at Vassar Brothers Medical Center in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. after a brief illness. He was 80. Born in Detroit, Michigan, Mr. Hollander was the second of four sons of Emil and Berte Hollander. His father led an orchestra that accompanied the then silent movies and his early life was spent traveling with his family throughout the eastern United States. During World War II, he served with the Marines in the Pacific Theater. He subsequently attended the State University of Iowa at Iowa City, receiving his Master's degree from its School of Journalism in 1952. He worked for Moody's Financial News, for the New York Post and finally for the New York Times where he spent most of his professional life. He worked on the real estate desk there for 16 years until his retirement. According to his colleagues, he was the epitome of an old-time newspaperman with his Lou Grant smile and cigar and daily lunch at Gough's, a now defunct newsmen's watering hole, who totally lived his passion, to be a meticulous, honest editor. Mr. Hollander's wife Shirley died in 1983. He met his companion Janet Bertomen, in 1985. In recent years, they divided their time between Ms. Bertomen's Millerton, N.Y. home and a Manhattan apartment. In addition to Ms. Bertomen, Mr. Hollander is survived by his nephews Eric Hollander of Irvine, CA, and David Hollander of Virginia Beach, VA and three grandnephews and a grandniece. A memorial mass was celebrated at Transfiguration Church in Manhattan, 29 Mott Street on Tuesday, May 23, at 6 P.M. The Reverend Raymond Nobiletti officiated.
The biographical note with Ted Koppel's column on Monday misidentified the company where he is the managing editor. It is the Discovery Channel, not the Discovery Network.

The skin of a Taylor's Gold pear has the matte-brown finish typical of a Bosc. But its generous, wide hips suggest Comice. Inside, the flesh is creamy white, exceptionally juicy and fragrant. It is a Comice mutation first discovered in 1986 in an orchard on New Zealand's South Island. Its season in New Zealand is fall, but below the Equator that is the equivalent of our spring, from April until mid-June. Agata & Valentina has the pears until the second week of June, $2.49 a pound. They are also available from some fruit-of-the-month clubs, like www.gotfruit.com, which will have them as a June selection. The pears are starting to be cultivated in the Pacific Northwest; at Harvest Deluxe, at www.cherrymoonfarms.com, they will be the October selection in the fruit-of-the-month lineup.

HIRSCHHORN--Herbert H. Born in Brooklyn, New York, April 13, 1909; admitted to the Bar, 1934, New York; U.S. Supreme Court, 1962; U.S. District Court, Southern and Eastern Districts of New York, 1966; U.S. District Court, Western District of New York, 1966; U.S. Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, 1966. Education: New York University -Bachelor of Arts, 1930; Doctor of Jurisprudence, 1932; Doctor of Juridical Science, 1934; Master of Arts, 1937. Director Emeritus of the New York University Alumni Federation. Recipient: Meritorious Service Award, New York University, 1982; Life Membership in the Albert Gallatin Associates of New York University, 1991. Distinguished Service Awards Washington Square College and New York University, 1992; Judge Edward Weinfeld Associate and Award, New York University Law Center, 1993. Inscribed on the New York University School of Law Wall of Honor, 1996; Honorary Life Member of the board of Directors of the College of Arts and Science at New York University, 1999; Director Emeritus of the New York University School of Law Alumni Association, 2000; Charter Member of the Society of the Torch, The President's Council, The Golden Circle and the Medallion Society at New York University. Member: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York; New York State and American Bar Associations; New York County Lawyers Association; American Judicature Society; The Association of Trial Lawyers of America; Society of Medical Jurisprudence; The International Association of Jewish Lawyers and Jurists; Jewish Lawyers' Guild; Metropolitan Women's Bar Association; New York Women's Bar Association; New York State Trial Lawyers Association (Director, 1954-1980; Director Emeritus, 1982-). Mr. Hirschhorn had been associated with the New York City law firm, Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf and with Dr. Harry A. Gair (Honoris Causa), the founder of its predecessor firm, since December 1932. He was an Honorary Trustee and former President (1955-1959) of the Mount Freedom Jewish Center (Randolph, New Jersey); an Honorary Trustee and former Vice-President of the Prospect Park Jewish Center (Brooklyn, New York); a Founding Member of the Fifth Avenue Synagogue (New York City); and a Member of the Wall Street and Civic Centre Synagogues (New York City). He was married to the former Rose Berger on July 10, 1968. She died at the age of 87 on February 10, 1996. In their marital lifetime, Rose was his constant companion in his academic, cultural and professional pursuits. In their names, scholarships were endowed in Washington Square College, the Graduate School of Arts and Science and the School of Law at New York University. A grant was also made to the Bobst Library at the University. Mr. Hirschhorn was the son of Rae and Bernard Hirschhorn, formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Upon retiring to Mount Freedom, New Jersey, his father served as a Justice of the Peace in Randolph Township. He is survived by his nieces and nephews, Dr. Lynda Cowan, Carol and Saul Goodman, and Nancy and Craig Karlebach, his grandniece Nicole Karlebach and his grandnephew Jared Karlebach. Funeral services will be held at Mt. Freedom Jewish Center, 1209 Sussex Turnpike, Mt. Freedom, NJ on Thursday, May 25, 2006 at 11 A.M. Contributions may be made to Mt. Freedom Jewish Center or New York University. For additional information please call ''Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman'' 1-800-938-6372. $(6$)HIRSCHHORN -- Herbert H. The entire New York University community deeply mourns the death of Herbert H. Hirschhorn-distinguished alumnus and director emeritus of the New York University Alumni Federation. A fourtime graduate of NYC (A.B., 1930, Washington Square College; A.M, 1937, Graduate School of Arts and Science; J.D., 1932, J.S.D., 1934, School of Law), he was associated since 1932 with the law firm of Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf and its predecessors. Highly esteemed by men and women of the legal community, he achieved national eminence in his profession. He was also a man of faith, tirelessly serving leadership roles at synagogues in New York City and New Jersey. For his decades of exceptional service to NYU, he received the Meritorious Service Award; Life Membership in the Albert Gallatin Associates; the Distinguished Service Award of Washington Square College and of the University; and the Judge Edward Weinfeld Associate and Award. His name is inscribed on the New York University School of Law Wall of Honor. The absence of this wise, caring, and generous man will be keenly felt by the NYU community, and we express our profound and deepest sympathy to his loved ones. John Sexton, President, NYU $(6$)HIRSCHHORN--Herbert H., 97. With deep sadness we mourn the passing of our beloved friend, colleague, and mentor. The recipient of four degrees from N.Y.U., he joined our firm 73 years ago, and we will miss him greatly. His late wife and constant companion, Rose, predeceased him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his nieces and their families. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM on Thursday, May 25 at the Mt. Freedom Jewish Center, 1209 Sussex Turnpike, Mt. Freedom, New Jersey. Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf

CONTROLLING THE PURSE STRINGS To its critics, the compensation committee of the Home Depot board exemplifies the close personal and professional ties among board members and executives at many companies -- ties that can make it harder to restrain executive pay. [Page A1.] ABC NAMES NEWS ANCHOR Less than six months after ABC named Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff as successors to the late Peter Jennings on ''World News Tonight,'' the network announced that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment and installing Charles Gibson as the sole anchor. [A1.] 'LAPSE OF JUDGMENT' Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, publicly conceded a ''lapse in judgment'' in telling a television reporter at a Washington banquet last month that investors had ''misunderstood'' him. When reported, Mr. Bernanke's remarks touched off a brief furor among traders. [C1.] DOGFIGHT OVER PLANE The C-17 Globemaster III cargo jet, a $200 million flying giant, is at the center of a war involving the White House, Pentagon, Boeing and lobbyists. They are battling over whether the military needs more C-17's at a time when resources are being squeezed. [C1.] EURONEXT BIDDING Shareholders of the Euronext exchange rejected a proposal to merge with Deutsche Börse of Germany. But Euronext's chief executive, Jean-François Théodore, left, who favors a proposed tie-up with the NYSE Group, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, insisted that the German exchange was not out of the picture -- a strategy possibly aimed at spurring the American group to raise its bid. [C3.] NEWSPAPER DEAL The McClatchy Company announced it had agreed to sell The Philadelphia Inquirer and its sister paper, The Daily News, to a group of local business executives and investors for $562 million. [C1.] NURSE SHORTAGE As the United States runs short of nurses, senators are looking abroad. They included a little-noticed provision in their immigration bill that would throw open the gate and, some fear, drain nurses from developing countries. [A1.] FANNIE MAE REPORT In a blistering report, federal regulators said they had found that financial results at Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of mortgages, were ''illusions'' created by its top executives in an $11 billion accounting scandal. The company agreed to pay $400 million in a settlement. [C1.] OIL PRICES WEIGH ON MARKET Wall Street closed moderately lower after worries about the impact of high oil prices on the economy set off a late-day drop. At the close, the Dow lost 26.98 points, or 0.24 percent, to 11,098.35. [C10.] CLOSING ARGUMENTS IN ENRON CASE Prosecutors gave closing arguments in a second trial involving Kenneth L. Lay, the former Enron chief executive, in which he faces four charges of fraud and lying to banks. The jury in the first and bigger case deliberated for a fourth day. [C3.] DATA THEFT The Department of Veterans Affairs learned about the theft of electronic data on about 26.5 million veterans shortly after it occurred, on May 3, but waited some two weeks before telling law enforcement agencies, government officials said. [A22.] UPDATE ON NEW WINDOWS Microsoft said Vista, the much-delayed new version of its Windows operating system, was ready for its last and broadest round of testing. [C4.] DELL TO TEST STORES Dell, which built its business selling PC's and other electronics directly to customers by phone and online, has decided to try something new: a storefront. Dell said it would open two mall stores this summer as a test. [C9.] HOME BUILDER REPORTS The luxury-home builder Toll Brothers reported a 3 percent increase in quarterly income, to $174.9 million, but said higher costs for materials and labor, as well as steeper write-downs, would reduce earnings for the year. [C3.] SMART SHOES Nike said it was making running shoes that will be able to send data about the wearer's performance to an Apple iPod. [C4.] ONLINE THE TREO David Pogue says the Treo 700P smartphone is the Windows Treo without the Windows, and it's almost everything a user could wish it to be. Heinz Company has received a proposed growth strategy from shareholders led by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz, who has sought to pressure the company into increasing its returns. The plan calls for Heinz to cut costs by $575 million a year and reduce deals, allowances and other incentives to retailers by at least $300 million. An article in The Arts on Thursday about plans for the fall television season misstated the time ''The New Adventures of Old Christine'' will be shown on CBS on Monday nights. It is 9:30, not 9.

Below deck aboard ABN Amro Two, the crew felt a quick deceleration, then heard water rushing above. When the waves cleared, the spinnaker flapped loudly, shaking the rig and boat uncontrollably. The wind quickly built to a screaming pitch. ''I began grinding, but it kept flapping,'' the crew member Simeon Tienpont said yesterday. ''But there was nothing there.''

A sports article on Monday about Lorena Ochoa's victory in the Sybase Classic at Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., misidentified the university where she and Natalie Gulbis, a fellow pro, were golf teammates. It is the University of Arizona, not Arizona State.

The only thing that's missing at Three Tarts, a new shop at 164 Ninth Avenue (20th Street), is a cafe table or two, so some of the treats can be sampled on the spot. There is a lot to choose from, including layered parfaits in flavors like chocolate-banana ($5.50) and espresso-scented pots de crème in espresso cups ($5.85), right. Buttery cookies (mostly 45 cents each), chocolate truffles ($1.10 each) and miniature tartlets ($1.10 each) are a real draw. For desserts like the parfaits, pots de crème, brioche bread pudding ($4) and fruit crisps ($5), the price includes the glass, ceramic or china container to take home. The shop also sells gift items like ceramic cake stands ($57) and artisanal honeys ($19).

The Mets are allergic to sit-back-in-your-recliner-and-watch games. Too easy. They favor the finger-gnawing kind, the one that draws players to the top step of the dugouts, the one that amplifies the agony of a loss or the ecstasy of a thrilling victory. Last night, in their first game since sweating through three one-run games against the Yankees, the Mets came back from four- and three-run deficits, tying the score in the eighth inning, before Carlos Beltrán swatted a game-winning homer in the 16th inning to defeat the Phillies, 9-8, before a crowd of 28,958 at Shea Stadium.

To the Editor: Re ''In Medicare Debate, Massaging the Facts'' (Political Memo, May 23): Since I've done the math, I know that come September, I will be caught in the ''doughnut hole,'' where I will be paying for the total costs of my nine generic drugs. As a result, I'm rationing the pills I'm taking and refusing any new prescriptions that will get me to the $2,250 beginning of the doughnut hole all the sooner. That's not helping me.
Alison Leigh Cowan goes for a ride with a 94-year-old driving coach for the A.A.R.P. (Producer: Craig Duff)

While watching the first half of the practice this morning and thinking yet again about how little the regular race drivers go out onto the track during that first session - with most of the work being done by the third drivers, or test drivers - I commented to Richard Williams, the sports writer of The Guardian, that I thought that the system was unfair to the spectators. They pay a lot of money to come and watch the stars, and only see the workhorses slaving away cleaning the track with lap upon lap of setup and tire work.
The Times's Paula Dwyer discusses the Enron verdict. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

Here is an odd quirk of timing: On the same day a jury convicted Enron's former chief executives of fraud and conspiracy related to its spectacular collapse, the company announced the sale of its last major business unit. Enron -- yes, it still exists, as a vehicle to pay its creditors -- said Thursday that affiliates of Ashmore Investment Management have agreed to buy its international assets, operating as Prisma Energy International. The sale should raise $2.9 billion for Enron's estate, including about $800 million in cash dividends already paid to Enron by Prisma, the company said.

Speaking of World Cup preparation matches, last night at Giants Stadium more than 50,000 people turned out to watch Ecuador play Colombia. As always in these matters, not a single New York City English-language daily carried a word about the match, which ended in a 1-1 draw. Fortunately, we have the Internet, which gets us to the account of the match in the Quito daily El Universo. And in El Comercio, Jacinto Bonilla Prado gives us a more analytical perspective: "The national team presented a new physiognomy, with a very fast lineup after some changes up front -- a much more vertical soccer." Shades of Dick Young.

Making good on our promise to span the globe -- which, like the ball and the blog, is indeed round -- we see that The Sydney Morning Herald reports a big crowd was on hand today in Sydney to see their beloved Socceroos beat Greece, 1-0, in the Aussies' first pre-World Cup friendly. Thanks to the editors of the FIFA blog, here's video of the goal posted on YouTube - and a chance to hear the local announcer in Oz call it "an absolute cracker!" - J.K./R.M.

Just because you're American doesn't mean you're immune to worrying obsessively over the national team's poor performance. So let's look in on the hyperventilating taking place over the United States national team's 1-0 loss to Morocco in Tuesday night's friendly in Nashville. Newspaper accounts are one thing -- not that there's anything wrong with them, but they'll all give you the rational line, that it was the first time out for this group of players, that the game didn't mean anything, that it came after a grueling camp and that the main thing is to avoid serious injury. And on and on. But the fans ... they know. Take Sam's Army, the great grass-roots traveling support group for the United States National Team. In their post-match poll of members who rated the team's performance, the Amerks earned a meager 4.01 on a scale of 0 to 10, with Steve Cherundolo, the right back and goat on Morocco's 90th-minute goal, rating a dismal 2.88.

Wilkommen! Today we begin our World Cup blog for Germany 2006. This will be one element of The Times's comprehensive coverage of the tournament on the Web and in the paper. In this blog we'll be relaying news and notes from all around the soccer world to you -- and when the matches begin in earnest on June 9, we'll put you right there in the stadium, virtually speaking, even as you sit at your desks, staring into your computer. There will be live game reports and descriptions of breaking news, limbs and hearts relayed to you in real time, which will have you on the edge of your browser's refresh button throughout the day.
A. O. Scott reviews "An Inconvenient Truth," a documentary about the dangers of climate change featuring Al Gore.

Priceless? Not exactly, but newly minted shares of credit card giant MasterCard were certainly in heavy demand on Thursday. The stock jumped 18 percent in its first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Of course, the rise also reflected how the shares were sold at a discount to the expected price range -- they priced at $39 apiece, below the company's previous estimate of $40 to $43 per share. By Thursday's close, the stock was at $46.
Enron founder Ken Lay spoke to reporters Thursday after he was found guilty of all six counts against him, including conspiracy to commit securities and wire fraud.
Existing home sales fell 2 percent to 6.76 million homes, about what everyone expected.

The next big thing to worry about: foreclosures. It doesn't seem like a source of anxiety yet, but the numbers are climbing. Keep the scale in perspective as you look at some of these articles from across the country. We are coming off a low base.
More action in the virtual real estate of real estate sites.
The folks who run the growing empire of Curbed blogs have taken their manifest destiny to the sea by launching The Beach.
The federal prosecutors who tried the case against Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling spoke to the media after the guilty verdicts were announced.

Hoping to seize on Wall Street's recent embrace of investment bank stocks, Keefe Bruyette & Woods said Thursday it would pursue an initial public offering. The New York-based bank, which specializes in the financial-services sector, said in a news release that it "decided on this course of action given the recent strength of the market, the company's strong performance and growth and its continued optimism in the company's future."
In the run-up to the 2008 election, former New York City Mayor Edward I. Koch may be distancing himself from another former Mayor and recent political bedfellow, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

A mortgage lender, the Accredited Home Lenders Holding Company, said on Thursday it had agreed to acquire the Aames Investment Corporation for about $340 million in a stock-and-cash deal that will almost triple its retail branches.
Jeffrey Skilling and his attorney, Daniel Petrocelli, respond to the Enron verdict.
Maybe Robin Hood wasn't so bad after all.

After abandoning an effort to find a buyer while under bankruptcy protection, the outdoorsy clothing chain Eddie Bauer Holdings is trying again. The company, which emerged in June 2005 from the Chapter 11 reorganization of the catalog retailer Spiegel, said Thursday it had hired Goldman Sachs to explore strategic alternatives, including a possible sale.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's May 25 column, "Laid Off and Left Out"
Readers respond to David Brooks's May 25 column, "Of Love and Money"

As some commentators predicted in Wednesday's edition of The New York Times, things went from bad to worse for Vonage Holdings, the Internet telephone company that went public on Wednesday only to elicit a chorus of Bronx cheers. After dropping nearly 13 percent on their first day of trading, Vonage's shares were down almost 11 percent in early-afternoon trading on Thursday. All told, the stock was down more than 22 percent from its offer price of $17 per share.

Yahoo and the Web auctioneer eBay announced a partnership designed to improve their position against Microsoft and the Web search leader Google, underscoring recent speculation the two companies could eventually merge.
Former Enron chiefs Ken Lay and Jeff Skilling were convicted of conspiracy to commit securities and wire fraud.

Former Enron chief executive Kenneth L. Lay was found guilty Thursday of all six charges against him in the criminal trial related to the collapse of the energy company he once led. A jury found Jeffrey K. Skilling, who also was chief executive of Enron, guilty of 19 of the 28 charges against him.
A reader is seeking my advice on how to stop junk faxes. Now that I have a new, improved blog, I turn to you for help answering.
"I personally put away more dirty cops in Brooklyn and Manhattan than anybody except Rudy Giuliani." - William F. Weld
May 25 - Veterans Affairs Secretary Jim Nicholson said Thursday he is trying to find out why it took his agency two weeks to reveal the theft of personal data from 26.5 million veterans.
The tiny Hutch School in Seattle is designed to make it easier for students while a parent or a sibling endures a punishing medical treatment.
As the jury reaches a verdict in the trial of two former Enron executives, a look back at the scandal that rocked corporate America.

Potential buyers of utilities in the United States are likely to tread carefully, with two mergers mired in regulatory issues and local politics. Speaking at the Reuters Global Energy Summit this week, executives and regulators said that while more consolidation is ahead for the industry, companies would have to work carefully to get deals done.

Tired of the liberal agenda that Clear Channel insists on cramming into your ears every time you turn on the radio? Hearing too much Neil Young ("Let's Impeach the President"), Rolling Stones ("Sweet Neo Con"), and Kanye West ("George Bush Doesn't Care About Black People")? Fill your iPod with the songs from National Review's top 50 conservative rock songs of all time [$]. Introducing the list, national political reporter John J. Miller explains the criteria:

The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company agreed to sell Gartmore Investment Management Plc, the London-based arm of its Gartmore Group money management business, to a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman Advisors, for undisclosed terms, the companies said on Thursday.

Regulators around the world are examining the conflicts that arise when investment banks trade in their own accounts, according to a report in Thursday's edition of The Wall Street Journal. Though the article suggests this heightened scrutiny extends to the United States, the specific examples it offers are in Australia (involving Citigroup) and England.

The bankrupt Russian oil company Yukos expects to sign a deal on Friday to sell its stake in the Mazeikiu Nafta refinery in Lithuania to PKN Orlen of Poland after a judge in the United States declined to extend an order that would have blocked the sale.

WL Ross & Company, the investment firm run by the billionaire turnaround specialist Wilbur Ross, said on Thursday it had agreed to invest $100 million in a reinsurer, Montpelier Re Holdings, through a private sale of 6.8 million shares.
May 25 - A power outage between New York and Washington, D.C. has halted passenger rails on the northeast corridor. Thousands of commuters are stranded.

Apollo Management has agreed to buy industrial parts manufacturer Rexnord from the Carlyle Group and management for $1.825 billion, the two private equity firms said on Thursday. The deal, which is subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to close in the third quarter. No other terms were disclosed.

Citic Bank will follow in the footsteps of its fellow Chinese lenders, offering a $1 billion initial public offering in Hong Kong, MarketWatch reported Thursday. A source told MarketWatch that Citigroup, Lehman Brothers and HSBC will underwrite the I.P.O., which will be priced later this year.

Robert Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, may be ready to trade Washington for Wall Street. Speculation is mounting that Mr. Zoellick, who has worked for Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice for barely 15 months, may soon leave the Bush administration for a post at an investment bank, according to news reports.
The verdict in the the fraud and conspiracy trial of Enron founder Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling will be announced at noon.

The convention is a week away. So whom do likely Republican primary voters like for governor and United States Senator? According to a poll that the Siena Research Institute will release later today, the "don't knows/no opinions'' still carry the day.
President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain insisted that the election of a constitutional government in Iraq justified their decision to go to war three years ago.
Are any of New York's Republican stars going to next week's state party convention in Hempstead? Not Mike Bloomberg. Not Rudy Giuliani.

UBS said Thursday it would buy ABN Amro's futures and options business for $386 million. The deal would transform UBS into the world's largest futures and options trader, with about $13 billion of customer accounts on deposit, according to Bloomberg News.

A former Enron lawyer who went to work last month for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission vigorously denied involvement with the company's questionable trading tactics on Wednesday after two senators raised questions about her hiring.
Hollywood studios and television networks are asking a federal court to stop a video-on-demand service that Cablevision Systems had planned to start offering next month.
Four more companies said on Wednesday that they had received requests for information from federal investigators in connection with a government investigation of stock option grants.
The newspaper publisher Hollinger International said on Wednesday it had agreed to pay $3.5 million to settle litigation initiated by a shareholder, Tweedy Browne, in December 2003.

DHB Industries, a maker of body armor for soldiers, said Tuesday that it had received a letter from the American Stock Exchange warning the company that it did not comply with certain standards for listed companies.

Jurors in the trial of former Enron chiefs Ken Lay and Jeffrey Skilling finished a fifth day of deliberations without reaching a verdict on Wednesday, after making their first request for additional materials. The jury of eight women and four men, who have given no clue toward their progress, sent Judge Sim Lake of United States District Court a note shortly before lunch asking for lists of trial exhibits and transcripts of trial testimony.
Indicted dot-com financier Frank Quattrone and his tech mogul pals are raising millions for a tiny charity that helps free the wrongfully imprisoned.

The H.J. Heinz Company, the food manufacturer, said yesterday that it had rejected a demand by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz for representation on the board. Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, also said Mr. Peltz's demand to cut annual costs by $575 million was "unrealistic."

Robert Tchenguiz, the property entrepreneur, has acquired a minority stake in Mitchells & Butlers - just three weeks after having a 4.4 billion pound ($8.2 billion) bid for the pub company rebuffed.

the media buyout firms Abry Partners and Providence Equity Partners have settled their litigation over F&W Publications. Providence has agreed to invest in the specialty publisher and designate a member of its board of directors, a long-standing investor with one of the two firms said.
The Times Square building at 1540 Broadway is in contract to be sold to a combination of Steve Roth's Vornado Realty Trust and Sam Zell's Equity Office Properties for an estimated $825 million.

Nearly seven months after disclosing that it had hired a financial adviser to sell its Celerant consulting business, Novell on Wednesday said it has sold the unit for $77 million in a management buyout backed by a British investment fund.

During the technology boom, venture capitalists pushed Internet-related ventures as the answer to health care's woes, promising to deliver great efficiencies, create better-informed patients and indirectly help provide better overall health care. Those efforts largely failed.

Zeugma Systems, which takes its name from an ancient Mesopotamian city, has completed a $13.5 million Series A financing as it continues to develop a new telecommunications network optimization system.

Zipcar, a car-sharing service in such cities as San Francisco, New York and Toronto, has raised $20 million from GE Commercial Financing Fleet Services, the company said this week. ZipCar, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it would use the money to double its fleet of 1,500 cars within the next year and expand into other urban and international markets.

The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States has notched a few deal kills this year. But at least one of the committee's victims, open-source software purveyor Sourcefire, is grateful for the new lease on life.
Commerzbank, the German bank that owns Jupiter Asset Management, is considering floating the British fund management group on the London stock market despite recent market turbulence.

Kittiratt Na-Ranong, Thailand's stock market chief, resigned on Wednesday in an unusual show of responsibility as a result of the Thai bourse's losing what would have been its biggest initial public offering to its rival in Singapore.Thai Beverages, Thailand's biggest brewer and distiller, said on Wednesday that it had raised $865 million on the Singapore Stock Exchange, selling 4.89 billion shares at 0.28 Singapore dollars each, the lower end of its indicative price range of 0.26-0.36 Singapore dollars per share.
The Macquarie Group, continuing to expand its corporate finance business in Asia, has hired Jack Zhai, Stephen Panizza and Johnson Tan, FinanceAsia reported.
Ron Suber, a top Bear Stearns executive and one of several employees implicated by securities regulators in the mutual fund trading scandal, is leaving his job, TheStreet.com reported.

German media giant Bertelsmann said on Thursday it had agreed to buy back the 25.1 percent stake held by an investment group, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, for $5.75 billion, eliminating the prospect that the company could be forced to be a publicly traded firm.

Regions Financial and AmSouth, two regional banks based in Birmingham, Ala., announced Thursday that they would merge in a deal valued at $10 billion. The combined entity would have almost $140 billion in assets and operate 2,000 branches in 16 states across the South and the Midwest, Regions said. It will keep the Regions name.

China Mobile's reported $5.5 billion offer for Millicom is a rich price - and an effective premium of nearly 100 percent, says Breakingviews. China's deep pockets mean it can afford to pay and that means trouble for mature operators struggling to buy emerging-market assets.

Lakshmi Mittal expects Arcelor's management to come to the negotiating table next week, once they have had a chance to look at the Mittal Steel business plan, which will be with the Luxembourg-based company in a matter of days, The Times of London said.

A former chairman of the Sussex County Democratic Party has pleaded guilty to two counts of conspiracy in connection with the bankruptcy of a labor union he founded, federal prosecutors announced yesterday. The defendant, Charles W. Cart, faces up to two and a half years in federal prison when he is sentenced in September, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Christie said Mr. Cart admitted in court that he had conducted two schemes to embezzle money from the union, Local 16 of the United Service Workers of America, while managing its medical expenses fund.

A Bronx grand jury has indicted two teenagers in the rape and stabbing death of their 26-year-old roommate, Monique Hattan, whose body was found in a garbage can on the roof of their building. The teenagers, Dashawn Harris, 16, and Raymel Poole, 18, were indicted on Tuesday. The Bronx district attorney's office said that they would be tried as adults. Ms. Hattan was killed between May 1 and May 16, when her body was found by the building's superintendent. Mr. Harris and Mr. Poole had continued to live in the one-bedroom apartment on the Grand Concourse they shared with Ms. Hattan and her boyfriend, Meek Hall. Mr. Hall, who prosecutors said was not involved in the crime, said he had thought Ms. Hattan had gone to stay with friends.

A police van hit a sport utility vehicle yesterday in Brownsville, injuring a woman, her two sons, and five officers, the police said. The woman, Pearl Nicholas, 35, and the boys, Raven, 10, and Diamond, 6, were taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. Diamond was in critical condition, the police said, and Ms. Nicholas and Raven were stable. The officers were taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where two were treated and released, two were admitted for broken bones and one was being treated, a police spokesman said. The officers were on their way to help another officer, the spokesman added. According to several witnesses, the police van, traveling east about 4:30 p.m. on Blake Avenue, went through a red light and hit the Nicholases' Jeep Grand Cherokee, which was going south on Amboy Street. The police said the van had its siren and flashing lights on. Witnesses said the two boys were thrown out the windows and into a wall.

A labor board has sided with a union in a long-running dispute over representation of some workers in city hospitals, a spokeswoman for the union, Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, said yesterday. Ending a battle that dated to 1994, the Office of Collective Bargaining ruled last week that 1,300 workers, called coordinating managers, could be represented by the union, said Esther Kaplan, a spokeswoman for the local. The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation had opposed the move. The local now represents 2,362 workers in the public hospitals, city officials said. Union officials said that as a result of the decision, the coordinating managers would receive overtime pay.

Two officers in the Nassau County Police Department's Highway Patrol Bureau have been charged with grand larceny in connection with the theft of paid leave time, prosecutors said yesterday. The officers, Thomas Sirianni and Mary Ingargiola, were assigned as time clerks in the bureau, the district attorney, Kathleen Rice, said. She added that Officer Sirianni was charged with stealing $20,474 and Officer Ingargiola was charged with stealing $9,446 by falsifying time records. Both officers have been suspended. Both also pleaded not guilty, according to Steven Barnwell, a lawyer for Officer Ingargiola.

Leonardo Piepoli edged the overall leader, Ivan Basso, at the top of Passo Furcia yesterday to win the 17th stage of the Giro d'Italia. The stage was marred by bad weather and freezing temperatures, which forced organizers to make changes to the course. As snow and wind whipped around the original finish line at Plan De Corones, the distance was shortened and the finish line was moved to a lower altitude of 5,699 feet.

The dollar is still king in Russia's economy, but it may soon disappear from the lips of the country's officials. The lower house of Parliament gave preliminary approval to a bill that would bar officials from citing dollars — or euros — in any public statements or media interviews. The significance appears largely psychological, but the bill's supporters consider it an important step to bolster the country's currency, the ruble. Russian law bans transactions in any foreign currency, but prices for all manner of goods — from apartments to cars — are routinely discussed and advertised in dollars.

The Family Court of Appeals in Cairo ruled in favor of a 28-year-old woman, Hind el-Hinnawy, in her paternity suit against Ahmed el-Fishawy, 26, a famous actor. The case set off a major scandal along with a national debate over the secret marriage contracts couples use to have sex in conservative Egypt.

The Canadian newspaper National Post apologized for a front-page article last Friday that said Iran planned to require Jews, Christians and other religious minorities to wear badges to distinguish themselves from Muslims. The article, which the newspaper ran with a photo of a Jewish couple wearing yellow stars in the Budapest ghetto in 1944, was picked up widely by Web sites and other media outlets, and circulated around the world. Iranian legislators quickly dismissed it.

Rescue operations moved into high gear in northern Thailand to recover survivors and the dead after flash floods that may have killed more than 100 people. The government said 51 people had died and 87 were missing. The floods began Monday after several days of heavy rain.

Paul Schäfer, the German-born, 84-year-old leader of Colonia Dignidad, an apocalyptic religious sect established in southern Chile more than 40 years ago, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for sexually abusing 25 children who lived at the group's compound. He went underground in 1997, after the charges were filed but was captured in Argentina last year and extradited to Chile. Mr. Schäfer, who was also ordered to pay $1.4 million to his victims, still faces rights abuse charges, including kidnapping and torture, stemming from his cooperation with the military and intelligence services during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

Orlando Bosquette, who escaped from prison in 1985 and spent 10 years on the run after being wrongly convicted of rape, was ordered to appear before an immigration judge on charges that could lead to his deportation. The conviction of a man in the killings of four teenage girls during a robbery at an Austin yogurt store in 1991 was overturned by the Texas Criminal Court of Appeals, state's highest criminal court. The court ruled that the man, Robert Springsteen IV, was improperly barred from cross-examining the state's principal witness against him. Mr. Springsteen was among four men arrested in the killings, but charges against two of the four were eventually dismissed while the fourth, who had incriminated Mr. Springsteen, was given a life prison sentence. The death sentence given Mr. Springsteen was reduced to life in prison last year.

Demonstrators would be barred from disrupting military funerals at national cemeteries under legislation approved by the Senate. The measure, which passed the House in nearly identical form two weeks ago, specifically focuses on a Kansas church group that has staged protests at military funerals around the country, claiming that the deaths are a sign of God's anger at American tolerance of gay men and lesbians. The Senate bill bans protests within 300 feet of the entrance of a cemetery and within 150 feet of a road into the cemetery, from one hour before to one hour after a funeral. Those violating the act could face up to a $100,000 fine and up to a year in prison.

Though no one called for the filmmaker's head, ''Marie Antoinette,'' Sofia Coppola's sympathetic account of the life and hard-partying times of the ill-fated queen, filled the theater with lusty boos and smatterings of applause after its first press screening on Wednesday. History remembers the queen for her wastrel ways, indifference to human suffering (''Let them eat cake'') and death by guillotine, but Ms. Coppola's period film, which is playing in competition, conceives of her as something of a poor little rich girl, a kind of Paris Hilton of the House of Bourbon. Kirsten Dunst stars as the Austrian princess who was just 14 when she arrived in the French court at Versailles in 1770, as part of an alliance between her mother, the powerful Maria Theresa of Austria, and the French king, the grandfather of her betrothed, the future Louis XVI (the unlikely Jason Schwartzman, in a bit of gag casting).
LANE--Lawrence. We will miss him. Memorial sevices will be announced later. Martha & Martin Reinken

The Life's Work column in the Job Market section on Sunday, about professions that are still dominated by men, misstated the location of Brookside Junior High School, where the writer was the first girl allowed to take machine shop with the boys. It is in North Merrick, N.Y., not Bellmore.

Eurotunnel, the struggling operator of the undersea rail line linking Britain and France, said it reached a preliminary agreement with some creditors on reworking nearly $12 billion of debt. The accord, signed by an ad hoc committee of five creditors that are owed more than 50 percent of the outstanding bonds, could be a new lifeline for the company, which is facing a possible default on interest payments early next year. But analysts remained cautious as terms of the deal were yet to be disclosed to Eurotunnel's smaller bondholders or to its shareholders, each of which has the right of veto. NICOLA CLARK (IHT)

Murphy of Rockland, ME; Oren Murphy of Beirut, Lebanon; Sheila Pierce Ortona, of Rome, Italy; C. Eliot Pierce III, of Brooklyn, NY; Christopher Uraneck, of Portland, ME; Scott and Caroline Pierce of Devon, PA. Her brother, Albert James Redway, Jr., of Washington, DC, predeceased her. TROLLING the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, visitors found wares from around the globe -- from Italy to the Bronx -- many retaining the mark of its maker's hand. Some designers transformed vintage pieces with materials like silicone or spray paint. 1. Painted felt throws ($275) and pillow covers ($375) by Loes Wagemans, a Dutch designer, can be ordered from Lost & Found in Hollywood, (323) 856-5872. 2. Gaetano Pesce's tufted modular sofa, called La Michetta, can be configured in many ways; $1,570 to $3,470 a unit by special order at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street), (866) 888-6677. 3. Spore, a polyester pendant lamp from Japan, designed by Chihiro Tanaka, comes in small ($500) and large ($800); at CITE, 131 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 431-7272. 4. Michelle Ivankovic dipped vintage cups and saucers in food-safe silicone for Umbra; $60 a set at Clio, 92 Thompson Street (Spring Street), (212) 966-8991. 5. The plastic T-Table, by Patricia Urquiola for Kartell, has a 20-inch top with holes that make it look like coral. It comes in three heights (11, 14 or 17 inches) and in four translucent colors as well as clear and opaque black for $227; information at kartellus.com or (212) 966-6665. 6. The Beam sofa sits on lumber supports; $8,700 as shown with wool upholstery. It's also available with fur or leather; at Shimna, 325 Lafayette Street (Houston Street), (212) 529-6616. 7. The Signature 2.0 cabinet, by Michael Iannone and James Sanderson, is made with boards of reclaimed plant stalks patterned with glossy white laminate. The cabinet is 54 inches long, 24 inches high and 18 1/2 inches deep; $1,700 at i-sdesign.com or (856) 889-7307. 8. A polyester shag rug glistens in silvery taupe, burgundy or black. Made in Italy by G. T. Design, it comes in two sizes, 6 by 8 feet ($1,168) or 7 by 10 feet ($1,725), and can be ordered from Suite New York, 625 Madison Avenue (58th Street), which is open by appointment; (212) 421-3300. 9. In a nice change from the usual ''seen that'' bedding, Wenlan Chia, a Taiwanese fashion designer, offers a cashmere and wool throw with a unicorn pattern ($392) and cotton sheets and shams in many patterns to mix and match; to order from Twinkle Living, (917) 338-6622. 10. A machine-made quilt by Denyse Schmidt called Tangerine/Poppy comes in bed sizes from crib to king; $325 to $1,375 from dsquilts.com or (800) 621-9017. On the front page of this section: A vintage highboy painted with graffiti merges fine furniture and street art. It is from a collection called the Bronx Project, by Douglas Homer; $6,500 to $20,000, (484) 883-1804.

HEALTH CLAIM CHECKUP The claims-processing company Athenahealth plans to present a rare warts-and-all look at how well -- or not -- the nation's seven biggest health insurers pay their bills. [Page C1.] VONAGE'S TOUGH RECEPTION In their first day of trading, shares in Vonage, the country's leading Internet phone provider, fell nearly 13 percent below the initial offering price. The sour reception suggested that investors had doubts whether the company could survive in a market where big cable providers are rushing to offer competing services. Market Place. [C1.] MARTHA STEWART CASE TO RESUME A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must again confront insider trading accusations. The three-year-old civil case against her is resuming. [C1.] TASERS UNDER SCRUTINY The safety of Tasers, the electric pistols widely used by police, is under new scrutiny after a study by a Wisconsin scientist showed that shocks from the guns cause the hearts of healthy pigs to stop beating. Previous studies showed that Taser shocks did not cause heart disturbances in pigs, whose hearts are similar to those of humans. [C3.] WYETH ADDS TO FEN-PHEN FUND Wyeth won final judicial approval to add $1.3 billion to a $3.75 billion settlement of lawsuits over the fen-phen diet drug combination. The extra money will help settle about 42,000 pending claims, the company said. Wyeth withdrew Pondimin and Redux, part of the fen-phen combination, in 1997 after researchers linked them to heart and lung problems in some users. [C3.] OFFICIAL'S PLANS Robert B. Zoellick, the former United States trade representative, intends to resign as deputy secretary of state after barely 15 months in the job, aides and associates said. He has told associates he would like to be Treasury secretary if John W. Snow resigns. [A14.] CBS-STERN SETTLEMENT CBS Radio has settled its breach-of-contract lawsuit with the talk-show host Howard Stern, the judge presiding over the case said, but lawyers on both sides said the agreement had not yet been signed. CBS sued Mr. Stern in February for promoting his move to Sirius Satellite Radio on his CBS morning show. [C4.] G.M. REPLACES WORKERS General Motors shares rose after the company began replacing union employees lost to buyouts and retirements with temporary workers. The company is using the temporary employees to avoid hiring at factories that are closing and to cover shortages caused by the departures. [C3.] A.C.L.U. PHONE INQUIRY The American Civil Liberties Union said it was asking utility commissions in 21 states to investigate whether the country's largest phone companies handed over their customer records to the National Security Agency without warrants. [A18.] OUR SPONSOR For the next 40 days a radio station in Boston will be, when it comes to advertising, all Snapple, all the time. Beginning tomorrow, the Snapple line of drinks sold by Cadbury Schweppes will be the sole sponsor of all programming and promotions on WFNX, a Boston FM station. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C4.] SUPPORT FOR NUCLEAR POWER Speaking in Pennsylvania, President Bush called for the construction of more nuclear power plants to help reduce the greenhouse gases believed to contribute to global warming. [A18.] A MATTER OF TASTE After more than 40 years, the fashion label St. John -- the choice of powerful women in business and politics -- decided it needed a face-lift. To the label's devotees, it was scandalous. [G1.] ECONOMIC SIGNS New-home sales rose last month, but failed to keep up the robust growth pace of March. The home sales numbers, along with a second government report that showed a steep decline in orders for durable goods, were seen as pointing to a softening economy. [C1.] STOCK MARKET RALLIES Stocks rallied for the first time this week after oil dropped below $70 a barrel and the government said new-home sales unexpectedly jumped in April. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 18.97 points, to 11,117.32. [C12.] MASTERCARD OFFERING MasterCard priced its long-awaited initial offering at $39 a share, slightly below expectation. Some 61.52 million shares will begin trading today. [C6.] MOBILE PHONE DEAL China Mobile Communications is poised to make one of the country's largest foreign purchases. The deal, worth about $5 billion, is for Millicom International Cellular, a Luxembourg-based mobile phone company. [C7.] ONLINE The Business of Green Businesses are going green for many reasons, not just to enhance their image. Some are seeking a competitive advantage. A special report is at nytimes.com/business. Online, Dealbook: A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Investor Tools Information on all United States stocks, and on bonds, mutual funds, commodities and foreign stocks, as well as analysis of industry sectors and stock indexes can be found at nytimes.com/business.

An article about emissions trading in the special Business of Green section on May 17 misstated the costs and benefits of an Environmental Protection Agency program to limit sulfur dioxide emissions. The agency estimates that by 2010 the program will generate $122 billion a year in health and visibility benefits at a cost of $3 billion annually, not $120 billion at $2 billion a year. The article also misstated a type of pollutant that the government regulates. They are nitrogen oxides, not nitrous oxide.

If Marie Antoinette were alive and well and living in Moscow, chances are she would dine at Turandot, a 65,000-square-foot, $50 million recreation of a Baroque palace that opened here last December. In a city where rivers of oil money and a concentration of billionaires has restaurants outdoing each other to lure a rich clientele, Andrei Dellos's elaborate restaurants, which include the aristocratic Cafe Pushkin and the earthy Shinok, stand out, inspiring comparisons of Mr. Dellos to a "neo-classical Walt Disney", and his restaurants to "reality shows."
