A picture caption with an article yesterday about the rising cost of fuel for boats misidentified the owner of a racing boat in Marina del Rey, Calif. He is Richard Green, not Troy Litke. (Mr. Litke is a dock attendant who was fueling the boat.)

The Summer North American Bridge Championships in Chicago will open with the Grand National Teams, starting on July 12 and running for four days. In the Championship Flight, District 24 (New York City and Long Island) will be represented by Kevin Bathurst, Mark Feldman, Joe Grue, John Hurd, John Kranyak and Kent Mignocchi, all of New York. In the final qualifying match, they won by a comfortable margin over Brian Glubok, Michael Kopera, James Rosenbloom and Aaron Silverstein of New York, and Adam Wildavsky of Jackson Heights, N.Y. Feldman and Grue combined to gain points for their team on the diagramed deal.

Country Music Honors Kenny Chesney, below, was named entertainer of the year when the Academy of Country Music bestowed its awards on Tuesday night in Las Vegas, where the ''American Idol'' alumna Carrie Underwood received two prizes and Brad Paisley three, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Underwood, who won single-of-the-year honors for ''Jesus, Take the Wheel,'' which she performed on the show, was also chosen top new female vocalist. Mr. Paisley won album of the year for ''Time Well Wasted,'' and his duet with Dolly Parton on ''When I Get Where I'm Going'' took the prizes for best vocal and video event. Keith Urban was named top male vocalist for a second year, and Sara Evans, top female vocalist. The Grammy Awards will return to Sunday night next year after compiling their second-lowest television ratings ever when broadcast this year on a Wednesday. An announcement from Neil Portnow, president of the Recording Academy, and Jack Sussman, an executive vice president at CBS, said the awards ceremony, at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, would be broadcast live on CBS on Feb. 11. Libel Damages Awarded To Elton John Elton John accepted libel damages of $188,000 yesterday from The Daily Mail of London in connection with its claim of haughty behavior by Sir Elton at his annual charity ball, Reuters reported. In a brief hearing in High Court in London, his lawyer, Nigel Tait, said, ''The articles falsely alleged that Sir Elton issued a bizarre and absurd edict to guests'' not to approach him, ''thereby acting like old-fashioned royalty or some tin-pot dictator and exhibiting self-important, arrogant and rude behavior bordering on paranoia.'' He said that the assertions ''caused Sir Elton considerable embarrassment and distress,'' and that the newspaper had issued a prompt apology and agreed to substantial damages. He added that Sir Elton intended to donate the award to the Elton John AIDS Foundation. Stones Don't Roll The first 15 dates of the Rolling Stones European tour were postponed yesterday while Keith Richards recovers from a head injury, The Associated Press reported. The tour, scheduled to begin on Saturday in Barcelona, Spain, will now begin in July at a city and site to be announced in the next few days, according to LD Communications, a publicity representative for the band. Plans for a 'Code' Ban The Solomon Islands has no movie theaters, but that didn't keep its new prime minister, Manasseh Sogavare, from announcing plans to ban ''The Da Vinci Code'' from showing in movie theaters there, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Sogavare told state-run radio on Tuesday that he would seek the ban because the content of the film tended to destroy the moral fabric of Christian society, according to news media in that country in the southwest Pacific. Some 97.1 percent of the islands' 500,000 people are Christians. Footnotes Stacy Schiff has won the second annual George Washington Book Prize of $50,000 for the most important new book about the founding era. Ms. Schiff won for ''A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America'' (Thomson Gale). Her biography ''Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov)'' (Random House) won the Pulitzer Prize for biography in 2000. The jazz pianist and composer Hilton Ruiz, who turns 54 next week, was in critical condition yesterday in New Orleans, where he was found last week on Bourbon Street with an unexplained skull fracture and broken facial bones, according to Joel Chriss, his agent, The Associated Press reported.

DAVIS--Lewis. The Juilliard community mourns the passing of Lewis Davis, architect of The Juilliard School's Meredith Willson Residence Hall, which rises above the Samuel B. and David Rose Building. With creativity and a wonderful wit, Lew was an extraordinary architect, who responded to Juilliard's needs with exceptional artistry. We send our condolences to his wife, Anne, and to his entire family. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and neighbor. He was brilliant yet humble. He will be missed by all who knew him. Our deepest condolences to his dear wife Anne and his family. Terry & Rickey Rackow

The New York rapper Cam'ron's new album, ''Killa Season'' (Asylum), sold 123,000 copies in its first week out, which was enough for No. 2 on the Billboard chart but not No. 1: the Red Hot Chili Peppers hold the top spot with ''Stadium Arcadium'' (Warner Brothers), below, which sold 157,000 copies in its second week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ashley Parker Angel, a former member of the B-list boy band O-Town whose climb back to fame has been chronicled in the MTV reality show ''There and Back,'' reached No. 5 with his new album, ''Soundtrack to Your Life'' (Universal Motown). ''Broken Boy Soldiers'' (V2), the debut album of the Raconteurs, the new band with Jack White, opened at No. 7. BEN SISARIO

THREE years ago, waterproof performance apparel that was stain-resistant and breathed well was hard to find. But now dozens of American companies coat fabrics with minuscule silicon-based particles to transform the properties of backcountry clothing so that hikers and campers can live in the same outfits for days without any telltale smudges. Called NanoSphere, the treatment was developed by Schoeller, the Swiss textile company and promises to repel stains and keep users cool without changing the feel of the fabric. To test NanoSphere, Mike Kautz, a manager for the Appalachian Mountain Club, wore treated garments as he hiked to huts in the White Mountains of New Hampshire to clean them in preparation for summer. He got covered with mud, grease and rust in the process. He also splashed on honey, ketchup and other foods to assess which clothes were easily wiped clean and which defeated the purpose of looking unsoiled for days. KATE SIBER
SENDAR--Neil, 59. Passed away May 20, 2006 in Santa Rosa, CA. Survived by his mother Sylvia and sister Marsha. Formerly of NYC, Neil worked the Sendar Company.

An article last Thursday about the events that led to the fatal stabbing of Edwin Owusu-Hammond, a 15-year-old from the Bronx, referred erroneously to the legal status of Wendell Belle, one of two 13-year-olds charged in the killing. He was not under the supervision of the Probation Department at the time of the killing.

An article on Tuesday about the Mexican presidential race incorrectly described the actions of Juan Camilo Mouriño, the campaign manager for Felipe Calderón, during an interview. He was looking at his laptop to monitor bets being placed on each candidate on an Internet site; he was not checking sports scores.

Edward was born July 30, 1936 in Queens, NY, to the late Edward & Loretta Joyce O'Neill. Edward served in the U.S. Marine Corps and graduated from St. John's Univ. and NY Law School. He is survived by his wife, Clare, two sons, Edward and Arthur, his daughter & her husband, Barbara and Jeffrey Smith, and two granddaughters, Meghan and Emily. He is further survived by his sister and her husband Loretta and Ernest Ranalli & his brother, Cornelius O'Neill. Edward was preceded in death by his brother, Kevin. Reposing at The Doyle Shaffer Funeral Home, Little Neck, NY. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Friday 9:45 A.M. at St. Anastasia's RCC, Douglaston, NY. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Edward's honor to The Greenbaum Cancer Center, 22 S. Greene Street, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

HIRSCHHORN -- Herbert H. New York University School of Law and the Law Alumni Association mourn the death of Herbert H. Hirschhorn, alumnus, colleague and friend, a giant in the Law School community. He was an active, vibrant, and devoted member of our alumni family since receiving his J.D. and J.S.D. degrees in 1932 and 1934. He was frequently honored by the Law School and the Law Alumni Association, which awarded him the prestigious Judge Edward Weinfeld Award and named him Director Emeritus. He established his legacy with the Rose and Herbert H. Hirschhorn Scholarship Fund, which has supported promising scholars in their pursuit of legal education. Herb inspired all of us with his zest for life, his passion for the law, and his commitment to make a difference in the world. Richard Revesz, Dean NYU School of Law Lawrence A. Mandelker '68 President, Law Alumni Assoc $(6$)HIRSCHHORN--Herbert H. To the Editor: Re ''Hang It Up,'' by Jesse Scaccia (Op-Ed, May 23):

The dollar is still king in Russia's economy, but it may soon disappear from the lips of the country's officials. The lower house of Parliament gave preliminary approval to a bill that would bar officials from citing dollars -- or euros -- in any public statements or media interviews. The significance appears largely psychological, but the bill's supporters consider it an important step to bolster the country's currency, the ruble. Russian law bans transactions in any foreign currency, but prices for all manner of goods -- from apartments to cars -- are routinely discussed and advertised in dollars. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

''When you look into a kaleidoscope you catch images very fleetingly,'' Jocelyn Warner said of her wallpaper design Kaleido, above, just introduced by Designtex, a company in New York. ''This design is made from layering circles and semicircles, and when the circles overlap each other, you've got starlike patterns.'' The pattern comes in six color combinations: matte pink and white, above; matte black and white; and four psychedelic metallics (gold, copper, silver and white, and gold and white) that use pearlized inks to make the paper shimmer. A roll of Kaleido 20 inches wide and 11 yards long is $175 to the trade at Designtex, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street), (212) 752-2535. ELAINE LOUIE

Vallone and his life partner Christine Knickerbocker of Liberty, NY and Philip E. Vallone and his wife Donna of Roscoe, NY, and four grandchildren. To the Editor: When I was in the fourth grade in the early 1960's, we would pass notes on paper by wadding them up, and when the teacher turned her back, tossing them to the intended recipient. If we got caught, she'd hit us with a yardstick.
To the Editor: Re ''Vast Data Cache About Veterans Has Been Stolen'' (front page, May 23):
ROSS--Sidney. Palm Beach Orthodox Synagogue mourns the passing of its esteemed Board member. Moshe Scheiner, Rabbi Michael Gelfand, M.D., Pres.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the future of the C-17 Globemaster III cargo plane referred incorrectly to its use by the military. The Globemaster has been in service about 15 years, not more than 20 years. A chart with the article misstated the aircraft's wingspan. It is 170 feet, not 70 feet.

TANCER--Dr. M. Leon. A distinguished obstetrician and gynecologic surgeon, M. Leon Tancer died peacefully at his home in Teaneck, NJ on May 24, 2006, four days before his 90th birthday. In a career that spanned more than six decades, Dr. Tancer was Director of Obstetrics and Gynecology at three New York City intitutions: French Hospital (1949-1971), Brookdale Hospital Medical Center (1971-1984), and Maimonides Medical Center (1984-1990). He was also Professor of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York University School of Medicine (1958-1979), at State University of New York, Health Science Center at Brooklyn (1979-1990) and at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons (1990-recently). An internationally known uro-gynecologist, he was an expert on the surgical repair of fistulas and other complications of unattended childbirth. Dr. Tancer was also a sought-after teacher who traveled to medically underserved countries, such as Ethiopia, to share knowledge and surgical techniques which radically improved the lives of many women. The son of Jewish immigrants from Galicia, M. Leon Tancer graduated from Erasmus High School in Brooklyn, New York University College of Arts & Pure Science in 1936, and New York University College of Medicine in 1940. Dr. Tancer served as a Lieutenant Commander (Active Service, 1942-1946) in the US Navy during WWII before completing his postgraduate study and training at NYU School of Medicine, Harlem Hospital and French Hospital. Throughout his career, he remained close to his alma mater as President of NYU Medical Alumni (1970-1971), Director of NYU Alumni Federation (1971-1976), as a recipient of the NYU Alumni Meritorius Award in 1975, and as a 1993 recipient of the Solomon A. Berson Medical Alumni Achievement Award. ''I always thought of him as the consummate physician in his humanistic approach to the patient and her family,'' said Dr. Anthony Grieco, Associate Dean of New York University School of Medicine. ''You have no idea how important it was to have someone of his stature, someone who was looked up to as a role model, inspiring the new Berson inductees. He was a commanding figure, with excitement in his eye and in his voice, with a spark, a dynamism that never left him, even when he was ill.'' Dr. Tancer was also active in civic and Jewish affairs in Teaneck, NJ, where his two children grew up. He loved music, opera, theater and the culture of NYC. Throughout his life he was an avid and outstanding athlete and tennis player. He was the patriarch and fulcrum of the farflung but close-knit Tancer family. Dr. Tancer is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Norma Gorshen Tancer; his daughter, Jo Ann Tancer and her partner Martin Hennessey; his son and daughter-in-law, Steven Bennett and Nancy Kaplan Tancer; his cherished grandchildren Jason, Matthew and Lauren Tancer; his sister, Reni Tancer Kaye of Providence, RI; numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews; and the hundreds of physicians whose lives and careers he sternly but lovingly shaped. He made a meaningful impact on everyone who knew him. His loss is deeply mourned by all. Services Thursday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. $(6$)TANCER--M. Leon. The Department of OB/GYN at Maimonides Medical Center regretfully acknowledges the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. M. Leon Tancer on May 24, 2006. Dr. Tancer served honorably asChairman in the Department of OB/GYN at Maimonides Medical Center from 1984 until 1990. Our deepest sympathy is with the family. Howard Minkoff, M.D. Chairman, Dept of OB/GYN Maimonides Medical Center

LAUGHLIN--Chester Frank. Frank died in New York City on May 22, age 65. He is survived by his daughter, Beth Warner, her husband Brian and their children Brienna and Tyler in Hilliard, OH; a sister Nellie Laughlin, PhD and her children Camille and Franklin in Madison, WI, and by a loving companion, Mary Vetri. After a long career at IBM, he wrote a successful book on the history of Coca Cola and had an extended family of friends in the New York area. Service will be today 10 AM at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn.

Langone, and its compensation committee, referred incorrectly to Mr. Langone's tenure as a director at the General Electric Company. He left the board in April 2005; he is not currently a member.

PIERCE--Helen L., 79, educator, died peacefully in her home in Fishers, IN on Monday, May 22, 2006. She had been retired from the NYC public school system for 15 years after serving 37 years as an Elementary School teacher, Reading Specialist and Assistant Principal. Her preparation included a B.A. from Cornell University and Master's Degree from City University of NY. She is the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Adams of Lakeland, FL and the niece of the late Attorney and Mrs. Thomas B. Dyett of NYC. Her husband, Frank, preceded her in death. Helen is survived by daughter, Glynis, of Fishers, IN; son, Dwayne (Denise) of Teaneck, NJ, and sister, Peggy Adams of Riverdale, NY. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Former Deputy Testifies In Hussein's Defense Tariq Aziz, Saddam Hussein's former principal international envoy, testified in defense of Mr. Hussein at his trial on charges of crimes against humanity, saying his old boss's actions were backed by law. A1 Rice's Deputy May Resign Robert B. Zoellick intends to resign as deputy secretary of state, Condoleezza Rice's second in command, aides and associates said. Mr. Zoellick frequently remarked that he was finding the adjustment difficult after four years as United States trade representative. A14 Debate Over Border Wall The proposal in the United States to build a wall at its southern border is gaining traction in Mexico. President Vincente Fox, traveling in the United States, did not publicly endorse the idea but made clear his government was prepared to live with increased border security. A1 Bush Rejects Talks With Iran The Bush administration rejected calls for a direct dialogue with Iran to defuse the crisis over its nuclear program and declared that it had taken steps toward closing differences with the European Union, China and Russia on a package of incentives and threats of punishments for the Iran government. A6 Britain Detains Terror Suspects Eight people suspected of plotting terrorist attacks outside Britain were being held after a series of raids across England, the authorities said. A6 Hate Crimes in Russia The authorities in St. Petersburg announced that they had broken up an extremist group that had shocked Russia with a string of racially motivated killings. A9 NATIONAL A16-24 Senate Ready to Pass An Immigration Overhaul A Senate bill that would toughen border security and put most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship emerged intact from more than a week of impassioned debate, setting up a showdown with the House over the most substantial overhaul of immigration law in 20 years. A1 House Demands Seized Files The clash pitting Congress against the executive branch escalated as the bipartisan leadership of the House demanded the immediate return of materials seized by federal agents when they searched the office of a House member who is under investigation in a corruption case. A1 New Orleans Levees Repaired In a breathless finale that has been called one of this generation's greatest adventures in civil engineering, the Army Corps of Engineers has all but completed its repairs to New Orleans' ruined levee system. A1 New Trends in Housing In a society where so many live alone and where the scattered family is almost a cultural institution, a new type of housing arrangement with grandparents, adult children and grandchildren living under the same roof is growing faster than any other, census records show. A1 EDUCATION Science Scores Released The first nationwide science test administered in five years shows that achievement among high school seniors has declined across the past decade, even as scores in science rose among fourth graders and held steady among eighth graders, the Education Department said. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 Man Convicted in Plot To Bomb Subway Station A federal jury in Brooklyn convicted a Pakistani immigrant in a plot to blow up the Herald Square subway station in 2004, rejecting his defense that a paid police informer entrapped him by stoking his rage with images of Muslims abused at the hands of Americans. A1 9/11 Memorial Plans Another group tasked with determining cost estimates for alternative plans for a ground zero memorial has been created, reflecting the distrust that exists between the many agencies involved with the memorial. B1 Bouncer Questioned in Death The police were questioning a nightclub bouncer who witnesses say unleashed a flurry of bullets into a group of unruly patrons in Chelsea, killing a New Jersey man and wounding three others. B1 ARTS E1-10 Price of Comedy? Too High It seemed to be a can't-lose movie for 20th Century Fox: a comedy from the reigning superstars Jim Carrey and Ben Stiller. But this month Fox and its financing partner, Sony Pictures Entertainment, suddenly pulled the plug on ''Used Guys,'' a futuristic comedy. With a budget that had crept to 112 million, it stood to be one of the most expensive original comedies ever made. B1 New Design for Cooper-Hewitt A year after exploring a 75 million expansion that would create three new floors underground, the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum has decided on a relatively modest 25 million renovation that involves little construction. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Civil Case for Martha Stewart A year after her prison release, Martha Stewart must again confront insider trading accusations in a civil case. A trial would give her the chance to clear her name. But the move also carries substantial risks. C1 Vonage Sells At Lower Price In the first day of trading, shares in Vonage, the Internet phone provider, fell below the initial offering price. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: A viable Palestinian state; the speaker's decree vs. democracy; monitoring profit-making colleges; Brent Staples on why American students hate science. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge: E4 Crossword: E2 TV Listing: E9 Obituaries: C15 Weather: D7

According to the original plan, Harold Prince, left, the Broadway producer and director who is 78 years old, would receive his Lifetime Achievement Award at a special reception in his honor on June 10, the night before the Tony Awards. But Mr. Prince is in Las Vegas working on a production of ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' which is to start previews on June 12. ''I'd like to be there in person,'' Mr. Prince said in an e-mail statement. ''I've been watching honored colleagues on that stage for years. The point is, I'm working, and isn't that the point, to keep working?'' So the Saturday-night event will now be a reception with nominees, past winners and presenters celebrating the 60th anniversary of the Tonys. It remains undecided when or how Mr. Prince will receive his award. In other Tony news, the executive producers announced that instead of one host, there will be 60 presenters, including Oprah Winfrey, Glenn Close, Bernadette Peters, Liev Schreiber, Kyra Sedgwick and, as previously announced, Julia Roberts. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

An article yesterday about the theft of electronic information on about 26.5 million military veterans misstated the surname of a Washington lawyer who specializes in security cases and who commented on the data breach. He is Christopher Wolf, not Walsh.

The Family Court of Appeals in Cairo ruled in favor of a 28-year-old woman, Hind el-Hinnawy, in her paternity suit against Ahmed el-Fishawy, 26, a famous actor. The case set off a major scandal along with a national debate over the secret marriage contracts couples use to have sex in conservative Egypt. MONA EL-NAGGAR (NYT)

7 P.M. (Cinemax) FAVELA RISING -- Like many youngsters in the Vigário Geral favela (above) -- one of the 600 squatter settlements in Rio de Janeiro -- Anderson Sá felt the lure of easy money and turned to drug trafficking. That is, until August 1993, when a drug lord killed four police officers, and the police retaliated by killing 21 innocent people in Mr. Sá's favela, including his brother. Haunted by the incident, Mr. Sá set out to forge a different path for the children in his slum with the pulse from a fusion of rock, hip-hop, reggae and Brazilian percussion he called Banda AfroReggae. This documentary, which earned film-of-the-year honors from the International Documentary Association, follows Mr. Sá as he establishes the beat for a drug-free movement. 8 P.M. (13, 49) LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER -- ''A Lincoln Center Special: 30 Years of 'Live From Lincoln Center.' '' For those who couldn't make it in person, this concert series has been the next best thing to being there. This two-hour special is a cavalcade of talent: from Beverly Sills, Luciano Pavarotti, Van Cliburn and Lang Lang to Ray Charles, Wynton Marsalis, Cynthia Gregory and American Ballet Theater. And it bids a fond farewell to Martin Bookspan, the series's host. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Season premiere. Americans, be warned. Just as we were coming up for air after ''Idol,'' the next in Nigel Lythgoe's string of productions threatens to suck us back under.We thank our lucky tap shoes -- and this auditioner's (right) --that we can watch it with the sound off. 8 P.M. (Bravo) THE JAKE EFFECT -- ''Arrested Development'' was but a glimmer in Jason Bateman's eye when he signed on to play Jake Galvin, a corporate lawyer-turned altruistic teacher, in this brilliant-but-canceled NBC comedy. Actually, it never even aired. Tonight, viewers can watch six episodes back to back and decide why for themselves. 8:30 P.M. (Showtime) THREE DAYS IN SEPTEMBER -- Julia Roberts narrates this documentary about the 2004 Chechen terrorist attack on the opening day of a school in southern Russia: 331 died -- more than half of them children (left). The film had its premiere earlier this month at the Tribeca Film Festival. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- America's newest idol speaks. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about an alert to New York police officers to be on the lookout for guns disguised as cellphones misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, who said his agency had not yet seen them in the United States. He is Joe Green, not Greene.

A little-known Richard Neutra building, below, in the North Hollywood section of Los Angeles will be open to the public Saturday and Sunday. Called the Poster Neutra, it has eight small units (an early interior is shown above), built as low-income housing in 1964 with the same post-and-beam construction, window walls and open plans as Neutra's earlier masterpieces. The units have been renovated for the rental market by Mike Resnick, a developer who had rooms decorated in show-house tradition by, among others, Cletus Dalglish, a conceptual artist and designer; Steve King, a furniture designer; and Jay and Frank Novak, who own the Modernica furniture stores. Admission, $10, will benefit the restoration of Neutra's VDL house in the Silver Lake area. Poster Neutra is at 6847 Radford Avenue (Vanowen Street). Information: not-a-box.net. KATHRYN HARRIS

Down to its final contestants, Taylor Hicks and Katharine McPhee, Tuesday's ''American Idol'' featured three performances by each. That show, on Fox, delivered an audience of 30.6 million, according to Nielsen's estimates, and 33 percent of 18-to-49-year-olds who were watching television between 8 and 9 p.m. With ''Idol'' as a rocket launcher, the season finale of ''House'' (25.74 million) achieved its highest ratings ever, as Dr. House (Hugh Laurie) was shot by a disgruntled former patient. For the other networks, the leftovers were slim pickings. CBS's three-hour ''41st Annual Academy of Country Music Awards'' brought in 11.95 million viewers. In third place was ABC; its movie ''Stephen King's Desperation'' scared up a mere 7.54 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m. KATE AURTHUR

Ryan Zimmerman tripled and scored in a four-run eighth inning last night as the Nationals rallied to beat the Houston Astros, 5-1, in Washington. Zimmerman scored on Daryle Ward's pinch-hit run-scoring single, Matthew LeCroy came home on a wild pitch by Brad Lidge, and Alfonso Soriano and Royce Clayton singled off Lidge to complete an outburst that gave the Nationals their fourth victory in five games.

DEGROAT--William. May 18, 2006, North Branford, CT. A true gentleman. He is loved and missed by his staff at the Blackstone Library.

TROLL--Walter Ph.D. Professor at NYU Medical Center for many years died May 21 due to complications of multiple sclerosis. He is survived by his wife, Elaine, sons Mark and Victor, daughters-in-law Lalli and Nell and grandchildren, Emily, Phoebe, Maya and Rajan. Memorial service will be scheduled.

President Bush named Karl Zinsmeister, the founding editor of The American Enterprise magazine, as his chief domestic policy adviser. Mr. Zinsmeister succeeds Claude A. Allen, who was arrested in March on charges of stealing thousands of dollars from Target and other stores in a scheme to fake returns. Mr. Zinsmeister served on an Education Department board under the first President Bush and as a legislative assistant to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat. In a statement released by the White House, Mr. Bush called Mr. Zinsmeister ''an innovative thinker'' and said he would lead the White House domestic policy team ''with energy and a fresh perspective.'' Mr. Zinsmeister declined to comment on the appointment. ELISABETH BUMILLER (NYT)

PETTEYS--David Floyd. Professor of English C.W. Post. Husband of Diana Miller (nee Brown). Father of Michael, Timothy and Jonathan. Brother of late William Jr. For info: Michael Petteys, 718-856-5099. Raccuglia & Son Funeral Home, 718-855-7737.

If Marie Antoinette were alive and well and living in Moscow, chances are she would dine at Turandot, a 65,000-square-foot, $50 million recreation of a Baroque palace that opened here last December. In a city where rivers of oil money and a concentration of billionaires has restaurants outdoing each other to lure a rich clientele, Andrei Dellos's elaborate restaurants, which include the aristocratic Cafe Pushkin and the earthy Shinok, stand out, inspiring comparisons of Mr. Dellos to a "neo-classical Walt Disney", and his restaurants to "reality shows."

When Finnish architects rebuilt and expanded neighborhoods after World War II they often replaced wood components with steel, stone or concrete. ''Wood was neglected because it was seen as a reminder of poorer times,'' said Roy Manttari, the head of exhibitions at the Museum of Finnish Architecture in Helsinki. But in the past decade, he said, there has been a nationwide resurgence of wood's popularity, partly because its warm tones are a relief during Finnish winters. Tomorrow an exhibition he organized, ''From Wood to Architecture,'' opens at Scandinavia House in Murray Hill. Photographs and models show 17 buildings dominated by exposed timbers, including schools, churches, a concert hall and a cafe.

To the Editor: As a graduating senior from Manhattan College's School of Education, I can attest to the annoyance of cellphones. Last fall, I taught in two New York City public schools in the Bronx. Inappropriate cellphone use was a common distraction in class.
To the Editor: Re ''The Big Sleep,'' by David Brooks (column, May 21):

The budget airline Air Deccan said it would cut the price of its initial share offering and extend the deadline, after it received barely enough bids. Deccan Aviation, the company that runs Air Deccan, received just enough bids for the 24.54 million shares on offer when the time limit for bids closed on Tuesday. Even before the close, the company announced that the offer would be extended for three more days, until tomorrow, and the price range would be lowered by 4 rupees, to 145 to 175 rupees ($3.20 to $3.86) a share. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

The manufacturer of a new line of garbage bags treated with harmless oil-based scents -- peppermint, citronella, rosemary, clove, geranium and lemon -- claims that they will keep animals and insects away. Repell-em, which makes the bags, says that they are effective against dogs, cats, bears, raccoons, even insects, and that in tests, bags loaded with all sorts of throwaways were approached by animals and sometimes even touched, but survived untorn and unopened. The bags are bright red and come in two sizes, 13 gallon ($14.95 for 20) and 33 gallon ($14.95 for 10); repellem.com or (631) 273-3992. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

A court filing on Wednesday by the special counsel in the C.I.A. leak case suggested that Vice President Dick Cheney would testify as a government witness in the trial of his former chief of staff, I. Lewis Libby Jr. The legal brief did not say with certainty that Mr. Cheney would be called as a witness. But the latest filing, like earlier court papers, underscored the prosecutor's contention that the vice president's role was critical to understanding Mr. Libby's wrongdoing. But the new filing was the first to indicate that Mr. Cheney himself might be called as a government witness.

AT the mike the vibe is earnest; the succession of performers at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in Manhattan lob verbal grenades at targets as disparate as the R&B star R. Kelly and the war in Iraq. But the crowd is something else. Jamming the long, narrow barroom on East Third Street on Friday nights for regular poetry slams is a colorful gathering of seminary students, artists, actors, scholars and exuberant gawkers. Most are dressed to the nines in a playful pastiche, their get-ups a vibrant riposte to the moody rants on stage.

The first sounds you hear in ''Marie Antoinette'' are the abrasive guitar chords of the great British post-punk band Gang of Four. The effect may be jarring; this is not the kind of thing you normally associate with the 18th century. But the song turns out to be bracingly apt. The first lines invoke ''the problem of leisure/What to do for pleasure,'' one of the chief problems the title character will face. And the name of the song is ''Natural Is Not in It,'' a fitting motto for a film that conjures a world of pure and extravagant artifice.

For Martha Stewart, Another Legal Decision A year after her release from prison, her carefully executed makeover complete, Martha Stewart must again confront insider trading accusations. The three-year-old civil case against her is resuming. Contesting the accusations in a trial would help give Ms. Stewart the opportunity to clear her name and win back her title as chairwoman and chief executive of the company she founded. If she loses, the financial burden will not be onerous. Still, a trial could be an embarrassing blow to Ms. Stewart's image and to her company. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Science Scores Slip for Some The first nationwide science test administered in five years shows that achievement among high school seniors has declined in the past decade, even as science scores rose among fourth graders and held steady for eighth graders, the Education Department said. PAGE A20 Generations Living Together In a society where the most common type of household is led by those who live alone, many grandparents, adult children and grandchildren are gathering to live under the same roof. The last census showed that this type of living arrangement is growing faster than any other. PAGE A24 Dogs, Abuse and Abu Ghraib Testifying at the court-martial of a dog-handler accused of abusing prisoners at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, Maj. Gen. Geoffrey D. Miller said he never suggested that dogs be used to intimidate prisoners during interrogations in Iraq. PAGE A19 And the Winner Is . . . It took two hours and diversions worthy of Scheherazade for Fox to declare Taylor Hicks the official winner of ''American Idol.'' And all that padding made for a supersize letdown. The TV Watch by Alessandra Stanley. PAGE A24 Experts to Study Flu Cluster A team of World Health Organization experts has been deployed to help investigate what is being called a worrisome family cluster of human cases of avian influenza in northern Indonesia. Kayla Velasco, bottom left, and her sister Nadia, right, have their own TV, which they watched with their cousin Michelle Velasco. PAGE A16

Today's parents (or grandparents) will pay anything, it seems, to instill good taste in sophisticated children. And what better way to ensure a sense of good design in a toddler than by sending him to his room for time out on a miniature classic midcentury modern chair? Scaled-down classics now include the Mini Mies, two-thirds the size of the original Barcelona chair designed by Mies van der Rohe in 1929, and still in production. The child's version is made in the same factory in Long Island City, Queens, that produced some original Barcelonas decades ago (but isn't doing so now). The frame is stainless steel and the upholstery is butter-soft leather. Naturally, good taste isn't cheap, even in small sizes. But the Mini Mies does come in the two most important colors: the black leather version might fit well in a city apartment ($3,900), the white in a Palm Beach condo ($4,400). Both are available from Genius Jones in Miami Beach, (866) 436-4875 or geniusjones.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Paul Schäfer, the German-born, 84-year-old leader of Colonia Dignidad, an apocalyptic religious sect established in southern Chile more than 40 years ago, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for sexually abusing 25 children who lived at the group's compound. He went underground in 1997, after the charges were filed but was captured in Argentina last year and extradited to Chile. Mr. Schäfer, who was also ordered to pay $1.4 million to his victims, still faces rights abuse charges, including kidnapping and torture, stemming from his cooperation with the military and intelligence services during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. LARRY ROHTER (NYT)

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Dr. Lee Jon Wook, the director general of the World Health Organization, referred incorrectly at one point to the period in which the agency battled the spread of SARS. The agency did so before Dr. Lee assumed the leadership post, not during his tenure.
In Monaco, as any Formula One fan knows, there is no track action on Friday. But who knows the reason behind this quiet day?
David W. Dunlap of The Times reports that Gretchen Dykstra has resigned as president and chief executive of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation.

Clocking in at $1.42 trillion so far this year, the value of announced mergers and acquisitions has topped the previous record set in 2000, Bloomberg News reported on Friday. What better reason does an investment banker need for starting the holiday weekend a little early?

For those who love a good corporate scandal, the conclusion of the Enron fraud trial might be a bit of a letdown. Fans of scandal can take heart from the words of former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey Pitt, who writes on Friday that the back-dating of stock options may be the Next Big Thing in fiduciary misconduct.
The Times's Glenn Collins discusses efforts to preserve amateur video and other materials from the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

In New York City, letters of recommendation are part of the hazing ritual known as a board package, whereby a buyer must convince a co-op board that he or she would make a worthy neighbor. But in this era of cellphones and instant messaging, formal letters of recommendation solicited from friends and associates can seem as quaint as cucumber sandwiches, with buyers and writers alike tempted to treat them as crustless formalities.

For a moment there, I thought the real estate market had touched bottom. You know my theory about mass-market magazine covers being contraindictors of economic events. I heard that the Economist magazine, or as its readers like to say, "The Economist of London," put the bad news about real estate on its cover.
And you thought all this blogging was just navel gazing?
Glenwood Management owns and manages 22 buildings in Manhattan, including the Bamford, where Alexander Greenberg and Victoria Bronstein live.
Russian steel maker Severstal may be riding in to save Arcelor from an unwelcome acquirer, but there was a skeptical buzz surrounding the latest development in this global takeover saga.
Gov. George E. Pataki endorsed Jeanine Pirro again today - this time, for Attorney General. He last endorsed her in October, for United States Senate. (Two months later, she dropped out of the race.)
There must be a lot of real estate agents in California with little to do. The state association of Realtors reported the sales figures for April and they are down 21.4 percent from April 2005.
The assumption that the real estate market won't come crashing down is built on the idea that the economy is strong.

It was overshadowed by Thursday's Enron-related news deluge, but former Goldman Sachs associate Eugene Plotkin was formally indicted on Thursday on charges that he ran a far-reaching insider trading scheme. And, after some haggling over his bail terms, Mr. Plotkin was escorted back to jail, The New York Post reported.
Will there be a top 10 list? Stupid pet tricks? A Monday-night party at the Democratic convention in Buffalo is being billed as "Late Night with David Paterson."
Looking closely at developments in the French camp, we find one piece of high art and one piece of high comedy, both, for some reason, concerning bald superstars.

Shares of Univision are up 15 percent since the Spanish-language broadcaster announced plans to put itself up for sale. Barron's Online thinks it may eventually fetch more than $40 in a buyout, which would mean an additional 12 percent of upside. Univision "has been a bright light in the cloudy and contentious world of mainstream broadcasting," was the article's rather flowery assessment. "And this light could shine even brighter in the months ahead."

In this Sunday's New York Times Magazine, Matt Bai examines YearlyKos, the upcoming convention for the Democratic "netroots." (The article is available early on Times Preview.)Bai calls it the "first-ever corporeal assemblage" of Daily Kos bloggers, "the people who are said to be changing the very nature of American politics, transforming the old smoke-filled room of insiders into an expansive chat room for anyone who wants in." Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi and Harry Reid (the convention's keynote speaker) are expected to show up, along with the traveling gang of political reporters who usually head to things like the Southern Republican Leadership Conference.

Not one to hide his opinions, explosive stock picker and markets pundit Jim Cramer is weighing in on the New York Stock Exchange's international merger plan. In his commentary in Friday's edition of The Wall Street Journal, Mr. Cramer argues that the real reason that the NYSE Group has offered to pay $10.2 billion for Euronext -- "some European outfit that no one had ever heard of," he sniffs -- is the stifling regulatory climate created in Washington after the financial scandals of Enron and WorldCom.

It appears that Martha Stewart's stock-selling travails are headed back to the courtroom. Bloomberg News reported late Thursday that Ms. Stewart has decided -- for now, anyway -- to fight the Securities and Exchange Commission's civil charges that she sold shares of pharmaceutical company ImClone Systems in 2001 based on nonpublic information.

Enterprise software developer Hummingbird said Friday it agreed to be acquired for $465 million cash by affiliates of holding company Symphony Technology Group. Shareholders of Toronto-based Hummingbird will receive $26.75 for each share held, a premium of 16 percent to its Thursday closing price of $23.12.

Gov. George Pataki may have been the New York Republican in Iowa yesterday, sounding like the '08 presidential contender he wants to be, but it was Mike Bloomberg who injected himself into another major Issue Of Our Day with a speech at Johns Hopkins yesterday.

For your Friday blog-reading pleasure: Yet another followup to my writeups last week about how high-tech companies can produce a turkey without somebody raising the red flag somewhere along the along the line.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and the U.S. attorney in Northern California are looking into Altera's stock-option grants, company officials said Thursday evening. The SEC has opened an inquiry, while the U.S. attorney has subpoenaed information, according to the company.

A federal jury has awarded $125 million in damages to OSI Systems, a California maker of airport security-detection systems, after lawyers successfully argued that a dispute with L-3 Communications caused it to lose substantial business after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
A followup on how high-tech companies can produce a turkey without somebody raising the red flag somewhere along the along the line.

Time Warner and other defendants including America Online and Ernst & Young have agreed to pay $23 million to settle a lawsuit accusing them of defrauding pension and investment funds in Pennsylvania, the state's Attorney General said Thursday.

A lead plaintiff in a proposed tax shelter settlement that was brokered by the class-action securities law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman indicated that he was offered a financial incentive to serve as plaintiff, according to documents filed yesterday in federal court in Newark.
CLSA Capital Partners announced the closing of its third domestic consumption fund Aria Investment Partners III with $330 million exceeding the original $250-300 million announced.

Private equity firm Water Street Capital Partners' $50 million investment in a New Jersey pathology company helps maintain the Chicago area's reputation as a major source for the health-care industry's capital needs for growth.

And the winners are James Simons of Renaissance Technologies and T. Boone Pickens Jr. of BP Capital Management pocketed $1.5 billion and $1.4 billion in 2005, putting them at the top of the Institutional Investor's Alpha magazine list of the Top 25 highest paid hedge fund managers.
Telent, the telecommunications equipment maker formerly known as Marconi, said Thursday it had agreed on a possible 346 million pound ($647 million) takeover by Fortress Investment Group.

Gartmore Investment Management, a $45 billion asset manager, agreed on Thursday to be acquired in a management buyout backed by private-equity firm Hellman & Friedman, in a move designed to help expand its hedge-fund business.

The private equity group that is set to buy out information provider VNU offered on Friday to buy back most of the Netherlands-based group's outstanding bonds and notes, worth about 1 billion euros in total.

Applied Identity said Thursday that Silicon Valley investors contributed to its recent $12 million funding round. The latest round brings San Francisco-based Applied Identity's total funding to $23 million since its founding in 2003. The company, which develops identity-driven authorization mechanisms for controlling access to internal networks, said lead investor was OVP Venture Partners, which has offices in Seattle and Portland.

InterSouth Partners said Thursday that it has raised its seventh venture capital fund. The new fund, Intersouth VII, totals $275 million and brings Intersouth's capital under management to $775 million, which the company says makes it the largest early stage venture fund in the Southeast.

Arcelor has agreed to take control of Russian steelmaker Severstal in a 13 billion euro ($16.6 billion) deal that could scupper Mittal Steel's hostile bid for the Luxembourg-based group. The move prompted an angry response from Mittal, which accused Arcelor of "manipulating" shareholders.
Mueller Water Products' initial public offering of 25 million shares priced at $16 each late Thursday, raising $400 million.
Intel, the world's top computer chip maker, denied speculation on Thursday it might spin off and list its memory chip business.

Is the IPO window shut? Breakingviews thinks so. With CMC and Sigma Capital pulling their offerings in London and Vonage's I.P.O. flopping in the U.S., it seems nervous investors aren't in the mood for new paper.

Toronto-Dominion Bank reported a 22 percent rise in second-quarter profit driven by domestic consumer banking and wealth management operations, but its shares dropped after results missed analyst expectations.
Bank of America said on Thursday that it was restating financial data for the past five years to adjust for accounting treatment for certain derivative transactions.
Lehman Brothers was fined $400,000 by NYSE Regulation for submitting inaccurate monthly reports of short positions.

The damage from the Enron collapse filtered across the Canadian border, affecting the reputations of some of the country's biggest financial institutions, and shaking the foundations of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, in particular, which was one of Enron's top lenders.
Angiotech Pharmaceuticals has agreed to buy private aesthetic surgery and wound closure technology firm Quill Medical for at least $40 million US in cash.

After 26 years as a construction law boutique, Griffin Cochrane & Marshall has combined with Sutherland Asbill & Brennan. The Griffin Cochrane firm, including 10 lawyers and their staff, has moved from the Candler Building in Atlanta to the 22nd floor of Sutherland's offices at 999 Peachtree St.

The board of Canada Southern Petroleum is urging its shareholders to reject Petro-Canada's takeover offer, labelling it "financially inadequate." In a release Thursday, the board says it unanimously rejected the hostile $113-million bid made by Petrocan last week.
The torrid pace of mergers and acquisitions that swept through Canada last year has carried on into 2006, with the year getting off to its most active start in more than a decade.
NYSE Group could strike an agreed deal to buy pan-European exchange Euronext for about 8 billion euros ($10.22 billion) within weeks, according to Reuters.
Energy Partners, an oil and natural gas producer, offered to buy Stone Energy for about $1.4 billion after the value of another suitor's agreement to acquire Stone plunged along with its stock price.

Norwegian entrepreneur Alexander Vik has written to Vivendi about his idea to break it up, a source close to him said on Friday, stepping up pressure on the French media and telecoms group to defend its strategy.

Shareholders of military-truck maker Stewart & Stevenson approved Thursday the $1.11 billion sale of the Houston company to Armor Holdings, the only provider of armor for vehicles used by U.S. armed forces in Iraq.

Caisse des Dépôts et Consignations, the French state-owned financial institution, has agreed in principle to sell its 35 percent stake in Caisse d'Epargne, the French mutual savings bank, for 6.8 billion euros ($8.7 billion).
EMI's plans to snare rival music major Warner have been rocked by Bertelsmann's decision to put its music publishing division, BMG, up for sale.

Carl Icahn and Warren Lichtenstein are preparing a hostile takeover for KT&G after South Korea's biggest tobacco company rejected a $10 billion bid by the U.S. investors, according to a local securities company.
More than 100,000 National Guardsmen were sent to Iraq. Many are having a hard time making it all the way back.

Beach season officially begins this weekend, and with it comes a
brigade of carryalls, a little less disposable than in summers past.

Minutes after his client was found guilty of fraud and conspiracy on Thursday, the lawyer for former Enron chief executive Jeffrey Skilling promised a "full and vigorous appeal." The general consensus on Friday, however, was that lawyer Daniel Petrocelli and Mr. Skilling will find it extremely difficult to get the verdict overturned. The same applied to former Enron chief Kenneth Lay, who was found guilty of all six of the fraud and conspiracy charges against him.

A simulation that New York City officials held in March to test the ability of city agencies to respond to a deadly chemical explosion was marred by rescue workers' delays in reaching mock victims and a pileup of official vehicles that thronged the area, officials said yesterday.
The N.C.A.A. punished Oklahoma and its former coach Kelvin Sampson for recruiting violations. Some of the penalties will also apply to Sampson's new team, Indiana.
Robert N. Giaimo was co-sponsor of the bill that led to the creation of the National Endowment for the Arts.

If you want to find Melky Cabrera, just look for Robinson Cano. Chances are Cabrera will be with him. "They're like shadows of each other," said Alex Rodriguez. "I call him 'The Shadow.' They're always together, tied at the hip."

Germany's Stefan Schumacher beat four breakaway rivals in a sprint finish yesterday to win his second stage at the Giro d'Italia. Italy's Ivan Basso finished in the main peloton, 2 minutes 43 seconds behind Schumacher, but retained the overall lead, 5:43 ahead of José Enrique Gutierrez of Spain, in second.

A panel said it would not rule on a lower court's decision that ordered a school district to remove textbook disclaimer stickers that called evolution "a theory, not a fact."

A man accused of driving a car that struck two sisters and their three children in a McDonald's parking lot in Covington was charged with murder after the youngest victim died, the authorities said. The girl, Avery Nicole King, 2, died Wednesday, a day after she was struck while leaving the restaurant with her mother, her aunt and her cousins, ages 3 and 4. The man, Lanny Barnes, 46, left, already facing five counts of felony aggravated assault, is now charged with felony murder, malice murder and aggravated battery.

The city, under pressure from the United Federation of Teachers, is changing the site of a charter school being opened by Eva S. Moskowitz, left, former chairwoman of the City Council Education Committee, union officials said yesterday. The charter school, Harlem Success, had been set to open at Public School 154 on West 127th Street. But after parents and union leaders complained that the charter school would force program cuts and increase class sizes at P.S. 154, a formerly failing school that has markedly improved in recent years, the school system agreed to revisit the issue. Randi Weingarten, the union president, said Harlem Success would now open at P.S. 162 on West 118th Street. Garth Harries, chief executive of the Office of New Schools, said a final decision had not been made, but added,

Seven people have been charged with lying about criminal histories on background disclosure forms required for the New York City trash hauling industry after an investigation, prosecutors said yesterday. An investigation by the New York City Business Integrity Commission found that the people failed to disclose charges of assault, drug possession, arson and larceny, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Disclosure has been a requirement for a trash hauling permit since a series of prosecutions against organized-crime groups that controlled the industry, Mr. Morgenthau said.

A ferry will open between Yonkers and Manhattan next spring, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday. The operator, New York Water Taxi, will run ferries between Yonkers, the Battery Park City Ferry Terminal in Manhattan and Pier 11, at the foot of Wall Street, the Port Authority said. The trip is expected to take about 45 minutes. The service is scheduled to coincide with the planned opening of the Battery Park City Ferry Terminal.

With the $7 billion state budget unresolved and the deadline for the General Assembly's adjournment only hours away, Gov. Brad Henry, a Democrat, called the body into special session, allowing negotiations over taxes and appropriations to continue. The state government will lose its spending authority unless a budget is in place by July 1.

State officials are pressing the Department of Veteran Affairs to allow the family of a soldier killed in Afghanistan to place a Wiccan symbol on his headstone. Federal officials have refused to grant the requests of the family of the soldier, Sgt. Patrick Stewart, 34, of Fernley, who died in September when a Nevada Army National Guard helicopter was shot down. He was a follower of the Wiccan religion, which the department does not recognize. The family hopes to add a pentacle, or five-pointed star inside a circle, to the stone.

A teenager distraught over a breakup brought a rifle, a hunting knife, a box-cutter, bottle rockets and smoke bombs with him to school in Northhampton. After the police persuaded the student, Max Brotzman, 18, of Northampton Area Senior High, to surrender, he was taken to a hospital for a psychiatric evaluation. He was expected to be charged with two misdemeanors, the police said. Other students were evacuated, but classes later resumed.

Ukraine's new Parliament convened for the first time since elections two months ago produced a political stalemate. It promptly adjourned until June 7. The adjournment won the support of three parties that backed the uprising that swept President Viktor A. Yushchenko to office in December 2004, suggesting that they could reunite to form a coalition and a government despite divisions and personality clashes. Coalition talks remain stalled over who will be the new prime minister, a post Mr. Yushchenko's erstwhile partner and former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, has claimed should be hers because her bloc won more seats than his party did.

Thirty-six of the 57 countries with the severest shortages of health workers are in Africa — and those 57 countries together need four million more doctors, nurses, midwives and other workers, the World Health Organization estimates. The agency announced that Canada, Norway, the European Commission, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Council of Nurses would join in trying to rapidly increase the number of workers by expanding the ranks of teachers and the capacity of educational institutions.

Sudan has agreed to admit a joint African Union-United Nations team in the coming days to prepare for a possible deployment of United Nations troops to help enforce a shaky new peace accord for Darfur, where up to 200,000 people have died in fighting and two million others have been driven from their homes, said Lakhdar Brahimi, a special envoy sent to Khartoum by Secretary General Kofi Annan. After three days of meetings with Sudanese leaders, Mr. Brahimi announced that the team would assess the need to strengthen the 7,000-member African Union force.

Residents of Mogadishu, the capital, took cover as fighting raged between militias allied with traditional warlords and those defending rival Islamic leaders. Despite a cease-fire reached in recent days, civilian deaths from the latest upsurge in violence reached into the dozens, officials said, and the wounded lined the hallways in hospitals.

Students clashed with the police in Tehran at protests over restrictions since President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was elected last June. Students threw stones and set fires outside a Tehran University dormitory, the news agency ISNA reported. Paramilitary forces entered the dormitory around 5 a.m. and detained some protesters. Nearly 40 students were injured and at least 7 were arrested, students said. The daily Etemad Melli reported that 40 police officers were injured.

Prosecutors said President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, Chao Chien-min, had been detained on suspicion of insider trading. Investigators spent hours questioning Mr. Chao and his parents, brother and sister-in-law on Wednesday about the purchase of shares in the ailing Taiwan Development Corporation. The value of the stock skyrocketed shortly after the purchase was made.

The Mets acquired their second starting pitcher in two days yesterday, obtaining the left-handed Dave Williams from the Cincinnati Reds in exchange for the minor league pitcher Robert Manuel. They immediately optioned Williams to Class AAA Norfolk. Williams, 27, was 2-3 with a 7.20 earned run average in eight starts for the Reds before he was designated for assignment Saturday.

DAVIS--Lewis. It is with deep sorrow that the National Multiple Sclerosis Society mourns the passing of our friend, Lewis Davis. Lew, a longstanding board member and volunteer, not only shared our mission, but helped define and expand it. He sought new ways to raise money, recruit invaluable supporters, and help MS patients in New York City get access to better care. Lew's contributions to the Society went beyond ideas and actions; his warm and humorous personality was always welcome in our office. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Anne and their entire family. $(6$)DAVIS--Lewis. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and neighbor. He was brilliant yet humble. He will be missed by all who knew him. Our deepest condolences to his dear wife Anne and his family. Terry & Rickey Rackow

JOSEPH, in the far northeast corner of Oregon, doesn't have great shopping, country clubs or many other amenities most people look for in a resort community. But for the growing number of urbanites buying second homes there, it's an unbeatable place to hide. ''I could have been down at the beach, or I could have been in Sun Valley,'' said Marc Robins, a financial analyst who lives in Portland. ''But if I went to those places, I'd either be with my other colleagues or with my clients.''

A week after putting up for sale a historic painting of Mao Zedong, a Chinese auction house has canceled the June 3 auction of the portrait, below, saying it will probably be sent to a national museum in China. The Huachen Auction Company, which had said it planned to auction a painting that served as the model for the large portrait now hanging in Tiananmen Square, said the owner withdrew it after the government intervened this week. The potential auction of Mao's portrait, painted by Zhang Zhenshi, one of his official painters in the 1950's and 1960's, drew widespread criticism on the Internet in China and raised concerns about the historic image being sent overseas, even though it is already owned by an unidentified Chinese-American. In a statement yesterday the auction house said that after the government made ''suggestions,'' the owner withdrew the painting from Huachen's spring auction in Beijing and began negotiating with Chinese museums about a sale or donation. Measuring 36 inches by 27 inches, the portrait, believed to have been painted in the 1950's or 1960's, has been widely reproduced in China and was expected to sell for at least $120,000. DAVID BARBOZA
COWIN--Daniel. Dearest Daniel--it is hard to believe it's been 14 long years. Those of us who knew you best, continually miss your kindness, encouragement, intelligence and taste. Love, Joyce

Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. Theater Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. Previews and Openings 'ARABIAN NIGHT' Previews start on Wednesday. Opens on June 12. An erotic new German drama about five urbanites on one summer night. Trip Cullman directs (1:05). The East 13th Street Theater, 136 East 13th Street, East Village, (212) 279-4200. 'BURLEIGH GRIME$' In previews. Opens on June 13. Roger Kirby's new comedy sends up Wall Street and features a Gordon Gekko-like financial titan. David Warren directs, and, interestingly, David Yazbek (''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'') has written music for the show (2:10). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. 'THE FIELD' In previews. Opens on Thursday. This drama by the Irish dramatist John B. Keane is about a farmer who has leased a few acres of land and decides to take action when the owner sells the property. In 1990 it was made into a film starring Richard Harris (2:30). Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2737. 'THE HOUSE IN TOWN' In previews. Opens on June 19. Richard Greenberg's latest drama, about a troubled marriage, is set in early-20th-century New York society. Doug Hughes directs (1:30). Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. 'SATELLITES' Previews start on Tuesday. Opens on June 18. A new play by Diana Son is about an interracial couple moving into a gentrifying neighborhood in Brooklyn. Sandra Oh stars; Michael Greif directs (1:45). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 239-6200. 'SOME GIRL(S)' In previews. Opens on June 8. Neil LaBute's latest relationship drama is about a man, played by Eric McCormack (''Will and Grace''), who visits four ex-girlfriends in four cities before getting married. Fran Drescher also stars in this MCC Theater production (1:40). Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200. 'SPRING AWAKENING' In previews. Opens on June 15. The Atlantic Theater presents a musical version of Frank Wedekind's 19th-century classic about teenagers growing up fast in a repressive society. Michael Mayer directs. Duncan Sheik wrote the music. Stephen Sater wrote the book and lyrics (2:10). Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200. 'STOPPING TRAFFIC' In previews. Opens on June 7. A new comic solo show written and performed by Mary Pat Gleason about a woman struggling with bipolar disorder (1:30). Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, , (212) 353-0303. 'WAITING FOR GODOT' In previews. Opens on Thursday. The Classical Theater of Harlem mounts a new production of Beckett's absurdist classic. Christopher McElroen directs (2:00). Harlem School for the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 141st Street, Hamilton Heights, (212) 864-4444. 'THE WATER'S EDGE' In previews. Opens on June 14. Kate Burton and Tony Goldwyn star in Theresa Rebeck's new play about a woman whose life is interrupted when her estranged husband shows up at her lakeside home (2:10). Second Stage, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422. Broadway * 'AWAKE AND SING!' Dreams and disappointments, hopes and fears, encouraging words and bitter put-downs clash by day and night in Clifford Odets's turbulent comedy-drama about a Jewish family struggling to stay afloat in the 1930's. A gifted roster of performers -- including Mark Ruffalo, Lauren Ambrose, Zoë Wanamaker and Ben Gazzara -- manage to locate the dreaming centers of their characters, buried beneath layers of political sloganeering, everyday gripes or street slang. And even when the focus occasionally blurs in Bartlett Sher's ultimately moving revival, Odets's zesty dialogue, in which jazzy period colloquialisms are slung around like punches at a prize fight, is a joy to hear (2:30). Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Charles Isherwood) * 'BRIDGE & TUNNEL' This delightful solo show, written and performed by Sarah Jones, is a sweet-spirited valentine to New York City, its polyglot citizens and the larger notion of an all-inclusive America. In 90 minutes of acutely observed portraiture gently tinted with humor, Ms. Jones plays more than a dozen men and women participating in an open-mike evening of poetry for immigrants (1:30). Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'THE COLOR PURPLE' So much plot, so many years, so many characters to cram into less than three hours. This beat-the-clock musical adaptation of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about Southern black women finding their inner warriors never slows down long enough for you to embrace it. LaChanze leads the vibrant, hard-working cast (2:40). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Ben Brantley) 'DIRTY ROTTEN SCOUNDRELS' The arrival of Jonathan Pryce and his eloquent eyebrows automatically makes this the season's most improved musical. With Mr. Pryce (who replaces the admirable but uneasy John Lithgow) playing the silken swindler to Norbert Leo Butz's vulgar grifter, it's as if a mismatched entry in a three-legged race had become an Olympic figure-skating pair (2:35). Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE DROWSY CHAPERONE' This small and ingratiating spoof of 1920's stage frolics, as imagined by an obsessive show queen, may not be a masterpiece. But in a dry season for musicals, ''The Drowsy Chaperone'' has theatergoers responding as if they were withering house plants, finally being watered after long neglect. Bob Martin and Sutton Foster are the stand-outs in the eager, energetic cast (1:40). Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) *'FAITH HEALER' In the title role of Brian Friel's great play, Ralph Fiennes paints a portrait of the artist as dreamer and destroyer that feels both as old as folklore and so fresh that it might be painted in wet blood. Also starring Cherry Jones and the superb Ian McDiarmid, this mesmerizing series of monologues has been directed with poetic starkness by Jonathan Kent (2:35). Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'THE HISTORY BOYS' Madly enjoyable. Alan's Bennett's play about a battle for the hearts and minds of a group of university-bound students, imported with the original British cast from the National Theater, moves with a breezy narrative swagger that transcends cultural barriers. Directed by Nicholas Hytner, with a perfectly oiled ensemble led by the superb Richard Griffiths and Stephen Campbell Moore as schoolmasters with opposing views of history and education (2:40). Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'HOT FEET' A dancing encyclopedia of clichés set to the music of Earth, Wind and Fire. Numbing (2:30). Hilton Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Isherwood) 'JERSEY BOYS' From grit to glamour with the Four Seasons, directed by the pop repackager Des McAnuff (''The Who's Tommy''). The real thrill of this shrink-wrapped bio-musical, for those who want something more than recycled chart toppers and a story line poured from a can, is watching the wonderful John Lloyd Young (as Frankie Valli) cross the line from exact impersonation into something far more compelling (2:30). August Wilson Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'THE LIEUTENANT OF INISHMORE' Please turn off your political correctness monitor along with your cellphone for Martin McDonagh's gleeful, gory and appallingly entertaining play. This blood farce about terrorism in rural Ireland, acutely directed by Wilson Milam, has a carnage factor to rival Quentin Tarantino's. But it is also wildly, absurdly funny and, even more improbably, severely moral (1:45). Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE LIGHT IN THE PIAZZA' Love is a many-flavored thing, from sugary to sour, in Adam Guettel and Craig Lucas's encouragingly ambitious and discouragingly unfulfilled new musical. The show soars only in the sweetly bitter songs performed by the wonderful Victoria Clark, as an American abroad (2:15). Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE ODD COUPLE' Odd is not the word for this couple. How could an adjective suggesting strangeness or surprise apply to a production so calculatedly devoted to the known, the cozy, the conventional? As the title characters in Neil Simon's 1965 comedy, directed as if to a metronome by Joe Mantello, Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick reprise their star performances from ''The Producers,'' and it's not a natural fit. Don't even consider killing yourself because the show is already sold out (2:10). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley) * 'THE PAJAMA GAME' Sexual chemistry in a Broadway musical? Isn't that illegal now? If it were, then Harry Connick Jr. and Kelli O'Hara -- the white-hot stars of Kathleen Marshall's delicious revival of this 1954 musical -- would be looking at long jail terms. This intoxicating production, which features a charming supporting cast led by Michael McKean, allows grown-up audiences the rare chance to witness a bona fide adult love affair translated into hummable songs and sprightly dance (2:30). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. (Brantley) *'SHINING CITY' Quiet, haunting and absolutely glorious. Conor McPherson's impeccably assembled ghost story about being alone in the crowded city of Dublin has been brought to American shores with a first-rate cast (Brian F. O'Byrne, Oliver Platt, Martha Plimpton and Peter Scanavino), directed by Robert Falls (1:45). Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) * 'SWEENEY TODD' Sweet dreams, New York. This thrilling new revival of Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler's musical, with Michael Cerveris and Patti LuPone leading a cast of 10 who double as their own musicians, burrows into your thoughts like a campfire storyteller who knows what really scares you. The inventive director John Doyle aims his pared-down interpretation at the squirming child in everyone who wants to have his worst fears both confirmed and dispelled (2:30). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'TARZAN' This writhing green blob with music, adapted by Disney Theatrical Productions from the 1999 animated film, has the feeling of a super-deluxe day care center, equipped with lots of bungee cords and karaoke syntheziers, where kids can swing when they get tired of singing, and vice-versa. The soda-pop score is by Phil Collins (2:30). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley) 'THREE DAYS OF RAIN' In this revival of Richard Greenberg's slender, elegant drama of family disconnectedness, Julia Roberts is stiff with self-consciousness, glancingly acquainted with the two characters she plays and deeply, disturbingly beautiful. Otherwise, it is almost impossible to discern the virtues of the play itself in this wooden and splintered production, directed by Joe Mantello and also starring Paul Rudd and Bradley Cooper, who have little chance of capturing the audience's attention (2:30). Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) 'THE THREEPENNY OPERA' Presented as a long, pansexual orgy, Scott Elliot's numbing revival of the Brecht-Weill classic feels like a party where the hangover begins almost as soon as the evening does. The starry cast includes Alan Cumming (as Mac the Knife) and a Dietrich-like Cyndi Lauper, though only Jim Dale and Nellie McKay appear to have a clue as to what the show is about (2:40). Studio 54, 254 West 54th Street, (212) 719-1300. (Brantley) * 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' The happy news for this happy-making little musical is that the move to larger quarters has dissipated none of its quirky charm. William Finn's score sounds plumper and more rewarding than it did on Off Broadway, providing a sprinkling of sugar to complement the sass in Rachel Sheinkin's zinger-filled book. The performances are flawless. Gold stars all around (1:45). Circle in the Square, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'THE WEDDING SINGER' An assembly-kit musical that might as well be called ''That 80's Show,'' this stage version of the 1998 film is all winks and nods and quotations from the era of big hair and junk bonds. The cast members, who include Stephen Lynch and Laura Benanti, are personable enough, which is not the same as saying they have personalities (2:20). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley) Off Broadway 'ANNULLA' Eileen De Felitta is charming in Emily Mann's worthy one-woman play about a Jewish woman who passed for Aryan in Nazi Germany, but too much time is devoted to less intriguing aspects of the character's life (1:20). Theater at St. Luke's, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Anita Gates) 'ASSISTED LOVING' This warm and witty monologue by Bob Morris, who contributes the Age of Dissonance column to the Sunday Styles section of The New York Times, is performed by the author, who chronicles his widowed father's and his own search for love in and around New York. Engaging, subtle and winning (1:10). Daryl Roth Theater, D-Lounge, 103 East 15th Street, at Union Square, (212) 239-6200. (George Hunka) 'BEAU BRUMMELL' Ian Kelly is funny, engaging and intensely sympathetic as the early-19th-century British fashion plate who spent his last years in exile (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200. (Gates) *'BILLY CONNOLLY LIVE!' This popular comedian will remind you of a Scottish George Carlin, with a bit of Eddie Izzard mixed in (2:00). 37 Arts, 450 West 37 Street, (212) 307-4100. (Jason Zinoman) 'CAGE LOVE' The new thriller by Christopher Denham -- star of ''Red Light Winter'' -- is a compulsively watchable, sometimes ridiculous drama about a man who becomes increasingly suspicious of his wife-to-be (1:30). Rattlestick Theater, 224 Waverly Place, Greenwich Village, (212) 868-4444. (Zinoman). 'CIRQUE DU SOLEIL -- CORTEO' The Cirque du Soleil's latest extravaganza, which upholds the ubiquitous Cirque standard, is a fantasy of a dead (though cheerful) clown imagining his own funeral. Unsurprisingly, his cortege is full of circus acts. (2:30). Grand Chapiteau at Randall's Island, (800) 678-5440. (John Rockwell) 'COLUMBINUS' The grim ecosphere of the average American high school is analyzed with sympathy and precision in this new play by Stephen Karam and P J Paparelli, which aims to expose the cultural and personal pathologies that gave rise to the horrific events in Littleton, Colo., in 1999, when two students went on a murderous rampage at Columbine High School, killing a dozen students and a teacher before killing themselves. Well acted and stylishly directed, the play exudes earnestness, and a measure of self-importance, too (2:00). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood) 'DEFIANCE' The second in John Patrick Shanley's cycle of morality plays that began with ''Doubt,'' this ambitious tale of racial relations and the military mindset on a North Carolina marine base feels both overcrowded and oddly diffuse. If ''Doubt'' has an elegant and energy-efficient sprinter's gait, ''Defiance'' progresses with a flustered air of distraction. The excellent Margaret Colin, as an officer's wife, provides a welcome shot of credibility (1:30). Manhattan Theater Club, Theater 1, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. (Brantley) 'DRUMSTRUCK' This noisy novelty is a mixed blessing. Providing a two-foot drum on every seat, it offers an opportunity to exorcise aggressions by delivering a good beating, and, on a slightly more elevated level, it presents a superficial introduction to African culture, lessons in drumming and 90 minutes of nonstop music, song and dancing by a good-natured cast. So, while literally and figuratively giving off many good vibes, it adds up to lightweight entertainment that stops just short of pulverizing the eardrums (1:30). Dodger Stages, Stage 2, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Lawrence Van Gelder) 'HAMLET' Theater by the Blind's modest, pared-down production offers an angry, sarcastic prince; an Ophelia who won't stop singing; and a Polonius who actually seems to know what he's saying (2:15). Theater Five, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444.
