Holly Hughes, Joanne Leonard and Susan Meiselas consider, in very different ways, the binds entailed in sexual role-playing. Clarissa Sligh and Pat Ward Williams turn stories of African-American women into narratives of entrapment.

On certain spring and summer nights, it feels like quite a sacrifice to leave the purpling evening sky and birdsong behind for a cramped theater seat. Luckily, the River to River Festival offers an alternative; with its Sitelines series, you can have your sky and see dance too. This summer the program's curator and producer, Nolini Barretto, chose to pair established downtown choreographers with emerging ones, letting the chips fall where they might. ''Essentially, it was a foist,'' Ms. Barretto said with a laugh, adding that she hoped to create informal mentorships through the pairings. The first fruits of this experiment can be seen tonight at the South Street Seaport, when the wickedly clever Keely Garfield and Zach Morris present ''Hope & Anchor'' (with Donna Ahmadi, above), riffing on various aspects of New York's nautical history. As opposed to their partners, the artists could choose their locations; the idea, Ms. Barretto said, was to find unusual places within high-traffic areas. Later in the festival Douglas Dunn and Elke Rindfleisch will inhabit the elevated acre at 55 Water Street in ''Multiple Undo & Other Distortions,'' and H. T. Chen and Sharon Estacio will create an ''Oasis'' in frenetic Columbus Park in Chinatown. Performances will also unfold at Laundromats, lobbies, exterior balconies and street corners. So keep your eyes open, and your fingers crossed for good weather. (''Hope & Anchor'' can be seen tonight and tomorrow night, as well as May 31 and June 1 through 3, at 7. For a complete list of programs, visit www.rivertorivernyc.com. Performances are free; no rain dates.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO
To the Editor: Re ''The Rove Da Vinci Code'' (column, May 21):

Paintings, Collages and Drawings, 1957-1963 Acquavella Contemporary Art 18 East 79th Street Through June 2 While Franco ruled Spain with his deadening hand, a group of lively young Spanish artists got together in the mid-1950's under the rubric of El Paso, roughly translated as ''the Passage.'' Their aim was to ally themselves with the great postwar movements lost sight of in their country's cultural desert. One of the group's founders was the painter Manolo Millares (1926-72), a Canary Islander transplanted to the mainland.

The 36 Hours column last Friday about Syracuse referred imprecisely to the relationship between the designer Gustav Stickley and the city. Although he lived and worked there, he was born in Osceola, Wis.

A picture caption with an article yesterday about protests at Georgetown University over the hiring of a former Pentagon official, Douglas J. Feith, switched the order of the men shown and carried illegible credits in some copies. Mr. Feith was seated; Prof. Mark N. Lance, who organized the protest, was wearing small glasses and an open shirt; and Robert L. Gallucci, the dean who recommended the appointment, was in the closeup photo wearing larger glasses. Mr. Gallucci and Professor Lance were photographed by Andrew Councill, and Mr. Feith was photographed by Andrew Cutraro.
Forget any jury tea leaves. Guilty said it all. BY JOE NOCERA, PAGE C1

TERRIEN--DesNeiges, age 46 went to Heaven on May 21. She was predeceased by her parents, Georgeann Skakel Terrien and George Terrien and her siblings Alexandra Dowdle and John Joseph Dowdle. DesNeiges graduated from The Convent of The Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Connecticut and Mount Vernon College in Washington, D.C. She will be terribly missed by her family: Georgeann Dowdle, Beth Dowdle, Ann & Greg Closkey, James & Mary Evelyn Dowdle, George Dambrosio, Caroline Closkey and Georgeann & Joe Shenton and her grandnephews Joe, Johnny and Sam. We had an angel. Remember to be kind. DesNeiges' Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday at 10:00 AM, St. Patrick's Church in Bedford Village, New York. In Lieu of flowers, please make donations to DesNeiges' favorite foundation, your local chapter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

8 P.M. (CMT) THE GREATEST: SEXIEST SOUTHERN WOMEN -- There's really nothing surprising about the list of 20, which includes Reese Witherspoon, Julia Roberts, Eva Longoria and Faith Hill. What is rather startling are this episode's so-called ''expert interviews,'' which include James Denton of ''Desperate Housewives'' waxing rhapsodic about the, ahem, attributes of Ashley Judd (above). At 9, ''The Greatest'' reveals the sexiest Southern men, from George Clooney to George Strait. But who's counting? Well, maybe Mr. Denton, who's also on the list. 8:30 P.M. (13, 49) NOW -- Has the dream of opportunity turned into a nightmare of exploitation? This special tries to untangle some of the rhetoric behind the immigration debate by traveling to Montana where guest workers toil in American forests. 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE 100 FUNNIEST MOVIES -- Four hours of side-splitting scenes, plus interviews with the directors, actors and writers who made them so painfully amusing. 9 P.M. (BBC America) THE THICK OF IT -- Everything is going splendidly with the report for Hugh Abbott's housing bill in the House of Commons -- even though a junior minister is getting most of the media attention. Buy why should Hugh (Chris Langham, above) mind? He's having dinner with No. 10, a k a the Prime Minister. 9 P.M. (Style) MODERN GIRL'S GUIDE TO LIFE -- The Modern Girls -- Jane Buckingham, Eva La Rue, Claudia Jordan and Jess Zaino -- give tips on how to live a Champagne life on a beer income, though probably they don't really have to. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR -- Yes, it's a jungle out there. But must Jennifer N., an exotic animal trainer at the Miami Metro Zoo, wear her smelly, stained uniform for every occasion? In this new episode, Stacy and Clinton tame her animal instincts. 9:30 P.M. (Food Network) RACHAEL RAY'S TASTY TRAVELS -- Ms. Ray picks at the food and entertainment in Denver and gets a Rocky Mountain high. 10 P.M. (Discovery Times) THE QUEST FOR THE TRUE CROSS -- Based on Carsten Peter Thiede and Matthew D'Ancona's bestseller by the same name, this documentary unearths a new chronology of the life of Jesus' cross and tries to overturn centuries of assumptions about his crucifixion. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Mr. Letterman puts Bill Maher (left) in the hot seat. 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Nicholas Hearon, an 8-year-old dental expert, looks the big guy in the mouth. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

SILVERMAN--Franklin Michael, 59. Survived by wife Geri, devoted father to Risa and Adam, brother of Leon (Marilyn), step-mother Estelle, step-sister Sue (Ken) Kanrich and cousin Dr. Ivan (Robin) Jacobs and cousins & nieces. A kind person who gave of his time to help others. He will be greatly missed.

Power Failure Cripples Train Service in East Amtrak service between Washington and New York was halted for more than two hours by a power failure, stranding tens of thousands of riders on trains that were between stations or in tunnels, including four under the Hudson River. The blackout also disrupted service on regional railroads in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Maryland, making the morning a mess for much of the Northeast. Officials said several circuit breakers tripped, but they were not sure why. Some passengers, like these riders near Penn Station, had to be led to safety. PAGE B1 Chimp Virus Linked to H.I.V. Members of a research team reported in the journal Science that by studying chimpanzee droppings in remote jungles in west-central Africa, they have found direct evidence of a missing link between a chimpanzee virus and the one that causes human AIDS. PAGE A3 Being Joan Didion The author is working on a one-woman play based on ''The Year of Magical Thinking,'' her memoir of grieving. Casting is not a problem: Vanessa Redgrave, an acquaintance of Ms. Didion, will play the role. WEEKEND, PAGE E1 U.S. to Scrap a Phone Tax The Treasury Department said it would scrap the 108-year-old federal excise tax on long-distance phone calls. The move will bring consumers and businesses about $15 billion in refunds on next year's tax returns. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

Vera Orchard 47 Orchard Street, Lower East Side Through Sunday The single work in Jason Simon's exhibition is a 25-minute video interview with a woman named Vera that explores her addiction to shopping. Vera, who looks about 30, is attractive, intelligent and articulate about how she shops, what she shops for and what shopping means to her. Mainly, she shops for expensive clothes and accessories, but she shops intensely for ordinary things like toiletries too.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday about the music publisher Boosey & Hawkes referred imprecisely to its deal with Second Floor Music, which publishes jazz. Boosey & Hawkes has acquired the rights to license, promote and administer the Second Floor Music catalog; it did not acquire the music outright.

EIGHT years ago, when Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa were battling to become the first to surpass Roger Maris's mark of 61 home runs in a season, ESPN and Fox were in a competitive sprint, each fighting to be the first to carry the September game at which the record was likely to be broken. It was a delicious frenzy that was won by Fox, which televised McGwire's 62nd homer on a Tuesday night and drew a 12.9 rating, the largest for a regular-season ballgame in 16 years. The day before, ESPN showed McGwire slugging his 61st, which yielded a record baseball rating on cable.

MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL LEAGUE--Suspended San Francisco Giants minor league OF Abraham Nunez for 50 games for a violation of the minor league drug prevention and treatment program. On Wednesday, the last night of the May sweeps, Fox steamrolled its competitors as Taylor Hicks, below, won ''American Idol.'' The Nielsen ratings for the ''Idol'' finale were huge, as they have been since the talent competition returned in January. The two-hour show delivered an estimated average of 35.4 million viewers, and 42.9 million watched the final half-hour. That was up considerably compared with last year's ''Idol'' closer, which brought in an audience of 30.3 million. (Thanks to ''Idol,'' and helped by shows like ''24'' and ''House,'' Fox will finish the season No. 1 in the important 18-to-49 demographic.) On ABC 17.6 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour ''Lost'' finale. Its first hour competed directly with the second hour of ''Idol'' and suffered from it, attracting 16.25 million viewers. From 10 p.m. to 11 that jumped to 18.9 million viewers. Last year the final episode of ''Lost'' drew an audience of 20.7 million. KATE AURTHUR

BRESNAN--John J., 79. On May 24, 2006. Husband of Barbara, father of Patricia McCallion, Mark Bresnan, Peter Bresnan & Joan Popowics and grandfather of eight grandchildren. His careers included positions at the Ford Foundation from 1952 to 1982 with eight years representing them in Indonesia. He was a senior research fellow at Columbia University.

A ferry will open between Yonkers and Manhattan next spring, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday. The operator, New York Water Taxi, will run ferries between Yonkers, the Battery Park City Ferry Terminal in Manhattan and Pier 11, at the foot of Wall Street, the Port Authority said. The trip is expected to take about 45 minutes. The service is scheduled to coincide with the planned opening of the Battery Park City Ferry Terminal.

To the Editor: Wendy Knight's article on Northern California olive oil (''On the Olive Oil Trail, Glass by Glass,'' May 19) captured the new American passion for artisan olive oil and featured three fine producers that have their own mills. But the article omitted a part of the story. Several private estates in the wine country that are too small to have their own mills produce prize-winning, certified extra-virgin olive oils in many styles. These off-the-beaten-track properties, such as Poplar Hill in St. Helena and Villa Mille Rose in Oakville, have jaw-dropping views and ooze Mediterranean charm. Some offer cooking demonstrations and lunch.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Inquiry Cites U.S. Marines In Killings of Iraqi Civilians A military investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis last November is expected to find that a small number of marines in western Iraq carried out extensive, unprovoked killing of civilians, officials said. Two lawyers involved in discussions about marines' defenses said they thought the investigation could result in charges of murder. A1 President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, weakened politically by the continuing violence in Iraq, acknowledged major misjudgments in the execution of the war during a joint press conference. But they insisted that the election of a constitutional government in Baghdad justified going to war. A1 Abbas Pushes for Vote on Israel Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, said he would call a referendum on a proposal for a Palestinian state that would recognize Israel, if the governing Hamas party failed to accept the plan within 10 days. A1 Pope Visits Home of John Paul II Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Warsaw for a visit intended to maintain the strong ties with one of the few European countries where Roman Catholicism remains vibrant and to pay homage to his popular Polish predecessor, John Paul II. A6 SCIENCE/HEALTH Human AIDS Linked to Chimps By studying chimpanzee droppings in remote African jungles, scientists reported, they have found direct evidence of a missing link between a chimpanzee virus and the one that causes human AIDS. A3 NATIONAL A14-19 Representative's Records Ordered Sealed by Bush The president intervened directly in an increasingly tense constitutional fight between Congress and the Justice Department by ordering records that were seized from a Congressional office sealed for 45 days. A1 Charity Invites Accountability For the last four years, Direct Relief, which provides donated medicine and medical supplies around the world, has held a ''shareholders' meeting'' for contributors to demonstrate its accountability and to burnish its relationship with its donors. A14 Reports on Veterans Data Officials of the Veterans Affairs Department told angry lawmakers that an agency employee had been taking home sensitive data for three years before it was stolen from his residence, compromising the records of 26.5 million veterans. A14 Diocese to Sell Property The Roman Catholic diocese of Spokane, Wash., announced plans to sell its diocesan headquarters and other property valued at about $11 million as part of its efforts to settle claims by victims of sexual abuse. A16 New Vote to Drill in Preserve With gasoline prices unusually high, the House voted yet again to approve drilling for oil and gas in part of the Arctic National Wildlife Preserve. But given the Senate's recent disposition toward Arctic drilling, the vote may be little more than symbolic. A18 Treasury Chief May Resign John W. Snow has signaled his readiness to step down as Treasury secretary, possibly by the end of June, or as soon as the White House is ready with a candidate to succeed him, Republicans with ties to the administration say. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Power Failure Strands Thousands of Commuters Travel for tens of thousands of train riders between New York and Washington came to a sudden halt when a cascading electrical failure disabled dozens of trains, stranding travelers on the tracks and in dark tunnels for hours. B1 New Standards on Emissions Making good on a vow that New York would act on its own if the federal government did not get tough on mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed some of the most stringent mercury standards in the nation. B2 Man Questioned in Murders Officials said a bouncer charged with shooting a man to death and wounding three others outside a Chelsea nightclub is being questioned in connection with three other murders in Brooklyn, including two of bar bouncers. B1 WEEKEND E1-24; E25-32 A Brooklyn Jazz Renaissance The rise of Brooklyn's jazz scene has been one of the most significant developments for jazz in New York in recent years. E1 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-7 Faster Style With New Rules Every night has seemed like the Fourth of July during the N.B.A. playoffs, bright and breathtaking to the frantic finale, with few duds in the show. Some might wonder why the games have been more dramatic, but coaches offer a concise explanation: the new N.B.A. rules. D2 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Enron Chiefs Found Guilty Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the executives who guided Enron through its spectacular rise and stunning fall, were found guilty of fraud and conspiracy. A1 Phone Excise Tax Is Scrapped Bowing to technology changes, and pressure from taxpayers and phone companies, the Treasury Department said it would scrap the federal excise tax on long-distance phone calls. To the Editor: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert and President Bush have arrogated to themselves the right to negotiate away Palestinian land. Past colonial powers did precisely the same.

The Mets acquired their second starting pitcher in two days yesterday, obtaining the left-handed Dave Williams from the Cincinnati Reds in exchange for the minor league pitcher Robert Manuel. They immediately optioned Williams to Class AAA Norfolk. Williams, 27, was 2-3 with a 7.20 earned run average in eight starts for the Reds before he was designated for assignment Saturday. For the Mets, it was a chance worth taking because Williams bolsters their options. Williams could be called up to fill a spot in the rotation, allowing the Mets additional time to develop other pitchers, like Mike Pelfrey. And he could become part of a package as the trading deadline gets closer.

A front-page article on Wednesday about a proposal in the Senate to remove the limit on the number of nurses who can immigrate to the United States misstated the availability in recent years of medical care during childbirth in the Philippines, a major source of nurses for the United States. The percentage of women giving birth there with a doctor, nurse or midwife present has held steady; it has not declined.

The David Pogue column in Business Day yesterday, about the Samsung Helix, a radio for XM satellite broadcasts that can also record, described a ''wish list'' feature incorrectly. While users can be alerted to a designated band or song playing on another channel, the radio will not automatically tune to that channel to record it; the user must do that manually. The column also incorrectly attributed a quotation about legal objections to lawyers for the Recording Industry Association of America, which is suing XM. They have not said the player is ''a tool for copyright infringement.'' That was the columnist's assessment of the recording industry's position.

Rolled and Forged Gagosian Gallery 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through Aug. 11 Richard Serra's best sculpture is always a compleat experience, head to toe. His achievement is to bring together the physical, the visual and the mental and to mix them unpredictably for effects that are simultaneously exhilaratingly real and profoundly abstract. Mr. Serra pursues this duality in five ambitious pieces that constitute his seventh spectacular courtesy of Larry Gagosian, who has spent money moving more Serras across the George Washington Bridge than anyone, although it has probably been worth the effort. These new ones forsake the spirals and ellipses of recent years and reinstate the blocks, rounds and uncurved slabs of earlier shows. They also seem to substitute simple mathematics for computer calculations.

DEMAR--Sumner. On May 25, 2006. Beloved husband of Eleanore. Devoted father of David and Melanie Rothman and father-in-law of Lee Rothman. Cherished grandfather of Alex, Jason and Noah. Services on Friday 11:30 AM at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Queens, NY.

The Havens column last Friday about Horseshoe Bay, Tex., a vacation destination near Austin, misidentified the state highway that runs through the town. As the accompanying map correctly showed, it is Highway 2147, not 2247

An Agence France-Presse report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the preparations for a staging of Richard Wagner's ''Meistersinger'' at Bayreuth next year referred incorrectly to the departure of the set designer. According to a Bayreuth Festival statement, Katharina Wagner, the composer's great-granddaughter, and Alexander Dodge, the set designer, decided to ''suspend their collaboration'' because of ''insurmountable artistic differences.'' Ms. Wagner did not dismiss him.

CHARLES Harris took a step back from the front desk at East Hampton Village Hall on Monday afternoon (1:40 to be precise), his mouth open as if he was in shock. ''Oh -- my -- God,'' Mr. Harris said. He had just been told that he had bought, for $250, the last of 2,600 nonresident permits to park at the five beaches in East Hampton Village, a 12-square-mile enclave within the Town of East Hampton.

To the Editor: It is not a legitimate criticism of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert's withdrawal plan to declare that it will not bring peace, for no matter what Israel does, there is no hope of peace while the Palestinian people and their leadership cling to their unrealistic expectations and culture of violence.

Since his emergence early in the 1990's, Kurt Rosenwinkel has evolved into one of the leading guitarists in modern jazz and one of the most clearly gifted musicians of his generation. Mr. Rosenwinkel, above, made his first big impression as part of the bright new generation at Smalls, though by that time he had already received the imprimatur of the esteemed vibraphonist Gary Burton. What he developed at Smalls was a personal identity on the guitar: a warm, luminous sound to humanize his formidable technique. Mr. Rosenwinkel gradually began to apply that sound to bands led by his elders (notably the drummer Paul Motian) as well as by his contemporaries (the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner), but it was within his own ensembles that it fully flourished. Last year Verve released his fourth album, ''Deep Song,'' featuring a group of accomplished peers like the saxophonist Joshua Redman and the pianist Brad Mehldau, and the results were both striking and subtle. (Or to be more precise: striking in its subtlety, which may be why the album received less attention than it deserved.) Since then, Mr. Rosenwinkel has focused on a separate working band, superior in some regards because of his deeply intuitive rapport with Mr. Turner, the saxophonist. This ensemble, which also features the pianist Aaron Goldberg, the bassist Joe Martin and the drummer Eric Harland, imbues its performances with a blend of shadowy introspection and combustible interplay. In other words, it's a perfect home for Mr. Rosenwinkel, and an experience best savored live. (Wednesday through June 4 at Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, 212-582-2121; cover, $27.50 Wednesday and Thursday, $30 Friday through Sunday, with a $10 minimum.) NATE CHINEN

Unwit Paul Kasmin Gallery 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, Chelsea Through June 3 Angus Fairhurst, a Y.B.A. (Young British Artist) and sometime fellow exhibitor with the Y.B.A.'s Damien Hirst and Sarah Lucas, shows complex collages made by cutting out the central texts and images from glossy ads, fashion-magazine layouts and other found sources, then layering the scissored sheets atop one another. (In some cases he has used material from his own fashion shoots.) Shreds and shards of colors and images meld together in the cutout spaces to produce discordant, semi-surreal effects meant to deprive the ads of their consumer come-on.

A Gin Cure Roebling Hall 606 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through June 3 Deborah Grant continues to mold her interest in politics, language, graffiti and cartoons into an intense, distinctive art. At the moment she is leavening her obsession with increasingly refined and differentiated images, patterns and imaginary scripts with heavy doses of Picasso. Her primary victim is ''Guernica,'' which she has quartered and redrawn.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a survey of health insurance companies and how promptly and completely they pay claims gave an incorrect address for a Web site that posted the results. It is www.athenaPayerView.com, not www.athenaPayView.com.

Sudan has agreed to admit a joint African Union-United Nations team in the coming days to prepare for a possible deployment of United Nations troops to help enforce a shaky new peace accord for Darfur, where up to 200,000 people have died in fighting and two million others have been driven from their homes, said Lakhdar Brahimi, a special envoy sent to Khartoum by Secretary General Kofi Annan. After three days of meetings with Sudanese leaders, Mr. Brahimi announced that the team would assess the need to strengthen the 7,000-member African Union force. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

The TV Watch column in some copies yesterday, about the season finale of ''American Idol,'' referred incorrectly to Clay Aiken, a former contestant who appeared on the results show on Wednesday night. He was the runner-up in 2003, not the winner. The article also misspelled the surname of one of the finalists this year. He is Elliott Yamin, not Yasmin.

POLAKOV--Lester Marshall. On May 22, 2006. Husband of Mary E. Polakov. Father of Lucy, Liza & Jenny. Renowed scenic designer; established Studio and Forum of Stage Design in the West Village. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Theatre Development Fund.

PaceWildenstein 534 West 25th Street, Chelsea Through June 17 Nothing illuminates art like other art. Still, the juxtaposition of Jean-Michel Basquiat's early work with Jean Dubuffet's late paintings exudes a high-wattage electricity all its own. Both artists were aggressively chewing up culture and spitting out a new aggregate, playing with the so-called primitive and refusing to distinguish between drawing and painting. For Basquiat that culture was already mongrel, drawn from Europe, Africa and the Americas, in addition to poetry, music and sports.

An article on Sunday about the midterm Congressional election misstated the name of the committee coordinating the campaign effort by House Republicans. It is the National Republican Congressional Committee, not the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee.

Capella Pedregal WHAT -- Boutique resort with luxury residences. WHERE -- Cabo San Lucas, Mexico. AMENITIES -- Luxury yachts, a full-service spa and a private beach club. PRICES -- From $460,000 for a one-eighth fractional ownership in a three-bedroom unit to $2.9 million for full ownership of a four-bedroom house. STATUS -- Under construction; expected to open in fall 2007. DEVELOPERS -- Richard Holland and the Diaz Rivera Family. CONTACT -- 877-843-8385 or www.capellacabo.com. DETAILS -- This 24-acre development at the southern tip of the Baja Peninsula will run along the coasts of the Pacific Ocean and the Sea of Cortez and rise inland up mountains overlooking the town of Cabo San Lucas. At its center will be a 66-room resort with a full-service spa and restaurants. The residences, which will be divided into 31 fractional ownership units with three and four bedrooms and 20 full-ownership three- and four-bedroom houses, will offer buyers access to the resort's many amenities, among them maid service and personal chefs. Residents will also have added perks, including ownership shares in as many as 10 60-foot recreational fishing boats docked at the nearby marina (details are not yet final). The Cliffs at Mountain Park WHAT -- Private, outdoor-focused residential community. WHERE -- Travelers Rest, S.C. AMENITIES -- A golf course, a large trail system and a pedestrian village. PRICES -- Around $300,000 to more than $1 million for home sites; completed houses (including land) for $750,000 to more than $5 million. STATUS -- Home sites will be available starting this fall, and completed houses by next spring. The long-term construction plan, which will include a variety of housing options, is expected to be completed in eight years. DEVELOPER -- The Cliffs Communities. CONTACT -- 866-745-6446 or www.cliffscommunities.com/park. DETAILS -- This 5,000-acre gated residential community is in northwest South Carolina near the Blue Ridge Mountains. It will feature an extensive system of trails and a 300-acre central village with an inn, a cafe and outfitter shops. There will also be an 18-hole golf course designed by Gary Player and a center for golf and personal training. An organic farm will supply the village's cafe, and an arboretum will be developed with nearby Clemson University. There are seven other Cliffs communities in North and South Carolina, and residents have access to the amenities at all of them. There are also developments in British Columbia and in Patagonia, Chile. NICK KAYE Breaking Ground is a weekly look at projects, planned or under construction, that include weekend or vacation homes.

It always seems virtuosic when an actor portrays a handful of characters in one scene, but it's easier than it looks. Still, among the other triumphs of the ingratiating new solo show ''No Child'' is that Nilaja Sun, above, evokes an entire public school classroom without resorting to schtick. Ms. Sun, the child of African-American and Puerto Rican parents, is a master at subtle shorthand, communicating a wealth of information in a precise movement or vocal inflection. She uses her small, limber body like a champion bodybuilder manipulating his muscles: isolating a small area, drawing attention to it before shifting to the next one. It's a marvelous performance, so detailed that it avoids the potential clichés of the subject matter at hand. Based on Ms. Sun's own experiences, the plot is about a naïve teacher who enters one of the worst public schools in the city (it's never just pretty bad, is it?) and directs a group of hopeless teenagers in a production of ''Our Country's Good.'' While most reviews have harped on how the show portrays a school system in crisis, the play is just as much about another flagging institution, the theater. ''Thespian,'' she explains to her students, ''means actor, citizen, lover of all things great.'' It's a favorite subject of Ms. Sun's and one that she has sent up and celebrated in several past solos. ''No Child'' may sound like earnest political theater, but it's just as much about the heartaches of being an actor in this city. As she presents herself so candidly, the life can be embarrassing, absurd, rewarding. At the end of the show she imagines the payoff, a future with a Tony, an Oscar and Denzel Washington as a husband. ''His first wife,'' she says with a hint of a smile, ''never had a chance.'' (''No Child'' is playing at the Samuel Beckett Theater on Theater Row through June 18. 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, 212-279-4200.) JASON ZINOMAN

The government responded briskly to suggestions that the United Nations should help solve its political and economic crises, calling the idea a ploy by its Western enemies and withdrawing a longstanding invitation for Secretary General Kofi Annan to visit. South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, in London to meet with the British prime minister, Tony Blair, raised the prospect of United Nations help on Wednesday in an interview. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

Beanie Sigel Shot The rapper Beanie Sigel, right, was shot early yesterday morning during an attempted robbery in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Sigel, whose real name is Dwight Grant, was wounded in the upper right arm shortly after 8 a.m., the police said, but was able to drive himself to a hospital, where he was reported to be in good condition. The police said that five men traveling in two cars had attempted the robbery. The shooting was the latest chapter in a turbulent life. In January, Mr. Sigel, whose three albums have each reached the Top 5 on the Billboard album chart, was convicted of misdemeanor simple assault and sentenced to two years' probation as a result of an argument with a man outside a restaurant in 2003. Last August he left a federal prison after serving a year on a weapons charge. In September he was acquitted of attempted murder, and in November he was jailed briefly until he paid $27,000 in child support and $2,000 in fines. Baryshnikov Sidelined Mikhail Baryshnikov, left, has been forced to cancel his performances with Eliot Feld's Mandance Project at the Joyce Theater because of a shoulder injury, Mr. Feld's Ballet Tech company said. He was to have danced ''Mr. XYZ,'' a solo Mr. Feld created for him, during the run, from Wednesday to June 11. A Setback for 'Grendel' The Los Angeles Opera announced yesterday the postponement of the world premiere of ''Grendel,'' the new Elliot Goldenthal opera with a libretto written with Julie Taymor (who is also the director) and J. D. McClatchy. The company said that technical and mechanical problems had forced it to move the official first performance to June 8 from tomorrow night at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. The performances that had been scheduled for June 1 and June 3 have now been designated as previews. Record Price for a Kahlo ''Roots,'' above, fetched a record auction price for a Frida Kahlo painting and for a Latin American work of art when it was sold for $5.6 million to an anonymous telephone bidder at Sotheby's in New York on Wednesday night. The 1943 oil-on-metal painting, never previously on the public market, was sold by a private collector who preferred to remain anonymous, Sotheby's said. The sale realized $18.6 million over all, described as the highest ever for an auction of Latin American Art, far exceeding the presale estimate of $11.9 million to $16.2 million. Walter Mitty, Musician Opportunity is knocking for any instrumentalist who has ever dreamed of performing with Marvin Gaye or the Jackson 5 or Elton John. In the latest twist on digital sales, a new Web site is offering songs that can be bought without certain musical parts, like drums, keyboards, guitar or bass guitar, The Associated Press reported. Since early this month the site, DreamMusician.com, has been selling song downloads for about $2 each and compilations of the same song with different instrumental parts removed, starting at about $18. The aspiring musician then inserts his performance. The site says it expects to offer more than 1,000 songs by the end of the year. Footnotes The Dance Theater of Harlem announced yesterday that it had received a $1 million grant from the Ford Foundation. The money is to be used to finance the Dance Theater of Harlem School and Dancing Through Barriers, its education and community program. An English-language version of Ingmar Bergman's official Web site has become operational, The Associated Press reported. The site, with thousands of photographs, video clips and texts about Mr. Bergman, the director, 87, originated in Swedish in September. Maintained by the Ingmar Bergman Foundation, established by the Swedish Film Institute, to which he donated his archives, the site can be reached at www.ingmarbergman.se.

ENRON CONVICTIONS A jury in Houston found Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executives, guilty of fraud and conspiracy. If they lose their appeals, they face potential sentences that experts say will keep them in prison for the rest of their lives. [Page A1.] WHAT JURORS SAID In the end, jurors said, they just could not believe that Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling were telling the truth when they said they did not know that something was rotten at Enron. [A1.] WHO MAKES WHAT Last year, hedge fund managers had to take home $130 million to make it into the top ranks in a survey of the best paid in hedge funds, a survey closely followed by people in the business. [C1.] LONG-DISTANCE TAX TO BE REVOKED After a series of court reversals, the Treasury Department said it would scrap the 108-year-old federal excise tax on long-distance phone calls. The move will bring consumers and businesses about $15 billion in refunds on next year's tax returns. [C1.] EBAY-YAHOO PARTNERSHIP EBay and Yahoo, two top Internet companies that have been losing influence to Google, said they would work together in several areas, including advertising and online payments. Advertising. [C1.] FORD CREDIT RATING AT RISK Standard & Poor's Ratings Services said it might cut Ford's debt rating deeper into junk status, citing concerns that a turnaround was falling short of expectations. S.& P. put Ford and its finance unit on CreditWatch with negative implications. [C3.] HOUSE APPROVES REFUGE DRILLING The House has again voted, 225 to 201, to approve drilling for oil and gas in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. It was at least the 12th time that the House had voted to allow energy exploration in a small piece of the preserve's 19 million acres. [A18.] REPORT SHOWS STRONG GROWTH Concerns the economy might have overheated in the first quarter eased after revised economic growth figures showed expansion was strong, but not too strong. The Commerce Department said gross domestic product expanded 5.3 percent. [C3.] DEALS SPUR STOCKS Stocks rallied as corporate deals and mergers, as well as a robust initial public offering for the credit card company MasterCard, lifted investor sentiment. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 93.73 points, or 0.84 percent, to end at 11,211.05. [C8.] NO DOLLS AFTER ALL Hasbro has canceled plans to produce fashion dolls modeled on the pop act the Pussycat Dolls after parents objected to the group's racy image. Hasbro viewed the Pussycat Dolls line as one that would compete against the Bratz, fashion dolls known for curvaceous figures and trendy outfits. [C8.] PAPERS TELL OF PLAINTIFF PAYMENT A lead plaintiff in a proposed tax shelter settlement brokered by the law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman indicated that he was offered a financial incentive to serve as plaintiff, according to court documents. Milberg Weiss and two of its partners have been indicted by a federal grand jury. [C3.] SNOW REPORTED READY TO LEAVE John W. Snow has signaled his readiness to step down as Treasury secretary, possibly by the end of June, or as soon as the White House is ready with a candidate to succeed him, according to Republicans with ties to the administration. [A18.] BANK MERGER The Regions Financial Corporation has agreed to acquire the AmSouth Bancorporation for $9.8 billion in stock. The companies said the combination would create the United States' 10th-largest bank. [C10.] ARCELOR PLANS PARTIAL SALE Arcelor, the steel maker struggling to fend off a hostile takeover bid from Mittal Steel, is planning to sell a third of the company to Severstal, a Russian steel company controlled by the billionaire Aleksei Mordashov, according to executives. [C10.] BERTELSMANN TO BUY OUT INVESTOR Moving swiftly to fend off a public stock offering, the founding family of Bertelsmann, Germany's leading media conglomerate, announced that it had agreed to buy out its only outside shareholder for 4.5 billion euros, or $5.8 billion. [C3.] BRITAIN TO OVERHAUL PENSIONS Britain announced far-reaching plans to overhaul its cumbersome state pension system. The plans would re-establish a link between pensions and earnings scrapped 26 years ago and introduce a national pension savings program that would automatically enroll workers. WHO -- Jeanette Lawson, 42, a property manager from Charleston, S.C., shown with her husband, Shawn, 43, an advertising salesman for a tourism guide, and their sons, Benjamin, 14, left, and Theodore, 12 WHAT -- 3-bedroom condominium WHERE -- Kiawah Island, S.C. We used to live on Kiawah Island full time but sold our house in 1999 to move to Charleston. It can be tough to live on Kiawah year round because it's a long drive to school and work. But we missed the island, so a few years ago we bought our first condo here.

In a way, you always know exactly what you're going to get with the Fall. As the most deliberately repetitive band in rock history -- its first record contained a song-manifesto called ''Repetition'' -- this is its virtue, its legacy. Since 1978 this British group, led by the invariably bored-looking and -sounding Mark E. Smith, above, has issued a steady, mostly predictable stream of songs characterized by jagged, jabby guitar; choppy rhythms; and Mr. Smith's cynical, tuneless slur, in lines that can be droll (''The dead cannot contradict'') or simply stupid (''Pay your rates/Pay your water rates''). Nothing else has ever sounded quite like the Fall, even the many postpunk groups it influenced, from Sonic Youth and Pavement to Franz Ferdinand and Clinic. But there has always been something tantalizingly unpredictable about Mr. Smith, particularly on tour. Churlish as ever well into his 40's, he has on recent tours gotten into fights with band mates and been arrested. A few weeks ago, just days into the band's current American tour, three members left and were quickly replaced, as so many Fall players over the years have. ''They are always different,'' the British D.J. and Fall admirer John Peel once said of the band, ''they are always the same.'' (Thursday at 11:30 p.m., the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, 212-219-3132; also June 2 at 9 p.m. at Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-230-0236. Both shows sold out.) BEN SISARIO
MOSS--Martin, 87. Of Amherst, MA, died Wednesday, May 24. Funeral services will be Friday, May 26, at 11:30 AM, at Riverside Chapel in New York City.

Diner's Guide presents excerpts from recent restaurant reviews. Sascha Downstairs is a brasserie-style space that would clearly like to compete with the nearby Pastis. Upstairs is a quieter refuge with leather booths, tasseled lampshades and tablecloths. And uniting the two levels is the menu and cooking of Sascha Lyon, whose American and Continental standard-bearers seem to channel the spirit of a Midwestern hotel. It's an odd and uneventful restaurant but an often enjoyable one, with a rack of lamb (upstairs) and double burger (downstairs) that prompt no complaints. 55 Gansevoort Street, at Ninth Avenue, meatpacking district; (212) 989-1920. Lunch and dinner entrees, $15 to $42. * [Rating: One Star] Crema Taking Mexican cooking in the kind of nuanced directions that too few restaurants in New York do, Julieta Ballesteros, formerly of Mexicana Mama, lays chicken on a purée of squash blossoms, puts portobello mushroom atop it and crowns it all with goat cheese. Imaginative flourishes or intricate architecture define many of her dishes, but the kitchen's execution does not always live up to the recipes. The cheerful, orange-tinged setting and fine margaritas are definite compensation, and Ms. Ballesteros is a chef to watch. 111 West 17th Street, Manhattan ; (212) 691-4477. Dinner entrees, $17 to $26. * [Rating: One Star] A Voce The chef Andrew Carmellini's solo debut, A Voce concerns itself more with sating than wowing you and does so with seasonal ingredients, full-flavored dishes and superior cooking. Mr. Carmellini's terrific pasta dishes include agnolotti filled with duck and covered in a foie gras sauce, and pappardelle with a lamb Bolognese shine, and he's got a talent for meatballs, alternately made of duck, pork and shrimp. The stylized, contemporary room doesn't really go with the food, but there are enormously comfortable swivel chairs as a compensation, along with a thoughtful wine list. 41 Madison Avenue, entrance on 26th Street; (212) 545-8555. Dinner pasta dishes and entrees, $19 to $55. *** [Rating: Three Stars] Buddakan Buddakan is the apotheosis of a distinct genre: the postmillennial urban mess hall as supersize cocktail lounge with stylized dishes that chart a far-out trip to the Far East. It covers 16,000 square feet, including a main dining room with a ceiling as high as the Himalayas and a row of gaudy chandeliers. The biggest surprise is the food: alternately faithful and fanciful interpretations of Chinese cooking that are much better than they have to be. 75 Ninth Avenue, at 16th Street, Chelsea; (212) 989-6699. Appetizers and noodle and rice dishes, $9 to $14; entrees, $17 to $47. ** [Rating: Two Stars] What the stars mean: (None) Poor to satisfactory; * Good; ** Very good; *** Excellent; **** Extraordinary.

A look in The Mirror reveals that German soccer's first couple, the Ballacks, are cut no slack by the nation's customs officers. Despite being the German captain, Michael was stopped on his way through the "nothing to declare" channel at the airport in Munich earlier this year and found to be concealing a $2,000 Fendi handbag in his luggage, which he'd bought as a gift for his partner Simone in Dubai. Now a court in Bavaria has decided that the Ballacks, like any other mortals, are not entitled to dodge import duties on luxury items. Their problem is that the statutory fine for this offense is not a fixed amount but rather, a percentage of the smuggler's income.

Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Thursday, 27 May 1784: 29 7/10; 59; W. Sun & clouds, brisk gale, bright gleam. Distant thunder. Young red-breasts. St. foin begins to blossom. Honey-suckle against the wall begins to open. Lime trees shew their bracteal leaves, & rudiment of fruit. Wall-nut trees shed their catkins and show rudiments of fruit. Maples shew fruit. My great single oak shews many catkins.

Continuing with our theme of disgruntled 'keepers, next we hear the woes of Germany's Jens Lehmann, who told reporters this week that he's unhappy with the high-tech Adidas Teamgeist ball that will be used in this year's competition, because "it's a ball for the outfield players and the crowd -- not for the goalkeepers." Apparently it hasn't occurred to Lehmann -- who went on to complain that this ball "moves a lot in the air" and "gets very slippery" in the rain -- that games played with a ball that was engineered to make the goalkeepers happy, and the other 20 players on the field, tens of thousands of spectators in the stands and millions watching at home unhappy, might not go down so well.

Myanmar's military junta has extended the period of house arrest for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning pro-democracy leader, a Home Ministry source said today. The source said it was unclear if the extension was for six months or one year. Security outside Suu Kyi's lakeside home in the capital, Yangon, had been stepped up ahead of the extension of her detention, with armed police and barricades preventing any traffic from passing. Hope for her release by the military rulers of Myanmar, formerly Burma, had swelled when the junta made the surprise decision to allow a United Nations envoy to meet with her last week. A Moscow court upheld a decision by Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov to refuse permission to hold a gay-rights parade in the city today. Plans for the parade, which would have been the city's first, provoked a storm of condemnation in Russia, where homosexuality has gained little acceptance since it a criminal ban on it was lifted in 1993. Nepal's new government and Communist rebels concluded a first round of peace talks, agreeing to continue the peace process, government and rebel negotiators said. During the nearly six-hour meeting at a hotel outside Katmandu, the sides agreed on a 25-point code of conduct to be followed as they continue the talks, said the home minister, Krishna Situala, and the rebel spokesman, Krishna Mahara. No date has been set for the next round of talks, but the two men said it would take place soon.

BENVENISTE--Benjamin on May 25, 2006, age 70. Beloved husband of Evangeline. Devoted father of Jean-Paul and Tamara. Beloved brother of Joyce Lederman. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday 9:30am. Interment, Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

A Moscow court upheld a decision by Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov to refuse permission to hold a gay-rights parade in the city today. Plans for the parade, which would have been the city's first, provoked a storm of condemnation in Russia, where homosexuality has gained little acceptance since it a criminal ban on it was lifted in 1993. In remarks yesterday, Mr. Luzhkov called homosexuality ''a deviation'' and declared that a parade was ''absolutely unacceptable for Moscow, for Russia.'' A parade organizer, Nikolai Alekseyev, said a decision would be made today whether to defy the ban, and, if so, where to hold the march. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

EPSTEIN--Dorothy. Longtime activist, organizer, feminist and entrepreneur died on May 25, 2006 at the age of 92. She was independent, strong willed, generous, a fighter for causes she believed in, and the first woman to achieve many of the positions she held. Born in the Bronx in 1913, she graduated from Hunter College in 1933. Grateful for her free education at the college, she created the first endowed chair at that institution, and was an active member and contributor to its Scholarship and Welfare fund. She worked at the Department of Welfare where she organized the first sitdown strike and later became the first female local president at DC37. She worked for Russian War Relief and the American Labor Party and developed the Furriers' union dental clinic. Later she went into private industry and was the first female president of a vitamin production company, Synergy Plus. When she retired at age 76, she became a senior activist, first as president of the Hudson Guild Senior Center, then as the founding director of the Institute for Senior Action, a program which trains seniors to advocate for their needs. She is survived by her brother Donald of Pittsburgh and her son, Robert Jacobson and his partner Marilyn Gelber, of Brooklyn. A funeral will be at the Riverside Chapel at Amsterdam Av. & 76th St. on Sunday at 11:30AM. In her honor, contributions can be made to the Dorothy Epstein Legacy Fund, JPAC for Older Adults, 132 W. 31 St. NYC 10001. $(6$)EPSTEIN--Dorothy.We mourn the loss of a tremendous community leader. Hudson Guild

An article on Thursday about testimony at Saddam Hussein's trial by Tariq Aziz, once Mr. Hussein's principal international envoy, referred incorrectly to the Chaldean Christian religion Mr. Aziz practices. It is a rite of the Roman Catholic church, not a sect.

He avoided execution because of a Russian moratorium on capital punishment. The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Gen. Michael V. Hayden on Friday as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, despite some senators' criticism of his role in overseeing a domestic electronic surveillance program. The 78-to-15 vote showed that General Hayden's popularity on Capitol Hill as an articulate advocate for the spy agencies outweighed doubts about the legality of the eavesdropping program he ran as director of the National Security Agency. The only Republican to vote against confirmation was Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who has said he believes the program violates the law.

JUDGMENT day arrived for the two top executives at Enron, and the jury found both men guilty of fraud and deceit. The case was perhaps the most closely watched corporate crime trial of the decade. GUILTY, GUILTY, GUILTY -- Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling did in fact deceive investors about the real financial straits at Enron, the once-highflying energy company that imploded in a wave of accounting scandals, as a midlevel executive once predicted. After hearing four months of testimony and deliberating for five days, jurors convicted Mr. Lay, Enron's chairman and for many years its chief executive, on six counts of conspiracy and fraud. He is 64 and could be sentenced to as much as 45 years in federal prison.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Dean Singleton, the chief executive of the MediaNews Group, referred incorrectly to his management of The Dallas Times Herald. Mr. Singleton sold the newspaper before it was closed; he did not let it ''die.'' The article also referred incorrectly to a joint operating agreement between his paper, The Salt Lake Tribune, and its competitor, The Deseret News. The agreement existed before Mr. Singleton bought The Tribune; he did not force the The News into it.

CBS's criminal procedurals tend to draw an older audience, particularly after the season has wound down. On Thursday, its reruns of ''Numbers,'' featuring Rob Morrow, below (8.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen estimates); ''CSI'' (13 million); and ''Without a Trace'' (11.8 million) won the night in total viewers. But the shows were the strongest among viewers 55 and older, allowing Fox to take the night among adults 18 to 49, the chunk of the population advertisers prefer. Fox's lineup was made up solely of the premiere of the second season of ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' a competition from the producers of ''American Idol.'' It built its audience steadily over the course of two hours, during which a bunch of freaks and a few talented people auditioned for the show. Over all, ''Dance'' delivered 10.6 million viewers, and high ratings in both the 18-to-49 and 18-to-34 age groups. KATE AURTHUR

The night was damp, the Yankees' opponent was doleful, the holiday getaway traffic was dispiriting. The reason why 48,035 fans braved gloomy skies, gridlock and the Kansas City Royals last night would become as clear as an indelible memory in the bottom of the fourth inning. Derek Jeter, the Yankees' shortstop, led off against Royals starter Scott Elarton, who had retired him on a first-pitch flyout in the first. Popping flashbulbs blazed Jeter's path from the Yankee Stadium on-deck circle to home plate, as if he were a leading man at a red-carpet premiere.

We extend condolences to her loving family on this sad occasion. She will always be in our hearts, memories and prayers. Laura Kennedy, President and Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director, AHRC

To the Editor: ''Verdict on an Era'' (news analysis, May 26) says that the Enron trial was in fact an indictment of the era of corporate madness that swept over certain American businesses in the late 1990's.

A report in the Observatory column of Science Times on Tuesday about a study of dragonflies' migration misstated the direction of the prevailing winds they follow. The winds are northerly, not southerly.

The Yankees' Jorge Posada is at that age when catchers cannot ignore the wear and tear on their bodies. But a literal tear, in a little-used tendon behind his left leg, is hard for the 34-year-old Posada to deal with stoically. ''It's freaky,'' he said yesterday in the Yankees' clubhouse. Posada sat slumped on his folding chair, a solitary figure amid a hive of activity as his teammates busily prepared for the opener of a three-game series against the Kansas City Royals at Yankee Stadium.

A commentary article in Science Times on Tuesday about cervical cancer referred incorrectly to a vaccine, awaiting federal approval, that would protect against strains of human papillomavirus that cause the cancer. It is the second vaccine that would prevent a type of cancer. (The first such vaccine was against hepatitis B; in its chronic form, that disease can lead to liver cancer.)

To the Editor: Some years ago, I cut evening classes at Brooklyn College to visit my grandmother, when she was in bed with a stroke in the Bronx.

An obituary yesterday about James W. Carey, a scholar of communications theory at the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, misstated the length of the more academically rigorous master's degree program he helped to develop. It is one year, not two.

Oxford University won a qualified legal victory in its effort to limit protests by animal rights activists opposed to a new biomedical research center. Last week the university applied to the High Court to extend a so-called exclusion zone to keep protesters away from the center's $37 million construction site. The court agreed to a ''moderate'' extension of the zone -- less extensive than the university had sought -- but declined to reduce the permitted number of demonstrators to 12, from 50. It barred the use of megaphones during weekly protests and extended legal protection against harassment to contractors and other people associated with the university. The animal rights protesters said they would continue their campaign. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

6 P.M. (ESPN2) INDIANAPOLIS 500 FESTIVAL PARADE -- We don't know what she has to do with automobile racing, but Rachael Ray, the speedy television chef, will lead the pack as grand marshal of this 49th annual event. Lance Armstrong, the fast-and furious cyclist, will drive the official Indy pace car, followed by the 33 starting drivers -- among them (above, from left, shown on the flight deck of the Intrepid on May 22) Kosuke Matsuura, Danica Patrick and Michael Andretti -- and celebrities like Jim Nabors, Luke Perry and Florence Henderson bringing up the rear. As for Ms. Ray, perhaps she'll be whipping up the celebratory meal after the race's 90th running, tomorrow at 1 p.m. on ABC. 7 P.M. (Spike) THE PLAYBOOK -- ''Hitting the Beach Without Getting Burned.'' Donald Faison explains the basics of surviving sand and surf in this easy-to-navigate television manual for the common man. 7 P.M. (55) EBERT AND ROEPER -- The twitchy thumbed Roger Ebert and Richard Roeper discuss some of the year's biggest box-office hits and reveal their individual picks for the best movie of 2006, at least so far. 8 P.M. (Hallmark) THE CURSE OF KING TUT'S TOMB -- An Indiana Jones-type blazes a trail to Egypt to find the remaining piece of a jade tablet before his rival, who carries a dream of world domination, does. But who knew the gates of hell were about to open? Casper Van Dien (above), Jonathan Hyde and Leonor Varela star in this three-hour, made-for-television adventure. 9 P.M. (Fox) AMERICA'S MOST WANTED: AMERICA FIGHTS BACK -- The show reveals its winning All-Star, a first responder who personifies the best in law-enforcement officers, firefighters or emergency medical technicians. This hero receives $10,000 and a trip to the Nascar Nextel All-Star Challenge in Charlotte, N.C. 9 P.M. (Food Network) PILLSBURY BAKEOFF -- One hundred finalists rev up their burners for a $1 million prize. And only one of them bakes a cake. 9 P.M. (HGTV) MY FIRST PLACE -- Buying, let alone furnishing, a first home can be a rollercoaster ride. In this new episode, a bachelor's garage-sale furnishings are traded in for a stock car racing theme. 11 P.M. (IFC) CELEBRITY -- (1998). Kenneth Branagh plays a journalist peering in on famous lives and liking just a bit too much what he sees in this fizzy Woody Allen satire than only half works. But it's his wife, portrayed by Judy Davis (above, with Mr. Branagh, far left, and Joe Mantegna), who offers a brilliant moment of perspicacity: ''You can tell a lot about a society by who it chooses to celebrate.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

A senior official of Islamic Jihad and his brother were killed in Sidon, in southern Lebanon, when their car blew up. A spokesman for Islamic Jihad accused Israel of the attack and said it would take revenge. A spokeswoman for the Israeli Army, Capt. Noa Meir, denied its involvement in the deaths of Mahmoud Majzoub, known as Abu Hamza, and his brother Nidal, also a member of the radical militant group. Israel rarely acknowledges action outside Israel and the territories. STEVEN ERLANGER (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''Bush and Blair Concede Errors, but Defend War'' (front page, May 26):

For all their pluck and spunk, the Florida Marlins, the majors' youngest team, again entered Friday night's game at a disadvantage. Their lineup boasted a combined 10 plate appearances against the Mets' ace, Pedro Martínez, and only one hit. For all their talent and payroll, the Mets have proven unsuccessful in solving young pitchers. Their lineup boasted a combined zero plate appearances against the Marlins' impressive rookie starter, Josh Johnson.

A question came in at the last race, in Spain, in response to my virtual paddock post, with someone wanting to know what preparations the drivers do just before a race. I thought I'd gather together the responses for you and put them here, just before the race in Monaco so you can imagine what these drivers are doing right now. Incidentally, when I carry out this virtual paddock exercise in asking people in the paddock your questions for you, I tell the people that the questions are coming from readers of the blog, from the public, the fans, and not from me. They're generally delighted to be responding "directly" to the public.

The N.F.L. has proposed playing two regular-season games outside the United States starting in 2008, league officials said yesterday. Mark Waller, head of N.F.L. international development, said the proposal was put to team owners Tuesday in Denver. It came after the 49ers and the Cardinals played last October before a record crowd of 103,000 in Mexico City. The owners will discuss the issue again in October. The games would be played in Mexico, Canada, Britain and Germany, where five of the six N.F.L. Europe teams play.

Nikolay Davydenko of Russia, the defending champion, beat Andrei Pavel of Romania, 6-0, 6-3, yesterday in the final of the Hypo Group tournament in Pörtschach, Austria. Davydenko, 24, earned his sixth career title in winning the outdoor tournament on clay.

Second-seeded Nicole Vaidisova of the Czech Republic beat Peng Shuai of China, 7-6 (7), 6-3, yesterday to win the Strasbourg International in France. The 17-year-old Vaidisova won her sixth career W.T.A. title.

The American Bryan Clay led the decathlon at the Hypo Meeting yesterday in Götzis, Austria, after the world-record holder, Roman Sebrle of the Czech Republic, dropped out because of muscle problems. Clay led with 4,521 points through five events, followed by Dmitriy Karpov of Kazakhstan with 4,473.

Ivan Basso won the 20th stage of the Giro d'Italia yesterday, virtually clinching the overall victory one day before the race ends. It was Basso's third stage victory. He raised a photo of his son, Santiago, who was born Friday, as he crossed the finish line. Basso covered the 131-mile route from Trento to Aprica, over the famed Gavia and Mortirolo passes, in 6 hour 51 minutes 15 seconds. He has a lead of 9:18 over José Gutierrez Cataluna in the overall standings.

An article last Sunday about the difficulty in comparing the health of countries misinterpreted a finding on cholesterol in a British study that said Americans are sicker than Britons. The study showed that Americans have lower HDL cholesterol than the Britons; it did not conclude that Americans have lower LDL, or total, cholesterol. (HDL is the so-called good cholesterol, so lower levels do not indicate better health.).

Kelly assumes that people who encounter a tasty snippet on Google will be prompted to read the entire book. But the idea of reading may evolve over time to reflect the experience of using the new technology. Increasingly, we may read just the tiny chunks of books that correspond to our searches and fit comfortably on our BlackBerry-size screens. Mark Lewis New York

CHILDREN who love the magic of a carousel ride may begin to feel a tingle when they hear that a carousel has been proposed for a waterfront park in the Town of Oyster Bay. But their parents will quite likely be jolted out of their nostalgia, because this symbol of youthful fun is generating heated debate. ''Hand-carved horses, old-style seats shaped like Teddy bears -- the best of the folk art traditions is what we have in mind for the Theodore Roosevelt carousel,'' said Joan Mahon, the executive director of the Oyster Bay Main Street Association, which proposed the project. ''Our plan is to link the downtown shopping district of Oyster Bay hamlet to the waterfront area with this fun, friendly, family-oriented amusement ride.''

To the Editor: Re ''Remember This, Lucy Will Never Forget'' (May 14): I don't know what Sigmund Rimm, a Margate city commissioner, did to save Lucy the Elephant, a National Historic Landmark. But when my design firm worked with many other disciplines and trades to make it into a museum, we were all impressed with the efforts of Josephine Harron and Richard Helfant of the Save Lucy Committee. They had little local support and less money, yet they revived this rare artifact for the benefit of the city, state and nation.

While it is not quite an invasion of Long Beach Island, there will be a foreign presence patrolling the beaches in Ship Bottom this summer. If someone is floundering in the water, people don't care what accent the rescuer has. But what has set some residents' teeth chattering is the fact that the borough is spending $12,000 to rent an apartment for the lifeguards.

For fans of public apologies, May has been a good month. We've had Clear Channel Communications apologizing for an obscene rant by a New York hip-hop radio shock jock, Kaiser Permanente apologizing for ignoring voluminous complaints from patients about its new kidney transplant center in San Francisco and Hillary Clinton apologizing for saying that today's college graduates ''think work is a four-letter word.'' (Isn't it?) The chief executive of Raytheon was sorry that a company-produced booklet he wrote plagiarized a book published in 1944, a Missouri high school teacher was sorry for asking students to write about whom they would kill and how they would go about doing it and Hideki Matsui of the Yankees was sorry for breaking his wrist while diving for a ball.

To the Editor: Some questions about immigrants' taking jobs from citizens struck me when I read ''The 'Locusts' Have Their Day'' (editorial, May 14). Like the village of Mamaroneck described in the editorial, many communities have areas where day laborers congregate to be selected for odd jobs. I wonder how many of those job seekers are United States citizens. Are immigrants, legal or otherwise, hired at a greater rate? And if so, why? Do they tolerate lower pay or poorer working conditions? Do they just work harder? Are immigrants really taking jobs away from us citizens? Terry Takahashi Eugene, Ore.

To the Sports Editor: I would like to thank William C. Rhoden for his column about the death of Lauren's Charm at Belmont (''An Unknown Filly Dies, and the Crowd Just Shrugs,'' May 25). The Times pointed at something that people choose not to see. It is about time someone did. Jules Febre New York

To the Sports Editor: Although Major League Baseball and Commissioner Bud Selig may claim to commemorate only records, we all know why baseball will not acknowledge Barry Bonds's 715th home run. With No. 715, the fans have an opportunity to make a statement against Bonds, the steroid era and baseball's passive dissent.

To the Editor: I can scarcely believe that the island of Oahu described by Mr. Downes is the same place where I have been a half-year resident for the last 10 years. He seems to have missed the wild, unspoiled beauty of the North Shore, whose awe-inspiring 30-foot waves draw spectators and surfers from all over the world; the serenity that exudes from the many Buddhist temples that dot the island; the fun and exoticism of Chinatown; the world-class food (I'd rather eat in Honolulu than in Paris); the sensuousness of the color; and texture of island clothing. Boring? Like Fort Lauderdale and Cancún but for the Royal Mausoleum? Indeed! Irene Fischl Stamford, Conn.

To the Editor: I read with great interest your article about the Upper West Side and Eddie Cantor (''Through a Glass Brightly,'' May 14). As a former West Sider, I remember all of the places mentioned, though I wish some mention had been made of others, such as Tip Toe Inn, Ellman's and the bowling alley on 79th and Broadway.

An evil genius is the tick, which spreads disease by hiding in the fur of adorable woodland creatures. We freely slaughter the disease-bearing mosquito, but cannot as easily assault the tick because of our love for the white-tailed deer, its dainty, doe-eyed hostage. Instead of culling overabundant herds of suburban deer, we argue over how to subdue them with compassion, by fencing ourselves in, adjusting our gardening techniques or promoting deer family planning. The sturdy tick laughs, and multiplies. This looks to be another bad tick summer in the Northeast. Reports of Lyme disease were up 34 percent last year in Connecticut. Checking for ticks and taking antibiotics are a way of life on the East End of Long Island, particularly on Shelter Island, which has the highest incidence of Lyme disease and other tick-borne ailments in Suffolk County. The term ''Shelter Island foreplay'' describes nothing naughty but rather the fastidious monkey business of checking one another for ticks before bedtime.

For more than two years, a high-powered group of New Yorkers has been trying to figure out ways to bring the state's huge shadow government into the daylight and thus give the public a handle on hundreds of loosely regulated public-private authorities responsible for almost $30 billion in state revenue and $114 billion in outstanding debt. Last week, the group -- known as the New York State Commission on Public Authority Reform -- proposed several useful but modest reforms that will need to be strengthened to ensure that the authorities operate more openly and responsibly. The authorities were originally set up to be more like private corporations, avoiding bureaucratic snarls and moving nimbly to build and maintain public works projects like canals and subways. But over the years they have grown in number from a few big construction agencies to several hundred authorities free of government meddling and the market constraints that keep most public corporations in check.

''THE DA VINCI CODE'' opened in movie theaters on the day I saw Glen Berger's ''Underneath the Lintel'' at the Long Wharf Theater. So it was fairly easy to get into the mood for an ancient religious mystery and a related quest involving extreme secrecy, intricate detective work and global travel. This one, which reaches back to ancient Judea and the day of Jesus' crucifixion, turned out to be disarmingly entertaining.

The police arrested two young men yesterday in the fatal stabbing of a 19-year-old Bronx man on the Upper West Side on Friday. The victim, Eric Herrera, was attacked by a group of teenagers shortly before 2 p.m. outside 592 Amsterdam Avenue, between 88th and 89th Streets, the police and witnesses said.

THE mention of Rees Jones in Barbara Bush's autobiography tells one part of the story. It is a brief note in ''Barbara Bush: A Memoir,'' about her and former President George H. W. Bush's 50th anniversary weekend in Sea Island, Ga., where they had spent their honeymoon. Mr. Jones got to play in a fivesome that included Bill Jones, the chief executive of Sea Island, the professional golfer Davis Love III, former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell and Mr. Bush. ''One time Mr. Bush hit a ball in some swampy area and started to search for it,'' said the 64-year-old Mr. Jones, who was invited along because he had designed the course. ''I told him he didn't have to do that, that we would give him a good lie.''

To the Sports Editor: Jane Schwartz writes that the real miracle ''is that so many of us are still capable of caring so much.'' But the more important question is why we are moved by an injured horse yet remain unmoved by the millions of children worldwide who are victims of brutal human rights violations each day. Jonathan Todres New York
