To the Editor: Re ''Of Love and Money,'' by David Brooks (column, May 25):
An article last Sunday about the Dixie Chicks reversed the instruments that two of the musicians play. Emily Robison plays banjo, and Martie Maguire plays fiddle.

Beach season officially begins this weekend, and with it comes a brigade of carryalls, a little less disposable than in summers past. (Even a line of bags made from recycled candy wrappers runs into the $200 range). In canvas and terry, repurposed paper and sailcloth, here are some of the season's most shoreworthy totes. 1. Chanel's surf-print canvas tote comes in buoyant blue and red and has an outside zip pocket. The straps are made of nylon webbing ($1,250 at Chanel stores 800-550-0005). 2. L. L. Bean's Vacationland Multistripe Boat & Tote, with a zip top and a hidden key clip, provides lots of retro bang for the buck at $29 (at www.llbean.com). 3. A classic Bahia beach basket by Rafé has braided leather straps and green or coral floral handkerchief trim ($350 at Rafé New York, 877-772-3369). 4. Pucci's floral terrycloth hobo has canvas straps and white leather trim ($690 at Bergdorf Goodman). 5. An Ecoist tote bag made of braided recycled candy wrappers has a detachable orange nylon zip pouch and leather straps ($238 at www.orangelola.com). 6. Desmo's arts-and-crafts white cotton bucket bag is finished with dark leather trim and a drawstring ($598 at Searle stores). 7. The tweedy linen Sac Marine by Hermès cuts a long silhouette with a flat-front zipper pocket and a drawstring top ($2,100 at Hermès stores). 8. Nanette Lepore's 40's-inspired banana-leaf print bag has ribbon-wrapped handles and a flap front adorned with a bow ($310 at Nanette Lepore in New York, 212-219-8265). 9. Seabags are made of recycled sails that come complete with stars, bars and numbers and have hand-spliced rope handles ($95 at www.seabags.com).
To the Sports Editor: Re ''We Care. But Why Do We Care So Much?'' (May 22) by Jane Schwartz:

A Dance entry today in the Week Ahead report on Page 4 of Arts & Leisure includes an outdated reference to Mikhail Baryshnikov's appearances with Ballet Tech. Because of a shoulder injury, he will not dance when the company performs at the Joyce Theater beginning May 31.

GUTH--Bernard. The family of The Curtis Institute of Music mourns the loss of its devoted friend Bernard Guth and extends deepest sympathy to his family. He was a longtime and invaluable member of our Board of Trustees, combining business acumen with highly sophisticated musicianship. A gentleman of impeccable taste, wit, and an infectious zest for the good life, he was an excellent companion, as well as a committed advocate for maintaining the highest quality of artistic effort. We will always remember him with the greatest respect and love. Richard A. Doran, Chairman Gary Graffman, President/Director The Curtis Institute of Music

To the Editor: The books about tramp steamers fondly recalled by E. L. Doctorow in ''Globe-Trotters' Favorites; Tomes That Can Trigger a Writer's Wanderlust'' (Influences, May 14) are the Tod Moran mysteries by Howard Pease. This wonderful series of books for young people is long out of print, but used copies are widely available on the Internet. Wallace Johnson Rochester, N.Y.

MILFORD, MICH. The News -- The F.B.I. began tearing down a horse barn at a farm outside Detroit, continuing the search for signs of the former Teamsters union president James R. Hoffa. Behind the News -- A week of digging has produced no evidence of the remains of Mr. Hoffa, who disappeared in 1975. But the F.B.I. has called the tip that led agents to the site the most credible lead in years. An informant, in prison on drug charges, claims he saw the labor leader buried at the spot where the barn stands now. At the time of the disappearance the farm was owned by a Hoffa associate, Rolland McMaster, now 92. WASHINGTON The News -- Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales said journalists who publish classified information might be open to prosecution. Behind the News -- In a television interview, Mr. Gonzales said the government had ''an obligation'' to protect national security, and appeared to refer to espionage laws. Scholars say those laws were never meant to apply to journalists, yet Mr. Gonzales's comments raised the possibility, at least, that they might be applied in recent cases, including publication by The New York Times of information about a National Security Agency surveillance program. CONGRESS The News -- The F.B.I. searched the offices of a congressman as part of a bribery investigation, touching off a dispute between Congress and the Justice Department. Behind the News -- The department refused to relinquish records seized from the office of Representative William J. Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana. Congressional leaders had demanded their return, saying the search violated constitutional doctrines, including the separation of powers, and historical practice. By midweek, President Bush intervened, ordering the records sealed for 45 days to give both sides time to work out an agreement. WASHINGTON The News -- The Department of Veterans Affairs was investigating the theft of electronic records of 26.5 million veterans, including information like Social Security numbers and dates of birth. Behind the News -- The records were stolen from the home of an employee who routinely took sensitive data out of the office to work on. Secretary Jim Nicholson said procedures for reporting the theft were not followed -- he said he did not hear about it for two weeks. He was expected to ask Congress for money to pay for the incident. Just sending letters to the affected veterans was estimated to cost more than $10 million. NEW ORLEANS The News -- With the hurricane season about to begin, the Army Corps of Engineers put the finishing touches on the rebuilt levee system of New Orleans. Behind the News -- The rebuilding project, which cost $800 million and involved more than 150 miles of levees, was lauded as a major engineering feat. Experts noted the system was better in many ways. But critics wondered if it was improved enough, given how inadequate the system was to begin with. Even corps officials acknowledged they could not guarantee it would not fail again in another catastrophic storm.

Kelly has mixed together two articles, one that deals thoughtfully with issues of copyright law and one that attempts to revive the medieval, Faustian dream of latching on to a divine knowledge of the universe. Joseph Fitzer La Grange, Ill.

TO Harvey Weisman, a Woodmere developer, the former Mill Neck Marina in Locust Valley seems like a fine setting for four $800,000 to $1 million houses that he wants permission from the Town of Oyster Bay to build. A local county legislator, some neighbors and an environmental group, Friends of the Bay, all disagree. They say that the property, which is on the shore of a national wildlife preserve, is fit only for cleanup and preservation.

To the Editor: The article mentions that public health advocates are likely to oppose BabyFirst. The article does not elaborate however. Television viewing in small children is far from innocuous. Numerous studies have linked television watching among infants and toddlers to increases in attention problems and obesity. The Times should address these issues rather than tout this ridiculous channel. Fiona Havers Seattle

To the Editor: I was saddened to see that the Long Island Maritime Museum in West Sayville was not included among the ''don't miss'' Long Island museums (''The Island's Attics, With Plenty of Quirks,'' May 21).

ON a recent Saturday, Drew Wendol, the Hastings High School boys' lacrosse coach, left home at 7 a.m. Fifteen hours, two lacrosse clinics, a lacrosse luncheon and a narrow victory over Pelham later, he returned.

As a man with an artificial knee, I instantly smelled a rat when I saw the headline and lead on the airline seating article. Even now, has any member of The Times contacted the Federal Aviation Administration about the insurmountable safety and medical concerns such a scheme would present?

To the Editor: I am not a fan of recorded books in any format myself, but I am always dismayed when authors like David A. Kelly, in his article ''Digital Entertainment: New Audio Books Pack a Lot More Prose'' (Practical Traveler, May 14) fail to mention that the materials they are writing about are available free to registered borrowers at many public libraries. He did give a nod to talking books for the blind through the National Library Service, but you do not have to have a disability to have access to downloadable audio books through a library. Check www.bccls.org for one example of a library consortium in Northern New Jersey that offers these to residents of 73 communities. Gail Enid Zimmer Fair Lawn, N.J.

Ever since the Morgans Hotel Group went public in February, Lance Armstrong, the seven-time champion of the Tour de France, has served on its board. So why is he lying in a hammock in an ad for the rival Mandarin Oriental luxury hotel chain in a recent issue of The New Yorker? On the Web site of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group, Mr. Armstrong, who has had an endorsement deal with that company for four years, raves that he ''fell in love with Mandarin Oriental, San Francisco, it's a great place with great people and great views.''
SOKOLOW - Isabel. Dear friend, 58 years ago at Erasmus High we met. I will miss and remember you as a devoted friend, great sculptor, gentle soul and beautiful lady. Joyce Altman Rosenberg

For many of us in New Jersey, life comes down to two basic needs: home and the Shore. And as we gear up for another blissful season of traffic jams, sunburns and sand fleas, it's a good time to read Emil R. Salvini's recent book, ''Boardwalk Memories: Tales of the Jersey Shore'' (Globe Pequot, $24.95). Mr. Salvini is a historian with solid credentials. He is a member of the Cape May Historic Preservation Commission, a past president of the North Jersey Highlands Historical Society and a life member of the Cape May County Historical Society. His lifelong love of boardwalks began with visits to his grandparents' home in Bradley Beach and walking the boards in Asbury Park. That was where he learned to play Skee-Ball and where, years later, he taught the game to his daughters.

IT was a bit eerie last Sunday on many Connecticut soccer fields. It was cold and raining, and the parents huddled under umbrellas were unusually quiet. They were quiet even when their team scored a goal. It was Silent Sidelines Weekend across the state and parents were supposed to refrain from their usual oratory, trading shouts and whoops for polite applause and maybe just a word or two of encouragement instead.

A review on May 14 about ''Sons of Providence: The Brown Brothers, the Slave Trade, and the American Revolution,'' by Charles Rappleye, misstated the year that a band of Rhode Islanders destroyed the Gaspee, a British revenue ship. It was 1772, not 1773.

Of all the third-rail issues in New Jersey -- and there are almost as many of those as New Jersey Transit cars in disrepair -- the big one is home rule. Whatever that is. Former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, who knows a few things about politics, says ''Home rule in New Jersey is a religion'' -- but is careful enough not to add that people are worshiping a false idol.

COASTAL towns and cities all around America are deciding whether to let the government pay 90 percent of the cost of having the Army Corps of Engineers protect property along their shore by dredging and pumping sand to replenish beaches that have suffered from decades of erosion and overdevelopment. With sea levels rising and stronger, more frequent storms all but certain, how can communities pass up this offer? Recently, though, the City Council of Long Beach, N.Y., the largest coastal community in Nassau County, voted unanimously against a corps proposal to protect them from storms.

ANYONE who thinks that a signature on a painting confers authenticity may want to consider the curious case of ''Keene Valley,'' a late-1860's oil painting now in an exhibition of works from the permanent collection at the Heckscher Museum of Art here. These days, the painting is attributed to Asher B. Durand, a highly valued Hudson River School painter -- one of his works, ''Kindred Spirits'' (1849), was sold by the New York Public Library a year ago to the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton for more than $35 million. But for much of the life of ''Keene Valley,'' this was not necessarily the case.

To the Editor: ''Mark Twain in Hawaii, The Original Surf Bum?'' (May 14) by Lawrence Downes was stunning. Mr. Downes was taken with Mr. Twain's perspective on Hawaii, but I was taken with his. That image of the old lava flows as crunchy ''coffee grounds'' was perfect and accurate, though definitely not something you'd find in a hotel guide book. Kaui Hart Hemmings San Francisco, Calif.
ROSENBERG--Fred. We love and miss you. Henriette & Marilyn

So I have a deal worked out with the newsstand guy at Astor Place. Y'know that cool cat with the cigarette stub in his mouth all the time? Well, I hate to break it down this way -- but I just buy The Times Magazine for a dollar and nothing else. Why? For Jaime Hernandez's weekly comic, ''La Maggie La Loca.'' Do you know how good you guys have it, how good we all have it now? It's the return of the romantic adventure comic strip! I'm hooked! I'm buggin' the vendor at 4 p.m. on Saturday afternoons, ''Did you get The Times Magazine yet, huh?'' I'm not kidding. Frank Santoro New York

OF all the possible business investments over the last decade, real estate at the Jersey Shore has been among the rosiest. While this is still largely true, real estate brokers say they have noticed an odd twist this season: extravagant houses in the $5 million to $10 million range are moving quickly, but sales of midpriced housing have slowed. ''Sometimes you don't know when a market is changing until it actually happens,'' said Ron Soldano, an agent with James C. Otton Real Estate in Stone Harbor. ''Suddenly, those meat-and-potatoes properties in Avalon and Stone Harbor, those that go for between $1 million and $2 million, these are just lying fallow.''

EACH year, the International Festival of Arts and Ideas focuses on bringing hundreds of artists from throughout the world to New Haven for about two weeks to dance, sing, perform and display their works. This year, with a new director, the theme grew more specific: Reach out to New Orleans and the artists affected by Hurricane Katrina. So New Orleans, with its distinct flavors and sounds, will be descending on New Haven on June 10 through 24.

To the Editor: Michael Patrick Hearn, reviewing ''The Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane,'' by Kate DiCamillo (May 14), compares the illustrations of Bagram Ibatoulline with those of ''Andrew Wyeth, Howard Pyle and Maxfield Parrish.'' The referenceshould have been to N. C. Wyeth, the father of Andrew and the best-known artist of the Golden Age of Illustration. Howard Pyle was N. C. Wyeth's teacher and mentor. Maxfield Parrish rose to prominence during this same era. Andrew, on the other hand, was a young boy at that time, learning to paint under the tutelage of his father. He is not an illustrator. Cathryn C. Girard Sarasota, Fla.

IF the crowd at the Jacob Burns Film Center last Monday was any indication, Al Gore's documentary crusade to save the planet may start a national debate on global warming. ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' shown in a preview, segued to a discussion on how to reduce greenhouse gases and -- more important, some said -- how to get more people to see the movie so they, too, could talk about reducing greenhouse gases.

Mills Corporation, the developer of the Xanadu shopping and entertainment complex at the Meadowlands, has acknowledged that the project will take longer, cost more and earn less money than originally projected, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. That disclosure rekindled fears on Wednesday that New Jersey may be spending hundreds of millions in tax dollars to provide infrastructure improvements for what could turn out to be little more than a shopping mall. But Mills executives and state officials say that there are no plans to curtail construction of the entertainment and extreme-sports facilities intended to make the complex as much of a tourist destination as a shopping center. In its filing with the S.E.C., Mills, based in Arlington, Va., said that Xanadu's opening would be delayed six months to a year beyond the recently announced date of the fall of 2007, and its cost would be higher than anticipated.

To the Editor: ''Where are the literary women?'' I wondered as I read ''Literary New York'' (Going To, May 14). Of the 27 writers in Steven Kurutz's article, only 2 were women -- Jhumpa Lahiri and ''Vogue contributor Plum Sykes.'' For starters, I wrote in Edith Wharton, Dorothy Parker, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Willa Cather and Dorothy West. Undoubtedly, other readers of The New York Times had the same reaction I did and started a more balanced, if not exclusively female ''Going to Literary New York.'' There are choices galore. Penny Colman Englewood, N.J.

THE deep horizontal lines across his forehead and the yawning crevices between his brows bothered Michael Ross. In younger days, he said, he had baked too often in the sun, using a double record album covered in aluminum foil as a reflector. ''I take care of my body,'' said Mr. Ross, now 42 and a middle school teacher. ''In a tank top and shorts, I look younger than the average 40-year-old. I was concerned that, from the neck up, I didn't.''

The MUSEUM OF MODERN ART has adopted a title with missionary zeal, ''To Save and Project,'' as the title of its annual festival of newly preserved films from the world's archives. And a mission it is, against the deadly alliance of time and chemistry that has destroyed, according to the figure most often quoted by preservationists, around 90 percent of the world's stock of silent films and at least 40 percent of all sound cinema. The monthlong program, which began on May 19, covers an array of genres and countries, from Hollywood films of the 1950's and 60's to a selection of features by TEUVO TULIO, a Finnish filmmaker active from 1929 to 1972, whom Aki Kaurismaki, Finland's current leading director, has praised as a master. Four of Tulio's melodramas are on view this week: ''THE CROSS OF LOVE'' (1946) Sunday at 5:30 p.m.; ''IN THE FIELDS OF DREAMS'' (1940) Monday at 1:30 p.m.; ''THE WAY YOU WANTED ME'' (1944) Monday at 3:45 p.m.; and ''THE SONG OF THE SCARLET FLOWER'' (1938), Monday at 6 p.m. The Italian filmmaker PIETRO GERMI is known for his acerbic social comedies, including the murderous satire ''Divorce, Italian Style'' (1961). But he began his career in the postwar era making crime films, very much in the American noir style of shadowy social realism. ''GIOVENTÙ PERDUTA'' (''Lost Youth'') was Germi's second feature, made in 1947 but still concerned with the lingering influence of fascism in the confused years after the war. Jacques Sernas stars as a strikingly Aryan college student, the son of a respected professor, who has organized his impressionable friends into a criminal gang that robs for thrills; a melodramatic flourish is provided by the enduringly popular leading man Massimo Girotti as a police infiltrator who falls in love with Sernas's sister. It's a terse, violent film that recalls the contemporary Hollywood work of Richard Fleischer and Anthony Mann. ''Gioventù Perduta'' screens on Sunday at 1 p.m. and Wednesday at 6 p.m. But the revelation of the week is an early film by the American master KING VIDOR. ''THE FAMILY HONOR,'' made in 1920, stars Florence Vidor, a beauty out of John Singer Sargent who was married to the director at the time, as a fallen aristocrat of the Old South. Like many of Vidor's protagonists, she is caught between the lure of urbanization (represented by her suitor, an enterprising local newspaper editor) and the comforts of rustification. But this time, it's the small town that turns out to be corrupt, and Vidor's indictment of the narrow village types is as sharply observant as his depiction of the vanished milieu of the self-contained small town. This lovely and trenchant film has been preserved by the Cinémathèque Française with its original tints. It shows on Friday at 2 p.m. 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400.

WHAT WE OWE IRAQ: War and the Ethics of Nation Building, by Noah Feldman. (Princeton University, $14.95.) In the spring of 2003 Feldman, a professor of constitutional law at New York University, helped shape Iraq's Transitional Administrative Law, the political road map for the country's journey from occupied territory to democratic nation. In ''What We Owe Iraq'' -- part theoretical treatise, part political analysis, part memoir -- Feldman, right, makes the case that when the United States invaded Iraq, it not only toppled a tyrant but also undertook a ''trusteeship'' on behalf of the Iraqi people. In SQUANDERED VICTORY: The American Occupation and the Bungled Effort to Bring Democracy to Iraq (Owl Books/Holt, $15), Larry Diamond recalls his time spent in Iraq as part of the Coalition Provisional Authority and argues that the country's postwar troubles are the result of ''gross negligence'' on the part of a Bush administration that rushed to war.

For more than two years, a high-powered group of New Yorkers has been trying to figure out ways to bring the state's huge shadow government into the daylight and thus give the public a handle on hundreds of loosely regulated public-private authorities responsible for almost $30 billion in state revenue and $114 billion in outstanding debt. Last week, the group -- known as the New York State Commission on Public Authority Reform -- proposed several useful but modest reforms that will need to be strengthened to ensure that the authorities operate more openly and responsibly. The authorities were originally set up to be more like private corporations, avoiding bureaucratic snarls and moving nimbly to build and maintain public works projects like canals and subways. But over the years they have grown in number from a few big construction agencies to several hundred authorities free of government meddling and the market constraints that keep most public corporations in check.

ANNE CUBBERLY spent her teenage years staring closely at the paintings in the halls of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art. She stood so close to the art that she feared a security guard would bark at her to move back. But no one did, she didn't move, and after years of exceptionally close examination, Ms. Cubberly found her artistic future. That future was in trash.

The Going To column on May 14 about literary New York misstated the setting of the novel ''Requiem for a Dream'' by Hubert Selby Jr. It is the Bronx, not Coney Island, which was the setting for the movie based on the book.

THE gamble behind a new exhibition at the Pierro Gallery of South Orange has paid off. It is a success for the artists and for the curator, Mary Birmingham, who wanted to create an exhibition that reflected current issues in American society. She chose headlines as a theme, finding artists who worked with material gathered from the mass media to make art. The result is an intensely topical show. Ms. Birmingham, an independent curator, has selected artwork that refers to current events, politics and world affairs. Some of the work directly engages these issues, making social, cultural and political statements. But other work looks at what Ms. Birmingham calls in a catalog essay for the exhibition ''the mediation of news,'' or the way in which the news media package and filter information for consumption.

LILIENFELD--Harold. Died May 26 at age 71. Most loved husband (Eva), adored father (Debra, Gary) and father-inlaw (Karen, Alan). Cherished Grandpa (Alison, Eric, Erika, and Julie). Always caring son (Trude). Fondest brother (Curt). Uncle, cousin and invaluable friend to all.

FOR me, Memorial Day weekend brings back memories of yard sales that have come and gone, but there is one that particularly sticks in my mind. It was an estate sale, to be exact, in Goldens Bridge. The books were heaped haphazardly across a floor muddy with the footprints of antiques hunters. I got there late, and the bookcases had been sold, along with most of the furniture. No matter; it was the books that caught my eye, old but in excellent shape, covers solid and bright, gilded titles still gleaming. I went right to my knees. Books only an English professor could love: American, a century old, mostly by forgotten writers. I began stacking them up, leafing through each volume to assess condition and to search for the treasures that sometimes fall out of old books: flowers, letters, handmade paper dolls.

I'm a linear person usually, but I fell in love with Chris Ware's tender and melancholy comic strip, ''Building Stories,'' and miss it now that it's gone. His everyday people in muted tones cast a mood all their own. Please have him come back soon. Carol Netzer Brooklyn

Mame Dennis, that self-styled life force in a turban and high heels, may have launched a thousand drag queens since she showed up in Patrick Dennis's 1955 novel, ''Auntie Mame.'' But the indefatigable old siren has definitely had her effect on real women too, particularly American actresses in mid-career. In the 1950's Rosalind Russell (pushing 50 herself) acquired a sheen of high glamour (plus Tony and Oscar nominations) by appearing in the stage and film adaptations. And it was ''MAME,'' the 1966 musical version of the play, that made an A-list star out of Angela Lansbury. (Without Mame, would there have been a Jessica Fletcher?) And now it is the turn of CHRISTINE BARANSKI, who opens as the singing, dancing high-bohemian socialite on Thursday at the KENNEDY CENTER in Washington. Though she was won two Tonys and an Emmy for supporting roles, Ms. Baranski has long been a major musical comedy star waiting to happen, as anyone can testify who saw her show-stealing turn in the Encores! concert production of ''Promises, Promises'' at City Center. The question is whether ''Mame,'' which is really just a sweet sherry pretending to be a martini, will avoid the time-warp cramps that critics found in the 1983 Broadway revival (again starring Ms. Lansbury). Trying to ensure against signs of cultural aging are the inventive director ERIC SCHAEFFER and a supporting cast that includes HARRIET HARRIS (as the sourly pickled diva Vera Charles) and EMILY SKINNER (as the nerdy Agnes Gooch). The songs, of course, are by JERRY HERMAN, who, as the composer of both ''Mame'' and ''Hello, Dolly!,'' has kept many a post-ingénue actress in mink. (800) 444-1324; $25 to $90.

The Simple Art of the Story In a world rocked by iPods, computer games and ''American Idol,'' sometimes pulling up a seat and listening to a simple story can be just plain refreshing. This Sunday in Riverhead, the East End Arts Council will offer a retreat from sensory overload at the 10th annual Community Mosaic and Street Painting Festival and, more specifically, its Storytelling Tent.

Julie Ann Karp and Eddan Elizafon Katz are to be married today by Rabbi James E. Ponet, the Jewish chaplain at Yale, at the Colonnade Hotel in Boston, with Rabbi Jonathan E. Kraus taking part. The bride, 30, a doctoral candidate in epidemiology and public health at Yale, graduated cum laude from Harvard and received a master's degree in public health from Columbia. The bride's father, Dr. Daniel D. Karp, lives in Houston, where he is the deputy division head for clinical programs and cancer medicine at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, and a professor of thoracic, head and neck medical oncology at the University of Texas. Her mother, Elizabeth Karp of Cambridge, Mass., is an associate in the Boston office of Gensler Architecture, Design and Planning Worldwide.

As Memorial Day opens the beach season, the shores of Long Island and New Jersey will teem with sunburned masses. But for pure nostalgia and intriguing restaurants, it's hard to beat Coney Island and Brighton Beach. CAFE GLECHIK (718) 616-0494; 3159 Coney Island Avenue (Brighton Beach Avenue), Brighton Beach; $; $25 and Under: 5/10/06. Dumplings are the main attraction at this Russian-Ukrainian restaurant a block from the Riegelmann Boardwalk. Vareniki, crescent-shaped dumplings less bulky than pirogi, are offered with nine stuffings, including sweet farmer cheese, salted farmer cheese and sour cherry. If meat-stuffed dumplings are what the evening calls for, the pelmeni -- almost shu mai-like in their crinkled delicacy -- aren't to be ignored. Three varieties are on offer: chicken, veal or a hearty mix of pork and veal called Siberia. GARGIULO'S (718) 266-4891; 2911 West 15th Street (Mermaid Avenue), Coney Island; $$; Article: 11/06/02. Rumor has it that Al Capone was a busboy at this old-time family-run Neapolitan restaurant, which opened in 1907 in the heart of Coney Island. The large menu is everything you would expect it to be, with appetizers like baked clams, stuffed mushrooms, eggplant and peppers and fish salad, an array of pasta dishes and risottos offered in full or half portions, and entrees like lobster fra diavolo, shrimp scampi and veal scallopine. NATHAN'S FAMOUS (718) 946-2202; 1310 Surf Avenue (Stillwell Avenue), Coney Island; $; Article: 5/25/05. Nathan Handwerker, egged on by his friends Jimmy Durante and Eddie Cantor, opened this hot dog stand in 1916 to cater to the many poor and working-class people frequenting Coney Island. The Nathan's in Coney Island still serves an excellent natural-casing all-beef hot dog. Avoid the skinless all-beef dog that is a pale imitation. PRIMORSKI (718) 891-3111; 282 Brighton Beach Avenue (Brighton Third Street), Brighton Beach; $$; Article: 4/7/00. Primorski is one of those overflowing Brighton Beach restaurants where excess is the rule. It's Russian but it's not Imperial Russian, so the caviar is salmon caviar, which is fine. The point is not connoisseurship but enjoyment, with a five-piece band and dancing thrown in. The menu features more than 150 selections of cold appetizers, hot appetizers, seafood and meat. TOTONNO PIZZERIA (718) 372-8606; 1524 Neptune Avenue (West 15th Street), Coney Island; $; Article: 11/6/02. Totonno's, one of the early giants of New York coal-oven pizza, is legendary for its devotion to artisanal pies served in humble surroundings; the pressed-tin walls are covered with testimonials. With its site in a small Italian bastion, Totonno's almost feels as if it's in another city.

New Jersey residents who commute to Manhattan by ferry now have a gleaming new terminal in Weehawken. It opened last Monday, just in time to ease the pain of an increase in fares. The terminal, which cost $44 million in public money, will be the home base of New York Waterway, a private company that runs ferries between several docks in New Jersey, Midtown and Lower Manhattan. This coming week, Waterway plans to raise its fares to and from the new terminal to as much as $9 each way. New Jersey Transit owns the terminal but will not run it or set fares, said Kris Kolluri, the state's commissioner of transportation and the chairman of the transit agency. PATRICK McGEEHAN
To the Sports Editor: Whenever I refer to horse racing and dog racing as inhumane, I'm inevitably met with, ''It's a sport; it's part of our culture.''
KORNICKI--Manny. On May 7, 2006. Devoted husband of Bertha and beloved father of Marian. Always in our hearts.

O.K., so he didn't hop aboard a bulldozer and help raze an abandoned building in Camden. But for more than 24 hours last week, Assembly Speaker Joseph J. Roberts Jr., a Democrat from Camden, could be called something that few others can claim: acting governor. When a sitting governor is out of state, the next in line is the Senate president, and that is what happened when Gov. Jon S. Corzine left last Sunday for a weeklong trip to Asia, and former Gov. Richard J. Codey, no stranger to the title, took over.

EPSTEIN--Dorothy. Longtime activist, organizer, feminist and entrepreneur died on May 25, 2006 at the age of 92. She was independent, strong willed, generous, a fighter for causes she believed in, and the first woman to achieve many of the positions she held. Born in the Bronx in 1913, she graduated from Hunter College in 1933. Grateful for her free education at the college, she created the first endowed chair at that institution, and was an active member and contributor to its Scholarship and Welfare fund. She worked at the Department of Welfare where she organized the first sitdown strike and later became the first female local president at DC37. She worked for Russian War Relief and the American Labor Party and developed the Furriers' union dental clinic. Later she went into private industry and was the first female president of a vitamin production company, Synergy Plus. When she retired at age 76, she became a senior activist, first as president of the Hudson Guild Senior Center, then as the founding director of the Institute for Senior Action, a program which trains seniors to advocate for their needs. She is survived by her brother Donald of Pittsburgh and her son, Robert Jacobson and his partner Marilyn Gelber, of Brooklyn. A funeral will be at the Riverside Chapel at Amsterdam Av. & 76th St. on Sunday at 11:30AM. In her honor, contributions can be made to the Dorothy Epstein Legacy Fund, JPAC for Older Adults, 132 W. 31 St. NYC 10001. $(6$)EPSTEIN--Dorothy. The Jewish Association for Services for the Aged (JASA) and JPAC for Older Adults mourn the loss of longtime activist leader and friend, Dorothy Epstein and extend condolences to her family. Founder of JPAC's Institute for Senior Action (IFSA) in 1993, Dorothy was a leading force in the senior empowerment movement for over 17 years. Through her personal example, she inspired older adults and the public to recognize the capacity of older persons to grow, create and contribute to society's well being. She will be missed. David Warren, President, JASA Aileen Gitelson, CEO, JASA Molly Krakowski, JPAC Dir $(6$)EPSTEIN--Dorothy. We are saddened by the loss of our beloved and loyal alumna. While at Hunter and since graduating in 1933, Dorothy dedicated her life to political and social activism. She established the first endowed chair at Hunter, the Dorothy Epstein Chair in Latin American History. Our deepest condolences to son Robert Jacobson & daughterin-law, Marilyn Gelber. Her lively and engaging spirit will long be rememberd. Jennifer J. Raab, President, and the Hunter College Community $(6$)EPSTEIN--Dorothy. The New York City Department for the Aging mourns the loss of our friend and colleague, Dorothy Epstein. Dorothy was a longstanding member of the Department's Senior Advisory Committee and helped to define its mission. We extend our condolences to the family $(6$)EPSTEIN--Dorothy. Writer, political activist, founder of the Institute for Senior Action, generous benefactor, and beloved friend. My condolences to Robert and Marilyn. Rose Dobrof

There is perhaps nothing so idealistic, in the best sense, as the ambition to make information available to the largest possible number of people. But Kevin Kelly's argument (May 14) in favor of a ''universal'' electronic library possesses a common flaw, which is expressed when the contents of books are routinely referred to as ''information.'' Books (and other forms of text) are, of course, far more than that; it is the purveyors of scanning technology who must portray books solely as information, for it is only as bits of information that books can be processed. Texts, which are not just objects but encounters, possess context: ideology, historicity, consciousness, form, not to mention body, material depth. This is true not just for verse and fiction, but for history and science. To ''integrate'' texts by extracting, remixing and reassembling them, to use Kelly's terms, is to obliterate the meaningful autonomy that distinguishes the individual work. Jeffrey Weiss Head of the Department of Modern and Contemporary Art National Gallery of Art Washington

Welcome to this book, this feast. 1 I wrote this book to encourage others to start their own traditions. To help others find their own way to celebrate. 2 For me, purity is the only true approach. 3 Nothing is better in the morning than the enlivening vodka drinks. . . . I have a predilection for rising early, and when I am preparing for a dinner party, I enjoy rising at 5 or 5:30 and going straight from the bath to the kitchen. I call this ''cooking in the nude.'' 4 Food respects confidence, and abhors uncertainty. 5 By embracing my imperfections, I hope to encourage others to feel at home with this book. 2 It's all bueno! 6

THE Village of Great Neck Plaza, which covers one-third of a square mile on Long Island's Gold Coast, has 1,100 parking meters that in the last fiscal year added almost $1 million to the village's coffers -- nearly one-fifth of its budget. In stark contrast, neighboring Great Neck Village, which spans 1.4 square miles, does not even have parking meters.

Of the teams in the N.C.A.A. Division I lacrosse semifinals, the University of Massachusetts had the least impressive pedigree and seemingly the least amount of potential. The Minutemen, in the national semifinals for the first time, were regarded as an afterthought in the company of lacrosse blue bloods like Maryland, Virginia and Syracuse.

CONNELLY--Elizabeth A. A longtime friend to United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Betty was a frequent visitor to our center on Staten Island, always talking with and listening to our program participants, asking what she and her colleagues in government could do to make their lives more hopeful and increase their independence. As a result of her unwavering leadership and advocacy, New York State agreed to close all its institutions serving over 50,000 individuals with disabilities and create the community based settings that are the benchmark of our services today. The board and staff of UCP/NYC, and especially our consumers and families, mourn her loss and extend our deepest sympathies to her husband, Robert, and her entire family. Martin Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Executive Director UCP of NYC, Inc. $(6$)CONNELLY -- Elizabeth A. The Board and staff of the Staten Island Mental Health Society mourn the loss of Assemblywoman Elizabeth A. Connelly, a tireless champion for the rights and dignity of persons with disabilities. She will be greatly missed.

What's in a Name? A Band Won't Say What About Frank?, a five-member band from Red Bank, won't reveal the origin of its name. ''It's kind of a secret,'' said Sam Bey, the drummer. And besides, he added, the band is going to change it. ''We're looking for a name that's less hokey and more representative of our music,'' he said. The band, which formed in the fall of 2004, is reminiscent of early Led Zeppelin, T-Rex and the White Stripes. Earlier this month, What About Frank? signed a deal with Capitol Records, home of the Beastie Boys, Coldplay and Radiohead, after a bidding war among major labels. The band's lead singer, Mark Melicia, said, ''They were just the coolest people and the most understanding of what we were going for.'' The band recently left for Los Angeles to record a five-song EP that will be released this summer. The band hopes to have a full-length album out in early 2007.

Stephens Inc., the big investment bank built by two brothers in Little Rock, Ark., is being broken up by their children. The company said that the current chief executive, Warren A. Stephens -- son of Jackson T. Stephens, a former chief executive who died last year -- would run Stephens Inc. and its financial services companies.

Survived by the love of his life--wife Muriel, married 58 years. Proud and loving father of Andrew (Donna), Peter (Debbie), and Tom (Pam). Beloved and loving Grandpa ''Pop'' of Liza, Todd, Martin, Matthew and Alexander. Brother of Ruth Schatz, loving uncle of many nieces and nephews. His family was the most important part of his life. Private services held in Tucson, Arizona. Information: East Lawn Palms Mortuary, 520-885-6741

The SOLOMON R. GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM's Frank Lloyd Wright rotunda is about to be the setting for another innovative architect's work, that of the Iraqi-born, London-based architect ZAHA HADID. Ms. Hadid, whose buildings are often characterized by their floating lines and sharp angles, has designed the show herself, and it includes 30 years of projects. The scope of Ms. Hadid's work is particularly large. On view starting Saturday will be some 140 of her Constructivist-inspired paintings, sketchbooks and drawings, which she calls her ''testing fields.'' The building's top three ramps will be lined with 95 architectural models from her projects. The show will explore many of her recent buildings, including the Phaeno Science Center in Wolfsburg, Germany, and the BMW Central Building in Leipzig, Germany, along with her design for the Vitra Fire Station in Weil am Rhein, Germany, and the Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati. Also on view will be her prototype for the environmentally responsive, three-wheeled urban Z-Car, a commission for Kenny Schachter, a British collector and art dealer, as well as the Z-Kitchen, which was unveiled at the Milan Design Fair last month. The ''sensory responsive,'' science-fiction environment has two islands, one for fire, the other water, as well as a complete multimedia system. Ms. Hadid, who was the first woman to be awarded the prestigious Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004, is well known to the Guggenheim. She has collaborated with the museum on other projects, including the exhibition ''The Great Utopia: The Russian and Soviet Avant-Garde, 1915-1932,'' in 1992. ''Zaha Hadid, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500; through Oct. 25.

To the Editor: In his review of''Desperate Networks,'' by Bill Carter (May 14), Ron Powers asserts that the fourth day in Genesis was a Thursday. Since the Jewish Sabbath has always been Saturday, the fourth day of creation would have to be Wednesday. David Rosenblutt High Point, N.C.

One day, I may be able to find every instance of the phrase ''Franco-Prussian War,'' but if there is no means to differentiate between relevant, useful texts and incidental occurrences of the phrase, it won't help me much. Thomas Klein Pocatello, Idaho

An article on May 14 about Ségolène Royal, who is running for the presidency of France, misspelled the surname of a former president. He was François Mitterrand, not Mitterand.

On Tuesday night one of the year's most anticipated avant-garde sludge-metal concerts comes to AVALON, the Chelsea dance club that has lately played host to a number of rock shows. All right, so that sounds like a pretty small category, but the cult of avant-garde sludge-metal is clearly growing: listeners are embracing bands that emphasize the atmospheric impulse that has always been a part of the heavy-metal tradition. Tuesday's concert has the minimalist producer OREN AMBARCHI as an opening act. One headliner is SUNN O))), a band that emits a low, ultra-heavy drone that can sound either welcoming or menacing or both. The other is BORIS, a Japanese trio that has grown less single-minded over time. The new Boris album is ''Pink'' (Southern Lord), which alternates between sludgy epics and fuzzy, punkish tantrums. 8:30, 662 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street, (212) 807-7780 or (212) 307-7171; $18 in advance, $20 at the door. A very different -- but also highly anticipated -- show comes to the APOLLO THEATER on Thursday night: the Atlanta rapper T. I. is to play two sets. His new album is ''King'' (Atlantic), and it's true, for now. It's the year's best and most popular hip-hop album so far. T. I. is part of the Southern insurgency that has redefined mainstream hip-hop over the past few years, but he's also something of a throwback: a meticulous craftsman, justly proud of his elegant flow. Expect some high-profile guests, along with an even more entertaining spectacle, a room full of New York hip-hop fans learning how to respect an out-of-towner. 7:30 and 11 p.m., 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 531-5305 or (212) 307-7171; $30 to $50.

SENIORS aren't the only ones moving on after graduation ceremonies next month. Among this year's ''graduates'' are Westchester school superintendents in four districts: Dobbs Ferry, Hastings-on-Hudson, New Rochelle and Port Chester. On the eve of retirement, they talked about their experiences in the county, and about the challenges facing their districts and public education.

ELIOT FELD has been having a good season. It started with his spectacular ''Sir Isaac's Apples'' at the Juilliard School and continued with a Diamond Project premiere and two all-Feld programs at New York City Ballet. Now comes the annual stint of his BALLET TECH at the Joyce Theater, with the Mandance Project. The repertory will include two of the ballets seen at City Ballet, along with ''Mr. XYZ,'' with MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV in all performances during the first week. Wednesday through Saturday at 8 p.m., next Sunday at 7:30 p.m. and June 6-11, along with Kidsdance, next Sunday and June 10 at 2 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or joyce.org; $42; Kidsdance, $30 for adults, $20 for children; for Wednesday gala tickets, call (212) 777-7710, ext. 316. Coincidence or competition? In the midst of American Ballet Theater's ''All Star Stravinsky'' program at the Metropolitan Opera House, the NEW YORK CITY BALLET has slipped its very own ''All Stravinsky'' program into the repertory at the New York State Theater. There is no overlap of scores or choreography, but the two programs should still make for a piquant comparison. Today at 3 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570 or nycballet.org, $30 to $86, $15 for student rush tickets. DANCEMOPOLITAN -- or dancemOpolitan, as they write it down at Joe's Pub -- has established itself as one of the livelier, more unusual dance showcases in town. On the club's vest-pocket stage, with a different curator for each program, you can enjoy a dizzying revue of 10 or more dancers and dance companies. Friday and Saturday offer the ''Thrash and Rock Show,'' with a live band and, as hosts, THE NICOLES, who are Nicole Berger and Nicole Wolcott. Friday and Saturday at 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 239-6200 or telecharge .com; $15 in advance, $20 at the door; dinner reservations at (212) 539-8778.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest THE EAGLE'S THRONE, by Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Kristina Cordero. (Random House, $26.95.) The spirit of both Machiavelli and ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' hovers over the down-and-dirty politics of this epistolary novel, set in 2020, when Mexico's presidency is up for grabs. IN PERSUASION NATION: Stories, by George Saunders. (Riverhead, $23.95.) Offering a scary glimpse of a future in which our lives are swamped by marketing, Saunders maintains a delicate balance between the grim and the funny. DIGGING TO AMERICA, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $24.95.) In Tyler's new novel, two families -- one recently arrived Iranian-American, the other All-American -- begin an unlikely friendship after both adopt Korean babies. THE COLLECTED STORIES OF AMY HEMPEL, (Scribner, $27.50.) The themes of Hempel's unsettling and blackly funny vignettes -- mortality, desire and fear of human connection -- are threaded with only the slenderest hopes of redemption. JPOD, by Douglas Coupland. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A disenchanted video-game programmer narrates this novel by the geek-culture chronicler Coupland, his ninth since ''Generation X.'' THE UNFINISHED NOVEL: And Other Stories, by Valerie Martin. (Vintage; paper, $13.) Cautionary tales about artists and the power of the artistic ego. GENEALOGY, by Maud Casey. (Harper Perennial; paper, $13.95.) The family in this novel unravels under the weight of its own hopes and passions. THEFT: A Love Story, by Peter Carey. (Knopf, $24.) Smitten by a well-connected, fetching blonde, this novel's hero, an ex-con painter, is drawn into a deadly international art scheme. GOD'S SILENCE: Poems, by Franz Wright. (Knopf, $24.) In the silence of his title, Wright, a Pulitzer Prize winner, apprehends an apocalyptic release from the tragicomic suffering and injustice that is his vision of America today. THE DEAD FISH MUSEUM, by Charles D'Ambrosio. (Knopf, $22.) Stories of understated realism centered on the charged relations between fathers and sons, drifters or workers. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
WELCOME to New Jersey, the sloganless state. Twice in the past year, officials failed at finding a clever catchphrase to promote tourism, and now comes word that the think tank is empty.

THIS column starts with true confessions and it will end that way. The aspiring writers wore dreary green scrubs, their uniform at the Riverhead Correctional Facility. They sat on pews in the chapel, clutching stories they had written. The inmates -- most of them in jail on drug-related or robbery charges -- are members of Herstory, a memoir-writing project for women.

GLASSER--Rita. Wife of the late Abe. Devoted mother of Phyllis Orent and Judith Rosenthal. Loving grandmother of Lisa and Rick, Richard and Lauren, Michael and Kim, Jeffrey and Lauren. Great-grandmother of Amy and Mike, Missy, Lizzie and David, Ryan and Noah, and Riley and Baby M.

SOKOLOW--Isobel A. Passed away Friday, May 19. She was a professional artist living and working in New York, Florida and Italy. Her work was exhibited in museums and galleries both nationally and internationally. She has been the recipient of several awards including the Silver Medal Audubon Artist Award and Best in Show National Association of Woman's Artists Award. She produced and hosted cable show Art Scene Through An Artist's Eye. Taught art therapy at the Aged Jewish Guild for the Blind and created and led ''Art Study Vacations'' in Pietrasanta, Italy, where she returned each year to work. She is survived by her two daughters, Cheryl of NYC and Helene (Gregory) Pokrywka of MD., and two beloved grandchildren Hillary and Josh. An art scholarship will be set up in Isobel's memory at a later date. Donations to www.MDS-foundation.org Information: George T. Davis Funeral Home, 914-632-0324.

An article last Sunday about plans by NewYork Presbyterian Hospital to build a residential tower on the Upper East Side contained outdated remarks by David G. Liston, the chairman of Community Board 8. Referring to neighborhood opposition, he said, ''I haven't heard anything'' and added, ''So far this is not something that has generated any controversy.'' His comments were made during an interview several weeks before he chaired a meeting of the community board on May 10, when residents did indeed raise concerns; he was not asked for follow-up comments after that meeting.

SEGAL--Ethel. Died May 23 at 99. Even in her 100th year, she took great joy in life and communicated it to all who knew her. She was much beloved by her sons, David and Joel, her seven grandchildren and her five great-grandchildren. Ethel was active in the NYC Opera and Ballet Guilds, Brandeis University Women's Committee and The Lucy Moses School. She was a remarkable woman whose passing left a great void in the lives of all who loved her. Donations to The Lucy Moses School in NYC.

Model mother (Style, May 14)? Puh-leeeese! Kirsty Hume wears a $3,700 dress while the kids wear the most miserable expressions. It might be Mother's Day, but this was way too much ''it's all about me.'' The photo of Hume holding an ice cream cone while the little boy keeps her in the shade with an umbrella borders on sadistic. Not to mention the ridiculousness of the so-called fashions she sports. What were you thinking? Dee Dennis San Rafael, Calif.

THE 9-year-old girl sat on a cafeteria table, her white sneakers resting on the bench seat, and surveyed the scene where she said her best friend had betrayed her. Urged on by the friend, three classmates had taunted her with insults all through lunch and called her ''unibrow,'' she said, her brown eyes saddening under her two perfectly normal third-grade brows. No, she didn't believe their words, she said, pressing her lips together into a tight, thin line: ''I knew they were just mean.''
To the Editor: Ted Koppel ponders the value of having outside contractors supplement the volunteer military that is finding volunteers harder to come by.
HIRSCHHORN -- Herbert H. Lucky to have you as my neighbor; honored to be your friend. Wendy Hirschhorn
PART 6
LUBALIN--Herb F. 1918-1981. Herb's work lives on. Lovingly remembered Rhoda Sparber Lubalin
The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Croton Dam, omitted the byline. It was written by Christopher Gray.

RIESS--Jonathan B., 58. On May 17, 2006. Darling beloved of Beth Eline. Adored father of Marine Corporal Christopher Morgan-Riess. Cherished brother of Claudia Wasserman and brother-inlaw Robert, uncle of Eric and Lise. Grand-uncle of Emily, Brian, Danielle and Gabrielle. As Professor of Art History at the University of Cincinatti, Jonathan also served terms as the Director of the School of Art and Graduate and Undergraduate Advisor in Art History. He authored books, essays and reviews, primarily in his field of concentration, the Italian Renaissance. Jonathan's passion for teaching was transformed by his loving students into a profound appreciation of pure art and academic research. He will be deeply missed. Private services.

THE control room of the Shoreham nuclear power plant looks as if everybody left in a hurry a long time ago. Papers are strewn about, desks and chairs are askew, and here and there keys are still inserted in switches on dusty panels. It has been 14 years since the Long Island Lighting Company signed over the $5.5 billion, 800-megawatt Shoreham plant to the Long Island Power Authority for a ceremonial $1, sealing its fate as the only fully licensed nuclear power reactor never to go into commercial operation.

To the Editor: Thank you for publishing the informative question and answer on the little-publicized topic of human milk banking (''A Mother's Memory,'' F.Y.I., May 14). It was heartening to see that our foremothers, and the federal government, saw the value of breast milk for our infants.

To the Sports Editor: Michael Matz came from the world of international show jumping and understood the risks of pushing a young horse, hence Barbaro's light schedule before the Derby. I was hopeful that his success with Barbaro might have an impact on the overall approach in thoroughbred racing.

KLEINFELD -- Leonard M. Devoted husband of the late Ruth. Beloved father of Eve. Cherished brother of Stanley and Marvin. Dear brother-inlaw of Audrey and Bernice. A successful and respected businessman, he touched the lives of all who knew him. Services Sunday, May 28, 2PM, at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opp. the LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

KETCHAM--Ira D. 76, of Jamestown, RI, passed away on May 25, 2006, after a courageous battle with cancer. She was the devoted wife of the late James B. Ketcham for 52 years. Born in Weston, WV, she was the daughter of Mary Hart Davisson and George Izard Davisson. She was a graduate of the Baldwin School and Chatham College (Pennsylvania College for Women), where she was president of her class both junior and senior year. She was also a member of the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America. She was a devoted wife and mother. Besides her twin sister Bruce Hart Randolph, she is survived by her son George Bonbright Ketcham of Newport, RI, three daughters, Laurie Camden Ketcham of Jamestown, RI, Susan Ketcham Coffin of Manchester by the Sea, MA, and Brucie Ketcham Donahue of Northfield, VT. In addition, she is survived by sons-in-law Lloyd H. Coffin III, Thomas M. Donahue, a daughter-in-law, Mimi D. Ketcham, and grandchildren Benjamin Bonbright Coffin, Sarah Camden Coffin, James Tredwell Donahue and Catherine Bruce Donahue. She is also survived by her brotherin - law William Tredwell Ketcham Jr. of New York, NY, and Lawrence, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made in her memory to the Baldwin School, 701 Montgomery Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA 19010-3505. Funeral service will be private.

To the Editor: While it is fair game to compare the musical ''Tarzan'' with ''The Lion King,'' what is the point of claiming that the former is an advertisement for merchandise while the latter was a work of art? Aren't both attempts at morally uplifting art and sustainable commerce at the same time? I would not know how relevant such an effort could be if it weren't for the remarkable effect the ''Circle of Life'' theme had on my 10-year old nephew after he lost his mother to cancer. The associated merchandising of entertainment may be a necessary evil to support such efforts, but it is not a valid criticism. Dennis Wedlick New York City

To the Editor: Re ''The Day the Musical Died'' [May 21]: Ben Brantley's personal distress at this season's musical Tony Award nominees is not unexpected, given his reviews, but I'm not sure it justifies his conclusion that the form is finished. It might have been more interesting to note the following, and make the opposite argument: of the 13 writers nominated for musicals this year, all but one is making a Broadway debut. Then think of the hundreds of young writers represented by the New York Music Theater Festival; the success of that anti-McMusical, ''The Light in the Piazza''; and the burgeoning number of nonprofit theaters around the country developing musicals. It appears that while The Times's critic supposes he's standing in the desert, he's actually on the beach, where the tide is beginning to come in. Jack Viertel Tarrytown, N.Y. The writer is artistic director of New York City Center Encores! and creative director of Jujamcyn Theaters.

Ten current or retired corporate executives -- none of them Donald J. Trump -- have publicly told Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld: ''You're fired!'' Or, at least, he would be fired if he worked for any one of them. The executives listed their bill of particulars against Mr. Rumsfeld -- himself a former C.E.O., of the drug maker G. D. Searle & Company -- in a full-page ad published in The New York Times and paid for by Business Leaders for Sensible Priorities, a liberal advocacy group.

We desire to knock the bell.'' That's what the great foodie A. J. Liebling used to announce in his favorite Paris restaurants when he knew that he and his guests really wanted to eat. This special food issue of the Book Review was put together in a similar frame of mind. When we saw the remarkable range and depth of the food-related books being published this season -- more and better than in any single season we can remember -- we thought: Surely there's enough here for an entire issue. Why not knock the bell?

To the Editor: Mr. Brantley's requiem for the Broadway musical misses the major reason that the form is in decline: a dearth of musical genius. While the books and jokes of so many musicals from the past are dated, their music continues to be played and is as fresh as when first heard. Does anyone seriously think that the music from ''The Producers'' or ''The Light in the Piazza'' will become a standard part of the American songbook? Dennis DeSantis Hamilton, N.J.

DAVIS--Lewis, 80. Died May 21, 2006. He is survived by Anne, his wife of 30 years, four children, Steven, Michael, Peter and Ariel, and five grandchildren, Emily, Nicholas, Alexander, Zachary and Nina. He founded the architectural firm Davis, Brody and Associates with his partner and best friend Samuel Brody, and leaves a legacy fueled by a passion for architecture, people and the city of New York. His love, humor and stewardship were a gift to us all and he was adored by so many in return. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service at the New York Public Library on June 20. Gifts may be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, NYC Chapter, 733 Third Avenue, NYC, 10017 or the Mt. Sinai Palliative Care Program, P.O. Box 1070, New York City 10029.

SCHWAGER--Elaine, Ph.D. Members and candidates of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourn the tragic lose of our esteemed colleague and friend, Elaine Schwager. Elaine was a psychologist, psychoanalyst, poet, wife and mother. Our heartfelt condolences to Elaine's children, Carl and Julia, and to her husband, our colleague and friend, Marvin Hurvich. Shiva calls Tuesday through Friday, 7:30-10 PM, 100 Bleecker St, Apt 2B. The IPTAR Community
COTLER--Howard. Beloved husband of Rachelle. Loving father of Brenda and Brett and Elise & Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather of Alex, Dylan, Melissa, Allison and Josh. Forever in our hearts.

To the Editor: David Brooks says that much of the inequality between rich and poor can be explained by love, and that economically successful children are more likely to come from stable, loving families, while poor children, raised mainly by single parents, lack sufficient love-providing adults.

Kelly envisions the supply side of a future culminating in ''the universal library of all human knowledge.'' Meanwhile, I'm stuck over here on the demand side, with two eyes, one brain and a couple hours a day. Harry E. Owens Philadelphia

To the Editor: Greg Sandow's review of Stephen Walsh's ''Stravinsky: The Second Exile'' (April 30) quotes Walsh to the effect that much of my work ''is riddled with bias, error, supposition and falsehood.'' I maintain that these terms apply more aptly to Walsh's work. The review concedes that ''Walsh is no longer courteous, and when discussing Craft his tone shifts from sarcasm to outrage.'' This hostility is glaring in the book's caption to a picture taken in January 1947: ''Studying the score of 'Persephone' with James Fassett'' (the producer) ''and Robert Craft, who has sneaked into the photograph.'' In reality, several other people standing between Stravinsky and me have been airbrushed out, since I was the last person in a line-up, positioned there by the photographer herself. Otherwise, the book pays me several unintended compliments, even elevating me to a higher realm: after berating Boulez for several paragraphs on Stravinsky's mistrust of him, Walsh quotes another composer's statement that ''Boulez rates (and fears!) only Craft and Stockhausen. He spits on the rest.'' Walsh relies heavily on oral history, with which the book is stuffed, but why does he continue trying to discredit someone who lived in the closest daily relationship with the composer for a quarter of a century? He also manages to avoid other accurately informed people who knew Stravinsky well, like Elliott Carter and Harold Shapero. A paragraph on Michael Tilson Thomas describing Stravinsky, taken from someone else's book, should have suggested to Walsh that the young conductor would qualify as a primary source. While a U.S.C. music student, Thomas was the keenest observer of everything about Stravinsky as conductor and composer, superbly mimicking the older man's conducting gestures and his speech. Thomas attended not only Stravinsky programs at the Los Angeles Monday Evening Concerts but others with the composer in the audience. The younger man can still point out passages in ''Agon'' that Stravinsky lifted from such masters as Schutz and Monteverdi. Thomas recalls the composer's own California concerts, imitating the expression on Stravinsky's face, as when he confused the program order and began beating the slow 12/8 of ''Firebird'' while the orchestra launched into the Fourth Tableau of ''Petrushka.'' Concluding that Stravinsky's 1959-60 concert series in New York left him ''out of pocket,'' Walsh misses an important aspect of the composer's character, his financial foxiness. In actuality, Stravinsky realized a handsome profit from the series by enlisting three different sponsors for the same event: the wealthy husband of his piano soloist in ''Movements''; Goddard Lieberson, who was induced to double Columbia Records' contribution; and the scrap-metal tycoon Hans Popper, who had hosted the composer's 1959 Japanese tour. A further boost to the budget came from Aaron Copland, Roger Sessions, Lukas Foss and Samuel Barber, who waived their performance fees as pianists in ''Les Noces.'' Having mentioned Sessions (another intimate source ignored by Walsh, who occasionally visited Stravinsky in his last years for the pleasure of conversing with him in Russian), I am reminded of a splurge of mistakes in ''The Second Exile'' concerning Stravinsky's participation in a Princeton symposium in 1959. Walsh claims that the Stravinskys ''set off from Hollywood at the end of August, and after a few days in Princeton . . . they flew on to London for the discussions with Eliot.'' In truth, the composer, coming by car from New York, spent a single day at the university, his purpose being to collect me for an earlier departure to Britain. Stravinsky arranged with Sessions to replace my lecture by giving one himself. There were no discussions with Eliot, since the two men had already abandoned the idea of collaboration. The crucial shortcoming of ''The Second Exile'' is its utter distortion of history in the sordid tale of the Stravinsky family rift, both before the composer's death and in the decade of litigation following. A full discussion of these matters would require a hefty volume, and would include New York City Surrogate Court records and the depositions taken by Martin Garbus. Walsh's bias in favor of the Stravinsky family heirs against his widow deprives the biography of any claim to objectivity. This is evident from the outset, since the book begins with a paean to the composer's 60-year-old grandson, who has consistently blocked the publication of a long overdue variorum edition of his grandfather's works, Stravinsky's most fervent wish. Robert Craft New York

A report in the Cross Westchester column on May 7 about the county's Independence Party misstated the number of registered party members in the 35th State Senate District, in the southwestern part of the county. There are 5,200 independents, not 6,000. The report also misstated the edge that Democrats have over Republicans in countywide voter registration. They outnumber them by about 80,000, not 100,000.
To the Editor: Ted Koppel's examination of private companies that perform military functions for the United States does not consider how this outsourcing may be fueling serious human rights abuses.
A recipe on May 14 for pasta with smoked salmon and yogurt misstated the amount of dill. It is 1 1/2 tablespoons, not teaspoons.

In the May 14 letters column, you published two letters critical of Deborah Solomon's interviews. Both letters seem to me to miss the point, expecting Solomon to be more solemn. Solomon's interview with Tim Russert, in the same issue, perfectly illustrates what's priceless in her work. What could be funnier than Tim Russert's refusing to answer insistent, Russert-like questioning about the things he learned from his mother? Jamie Baldwin Redding, Conn.

To the Editor: In ''Pomp and Altered Circumstances'' (May 14), Michael J. Agovino notes that New York University is no longer the commuter school he attended 15 years ago. Most of N.Y.U.'s undergraduates now come from out of state, necessitating what Mr. Agovino calls the university's ''relentless expansion,'' replacing historic buildings with architecturally lifeless dorms that dwarf surrounding neighborhoods and infuriate neighbors.

This affluent city in southern Germany has fantastic vineyards, world-class museums like the Neue Staatsgalerie and delightful restaurants. But its most popular attraction is the Mercedes-Benz Museum -- and that was even before its splashy new home opened this month. GAMES -- Gottlieb-Daimler Stadion will welcome neighbors France and Switzerland in a match on June 13, followed by what could be a tight game between Ivory Coast and the exciting Dutch squad on June 16. Otherwise, expect lopsided matches when Spain plays Tunisia on June 19 and Australia faces the powerhouse Croatia on June 22. A second-round game is on June 25, and the third-place match between the losing semifinalists is on July 8. HOTELS -- With few hotels in this less-traveled city, rooms on game days are likely to be booked. Try the city's hotel hotline (49-711-222-8233, www.stuttgart-tourist.de) for last-minute cancellations. Or, failing that, head out to Ludwigsburg (30 minutes by the S-Bahn train), not only because this fairyland town has vacancies, but for the Baroque palace. NO TICKET? Two choices. Brave the throngs at the Schlossplatz, where a 660-square-foot screen will be set up. Or party at Skybeach, a sand-filled garage above Kaufhof, a department store (Königstrasse 6; www.skybeach.de), where smaller screens will compete with drinking, dancing and volleyball. BAR -- Unlike most of this beer-soaked country, Stuttgart is surrounded by noble vineyards. So skip the old breweries like Calwer-Eck-Braü (49-711- 222-494412, www.calwereck.de), and go instead to the Wine Village in Schillerplatz, a Hansel and Gretel-like bazaar where you can wash down a plate of maultashen (a raviolilike dish) with large glasses of riesling. DOWNTIME -- If the 180 dazzling cars at the Mercedes-Benz Museum (Mercedes Strasse 100, 49-711-172-2578; www.museum-mercedes-benz.com) leave you thirsty for more, head across town. The Porsche Museum ( Porscheplatz 1; 49-711-911-25685; www.porsche.com/international/faq/museum) has 20 more legendary models.

DIAZ--Horace, Jr. 97, formerly of Rego Park. Dear father of Donna Hauck of S. Amherst, Ohio. Beloved husband of the late Rose, nee Caputo. Service Tuesday, 1:00 P.M. Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, NY.

It saddened me to read Daphne Merkin's Lives column (May 14) on a day when we are supposed to be honoring our mothers. No, the size of an inheritance does not measure love. Her family's dysfunctional behavior may prompt her to ask the question, but this is a question that does not usually need to be asked. It would seem to me that, in most families, an inheritance would be distributed in one of two ways -- either equally or, with some discussion, based on need. Love shouldn't enter into this equation, except as expressed by children and family to do the right thing for each other. Ellen Belmont Rosichan Miami Beach

The City of Hartford and the Trust for Public Land, a nonprofit conservation group, have announced that they will work together to renovate the city's park system, created more than 100 years ago with the help of the famous landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted, a Hartford native. The trust will study the parks and make recommendations to the city in nine months, according to David Queeley, the New England director of the trust's Parks for People program. Mr. Queeley said the group would seek input from neighborhood leaders and civic organizations throughout the city.

There is a wider lesson for Times readers (or readers of any newspaper) in the Page 1 farcical story of the standing-room-only airline ''seat.'' If you see an offbeat Page 1 story, enjoy it but be skeptical. Conditioned to schedule ''required'' but often dull news on the front page, editors may overreach to put lively but questionable stories there to try to keep readers from being bored. Ask yourself: is the colorful story a hoax, suspicious looking or simply too good (or bad) to be true?

The fact that Google is mentioned no fewer than 53 times in Kevin Kelly's article is a bit of a giveaway where his loyalties lie. Forgive us if we're less than enthusiastic! There is no question that Google has created an amazing search engine. There is also no question that without exciting, interesting, well-researched and well-written information, Google would have nothing to search. We do well to remember that Microsoft, Yahoo and others in the Open Content Alliance are also in the business of connecting words and ideas -- the difference is that they first obtain permission to copy works under copyright. (The problem of ''orphan'' copyrighted works, whose owners can't be identified or located, is currently being looked at by Congress, where responsive legislation is being drafted.) No one at the Association of American Publishers or the Authors Guild was quoted in the piece. Our two lawsuits challenging Google's right to take millions of our books, make complete digital copies and store them on their computers to promote their search engine and generate ad revenues were dismissed as the last hurrahs of an ancient order of mastodons who refuse to stand aside as the Google technological juggernaut rolls on. Google is a $100 billion, profit-making, publicly held corporation, with the interests of stockholders and partners to serve. Pat Schroeder President and C.E.O. Association of American Publishers Washington

NOWADAYS, Patrick Sullivan is a good Catholic boy with a mezuza on his bedroom door. He said he was called to buy the mezuza, a metal tube holding a small scroll with a Biblical verse in Hebrew, on a walk through Jerusalem last winter.

To the Editor: David Rabin and Robert Bookman argue against proposed legislation that would make it impossible for a new establishment to obtain an alcohol license if there are three existing licensed premises within 500 feet. But until the State Liquor Authority begins issuing licenses responsibly, we must have the 500-foot rule in place, without exceptions.

EACH year, the International Festival of Arts and Ideas focuses on bringing hundreds of artists from throughout the world to New Haven for about two weeks to dance, sing, perform and display their works. This year, with a new director, the theme grew more specific: Reach out to New Orleans and the artists affected by Hurricane Katrina. So New Orleans, with its distinct flavors and sounds, will be descending on New Haven on June 10 through 24.

MARGUERITE WILLIAMS always wanted to own a home in Bridgeport, Conn., the Fairfield County city where she grew up, but it took a gentle nudge from the pastor of her church to move her out of her rental rut. It wasn't a lack of money that held her back -- she works in admissions at Southern Connecticut State University --as much as a lack of information. A widow for more than 20 years, Ms. Williams feared that someone would talk her into a bad decision, or that the cost of keeping up a property would be more than she could handle.

It is the rare undertaker or priest who sees as many coffins in a day as the soldiers who make up the Third United States Infantry, also known as the Old Guard, at Arlington National Cemetery. With pride and precision the 1,400 soldiers there provide the military honors for 20 or more Arlington funerals daily, excluding weekends. They escort the coffins, fire rifle volleys, fold and refold flags and, with buglers borrowed from other divisions, play taps as veterans from a century's worth of wars, as well as others who served in the armed forces, seek their final rest.
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the soprano Birgit Nilsson misstated the surname of her husband. It is Bertil Niklasson, not Nilsson.

The death last month of Stephen Molinaro, the 40-year-old son of the Staten Island borough president, was caused by a drug overdose, the authorities said. An autopsy completed on Friday ruled the cause of death as acute intoxication by the combined effects of alcohol, opiates, Valium and Xanax, said Ellen S. Borakove, a spokeswoman for Charles S. Hirsch, the city's chief medical examiner.

The University of Missouri has let Kenneth L. Lay know politely but firmly that he cannot have his money back. Again. In 1999, when Enron was still hailed as a miracle company and Mr. Lay was still lauded for his performance as its chairman and chief executive, he donated $1.1 million to Missouri, his alma mater, to endow the Kenneth L. Lay Chair in Economics.

ONE thing audiences may not expect to see at a revival of ''Li'l Abner'' is a Dick Cheney look-alike. Or actors in George W. Bush and Condoleeza Rice masks. But they would be forgetting that this musical, which hit Broadway in 1956, was largely a political satire. The newspaper comic strip ''Li'l Abner,'' which ran from 1934 to 1977, was mostly about the adventures of the hillbilly residents of Dogpatch, including Abner, a big, handsome, good-natured young lug with grits for brains, and Daisy Mae, the blond beauty who wants desperately to marry him before she is past her prime (she is pushing 18). But Al Capp, the strip's creator, was fiercely political and his work showed it.
