FOR one of the freshest and most interesting perspectives on youth sports in recent years, consider the observations of Jeff Van Gundy, the former New York Knicks coach. After resigning from the Knicks and before taking over as head coach of the Houston Rockets in 2003, Mr. Van Gundy, then a Chappaqua resident, could often be found knocking around town; in fact he became a fixture at all levels of local basketball, from varsity boys' games to seventh-grade girls' games.

To the Editor: According to David Rabin and Robert Bookman (''Is It Last Call for the City?,'' Op-Ed, May 21), two of the ''true reasons'' legislators want to freeze the number of liquor licenses issued in New York City are gentrification and the smoking ban. Yet it is not for a late-night puff that tipsy clubgoers go yelling, stumbling and urinating through the streets.

Speaking as a reporter, editor and metro publisher of more than 50 years, I think The Times's greater concern about the Airbus ''standing room'' article should be about the news department culture that allows repeated and embarrassing sloppiness and suggests a mistake-prone environment.

A woman was found dead in Brooklyn yesterday and the police said it appeared as if someone had tried to burn her body. The police found the body yesterday about 3:30 p.m. in a wooded area across from a residential neighborhood on Louisiana Avenue, in the Starrett City section.

WEINSTEIN--Hannelore. On May 26, 2006. Beloved wife of Victor, sister of Seligman, mother of Mitchell, Alan, Kenneth, Stuart and Jeffrey, grandmother of Jacob, Joshua, Raina, Harrison, Eden and Jordan, friends, and teacher to many generations. Funeral service Sunday, 10 AM, May 27, 2006, at Schwartz Bros.Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., corner of 76th Rd. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society or the Solomon Schechter Schools.

To the Editor: I enjoyed Carole Getzoff's article about her mom's shopping (''The Demon Shopper of Fordham Road,'' May 14), but she was not quite as savvy a shopper as my mom. We lived walking distance from Alexander's: as a matter of fact my mom's route home from teaching at Bronx Science was a direct path to where the Grand Concourse intersected with Fordham Road -- right into that mecca of non-retail shopping.

Here are recent recalls reported to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. More information is available at www.nhtsa.dot.gov. 2005-6 Land Rover LR3 2006 Range Rover Sport PROBLEM: Someone could remove the ignition key when the transmission is not in park, allowing the vehicle to roll away. REMEDY: Software update. VEHICLES AFFECTED: 44,087. 2004-6 Chevrolet Colorado 2004-6 GMC Canyon 2006 Isuzu I-280 and I-350 PROBLEM: Brake lights on these pickups may not work or may stay on. REMEDY: Replace brake lamp switch assembly. VEHICLES AFFECTED: 404,733. 2006 Chrysler 300 Dodge Charger Dodge Magnum PROBLEM: Brake fluid tubes on vehicles with 2.7-liter engines may wear through and leak, reducing braking force or causing a fire. REMEDY: Inspect brake tubes for damage and replace if necessary. VEHICLES AFFECTED: 44,367. 2006 Jeep Wrangler PROBLEM: The clutch master cylinder linkage on vehicles with six-speed manual transmissions may break. REMEDY: Replace clutch master cylinder linkage rod. VEHICLES AFFECTED: 6,876. 2003-6 Volvo XC90 PROBLEM: Outer tie rod joint may crack, making it hard to drive. REMEDY: Replace tie rod joints. VEHICLES AFFECTED: 108,766. CHERYL JENSEN

To the Editor: In ''Tug of War Over Commuters'' (May 14), about DeCamp Bus Lines' lawsuit against New Jersey Transit, you report that Gary Pard, vice president and chief operating officer for DeCamp, testified that the company had not conducted surveys to determine why the company was losing riders because, as he put it, ''we know why.'' No survey has been conducted because the results would not back the company's allegation.

The State Department of Transportation opened the new section of the Sikorsky Bridge over the Housatonic River between Milford and Stratford on Thursday morning. The new section of the bridge carries three lanes of southbound Route 15 traffic. The old bridge will be used for northbound traffic, with two lanes at first. A third lane will eventually be opened.

STEIN--Morris. New York University's Psychology Department mourns the loss of Dr. Moe Stein who died May 6 at age 84. Retired as Professor Emeritus in 1991, he was on the NYU faculty since 1960 and had headed the Doctoral Program in Social Psychology. Well known for his work on personality and the nature and encouragement of creativity, he authored over ten books and accrued many honors. He was born in the Bronx, educated at De Witt Clinton High School, CCNY, and Harvard, and taught at Wheaton College and Chicago University before returning to New York City. We extend our condolences to his family and former students.

IT took almost three years for Joseph Gentile to win town approval for Utopia Studios, a $1.6 billion proposal for an entertainment complex in Preston. Now it will take Mr. Gentile, of Southampton, N.Y., about that long to get the governmental approvals he needs and to finish construction.

Elizabeth Helen Stoel, the daughter of Carol F. Stoel and Thomas B. Stoel Jr. of Washington, is to be married this evening to Christopher David Bynum, the son of Stephanie Woolf of Rockport, Mass., and Hal Bynum of Nashville. Warren R. King, a retired judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, is to officiate at the Arts Club of Washington. Ms. Stoel, 29, will keep her name. She is an intern at the Architecture Research Office in Manhattan. She graduated magna cum laude from Princeton and received a master's degree in architecture from Harvard.

ON THE ALFONSO XIII CANAL, SEVILLE, MARCH 6, 2006 -- Anne Pastorius, reclining, a student at the University of Wisconsin, Eau Claire. ''When I was little, my favorite babysitter was a Spanish major; she's now a Spanish teacher and she studied in the same study-abroad program I'm in. This was the first really nice day of the spring, and my roommate had just got over being sick, so we were all down by the river hanging out. It was the first time we could take out our capris and sandals and swimsuits and get a little color. Coming to Spain really, really opened up my eyes to a different lifestyle. In Seville, they are very much night people. I'm also really surprised how much ham they have. They have ham with everything; it's crazy.'' As told to Seth Kugel

The weekend hanging-out look is all about a self-assured mix of clothes and a calculated language of style as summer approaches. Stunners wearing skinny calf-length jeans chat up the guys. A sun shield, left, suits the secretive type. Women driving sleek convertibles are a magnet to men, and there's always the traditional ploy: a cuddly lap dog to initiate conversation.

Peter Morton, a founder of the Hard Rock Cafe chain, agreed this month to sell the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas for $770 million, but even at that price there were a few things he refused to part with. The sale agreement states that Mr. Morton can select pieces from the resort's collection of musical memorabilia with a combined value of as much as $100,000. In an interview with The Las Vegas Review-Journal, he said that his sons insisted on keeping two items that belonged to Jimi Hendrix: a Gibson Flying V guitar and a floral-print blazer.

VANDER VEER -- Martha Jane (nee Ashton) of Syosset, NY on May 23, 2006. Among her many accomplishments she was a graduate of the University of Washington, a columnist for Oyster Bay Guardian, Governor of the International Platform Association, a freelance author and a member of the Writer's Roundtable. Beloved wife of the late John H. Loving mother of John H. and Denise, Patricia and David Spaulding, Sandra & Edward Falconer, Brian and Alana. Cherished grandmother of five. Funeral service to be held at Christ Church, 61 E. Main St., Oyster Bay, NY on Wednesday, May 31, 2006 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Holland Society of NY, 122 East 58th St., NY, NY 10022 or The Children's Aid Society, 105 East 22nd St., Room 504, NY, NY 10010-5413.

To the Editor: Re ''TV Moves a Step Closer to the Womb'' [May 21]:
To the Editor: Re ''These Guns for Hire,'' by Ted Koppel (column, May 22):
To the Editor: ''Rebuilding the Planes That Took the City Aloft'' (May 14) did not mention another famous around-the-world flight that started and ended at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

A picture caption on the Wheelspin page last Sunday misidentified the model year of the Best in Show car at the 2005 Pebble Beach Concours. It was a 1937 Delage, not a 1938. Also, the credits for that photo and for another of a sports car race in Monterey, Calif., were reversed. The concours picture was by Ron Kimball for the Pebble Beach Company; the racing photo was by Gavin Lawrence for Getty Images.

Your provocative article should cause any writer to stop and think before lifting from another's work. Publishers may claim that vetting manuscripts would be too expensive.Yetin the not too distant future, perhaps they will merely runmanuscripts through the rinse cycle of the Google library, which will instantly compare themwith an enormous database of literature going back to the ancient Sumerians. Ellen Geiger New York

RUMAGE--William Timothy, JR., M.D., 82, of Louisville, KY, passed away on Wednesday, May 24, 2006. He was born in Newark, N.J., graduated from Columbia University in 1943, and received his M.D. from New York University in 1946. He married Eleanor Wisner Burge, of Louisville, in 1945. He was a Captain in the Army Medical Corps, and did his medical residency at U of L., Louisville General Hospital. He retired from active medical/surgical practice in 1994. During his medical career Dr. Rumage was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, Fellow of the Southeastern Surgical Congress, and its President in 1985. He was also a Fellow of the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma and a Fellow of the Southern Surgical Association. He served on the AMA Council of National Security, the AMA Committee on Community Emergency Services. He was a member of the Jefferson County Medical Association and was a member of its Disaster Planning Committee and its Emergency Medical Services Committee. He was a member of the Kentucky Medical Association, as well as a previous member of its Highway Safety Committee and was a previous Chairman of its Disaster Planning Committee. He was a Member of the Kentucky Chapter of the American College of Surgeons and served as its Secretary/Treasurer from 1960 -1963 and its President in 1964. He also performed one of the first televised surgeries in the United States in 1963 on CBS affiliate WHAS He was a member of the Kentucky Surgical Society and the Louisville Surgical Society. He was Active Staff at Norton Hospital and President of the Medical Staff of Norton Memorial Hospital in 1966. He was also active staff at Methodist Evangelical Hospital and a Clinical Professor of Surgery at the University of Louisville. In 1994, he was appointed Medical Director for the Visiting Nurse Association. Outside of his medical practice, Bill Rumage loved gardening, swimming, sailing, reading, learning, philately, knowing ''about place,'' collecting artifacts and memorabilia of the medical history and the medical arts and seeing ''the big picture''. He is survived by his sister Agnes Rumage Sullivan, his brother Joseph P. Rumage, his son, Wm Timothy Rumage, lll, his daughter Ann Rumage Fritschner, his three grandchildren, Benjamin Lawrence Jones, Matthew McNally Jones and MacKenZie Caswell Rumage and his two step grandchildren Aaron Samuel Fritschner and Hannah Stuart Fritschner.

SINCE 22 year-old Carla Vicentini disappeared in Newark on Feb. 9, Karlos Kohlbach has written more than 35 newspaper articles about her case. One of the nation's most popular television shows ran a segment on it. And a Senate commission held a hearing. It was not here that all this happened, but in Ms. Vicentini's native Brazil. Mr. Kohlbach is a reporter for Gazeta do Povo, or People's Gazette, in her home state of Paraná. The television show, Fantástico, is a Sunday night must-watch on the Brazilian network Globo. And the Senate hearings were in Brasília.

SUSER--Fred. He spent his life taking care of children. All who knew him loved and respected him. He will be remembered always and greatly missed. Our condolences to Laurie, Samantha and Stephanie. The Levy and Golden Families

I am planning to stay in Nice and notice that prices quoted by hotels are much higher than those quoted by online travel sites. Should I risk giving my credit card details online or grit my teeth and pay a higher price directly with the hotel? -- Brittmarie Janson Perez, Albuquerque When you call a hotel, you will normally be quoted the rack rate, or the published price, whereas a travel agent or travel site should be able to offer you a discounted price. But, as with air fares, you never know whether the price you are offered is the best you can get. So it is worth comparing prices: 20 to 30 percent off the published price is a good deal for a four-star hotel.

Don't let the cool blue eyes and upturned collars of Germany's second-largest city and media capital fool you. Hamburg's moneyed set may subsidize a lavish array of Michelin-starred restaurants and sumptuous hotels, but it is the gritty, somewhat seedy districts of St. Pauli and the Reeperbahn that still show visitors a rollicking good time. GAMES -- An intriguing match up is in store when Argentina plays Ivory Coast on June 10. Scalpers won't be earning much, though, when Ecuador plays Costa Rica on June 15 or when Saudi Arabia takes on Ukraine on June 19. But expect prices to jump when two of Europe's leading teams, the Czech Republic and Italy, clash on June 22. There will be a quarterfinal on June 30. HOTELS -- A growing tourist spot, Hamburg has new design hotels, old guest houses and everything between. Last-minute travelers can call the city's tourist office (49-403-005-1500, www.hamburg-tourism.de) or show up at the welcome center in front of the city hall. For less bustle, drive an hour north to Lübeck on the Baltic coast (hotel hotline: 49-180-588-2233; www.luebeck-tourism.de). NO TICKET? -- An 860-square-foot screen will be set up in Heiligengeistfeld, a giant field next to Germany's favorite underdog team, St. Pauli. The site, which will have a food court resembling the city's famous fish market, is within stumbling distance of the Reeperbahn. BAR -- Fans of St. Pauli are among the world's most loyal, and patient. Get to know them at Herzblut (Reeperbahn 50; 49-403-339-6933; www.herzblut-st-pauli.de). Order the local brew, Astra, or risk dirty looks. After, head to Barbarabar (Hamburger Berg 11; 49-171-418-1418; www.barbarabar.de), where the crowd will relive the day's glories and tragedies on the foosball tables. DOWNTIME -- Hamburgers love their show tunes. Among the musicals you can sing along with between matches are ''Dirty Dancing,'' ''Mamma Mia!'' and ''The Lion King'' (''Der König der Löwen''). ANDREAS TZORTZIS

IT is not without cause that followers of the summer music scene have come to associate New Jersey with scowling youths in black T-shirts who ask only that stages be packed with bands that make their ears bleed. The head-banging earlier this month at the Meadowlands' Bamboozle fest certainly helped solidify that hardcore rap sheet. And on its heels, the all-metal cross-country One Nation Undivided tour, headlined by the New Jersey bands Ill Niño and God Forbid, will provide reinforcement on June 8 at the Starland Ballroom in Sayreville.

Could someone please turn off the fireworks? We're trying to watch television. On Wednesday night, to the dismay of ''Lost'' and ''American Idol'' fans watching the season finales, a pyrotechnic display was launched from a state-owned park near the Goldman Sachs tower on the Hudson waterfront. The noise was so shattering, it spooked dogs, frightened children and -- what would seem most important -- smothered dialogue.

Your column about the Airbus stand-up ''seat'' story describes a comical journalistic misadventure. But it does raise the question: Whatever happened to fact-checking? Obviously, with breaking news stories, less checking can be done. But with articles that a reporter spends a couple of weeks writing, why can't a better review be done?

''I don't think it's in anybody's interest, including the Forest Service, to enforce immigration -- they're benefiting from it.'' BLANCA ESCOBEDA, owner of an Oregon company that supplies fire crews. [1]

8 P.M. (Showtime) PATRIOT ACT: A JEFFREY ROSS HOME MOVIE -- They call them the Iraq Pack: a band of comedians armed with jokes and a camcorder on a mission to entertain troops. This feature film follows Mr. Ross (above), Drew Carey, Blake Clark, Kyle Dunnigan and Kathy Kinney, among others, as they muster laughs in the Sunni Triangle -- while dealing with a mortar attack on their hotel and a common malady known as Sadaam's revenge. 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) NICK NEWS SPECIAL EDITION -- No one does tween-speak better than the beguilingly candid Linda Ellerbee, precisely because she treats adolescents like adults, no matter how mature the subject matter. This 15thanniversary special looks at some of the brightest moments in her tenure at the helm of ''Nick News'' and demonstrates that, whether discussing religious differences, AIDS, eating disorders, gay parents, the war in Iraq or the race for president with 9- or 90- year-olds, Mr. Ellerbee never recoils. 9 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- Tim Allen (left) talks about being a man for all seasons (and all species) in films like ''The Santa Clause,'' ''The Shaggy Dog'' and the forthcoming ''Zoom.'' 9 P.M. (CMT) TRUE GRIT -- Evel Knievel couldn't go high enough, fast enough or far enough for his own tastes, as his wreck of a body can testify. This special traverses Mr. Knievel's rocky evolution from abandoned child and career burglar to a daredevil of near-mythic proportion. If only he could still straddle a Harley. 9 P.M. (Discovery Channel) IRAQ CONFIDENTIAL WITH JESSE JAMES -- Mr. James, the mechanic, leaves his heart in Texas with his wife, Sandra Bullock, but takes his prowess to U.S. troops in a secret location outside of Baghdad. 9 P.M. (VH1) MY FAIR BRADY: WE'RE GETTING MARRIED -- He got his start on ''The Brady Bunch.'' She got hers on ''America's Next Top Model.'' And when we left them last season, Christopher Knight -- despite negative feedback from his TV mom, Florence Henderson -- had just proposed to Adrianne Curry (above, with Mr. Knight), to which she responded with a teary yes, followed by a statement not fit to print. This season, we follow them to the altar, but not before the prenup, the bachelorette party and the approval (or not) from Ms. Henderson. 9:30 P.M. (13, 49) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE -- ''The Congressional Picnic.'' Congress dines with the president and the first lady on the South Lawn, amid refrains from Shirley Jones, Tom Wopat and Harolyn Blackwell. Ah, Washington. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

As the season trails away, opera houses close, concert series take a breather, and summer festivals get ready, the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC offers one of its more interesting programs of the year. Played first on Thursday and repeated on Saturday, Elliott Carter's ''Dialogues'' will sit beside Stravinsky's Concerto for Piano and Winds. The Stravinsky features the estimable French pianist PIERRE-LAURENT AIMARD, who seems to be spending more and more time in this country. For the fainter of heart, there will be Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' after intermission to send audiences home happy. LORIN MAAZEL conducts. Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Saturday at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $26 to $94. If you want the chance to hear the same New York Philharmonic more than once at the same time, the estimable XIAN ZHANG conducts Verdi and Tchaikovsky in a Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The free concert will be in the east and newly cleaned end of the cathedral. Given the acoustical hugeness of the space in toto and the relatively slow speed of sound, you might get to hear every note at least a couple of times. Monday at 8 p.m., Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 875-5709. Now that concert schedules are slowing down, it may also be time to invest an evening in something a little different. People who like to read have followed SIMON SCHAMA's literary peregrinations through Dutch culture and French revolutionary politics. His new book, ''Rough Crossings'' -- from which he will read at Symphony Space on Friday -- is about slavery, and the words will be interleaved with music by JASON MORAN and ALICIA HALL MORAN. 8:30 p.m., Leonard Nimoy Thalia, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400; $21, $18 for students and 65+, $16 for members.

Enron's Trading Legacy Lives With the conviction of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey Skilling, the books have closed on Enron. But the company left behind a world where almost anything can be traded. WEEK IN REVIEW Hastert Fight May Linger Speaker J. Dennis Hastert is trying to move past his showdown with the Justice Department over the search of a lawmaker's office. But many on Capitol Hill believe the fight will resonate. PAGE 26 Seeking to Add French Twist Roger Federer, who has dominated tennis for the last three years, begins a two-week quest to win the only Grand Slam title he lacks: the French Open. Standing in the way is his emerging rival, Rafael Nadal. SPORTSSUNDAY A Peek at Undercover Tactics The recent trial of a man accused of plotting to blow up a subway station provided new clues about the extent of police surveillance in and around the city's mosques. PAGE 29 Classical Music's Golden Age Classical music lovers have long mourned the field's imminent demise. But the numbers show that it is stronger than ever. ARTS & LEISURE

A noir writer may be expected to be cynical and brooding, but that description does not fit Ira Berkowitz, a first-time author whose crime novel ''Family Matters'' was published last month. Friendly and outgoing, he looked brooding only fleetingly during a recent interview, when he spoke about the rejections he had received on the path to publication. ''Rejection is a terrible thing to take,'' he said. For Mr. Berkowitz, 66, a retired advertising executive, the word ''no'' does not exist in a competitive marketplace. ''Somehow you're going to sell this thing,'' he said of the prevalent attitude in advertising, which is the approach he has taken to his writing.

INTERNATIONAL 3-17 Iranian Eclipses Clerics' Power President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran is trying to consolidate power in the office of the presidency in a way never before seen in the 27-year history of the Islamic Republic, apparently with the tacit approval of Iran's supreme leader, according to government officials and political analysts in Tehran. 1 Deadly Quake in Indonesia A powerful earthquake flattened buildings and historical sites in central Indonesia, killing at least 3,500 in the nation's worst disaster since the 2004 tsunami. 1 Iran and Iraq Discuss Borders Foreign Minister Manouchehr Mottaki of Iran, on the second day of his visit to Iraq, said that the two countries had agreed to form a commission to oversee border issues and that its primary task would be to ''block saboteurs'' crossing the border. 14 Concerns in Colombia Election While President Álvaro Uribe of Colombia is favored to win a fourth term in elections today, some analysts and human rights groups have raised concerns about the power he will amass and his style of governing. 16 Vote Nears on Israeli Boycott Two days before British academics were to vote on a possible boycott of their Israeli colleagues, 600 university teachers from Britain, Canada, the United States and Israel opposed the move while Palestinian and other academics supported it. 9 Left for Dead on Everest An Australian climber who collapsed and was left for dead on Mount Everest was rescued after passing climbers saw signs of life and radioed for help, offering a counterpoint to the grim destiny of another climber who died on the mountain earlier this month. 10 More Violence In East Timor The arrival of Australian and Malaysian peacekeepers in East Timor had failed to stem the chaos that has engulfed the city after a week of violence between factions of East Timor's security forces. A6 NATIONAL 18-27 Border Battle on Fire Lines As many as half of the roughly 5,000 private firefighters based in the Pacific Northwest and contracted by state and federal governments to fight forest fires are immigrants, and an untold number of them are working here illegally. 1 Kerry Battle Continues Three decades after the Vietnam War, and nearly two years after John Kerry's failed presidential bid, most Americans have probably forgotten why it ever mattered whether Mr. Kerry went to Cambodia. But among those who were on the frontlines of the 2004 campaign, the emotional battle over his wartime service continues. 1 Chicago Weighs Store Wages Chicago may become the first city in the nation to require ''big box'' retailers like Wal-Mart to pay employees a ''living wage'' of at least $10 an hour plus $3 an hour in benefits. 18 House Fight May Resonate J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, is moving publicly to put his constitutional showdown with the Justice Department in the past, but most on Capitol Hill believe the confrontation will resonate in the coming months. 26 Scandal Afflicts San Diego San Diego, once a model of prosperity and competent governance, is reeling under a seemingly endless series of scandals in the city government. Many are now wondering if San Diego has hit bottom, or if worse is yet to come. 8 NEW YORK/REGION 29-33 Trial Reveals Police Tactics The outcome of the terror trial in United States District Court in Brooklyn, is seen by police officials as a victory and a vindication, even though much about the New York Police Department's latest tactics, and clandestine programs, were disclosed during the trial. 29 Mixed Success in Yonkers Fifteen years later, residents of Yonkers reflect on one of the country's more ambitious social experiments: the court-ordered effort to desegregate the city. 29 Chess 33 Obituaries 35 Weather 36

TALMADGE - Arthur. Of Palm Beach, FL, on May 25, 2006 at the age of 92. He was the former Executive Vice President and Co-Founder of Mercury Records, former President of United Artists Records and former President and Founder of Musicor Records. He was born in Chicago, IL, in 1913, and served his country as an Army Sergeant during World War II. Mr. Talmadge was predeceased by his wife, the late Dorothy (nee Burg) who died in 1992. He was the loving father of Richard Talmadge, and Joyce Talmadge, and her husband Eric Lane. He was the adoring grandfather of Adam, Joshua, Taryn, Courtney and Travis. He was the dear brother of Grace Dorf and Norman Talmadge. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 30, 2006, 12:30 P.M., at ''Westchester Reform Temple,'' 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. For additional information, please contact Hellman-Garlick Memorial Chapel, Briarcliff Manor, NY 866.762.5501.

A Name to Read By While John Cheever's fiction does not always treat the suburbs kindly, his suburban hometown, Ossining, has done him the kindness of naming the reading room of the new Ossining Public Library after him.

It would have been nice if you had given a definition of ''enterprise stories,'' a term you used in your headline and the article. As a lifelong communications professional, I detect a sense of disdain when you write, ''Only two of the 23 enterprise stories started with ideas from public relations practitioners,'' as if having more stories originate with P.R. people would be a bad thing.

ROMERO - Manuela. The Romero family and their friends mourn the passing of our beloved sister, aunt and comrade Manuela Romero on April 5 2006. Born in Astoria, New York on July 19, 1924, Manuela was a long term resident of East Rockaway, New York, a graduate of City College, founder and partner in BFW Management, and dedicated long term volunteer and employee of the Helen Keller Services for the Blind. Devoted daughter and caretaker, she is predeceased by her mother and father, Manuela Garcia Romero and Manuel Romero, her brothers Anthony Romero and Joseph Romero, and her nephew Robert Romero. She is survived and grieved by her sisters-in-law Lee Murphy and Mildred Romero, her nephews Thomas Romero, Paul Romero and Philip Romero, her grand-nieces Kate and Tessa Romero, and her godchildren Morgan Avila and Robert Locke. Manuela was a woman of taste elegance and dignity. Respected and admired by all for her intelligence and independence, Manuela was a shining example of a life well lived, of happiness achieved through rigorous attention to detail and forthright honesty. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 18 at 2:00 P.M., at the home of Morgan Avila, 292 Ocean Ave, Lynbrook NY. All are encouraged to join us and celebrate her remarkable life. Manuela Romero was the person we all wish to be, a woman held in the highest esteem and missed by all who knew her.
An article last Sunday about Huatulco, a resort area on Mexico's southern coast, misstated the name of a popular Oaxacan cheese. It is quesillo, not quesadillo.

One thing my friends and family find amazing about me is that I'll eat anything at least once. I can't help it. I'm curious about why people from other cultures eat certain animal parts that would make even the hardiest ''Fear Factor'' contestant squeamish. When I was in a Beijing restaurant a few years ago, I pointed to chicken feet on the English menu. ''Ohhh, we don't have that,'' said the waitress, amused that an American tourist would pick the most inedible-sounding thing on an outdated menu. Little did I know then that I didn't have to go all the way to Beijing to satisfy my craving for chicken feet; all I had to do was drive a few miles to Kam Man Food in East Hanover. The supermarket, one of two Kam Mans in New Jersey, has a food court with a Chinese food counter, a Vietnamese food counter and a counter that serves Asian pastries, sweets and smoothies.

Most distressing is the comment by Chuck Strum, an associate managing editor of The Times: ''In general,'' Mr. Strum said, ''we don't assume that the various desks submit articles in which the central premise is wrong.'' That was a foolish comment from a person with such senior managerial and quality-control responsibility.

To the Editor: I agree entirely with your editorial supporting the proposal of Nassau County's executive, Tom Suozzi, for building ''next-generation'' housing in Garden City (''The Forbidden Garden,'' May 14), but it is worth noting the irony in this community's opposition to affordable housing: according to Pete Hamill's ''Downtown: My Manhattan,'' Garden City was founded by an Irish immigrant from Belfast, the department store pioneer A. T. Stewart, to provide affordable housing for his workers. (Rev.) Thomas W. Goodhue Executive Director Long Island Council of Churches Hempstead

Weingut Steininger produces wine in the Kamptal region, northwest of Vienna. Its 2005 grüner veltliner shows why Austria drinks 78 percent of its annual wine production. With zippy, peppery whites like this, who needs imports? Grüner veltliner is Austria's signature grape. Consumers relish Steininger's version with tafelspitz (boiled beef), apple-horseradish sauce, fried potatoes and creamed spinach. The 2005, with an innovative German glass stopper, is $19.99 at 67 Wine, 179 Columbus Avenue (68th Street). HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

After 18 N.H.L. seasons, Carolina Hurricanes defenseman Glen Wesley knows that time is running out on his chances to win his first Stanley Cup. Wesley, 37, has played in more playoff games than any active player who has never had his name engraved on the Cup, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.

To the Sports Editor: The obvious debate over Barry Bonds's achievement will go on. But one thing is certain: the Babe's achievement is still the more remarkable, since he did it under the influence of performance-detracting substances. David D. Doniger Washington
To the Editor: Those with money will always believe that you can't solve social problems by throwing money at them.

''RESCUE ME'' returns this week (FX, Tuesday at 10 p.m.), and viewers who thought that the Season 2 death of Tommy's young son might sink the show into a maudlin morass will be pleased that Tommy (played by DENIS LEARY) is showing surprising resilience. Of course what passes for resilience on ''Rescue Me,'' the firefighter drama, is a character who still drinks and talks to ghosts, and who remains angry to the point of near violence, but at least he's making jokes. SUSAN SARANDON will guest star as a love interest for Franco (DANIEL SUNJATA) beginning in the second episode. Nerds in prime time! ABC will broadcast ''THE 2006 SCRIPPS NATIONAL SPELLING BEE'' for the first time (Thursday at 8 p.m.). The preliminary rounds will be on ESPN earlier in the day (noon to 3 p.m.) so you can figure out your rooting interest. Elsewhere in nerd news, NBC's reality franchise ''LAST COMIC STANDING'' has made its way back onto the schedule (Tuesday at 8 p.m.) after flaming out in an ill-conceived, hurried third season in the summer of 2004. JAY MOHR, the irascible former host, has been replaced by ANTHONY CLARK of ''Yes, Dear'' infamy. Can the once breezily enjoyable comedy competition overcome these obstacles? Members of the ''LAGUNA BEACH'' cult who have wished that every reality series could be stuffed with compelling characters, gorgeously filmed and hypnotically paced can look forward to ''THE HILLS'' (MTV, Wednesday at 10 p.m.). This ''Laguna Beach'' spinoff follows the guileless, possibly simple-minded LAUREN CONRAD, late of Orange County, in her move to Los Angeles, where she gets an internship at Teen Vogue and enrolls in fashion school. From what viewers know of her already, Ms. Conrad seems destined to be surrounded by backstabbers and game players, and escaping Laguna has not changed her fate. Bad news for her, great news for us.

To the Editor: Ted Koppel writes, ''The United States may not be about to subcontract out the actual fighting in the war on terrorism, but the growing role of security companies on behalf of a wide range of corporate interests is a harbinger of things to come.''

To the Editor: The type of mercenary force Ted Koppel discusses that ''might relieve us of an array of current political pressures'' is a frightening prospect. Private contractors have acted with impunity in Iraq -- some of them are alleged to have been involved with the torture at Abu Ghraib.
To the Editor: If we as citizens are unwilling to volunteer to defend and protect our nation, the alternative of hiring mercenaries is unacceptable.

SIEGEL - Fred. Greenwich, CT, on May 25, at the age of 46, after a three and a half year fight with leukemia. Buried May 28. Beloved husband of Jane, father of Yale, son of Eve, brother of Reva and Laura, nephew of Abe, Mimi, and Paul, cousin of Julia, Solange, and Diane, sonin-law of Marjorie and Victor, brother-in-law of Gwynne, Neill, and Thomas. Good and loyal friend to many. Graduate of Yale and Wharton, Vice President of Morgan Stanley, member of the Greenwich Chabad. We love him and will miss him. His love and delight in life lives in us. Gifts to honor his struggle can be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Hospital, Greenwich Hospital, or Chabad of Greenwich.

Tariq Aziz, deputy prime minister under Saddam Hussein, testified at his former boss's trial last week in what appeared to be hospital pajamas. Mr. Aziz' attire may have been intended to support claims that he is too sick to stand trial on charges similar to those Mr. Hussein faces.

Re ''Landing on Page 1 With Hardly a Wary Eye'' (May 21): You say that the ''Wow!'' factor played a part in the front-page placement of the April 25 article about standing-room-only ''seats'' for airline passengers. This reader was not wowed.

The number of reported Lyme disease cases rose 34 percent in Connecticut last year, compared with 2004, according to the State Department of Public Health. Dr. Mathew L. Cartter, the epidemiology program coordinator with the department, said he was not surprised by the increase.

To the Sports Editor: Placing an asterisk next to Barry Bonds's 715th home run would be wrong. Babe Ruth benefited from a much more unfair and distasteful advantage: the color line. Though it was not of his choosing (that difference may keep Bonds far from Cooperstown), it nevertheless spared Ruth from facing many players, perhaps the best, of his generation.

To the Editor: Could your article about Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, ''Coffee Wars in a No-Frills Zone'' (May 21), have been any more insulting? Windsor Terrace has never been populated with ''multiple laundries and bodegas,'' let alone the working-class hicks who couldn't find a decent cup of coffee until the people who run Lonelyville Coffee showed up. Terrace Bagels and Connecticut Muffin have been serving great coffee to us rubes for years.

To the Editor: Joe Queenan's astute comparison of Frank Sinatra and Bruce Springsteen ('' 'My Way' or the Highway?,'' May 21) accurately points out the many similarities between these accomplished performers from the Garden State. However, I think he may have sold Springsteen short. Although Sinatra's music ''makes you feel like a million bucks,'' we need to remember that those ''feel-good'' songs were emblematic of the 1950's and early 60's, when, indeed, many Americans were happy just to enjoy the positive side of life and often avoided facing conditions that would later demand answers. Springsteen's darker music reflects the realism that had become necessary by the close of the 20th century, when many of the problems that were ignored in that earlier generation finally demanded our attention.

Jennifer Sharon Taylor and Joseph Ryan Farrell, both actors, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Carleton Jones officiated, and the Rev. Stephen McConnell, a Presbyterian minister, participated in the ceremony. The bride, 28, will continue to use her name professionally. Last year, she had roles in ''Thoroughly Modern Millie'' and ''The Full Monty'' at the North Shore Music Theater in Beverly, Mass. She also has performed at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., where she met the bridegroom during a production of Stephen Sondheim's ''A Little Night Music.'' She is also an administrative assistant at Centerbridge Partners, an investment firm in New York. She graduated cum laude from New York University.

Re ''That First Inkling: The Origins of Enterprise Stories'' (May 7): It was interesting to read how many reporters suggest the topics for their articles, but disappointing to see how few are concerned about the serious threats to the health and well-being of our nation.

In 2002, during the last World Cup, Tim Parks wrote an interesting article in The New York Review of Books called "Soccer: A Matter of Love and Hate," in which he looked at the contrast between the official line about the World Cup, that, like the Olympics, it's about bringing nations together through sport, and the darker reality he sensed, based on the time he spent living in Italy and supporting a small club side, that it is really about something far less positive for the most die-hard fans.
A Memorial Day weekend gathering helped children in military families cope with death and talk about loss. (Producers: Matthew Orr and Adam B. Ellick)

The BBC has struck a serious blow against workplace productivity around the planet by including, on the part of its World Cup site that profiles each of the teams in the competition, two features that could render otherwise productive office workers completely useless for hours at a time over the next six weeks. The first is an interactive "Squad Selector" allowing you to pick different starting 11's for each nation in the tournament, then arrange those players into various formations and finally e-mail the whole thing to all your friends, so that they can also stare intently at their screens all day, clicking away like mad and appearing to be deeply engaged in their jobs, while in fact doing nothing of any use to their employers. (Here, for example, is the Squad Selector for Holland -- whose manager, Marco van Basten, might now be rethinking his commitment to playing in a 4-3-3 after what The Guardian called a less-than-impressive 1-0 win over Cameroon this past weekend, despite the fact that the Indomitable But Argumentative Lions "argued constantly, both with each other and the referee" and had no less than 5 players booked for dissent during the match.)

It was a busy evening for Charlie King. The attorney general candidate spent a considerable amount of time walking through the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Buffalo, trying to persuade convention delegates to support his campaign's effort to suspend the rules and allow all five candidates for that office onto the ballot. Mr. King's aides have acknowledged that their candidate is far short of the 25 percent of the delegate vote needed for an automatic spot on the September primary ballot.

In his high-octane rally Monday night at Dunn Tire Park in Buffalo, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer had this to say: "We don't need governors and leaders who are criss-crossing this state with their eye on other offices.'' Okay, so Gov. George E. Pataki was in Iowa this weekend. But, umm, which other leaders might be criss-crossing the state with an eye to higher office? It couldn't be Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, could it?

Late last month the Chicago City Council took the incredibly courageous step of banning the sale of foie gras - the livers of ducks and geese that have been force-fed corn - within the city limits. The move, which followed on the heels of an equally bold ban signed into law by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, risked offending such well-organized and powerful food-industry interests as, well, let's see . the two tiny farms, one in Sonoma County and one in New York's Hudson Valley, that produce the entire U.S. foie gras crop. And don't forget the several dozen tony restaurants that serve the delicacy to a slightly larger handful of well-heeled Francophiles.
The heavy drone of the private neighborhood generator slowly eased down into a familiar whir, marking its shutdown for the night. I cursed the owner under my breath. It was only 8:30 p.m.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will not attend the state Republican convention in Hempstead this week, but he still has advice for political leaders in both the Republican and Democratic parties. "I tend to be somebody down the middle," Mr. Bloomberg said today before marching in a Memorial Day parade in Whitestone, Queens. "And I would like to see both parties pick candidates that have exactly that view, that you can't be an absolutist. You have to understand, in a democracy, if we're going to build a consensus, everybody's got to give a little and you've got to do something that may not be perfect, but is fundamentally what you can agree to."

Attempting one of the largest buyouts in recent years, a group led by the chairman of Kinder Morgan has offered to buy the Houston-based pipeline owner for $100 per share, valuing the company at about $13.4 billion. Including debt that Kinder Morgan would either retain or refinance, the proposed buyout has an overall value of about $22 billion, according to a press release from the consortium.

Heightening the disconnect between a state Democratic Party that largely opposes the Iraq war, and the planned coronation of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who supported it, is a long-shot challenger and his modest proposal for an anti-war resolution.

A couple of our readers have rightly pointed out that we've been a bit thin on Argentina content so far. We're out to correct that situation, so while also noting that Diego Armando Maradona recently expressed his desire to one day coach the albicelestes, we offer this paean to El Pibe de Oro, the actual play by play of the second goal he scored against England in the 1986 World Cup quarterfinals, thanks to the vivadiego Web site.

Did it cross the line or not? That's been the question since Geoff Hurst's shot in extra time during the 1966 World Cup final at Wembley hit the crossbar and dropped down either on or over the goal line, giving England a 3-2 lead en route to a 4-2 victory. (And the English have been insufferable about it ever since -- ask any Scot.)
It's a busy day for political consultant Bill O'Reilly, whose shop is working for two Republican candidates this year, John Faso for governor and K.T. McFarland for Senate.

One question we haven't seen addressed is whether it was a good idea for Bruce Arena and the U.S. Soccer Federation to have scheduled all the team's World Cup preparation matches in the United States in the fortnight before the tournament begins, and none in Europe.

The United States' 1-0 victory yesterday in East Hartford against a Latvia team that hadn't played in six months received enthusiastic reviews from most of the reporters who covered the game. Their game accounts, as in The Boston Globe, Los Angeles Times, New York Daily News and Hartford Courant focused on the Americans' getting a good result and on Brian McBride's grit in scoring the lone goal after getting whacked in the forehead.

Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Saturday, 29 May 1784: 29 6/10; 53, 61; S, SE. No dew, dark, rain, sun, grey. Flag-Iris, & Narcissus blow. Gryllo-talpa churs in moist meadows. Aphides appear on the shoots of the wall-cherries.

The authorities were investigating yesterday a drive-by shooting at a barbecue that left a 15-year-old Irvington boy dead and two other people injured. The shootings were reported about 10:40 p.m. Saturday. Police Chief Michael Chase said that when officers arrived, the 15-year-old was lying in front of a house on 22nd Street. He was declared dead at the scene. A 13-year-old Irvington boy was also shot, in the leg and a third victim, Jerome Glasco, 30, of Newark, was shot in the face, Chief Chase told The Star-Ledger. Both of the boys were taken to University Medical Center in Newark and treated for injuries that were not life-threatening. The teenagers were not identified by the police. Chief Chase said the police believed that the gunfire had come from a late-model Nissan.

A woman found dead and burned Saturday afternoon in an isolated wildlife preserve had been stabbed to death, the city medical examiner's office said yesterday. The police did not identify the woman. Her body was found by two bicyclists several feet from a footpath in the Fresh Creek preserve, near Louisiana Avenue and the Spring Creek apartments. The woman had been stabbed in the chest and neck and her body was burned, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office, which conducted an autopsy yesterday.

An 18-year-old man was shot yesterday by a gunman who fired over a fence at a house party in St. Albans, the police said. The man, whose identity was not released by the police, was in critical condition at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica. The shooting occurred about 1:10 a.m. at 202-01 116th Avenue, when a person who was not invited to the party fired several shots over the fence, striking the man in the neck, the police said. There were no arrests. A man who answered the door at the house declined to discuss the shooting. Police officers were seen removing a silver-colored pistol from the residence later yesterday morning.

A man was shot seven times and killed in East Flatbush shortly before 5 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The victim was a 31-year-old man from Maryland. The police declined to identify him last evening because it was unclear whether his family had been notified of his death, a police spokesman said. The shooting took place on Albany Avenue near Albany Manor, a dance hall where a reggae party was held on Saturday night, but it was unclear whether the victim had been at the party or had been involved in a fight there. The gunman sped away in a car, said a man who heard the shots, Thomas Gore, 70.

BLOOM--Leslie. June 19, 1943, to May 26, 2006. Beloved sister of Deborah and Michael, loving daughter of the late Bea and Sam. Leslie loved her family and friends, bird watching, books, and the New York Mets. She will live forever in our hearts. Contributions in Leslie's memory may be made to the Samuel and Beatrice Marks Bloom Memorial fund, c/o the Westchester Community Foundation.

ENLANDER--Caron. My darling Caron has died and left me bereft. All who knew her are saddened. She was a gift to all who knew her. To the Editor: All of the new construction work on the site must allow the existing Javits Convention Center to continue to function normally. It would be impossible, without closing the center for a considerable period, to deliver a building that faces the waterfront and is serviced from 11th Avenue.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Pentagon Urges Approval Of Quick-Strike Weapon The Pentagon pressed Congress to approve development of a new non-nuclear weapon that could be used to attack terrorist camps, enemy missile sites, suspected caches of biological, chemical or nuclear weapons and other potentially urgent threats within an hour of detection, military officials say. A1 Haditha Survivors Speak Four people who survived the killings in Haditha described them to an Iraqi writer and historian who was recruited by The New York Times to interview survivors and witnesses of what military and Pentagon officials have said appear to be unjustified killings of two dozen Iraqis. A1 Harrowing Exodus by Somalis Fighting between Islamists and Somali warlords has left hundreds dead and many more injured in Mogadishu, Somalia's capital, spurring many to leave, seeking aid from smugglers to get them by boat to Yemen in order to find work. It is a perilous journey that has claimed 1,000 lives this year alone. A1 Pope Tours Camps in Poland Pope Benedict XVI prayed at the cells and crematoriums of the Nazi death camps in Poland. While he spoke eloquently about ''forgiveness and reconciliation,'' he did not beg pardon for sins of Germans or of the Roman Catholic church during World War II. He laid the blame squarely on the Nazi regime. A7 Israeli-Lebanese Violence In skirmishes across the Israeli-Lebanese border, militants fired rockets into northern Israel, and Israel responded sharply, pounding militant bases in Lebanon and trading artillery fire across the frontier. A militant was killed in Lebanon and combatants were injured on both sides of the border. A3 Indonesia Quake Toll Rising The earthquake has killed more than 4,500 people so far, the Indonesian government said. Joh Budd, a spokesman for the United Nations Children's Fund, said tens of thousands more have been injured and at least 100,000 have been left homeless, nearly half of them children younger than 18. A10 Doubts on Iran Nuclear Effort Iran boasts that it has joined the ''nuclear club'' by enriching uranium on an industrial scale, but it may have slowed its drive to produce nuclear fuel, according to European diplomats who have reviewed reports from inspectors inside the country. A9 Riots by Azeris Spread in Iran Four people were killed and 70 were injured in riots in the Azeri northwest of Iran, according to local news reports, as tensions spread after the publication of a cartoon that offended the nation's Azeri population, Iran's largest minority group. A9 Uribe Re-Elected in Colombia Álvaro Uribe, president of Colombia, was re-elected in a landslide victory, receiving 62 percent of the vote with all ballots counted. A10 NATIONAL A11-13 Legal Channels Limited For Mexican Immigrants In the immigration system being debated in Congress, immigration from Mexico is a critically broken part and, researchers and analysts say, central to any meaningful fix. Mexican workers have been the dominant group coming to the United States over the last two decades, yet Washington has opened only limited legal channels for them. A11 Lawmaker at Center of Battle Even as Representative William J. Jefferson, whose Congressional offices were searched May 20 by the F.B.I., built a reputation as one of Louisiana's brightest and most effective leaders, a less flattering view began to emerge, one signified by his nickname in political circles, ''Dollar Bill.'' A1 Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, defended the raid by federal agents on Mr. Jefferson's Capitol Hill office, breaking with senior House Republicans who had said the search was unconstitutional. A12 Grief Camp for Military Children An estimated 1,600 children have lost a parent to the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Over the weekend, nearly 150 of these children gathered at a yearly grief camp run by the Tragedy Assistance Program for Survivors, a nonprofit group founded in 1994 that helps military families and friends cope with death. A1 Rains Push River to New Path The Suncook River in Epsom, N.H., cut a new course during torrential rains and flooding this month, leaving a 1.52-mile stretch of what was once river close to empty. State officials are considering a plan to move it back. A11 Third Bush Presidency Debated Bush III? Or has the dynasty run its course? Those are the questions some Republicans are asking themselves as political talk bubbles up yet again about President Bush's brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida and his interest in the White House. A12 OBITUARIES B7 Carolyn Shaw Bell An economist at Wellesley College who took her fight for equal opportunities for women in economics from the college into the national arena, she was 85. B7 Craig Heyward The powerful fullback known as Ironhead, who played 11 seasons in the National Football League despite battling binges of food and drink, he was 39. B7 Gen. Romeo Lucas García A former president of Guatemala whose rule is remembered for a bloody police raid on the Spanish Embassy, which left 37 people dead, he was 85. B7 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Wild Animals Roaming In Urban Areas In recent weeks, a variety of wildlife, including black bears, a moose and white-tailed deer -- large mammals native to the East -- have visited New York City and its environs, causing a fair degree of chaos. The factors causing their return include both environmental triumphs and travesties. A1 Bikers Help Mourn Soldiers A group of bikers called the Patriot Guard Riders have attended military funerals around the country for the last six months as a counterprotest to a Christian splinter group that has been bringing its antigay message to military funerals. The bikers recently attended the Long Island funeral of a Marine Corps lieutenant killed in Iraq. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Bonds Breaks Babe's Record Barry Bonds passed Babe Ruth's record for career home runs, hitting the 715th home run of his 21-year major-league career on a 3-2 fastball in the bottom of the fourth inning of San Francisco's game against the Colorado Rockies. Bonds now trails only Hank Aaron's 755 for first place. D1 Andretti Edged Out at Indy Sam Hornish Jr. passed Marco Andretti only 150 yards from the finish and won the second-closest Indianapolis 500 in history. Andretti, a 19-year-old rookie, lost by 0.0635 seconds. D1 Stars Struggle at French Open Roger Federer and Maria Sharapova both overcame surprisingly stiff resistance in their first-round matches and then made it clear that they would have preferred not to play on the first day of the tournament's expanded schedule. D5 ARTS E1-10 Irish Rebellion Wins at Cannes ''The Wind That Shakes the Barley,'' a film about the Irish rebellion against British rule and the country's subsequent civil war, won the top prize at the 59th Cannes Film Festival. This was the 13th time Ken Loach, at 69 the oldest director in competition this year, had brought a film to Cannes. E1 Spacey Unfazed by Critics Kevin Spacey, whose first year and ahalf as artistic director of the Old Vic has been met with scathing reviews from London theater critics, asserted his right to learn from his mistakes while announcing an ambitious program for next year that includes plays by Shakespeare and Eugene O'Neill. E1 Watching Dueling Poets Online On a Web site called QuickMuse two writers are given 15 minutes each to compose a poem based on a little inspiration furnished by an editor. Fifteen minutes later the poems go up on the site, and can be played back so that readers see the keystrokes unfold second by second and follow each erasure and false start. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Restoring Sony's Image Sony has expanded into so many business areas in Japan and abroad that it has blurred its original identity as an engineering innovator. Analysts say this murkier image threatens one of the company's most profitable assets: the so-called Sony premium, the higher prices long commanded by its electronics products. C1 Bank Trying to Block Steel Sale The investment bank Goldman Sachs is trying to organize Arcelor shareholders to block the steel company's controversial plans to sell off a major stake to Severstal, a Russian company. C2 Tire Maker Loses Leader Michelin, the tire maker, moved swiftly over the weekend to assuage a looming management crisis after Édouard Michelin, its co-managing partner, drowned Friday in a boating accident at age 42. Michelin said its other managing partner, Michel Rollier, would take over sole responsibility for running the 117-year-old company. C2 Limits on Canada's Press Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada and his staff have repeatedly tried to change how Canada's news outlets deal with its prime minister. Mr. Harper's office is vetting minor government announcements and members of his cabinet have generally been off-limits to reporters. C3 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: A grand entrance to New York; remembering and forgetting; the interest must be paid. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E8 Crossword E8 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E10 Weather B8

The traditional television season ended on Wednesday, and not surprisingly, Fox's ''American Idol'' accounted for the two top-ranked shows. In Nielsen's estimates, the Tuesday edition of that mammoth talent show drew an average of 31.2 million viewers, and the Wednesday show drew 30.2 million. Both were up in double-digit percentages compared with the previous season in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 years old. After the two nights of ''Idol'' came CBS's ''CSI'' (25.2 million), followed by ''Desperate Housewives'' (22.2 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' (19.9 million). The most-watched new show of the season was the Monday edition of NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' (15.8 million), which ranked 13th. ''The Unit'' (15.5 million) on CBS followed that and was the top scripted new show. ''Veronica Mars,'' formerly of UPN and now of the CW, was the least-watched show to be renewed for next season. That girl-detective cult series brought in an average of 2.3 million viewers and ranked 145th out of 156 shows. KATE AURTHUR

Diego Urcola ''Viva'' (Cam Jazz) The Argentine trumpeter Diego Urcola has a clear, soft-featured tone better suited to lullabies and lamentations than to any sort of blaring spectacle. Yet he makes a point of covering all bases -- bright and muted alike -- on ''Viva,'' his third and strongest album.

To the Editor: It seems as if the debate on immigration (front page, May 25) excludes some middle ground on which compromise might be reached.

Mike Stamberger, despite closing out with a three-over-par 74, registered a 54-hole total of 207 to win the New York City Amateur championship yesterday at LaTourette Golf Club on Staten Island. Albert Oh, who shot a 72, was second at 215. BERNIE BEGLANE (NYT)

FIELD--George. One of the founders of Freedom House and its Executive Director from 1941 to 1967, has died at age 101 in Kennett Square, PA. Mr. Field devoted his life to the pursuit of freedom, democarcy and human rights. After serving as Program Director of WEVD Radio, he became the first Executive Director of Freedom House, a position he held until his retirement in 1967. Mr. Field was predeceased by his wife Molly (nee Mass). He is survived by two children, Paul Field and Ellen Balkan; five grandchildren, Gary Field, Craig Field, Laurie Liberty, Donna Balkan and Liza Balkan, and six great-grandchildren. In his memory, donations may be made to Amnesty International.

Shearwater ''Palo Santo'' (Misra) The last Shearwater album, ''Winged Life,'' was modest and charming, full of precisely written songs about bittersweet revelations. Shearwater, from Austin, Tex., is led by Jonathan Meiburg, a singer and songwriter and (as it happens) ornithologist who also plays in Okkervil River. That band keeps getting better, and so does this one; ''Palo Santo'' is much more charming and much less modest than its predecessor. This is one of the year's best indie-rock albums. Mr. Meiburg is figuring out some of the places a fearless falsetto will take him. (From time to time Shearwater evokes a ramshackle Radiohead.) These 11 flickering -- and hummable -- songs tell a desperate but not quite decipherable story
To the Editor: The effect of nurse emigration on the countries of origin is not that simple (''U.S. Plan to Lure Nurses May Hurt Poor Nations'').

9 P.M. (History Channel) WASHINGTON THE WARRIOR -- He suffered defeat more times than not and his decisions, sometimes ill-conceived, occasionally failed to inspire loyalty. He was also something of a social climber and joined the military to get there. Still, George Washington (above, as portrayed by Jackson Bolt) is the standard to which American commanders are held. This documentary uses historical documents and interviews with historians including Joseph J. Ellis, Caroline Cox and Lt. General Dave R. Palmer, a former superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point. 8 P.M. (13, 49) ANTIQUES ROADSHOW -- What are Marilyn Monroe memorabilia, James Dean's high school yearbook, a photograph of Annie Oakley and the first mask worn by Clayton Moore in ''The Lone Ranger'' worth? You'll find out here in a special episode titled ''Fame and Fortune.'' 9 P.M. (BBC America) SECRET SMILE -- (2005). An unrequited lover with what you'd call issues insinuates himself into the life of his one-night stand. Now he's going down. David Tennant (left) and Kate Ashfield star in this tale of torment and terror, the first in ''Crimes of Passion,'' a series of thrillers on Mondays and Tuesdays through July 4. 9 P.M. (NBC) THE APPRENTICE -- Sean oozes British refinement. Lee is all New York street smarts. In this final battle, these remaining two candidates compete by planning (with a little help from their former teammates and friends) big charity blowouts in hopes that next week they'll hear Donald Trump say, ''You're hired.'' 9 P.M. (11) EVERWOOD -- Season finale. The town gathers for the funeral of a beloved citizen and pays homage to a life well lived. And suddenly, relationships begin to matter so much more than they did. 9 P.M. (Sundance) SEARCHING FOR THE WRONGEYED JESUS -- (2003). Jim White (right), an altcountry singer, explores his Southern heritage on a backroad trip through churches, prisons, truck stops, coalmines and biker bars in this documentary by Andrew Douglas. Along the way, he hears music by the Handsome Family, Johnny Dowd, 16 Horsepower and David Johansen, and a few grisly stories from Harry Crews. 10 P.M. (MTV) REAL WORLD/ROAD RULES CHALLENGE: FRESH MEAT -- The challenge heads down under to Australia and changes the game: each of the 12 ''Real World'' and ''Road Rules'' alumni will be paired with players who've never been on a show. Among the obstacles they'll face: unpleasant housemates, grueling physical tasks and an elimination process called exile. 10 P.M. (Showtime) PENN AND TELLER -- The comedians-cum-magicians demonstrate that statistics don't always add up. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
To the Editor: The United States' plan to lure foreign nurses to America is a guaranteed plan to reduce the decent salaries offered to Americans.

To the Editor: What a sad commentary on this country that we put our efforts into luring outsiders at the expense of their own countries instead of investing in our own, willing and able-bodied citizens.

DAY OF REST -- All stock markets, government offices and many businesses are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. BEFORE THE DEAL IS DONE -- The grocery giant Albertson's will release its last quarterly earnings before it is acquired by Supervalu, a deal that is expected to close in June. Like other grocery chains, Albertson's has been hurt by competition from Wal-Mart. (Tuesday.) EXPECTING LOSSES -- Vodafone, a British company that jointly owns Verizon Wireless with Verizon, will state its yearly earnings. Analysts expect Vodafone to report losses in the billions, attributed in part to asset write-downs. (Tuesday.) WORD FOR WORD -- The Federal Reserve will release the minutes of its May meeting, where, as expected, the central bank decided to raise interest rates for a 16th consecutive time. (Wednesday.) SALES WATCH -- Automakers are expected to release sales figures for May. The data should reveal whether gas prices are affecting the kind of vehicles being sold. The industry will also take note if Toyota outsells DaimlerChrysler in the United States for a second consecutive month. (Thursday). PLACATING -- H.J. Heinz will announce its growth strategy, hoping to satisfy angry shareholders and the leveraged buyout specialist Nelson Peltz. Presumably the company will propose something less drastic than the cost-cutting that Mr. Peltz is demanding. (Thursday). PAIN INTO GAIN -- Quarterly earnings numbers are expected from Jackson Hewitt Tax Service. The company may have benefited from the recent embarrassments and lawsuits that have plagued H&R Block. (Thursday.) ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- Several barometers will be released, including the Chicago purchasing managers report for May (Wednesday); productivity for the first quarter, the Institute of Supply Management manufacturing index for May and construction spending for April. (Thursday.) JOBS -- The main economic indicator of the week, the jobless report for May, will be released. An addition of 175,000 jobs is expected. About 138,000 jobs were added in April. (Friday.)

STROMBERG - Hank. Be loved spouse and father, 62, died on May 26, at Westchester Medical Center, after a courageous battle with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Hank was born on February 5, 1944, to Ruth and Hyman Stromberg of Bronx, NY. He attended the School of Visual Arts and was a veteran of the US military. In 1975 he was married to Virginia Connors, who was the light of his life. His expansive and recognized art career included numerous conceptual and unconventional art shows at the Musuem of Modern Art, the White House and Central Park, all of which were covered by the ''Village Voice,'' ''The New York Times'' and ABC News. He was also recognized as an influential advertising executive and worked for companies including L. W. Frohlich, Bozell Worldwide, and Ogilvy & Mather, where he held the position of Creative Director and Vice President for 14 years. He also established his own advertising agency called Leapfrog Advertising. He received numerous advertising awards from the Advertising Club of New York, Direct Marketing Co., Target Marketing and the Advertising Club of Westchester. His hobbies included spending time with his family and cherished dog Bailey, gardening, traveling and fishing. He is survived by wife of 31 years, Virginia Stromberg of Chappaqua, NY, daughters Alison, 27, of Brooklyn, NY, Dana, 25, of Charlottesville, VA, and son Matthew, 21, of Chappaqua, NY. Memorial services will be held at Hawthorne Memorial Home in Hawthorne, NY, at 10 am, on Monday, May 29

FINE--Edith. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Edith Fine. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

Adored brother of Timothy Breslin, Eileen Breslin Rocca and Sally Breslin Dibble. Loving fiance of Helen DiScala. Also survived by many nieces and nephews.
