Despite limited radio play and a three-year feud between the Dixie Chicks and country music fans, someone is buying ''Taking the Long Way.'' When the seventh studio album by the band (above, from left, Emily Robison, Natalie Maines and Martie Maguire) was released on May 23, it had already been the best-selling title -- through advance sales -- in the country music category at Barnes&Noble.com for 15 days. It registered the biggest opening week of any album in 2006 and promptly took over the top spot for all online sales. SHELLY FREIERMAN

FARBER--Anne. At the age of 57. A resident of New Rochelle. Loving wife of Richard Kaiser. Devoted mother of Rachel (Mike), Emily (Michael), Deborah, Samuel. Cherished grandmother of Zachary. Survived by her mother Marjorie and beloved sister Elizabeth (Bill), and aunt of Doris and Sophie. Temple service on Tuesday, 11 am, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle. Interment to follow Hillside Cemetery, Rutherford, NJ. For more information contact George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, NY.

To the Editor: Re ''Hoffa Search Finds Town's Sense of Humor'' (Milford Journal, May 24): I am disappointed by your portrayal of the so-called ''cavalcade of colorful characters'' in the town of Milford, Mich.

A German Pope Visits Auschwitz Pope Benedict XVI, once a German soldier, visited Auschwitz, walking through the infamous gate promising ''Work Shall Set You Free.'' PAGE A7 Iran's Drive to Nuclear Fuel Slows, Diplomats Say After boasting last month that it had joined the ''nuclear club'' by successfully enriching uranium on an industrial scale, Iran appears to have slowed its drive to produce nuclear fuel, European diplomats say. PAGE A9 Indonesia Quake Toll Rising Officials said the earthquake that struck Indonesia on Saturday killed at least 4,500 people, a number that was expected to rise as aftershocks continued and the rubble of collapsed buildings was searched. PAGE A10 Bloomberg's Political Future For a man who says he is not running for president, Mayor Bloomberg has been sounding a lot like a candidate. Last week, he dived into national issues, but then denied any interest in higher office. PAGE B1 Bonds Passes the Babe With his 715th career homer, Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants passed Babe Ruth on the career list. He now trails only Hank Aaron, who hit 755. SPORTSMONDAY, PAGE D1 Close Finish in Indianapolis Sam Hornish Jr., above, beat the rookie Marco Andretti by 0.0635 of a second to win the second-closest Indy 500 in history. Andretti's father, Michael, was third. It was the first time that the winner took the lead on the final lap. SPORTSMONDAY, PAGE D1 The Best of Cannes On his 13th try, Ken Loach won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival with ''The Wind That Shakes the Barley,'' about the Irish rebellion against the British. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

MEMORIAL DAY MEANS the unofficial start of summer. But it also means the official start of another season: reality television season. The kickoff was last Thursday, when Fox presented the first reality show of the summer, ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' a talent competition for hoofers. That series jump-started the summer reality show monsoon one week early in a successful effort to grab some of the huge audience glued to the latest ''American Idol'' lollapalooza. [C1.] BRIAN TIERNEY, ADMAN, corporate pitchman, part P. T. Barnum, part Little Engine That Could, is grabbing any and all opportunities to expand outlets for the Philadephia newspapers and their shared Web site that he agreed to buy last week. [C1.] SONY, KNOWN IN the United States for electronics, has expanded into so many business areas in Japan and abroad that it has blurred its original identity as an engineering innovator. Analysts say this murkier image threatens one of the company's most profitable assets: the so-called Sony premium, the higher prices long commanded by its electronics products, which still account for 64 percent of revenue. [C1.] TV GUIDE PLANS give a free DVD of television clips to people who buy the magazine on the newsstand. The DVD, which will go on sale this Thursday and will be affixed to the front of 700,000 issues on newsstands on the East and West Coasts, features clips of 17 new and returning shows that editors recommend for summer viewing. The goal, TV Guide said, is to grab the attention of younger readers in an era when television listings are available free on cable and newspapers and magazines burst with articles about television shows and their stars. [C6.] THE NUMBER OF PEOPLE paying their bills online instead of by check is booming, according to a recent survey. Matthew Lewis, below, executive vice persident of CheckFree, which helps banks and billers build online bill presentation and payment serivces, says online payment services can help consumers. His company, he said, wants to make online bill payments part of the way Americans live their lives. [C4.] TACIT SOFTWARE IS preparing a Web service that will make it simple for online shoppers to pick the brains of friends and colleagues for opinions and expertise. Tacit plans to start testing the service, called Illumio, next month. The service allows the user to data mine the computers of friends, business associates and others with shared interests on any number of subjects. The system is intended to extend a growing category of software that helps groups collaborate and work together more efficiently. [C5.] THE ADVERTISING AGENCY that created the character of the lonely Maytag repairman is about to become lonely, too, as the new owner of Maytag appliances moves the account to another agency. Leo Burnett in Chicago, which has produced Maytag campaigns since 1955, is losing the assignment as the Whirlpool Corporation, which acquired the Maytag Corporation in March, consolidates accounts at its own agency, Publicis Worldwide in New York. [C6.] THE FRENCH INVESTOR Vincent Bolloré maneuvered four representatives onto the Havas board and eventually took over as chairman of the company last year. Now he hopes to star in a sequel. After installing himself at Havas, Mr. Bolloré started accumulating a stake in Aegis, which owns Carat, the largest buyer of media space and time in Europe and this month has taken steps that could give him more control and perhaps eventually a combiniation of Aegis with Havas. [C5.] WHEN CMP MEDIA and O'Reilly Media, sponsors of the Web 2.0 conference on technology and business, tried to prevent a nonprofit organization in Ireland from using the Web 2.0 name for a conference of its own, bloggers were incensed, saying the 2.0 philosophy is about sharing. CMP and O'Reilly said they were acting to protect a patent application they have for Web 2.0 but, in this case, they agreed to let the organizers use the name. [C6.] SINCE THE ELECTION of his minority Conservative government in January, Prime Minister Stephen Harper below, of Canada and his staff have repeatedly tried to change how Canada's news outlets deal with its prime minister. Mr. Harper's office is vetting minor government announcements, members of his cabinet have generally been off limits to reporters, and cameras have been blocked from covering the return of Canadian soldiers' remains from Afghanistan. About two dozen political reporters walked out of Mr. Harper's news conference last week in protest. [C3.] YOU LINK TO MINE; I'll link to yours. Readers of The New York Observer Web site may spot a box of headlines with links to news and opinion articles under the title ''Huff Post.'' Clicking on one of the headlines takes readers to The Huffington Post, the hub of political commentary and opinion created by the celebrity blogger Arianna Huffington. On The Huffington Post site, a similar list of newspaper headlines takes them whence they came: The New York Observer. [C6.]

SCHNALL--Jean. On May 28, 2006. She passed away at her home, 91 years old. Loving, devoted, self - sacrificing Mother, charming and witty friend, devoted daughter. She will be dearly missed. Graveside burial on May 30, at 11 am, Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Her daughter Flora will receive family and friends at 303 East 57th, NYC, on May 31, after 3 pm.

Modernista, Boston, opened a creative office in Amsterdam to serve an American client, the Hummer brand sold by General Motors, in Europe and the Middle East. Nick Simmonds leads the office as managing director; he had been client services director at the Amsterdam office of Wieden & Kennedy.

Juana Molina ''Son'' (Domino) In the solitude of a home studio, a songwriter can whisper intimacies or follow unihibited whims. Juana Molina does both on her fourth album, ''Son,'' which she made almost entirely on her own. Ms. Molina was a television comedy actress in Argentina before she turned to songwriting. But her sense of humor was muted on her two previous albums, ''Segundo'' and ''Tres Cosas,'' as she perfected the whispery side.

SCHWAGER - Elaine. We mourn the loss of our lifelong friend, Elaine Schwager. She was a good and loyal friend, a perceptive, insightful thinker and poet. We will miss her quiet, firm presence. Our hearts are with her mother, Inge, her husband, Marvin, and her children, Carl and Julia. Peter and Lauren Lese $(6$)SCHWAGER - HURVICH -Elaine, Ph.D. On May 26, 2006. Beloved wife of Dr. Marvin Hurvich. Loving mother of Carl and Julia. Devoted daughter of Inge Schwager and dear friend. Services, Tuesday, 9:30 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Kimberly-Clark, Irving, Tex., consolidated the creative duties for its personal care products sold in Europe and North America at the London and New York offices of JWT, part of the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at $200 million. JWT, which creates campaigns for household brands like Cottonelle, Kleenex and Scott, adds products like Depend, Huggies and Kotex, which had been at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, also part of WPP. Ogilvy continues to create ads for the personal care brands in regions like Africa, Latin America and the Middle East. Luxottica Group, Milan, named the San Francisco office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle the global creative duties for the Ray-Ban brand of sunglasses. Spending on the assignment, for which there was no previous agency, was estimated at $30 million.
To the Editor: Re ''Corn Laws for the 21st Century'' (editorial, May 22):
To the Editor: Re ''In Print, Staring Down a Daily Worry,'' by David Carr (column, Business Day, May 22):

Yung Joc New Joc City (Bad Boy/Atlantic) Over the last year Atlanta crack-rap has come into its own, driven by terrific CD's (not to mention mixtapes) from T.I., Young Jeezy and his former group, Boyz n da Hood; they've all found slick new ways to rhyme about selling cocaine. And so Yung Joc's timing couldn't be better: less menacing but not quite harmless, he has developed a more lightweight version of this tough-sounding style. His breakthrough single, ''It's Goin' Down,'' has hit No. 1 on Billboard's R&B/Hip-Hop chart, propelled by a jagged two-note synthesizer line (by the producer Nitti) and lots of greasy rhymes: ''Catch me in the hood, posted at the sto'/ Pistol in my lap, on the phone, counting dough.''

To the Editor: Re ''Corn Laws for the 21st Century'' (editorial, May 22):
To the Editor: Re ''In Print, Staring Down a Daily Worry,'' by David Carr (column, Business Day, May 22):

Yung Joc New Joc City (Bad Boy/Atlantic) Over the last year Atlanta crack-rap has come into its own, driven by terrific CD's (not to mention mixtapes) from T.I., Young Jeezy and his former group, Boyz n da Hood; they've all found slick new ways to rhyme about selling cocaine. And so Yung Joc's timing couldn't be better: less menacing but not quite harmless, he has developed a more lightweight version of this tough-sounding style. His breakthrough single, ''It's Goin' Down,'' has hit No. 1 on Billboard's R&B/Hip-Hop chart, propelled by a jagged two-note synthesizer line (by the producer Nitti) and lots of greasy rhymes: ''Catch me in the hood, posted at the sto'/ Pistol in my lap, on the phone, counting dough.''

Peeping Tom ''Peeping Tom'' (Ipecac) After years of ingeniously clearing rooms, the avant-noise guru Mike Patton has made music safe enough for hair salons. His album ''Peeping Tom'' looks back to the sinister trip-hop of the 1990's, adding hard-rock flourishes from his Faith No More days. There are guests on every track, including Massive Attack, Bebel Gilberto and the producer Dan the Automator, who worked with Mr. Patton in the lounge-hop spoof Lovage.
To the Editor: The so-called nursing shortage wouldn't exist if hospitals offered adequate pay and endurable working conditions commensurate with the responsibilities of registered nurses.

ALEXANDER - Simon. On May 28, 2006. Beloved husband of Rosalind. Devoted father and father-in-law of Judi and Stuart Oltchick, San dra and Frank Kaplan, Barbara and Warren Brandt. Adored grandfather to Amy Oltchick, Peter and Amanda Oltchick, Jeffrey and Allison Brandt. Cherished greatgrandfather of Zoe, Hailey and Andrew. Services Tuesday May 30th, 11:45 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

To the Editor: David Carr's lament over the decline of daily newspapers (column, Business Day, May 22) is similar to dozens of other nostalgic sighs from journalists, none of which address the essential cause of their situation: fewer and fewer people want to read newspapers.
To the Editor: I have been a registered nurse for 31 years and a nurse practitioner for 10 years.
''We know there are two possibilities: life or death.'' ABDI KAREEM MUHAMMAD MAHMOUD, a Somalian who plans to leave, on why people risk their lives to flee the country. [A1]
Fresh from the convention hoopla in Buffalo, Eliot Spitzer dropped by a campaign party this evening with a few hundred supporters in a parking lot in nearby Lackawanna.
On Thursday, the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight releases its figures on house appreciation. Think of it as the official scorecard for the real estate game.
An interesting comment for all those who gleefully await the real estate crash can be found at the end of the Surreal Estate column of the San Francisco Chronicle.
A U.N. report indicates that the number of people infected with H.I.V. may have stabilized globally since the 1990s, but the disease is still proliferating in several individual countries.
Soccer pornography: a video of unbelievable trapping, passing and beautiful goals from Zinedine Zidane and Ronaldinho. Delightfully, not assembled in the service of selling us anything. - J.K./R.M.
A few people have asked that we post a link to a full schedule for the tournament, showing what time each game starts here in New York, so we did. - J.K./R.M.

For those who enjoyed our colleague Sarah Lyall's fine article in today's paper, "England's Soccer Fans Expect the Best but Await the Worst," and England completists, we present a special bonus feature: the video console on the official England team Web site, where you can watch the English news media cross-examine Coach Sven-Goran Eriksson as though he had broken Wayne Rooney's foot himself. Perhaps, given today's 3-1 victory over Hungary, they will be kinder the next time. Perhaps. - R.M./J.K.
In Akron, Ohio, foreclosed homes -- especially those costing $20,000 or less -- are selling briskly, The Beacon-Journal reports. These bargain properties are usually sold to flippers.
Rate your broker? Brokerate.com, the site recently started by Brownstoner to rate New York real estate brokers, was suspended after just four days, due to vicious and uncivil broker bashing.

The Sam's Army player ratings are in for the U.S. national team's 1-0 victory over Latvia on Sunday. Members of the excellent traveling support group, voting on the Sam's Army Web site, gave a thumbs up to Brian McBride, who earned an average of 7.14 out of 10, and something of a thumbs sideways to DaMarcus Beasley, whom they gave a team-low 4.93, just a hair below mediocre.
For the holiday weekend, my wife and I took the kids to a water park in Pennsylvania. We were issued those snap-on wrist bracelets that show that you've paid your admission fee.
The delegate counting is nearing an end in the battle to replace Eliot Spitzer, and already the candidates are looking ahead to the petitioning process to get on the September primary ballot.

There was a long line for the free hot dogs and soda at Tom Suozzi's rally for governor outside the Democratic convention this afternoon -- and about as many people stood listening to the Man himself.

Our Viennese correspondent, Christian Höller, now bitten hard by the World Cup blogging bug, writes again to alert us to two more items of interest in the German press. First, in the English-language edition of Spiegel, there is this translation of an interview with the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad that ran in German on Sunday. As of that moment, Ahmadinejad said he was still thinking of attending the Iranian team's opening match in Nuremberg on June 11, which prompted Spiegel to point out to him that "denying the Holocaust is punishable in Germany." Perhaps having taken this in, now Ahmadinejad seems to have decided not to make the trip after all. There is a report from Tehran today that, while "he really wants to go," he may not be able to because "he has a lot of work to do."

It's really stunning, the manpower that Andrew Cuomo is deploying at the Democratic convention to drive up his vote count from delegates who are considering whom to back for attorney general right now.
There may be a rude surprise in store for investors who think they escaped getting burned by last year's scandal at hedge fund Bayou Group.

As the Democrats meet to decide whom to support in the race for Attorney General, Mark Green just acknowledged to the Empire Zone that he is not going to get on the ballot and that he will have a statement lambasting the county leaders who used strong-arm tactics to keep him down.
Other teams may be suffering injuries left and right, but for Tunisia, as Coach Roger Lemerre said today in the Tunis daily Le Temps, "everything is in order, even our injured are recuperating."

I spent a year in Cairo studying Arabic many moons ago, and so I've been appalled by the crackdown on dissidents in Egypt. President Mubarak's son, Gamal, seems like a nice guy, but he is hurting himself and his reputation by allowing himself to be portrayed as his father's eventual successor. And the U.S. should stand four-square behind those calling for democracy and an end to torture.
I've never been in Namibia before, and I was very impressed. Particularly after Swaziland, Namibia is incredibly clean and efficient. Windhoek looks more like a European capital than an African one.

Will a rival bidder emerge for Kinder Morgan? Investors on Tuesday seemed to have their doubts. The pipeline company's shares surged as high as $103 early in Tuesday's session but later eased back to close at $100.31. That was only slightly above Monday's offer to take the company private at $100 per share in a deal whose overall value is $22 billion.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

If the Senate confirms Goldman Sachs chairman Henry Paulson Jr. as the next Treasury Secretary, he will pack up his bags and head to Washington. One thing he will probably not take with him -- at least not in its current form -- is his huge equity stake in Goldman Sachs.
In her one-woman show, Nilaja Sun portrays a version of herself: an idealistic young teacher who leads rowdy students in a theatrical performance. (Web exclusive)
Readers respond to Paul Krugman's May 29 column, "Swift Boating the Planet"
Readers respond to David Brooks's May 28 column, "The Duke Witch Hunt"

Are liberal hawks like Peter Beinart, the editor-at-large of The New Republic and the author of "The Good Fight: Why Liberals-and Only Liberals-Can Win the War on Terror and Make America Great Again," actually secret neocons, or are they secret peaceniks?

Bidding for the shoe and apparel maker Jones Apparel Group has entered a second round and the price appears to be $32 a share, Women's Wear Daily reported on Tuesday, citing unnamed investment banking sources. The retail trade magazine said the company and its bankers want between $35 and $38 a share.
Wow, there really isn't a Suozzi supporter in the house, it seems.
Marsh Supermarkets said Tuesday an investor group offered to buy the company for about $107.8 million, nearly 23 percent higher than an existing offer.

As of late Tuesday morning, Goldman Sachs had not announced who will replace Henry Paulson when he steps down as chief executive to become Treasury Secretary. By most accounts, though, the next in line is Lloyd Blankfein, the securities firm's president and chief operating officer.

Shareholders of supermarket chain Albertson's have voted in support of the company's plan to sell itself to a group of retailers and private equity investors for about $9.7 billion, Albertson's said Tuesday in a press release. The deal must also be approved by shareholders of Supervalu, one of the proposed acquirers. That vote was expected later on Tuesday.

Philip Purcell, ousted nearly a year ago as chief executive of Morgan Stanley, has set up a company in Chicago to invest his own money. Joining him at the company, Continental Investors, is W. Eric Carlborg, formerly an investment banker at Merrill Lynch.

Under pressure to shore up its flagging stock price, the publisher and broadcaster Tribune on Tuesday announced plans to repurchase as much as $2 billion of its own stock. Tribune, which some analysts and investors have suggested should sell assets or perhaps even find a buyer for the entire company, also said it would sell $500 million in noncore assets.

We return our attention now to Australia, in the first place because we have a correction to make. As several readers have pointed out, in one of our first posts we mistakenly said that the crowd of 95,000 that turned out to see the Socceroos beat European champions Greece, 1-0, the other day had assembled in Sydney, whereas the report we linked to contained a clue that the match was actually played in Melbourne "at the MCG" -- the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
President Bush announced his choice of Henry M. Paulson, chairman and chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group, to succeed Treasury Secretary John Snow.

The bar at the Hyatt Regency Buffalo was bursting with bodies and buzz at 1 a.m. this morning as Democratic Party convention-goers - politicos, reporters, and a few candidates - refused to turn in for fear of being the only one to miss the gossip.
Following is a selection of emails from family members of military personnel, with their thoughts on the best care packages to send to soldiers overseas.
Archaeologists are searching what could be the first tomb uncovered in the Valley of the Kings in 84 years.
Industrial catalyst maker Engelhard has accepted BASF's $5.1 billion all-cash buyout offer, the German chemicals group announced Tuesday morning.
The options-backdating scandal has not exactly been good news for the beleaguered tech sector. But things could get worse, potentially a lot worse, TheStreet.com writes.

Schmoozing Wall Street is part of the job for most titans of industry. Not Steve Ballmer. The Microsoft chief executive prefers to let investors come to him -- just once a year, at an event the company hosts at its Redmond, Wash., headquarters.
WestJet Airlines agreed on Monday to pay 15.5 million Canadian dollars ($14 million) to settle accusations of spying on an internal Web site of its bigger rival, Air Canada.

Donald Watkins, the Alabama lawyer and businessman who last year engineered the acquittal of Richard Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, was not impressed with the defense strategy of Kenneth L. Lay. Mr. Watkins said the convicted former Enron chief was a "dream client" hobbled by a fundamentally flawed approach.

A plan to force companies to disclose salaries of high-paid employees who are not corporate officers is in jeopardy after a backlash from Hollywood, where film and TV stars often get bigger paychecks than executives.

A rule that lets executives sell shares in their companies according to a predetermined plan once looked like a way to stop businesspeople from trading on their access to inside information. But it hasn't worked out that way, according to a new study.

The Club Company, the golf course operator formerly known as Clubhaus, is understood to have appointed Close Brothers as adviser to a possible 100 million pound ($187 million) sale just two years after being taken private in a 56.5 million pound deal.

Advent International, the global buy-out firm, will on Tuesday announce the acquisition of Milano, Mexico's biggest discount clothes retailer, for $200 million in a deal financed with a high proportion of debt against future cashflow.

the Taittinger family of France has teamed up with Crédit Agricole, the French bank, to bid more than 600 million euros to buy back the Taittinger champagne brand that it was forced to sell last year.

When August Capital's David Hornik started writing about venture capital in a blog three years ago, his Internet musings were greeted with skepticism by his fellow investors. Blogs were being used with regularity by political pundits and the media, among others, but the clubby world of venture capital wasn't used to having an open dialogue with the public.
Asuragen, the offspring of an Austin, Tex., biotech executive, Matt Winkler, just ended its first round of investment funding with $49 million.

It is no secret to most entrepreneurs in Atlanta that the city has too few banks. And venture capitalists and bankers across the country have taken notice. Several major investment firms are increasing their presence in Atlanta, a city seen by many outsiders as ripe for opportunity.

When the private biotechnology company Microbia closed a $75 million round of funding in February, investors sat up and took notice. Not only because the Cambridge, Mass., firm had just landed the biggest local round of biotechnology venture financing in two years, but also because a large chunk of the money came from hedge funds.

Sprint Nextel has officially opened a venture capital arm, with its leader based in Overland Park, Kan. The unit, Sprint Ventures, already has invested in one unnamed company and will look to complete three to five deals a year. The group plans to invest nationally but will be active in the local startup scene.

The porn publishing empire formerly owned by Express newspapers owner Richard Desmond is planning to float shares on the Alternative Investment Market despite an internal dispute over the company's finances.
Trading in the Bank of China's placement of $9.8 billion in stock is set to begin on Thursday in Hong Kong and the issue is already getting high marks from investors.
Shares of Thai Beverage, Thailand's largest brewer, declined as much as 1.8 percent in its first trading day on concern over the company's growth prospects.

Last Friday afternoon, as many Wall Street workers were fighting traffic to get to the Hamptons or some other holiday weekend getaway, Bloomberg News reported a notable milestone. It seems that Friday's proposed deal between steel makers Arcelor and Severstal pushed year-to-date mergers and acquisitions volume past the previous record set in 2000, at least by Bloomberg's reckoning.
Bank of New York, State Street, Mellon Financial and Northern Trust, the biggest independent custodial banks in the United States, should have been a natural fit for hedge funds.

Using a plethora of baseball puns, columnist Allan Sloan outlines why Time Warner's sale of the Atlanta Braves to Liberty Media is a win-win situation all around. Mr. Sloan points out that the two companies would reap almost $700 million in tax savings, especially with help from new legislation:
The shipping giant FedEx moved on Friday to increase its heavy freight offerings, agreeing to buy a trucking company, Watkins Motor Lines, from Watkins Associated Industries for $780 million in cash.

Biogen Idec, the Cambridge, Mass.-based biotechnology company that makes the multiple sclerosis drug Avonex, can spend at least $2 billion to expand in the markets for drugs that treat cancer and neurological disorders, the Sueddeutsche Zeitung reported.
The Federal Trade Commission is extending an investigation of a $1.23 billion merger in the funeral home industry.

When BAE Systems, the British military contractor, announced last month that it was bowing out of its nearly 30-year relationship with Airbus, the split was greeted in Britain with shock, followed by nods of recognition of the kind that sometimes come when a long-married couple confide that they have grown apart.

Wachovia executives say the nation's fourth-largest bank is not planning to follow up its $24 billion acquisition of Golden West Financial with additional deals that are significant in size but will instead pursue small deals to supplement what it already has.

UBS' Peter Wuffli may turn what he calls his "wide-open radar screen" toward more potential takeover targets after buying a broker in the United States, a bank in Brazilian and a futures broker in Switzerland in a two-month, $3.6-billion spending spree.

Hankyu Holdings offered 392.1 billion yen ($3.5 billion) for Hanshin Electric Railway to combine the Osaka-based rail and retail companies, challenging investor Yoshiaki Murakami's attempt to take control of Hanshin.

After installing himself at the advertising giant Havas a year ago, the French investor Vincent Bolloré started accumulating a stake in a London-based advertising firm Aegis. This month, he proposed that two handpicked nominees be added to the Aegis board, the next step in an effort to exert more control over the company's management and, perhaps eventually, to push for some combination of Aegis and Havas.

Roman Abramovich, who doubles as Chelsea FC owner and Russia's richest oil oligarch, wants to become a steelman. Reports from Moscow yesterday said he is in talks to buy a 40 percent stake in Evraz Group, Russia's biggest steelmaker, for an estimated $3 billion. Last year he tried to persuade Alexander Abramov, who holds 59 percent of the equity, to sell the holding.

Both Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley are looking for a way to buy their way into mortgage lending, a business typically associated with retail banks, not Wall Street firms, Breakingviews reports. The two companies are on the lookout for smaller houses to beef up their capital-markets mortgages businesses. And Lehman Brothers, which has acquired five smaller mortgage businesses since 2003, has proved it can work.
BAA, the world's biggest airport operator, rejected a sweetened 9.73 billion-pound ($18.2 billion) takeover bid from the Spanish builder Grupo Ferrovial.

Despite immense resistance from Russia, the largest energy group in Poland has signed a deal to buy a majority stake in a Lithuanian oil refinery from a subsidiary of Yukos, the energy giant that was bankrupted by Kremlin tax claims.

In an effort to repel a hostile takeover bid from Mittal Steel, Arcelor agreed to sell a stake in the company to a Russian billionaire, Alexei Mordashov, but the deal could end up turning investors off instead.

If there was a question about whether potential conflicts would prompt investment bank Goldman Sachs to lower its profile in private equity investing, here is a $22 billion answer. The firm's buyout arm has a prominent role in Monday's proposed management-led buyout of Kinder Morgan, which, if it gets done, would be the largest leveraged buyout since Henry Kravis' private equity shop made its audacious run at RJR Nabisco in the late 1980's.
While visiting a water park, my family and I wore wrist bracelets with radio-frequency identification tags that took the place of both wallet and hotel room key.
"Rescue Me" has not stalled, in spite of the thud with which last season landed. It's still about a truculent Irish sinner and his life in flames.
John Allen Muhammad, who acted as his own attorney, is already under a death sentence in Virginia.
The F.B.I. today ended a search that began nearly two weeks ago on a suburban horse farm northwest of Detroit.
The attacks follow at least two other fatal attacks on aid workers in northern Afghanistan in recent weeks.
As Wall Street worried that the Fed may continue to raise interest rates, the Dow Jones dropped 1.6 percent today.
The third-seeded Nadia Petrova, one of the dominant figures on clay this season, did not make it past the first round at the French Open today.
The case, an appeal from Philip Morris, is expected to be an important test of constitutional standards set by the court for punitive damage awards.
The report finds reasons for optimism, but warns that the number of new infections is still rising in some countries.
Villagers rooting through rubble in central Java today said no relief agencies had made contact with them.
In its first major incursion into Gaza since last year's pullout, Israel tried a new tactic in its attempts to halt Palestinian rocket fire.
In a speech before delegates today, Eliot Spitzer promised to confront the culture of state government in Albany.
An F.B.I. raid on a congressman's office 10 days ago was heavily criticized today, with House members and witnesses saying it violated separation of powers rules in the Constitution.
Kimberly Dozier's condition was described as stable and responsive during the flight from Iraq.
About 150 masked youths wielding sticks and baseball bats fought with police in the worst violence since the unrest in November.
The Constitution does not always protect their free-speech rights for what they say on the job, justices said in a 5-4 ruling.

Volkswagen concluded a deal with the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade to open a factory in Russia, an agreement widely covered in newspapers on Tuesday as a sign of new and growing foreign investment.
The selection of Henry M. Paulson Jr. is a departure from Mr. Bush's initial reluctance to bring Wall Street executives into his administration.
The movement of a brigade comes as officials have raised doubts about possible troop reductions.
David Wright hit the game-winning single as the Mets won 8-7 before a crowd of 39,826 that endured two rain delays.
Dwyane Wade scored 12 of his 31 points in the fourth quarter, lifting the Heat to a victory and a 3-1 advantage in the series.
A man was fatally shot in the South Bronx last night about 8 o'clock, the police said.
Before starting at second base last night, José Valentín, a natural shortstop, had played 21 of his 1,530 career games there.

A woman died on Sunday night in a fire in her Upper West Side apartment, the police said. They said the fire started about 10 p.m. in Apartment 6H at 74 West 92nd Street, a 22-story building at Columbus Avenue.
Shortly after arriving for the state Democratic convention, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer excoriated the redevelopment of ground zero as "an Enron-style debacle."

A fast-moving fire broke out in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, killing a disabled woman and leaving her 1-year-old granddaughter in critical condition, their relatives and the police said. Both were victims of smoke inhalation, the police said.
By The Associated Press.
A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer Monday valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc.
As the summer travel season began, many Americans said they were looking for ways to cut their spending.
By Phoenix standards, the Suns were lethargic Sunday, with a playoff low 4 fast-break points, 88 total points, and 13 assists.
A deadly accident caused by a U.S. military convoy quickly touched off a full-blown anti-American riot.
The Hurricanes rallied to win 10 times after trailing by two or more goals this season. On Sunday, they stormed back from a 3-1 deficit to defeat the Buffalo Sabres.
A dispute in Massachusetts pits one of the nation's most powerful unions against one of the most successful companies.

HARTFORD, May 29 — Ned Lamont has already shown that his candidacy should be taken seriously. On May 19, a third of the delegates to the Democratic state convention voted to endorse him instead of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.

A court sentenced seven Islamist militants to death by hanging for killing two judges in a bomb attack in southern Jhalakati in November. The seven included Siddiqul Islam, who uses the nom de guerre Bangla Bhai and is the chief of the outlawed group Jagrata Muslim Janata Bangladesh, and Shaikh Abdur Rahman, the leader of Jamaat-ul-Mujahedeen, another banned Islamist militant group. Both groups demand Islamic rule in Bangladesh, a mainly Muslim democracy, and killed at least 30 people and wounded 150 in a spate of countrywide bomb attacks between August and December 2005.

Prime Minister Stephen Harper has reversed his decision to limit news coverage of the return of the bodies of Canadian soldiers killed in Afghanistan. Families of the soldiers may now decide whether the news media can watch the coffins being returned to a Canadian military base. The reversal came after the father of a Canadian soldier killed in Afghanistan criticized the government policy in his eulogy at her funeral, saying she "died to protect our freedoms, not to restrict them." Other critics had accused Mr. Harper of trying to blunt negative images that could damage public support for Canada's increasingly dangerous role in Afghanistan.

Congo said it was deporting 32 foreigners, including 3 Americans, that it charged last week with planning a coup before national elections in July, saying it would have taken too long to prosecute them. Officials said the men, who also included 10 Nigerians and 19 South Africans, worked as security guards and were found with weapons. The Americans' employer, AQMI Strategy Corp. of Orlando, Fla., said they were providing security and campaign consulting for a candidate in the elections and were not carrying any weapons. A United Nations spokesman in Kinshasa, the capital, has said the organization believes that the arrests are an attempt at political manipulation before the elections.

Morning commuters in Toronto, Canada's largest city, faced chaotic traffic jams when a strike by transit workers forced some 800,000 bus and subway users to seek alternative ways to work. News of the strike, set off by a plan to force maintenance workers to work overnight shifts, came late on Sunday, so many commuters were surprised to find locked subway stations yesterday morning. Picket lines were removed by midafternoon after the strike was ruled illegal by a labor relations board. Service was partly in place by the evening rush hour.

An Israeli helicopter fired a missile at Palestinian militants during a cross-border clash in northern Gaza, killing three and wounding four, Palestinian officials said. Islamic Jihad said the militants involved were its members. The Israeli military said the militants were about to launch rockets at Israel. Israeli forces also said they had foiled a suicide bombing, capturing two Palestinians carrying a bag with a bomb.

The European Union listed Sri Lanka's Tamil Tigers as a terrorist organization. The move will deprive the separatist rebel group of funds they collect from members and supporters in Europe. Sri Lanka's government had hoped a ban would force the rebels to the negotiating table, and the Europeans' move came just as the rebels had conditionally accepted an invitation to take part in talks in Norway next month. The United States, Britain and Canada have already listed the Tigers as a terrorist group.
In Marco Andretti, the Indy Racing League may have found a star in the making with a family name that is synonymous with speed.

A man died early yesterday after being shot near his home in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said. Marlon Bagot, 21, managed to ring the doorbell to his home at 28 Hampton Place before he collapsed about 11:30 p.m. on Sunday, the police said.

A TASTE OF SUMMER By tomorrow, the end of the Memorial Day holiday period, United States airlines will have carried 21 million passengers domestically and internationally since May 22, which the travel industry defines as the start of the holiday. The passenger count, an estimate from the Air Transport Association, will be almost 2 percent higher than last year's Memorial Day traffic record, mostly because of higher demand for international travel, the trade group says. The Transportation Security Administration, meanwhile, says it is gearing up to process a record 200 million air passengers during the peak summer travel season through Labor Day.

To the Editor: Re ''In the Quest for Coolness, Science Could Really Use a Vito Corleone'' (Essay, May 23): As a chemist, retired after 40 years in the field, I appreciate the efforts not only of scientists but also nonscientists to make the field attractive to the younger generation.

To the Editor: Although it is true that the scientific consensus for anthropogenic climate change has continued to strengthen, the results of numerous studies published in the past year are not qualitatively different from the conclusions published in the 1995 second assessment report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. We have, however, lost a decade of crucial time in which we could have started to address the problem of global warming; instead, politicians and pundits like Gregg Easterbrook worked hard to convince us that we should not act. The counter to this argument slips into his article when he admits that ''all air pollution problems of the past have cost significantly less to fix than critics projected.''

To the Editor: Abbas Amanat describes what the Bush administration fails to understand: United States policies toward Iran on the nuclear issue inflame Iranian nationalistic tendencies and unite Iranians behind a government that the majority despises. The theocracy in Iran has no agenda for governing; its legitimacy comes from the various international crises it can develop (first the hostage crisis, then the Iran-Iraq war and now the nuclear issue). As long as current United States policies toward Iran continue, the theocracy can blame the United States for the sorry state of its economy.

GIBBONS--Marie C. Age 82, of Summit, NJ, on May 25, 2006. Beloved wife for 50 years of the late Patrick J. Gibbons Jr. Loving mother of Christine Gibbons McKay and Patrick J. Gibbons III. Cherished grandmother of Andrew and John McKay and Aidan Gibbons. Dear sister of Elizabeth A. Cunningham. Mrs. Gibbons was an Alumna of Kent Place School and Vassar College, also an Emeritus Trustee of Kent Place School. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Teresa's Church, 306 Morris Ave, Summit, at 10:45 am, on Wednesday, May 31. Visitation on Tuesday, May 30, from 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at the Bradley - Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Ave, Summit. Private burial in Elka Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Kent Place School, Development Office, 42 Norwood Ave, Summit, NJ 07902-0308.

To the Editor: Re ''Finally Feeling the Heat,'' by Gregg Easterbrook (Op-Ed, May 24): So Mr. Easterbrook has finally decided to switch sides regarding global warming, ''from skeptic to convert.'' Well it's about time!

To the Editor: ''The Persian Complex,'' by Abbas Amanat (Op-Ed, May 25), is a fascinating peek into the modern Iranian mind-set. He outlines the identity of a nation still struggling against the perceived hegemony of great-power politics, both past and present.

To the Editor: We at Bronx Community College were dismayed by your depiction of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, the first hall of fame in America (''The All-American Pedestal Complex,'' Week in Review, May 21). To our campus, and especially our students, this historic structure stands as a symbol of the industry and achievement of American leaders. Visitors, historians, scholars, tourists, students, artists and architects come to admire the view from the highest point in the Bronx overlooking the Harlem River as well as the 98 exceptional bronze busts.
To the Editor: Lai-Sheng Wang's shape could easily be mistaken for a Wangdoodle, but its solid gold construction clearly makes it a Wangspangle. Lisa Wallerstein Livermore, Calif.

JACOBS--Louis. Age 88, of Bridgeport, CT, on May 29, 2006. Beloved husband of Shirley Wurtzel Jacobs, devoted father of Douglas & Mary Jacobs, Robert & Nomi Jacobs, Gail & Dan Leitman, Patty & Michael Kaplowitz, Fran Jacobs, and adoring grandfather of ten.

'X-Men' Cleans Up ''X-Men: The Last Stand'' hauled in an estimated $120.12 million at the box office over the four-day Memorial Day weekend, though its three-day gross was revised yesterday to $103.12 million from $107 million by the tracking company Exhibitor Relations. That total left ''X-Men'' (Fox), starring Halle Berry, Hugh Jackman, Rebecca Romijn, right, and Ian McKellen, far ahead of ''The Da Vinci Code'' (Sony), which took in $43 million for four days and $34 million for three. The third-place finisher was ''Over the Hedge'' (DreamWorks), with $35.34 million and $26.87 million, followed by ''Mission: Impossible III'' (Paramount), with $8.56 million and $6.69 million, and ''Poseidon'' (Warner Brothers), with $7 million and $5.53 million. The cumulative total, $228.58 million, amassed by the Top 12 films made this four-day Memorial Day weekend the second biggest, behind 2004 ($236.67 million). More New York Art for Berlin Buoyed by the spectacular success of a 2004 exhibition of 200 masterpieces from the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the New National Gallery in Berlin has announced plans for a major exhibition next year of 19th- and 20th-century art from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Agence France-Presse reported. The show, ''Metro,'' from May 30 to Oct. 7, 2007, will present nearly 150 paintings by masters including van Gogh, Renoir, Monet, Manet, Pissarro, Delacroix, Toulouse-Lautrec, Picasso and Modigliani, as well as Rodin sculptures, among them ''The Burghers of Calais,'' right. The 2004 exhibition attracted 1.2 million visitors from all over Europe and remained open around the clock during its final days. Discussing the 2007 exhibition, Peter Raue, chairman of the Friends of the New National Gallery, said, ''We are, of course, again hoping for many, many visitors and will do everything to ensure that the lines are as short as possible.'' 16th-Century Sting Sting, below, will go time-tripping to the 16th century for his next album. What's more, it will be issued on a classical label, Deutsche Grammophon, in October. The focal instrument is the lute. On his Web site, Sting.com, he said that about two years ago he received a lute as a gift from the Argentine guitarist Dominic Miller, ''and I sort of became fascinated with it and immersed myself in the lute and lute music.'' He added: ''It reminded of an interest I've had for a long time -- for almost 25 years -- in the works of John Dowland. John Dowland was a 16th-century English composer who wrote songs for the lute. He was really the first singer-songwriter that we know of, and so a lot of us owe our living to this man.'' From this came the idea of an album of Dowland music. ''It's a strange record, a delightful record and I think people will be intrigued by it,'' Sting said. Silencing James Blunt One radio station has had enough of the chart-topping British rocker James Blunt, below, Agence France-Presse reported. Responding to listeners who said they were fed up with hearing ''You're Beautiful'' and ''Goodbye My Lover,'' Essex FM in southern England has banned his songs. ''We don't have anything against James Blunt, and we're pleased he has been so successful, but we really need a break,'' said Chris Cotton, the program director. He noted that the music industry pressures radio stations to play the music of certain performers over and over again. ''We're happy to stand up to this pressure and follow the strong message listeners have given us,'' Mr. Cotton said. ''We encourage other radio stations to take the same step.'' Ice Cube's Oprah Complaint Ice Cube has joined the chorus of rappers complaining that Oprah Winfrey has no use for hip-hop, The Associated Press reported. In an interview in the July issue of FHM magazine, to be published on June 6, Ice Cube, right, said, ''I've been involved in three projects pitched to her, but I've never been asked to participate.'' He added that she has had rapists, child molesters and ''lying authors'' on her show. ''If I'm not a rags-to-riches story for her, who is?'' Ludacris and 50 Cent have also been critical. A spokesman for Ms. Winfrey's production company, Harpo, told The A.P. that she would not respond directly to Ice Cube's remarks. Earlier this month, in a surprise appearance on the New York radio station WWPR-FM, known as Power 105.1, Ms. Winfrey said, ''I've been accused of not liking hip-hop, and that's just not true.'' Handke Prize Stirs Debate Does the avant-garde Austrian author Peter Handke deserve the $50,000 Heinrich Heine Prize for literature, or should he be disqualified because of his sympathies for the Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic, who died in March in The Hague while on trial for genocide and war crimes? Fritz Kuhn, a parliamentary leader of the Green Party in Germany, said it would be a ''scandal'' to honor Mr. Handke, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Kuhn urged the city of Düsseldorf, the sponsor of the award, to overrule the jury. But Joseph Kruse, director of the Heinrich Heine Institute, who described Mr. Handke as ''increasingly lost,'' said it might be counterproductive to ''treat him as though he has the plague.'' The prize is to be awarded on Dec. 13 but must first be confirmed in June by the Düsseldorf authorities. Last month the Comédie-Française, citing his Milosevic support, canceled plans to produce a Handke play.

To the Editor: ''A Career That Has Mirrored Psychiatry's Twisting Path'' (May 23) nicely depicts my friend and colleague, Tom McGlashan, from Chestnut Lodge. I'll never forget his Lodge Symposium pronouncement about the ''grand experiment'' there: ''The data are in; the experiment failed.''

To the Editor: I was taken aback by the May 17 letter from Shashi Tharoor, United Nations under secretary general for communications and public information (''U.N. Is Best Hope to End Darfur Killing'').

Three years ago, Christopher Exline, a Dallas businessman, decided to open a branch of his furniture-rental company in Baghdad after he saw all the looting there on TV. ''I witnessed all of these liberated Iraqis embarking on their own redecorating schemes by looting the palace and office buildings,'' said Mr. Exline, who is chief executive officer of Home Essentials, which leases furniture to employees of government agencies and private companies in Iraq. ''I realized that any good furniture that did exist was now gone.''

To the Editor: Gregg Easterbrook's suggestions for action to mitigate climate change, while creative and promising, involve only a small minority of elite entrepreneurs. To confront climate change now and other environmental concerns in the future, we must engage the entire American public.

BARBIERI--Dolores. August 7, 1947, died May 29, 2006. She was the beloved life partner of Lucille Ferrari; daughter to Marie and the late Robert Barbieri; devoted sister and aunt; and adored friend of many. Dolores was Asst Commissioner of the NYC Dept of Transportation, and previously served as the Dir of Community Boards for the Bklyn Boro President's Ofc. Dolores also held positions with the NYC DEP & DCAS. She graduated from Pace Univ and held a Masters in Planning from Pratt Inst. Dolores touched the lives of everyone she knew. Her love flowed from the shores of Brooklyn, New York to the Grand Canal of Venice, Italy. She was and always will be our Angel. Viewing Tues 7-9 pm; Wed 2-5 and 7-9 pm at Guido's Funeral Home, 440 Clinton St, Bklyn, NY 11231 (718-852-2324). Funeral Mass Thurs. a.m. at St. Mary Star of the Sea Church, 467 Court St, Bklyn, NY 11231. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to Gilda's Club NYC, 502 8th Ave, Bklyn, NY 11215.

Q. If gorillas more closely resemble humans than chimpanzees do, at least in some features like teeth, why do scientists think humans are closer to chimps? A. ''Doing this comparison between humans and modern apes is not particularly helpful because we have all changed so much in the millions of years since the species diverged,'' said the paleoanthropologist Tim White of the University of California, Berkeley.

ENLANDER--Caron. She was a rare gem herself. We are deeply saddened by her passing. Our condolences to her adored and adoring husband, Derek, and the family. Wendy Brandes and Paul Steiger $(6$)ENLANDER -- Caron. You went too soon. We shall all miss you. The Walking Group

KENISTON--Dr. Ellen U. Of Cambridge, MA, psychologist and psychotherapy supervisor, died in her home on May 24, at age 73. She held academic appointments at Yale University, Tufts New England Medical Center Department of Child Psychiatry, and Harvard Medical School where, since 1989, she was a psychotherapy supervisor in the Victims of Violence Program. She was committed to peace and social justice. She is survived by her longtime partner, Brenda Steinberg; her daughters Ann and Sarah Keniston and their husbands Eric Novak and Brian Iler; and her grandchildren, Jessica, Jeremy, Paul, Rachel, and Jason. A memorial service will be held later this summer. Donations in her name to Doctors Without Borders and Planned Parenthood.
DIAMOND - Beatrice. Died May 29. Retired head bookkeeper of Sterling National Bank where she worked for 47 years. Predeceased by husband Lawrence Diamond.

LEVIN--Walter. 75, died on May 27 in Syracuse. Loving husband of the late Rachel (nee Farhi). Father of Robert, David and Laurie Katz; stepfather of Gary Bromberg and Janice Albin; grandfather of Justin, Zachary, Crystal, DeElva, Jennifer, Melissa and Jason; great-grandfather of Charles, Ryan and Christian; brother of Muriel Mandell; uncle of Mark and Jonathan Mandell and Bruce Segerman. Longtime active member of the Smith Sherman Lodge #

JACCOMA--George E. Formerly of Larchmont, NY, died at Connecticut Hospice on May 20 of cancer. He was 72. George's career in advertising spanned over 50 years, during which time he won numerous awards in art direction. At Grey Advertising he introduced the split screen in a Ford Pinto commercial many years before computer graphics. At J. Walter Thompson he named and art directed the Kibbles & Bits commercials for Quaker Oats. In 1987 George honored a dream and became a partner at Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell Advertising. His wife Lorraine, son Larry, daughter Lisa, daughter-in-law Elizabeth, and grandsons Christopher and Shaun survive him. A memorial service will take place at St. John's Episcopal in Larchmont on Wednesday, May 31, at 10 AM.

Adored grandmother of Marisa and Gregory Warren. Loyal sister to Donald G. Wolff. Daughter of the late Milton and Gertrude Wolff of Woodmere, LI. Services at Star of David Cemetery, 7701 Bailey Rd., N. Lauderdale, FL, Wednesday, May 31st, at 11:45 AM. In her memory, contributions may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486.

To the Editor: Bob Herbert paints a grim picture for American workers in ''Laid Off and Left Out'' (column, May 25). The fact of the matter is that the Bush administration cuts taxes for the wealthy, claiming that this creates jobs. Unfortunately, the wealthy then turn around and cut American jobs, moving them overseas.

As the N.B.A. playoffs continued, the basketball-laden TNT once again topped cable's rankings in prime time for the week that ended on May 21. ESPN was also boosted by basketball's postseason, placing third for the week, behind USA Network. That Top 3 -- TNT, USA and ESPN -- was the same across the 18-to-49 and 18-to-34 demographics. ESPN's May 19 Dallas Mavericks-San Antonio Spurs game was the most-watched program of the week, with 5.59 million viewers. Earlier in the week a matchup of the same teams on TNT brought in 5.42 million, making it the No. 2 attraction. USA's WWE wrestling placed third. The 10 p.m. edition of ''Monday Night Raw'' delivered an audience of 5.04 million, which was a better showing than its 9 p.m. hour (4.78 million). In the rankings, sandwiched between the two hours of WWE, was a primetime special of Nickelodeon's ''Fairly Odd Parents'' (5.03 million), in which Timmy's fairies had to compete in an ''American Idol''-style singing competition. KATE AURTHUR

The German Historical Museum in Berlin is to open its first permanent exhibition, ''German History and Testimonials From Two Millennia,'' on June 3. About 8,000 objects will testify to 2,000 years of German politics, struggles and developments in the context of European history. The museum director, Hans Ottomeyer, in charge of the project since 2000, said in a recent interview with the news magazine Der Spiegel that the exhibition is ''like an open book that wants to show all chapters of German history.'' The Nazi era will occupy almost a third of the overall exhibition space, spread across two floors of the former Prussian armory building. On display for the first time will be Hitler's desk, which the Russians removed from the burning chancellery in 1945. Other objects will include a mask from the battle of Varus (A.D. 9), where Germanic tribes defeated the Romans, and a portrait of Charlemagne by Albrecht Dürer. The plan for a national historical exhibition was formed in 1987 when Helmut Kohl was chancellor. SARAH PLASS

To the Editor: Re ''Restrictions on City Lobbying Ignore Loophole, Critics Say'' (news article, May 24): As the only private lobbyist to testify before the City Council in favor of its current lobbying reform efforts, I am sorry that the Council overlooked what is easily the most egregious loophole in the lobbying laws: the legality of council members' close relatives serving as lobbyists.

To the Editor: Gregg Easterbrook's sudden climate-science conversion and call for greenhouse-gas rationing represents a small step forward and a huge step back. Accepting the science of climate change has never been the real debate: there are, and always have been, reputable scientists, economists and policy analysts who accept mainstream climate science while arguing for affordable adaptive policies and additional research as the most rational policy response to the threat of climate change.

A long-shot challenger to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is highlighting the senator's support of the Iraq war by introducing a resolution here this week at the state Democratic convention calling for the withdrawal of all troops. The proposed resolution caused a stir among the delegates, many of whom are opposed to the war, but wary of doing anything that would embarrass Senator Clinton.

Volcano Threatens Indonesian Area Struck by Earthquake Substantial amounts of aid are arriving in the area of Indonesia hardest hit by Saturday's earthquake, which killed about 5,000 people and injured 15,000. But a nearby volcano that has been threatening the region has greatly increased its activity. PAGE A8 Deputy in Line at C.I.A. After clashes with aides to Porter J. Goss, Stephen R. Kappes resigned from the clandestine service at the Central Intelligence Agency about 18 months ago. But with Mr. Goss now gone, Mr. Kappes is poised to return to the agency as deputy director under Gen. Michael V. Hayden. The move, General Hayden said, would be a signal that ''amateur hour'' is over at the C.I.A. PAGE A17 Intelligence in Space As space missions become longer and more ambitious, communicating with the craft becomes tougher. Engineers are looking at artificial intelligence, developing a craft that could think for itself and execute commands without waiting for mission control. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1 Fleet Follows a City's Changes Unlike sailors of decades past, many of the young Navy men and women who stream off the West Side piers in their crisp summer whites for shore leave have plans more refined than carousing and tattoos. If their adventures are a bit tamer, they do not lack for variety. PAGE B1 England's Dreams Renewed Amid the large personalities, the even larger paychecks, the outfits, the injuries, the tantrums and the expectations lies a sobering reality: England has won soccer's World Cup only once, 40 years ago. PAGE D1 Disbelief on a Marine Base At Camp Pendleton, Calif., a Marine Corps ''company town,'' there is no shortage of people, both military and civilian, who are willing to give the benefit of the doubt to the American troops accused of the unjustified killings of civilians last November in Haditha, Iraq. PAGE A11 Slime of Frog Casts a Spell A tribal cure in Brazil, derived from the secretions of a poisonous tree frog, raises hope of a wonder drug that might benefit the country's indigenous people as well as its drug industry. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 14 Die in Afghan Riot After Crash of U.S. Truck A traffic accident caused by a United States military convoy that killed five people escalated into an anti-American riot that raged across Kabul, the Afghan capital, leaving at least 14 people dead and scores injured. Witnesses said American soldiers fired on Afghans throwing stones at them after the crash, though the United States military said only that warning shots had been fired in the air. A1 More Reserve Troops to Iraq The top American commander in Iraq has decided to move reserve troops now deployed in Kuwait into the volatile Anbar Province in western Iraq to help quell a surge in insurgent attacks there, two American officials said. A1 Two Britons working as members of a CBS News television crew were killed and an American correspondent for the network was critically wounded when a military patrol they were accompanying was hit by a roadside bomb. The police said at least 31 other people were killed in one of the worst days of bloodshed in the capital for weeks. A10 Support for Haditha Accused Denial and utter disbelief are the overwhelming reaction in Camp Pendleton, California, to reports of the killings in Haditha, Iraq, involving marines based at the camp. If there is any truth to the accusations, some say, then the troops must have been acting on direct orders, responding as they were trained to do. A11 Volcano Destabilized by Quake Significant amounts of aid began arriving in Bantul, the town hit the hardest by an earthquake on Saturday, but Mount Merapi, a nearby volcano, has increased its threatening activity. Volcanologists said the quake destabilized a dome at the mountain's peak, which if it collapses, would set off a large eruption of lava, rocks and hot gas. A8 Israeli Policy Debate in Britain Britain's biggest association of higher education instructors decided to urge its 67,000 members to consider boycotting Israeli academics who failed to renounce what it called Israel's ''apartheid policies'' in the West Bank and Gaza. A11 Call for Tiananmen Reparations A group of 126 people whose relatives died in the suppression of the June 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen Square issued a joint appeal to reassess the incident and compensate victims, even as Chinese authorities worked to stop any commemorations of it as the anniversary approaches. A8 Corruption Behind Brazil Unrest Fighting in São Paolo, Brazil between the police and criminal gangs that left at least 168 people dead has ceased, at least for now. The cause of the outbreak is what political leaders, lawyers and human rights groups describe as endemic corruption in law enforcement agencies and prisons. A3 NATIONAL A12-17 Identity Thieves Carve A Niche in Phoenix The Phoenix area has the highest rate of identity theft complaints in the nation, according to the Federal Trade Commission. In an economy that runs increasingly on the instantaneous flow of information and credit, the area provides a window into one of the system's unintended consequences. A1 FedEx Drivers Look to Unionize FedEx drivers in Massachusetts are looking to join the Teamsters, pitting one of the most powerful unions against a hugely successful company, where none of its 60,000 drivers is unionized. A12 Bush Invokes the Fallen President Bush paid homage to fallen members of the nation's military, using his annual Memorial Day speech at Arlington National Cemetery to draw a link among those who fought in an earlier era and those killed in Iraq and Afghanistan. A12 Pelosi Becomes a Target Some optimistic Democratic lawmakers, hoping to win a Congressional majority in November, have taken to referring to Representative Nancy Pelosi as ''speaker,'' as in speaker of the House. So have some optimistic Republicans. A1 New Scrutiny of Lawmaker Testimony in the trial of David H. Safavian, left, a former White House budget aide accused of lying about his contacts with the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, is expected to result in new scrutiny of Representative Bob Ney, an Ohio Republican caught up in the scandal. A15 Church Leaders Offer Amends Cardinal Sean P. O'Malley is leading a nine-day series of Masses and services to acknowledge sexual abuse by clergy members in the Archdiocese of Boston and to pray for forgiveness and healing. A14 Possible Return to the C.I.A. With Porter J. Gross being forced out as the C.I.A.'s director, Stephen R. Kappes is poised to become deputy director under Gen. Michael V. Hayden, making him the first person since 1973 to ascend to one of the agency's top two positions from a career spent in the clandestine service. A17 EDUCATION No Diploma, No Problem Many colleges are accepting students who have not graduated from high school or earned equivalency degrees. And it's fueling a debate over whether the students should be in college at all and whether state financial aid should pay their way. A1 OBITUARIES C11 George Field The guiding spirit of Freedom House, an organization dedicated to democracy and human rights, he was 101. C11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 9/11 Collectors Search For Permanent Archives Steven Rosenbaum, left, is one of the many collectors of 9/11 materials struggling with financing and the need to find a permanent home for their collections and electronic archives. B1 Sailors Take Shore Leave The Navy men and women who visited New York for Memorial Day experienced a very different, lower decibel shore leave than the one experienced by the thousands of sailors who have come before them over the decades. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Mice Ignore Mendel's Laws A perplexing strain of brown laboratory mice have white feet and white-spotted tails because of a genetic defect engineered into a gene that controls pigmentation, a gene that ignores Mendelian laws of inheritance, a group of researchers report. F3 Twin Births Tied to Dairy American women who eat dairy products appear to be five times as likely to give birth to fraternal twins than those who do not, according to a new study, and one explanation may be dairy products from cows injected with synthetic growth hormone. F7 Health & Fitness F5 ARTS E1-8 Treasure Stolen in Turkey Objects from the treasure of King Croesus, a collection that the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York returned to Turkey in 1993 after a legal battle, have been stolen from the Archeological Museum in Usak, Turkish authorities say. Kinder announced a $22 billion private offer to buy Kinder Morgan Inc., the pipeline giant that he founded in 1997. The deal would be the largest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. bought RJR Nabisco in 1989 for $25 billion. C1 Travelers Cut Back on Spending As the summer travel season began, Americans were jamming highways and filling airports. But in some small ways, with possibly large consequences, many travelers said they were cutting their spending. A1 Hispanics New Phone Target Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. It was a busy evening for Charlie King. The attorney general candidate spent a considerable amount of time walking through the Hyatt Hotel in Buffalo, trying to persuade convention delegates to support his campaign's effort to suspend the rules and allow all five candidates for that office onto the ballot. Mr. King's aides have acknowledged that their candidate is far short of the 25 percent of the delegate vote needed for an automatic spot on the September primary ballot. Aside from that effort, there is a split in the King campaign as to what to tell the roughly 10 percent of the delegates already committed to Mr. King. The candidate himself is said to favor freeing them to vote for their second choices. So far, the only candidate who is widely expected to get more than 25 percent is Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary and son of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

Before making his second consecutive start at second base last night against the Arizona Diamondbacks, José Valentín had played 21 of his 1,530 career games there, his least comfortable position. ''I'm not saying I'm scared of playing there or anything,'' said Valentín, who had two hits, including a home run, and three runs batted in in the Mets' 8-7 victory. ''I'm just not used to it.''

There's Elizabeth Taylor, pretty in pink, and beside her Nancy Reagan, elegant in white, wearing a cautious version of her adoring-wife gaze. Ms. Taylor looks pleased, too. It is 1987, and at her invitation, six years into the AIDS epidemic, President Ronald Reagan is making his first -- and, as it turned out, only -- speech on the subject. The scene is from ''The Age of AIDS,'' a gripping (eventually) two-part, four-hour ''Frontline'' documentary that begins tonight on PBS. It doesn't offer a lot of movie star scenes like that, but it's loaded with drama. The most bizarre juxtaposition has to be Bono, of the rock group U2, quoting Scripture to Senator Jesse Helms.
