8 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING -- Did you hear about the one about the comedian who went down with the ship? In this season premiere, aspiring comics find that seas can be rocky even when the boat is docked. This time around, funny types undertake outrageous tasks before celebrity judges including (above, from left, Tim Meadows, Kathy Griffin and Garry Marshall) while living on the Queen Mary, the luxury liner, in Long Beach, Calif. The punch line belongs to the viewers: they choose the winner, who gets a talent contract with NBC and a comedy special on Bravo. 9 P.M. (Food Network) GRILL GIRLS -- Put away the man-size utensils. Forget ''Kill It and Grill It.'' Female chefs across the country are seizing the tongs. 9 P.M. (National Geographic) MONEY FACTORY -- This documentary looks at the making and faking of the dollar bill, and the masterminds behind both. The moral: Accept no imitations. 9 P.M. (13, 49) FRONTLINE ''The Age of AIDS.'' On the 25th anniversary of the first diagnosed cases of AIDS, this two-part special examines its cost, in lives and liberties, while looking at the lessons of the past and the obstacles ahead. 9 P.M. (11) PEPPER DENNIS -- Pepper (Rebecca Romijn, right) and Charlie try to talk a football star into coming out in a big way. Meanwhile, the famously licentious Liz Phair performs at Chick's high-school reunion. 9 P.M. (Discovery Channel) DEADLIEST CATCH -- Freezing temperatures, 40-foot waves, shimmying crab pots the size of Volkswagens, and an injury rate of nearly 100. That's life for Alaskan crab fishermen. In this episode, the weather claims the life of a deck hand on the Cornelia Marie, while the Time Bandit navigates the northern ice pack. 9:45 (SUN) TREE OFFICER -- Imagine ''The Office'' set in a forest. In Neil Jack's stop-animation short, a tree-hugging bureaucrat wrestles with his mandate: to give the objects of his affection the ax. 10 P.M. (National Geographic) INSIDE NCIS -- You may know it as a Mark Harmon TV series. But the Naval Criminal Investigative Service is real. This documentary travels from crime scene to laboratory to classroom - and looks at some of the agency's most challenging cases, like the 2000 bombing of the U.S.S. Cole - to see how it deals with 21st-century danger. 10 P.M. (FX) RESCUE ME -- Tommy (Denis Leary, left), the firefighter and madman who needs the anger management version of the Heimlich Maneuver, finds coping mechanisms for the death of his son in this season premiere. You know: Drinking. Black humor. Rage. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
A headline with an article in some copies on Sunday about the arrest of two men in the fatal stabbing of a Bronx man misidentified the location of the crime. It was Manhattan, not the Bronx.
An article on Sunday about the Washington 2006 World Philatelic Exhibition gave an incorrect issue date in some copies for a rare stamp known to collectors as the ''Z-grill.'' It is 1868, not 1867.

Shortly after landing here to take part in the state Democratic convention, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer excoriated the redevelopment of ground zero as ''an Enron-style debacle'' and laid the blame on the leadership of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and Gov. George E. Pataki. His comments were his harshest yet on the matter, and came a day before he is expected to receive the endorsement of the Democratic party leadership to be the next governor. They also came on a day that saw considerable maneuvering among the Democratic candidates to replace him as attorney general.
To the Editor: Dr. Wang may want to consider Midaspheres. Stuart M. Ellerstein Princeton, N.J.

OFFER FOR KINDER MORGAN -- A group led by Richard D. Kinder announced a buyout offer valued at $22 billion for Kinder Morgan Inc., the parent of the pipeline giant he founded in 1997. The deal, which includes the assumption of about $8 billion in debt, would be the largest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company bought RJR Nabisco in 1989 for $25 billion. [Page C1.] TWO IN NEWS CREW KILLED -- Two Britons working as members of a CBS News television crew were killed on Monday and an American correspondent for the network, Kimberly Dozier, was critically wounded when a military patrol they were accompanying was hit by a roadside bomb. [A1.] THE BATTLE FOR AIR -- Americans are increasingly recognizing that the effects of carbon emissions on global warming are a serious problem, but there are no rules in the United States regulating heat-trapping gases comparable to those that most other developed countries have adopted under the Kyoto Protocol. Some United States businesses, though, are responding for a variety of reasons anyway: to satisfy customers or shareholders who worry about the environment, to improve their public image or to drive down their energy costs. In addition, some states and local authorities have stepped in to try to curb their contributions to global warming. [C1.] A STEEL WAR -- When it came to repelling a hostile takeover bid from Mittal Steel, Arcelor left no stone unturned as it searched for a poison-pill partner. But some critics say that the solution -- a deal that gives more than a third of Arcelor to a Russian billionaire, Aleksei Mordashov, left, may leave a bitter aftertaste. If it is approved by the shareholders, the agreement will put Russian executives in crucial management positions at Arcelor, raising questions about integration between the two corporate cultures, and concerns among some shareholders about what role the Russian government may want to play. [C3.] HISPANIC CALLERS -- Now that nearly three out of four people in this country have mobile phone service, cellphone companies are chasing new customers by marketing to ever more specific slices of the population. But one group is getting extra attention: Hispanics. And there is ample reason for the carriers' attention. One of the country's fastest growing demographic groups, Hispanics often have large families that span international borders, making for larger phone bills. [C1.] THAT 60'S SHOW -- AMC cable television network is considering a series that would explore how Madison Avenue remakes itself to meet the changing needs of clients as consumers and the media undergo transformation. So the show would be a reality series, right? Not exactly. It is fictional, a drama about the advertising industry circa 1960. In another example of how the more things change the more they remain the same, if AMC decides to pick up the series, each episode may be sponsored by a single advertiser -- just as was done in 1960. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C7.] A SUMMER OF HIGH GAS PRICES -- As the summer travel season began in earnest this past weekend, Americans were indulging their wanderlust, jamming highways, and filling airports, motels and eateries. But in some small ways, with possibly large consequences for the health of the economy, travelers interviewed across the country over the weekend said they were cutting their spending and downsizing their plans for summer trips. [A1.] A MOVE IN EUROPE -- When BAE Systems, the British military contractor, announced that it was bowing out of its nearly 30-year relationship with Airbus, the split was greeted in Britain with shock at first, followed by recognition that the companies had grown apart. BAE's departure now could be transformational not only for it, but also for Airbus, whose ownership -- and decision-making -- structure is evolving. [C4.] BRIGHT SPOT FOR G.M. -- Four years ago, Daewoo Motor was the biggest and ugliest addition to South Korea's junkyard of bankrupt companies. Its parent conglomerate had collapsed, and most potential investors were intimidated by its militant labor union. Its founder, Kim Woo Choong, left, is on trial on corruption charges linked to the disintegration of his conglomerate in 1998. But Mr. Kim is gone, and Daewoo has become a bright spot for G.M. [C4.] AIRLINE APOLOGIZES -- WestJet Airlines agreed on Monday to pay 15.5 million Canadian dollars ($14 million) to settle accusations of spying on an internal Web site of its rival, Air Canada. The settlement, which came with an apology, brought to an end two years of litigation. [C9.] THE OPEC MEETING -- Most delegates at this week's meeting of OPEC are expected to nod politely to Venezuela's calls for output cuts that could drive prices even higher, while doing the opposite by reaping all they can from the current bonanza of high prices. The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates rejected talk of a possible cut in the cartel's output quotas of 28 million barrels a day. [C1.] A SOFTWARE BATTLE IN CHINA -- Responding to years of intensive international lobbying, the Chinese government has introduced measures offering the potential to curb widespread piracy and increase revenue for software companies. The Business Software Alliance estimates that more than 90 percent of the software in China is unlicensed. [C3.] A NEW TAX COMPLAINT -- In an effort to raise revenues, tax writers in Congress added a last-minute provision that increased taxes for Americans living abroad. But the sudden imposition of taxes has surprised overseas taxpayers, and it has employers concerned about the added cost. [C3.] PAYING WITH ATTENTION -- With the cost of mobile phone calls already dropping sharply, Virgin Mobile USA plans to announce a way that people can talk for no money at all. They will, however, have to pay with a chunk of their attention. [C4.] FROG POWER -- A tribal cure in Brazil, derived from the secretions of a poisonous tree frog, raises hope of a wonder drug that might benefit the country's indigenous people as well as its drug industry [C1.] GLOBAL SECURITY -- In an increasingly global economy, more business travelers find themselves visiting places that, if not as obviously dangerous as Baghdad or Kabul, are unfamiliar and possibly treacherous. And a number of risk management and security firms are providing services to help them, and say their business is growing. [C8.]

To the Editor: Abbas Amanat seems to be a strong believer in the ''two wrongs make a right'' school of international relations. He argues, in essence, that because Iran has been oppressed and humiliated by foreign powers in the past, we should now sit back and accept the inevitability of Iran's drive toward what he naïvely refers to as ''nuclear energy.'' I, for one, hardly see how Iran's development of nuclear bombs will accomplish any moral reconciliation whatsoever. John McIntosh Salt Lake City, May 25, 2006

Call me a geek, but if a genie appeared before me and offered me a wish, here's what I'd wish for: detailed descriptions of at least 127 other randomly chosen planets in the galaxy, of which 63 would be home to life.This may sound greedy (wishes usually do). After all, life on earth holds uncountable mysteries. Here's one that puzzles me: Why is it that no birds have evolved pregnancy? Representatives of all the other major groups of backboned animals, from guppies to skinks, have evolved to give birth - why not birds? It would surely be better for an emperor penguin to give birth than to play ice hockey with its egg. Another: Can you alter the odds of conceiving a son or a daughter by altering how often and when you have sex? Tentative evidence suggests you might be able to - but the data are deeply unclear. And how about this: What, apart from thinking, does the sperm whale use its head for? A sperm whale's head makes up about one third of its body length, and much of the space is taken up by something called the spermaceti organ - but despite much speculation (is it acoustical? A battering ram?), no one knows exactly what this does.

Because some very interesting and valid comments continue to come in on the Michael Schumacher affair in two or three posts below, I thought that I had better post some of the details from the report of the race stewards on that qualifying incident. Rather than doing it in the two or three comments areas below where the incident is being discussed, I thought I'd do it as a new post.

Despite our distaste for the faux-viral video as an advertising form, it has to be said that some of the skills shown off in the Nike ads -- currently in heavy rotation on Fox Soccer Channel here in the U.S. and, apparently, just about everywhere else on the planet too -- are pretty amazing to watch. But rather than watching the blurry YouTube versions of these clips that have been arriving in your e-mail in-box for weeks now, or fighting your way through the various layers of sales pitches on the Nikefootball.com Web site, there is an easy way to get higher-quality versions to watch on your computer, or video iPod. The iTunes music store is offering all these "Joga Bonita" videos free, either a la carte or on a subscription basis. Look for the "Nike Football Videocast" there under Podcasts and enjoy at your leisure. Of particular note: Sweden's Zlatan Ibrahimovic juggling gum and engaging in a dribbling duel with Portugal's Cristiano Ronaldo -- that's the Ronaldo named after Ronald Reagan.
The Times's Andrew C. Revkin discusses several new scientific papers that say the Arctic was possibly far warmer than we thought 55 million years ago. (Produced by Erik Olsen)

In 2002, people in the United States who followed the World Cup did not have to worry about missing time at work because the games, played in South Korea and Japan, were on TV in the middle of the night. Millions gladly missed sleep, and then had to drag themselves out of bed and trudge to work. With the tournament in Germany this year, the time difference means that the games will be played in the middle of the day in the United States.

Reuters reports that Iran fought back from a two-goal deficit to beat Bosnia 5-2 in Tehran today. If you listen to Reuters, the match "raised serious questions about their defence." But if you get your news from the Mehr News Agency in Iran, you'll be reassured to know that "Bosnia & Herzegovina was bamboozled by Iran." Even less worried will be readers relying on Martin Reza Babry of Persianfootball.com who witnessed an "impressive comeback" by "a depleted Iranian team" who managed to "thrash Bosnia ... without their influential Bundesliga midfield trio." But this was all reported after the event. Here at the Times, thanks to a Farsi-speaker on staff, we got a full description of the game much earlier, apparently transmitted live through the ether as it was in progress, thanks to the match-tracking feature of the Iran Sports Network's Web site. - R.M./J.K.
Ordinarily, I don't rile easily. I try to keep life's annoyances in perspective. Or, to quote an old chestnut of my mom's: "Five years from now, will it matter?"

In a thought-provoking column published today on Times Select, our colleague Roger Cohen looks at the "Playing Field as Symbol for Global Conversation" and finds that the beautiful game, far from offering us distraction from weighty issues like "war, politics, economics and philosophy," often becomes a focus for all of these concerns. Speaking of war, Roger explains that

Spain has some excellent World Cup sites, well worth exploring even if you don't speak or read Spanish. Two leading Madrid newspapers, El Mundo and El Pais, often win international awards for their graphics. El Pais's World Cup site has, among many intriguing animations, this look at the history of the Spanish national team's uniform. Note that the only period when Spain did not dress in red was 1941-47. More on that in a post about soccer among the Axis powers, coming soon to this blog. (How's that for a tease?)

Inman News has introduced TurnHere, a Web site of video-ettes about neighborhoods and travel destinations. They've been making these films for months now, and they vary in quality, from good to great.

Investors who were betting on a sale for Extendicare got an unhappy surprise. The Canadian nursing home operator, which said in February that it would consider various alternatives for boosting its share price, unveiled a reorganization plan on Wednesday that did not include selling the company.

Redfin, the Seattle-based online real estate broker, said it won $8 million in financing from Paul Allen's Vulcan Capital venture fund and several other firms. It's the latest example of how serious amounts of money are flowing to companies that are changing the way real estate is bought and sold.
John Spencer just drew 63.48% of the Republican convention vote, making him the party's designee to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Whoa--so Canon is ceasing development in its film-camera business. It's joining Kodak, Nikon and Konica Minolta, each of which has completely or mostly exited the film-camera business.
Gov. George E. Pataki wasted no time this morning going after the Democrats' pick to replace him, State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.

The Times today carried an op-ed about Darfur that has all of us who have been banging the drums about the genocide there gnashing our teeth. Basically, the essay argues that the slaughter in Darfur is much more complex than it appears, that there are no good guys, and that well-meaning Westerners (like me) are only prolonging the genocide by calling for military intervention.
Another week, another Enron-related verdict. The latest one is only a partial victory for prosecutors, though.
Less than a day after it was announced, Mirant's hostile bid for NRG Energy is getting even more so.
Bill Weld just rolled out his running mate at the Republican convention, and there were a few claims worthy of, er, scrutiny.

Hugs all around for Ghana after Monday's 4-1 victory over Jamaica in a friendly at Leicester, England -- and not a moment too soon for the team's Serbian coach, Ratomir Dujkovic. He has been in hot water with Ghana fans for telling the German tabloid Der Bild, according to this translation, that for Ghanians "discipline is the biggest problem with Black Africans -- they have none." But in the wake of the big triumph, according to today's Daily Graphic in Accra, "a cross-section of fans" interviewed by the paper "have surprisingly toned down their language." Still, it doesn't look as if Dujkovic will stick around long after the World Cup is over. "I am not a person," as he told Bild, "who can work where I am not loved."
Mike Groll for The New York Times
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's May 31 column, "A Quick Fix for Gas Addicts"

The Carlyle Group is hoping that former fighter pilot W.W. Boisture Jr. can bring a bit of the right stuff to the giant buyout firm. Mr. Boisture, previously president of NetJets, has joined Carlyle as a senior adviser to the aerospace and defense team, the firm said Wednesday. In that role, he will help find potential investments in the sector, which has long been a sweet spot for Washington-based Carlyle. He will also provide management advice to Carlyle's current portfolio companies, the firm said in a press release.

The favorite nominator of Democratic candidates? The newly minted City Council Speaker Christine Quinn, who has stood up at the party's Buffalo convention for Andrew Cuomo, who she called "a man with courage, passion and commitment," and Comptroller Alan Hevesi, "one of our party's great progressive voices," and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, "an inspiration to all of us." By the time she stepped up late Wednesday morning to nominate Mrs. Clinton, the convention's final candidate, she quipped, "all right, I'm back."

European political correctness allows Muslims to resist integration, argues the culture editor of Jyllands-Posten. Instead, Muslims should be treated just like all Europeans -- including being subject to satire. He argues that publishing the caricatures was an act of "inclusion, not exclusion."

A trio of San Francisco-based software investment bankers are jumping to J.P. Morgan Chase from UBS, J.P. Morgan said in an internal memo on Wednesday. Those making the leap include KS Jangbahadur, UBS's global head of software, who will have the same title when he begins work at J.P. Morgan in August. Two other UBS bankers, vice president Jason Ream and associate Marek Biegulk, are expected to start at J.P. Morgan in June.

Further on Zinedine Zidane, for whom this World Cup may well be his swan song. Thanks to reader John Webster for hipping us to this video of Zidane's goal for Real Madrid in its 2-1 victory over Bayer Leverkusen in the 2002 Champions League final. We remember watching it in a Spanish social club on West 14th Street -- the whole room of old men stood as one when Zizou scored this goal, which the next day's Spanish-language papers in New York referred to as his "gol de fantasia." Watch the video and commentary from the Spanish network TVE1, and see why.
If the Democratic convention had an air of bursting exuberance to it, one reason was the tight packing of boisterous delegates into the Hyatt banquet-room-turned-convention-hall in Buffalo.
Dale Chihuly, a glass artist, has accused two glass blowers of imitating his signature creations.

Members of U.K. insurer Standard Life Assurance on Wednesday voted overwhelmingly to end 80 years of private ownership, clearing the way for a July listing on the London Stock Exchange that could raise up to 5.5 billion pounds ($9.5 billion).

For the latest crop of M.B.A. holders, here is a number to ponder: $92,360. That, according to the Graduate Management Admission Council, is the average starting base salary for business school graduates in the class of 2006 (among those who had jobs, that is). That is up 4.2 percent from last year, according to the nonprofit organization, which may be best known to business students as the outfit that administers the Graduate Management Admission Test.
Steve Mizerak became a national champion while a full-time schoolteacher, then emerged as a pop-culture celebrity doing TV beer commercials.

Are conservatives finally abandoning the central tenets of supply-side economics? Greg Mankiw, the Harvard economist and former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Bush, commits heresy in the pages of the Wall Street Journal, where he lets readers in on the secret that "most economists" don't believe that tax cuts increase tax revenues for the government [$]. While discussing Henry Paulson, President Bush's new nominee for Treasury secretary, Mankiw writes: "Some supply-siders like to claim that the distortionary effect of taxes is so large that increasing tax rates reduces tax revenue. Like most economists, I don't find that conclusion credible for most tax hikes, and I doubt Mr. Paulson does either."

Japan's surprising 2-2 draw with Germany yesterday in a World Cup tuneup match in Leverkusen -- a draw the Germans had to claw back from a 2-0 deficit to achieve -- gets us to wondering again: how come the Americans didn't schedule any warmup matches in Europe?

HealthSouth, which is struggling to put a massive accounting scandal behind it, may be implicated in the ever-widening controversy over the timing of stock option grants. A report Wednesday in The Wall Street Journal says that Richard Scrushy, HealthSouth's former chief executive, "repeatedly received stock options dated at low points in the company's stock price."

The Mercantile Bancorp said on Wednesday it had agreed to buy Royal Palm Bancorp of Florida for $44.4 million to raise its presence in areas growing faster than its traditional markets in Illinois and Missouri.

Pinnacle Entertainment will get what's left of Harrah's Entertainment's Lake Charles casino complex in Louisiana, while Harrah's will take over what's left of Casino Magic in Biloxi, Miss., under a deal announced Wednesday.

Genworth Financial, an insurance company based in Richmond, Va., said on Wednesday its Australian mortgage insurance subsidiary would buy Vero Lenders Mortgage Insurance in Sydney, Australia, for about $165 million before a substantial post-closing dividend.

Call center operator West Corporation said on Wednesday it had agreed to be acquired by an investor group led by Thomas H. Lee Partners and the Quadrangle Group in a deal valuing West at $4.1 billion, including debt.

The complex takeover maneuverings of the world's mining giants continued on Wednesday, when the board of Inco urged its shareholders to reject an unsolicited offer from Teck Cominco, a Canadian rival.
Summer entertaining has begun, and hosts are scrambling for the right paraphernalia to set up outdoors.

A New York Observer profile of Henry Paulson opens with an old quote of his about his fondness for snakes. "I like to hold them and look at them," said Mr. Paulson, the Goldman Sachs chief executive who is now headed for a job as Treasury Secretary. The article ends with the reason for his interest in predatory animals: "I'm fascinated," he is quoted as saying, "because they're at the top of the food chain."
Booting up with your feet up, a crescendo of steel, culminating in handbags, a touch of modern Africa and more.
Readers respond to Frank Rich's May 28 column, "The Cannes Landslide for Al Gore"
New York Democrats are exultant. New York Republicans are edgy.
Eurotunnel announced a long awaited debt restructuring proposal on Wednesday, backed by three international banks, and said it would go bankrupt without it.
The newest golf course in the Hamptons may already be No. 1 in at least one category: price.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton accepted the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate. At the Republican convention, John Spencer was voted the official designee to oppose her, but he faces a primary challenge.

General Motors named the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region Tuesday to run its troubled North American operations. The company's chief executive, Rick Wagoner, who has been in charge of North America for the last year, said the company's turnaround plan was far enough along to hand off the responsibilities so he could focus on broader restructuring efforts.

The broadband equipment maker ADC Telecommunications said Wednesday it would acquire a communications equipment maker, the Andrew Corporation, for about $2 billion in a stock swap that will create a company with $3.3 billion in annual sales.

The seven private equity groups that took SunGard Data Systems private in an $11.4 billion deal last year are likely to own the company for several more years after deciding against a recapitalization of the group.

Vonage, tarred by a disastrous initial public offering last week, is scrambling to reassure investors. The company, which provides Internet phone service, said yesterday that it would reimburse the bankers who handled the sale if any Vonage customers refused to pay for shares that were allotted to them.

The judge at the trial of two former executives of Enron Broadband Internet denied a request on Tuesday to question jurors about whether they had seen news reports about the convictions of former Enron chief executives Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling.
Richard P. Adelson, former president of Impath, was sentenced yesterday to 3½ years in prison, fined $1.2 million and ordered to pay $50 million in restitution.

Aeroports de Paris, the state-owned operator of France's biggest airports, will sell as much as 1.4 billion euros ($1.8 billion) of shares in an initial public offering to build terminals and raise money for the government.

The fallout from the federal investigation into stock option manipulation spread yesterday as McAfee, the maker of antivirus software, became the latest company to dismiss an executive. In addition, shareholders sued the American Tower Corporation.

Kim Woo Choong, whose career as the rags-to-riches founder of the Daewoo Group ended in South Korea's biggest corporate fraud scandal, was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years in prison and ordered to forfeit 21.4 trillion won ($22.5 billion).

Maybe Napster had it right. Federal antitrust investigators are reexamining the online music pioneer's long-standing claims that the major record labels improperly conspired to keep authorized downloads off the Internet, The Los Angeles Times reported.

Tim Schoonmaker, in his role as head of Credit Suisse's European media investment team, is evaluating a 300 million pound bid for the television production house All3Media, The Times of London reported.

A private equity firm in Houston, EnCap Investments, has raised a $1.5 billion fund from major institutional investors and wealthy individuals. Gary Petersen, one of EnCap's founders, calls the pool of capital the largest private equity fund ever raised specifically targeting the upstream oil and gas business.
A startup cable television channel sued the cable giants Time Warner and Comcast on Tuesday in an attempt to block their planned acquisition of the bankrupt Adelphia Communications.
Seattle-based Redfin, an online real-estate site, plans to announce today that it has raised $8 million in venture capital.

Three-year-old Affinity Engines has joined the crowded world of social networking with software focused squarely at university alumni groups. The company, which has signed deals with about 50 colleges, has raised $4.13 million to market its technology.
Ambient, a Newton development stage company specializing in broadband over power lines products, reports it has closed a private placement of $10 million to investors.

Drawing the interest of some of the largest biotechnology venture capital investors, FoldRx Pharmaceuticals, a drug developer focusing on diseases like Alzheimer's and cystic fibrosis affected by protein misfolding, raised $43 million in Series B financing.
Ethanol producer Hawkeye Holdings may raise up to $350 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

Marsh Supermarkets surged more than 20 percent after the Indianapolis-based grocery chain got a new takeover offer. The company said it received an unsolicited letter, dated May 22, from Drawbridge Special Opportunities Advisors and Cardinal Paragon in which the firms say they want to acquire Marsh for $13.625 a share.

In a sign that Wall Street sees plenty more takeover traffic coming, New York-based investment dealer Lehman Brothers returned to Canada yesterday by hiring BMO Nesbitt Burns deal maker Geoff Belsher to open Toronto and Calgary offices.

Wall Street's most prestigious investment banks are clamoring to get a piece of the next private-equity firm to float shares in a multibillion-dollar initial public offering.Apollo Management, founded by the former Drexel Burnham Lambert investment banker Leon Black, is planning a road show for its new $2.5 billion public fund this week, The New York Post reported.
In Henry Paulson, President George W. Bush chose a Treasury secretary nominee in the mold of Robert Rubin -- a Wall Street heavyweight with built-in credibility in financial markets.
CPI, a portrait photography company, said on Tuesday its board has begun the process of exploring strategic alternatives, which could include the sale of the company.

The mining industry, in the middle of a merger boom, was rife with speculation on Tuesday that rivals are weighing a bid of at least 20 billion Canadian dollars for Alcan, the world's second-largest aluminum producer.

Aleksei Mordashov, the chief executive of the Russian steel company Severstal, said Tuesday that he was baffled that his 13 billion euro ($16.5 billion) deal with the steel giant Arcelor had set off such a stir.
Financial services company E*Trade Financial is planning to buy Retirement Advisors of America, a Dallas-based investment advisory firm that manages more than $1 billion in assets.
Several hedge funds continue to oppose Micron's acquisition of Lexar Media, and recently told the companies that they plan to vote against the merger when shareholders vote on the matter Friday.
Dexia, the third-biggest bank in Belgium, agreed to buy 75 percent of Turkish lender DenizBank for about $2.44 billion to expand in an economy that's growing faster than its home market.

Kinder Morgan shareholders should not expect a bidding war to break out after Monday's news of a planned management buyout, but they may well see an offer above the $100 per share now on the table, according to analysts.

The Mirant Corporation, a power company that recently emerged from bankruptcy protection, said Tuesday that it had made an unsolicited bid to buy NRG Energy for $7.8 billion. The announcement comes a week after NRG rejected a Mirant offer and declined to enter takeover discussions.
The authors of "Two for the Road" answered readers' questions about the resurgence of mom-and-pop restaurants, the best chili and where they would eat their last meal.
Ordinarily, I don't rile easily. But I just about blew my stack trying to set up the Magellan RoadMate 300, a portable GPS unit.
The hum of earth-moving equipment and power tools is everywhere as Qatar strives to become a world-class business and leisure center.
The LeFraks own a third of the high-rise skyline that has grown up along Jersey City’s once dilapidated waterfront over the past 20 years.
The city council in Düsseldorf, Germany, will vote to override a literary award for the author Peter Handke, who has expressed sympathy for Slobodan Milosevic.
The noted environmental portrait photographer Slim Aarons died on Monday. He was 89.

With Hank Paulson headed to Washington to become the next Treasury Secretary, the heavy buzz on Wall Street is that Goldman Sachs president Lloyd Blankfein will land the job as the next leader of the storied securities firm.
John Birch hiked in six pairs of sports sandals for two days each across rocky terrain and the occasional creek crossing in Tucson
Clippers, a sweater, a gun and spectacles were among the props that helped define some characters on Broadway this season.
Canon is ceasing development in its film-camera business, joining a number of other companies who have already exited the business to focus on digital.
At the Heckscher Museum of Art, on Long Island, an exhibit shows how the Dada artist Man Ray captured the sense of excitement that electricity brings to life.
A look at some of the performers who could - nay, should - have been contenders in this year's Tony Awards race.
A look at some of the directors whose work on Broadway this season often reached sublime heights.
Former broadband unit finance chief Kevin Howard was convicted while former in-house accountant Michael Krautz was acquitted of five counts of fraud.
Frank Gehry and Bruce Ratner are proving how much influence architects have with developers, and how troublingly little.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Enough of the ingredients for a sultry downscale noir are in place in "Coastlines," that once the film turns perversely goody-good, it leaves you feeling vaguely disgruntled.
If you get the opportunity to taste a good bottle of Bierzo, with its haunting, exotic wildflower, licorice and fruit flavors, you can't help but remember it.
The senator's marquee appearance at the state Democratic convention strongly resembled groundwork for a presidential campaign.
The countries are underreporting because they lack the resources to track the disease adequately.
American soldiers involved in a car crash fired into the crowd of protesters, according to a police chief.
The cuts seemed at odds with officials' vows to steer more anti-terrorism money to the nation's highest-risk cities.
An analysis suggests that scientists have underestimated the power of greenhouse gases to warm the planet.
If laws were broken, the president said, "there will be punishment," the president said.
Kimberly Dozier was aware that they were there and was able to respond to their presence, CBS reported.
Newspapers led with President Vladimir V. Putin's speech on Tuesday outlining plans for the country's general savings account, known as the Stabilization Fund.
The women were apparently shot by coalition forces when their car failed to stop at an observation post.
Anti-doping authorities challenged conclusions by an investigator appointed by the International Cycling Union.
The Bush administration is willing to join multinational talks with Iran over its nuclear program if it suspends all nuclear activities.
Some shareholders of Arcelor, the world's No. 2 steel maker, are objecting to a $16.7 billion deal that would put a Russian oligarch in control of their company.
Youths threw rocks at the police and set a dozen cars ablaze in two Paris suburbs today, in a second night of violence.
Slobodan Milosevic may have hastened his death by refusing prescribed drugs, a U.N. investigation found.
Stocks closed higher today, buoyed by the first drop in oil prices in a week and by signs of easing tension with Iran.
Some of the cars in a 70-car train crashed into two buildings in Paterson, N.J., the authorities said.
Raja Bell, who could best be described as the Phoenix Suns' spiritual leader, made a surprise return to the lineup and provided the inspiration for the route of the Dallas Mavericks.
Mariano Rivera stifled the Detroit Tigers in the ninth and 10th innings and stayed in to finish them off in the 11th inning.
Christopher L. Jacobs, the New York secretary of state, could help William F. Weld gain support from upstate Republican leaders.
Houston Astros officials and Roger Clemens's agent denied that Clemens was about to re-sign with the club, but the Yankees were proceeding as if that would be the case.

For better or worse, watching the game was like gazing through a crystal ball for the Mets, who got a look at their future, with Alay Soler starting and 21-year-old Lastings Milledge starting in right field in place of Xavier Nady.
In a series pitting teams whose styles are mirror images, it is only fitting that the N.H.L. Eastern Conference finals will come down to a seventh, deciding game.

DETROIT, May 30 — The Yankees cannot shake their injury problems. Johnny Damon said his right foot was getting more and more painful, and Gary Sheffield complained of soreness in his left wrist after batting practice on Tuesday. Neither outfielder started against the Tigers.
By Bloomberg News.
Reporters have been trying for weeks to talk to Larry Brown and he finally obliged, climbing out of his Audi after reporters approached him at a traffic light.
A colonel uncovered evidence that contradicted claims by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha were victims of a roadside bomb.
Four Connecticut librarians had been barred from revealing that they had received a request for patrons' records from the government.
As renewed violence swept across Iraq on Tuesday, Iraq said it would investigate last November's killings in Haditha for itself.
The report finds reasons for optimism, but warns that the number of new infections is still rising in some countries.
If confirmed, Henry M. Paulson Jr.'s salary would drop by about $29.8 million and he would lose  authority over $700 million in Goldman stock.
Jeff Gross was ambushed and shot three times in the chest and arms Monday night as he returned to the commune's group of homes on Corson Avenue.
Steve Spurrier, South Carolina's coach, said that he would be in Gainesville, Fla., on Sept. 2 when Florida honors its 1996 national championship team, which he coached.
FEVER STAYS UNBEATEN IN W.N.B.A.
The bombing has deepened concerns among television executives about the risks their crews face trying to cover the Iraq war.
Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be Goldman's next chief executive, cuts an unusual profile for a Wall Street chief.
Henry M. Paulson Jr., President Bush's pick for Treasury secretary, is a deficit hawk with White House experience.
By Reuters.
Lastings Milledge, the Mets' top prospect, has one goal: Big leagues or bust.
victory over the Chicago White Sox.
The Pistons' energy is waning, their defense is sputtering after four consecutive trips to the Eastern Conference finals and they are one loss from elimination entering tonight's Game 5 vs. the Heat.
For now, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton can campaign without campaigning, and run for Senate just by being there.
A state appeals court reversed the disqualification of a lawyer who had advised both the developer and a state agency that is reviewing the project.
Cosimo and Maria Pisani ponder the improbability of a son of Italian immigrants, Fernando Pisani, becoming the hometown hero of a rejuvenated Canadian city and its favorite hockey team.
Barbaro was visited by his jockey, Edgar Prado, and seems to be recovering in remarkable fashion from complicated surgery for his life-threatening ankle injury.
The court ruled that public employees are not protected from retaliation for what they say as part of their jobs.

A federal magistrate in Brooklyn yesterday insisted that government lawyers defending former Attorney General John Ashcroft and other top officials in a lawsuit brought by former immigrant detainees cannot dodge the plaintiffs' persistent and unwelcome question: Are members of the United States trial team and likely witnesses — including Mr. Ashcroft and Robert S. Mueller III, the F.B.I. director — aware of any secret government monitoring of communications between the plaintiffs and their lawyers?.
Lottery Numbers.
To the Editor:.
Harry Reid's discomfort with the news that he got free seats to a boxing match should reinforce the need for Congress to upgrade the enforcement of ethics rules.
Unless the Bush administration eases its stubborn opposition to direct talks, it is hard to see what is going to stop the eventual emergence of a nuclear-armed Iran.
The Supreme Court whittled away at the First Amendment on Tuesday, ruling against a prosecutor who raised concerns about the validity of a search warrant.
At the Democratic State Convention, Eliot Spitzer pledged to confront "the crisis of leadership" in Albany with the same zeal he used to pursue Wall Street executives as the state's attorney general.
President Bush's nomination of Henry Paulson Jr. to be the next Treasury secretary is a master stroke.
Afghans placed blame for Monday's rioting on young hoodlums and criminal gangs, but also criticized the U.S. military's arrogance.
The announcement comes a week after NRG rejected a Mirant offer and declined to enter in takeover discussions.
State officials are preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well for the storm season.
A teacher with a writer's eye for detail noticed talent in one of her students, leading to a major prize.
Merck said that it erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use.
A witness in an assault case said his friend, the defendant, used a racial epithet to refer to the victim, who is black, during and after the beating.
A disclosure statement for a Republican House member intentionally understated the cost of a lavish golfing trip to Scotland with Jack Abramoff, a lobbyist testified.
Advocates of border security are sending bricks to Congress to emphasize the benefits of a fence on the Mexican border.
Andy Roddick retired from his opening match with an injured left ankle.  Martina Hingis offered the latest reminder that putting an end to her retirement was a fine idea.

A State Superior Court judge set bond at $3 million yesterday for a teenager charged in the fatal shootings of a man and his stepbrother in their Groton home over the weekend. Gregory D. Giesing and Derek C. Von Winkle, both 25, were found shot in their home on Saturday afternoon. Mr. Giesing had spina bifida and had to use a wheelchair. The defendant, Ian T. Cooke, 18, of Groton, was arrested on Saturday night and charged with murder. The Groton police said he knew the victims but they have not offered a motive for the slayings.

Paul A. Coughlin, the former mayor of Hazlet, admitted in Federal District Court yesterday that he took a $3,000 bribe to help a vendor obtain a town contract, federal prosecutors said. Mr. Coughlin pleaded guilty to one count of receiving a corrupt payment, said Gregory Reinert, a spokesman for the United States attorney. Mr. Coughlin admitted that he took the payment from a vendor — who was not identified by federal prosecutors — in exchange for using his influence to help the vendor get a contract for demolishing Town Hall, Mr. Reinert said. Mr. Coughlin entered the plea as his trial was scheduled to begin.

A man was stabbed and robbed by a group of teenagers at the 167th Street station of the B and D lines in the South Bronx last evening, the police said. The victim, 45, who was attacked in front of a MetroCard machine about 6 p.m., was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in stable condition with stab wounds on his torso. The teenagers, who stole the man's wallet, fled at Carroll Place, witnesses said.
The U.S. agreed to the change in hopes of enlisting Russian support for a United Nations Security Council resolution on Iran.
Three days after the earthquake that rocked central Java, many villages in the two worst-hit districts have yet to receive any help.
The European Union's highest court ruled that an agreement to transfer personal data on air passengers to the U.S. was illegal.
These days most people in Darfur die not from bullets, but from not being able to get health care, clean water or food.
A program that has helped thousands of students from the District of Columbia afford a college education could become a victim of its own success.
Law and order have broken down in recent months as the United Nations has prepared to leave East Timor after a five year stay.
By Bloomberg News.
By Reuters.

BUFFALO, May 30 — Andrew M. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary under President Bill Clinton and the son of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, received the Democratic Party's backing on Tuesday to replace Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, demonstrating considerable muscle by gaining more than two-thirds of the delegates' votes at the party's state convention.

A caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Monday about a grief camp for children who lost a parent to the wars in Afghanistan or Iraq misstated the name of a boy who met with a mentor. He is Johnathan Lane, not Jonathan Lake.
A boom in gold and silver may be a sign that the U.S. is finally going to pay for years of easy money, mounting debt and trillion-dollar budget deficits.
John A. Muhammad, who has already been sentenced to death in Virginia, now faces six life sentences in a Maryland case.

A policeman was killed and 21 people were wounded in a string of attacks in the Indian-administered part of the disputed Kashmir province, as India and Pakistan began talks on how to end such attacks.
Officials announced plans for a Global Seed Vault to protect frozen seeds — for crops like rice, wheat, barley and fruits and vegetables — from cataclysms.
Troy Clarke, who has been assigned to Asia since 2004, will take over as president of G.M. North America on July 1.
By The Associated Press.
Kim Woo Choong was sentenced on Tuesday to 10 years in prison and ordered to forfeit 21.4 trillion won ($23 billion).

Nicole A. Gordon, the executive director of the New York City Campaign Finance Board since it was created in 1988 in the wake of several political corruption scandals, will resign in September to join a philanthropic foundation, officials said yesterday.
The defending Nextel Cup champion, Tony Stewart, who crashed twice last weekend and sustained a fractured right shoulder blade, will be back in the driver's seat.
On the outskirts of Brooklyn, the last of the low-rent strip parlors have achieved something like indestructibility.
A Thursday spacewalk by astronauts on the International Space Station will not include a previously planned attempt to whack a golf ball into orbit for the longest drive in history.

Far more American consumers consider the way companies treat their employees a good indicator of their social conscience than their philanthropy, according to a survey by the National Consumers League and Fleishman-Hillard, the public relations company.

A serial killer who prosecutors say burned some of his victims to ash and bits of bone in his backyard pleaded guilty to killing eight women. Under a deal with prosecutors, the killer, Larry Bright, 39, of Peoria, escaped a possible death sentence and will instead get life in prison without parole. The killings and the time it took to solve them caused an uproar among Peoria's blacks. Mr. Bright is white; his victims were black, and several were prostitutes and drug addicts. Mr. Bright did not comment in court, but in a statement read by a lawyer, he said:
Gen. Michael V. Hayden was sworn in as director of the C.I.A. and told agents that they must be competent and cooperative to keep the "central" in Central Intelligence Agency.
A federal judge declined to force the Federal Emergency Management Agency to continue financing its rental-assistance housing program for Hurricane Katrina evacuees.
Advocates for abortion rights filed petitions with more than 38,000 signatures with the secretary of state's office to challenge the state's ban on almost all abortions.

Jury selection began in the trial of a former state lawmaker charged in a federal corruption sting. The former state senator, Roscoe Dixon, Democrat of Memphis, was indicted with four sitting state lawmakers in May 2005. He is on trial in Federal District Court in Memphis on charges of extortion and accepting bribes, accused of taking $9,500 from a bogus company created by the F.B.I. John N. Ford, a Memphis Democrat and uncle of Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., resigned his State Senate seat and will go on trial in the fall. Trial dates for two other state senators have not been set. Former State Representative J. Chris Newton, Republican of Cleveland, pleaded guilty and is serving a one-year prison sentence.

A man who pleaded guilty to manslaughter for lighting pyrotechnics in a nightclub that sparked a fatal fire can work as a bookkeeper while serving his prison sentence, a judge ruled. The man, Daniel M. Biechele, 29, left, was sentenced on May 10 to four years in a minimum-security prison and will be eligible for parole in 16 months. The judge, Francis J. Darigan Jr. of Superior Court, ruled that Mr. Biechele should be allowed to work full time for an organization in Woonsocket that helps disabled children and adults. The nightclub fire, in West Warwick in 2003, killed 100 people.
With his brother William, Mr. Conway began the Mister Softee ice cream company in Philadelphia in 1956, developing it into a multimillion-dollar concern.
Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street Tuesday.
The chief of Russian steel company Severstal, was baffled that his 13 billion euro ($16.5 billion) deal with the steel giant Arcelor had set off such a stir.
Norwich, Conn., seems to be experiencing a reversal of fortunes as developers convert its old mills and hotels to luxury apartments and open stores.
Tarred by a disastrous initial public offering, Vonage said it would reimburse the bankers who handled the sale if any customers refused to pay for shares.
The official supervised the analyst in the Veterans Affairs Department who took computer data on some 26.5 million people to his home, where it was stolen in a burglary.
By Bloomberg News.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,459 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
A new comedy on the Lifetime channel about a dysfunctional dating service was conceived with a single advertiser in mind.

The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation and the mayor's office said yesterday that they were taking aggressive steps to reassure immigrants that no one will question their status when they seek care at New York City's public hospitals.
Chinese churches in Alhambra, Calif., are helping newcomers who are educated but no longer as well heeled as their predecessors.
For the first time since Hugo Sánchez starred in Spain, the backbone of Mexico's World Cup team is composed of players from European clubs.
The trade of Scott Kazmir to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays for Víctor Zambrano might be the worst deal since the Mets sent Nolan Ryan to the Angels for Jim Fregosi in 1971.
Inco has agreed with a labor union to preserve all jobs at its main operations even if the company is acquired.
Democratic leaders hope Harold E. Ford Jr. can help them begin to turn the tide in the South.

As police investigators sought to link the suspect in a fatal shooting outside a Chelsea nightclub last week to three unsolved murders in Brooklyn last year, a common thread emerged: the Sweet Cherry bar.
The loss was a sign that European telecommunications companies had not completely recovered from the hangovers that followed the expansive late 1990's.
In addition, Tribune, the nation's second-largest newspaper company, plans to cut costs by $200 million over two years and raise $500 million.
Virginia Hall has been teaching people how to find harmony through quilt making.
Archaeologists are searching what could be the first tomb uncovered in the Valley of the Kings in 84 years.
Opening a new chapter in its effort to establish constitutional boundaries for punitive damages, the court will hear a cigarette maker's appeal.
Tiger Woods, who is preparing to play in the United States Open, made his first public golf-related appearance since the Masters.

The European Union's highest court found that Ireland, which wants Britain to close an aging nuclear power plant with a poor safety record, had illegally appealed to a United Nations tribunal when it should have used the Union's internal legal procedures. The Irish government claims the nuclear waste reprocessing facility at Sellafield, about 60 miles from the Irish coast, pollutes the Irish Sea with radioactive waste that includes Technetium 99. Irish officials said they would continue efforts to close the plant.

Culture Minister George Voulgarakis escaped a terrorist attack when a powerful bomb exploded near his home, in central Athens, wrecking a string of parked cars but causing no injuries. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but police and security officials said the bombing bore the hallmarks of the Revolutionary Struggle, a band of militant extremists active since 2003, when the police cracked down on Greece's most deadly terrorist group, November 17. Mr. Voulgarakis, 46, who was until February the minister for security, said he been threatened in recent weeks for his alleged role in the illegal interrogation of a group of Pakistanis last year.

A court sentenced the editors of two weekly newspapers to two months in jail for harming religious feelings by reprinting offensive caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad. The lawyer for Jihad Momani, left, chief editor of Shihan, and Hashim Khalidi, chief editor of Al Mehwar, said he would appeal, and both editors were released on bail. Mr. Momani said he had printed the cartoons to show readers "the extent of the Danish offense," and Mr. Khalidi said the cartoons had appeared in his paper alongside criticism of the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten, which first published the cartoons.

Law enforcement officials investigating the death of a New Jersey man who was beaten to death last week on a Chelsea street corner are seeking to identify and question three men who went on a two-day shopping spree with the victim's credit cards.
The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee called the F.B.I.'s search of a Congressional office "profoundly disturbing."

Hugh B. Patterson Jr. was the publisher of The Arkansas Gazette in 1957 when that newspaper was thrust into national prominence for its stand against segregated schools during a federal-state confrontation.
The decision by Engelhard, which is best known as the pioneer of the catalytic converter, came after BASF raised its offer a second time, to $39 a share.
An agent said there were no signs of the remains of James R. Hoffa, the former Teamsters leader, on a Michigan horse farm.
Where else but Britain would standing on a billiard-smooth green tapping colored balls through hoops be a firing offense?
About 150 masked youths clashed with police in Montfermeil and Clichy-sous-Bois, the suburb where last fall's unrest began.
In the Gaza Strip Monday, Israeli ground troops ambushed members of Islamic Jihad as they prepared to fire a rocket into Israel.
Mr. Imamura was one of the most significant filmmakers of Japan's postwar generation, whose works include "Black Rain" and two top-prize winners at Cannes.
A Philadelphia tract offers a suburban campus feel with city advantages and drawbacks.
Hospitals had been considered neutral during the years of conflict in Somalia until gunmen seized a Mogadishu hospital this week.
Can we change the spelling bee to make it more useful for teaching real-world skills to some of the nation's brightest students?
Monica Bellucci to star as Sonia Gandhi, Getty to exhibit Byzantine icons, Paris Hilton sings and more culture news.

Because of an editing error, a listing in the Calendar on May 3, about Cinco de Mayo celebrations at New York restaurants, misstated a component in a drink called a Bandera. It is sangrita, not sangria.
Darfur was never the simplistic morality tale purveyed by the news media and humanitarian organizations.
Modern care packages must account for the complicated logistics of 21st century warfare, advancements in technology and the diverse and sophisticated palates of today's troops.
Today's ice cream sandwiches are all spruced up: fancy flavors invitingly situated between cookies of all kinds.

Linny Boyette, the show's ultimate fan, is almost as familiar and beloved a face to many as Katie, Matt, Ann and Al.
Like the shy kid at the dance whose charms are not readily apparent, unpopularity has kept some species of fish in circulation, waiting to be discovered.
"I felt I could understand the animosity and hatred which an Islamic believer would have for our system," says John Updike about his new novel.
The National Academy Museum's "181st Annual" show comes close to reflecting accurately the pluralism of art in America.

The performances of Verdi and Tchaikovsky on Memorial Day were bold and vibrant, thanks to Xian Zhang's conducting technique and charisma.
Send us your nominations for best summer cocktails.
With clean, vibrant flavors and a rich, luxuriant consistency, the Lone Star State's Blue Bell ice cream hooks you from the first spoonful.

Neil Hanson's book brings to life the hottest sectors of the Western Front and examines the struggle of the combatant nations to memorialize the dead.

The chefs Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli take the easy approach to summer entertaining by serving dishes that are cooked well ahead of time and assembled at room temperature.

With more than 125 pilsners and lagers and bocks, along with a designated beer sommelier to explain them all, Cafe d'Alsace is New York's newest paradise for beer lovers.

Aperitivi are the key to an affordable stay in Bologna. Essentially, these are bars that offer free spreads to drinking customers.

PALMER--Edward L., of Mill Neck, NY, passed away peacefully on May 27th at the age of 88. He was the beloved husband of Margaret P. Palmer, his wife of 66 years, and the devoted father of Ned Palmer and Jane Palmer Morrison. He is also survived by his loving grandchildren, Edward L. Palmer II, Alix Palmer and Ben Morrison. A graduate of Brooklyn Academy and Brown University, he worked for the New York Trust Co. and for 23 years at Citibank, from which he retired as Chairman of the Executive Committee. He also served on active duty with the U.S. Naval Reserve 19421946 and attained the rank of Lieutenant Commander. Service St. John's of Lattingtown on June 3rd at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY 11560 or East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton, NY 11978.

GILILEO, the nickname Gil Rubenstein's grandfather used to call him, now adorns the sidewalk kiosk at 176 West 94th Street where Mr. Rubenstein serves coffees, pastries, panini and sandwiches, including a lobster roll ($9.50). He has added some tables to what had been Leaf Storm, and also sells ice cream from a cart that he runs jointly with L'Arte del Gelato of Chelsea Market: (646) 403-3215. PENZEYS SPICES, a Wisconsin company that has stores in 20 states, has opened a stall in the Grand Central Market, in Grand Central Terminal, selling dried herbs, spice blends, dried chilies and other seasonings in addition to spices. It replaces Adriana's Caravan, and it is the first national chain in the market: (212) 972-2777. FINANCIER, the excellent patisserie in the financial district, has opened a third location, its largest, at 35 Cedar Street (William Street). There are tables on a sunny terrace, and there will soon be a kiosk for ice cream and hot dogs. In addition to pastries, it has soups, salads and sandwiches, and expects to add brunch: (212) 952-3838.
To the Editor: Re ''War of the Worlds,'' by Charles Passy (Op-Ed, May 26):

To the Editor: The shortsightedness of Bloomingdale's, Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue may extend far beyond the demographic of the woman of a certain height, age and economic status (''Where's the Petite Department? Going the Way of the Petticoat,'' front page, May 28).

Because of an editing error, a listing in the Calendar on May 3, about Cinco de Mayo celebrations at New York restaurants, misstated a component in a drink called a Bandera. It is sangrita, not sangria.

An obituary on Friday about James W. Carey, a scholar of communications, misstated the year he left the College of Communications at the University of Illinois, where he was dean, to become a professor at Columbia University. It was 1992, not 1988.

PERDUNN--Richard F. Of Lakewood, NJ. Formerly of Point Pleasant and Brielle, NJ. Dear husband of Doris Andrus Perdunn. Beloved father and father-in-law of Justine and James Kovacs. Grandfather of Julia Perdunn Kovacs and Jacquelyn Kovacs. He was pre-deceased by his first wife Eugenia Morel Perdunn. Graveside service to be held today, Wednesday, at 11:00 A.M. in Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ. Contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society.

An obituary on Monday about Ted Berkman, an author and screenwriter, omitted a writing credit for the movie ''Bedtime for Bonzo.'' The script for the film was by Raphael David Blau and Mr. Berkman, not just Mr. Berkman.

An article on May 17 about dry-cured sausages misstated some federal inspection requirements. For a salami to be labeled ''ready-to-eat,'' producers must prove that their processing method kills pathogens; the government does not tell producers which procedures to follow to meet the standard.

Lawyers for a disc jockey facing criminal charges over statements he made on the air about a rival radio announcer's child asked a judge yesterday to dismiss the charges. The disc jockey, Troi Torain, left, known as DJ Star, threatened to sexually abuse his rival's 4-year-old daughter and offered a reward for information on where the child attended school, prosecutors said. In their motion in Manhattan Criminal Court, Mr. Torain's lawyers characterized his statements as part of an on-air battle between the announcers, and said they were not a crime.

KRISMAN--Col. Michael J., Ret. 91, Highland Falls, NY, on May 22 in West Point, NY. Beloved husband of Alys (nee Savage). Loving father of Michael Krisman, Alys Hart and Mary Ann Krisman-Hart. Devoted brother of Joseph C. Krisman. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Visitation June 1, 7-9 p.m. at William F. Hogan Funeral Home, 135 Main St, Highland Falls, NY. Funeral June 2, 10 a.m. Chapel of The Most Holy Trinity, West Point, NY. Donations to American Cancer Society.

To the Editor: Although Turkey's ambassador to the United States asserts arguably that ''history should be left to historians'' (letter, May 24), the Turkish government makes history a precondition for normalizing interstate relations with Armenia.

A Film entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report of Arts & Leisure included an outdated reference to screenings of Pietro Germi's ''Gioventù Perduta'' (''Lost Youth'') at the Museum of Modern Art. After the section had gone to press, the schedule was changed and another Germi film, ''Un Maledetto Imbroglio'' (''A Dirty Trick''), is being shown instead. The final screening is tonight at 6.

JAFFE - Matthew. Today marks your 85th Birthday. Daddy, no one ever dieswhose love lives in the hearts of those left behind. Your loving Children

An article in The Arts yesterday about new buildings in Miami by prominent architects misidentified the museum where Terence Riley, who commented on the city's awareness of top architects, is director. It is the Miami Art Museum, not the Museum of Contemporary Art. (Bonnie Clearwater is executive director and chief curator of that museum.)

An early-morning fire yesterday injured 11 people and forced the evacuation of an apartment building at 2499 Grand Avenue, the Fire Department said. The fire, reported at 1:23 a.m., was confined to a third-floor apartment, but smoke forced the evacuation of residents throughout the five-story building, fire officials said. Six residents and five firefighters were slightly injured before the fire was brought under control at 4:37 a.m., fire officials said.

WITTY--Spencer B. Passed away peacefully at home on May 29 at the age of 92. Darling beloved husband of Cecile and the late Henrietta; adored father of Jane and Lawrence Gould; cherished grandfather of Lance and Michele Gould and Eric and Robin Gould; loving greatgrandfather of Ruby, Benjamin, Spencer and Samantha Gould; treasured uncle of Richard, Kenneth, and Stephen Witty, and Pat Drasner; revered step-father of Jane and Joseph Michaels IV and Sally and Leonard Michaels; dear step-grandfather of Joseph Michaels V and Jess Michaels; and devoted brother of the late Ephraim, Sidney, Frederic, and Arthur Witty and brother-in-law of Judi Witty. Spencer was the former distinguished chairman of the Merchants Bank of New York and director emeritus of Valley National Bank. He was an extraordinary individual who will be sorely missed by his family, friends, and colleagues. Contributions may be made to Sloan-Kettering Gastroenterology Oncology, c/o Dr. David Kelsen. Services Thursday June 1, 11:30 a.m., at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. $(6$)WITTY--Spencer. In sorrow, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of our distinguished member, Spencer Witty. With his family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y $(6$)WITTY--Spencer. If we had to design the ideal brother-inlaw, it would be Spencer Witty. Always in perfect harmony with everyone around him, Spencer was a great friend and companion. He was also the human embodiment of the golden rule and he taught us the meaning of integrity. Even as we mourn his loss, we rejoice in a life well lived. Louise and Mike Stein $(6$)WITTY--Spencer. Associate, mentor, and most of all friend. We will miss you. Chuck and Joan Baum

DIAMOND--Helen. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Harry S. Katz, President

TREASURY SECRETARY NAMED -- President Bush said he had chosen Henry M. Paulson Jr., chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, as his next Treasury secretary, a move intended to add economic star power to his administration as it tries to fight its way through a thicket of political difficulties. [Page A1.] THE HEIR APPARENT -- Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be Goldman Sachs's next chief executive, has been instrumental in Goldman's transformation from a traditional investment bank to a fast-growing investing giant willing to make big bets with its own money. [C1.] STOCK SELL-OFF -- Worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates prompted a sell-off on Wall Street, the latest dip in a market that has experienced a high degree of volatility in the last few weeks. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 184.18 points, to 11,094.43. [C1.] AIR PASSENGER DISCLOSURE -- The European Union's highest court ruled that the union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism. The decision will force the two sides to renegotiate the deal. [A1.] MERCK ACKNOWLEDGES ERROR -- Merck said it had erred when it reported in early 2005 that a crucial statistical test showed that Vioxx caused heart problems only after 18 months of continuous use. The admission could undermine a core defense in Vioxx-related lawsuits. [C1.] ENGELHARD ACCEPTS BASF BID -- Dropping five months of resistance, the Engelhard Corporation agreed to be acquired by BASF of Germany for about $5 billion. The decision by Engelhard, best known as the pioneer of the catalytic converter for cars, came after BASF raised its offer a second time, to $39 a share. [C3.] G.M. NAMES EXECUTIVE -- General Motors named Troy Clarke, the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region, to run its troubled North American operations. [C1.] COURT TO HEAR TOBACCO CASE -- The Supreme Court, opening a new chapter in its effort to establish constitutional boundaries for punitive damages, agreed to hear a cigarette maker's appeal of a $79.5 million punitive damage award. [C3.] WORK PLACE PROTECTION -- The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 that the Constitution does not protect public employees against retaliation by their supervisors for anything they say in the course of performing their assigned duties. [A16.] APPEARING AS ITSELF -- When ''Lovespring International,'' a Lifetime comedy about a dysfunctional dating service, has its debut on Monday, the online dating service Perfectmatch.com will have a role -- a result of a deal with the Lifetime channel. ''Lovespring'' is being produced by the production company owned by the actor Eric McCormack, above. Advertising. [C3.] CONSUMER CONFIDENCE WEAKENS -- Consumer confidence soured in May, as Americans worried about the future of the economy and the outlook for jobs. The Conference Board said that its consumer confidence index fell almost 7 points, to 103.2. [C5.] POWER COMPANY BID -- The Mirant Corporation, a power company that recently emerged from bankruptcy protection, said that it had made an unsolicited bid to buy NRG Energy for $7.8 billion. [C3.] OPTIONS FALLOUT SPREADS -- The fallout from the federal investigation into stock-option manipulation spread as McAfee, the maker of antivirus software, became the latest company to dismiss an executive. Shareholders sued the American Tower Corporation. [C5.] STEEL DEAL -- Aleksei Mordashov, chief of the Russian steel company Severstal, said he was baffled that his 13 billion-euro deal with Arcelor -- devised in part to fend off a hostile takeover attempt by Mittal Steel -- had set off such a stir. ''I'm afraid it's not understood well enough,'' Mr. Mordashov said. [C6.] DAEWOO FOUNDER SENTENCED -- Kim Woo Choong, the rags-to-riches founder of the Daewoo Group of South Korea, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and ordered to forfeit 21.4 trillion won ($23 billion) in a corporate fraud scandal. [C6.] VONAGE OFFERS REIMBURSEMENT -- Vonage, tarred by a disastrous initial public offering last week, said it would reimburse the bankers who handled the sale if any Vonage customers refused to pay for shares that were allotted to them. [C7.] VODAFONE POSTS LOSS -- Vodafone, the world's biggest wireless operator in terms of revenue, posted an annual loss of £21.9 billion, its biggest ever, in a sign that European telecommunications companies had not completely recovered from the hangovers that followed the expansive late 1990's. [C7.] MINING COMPANY LABOR PACT -- Inco, the Canadian mining company entangled in a series of conflicting takeover bids, has agreed with a union to preserve all jobs at its main operations even if the company is acquired. [C6.] ONLINE ON THE ROAD -- It is one of the wonders of modern airline travel that the premium trans-Atlantic markets, and especially the New York-London routes, are thriving. A report by Joe Sharkey is at nytimes.com/business. THE BUSINESS OF GREEN -- Businesses are going green for many reasons, not just to enhance their image. Some are seeking a competitive advantage. A special report is at nytimes.com/business. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.
McCORMICK--William W. 79, entered into eternal rest on Saturday, May 27, 2006. For directions, additional information or to extend an online expression of sympathy, visit www.leetestevens.com

To the Editor: It would be nice to be able to ''put 2003's debates behind us,'' as Owen West suggests, and concentrate on the common ground. But we cannot do this because no one has been held accountable.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has agreed to hear the appeal of a prisoner from Long Island who claims that he was wrongly convicted of the 1988 murders of his parents. The inmate, Martin H. Tankleff, is appealing the decision of a Suffolk County judge, Stephen Braslow, who upheld the convictions in March. Mr. Tankleff claims that new evidence points to his father's embittered business partner and three ex-convicts as the culprits. One of the three said he was the getaway driver, but the others denied guilt. Judge Braslow said the new evidence was not credible. BRUCE LAMBERT (NYT)

SIMON--Rose. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed founding member. We extend deepest sympathy to her children David, Lois, and to the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Sarah A. Zemel, Hazzan Paul D. Hendler, Pres. Karen Goldstick, Chrmn
To the Editor: Re ''The Troops Have Moved On'' (Op-Ed, May 29):

9 P.M. (VH1) VH1 ROCK HONORS -- Pump up the volume. VH1 worships the gods of heavy metal in this tribute to Kiss (with Gene Simmons, above left, and Tommy Thayer), Queen, Def Leppard and Judas Priest. Godsmack, Foo Fighters and the All-American perform hymns of praise. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Ricki Lake leads celebrity contestants through classic games in this new revolving weekly tournament. Taking the first spin: Lance Bass, Paige Davis, Tim Meadows, Kathy Najimy, Leslie Nielsen and Brande Roderick in ''The Price Is Right.'' 9 P.M. (A&E) INKED -- Having the world's first casino tattoo parlor apparently wasn't extreme enough for Corey Hart, the motocross champion. Now he's starting an outré clothing line. This season, Mr. Hart maneuvers around fashion-industry obstacles while keeping his skin artists in line. 9 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES -- Gordon Ramsay (left), the celebrity chef with a temper perpetually set to boil, sure knows how to dish it out. In this season premiere of this British series, he sharpens his knives at down-and-out Momma Cherri's Soul Food Shack near the beach in Brighton and helps keep its burners lit. 9 P.M. (Bravo) CELEBRITY POKER SHOWDOWN -- Christopher Meloni, Jason Alexander, Macy Gray, Jorge Garcia, Fred Savage, Jennifer Tilly and Michael Ian Black bet and bluff their way to a $1 million prize pool for Hurricane Katrina charities. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- In the season premiere of this weekly trip down Illusion Lane, Mr. Angel merges mind, body and spirit to float from one building to another. 10 P.M. (BBC America) BAD LAD'S ARMY -- Thirty young petty criminals turn to military life to mend their ways in this new British documentary series, and transform themselves from boys into men in the process. 10 P.M. (MTV) THE HILLS -- On ''Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County,'' Lauren Conrad (right) was the emotional blonde who wore every smidgen of excitement or frustration on her face, sometimes both at once. This offshoot trails her to Los Angeles, where she attends the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising and flits through the offices of Teen Vogue. 10:30 P.M. (MTV) CHEYENNE -- When she was 8, she booked her own nightclub gigs. At 10, she was named America's Most Talented Kid. Now, at 15, Cheyenne Kimball is about to become a rock star. Come on, she's got her own show. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

An article on Saturday about a proposal to build a new Madison Square Garden one block west to make room for a grander Pennsylvania Station misstated the name of the architectural firm that worked on the original Penn Station and designed the James A. Farley Post Office, whose western end would be occupied by the new Garden. It was McKim, Mead & White, not McKim, Meade & Wright.

Treasury secretaries are typically called upon to give up control of investments in companies that may pose a conflict of interest. Mr. Paulson is no exception. If he is confirmed, ethics rules could force him to give up authority over most of his $700 million stake in Goldman Sachs. As Treasury secretary, Mr. Paulson will make $175,700, not much more than a junior investment banker; last year at Goldman Sachs, he made more than $38 million. BY ERIC DASH, PAGE C5

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Military Files Contradict Marine Accounts of Raid A military investigator uncovered evidence in February and March that contradicted repeated assertions by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha last November had been the victims of a roadside bomb, according to a senior military official. A1 War Not the Only Killer in Darfur While the war in Darfur, Sudan, has set off what the United Nations has called the ''world's worst humanitarian crisis,'' these days most people in the region die not from bullets, but because they cannot get health care, clean water or enough food. A1 Europe Court Rejects Air Pact The European Union's highest court ruled that the European Union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism. A1 Quake Victims Waiting for Aid Three days after a powerful earthquake rocked Indonesia, killing roughly 5,700 people, many devastated villages within the two worst-hit districts had yet to receive any help, residents said. A10 Somali Gunmen Seize Hospital Discarding the neutrality of hospitals in Somalia's long civil conflict, gunmen allied with a warlord linked to the United States seized control of a medical facility in Mogadishu, causing many wounded patients to flee and reducing medical services to a minimum. A8 For Support, U.S. Shifts on Iran The Bush administration, seeking to enlist Russian support for a United Nations Security Council resolution on Iran, has agreed to language ruling out the immediate threat of military force against Iran, American and European officials said. A10 NATIONAL A14-17 Officials Sternly Advise Hurricane Preparations Officials in hurricane-prone states are trumpeting dire warnings about the coming storm season, preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well.
