A16 F.B.I. Calls Off Search for Hoffa The F.B.I. called off its search for the remains of James R. Hoffa, saying it found no trace of him on a horse farm in Michigan. New surveys suggest that the global AIDS epidemic has begun to slow, with a decline in new H.I.V. infections in about 10 countries, the head of the United Nations AIDS program said in a report. He pledged to confront ''the crisis of leadership'' in Albany with the same zeal he used to pursue Wall Street executives as the state's aggressive attorney general. B1 Friend Testifies in Bias Trial Frankie Agostini, a childhood friend of Nicholas Minucci, a white man accused of a bias attack against a black man in Queens, testified during Mr. Minucci's trial that the defendant repeatedly used a racial epithet before, during and after the attack. B1 Librarians Break Silence Four Connecticut librarians who were barred from revealing that they had received a request for patrons' records from the federal government finally spoke out, expressing frustration about the sweeping powers given to law enforcement authorities in what is known as the U.S.A. To the Editor: Americans will no doubt express appropriate outrage, and sadness, at the apparently senseless slaughter of two dozen Iraqi civilians in Haditha. But can we as easily absolve ourselves for the thousands of civilian deaths that were a predictable and inevitable outcome of our war of choice?

I.B.M. said that its back-office operations in India had more than tripled in the last two years, to 20,000 employees. I.B.M. acquired an office services company, Daksh, in New Delhi in early 2004 when it had 6,000 employees. I.B.M. is India's largest multinational employer, with 43,000 employees, an increase from 9,000 in early 2004. The growth has been driven by the rapidly expanding demand for outsourced services by its customers. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

A report in Sunday Styles this week about the marriage of Alison Dykstra and Andrew Schulman contained an outdated reference to Gretchen Dykstra, a sister of the bride, at whose home the wedding ceremony took place. After the section had gone to press, Gretchen Dykstra resigned from her post as president of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation.

AMES--Margaret L (Peggie). May 16, 2006 of heart failure in Linthicum, MD. She was born in Argentina on August 24, 1911, raised in Staten Island and Chappaqua and lived in Greenwich Village for more than fifty years. She served in The American Red Cross in World War II, was a travel agent in New York for many years and a member of The Overseas Service League and The 41-74 Club. She enjoyed scrabble, bridge and a tot of bourbon, and was beloved of family and friends. Her survivors are seven nieces and nephews, numerous grand and great grands, and her adored dog, Runtley. She was the daughter of Edward Winslow Ames, and Katherine Millicent (Johnson) Ames, and the sister of Melita Ames Johnson and Winslow Ames, all deceased. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of The Chesakpeake, 445 Defense Highway, Annapolis, MD 21401.

SOKOLOFF -- Alice Hunt. Died April 29, 2006 in Sun Valley, Idaho. She was born in New York, June 3, 1912, the daughter of the late Dr. James Ramsay Hunt, professor of neurology at Columbia University, who was arguably the pre-eminent neurologist of the 20th century. Her mother was the late Alice St. John Nolan, of Springfield, Illinois. She survived her beloved husband, Dr. Boris Sokoloff, originally of St. Petersburg, Russia, who first came to this country at the invitation of the Rockefeller Institute from the Pasteur Institute in Paris. He also worked at Sloan Kettering and University of Washington Cancer Research Center, authored 27 books, and ended his career as head of The Cancer Research Laboratory at Florida Southern College. He also was editor of the scientific journal, Growth. Her much loved brother was the late James Ramsay Hunt Jr., former intelligence officer with the CIA. She was a loving and beloved mother to Kiril, of Boca Raton, Florida, and Sun Valley, Idaho, and leaves behind her precious grandchildren, Jay and Emily Sokoloff. As the last of her generation by more than 25 years, she was a loving aunt to four nieces and nephews, to whom she was a mainstay of support over the years, and was great-aunt to twelve great-nieces and nephews. Alice was a precocious student, being admitted to Radcliffe when she was only 16. A child of the Depression, she was obliged to leave college after only one year and worked as a researcher and writer in New York City. She was an accomplished pianist and musician who studied composition with Rubin Goldmark and Constantin Shvedoff. She wrote in many different forms and her works include a symphony, several shorter orchestral pieces, three string quartets and works for solo instruments and various chamber groups, several of which have been performed at Carnegie Hall. She was a pupil of Alexander Siloti, considered the greatest pianist of his day as well as a student of Franz Liszt, whose daughter, Cosima Wagner, was the subject of one of Alice's three biographies. Another biography was entitled Hadley: The First Mrs. Hemmingway. It is generally regarded that ''A Movable Feast'' by Ernest Hemmingway was written by Ernest as a love story for his first wife. The other biography was a riches to rags story, the life of Kate Chase Smith, who was the daughter of Salmon Chase, Secretary of the Treasury, under Lincoln who experienced a tragic fall. For 25 years, Alice wrote classical music reviews for a syndicate of newspapers. In her spare time, she wrote mystery stories, which were published in many popular magazines. When her husband died in 1979, she returned to her roots in Westchester County, where she spent many years as a volunteer in the oncology department of Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. She considered this the most rewarding work of her life. Sharp until the end, she was passionately interested in current affairs. She considered her childhood summers on the farm in Katonah, New York to have shaped her life. A great dog lover, she took much interest in the myriad canine personalities who became a part of her life over the years. Her loving devotion to and involvement in the lives of the younger members of her family was a sustaining pleasure for her and for them. A memorial service will take place on Saturday, June 3, 2006, 2 P.M. at St. Matthew's Church, in Bedford, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to the Idaho Compassion.

HELLINGER--Roslind (nee Codos). Loving wife to George, deceased in 1989,loving mother to Carol and Andrew, grandmother to Sophie, mother-in-law to Audrey and Frank. Lifetime member of Scarsdale Hadassah & ORT. Graveside ceremony and interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY 1pm, June 1st.

Chinatown Brasserie is a good half-mile north of Chinatown, but it is dim sum central. This 275-seat duplex, owned by John McDonald and Joshua Pickard, is to open tomorrow at 380 Lafayette Street (Great Jones Street), in the former Time Cafe location. It will serve more than 40 varieties of dim sum, including Shanghai-style soup dumplings, delicate pot stickers, steamed seafood dumplings, crispy beef and mushroom triangles, steamed pork buns and roast duck dumplings, off a menu (no rolling carts) from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. There is a shorter list at dinner.

Goldman Sachs has blazed a path on Wall Street, transforming itself from a traditional investment bank to a fast-growing investing giant. Its president, Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be the next chief executive, has been instrumental in sharpening this focus. So far, the results have been impressive. Some employees and clients wonder, though, whether the strategy is skewing Goldman's longtime focus on putting the client first. BY JENNY ANDERSON, PAGE C1

Culture Minister George Voulgarakis escaped a terrorist attack when a powerful bomb exploded near his home in central Athens, wrecking a string of parked cars but causing no injuries. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but police and security officials said the bombing bore the hallmarks of the Revolutionary Struggle, a band of militant extremists active since 2003, when the police cracked down on Greece's most deadly terrorist group, November 17. Mr. Voulgarakis, 46, who was until February the minister for security, said he been threatened in recent weeks for his suspected role in the illegal interrogation of a group of Pakistanis last year. ANTHEE CARASSAVA (NYT)

A Bronx man was convicted in State Supreme Court yesterday of raping and murdering his former girlfriend in the parking lot of a Metro-North train station, prosecutors said. The man, Ariel Menendez, 27, faces a minimum of 20 years to life in prison, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said that Mr. Menendez attacked and strangled Elizabeth Butler, 17, in her family's car, which was parked at the Croton Falls station near the market where Ms. Butler, a senior at North Salem High School, worked.

Officials with the Astros and Roger Clemens's agent denied that Clemens was about to re-sign with the club, but the Yankees were proceeding as if he would be playing again with Houston. Yankees Manager Joe Torre said Tuesday that he expected Clemens to return to Houston for the same reasons he went there: to be close to his family and to play with Andy Pettitte, his friend and former Yankees teammate.

BACK in the 1950's, when there were plenty of fish in the oceans and rivers, Americans -- other than Catholics on Friday -- had little interest in them. But now that we have discovered the pleasures and benefits of eating fish, many varieties are nearly depleted and many have been tainted by industrial pollution.

With the stock market showing signs of weakness, the administration has reached out to Henry M. Paulson Jr. to bring calm. But in some ways, he is an executive in the mold of Paul H. O'Neill, a Treasury secretary who was forced out by a White House that could not accept his contrarian tendencies. Like Mr. O'Neill, he has strong views on economic policies that support balanced budgets, which may not be consistent with administration policies. BY LANDON THOMAS Jr., PAGE C1

The European Union's highest court found that Ireland, which wants Britain to close an aging nuclear power plant with a poor safety record, had illegally appealed to a United Nations tribunal when it should have used the Union's internal legal procedures. The Irish government says the nuclear waste reprocessing facility at Sellafield, about 60 miles from the Irish coast, pollutes the Irish Sea with radioactive waste that includes Technetium 99. Irish officials said they would continue efforts to close the plant. BRIAN LAVERY (NYT)

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 18 about high-speed Internet service available through cellular carriers referred incorrectly to the hardware from one carrier, Verizon Wireless. Its 5740 card, used to receive the data signal, is available with support for Apple computers, not simply PC's. The article also referred imprecisely to an international plan offered by Cingular. While the $140-a-month plan is available on a limited basis to business customers, it will not be offered more widely until the summer.

To the Editor: Re ''Iraqis' Accounts Link Marines to the Mass Killing of Civilians'' (front page, May 29):

The city school system's top testing official announced yesterday that she would resign at the end of this school year. The official, Lori Mei, 50, has played a central role in implementing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's education initiatives, including new promotion rules tied to standardized test scores for third, fifth and seventh graders. Ms. Mei has worked for the city schools for 23 years. Her announcement highlighted tensions between her office, the Department of Assessment and Accountability, and James S. Liebman, a former law professor who was hired by Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein in January as the system's chief accountability officer. Ms. Mei will be succeeded by her deputy, Jennifer K. Bell-Elwanger. DAVID M. HERSZENHORN (NYT)

To the Editor: Owen West honors those who fight our battles and decries the delegation of this task to a ''small cadre of volunteers,'' and I agree. But there is a world of difference in historical perceptions between those like Major West, who argue for continuing the war in Iraq, and those of us who disagree.

Consolidated Edison said yesterday that improper wiring of a streetlight resulted in the stray voltage that injured an 8-year-old Great Kills girl. The child's feet were burned when she stepped on a service box on the sidewalk outside her home on Brookfield Avenue on Monday. ''Our records show that Con Edison crews replaced the wiring on this streetlight on Feb. 9 of this year, and we are investigating the work that had been done,'' said a Con Ed spokesman, Michael S. Clendenin. He said the wiring was repaired yesterday. The detection and control of stray voltage has been a major concern of city officials since a Manhattan pedestrian was electrocuted in 2004. ''It is very serious,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. ''Con Ed, from what I can tell, is diligently trying. It is a complex problem, and sadly, you're probably always going to have some risks.'' He said the utility should not be fined because the costs would simply be passed on to customers. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

PROFESSIONAL chefs will have you think they are calm, with their measured approach to winning ''Iron Chef'' battles and their patient guidance during cooking demos. But in their busy kitchens they're no different from the rest of us: panicked when guests arrive early and dinner is nowhere near done. Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli excepted. Even when their two Frankies Spuntino restaurants -- on Court Street in Brooklyn and Clinton Street in Manhattan -- are packed, they rarely break a sweat.

CASSON--Dr. Phillip Raynor. Died on May 29 following a recent illness. Born in Sydney, Australia, Dr. Casson graduated from the Sydney High Boys School and went on to attend the Sydney University medical School. After graduating with a BS and MB in medicine he went to Broome, Australia, to work as a surgeon in the Flying Doctor's Service, the airplane-based medical unit that made it possible for resident of the Australian Outback to receive emergency medical care. Dr. Casson then spent 12 years as a practicing surgeon in England, becoming a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons in 1958. He came to the United States in 1959 to do a Fellowship in head and neck cancer at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital. In 1963, he joined the staff at the New York University Medical Center at the urging of Dr. John Converse, who had recently founded the Institute of Reconstructive and Plastic Surgery at the hospital. There, Dr. Casson became involved in pioneering transplant research, most notably in that being conducted by Dr. Jean Dausset of Paris, France. Along with Dr. Converse and the late Dr. Felix Rapaport, Dr. Casson helped Dr. Dausset investigate the significance of tissue typing and histocompatibility in facilitating the successful transplantations of human organs, groundbreaking ideas in the medical field and for which Dr. Dausset received the 1980 Nobel Prize. Dr. Casson remained on the staff of NYU Medical Center as an Associate Professor of Plastic Surgery until his retirement in 2004. He was also an Assistant Attending Surgeon at Tisch Hospital and an Associate Attending Surgeon at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. He was a member of the American College of Surgeons, the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery and the Transplant Society. He was also a founding member of the Pawling Mountain Club in Pawling, NY. Dr. Casson will be remembered as a warm and caring husband, father and physician. A gifted surgeon who made enduring contributions to the medical community, he remained a mentor to many surgeons who trained under him over the course of his long career. He was an avid sportsman and oenophile who enjoyed the company of a wide variety of friends who shared his interests and sense of humor. He is survived by his loving wife Rosemary and daughters, Nicole, Victoria and Lindsay. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in his memory to the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 317 East 34th Street, Suite 901, New York, NY 10016. A memorial service will be held on June 1st at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, at 3 P.M.

After the final two women left on ''The Apprentice'' turned on each other in last week's episode, Donald Trump decided to fire them both for disloyal behavior. That left Sean and Lee as the finalists, and the two men competed in Monday's penultimate episode. NBC's ''Apprentice'' did not benefit from being one of the few original offerings on the prime-time schedule; in Nielsen's estimates, it brought in 9.63 million viewers, in line with its average for this edition. But NBC performed steadily, and its ''Deal or No Deal'' rerun at 8 p.m. was the night's most-watched show, with 13.66 million viewers, making the network No. 1 among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. On ABC the fourth game of the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference finals was broadcast live, so its ratings were preliminary. But it appeared to put the network in a tie with CBS for second place in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

A director at a private Manhattan elementary school has been charged with sexually abusing two former students, prosecutors said yesterday. The defendant, Lina Sinha, 40, who was a teacher at the Montessori International School of New York, was initially charged last fall with abusing one student, but charges were added at yesterday's indictment. The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said that Ms. Sinha was also charged with bribing one student not to testify before a grand jury. Gerald Shargel, her lawyer, said she took a polygraph test that indicated ''she was telling the truth when she denied the allegations.'' Ms. Sinha, who has pleaded not guilty, is on leave from the school.

The Indianapolis 500's rating for Sunday's broadcast on ABC fell 21.5 percent to a 5.1 (or 5.6 million TV households), from a 6.5 (or 7.1 million homes), despite the excitement of the second-closest finish in the race's history when Sam Hornish Jr. passed Marco Andretti with 150 yards to go.

WITH Spanish reds, whether rustic or refined, you can't go wrong with lamb. Though the mencía grape and the Bierzo wines made from it tended to tip the scale in the direction of rusticity, Bierzo is a region in transition, where modern winemaking is changing the flavor profile. Repeat: You can't go wrong with lamb, specifically, lamb on the grill. Because I found hints of rosemary in both the bouquet of some of these wines and on my palate, I decided to let this herb carry the day. You can't go wrong with rosemary, either.

AS European techniques have their inevitable impact on Asian desserts -- a trend you see both in Asia and in the United States -- it's pleasant to turn to a traditional Thai dessert, one that, oddly enough, reminds me of American strawberry shortcake. With mangoes, sticky rice and coconut milk, you have a sweet-and-acidic fruit over a sweetened starch topped with a sweet ''cream.'' O.K., it's not a perfect analogy, but with mango season in full swing, it's a great dessert. At this time of year the price of mangoes falls and their quality rises. The small, deep yellow Champagne mangoes are abundant now, and the standard red-green variety is sold ripe for a change.

A caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Monday about a grief camp for children who lost a parent to the wars in Afghanistan or Iraq misstated the name of a boy who met with a mentor. He is Johnathan Lane, not Jonathan Lake.

LEE--Mike of Shandaken, NY on May 20, 2006. Surviving are his wife Ulla. A memorial service will be June 3 at 10 am at the Evergreen Funeral Home, Inc, Brooklyn. Memorials may be made to the Mike & Ulla Lee Foundation, 51 N. 6th St., Brooklyn 11211.
GEFFNER -- Jeannine Vergnes. Renee's remembrance said it all. Je T'Aime. Dave

To the Editor: As a 74-year-old (5-foot-1, 105-pound) woman, I can't tell you how delighted I was to read that my preference in clothing has become ''more youthful, skin-baring and tighter-fitting'' even if it does not fit as well.
To the Editor: I mourn the end of the petite department, but I would also like to see an end to the ''petite'' euphemism.

HEFT--Edwin. Age 92 on May 30th in Stratford, CT. Beloved husband, devoted father, grandfather, great grandfather, cherished brother and humanitarian. Services Thursday 1:00 PM at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.
To the Editor: The controversy over television for preschoolers and infants (news article, May 25) is just the latest in the series of pronouncements of experts clashing with the reality of parents.

General Electric said that it was projecting $8 billion in revenue in India by 2010, up from a year-earlier forecast of $5 billion, while simultaneously setting a goal of $8 billion in assets in the country. Speaking to the Bombay Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Mumbai, the G.E. chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, said the company intended to rapidly expand its industrial and financial presence in the country. G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., has units and joint ventures in India spanning technology and back-office outsourcing, credit cards, consumer finance, hospitals, aviation and real estate. Mr. Immelt said G.E. would enter the banking sector when the regulatory guidelines changed. SARITHA RAI (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''Where's the Petite Department? Going the Way of the Petticoat'' (front page, May 28):

SOBEL--Helen. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on May 26th of Helen Sobel, beloved mother of our friend and partner, Marilyn Sobel. We express our deepest sympathies to Marilyn and to all other members of the family.

BACK in the 1950's, when there were plenty of fish in the oceans and rivers, Americans -- other than Catholics on Friday -- had little interest in them. But now that we have discovered the pleasures and benefits of eating fish, many varieties are nearly depleted and many have been tainted by industrial pollution. The information put out by food safety and environmental organizations paints a discouraging and sometimes confusing picture about which seafood to eat. They list dozens of species whose well-being is threatened by overfishing; fish whose harvesting threatens species that are accidentally caught and discarded; and fish that contain dangerous levels of mercury, PCB's and pesticides. Some people simply ignore the warnings.

ZIEGELLAUB--Hannah, 61 died May 29, 2006 in New York City of complications from Multiple Sclerosis. She is predeceased by her beloved husband Michael Brussell and her parents Dora and Detch Ziegellaub. Hannah was a consummate visual artist, a passionate social justice activist, and an extraordinary friend. Survivors include her devoted sister Mimi Ziegellaub, her brother-in-law Richard Eichler, her loving niece Emmy, close family friend Mimi Arsham, Irene and Veronica Selver and her cousin Ruthie Seglow with whom she grew up like sisters, and by her extended family and her legion of friends whose sorrow travels the globe. From all of us who love you.

Only days after Singapore announced that it had awarded its first casino license to Las Vegas Sands, its neighbor and occasional rival Malaysia said it aimed to put a tourist theme park across the narrow strait that divides the two countries, possibly a Disneyland. An official from the prime minister's office said that the government was in talks with the Walt Disney Company and the company that operates Tokyo Disneyland, Oriental Land, about the possibility of building a park in Johor, Malaysia's southernmost state. But the official said that Disney was just one of several options Malaysia was exploring. A spokeswoman for Disney in Hong Kong, where the company opened a park in September, told The Associated Press that Disney was frequently in discussions about potential parks but had made no commitment to a Malaysian park. WAYNE ARNOLD (NYT)
KLEIN--Barry. On your birthday & everyday I love you and miss you more than words can say.

ENLANDER - Caron. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of a distinguished member of the Presidium of the Yeshiva University Women's Organization, which honored her recently at its Opera Gala. She was internationally respected as a major leader in the diamond industry, and a role model for women in the business world. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her beloved and devoted husband, Derek Enlander, MD, a Board member of YU's Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration, and, with his wife, a Guardian of YU; to her beloved mother, Valerie Weiss, and to her cherished brother, Jeffrey (and Robyn) Weiss. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees $(6$)ENLANDER--Caron. With enormous grief, sadness and pain, I remember Caron for her courage, dignity, and the magic she brought to my life. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. To the Editor: Re ''British Teachers Favor Call to Boycott Israelis'' (news article, May 30):
State G.O.P. Convention Rebuffs Weld and Backs Faso for GovernorBy Patrick Healy (with audio)

I'm not used to being a cheerleader for the Bush administration. But when I saw recently that the president had convened a National Math Panel to study, in part, the effectiveness of teaching kids so-called "constructivist" math, I stood up, put my hand over my heart and shouted, "Amen."

Feel the need to get a handle on the basic rules of soccer before the games begin? Wondering just how so many quite different games all came to be called "football"? Help is at hand, in the form of a recently published edition of modern soccer's very first rule book, The Rules of Association Football, 1863, from the Bodleian Library at Oxford.

As a student in Baghdad, I am mostly focused on my studies. It wasn't always this way. Before I started my blog in February 2005, my studies were the only thing I thought about; my whole life was forming around them. That changed when I started blogging, making online friends, and meeting people outside my country. But as time passed, I realized that I was keeping this online part of my life hidden from my offline friends. I discovered that I could not really explain what blogging was all about to any of my friends. So now I am living two different lives, one online and one offline. It sometimes seems that I keep a different personality for each of them.

As word spread about controversial remarks by the state Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, his Republican opponent, J. Christopher Callaghan, stood happily under the media spotlight talking about flub.

Schumer ``will put a bullet between the President's eyes, if he could get away with it." He called the comments ``incredibly stupid and moronic'' and insisted that he is ``not a person of violence.''

Anyone who has traveled to Europe in the summertime knows that a large chunk of the Continent seems to be on vacation on any given day. This is part of the problem facing the clutch of United States-based private equity firms who are hoping to stage an initial public offering overseas, according to a story from Reuters.

It's come to our attention that some readers, new to all the mania that is global soccer culture, would like a little more annotation geared toward beginners, to supplement what one of them calls our "graduate-level material" aimed at those working toward their Ph.D's. In that spirit, freshmen take note: some readers seem not to be aware that the bearded French narrator of those "joga bonito" Nike commercials is not a character actor, or at least did not start out as a character actor. He is, in fact, a former player named Eric Cantona, who starred in the 1990's for Manchester United and, briefly, the French national team.

Brazilians' hopes for the World Cup are high, as Larry Rohter reports from Rio in today's Times. "All the stars are aligned in our favor," one fan told Rohter. "We've got the talent, the experience, a favorable draw and a steady-handed coach" -- Carlos Alberto Parreira -- "who has already guided us to one Cup."
Iraq has withdrawn from a World Cup warm-up match with Tunisia, Reuters reported today.

C. Virginia Fields, who lost her bid for the Democratic mayoral nomination last year, has ended her effort to capture the State Senate seat being vacated by David Paterson, she said in a statement. She suggested that it was the wrong time for the race. "My decision is very personal," she said. "This has been very draining on me so soon after a very grueling mayoral campaign."
The Americans may be in a "group of death," and they may not have looked terribly impressive lately, but it's also true that their opponents in that group seem to be in major disarray.

In today's El Diario there was an interesting passage about the Iran-Bosnia game played yesterday at Azadi Stadium in Tehran that didn't appear in New York's English-language papers -- or in a quick scan of other English-language papers in the United States, as far as we can tell.

Employees about to lose their jobs at H.J. Heinz may be tempted to pin the blame on billionaire investor Nelson Peltz. Heinz said Thursday it will shut down 15 plants and eliminate 2,700 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, with the savings going toward marketing and product development -- the kind of cost-cutting moves recently called for by Mr. Peltz, whose Trian Capital Management owns a 5.4 percent stake in Heinz.

Who said men of the cloth were non-partisan? Check out this bit of interesting video from the G.O.P. convention invocation, shot by Ben Smith of The Daily Politics. It shows Msgr. Jim Lisante, a Long Island pastor, urging Weld and Faso supporters not to "hate the other guy" because "the other guy, whoever he is, is still better than Eliot Spitzer." (Afterward, he seemed to indicate he was a Suozzi-leaning Republican, Ben reports.)

As the Republican state convention delegates vote on either William Weld or John Faso, there's lots of talk about loyalties here. Who keeps their promises? Which county chairmen control their delegates?
Golf may be wonderfully, maddeningly unpredictable, but one thing golfers can control is the stuff they carry.

Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Tuesday, 1 June 1784: 29 7/10 1/2; 59 1/2; NE, E, E. Deep fog, rain, rain, grey red even: Fraxinellas blow. The single white-thorn over the ash-house is one vast globe of blossoms down to the ground!

to wonder how athletes ever survived without them.

A firm agreement for NYSE Group to merge with Euronext could happen "within days," said John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, which operates the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Thain made his remarks to reporters Thursday at the NYSE's shareholders meeting, its first since it converted from a partnership to a public company.

Oracle announced yet another acquisition on Thursday. This time the target is Demantra, an Israeli startup that makes product-management software. Financial terms were not disclosed, but an Israel-based newsletter, Globes, put the price at $41 million in cash. Oracle has recently agreed to buy SleepyCat, Net4Call and Portal Software, among other companies.

Joseph Mondello just arrived at the arena where delegates are preparing to cast their vote for either William Weld or John Faso, and the Nassau County chairman repeated his recurring theme at this convention: the possibilities are endless.

Morgan Stanley on Thursday announced a small step toward the chief executive John Mack's goal of bolstering the firm's asset management business. The firm said it had bought Oxhead Capital Management, a Boston-based hedge fund led by former executives of Putnam Investments. Financial terms were not disclosed, but Oxhead is small as hedge funds go. According to its registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Oxhead has between one and five employees (not including clerical workers) and $168 million under management.

A rumor that chip giant AMD will merge with ATI, a much-smaller maker of graphics co-processors with a market capitalization of $4.2 billion, has been lifting ATI's stock in recent days. The speculation even made its way into a research report by an analyst from RBC Capital.

Follow along with all the breaking news at the World Cup as it happens on The Times Web site's Soccer page, which is right here. Today, keep your eye out for two friendlies: Norway-Korea at Oslo, and Netherlands-Mexico at Eindhoven.
These days, customized bikes aren't just for the pros. Even weekenders are tailoring off-the-rack bikes.

The battle between William Weld and John Faso just took a big turn, with the vote-rich Nassau delegation preparing to split its votes-giving each candidate half of their total 10.5 percent of the weighted vote, according to an official who has spoken with Joseph Mondello, the county chairman.

Slate editor Jacob Weisberg is the latest writer to develop a crush on Al Gore after watching his global-warming documentary, "An Inconvenient Truth." But unlike most liberal pundits, Weisberg thinks the movie's power is an indication that Gore would be making a mistake by running for president again. After hearing Gore speak at "a post-screening party in New York last week," Weisberg writes: "The premise of the exchange was that we made a big mistake not electing him the last time, and we'd be lucky if he gave us another chance. I couldn't agree more with the first statement. About the second, I continue to have my doubts."

A media-focused investment company, Veronis Suhler Stevenson, has named three managing directors: Trent Hickman, David Holland and Nick Veronis. All three had been associates at the firm for six years, Veronis Suhler said.
FasoWeldFasoWeldFasoWeld.
Curmudgeon David Pogue reviews the MovieBeam, a box that connects directly to your TV set and holds 100 movies on its hard drive.
A spate of big management-led buyouts has bankers guessing which companies might be next.

The student loan provider SLM Corporation, which is known as Sallie Mae, said on Thursday it had agreed to buy Upromise, a saving-for-college company, to be able to offer parents a comprehensive financial package to cover college costs. Terms were not disclosed.

XTO Energy said on Thursday it had agreed to purchase Peak EnergyResources, a privately held company that produces natural gas in north Texas, for 2.555 million XTO shares, valued at about $105 million.

Frank Quattrone said in a statement today that NASD's Department of Enforcement withdrew all its charges against him. The agency had accused him of "spinning" -- doling out hot I.P.O.'s to corporate clients in exchange for business -- and misusing his oversight of Credit Suisse First Boston's research department to direct favorable coverage for clients. NASD's decision to drop the matter marks the third major win for Mr. Quattrone in the past year. His conviction on obstruction of justice charges was overturned and a lifetime ban from the securities business reversed. The Justice Department could still decide to retry the obstruction of justice case against Mr. Quattrone.
Textron, the diversified manufacturer, said Thursday it had agreed to sell its fastening systems business to Platinum Equity, a private equity firm based in California, for $630 million.

As executive pay packages have rocketed in recent years, their defenders have contended that because most are tied to company performance, they are both earned and deserved. But investors who plow through company filings often find that executive compensation exceeds the amounts allowed under the performance targets set by the directors.
General Electric and Credit Suisse Group will team up in a $1 billion project to invest in infrastructure projects worldwide, the companies announced Wednesday.

A debt restructuring agreement between Eurotunnel and some of its major creditors ran into opposition after a group claiming to speak for holders of 30 percent of the debt said they would reject the proposals, despite the chairman's threat to file for bankruptcy if the deal is not approved.

The former chief executive of Gateway, Jeffrey Weitzen, won the dismissal of a fraud lawsuit after a federal judge said the Securities and Exchange Commission had not provided evidence of intentional wrongdoing.
Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, has defended his decision to increase spending next year and has signaled he is unlikely to increase the company's share buyback plan.
The European Commission issued one of its largest fines against a cartel on Wednesday when it found five acrylic glass makers guilty of colluding and fixing prices.
Teck Cominco's chief executive, Don Lindsay, said Inco shareholders favor his $16.4 billion takeover bid over Inco's plan to combine with rival nickel miner Falconbridge.

As the government's demands for waiver of privilege in white-collar prosecutions have sparked the ire of attorneys worried about the sanctity of client communications, the waiver issue in the Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman case is presenting an especially prickly problem.
Chung Mong Koo, Hyundai Motor's chairman, went on trial Thursday in Seoul on charges of embezzling funds from Hyundai, South Korea's largest carmaker, to bribe bank and government officials.

Sun Microsystems' Jonathan Schwartz wasted no time heeding Wall Street's calls for blood, swinging the ax on up to 5,000 employees only five weeks after taking over as chief executive of the troubled computer hardware company from Sun co-founder Scott McNealy.

Shareholders of the Exxon Mobil Corporation, whose last chief executive took home $147 million when he retired, overwhelmingly rejected resolutions at the company's annual meeting on Wednesday to rein in compensation.
One reached the pinnacle of wealth and prestige as a dealmaker on Wall Street. The other was an academic superstar, brilliant but somewhat shy and more at ease in Bermuda shorts than suits.
Vector Capital, a buyout firm focused on software makers, renewed its two-month effort to buy the Internet-security company WatchGuard Technologies by disclosing an offer price of $5.10 a share.
Lillian Vernon has changed hands for the second time in less than two years, with Sun Capital Partners deciding to try its hand at turning around the troubled catalogue retailer.
Turkish drinks company Mey Icki, the maker of raki, the country's most famous tipple, said on Thursday a private equity firm, Texas Pacific Group, had bought 90 percent of the company.
ChoiceStream has raised $13.1 million in Series B financing to bring its online personalization software to mobile phones and television set-top boxes.

A Chinese IT outsourcing company, Worksoft Creative Software Technology has worked up another $30 million in venture capital to fund acquisitions of companies in the United States and to make a run at a Nasdaq listing.

Proteolix closed its series B round of venture funding after raising $45 million. The South San Francisco biotech company said Wednesday that Delphi Ventures led the round and that Deepa Pakianathan, a Delphi partner, took a seat on the Proteolix board.

The New York Board of Trade, looking to use ethanol listings as a way to increase its commodities trading ahead of a possible I.P.O. of its own, received a visit Wednesday from the winner of the Indianapolis 500.

Bank of China shares surged 15 percent on Thursday as they made their opening in Hong Kong and were snapped up by investors eager to tap into the sizzling Chinese economy. The bank, China's No. 2 lender, raised $9.7 billion from its initial public offering, the world's biggest in six years.

Google on Wednesday poured cold water on speculation that it may be poised for a big buy. Company executives said they were looking toward big-name partnerships instead of major merger deals to expand Google's customer base.

Goldman Sachs' chief executive, Henry Paulson, has not departed for Washington quickly enough to avoid yet another accusation the investment bank abused its market power. This one revolves around NRG Energy's rejection of Mirant's $8 billion hostile bid on the basis its former adviser, Goldman, betrayed its confidence.

Fiduciary Trust International, a New York bank catering to the super-rich, allegedly fired its watchdog compliance officer after he tried to blow the whistle on an unexplained $2 billion found in an account used by one of the Sultan of Brunei's three wives.

Richard Kinder did not consider himself lucky when he quit Enron after losing out to a college classmate, Kenneth L. Lay, for the top job. Ten years later, Mr. Lay is facing jail; Mr. Kinder is leading a record management buyout.
Merrill Lynch Investment Managers faces disciplinary action in Japan for allegedly breaching securities laws in the country.

Citigroup, the Goldman Sachs Group and 13 other financial service companies have agreed to pay a total of $13 million to settle claims that they favored some customers in the $200 billion market for auction-rate bonds.
Oil and natural gas exploration and production company Pogo Producing said it intends to offer $400 million of senior subordinated notes due 2013 in a private offering to repay senior debt.

Fisher Communications said Wednesday that it is selling 24 small-market radio stations in Washington and Montana, and plans to reinvest the money in the pending acquisition of a Spanish-language TV station and other potential broadcast deals.
Six former Knight Ridder newspapers awaited word on their fate Wednesday as McClatchy collected offers on the final day of bidding for the newspapers, the last of 12 that McClatchy intends to sell.

Motorola, the world's second-largest mobile phone maker, said on Thursday it had agreed to buy Britain's TTP Communications, which develops software for 3G applications, for 103 million pounds ($193.5 million).
Shares of ATI Technologies jumped 9 percent Wednesday after a Wall Street analyst said the graphics chip maker might be acquired by Advanced Micro Devices, the PC microprocessor maker.

Despite moves on the part of dissident shareholders, the Lexar Media shareholder meeting can proceed for a vote on the company's proposed $688 million merger with Micron Technology, company officials said Wednesday evening.

Scottish and Southern Energy, the British power company, has appointed Credit Suisse First Boston to examine a possible move into the water industry and may join a consortium to bid for Thames Water, which has been put up for sale by its German parent RWE.

The governor of the Bank of Italy, Mario Draghi, said Wednesday that the central bank would put an end to protectionist tendencies that have recently thwarted several cross-border bank mergers and kept some investors leery of the Italian economy.
When United Breweries, the world's third-largest spirits company, said Monday that it had withdrawn from the bidding for the Champagne maker Taittinger, it cited a local reaction to its Indian roots.

Nasdaq's chief executive, Robert Greifeld, is clearly not sprinting to close a deal with the London Stock Exchange. In a meeting with his counterpart, Clara Furse, yesterday at the London exchange's headquarters, Mr. Greifeld did not raise the possibility of a friendly takeover of the exchange, nor even the possibility of any form of co-operation or strategic venture, according to The Telegraph.

Tabcorp Holdings, Australia's biggest gaming company, offered A$1.9 billion ($1.4 billion) in cash and stock for Unitab, topping an agreed bid from Tattersall's.

The body of a woman who had been fatally stabbed and burned and left in an isolated wildlife preserve was identified yesterday as that of Desiree Cherry, 36, who had been missing for four days, the police said. The identification was made from dental X-rays, said Ellen S. Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner's office. She said Ms. Cherry died of stab wounds to her chest and neck and had been burned after she died. Two bicyclists found the body on Saturday, several feet from a footpath in the Fresh Creek Preserve. She was last seen leaving her home on Schenectady Avenue at 10:30 p.m. on May 23 and was later reported missing by relatives, the police said. Friends said Ms. Cherry immigrated from St. Lucia nearly two decades ago and worked a few nights a week at a small go-go club in Plainfield, N.J., so she could be home days to raise her son, now 14. A cousin of Ms. Cherry's, Jecoliah Fortune-O'Brien, 22, said,

Two New Jersey couples were killed yesterday when the single-engine plane they were in broke apart and crashed in a wooded area in Ocean County, scattering small pieces of the craft on rooftops and in the yards in a small community of bungalows and narrowly missing a major highway, the authorities said.

Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, signed legislation cutting property taxes by almost $16 billion over the next two years and granting public school teachers a $2,000 raise. The legislation was passed in a special session to bring the Texas public school system into compliance with a State Supreme Court order. The one-third reduction in property tax revenue would be offset by a new, higher levy on business, a $1 per-pack increase in cigarette taxes and a portion of the state's $8 billion treasury surplus. The legislation also provides increased per-pupil aid to school districts and bonuses for teachers whose students demonstrate improvement.

More than a dozen family members of miners killed in a southeastern Kentucky mine explosion protested a closed-door hearing held in Harlan by state officials investigating the blast. Tracy Stumbo, the state's lead investigator in the blast, and other officials began interviewing about 25 employees and executives of the mine's operator, Kentucky Darby LLC. The May 20 blast at the Darby Mine No. 1 killed five miners. State officials rejected a request this week that representatives of the miners' families have access to the interviews and be able to ask the witnesses questions. Susan Bush, the state's natural resources commissioner, said Tuesday that the state wanted witnesses to be as comfortable and forthcoming as possible.

Struggling to cope with a 1,000-plus percent annual inflation rate, Zimbabwe introduced a new $100,000 bank note, double the $50,000 note that had been the largest denomination in circulation. Still, the new note is only worth about one American dollar at official exchange rates, and draws only about 30 American cents on the black market, which more accurately reflects its value. The new note may help ease a growing currency shortage. The United Nations regional news agency quoted Zimbabwe Reserve Bank officials as saying that the country had run short of money after the government ran out of the foreign exchange needed to buy the imported ink and paper required to print bills.

Youths wielding machetes battled in Dili, the capital, as troops from New Zealand bolstered a foreign force struggling to stop the unrest that has destabilized the country. Roaming bands fired slingshots, threw rocks and hacked rivals with machetes. Australian forces have failed to keep the warring bands apart. .

Chinese authorities closed 201 medical clinics in northern Hebei Province and fined several hundred others because they helped detect and abort female fetuses, the New China News Agency said. The government has been trying to cut down on selective-sex abortions, which are partly responsible for a lopsided birth ratio of 117 male births to 100 female births. It has long banned medical personnel from disclosing the sex of a fetus. But the practice remains widespread because China enforces strict population controls.

Archaeologists report in the journal Nature that an analysis of stone tools on the Indonesian island of Flores show that the diminutive species there up to 12,000 years ago probably inherited its toolmaking tradition from pre-Homo sapiens inhabitants as early as 800,000 years ago. In the most detailed investigation yet of the illness and death of Slobodan Milosevic, the former president of Serbia, the war crimes tribunal in The Hague said in a report that no evidence of foul play or suicide was found but that during his trial Mr. Milosevic took serious risks with his own health by not taking all prescribed drugs, taking other medicines of his own and repeatedly refusing treatment, tests and even hospitalization. The 42-page report was prepared by the tribunal judge, Kevin Parker, from Australia.

FIAMMA--August E. ''Gus'', of Merrick, NY and recently Boca Raton, FL, on May 27, 2006. Beloved Husband for 54 years of Loretta. Loving father of Stephen, Ronald, Eugene and Susan. Adored father-in-law of Fabrizia and Giancarlo. Deeply loved grandfather of Lavinia, Maria Cristina, Diego, Flavia and Gianpaolo. Gus was always known for his big smile, hearty laugh and generous personality. Among his greatest pleasures were his grandchildren, travel, the beach and his lefty golf game. He will be deeply missed by his friends on Wall Street and the NYSE, at Hempstead Golf Club and by every other dear friend and family member who had the pleasure of knowing him. We miss you Gus...Dad...Grandpa...and we will always love you. Viewing Saturday 6/3 and Sunday 6/4, 2-5pm and 7-9pm N.F. Walker Funeral Home, Merrick, NY 516-378-0303. Funeral Mass Monday 6/5 9:45am Cure of Ars Church, Merrick, NY.

The Critic's Choice column on Tuesday, about new DVD's, misspelled the given name of the pop singer who leads a reconnaissance unit in the World War II film ''Back Door to Hell.'' He is Jimmie Rodgers, not Jimmy. Because of an editing error, the column also referred incorrectly to the word ''Honeycomb.'' It was the title of a hit he recorded, not his nickname.

As rain pelted Comerica Park, Mike Mussina's body clock had already started. He had thrown most of his warm-up pitches in the bullpen, and he figured he had only three hours before he would wear down. He knew the Yankees' lineup was ravaged by injuries, and the bullpen was tired. The game against the Detroit Tigers could be a struggle. So how did Mussina pass time in the Yankees' clubhouse? He and the bullpen catcher, Mike Borzello, tried to think of actors who had starred in three long-running television series. Instead of cramming on scouting reports about Chris Shelton and Craig Monroe, Mussina was consumed with names like Michael Landon and Heather Locklear.

A group of East River piers has been transferred from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to a new agency that is developing the planned Brooklyn Bridge Park, the mayor and the governor announced yesterday. The Port Authority transferred ownership of Piers 1, 2 and 3 and part of Pier 5 to the Brooklyn Bridge Park Development Corporation. The 85-acre park, stretching from Atlantic Avenue to north of the Manhattan Bridge, is a joint effort by the city and state. City officials said Brooklyn Bridge Park would be the borough's first major new park since Prospect Park opened 135 years ago. Construction is scheduled to begin next year, and the park should be 85 percent completed by 2010, officials said.

''Last Comic Standing'' returned to NBC Tuesday night after being absent from the summer schedule last year. The comedy reality competition was a hit for the network in summer 2004, but when NBC rushed another edition into production at the end of that season, it bombed. But the two-hour premiere delivered a respectable audience of 8.51 million in Nielsen's estimates, and along with a rerun of ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (8.49 million) helped NBC easily win the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was No. 1 in total viewers, with episodes of ''NCIS'' (11.12 million) and ''The Unit'' (9.15 million) repeating well. At 10 p.m., a new ''48 Hours Mystery,'' which has moved to that time slot for the summer, brought in 9.59 million viewers and tied ''SVU'' in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

(Sundance) THE HUMAN BEHAVIOR EXPERIMENTS -- In this new documentary, Alex Gibney revisits three famous studies to explore age-old questions about why people do the things they do. The telling trio: Stanley Milgram's obedience-to-authority experiments in which subjects willingly inflict pain on another person; Philip Zimbardo's prisoner-and-guard role-play study, and the 1969 experiment at Columbia University that showed how being in a group can cause humans to behave like animals. 10:30 P.M. An art review on Saturday about ''In Pointed Style: The Gothic Revival in America, 1800-1860,'' at the Hirschl & Adler galleries on East 70th Street, referred incorrectly to the architect George Harvey. He made a painting of St. Thomas Church on Broadway, which is in the show, around 1837; he did not design it. (That was done by Josiah R. Brady.)

Three Manhattan Democrats -- Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Assemblyman Jonathan L. Bing and Borough President Scott M. Stringer -- urged the Legislature yesterday to pass a bill that would make it easier for government workers who took part in the 9/11 rescue, recovery and cleanup efforts to claim workers' compensation because of illnesses that developed after the attack. The bill would ease the workers' burden of having to prove that the illnesses were directly caused by the attack, would lift a two-year deadline for filing such claims that expired in 2003, and would allow for previously rejected claims to be heard again. The bill was introduced by Mr. Bing in the Assembly and by State Senator John J. Marchi, a Republican, in the Senate, but the politicians said they worried that the legislative session would end late this month without a final vote. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

HUNDLEY--Eleanor, on May 30th. Beloved wife of the late John Hundley, mother of Sally Bear, devoted grandmother of Sharon Terrill and John Bear, adoring great-grandmother of Sarah, Tyler, Peter and Natalie. Funeral services Thursday, 1 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, donations made to the American Red Cross or the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

Dr. John E. Niederhuber, a cancer surgeon from the University of Wisconsin, was named acting director of the National Cancer Institute, where he had served as a deputy director since last fall. Dr. Niederhuber, 67, succeeds Dr. Andrew C. von Eschenbach, who was director of the institute and is President Bush's choice to lead the Food and Drug Administration. Dr. von Eschenbach has been interim commissioner of the F.D.A. since September. DENISE GRADY (NYT)

Prince Albert of Monaco, who acknowledged paternity of a 2-year-old son last summer, was reported to have a second child, a girl, now 14 and living in California. The palace had no comment. Two French journalists wrote in Le Figaro that the girl was Jazmin Grace Rotolo, the daughter of a former waitress, Tamara Rotolo. The journalists said their source was the royal family's lawyer, Thierry Lacoste. The prince acknowledged paternity of the son, Alexandre. The two sons and two daughters of Princess Caroline are in line to inherit the throne. ARIANE BERNARD (NYT)

SUMMER entertaining has begun, and hosts are scrambling for the right paraphernalia to set up outdoors. On the other side of the table, guests are searching for gifts. Picnicware is always welcome, and melamine is a good choice to replace paper. Clear acrylic goblets come in enough sizes to suit all summer offerings, from ''ades'' to ''itas.'' 1. At Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street) or (800) 243-9810. 2. Lawn bowling is a good diversion from too much relaxation. The wood set comes with nine pins and two balls; $49 from L. L.Bean, llbean.com or (800) 441-5713. 3. A plastic serving bowl looks as good empty as it does filled with fruit salad; $18 at Mxyplyzyk. 4.Mini Bloomin' garden stakes are $38 for a set of six; target.com/redhotshop or (800) 800-8800. 5. ALDWELL - Edward. Mannes College and The New School mourn the passing of Edward Aldwell, distinguished pianist, educator, learned musician, and scholar. Over several decades, Ed taught and helped launch the careers of many pianists, unstintingly imparting his knowledge and artistry to generations of students. His groundbreaking text, ''Harmony and Voice Leading'' (co-authored with Carl Schachter), helped transform the teaching of music theory throughout the world. His immensely intelligent performances and recordings, especially of the music of J.S. Bach, are widely appreciated. He generously supported Mannes in all ways. A genuinely wise and gentle soul in an era with few such people, his presence will be sorely missed. Philip Scaturro, Chair, Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President, The New School John Beerbower, Chair, Mannes Board of Governors Joel Lester, Dean, Mannes College The New School for Music

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 U.S. Shifts Policy, Agreeing To Nuclear Talks With Iran The Bush administration, in a shift from a longstanding American policy, said it would join European talks with Iran over that country's nuclear program, but only if the government in Tehran first suspends uranium activities thought to be a cover for a nuclear arms program. A1 Emergency Declared in Iraq City Iraq's new prime minister visited the increasingly lawless city of Basra and imposed a state of emergency, ordering faction leaders to cease their violent struggle for power and allow order to be restored in the oil-rich region. A1 The American military said United States troops shot and killed two Iraqi women whose vehicle had failed to stop after entering a ''prohibited area'' near Samarra, a city north of Baghdad. The Iraqi police said one of the women might have been pregnant and on her way to a hospital. A14 Details Emerge in Afghan Riots American soldiers involved in a vehicle crash Monday in Kabul fired into a crowd of Afghans pelting them with stones, according to the chief of the highway police in Kabul, who saw the accident. Four civilians were killed by gunfire. A3 Lebanon's Militant Struggle Recent Israeli airstrikes on Palestinian militants in Lebanon have focused attention on Lebanon's difficulty in controlling and disarming militants, both those who cross into the country from the Palestinian territories, and the homegrown groups with long ties to the country's history. A12 NATIONAL A16-22 Travel Tougher Post 9/11, Muslim Americans Say Muslim Americans say they are having a harder time than most getting through American airports and border crossings since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, sometimes facing an intimidating maze of barriers, if not outright discrimination. A1 Antiterrorism Grants Reduced After promising a greater share of antiterrorism money to the highest-risk communities, Homeland Security officials announced 2006 grants that slashed financing for New York City and Washington by 40 percent. A18 Evacuees Missing School Throughout the areas where hurricane evacuees ended up are pockets where education has declined, raising the possibility that thousands of children have fallen behind and may become dropouts, child health experts and advocates for evacuees say. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Studies Suggest Tropical Arctic The first detailed analysis of an extraordinary climatic and biological record from the seabed near the North Pole shows that 55 million years ago the Arctic Ocean was much warmer than scientists imagined -- a Floridian year-round average of 74 degrees. A1 Bird Flu Feared Underreported A number of countries in the throes of serious bird flu outbreaks are underreporting the extent of the problem, because of a lack of money, expertise or health systems to track the disease adequately in animals, international health officials said. A3 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Clinton Formally Begins Re-Election Campaign Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton formally began her Senate re-election campaign by criticizing the Bush administration in an appearance at the state Democratic convention that signaled how she might approach a presidential campaign. B1 Gay Marriage Case in Court The issue of same-sex marriage reached the New York State Supreme Court, as judges heard arguments from lawyers representing a group of gay and lesbian couples from across the state who filed suit to challenge New York's current marriage laws. B1 Commune Reflects on Attack The shooting of a Staten Island commune founder has brought unwanted attention to a group of people who want to show outsiders that they are a civic-minded, environmentally friendly collective of professionals, not a cult of hippies living on the fringes of the city. B1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-7 Cycling Union Clears Armstrong Lance Armstrong, left, received a boost toward clearing his name of doping allegations connected with his victory in the 1999 Tour de France. A Dutch lawyer hired by the International Cycling Union issued a report that said Armstrong should be exonerated of all blame because Armstrong's urine samples were so mishandled. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-13 Fed Chief and Top Treasurer Henry M. Paulson Jr., the president's choice to become Treasury secretary, and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, are expected to work together at a time when global markets are more volatile and investors are more risk-averse. C1 High Pay for Low Results The chief executive and four top managers at the Las Vegas Sands Corporation received higher-than-expected bonuses. But shareholders saw the value of their holdings decline 18 percent last year. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Afghanistan, unraveling; on the low road to November; remaking the Memorial Foundation; a flagging commitment on AIDS. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E6 Obituaries A23 Crossword E8 Weather D8 TV Listing E9

You can get your work done even while relaxing outdoors with the help of a black mesh chair that has an adjustable back and a laptop tray. Side pockets hold papers and file folders, creating a work perch for the deck or patio. The chair and its accompanying ottoman fold and fit into their own bag, so they're convenient to take to the beach or the lake for the weekend; $59.95 from Hammacher Schlemmer, (800) 321-1484 or hammacher.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

After a fierce public debate, Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott said he would no longer use an official country residence where he was photographed playing croquet while technically running the government. Acknowledging a personal, political setback, Mr. Prescott said his continued use of the state-financed mansion called Dorneywood, on 214 acres of parkland, ''is getting in the way of doing my job in government.'' ALAN COWELL (NYT)
WITTY--Spencer. Associate, mentor, and most of all friend. We will miss you. Chuck and Joan Baum

The last of three men involved in the killing of a food deliveryman in February 2004 was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 20 years to life in prison, the office of the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. The defendant, Nayquan Miller, 18, of Jamaica, pleaded guilty last year to second-degree murder and robbery in the death of the deliveryman, Huang Chen. Mr. Chen, 18, who worked in his family's restaurant, was beaten and stabbed after making a delivery, and his body was dumped in a pond in Brookville Park. Mr. Miller's accomplices were convicted of murder in separate trials, and each was sentenced to 511/3 years to life in prison.

Sophie Mallebranche, winner of an award for textile design at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in May, creates lustrous woven fabrics by weaving metallic threads -- copper, stainless steel, bronze or brass -- with linen, silk or silicone fibers. ''I am not a designer,'' she said, but ''an artist and a researcher in textiles made with new materials.'' She uses the fabrics to make things like curtains, place mats and tapestries. (An example, from a Tokyo installation, is at lower right.) Some of the textiles look handmade, others more high-tech, but all are custom made by hand in Ms. Mallebranche's Paris atelier. They start at about $170 a foot (about three feet wide); 011-331-4252-4206 or sophiemallebranche.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the reactions at Camp Pendleton, Calif., to accusations that marines based there had taken part last November in unjustified killings of civilians in Haditha, Iraq, misstated the name of the Marine unit under investigation. It is the Third Battalion, First Marine Regiment; it is not the Third Battalion of the First Marine Division. Because of another editing error, the article referred incorrectly at one point to a news broadcast on Monday on which Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed Haditha. It was ''American Morning'' on CNN, not ''Morning Edition'' on National Public Radio.

In the most detailed investigation yet of the illness and death of Slobodan Milosevic, the former president of Serbia, the war crimes tribunal in The Hague said in a report that no evidence of foul play or suicide was found but that during his trial Mr. Milosevic took serious risks with his own health by not taking all prescribed drugs, taking other medicines of his own and repeatedly refusing treatment, tests and even hospitalization. The 42-page report was prepared by the tribunal judge, Kevin Parker, from Australia. MARLISE SIMONS (NYT)

Evacuating Quake Victims as Toll Climbs Indonesian soldiers carried injured people in their bed while evacuating them in central Java. The death toll from the earthquake on Saturday has risen to nearly 6,000, Indonesian officials said. PALMER--Edward L., of Mill Neck, NY, passed away peacefully on May 27th at the age of 88. He was the beloved husband of Margaret P. Palmer, his wife of 66 years, and the devoted father of Ned Palmer and Jane Palmer Morrison. He is also survived by his loving grandchildren, Edward L. Palmer II, Alix Palmer and Ben Morrison. A graduate of Brooklyn Academy and Brown University, he worked for the New York Trust Co. and for 23 years at Citibank, from which he retired as Chairman of the Executive Committee. He also served on active duty with the U.S. Naval Reserve 19421946 and attained the rank of Lieutenant Commander. Service St. John's of Lattingtown on June 3rd at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY 11560 or East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton, NY 11978.

Rapper's Killing Lawful, Prosecutor Says The man who shot and killed the rapper Proof was acting lawfully in defense of another person, according to the Wayne County Prosecutor Kym Worthy, The Associated Press reported. The shooter, Mario Etheridge, right, will nevertheless be required to face weapons charges in connection with the shooting on April 11 at CCC, a nightclub in Detroit. ''The evidence clearly shows that Mario Etheridge acted in lawful self-defense of another when he shot Deshaun Holton,'' Ms. Worthy said, using to Proof's legal name. She said Mr. Etheridge shot twice at the ceiling in an effort to deter Proof before aiming at him. In the shootout Keith Bender, Mr. Etheridge's cousin, was also killed. His survivors have filed a wrongful death lawsuit against Proof's estate. The Curtain Falls On Playhouse 91 Playhouse 91, for two decades home to companies like the Light Opera of Manhattan, the Riverside Shakespeare Company and the Jewish Repertory Theater, closed yesterday to make way for redevelopment. The 299-seat Off Broadway theater, at 316 East 91st Street, between First and Second Avenues, was built in a former stable and ice house in 1980. It opened with Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms'' and also housed Arthur Miller's ''After the Fall,'' with Frank Langella; ''The Syringa Tree,'' starring Pamela Glen, above; ''A Bronx Tale,'' with Chazz Palminteri; and, most recently, ''Menopause, The Musical,'' which ended a four-year run on May 14. Footnotes The prolific American author Paul Auster, below, whose novels include ''Moon Palace'' and ''The Music of Chance,'' has won the 2006 Prince of Asturias Award for Letters, carrying a cash prize of about $62,000. After two years as Detective Joe Fontana on NBC's 16-year-old ''Law & Order,'' Dennis Farina will not return. A statement said he would ''spend his time pursuing other offers and projects that he and his production company are developing.'' Michelle Rodriguez, a former star of ABC's ''Lost,'' has been released from jail in Los Angeles after serving less than a day of the 60-day sentence imposed on her for violating probation by being arrested in Hawaii for drunken driving, The Associated Press reported. ''Our prosecutors are not happy about it, but that is the sad reality of our overcrowded jails,'' said Contessa Mankiewicz, a spokeswoman for the city attorney's office. Ms. Rodriguez remains on probation and still must perform 30 days of community service. Elizabeth Taylor, 74, wants everyone to know that she is not being treated for Alzheimer's disease and is not gravely ill, The Associated Press reported. ''Oh, come on, do I look like I'm dying?'' she asked during an interview on CNN with Larry King. ''Do I look or sound like I have Alzheimer's?'' She said she uses a wheelchair because of chronic back problems. The writer Charles Webb said he has signed a publishing deal for a sequel to his 1963 novel, ''The Graduate.'' The new novel, ''Home School'' picks up the lives of Benjamin and Elaine about 10 years later, living in upstate New York with their two children and trying to keep Mrs. Robinson at bay, The Associated Press reported. Random House said it planned to publish the book in Britain in June 2007. It has not announced a United States publication date.

A man who met a widow through an online dating service admitted in State Supreme Court yesterday that he defrauded her of $100,000 by lying about a potential cure for leukemia, prosecutors said. The defendant, Alan Sarner, 65, pleaded guilty to second degree grand larceny and faces one to three years in prison, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Prosecutors charged that Mr. Sarner told the woman, whose husband had died of leukemia, that his company was about to announce cures for blood diseases. The woman, who was not identified by prosecutors, gave him $100,000 as an investment. Neither the cure nor the company existed, Mr. Hynes said.

After a six-month search the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven named its new managing director yesterday. Joan Channick, who since 1998 has been the managing director of Theater Communications Group, a national service organization for not-for-profit theaters, will move to her position at the Long Wharf on Sept. 1. Ms. Channick is no stranger to New Haven; she teaches a course on law and arts at the Yale School of Drama and once served as marketing director for the Yale Repertory Theater. She is the second high-level official to leave the Theater Communications Group this spring. On March 27 Ben Cameron, the group's executive director, announced that he was leaving for a position at the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON
To the Editor: Re ''Technology and Easy Credit Give Identity Thieves an Edge'' (''Stolen Lives'' series, front page, May 30):

Archaeologists report in the journal Nature that an analysis of stone tools on the Indonesian island of Flores show that the diminutive species there up to 12,000 years ago probably inherited its toolmaking tradition from pre-Homo sapiens inhabitants as early as 800,000 years ago. The team, led by Adam Brumm of Australian National University, said the technological continuity between the periods supported the contention that the now-extinct ''little people'' of Flores probably evolved as a separate species (Homo floresiensis), and were not modern humans, as asserted by skeptics. JOHN NOBLE WILFORD (NYT)

AARONS--George ''Slim'', Photo-journalist of Catonah, NY, died Tuesday May 30. Slim is survived by his wife, Lorita Dewart Aarons of San Francisco, their daughter Mary Dewart Aarons, and her partner Robert Kent of Gloucester, MA, nine nieces and nephews and eight great nieces and nephews. Slim also leaves behind his many friends all over the world. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the Overseas Press Club of America, 40 W 45th St NY NY, 10036. A celebration of Slim's life will be held in the Fall.

The Dixie Chicks' new album, ''Taking the Long Way'' (Columbia), may not be popular on country radio, but fans have rushed to buy it. In its first week of release the album, right, sold 526,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving it a cakewalk to No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. The next spot on the chart is held by a soundtrack: a two-disc special edition of ''High School Musical'' (Disney), with karaoke versions of the songs, was released last week, and the new and old albums sold a combined 175,000 copies. With a total of 2.2 million total sales, ''High School Musical'' is the best-selling album of the year. ''American Idol Season 5: Encores'' (RCA) sold 154,000, reaching No. 3. (Carrie Underwood, who won the fourth season, benefited from appearing on the show last week; her ''Some Hearts,'' on Arista Nashville, sold 65,000 copies, bumping it 12 spots to No. 10.) Angels and Airwaves, featuring Tom DeLonge of Blink-182, reached No. 4 with its debut, ''We Don't Need to Whisper'' (Geffen/Interscope). The reggaetón star Don Omar's ''King of Kings'' (VI/Machete) opened at No. 7; and ''WWE: Wreckless Intent'' (Columbia), a collection of entrance music to World Wrestling Entertainment matches (by P.O.D., Motörhead, Three 6 Mafia and others), reached No. 8. BEN SISARIO

LUBITZ - Sylvia, passed peacefully early Tuesday morning at home in Palm Beach, with her husband and daughter holding her hands. If you knew her, then you know how sad a passing this is, but you also know that it is not a tragic passing. Sylvia led a life so full of glamour and pleasure, full of humor and style, full of the love of her devoted husband and family and friends, a full life of joy and caring. She lived the life she wanted to live, uncompromisingly, with zest and vigor and passion and culture and love. Instantly and completely loved by friends, she is survived by husband Lewis Lubitz, daughter Sara Richter, son-in-law Morton Richter, grandchildren Matthew, Daniel and Ann Marie, and David. For information: Quattlebaum Funeral Home, (561)-832-5171. $(6$)LUBITZ--Sylvia. Our deepest sympathy to Lew and the entire family. We will always remember Sylvia and the happy times we shared. Helene and Irving Schwartz
