The SafeScout security system by Sentinel Vision, of Palo Alto, Calif., is compact enough for an apartment. It has a monitor, above left; a siren, center; and a remote control, right. The monitor plugs into an outlet and a phone line. Within seconds of sensing movement, it sets off the siren and sends pictures and an audio recording to Sentinel Vision, which can notify the police. The owner gets a phone call or an e-mail message with pictures; if there's no burglar, he can stop the siren, let the police know and reactivate the system, the company says. The system, with a monthly subscription fee of about $20, is $200 at target.com or (800) 591-3869. ELAINE LOUIE

FABIAN--G. Leslie. Michael Capasso, Diane Martindale and the Board of Directors of Dicapo Opera Theatre, Dr. William Preister, Chair mourn the passing of our friend and benefactor, G. Leslie Fabian. Our thoughts and prayers are with his beloved wife Jo, our dear and devoted Trustee.

An obituary on Tuesday about George Field, a founder of Freedom House, a nonpartisan organization started to foster democracy and human rights in the face of Nazi propaganda, misspelled the surname of a newspaper columnist who received one of its annual Freedom Awards. He was Walter Lippmann, not Lippman. The obituary also misstated the location of the federal prison from which Mr. Field's boyhood hero and correspondent, Eugene V. Debs, ran his 1920 Socialist Party campaign for president. It was in Atlanta, not in Leavenworth, Kan.

Struggling to cope with a 1,000-plus percent annual inflation rate, Zimbabwe introduced a new $100,000 bank note, double the $50,000 note that had been the largest denomination in circulation. Still, the new note is only worth about one American dollar at official exchange rates, and draws only about 30 American cents on the black market, which more accurately reflects its value. The new note may help ease a growing currency shortage. The United Nations regional news agency quoted Zimbabwe Reserve Bank officials as saying that the country had run short of money after the government ran out of the foreign exchange needed to buy the imported ink and paper required to print bills. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

Amaridian, a new gallery in SoHo, showcases contemporary pieces by African artists. Stainless steel chandeliers, top, by Sian Eliot and Adam Hoets, industrial designers in Johannesburg, are 28 inches in diameter and cost $7,500. Louise Gelderblom, a ceramist in Cape Town, makes contemporary vessels, $1,350 to $2,600, above, by using an ancient African technique -- building up coils of clay -- and a pattern inspired by tribal scarification, said Fraser Conlon, above, an owner of the gallery. Mr. Conlon grew up in Johannesburg and was a publicist for Tom Ford at Gucci; his partner, Mary Slack, is the daughter of the late Harry F. Oppenheimer, the South African diamond magnate. Amaridian is at 31 Howard Street (Crosby Street); (917) 463-3719. ELAINE LOUIE

A picture caption on May 18 with an article about the re-election campaign of Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans misidentified the event where he greeted other men at a banquet table. It was an Armed Forces Day luncheon sponsored by the Greater New Orleans Council of the Navy League of the United States, not a political fund-raiser.

If the Miami Heat faces the Dallas Mavericks in the N.B.A. finals, there will be myriad ways to characterize the matchup. Think of it as Shaquille O'Neal and Dwyane Wade versus Dirk Nowitzki and Jason Terry. Think next of the coaches: it could be a battle of the old lion Pat Riley against the sophomore Avery Johnson. Now think again. Think bigger. Think of large, inanimate edifices with wooden floors where basketball teams play.

Broadway was crowded this season with popular long-running musicals, surprise hits, celebrities and, apparently, tourists. All those crowds broke a few records. According to statistics released yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers, paid attendance climbed just above 12 million for the first time, up 4.1 percent from the previous season's 11.5 million. More than four-fifths of seats were filled for the season, a record. But the real jump on Broadway was in the grosses; this season, sales reached a record $861.6 million, up 12 percent from last season's receipts. The discrepancy between the leap in gross receipts and the growth in paid attendance can be explained in part by the popularity of premium tickets, for shows like ''Wicked'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' above, which can command three times the regular price of a top orchestra seat. Tourists continued to be a large part of the record crowds, making up more than half the tickets sold. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

WARM-WEATHER hiking used to present a special challenge: Trek in boots with thinner socks and risk blisters. Or aim to prevent dreaded rub by wearing either thicker but hotter socks or by trying a one-two punch, a liner under wool socks. With the right pair of performance sandals, hikers these days can give their feet some air. Makers of these alternatives to boots promise the same level of traction and support. Some waterproof models are designed to handle even the sudden shower with aplomb, unlike boots, which once wet, stay wet.

The ''Music Downloads'' listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day on Monday misstated the surname of the artist of the song ''Bad Day,'' the second-most popular download for May 15-21. He is Daniel Powter, not Porter.
To the Editor: Isn't it about time for a national defense railroad law to allocate enough funds to maintain our railroads and particularly their passenger capability?

EXECUTIVE PAY Defenders of executive pay packages have contended that because most are tied to company performance, they are both earned and deserved. But as some examples show, investors often find that compensation exceeds the amounts allowed under directors' performance targets. [Page A1.] JOB CUTS AT SUN Sun Microsystems, the struggling network computer maker, announced that it planned to cut 4,000 to 5,000 jobs in the next six months as it tries to return to profitability. The cuts will reduce Sun's work force by 11 percent to 13 percent. [C1.] STREET CREDIBILITY Henry M. Paulson Jr. is almost certain to win easy Senate approval as Treasury secretary and become a central player on President Bush's team. But analysts say he and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, need to establish their credibility in financial markets. [C1.] VENEZUELA'S PROSPECTS President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela will be the host for an OPEC meeting at which he can be expected to point up his country's vast oil potential. [C1.] ABOUT-FACE AT SAKS Of all the changes at Saks Fifth Avenue under the tumultuous three-year reign of Fred Wilson, none left shoppers and investors scratching their heads more than the elimination of Real Clothes, a popular in-house clothing label. Now, Saks's chief executive is introducing a replacement. [C1.] BRITISH INVASION British news media are entering the American market or seeking to raise their profile here. In the latest example, a campaign will introduce Americans to BBC World News, a 24-hour cable news network. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C3.] MINORITIES AND MORTGAGES Black and Hispanic home buyers entering the fast-growing market for subprime mortgages tend to pay higher interest rates than whites with similar credit ratings, a statistical study by an advocacy group says. [A22.] STOCKS RALLY Stocks closed higher, buoyed by the first drop in oil prices in a week and by signs that the tension with Iran over its nuclear program might ease. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 73.88 points, to close at 11,168.31. [C11.] HEALTH CARE SHORTFALLS Employers and consumers are paying a billion dollars more a year for medical care to compensate for shortfalls in the nation's health care system resulting from tight Medicare and Medicaid budgets, according to Blue Cross officials and actuaries. [C3.] ENRON VERDICTS A federal jury in Houston convicted one of two former executives of Enron's broadband unit in connection with an $111 million accounting fraud. The second executive was acquitted. [C3.] DELTA CONCESSIONS APPROVED A bankruptcy judge approved the $280 million-a-year concessions agreement between Delta Air Lines and its pilots, hours after the pilots gave their approval. [C4.] MIDWESTERN GROWTH A survey showed Midwestern business expanded in May at its fastest rate in seven months, surging at a time when many economists had been expecting slower growth. [C5.] PAY UP Vonage, the Internet telephone provider, said it might seek reimbursement from customers who fail to pay for shares they committed to buy during the company's disappointing initial public offering. [C11.] COURIC'S SEND-OFF NBC pulled out all the stops on Katie Couric's last morning as a co-anchor of ''Today.'' She is moving to CBS to become the first female solo anchor of a network evening news program. [E1.] VILLAGE VOICE EDITOR The Village Voice announced the appointment of Erik Wemple, editor of Washington City Paper, as editor in chief. [E1.] MICROSOFT DEFENDS SPENDING Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, left, defended his decision to increase spending next year and signaled that he was unlikely to increase the company's share buyback plan. Investors have publicly called for Microsoft to increase buybacks. [C11.] DEMAND FOR ARCELOR VOTE Some Arcelor shareholders, upset at the steel giant's deal to sell a stake to the chief executive of Severstal of Russia, demanded that the company hold an emergency shareholders meeting to vote on the deal. [C6.] FRENCH REACTION When United Breweries, the world's third-largest spirits company, said it had withdrawn from the bidding for the French Champagne maker Taittinger, it cited a local reaction to its Indian roots. [C6.] ONLINE TABLEWARE OR LEADING INDICATOR? A boom in gold and silver may be a sign that the U.S. is finally going to pay for years of easy money, mounting debt and trillion-dollar budget deficits. A column by David Leonhardt is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. TIFFANY & COMPANY, the jewelry retailer, said first-quarter earnings rose 7.7 percent -- to $43.1 million from $40.1 million -- on the strength of international sales. (AP) THE FORMER CHIEF EXECUTIVE of Gateway, Jeffrey Weitzen, won the dismissal of a fraud lawsuit after a federal judge said the Securities and Exchange Commission had not provided evidence of intentional wrongdoing. There was a time, not long ago, when the idea of jet travel in the Persian Gulf countries conjured up images of white-robed sheiks accompanied by cages full of squawking falcons and of European oil executives lounging in first-class luxury -- of a frequent-flier population more at home with a large entourage than a humble rolling suitcase. How things have changed. Now, in the domed rotunda of the old-fashioned little airport in Sharjah, you are as likely to come across a family of Egyptians returning from a shopping spree in Dubai or a group of young men from the United Arab Emirates off for a week of partying in Beirut. For the last three years, Air Arabia has been shaking up the world of Persian Gulf air travel with the Middle East's first no-frills low-cost airline. Based in the emirate of Sharjah and founded through royal decree by Sheik Sultan bin Mohammed al-Qasimi, the ruler of Sharjah, Air Arabia aims to do for air travel in the Arab world what budget airlines like Ryanair, EasyJet, JetBlue and Southwest have been doing the last decade in some Western countries.
To the Editor: Re ''At 12, a Mother of Two,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, May 28): I want to thank Mr. Kristof for his column about the negligent response to AIDS here and abroad.

An obituary on May 23 about the dancer and choreographer Katherine Dunham omitted a credit for the choreography in the 1940 Broadway musical ''Cabin in the Sky,'' in which she performed. It was by George Balanchine in collaboration with Miss Dunham; it was not solely by Balanchine. Because of an editing error, the obituary misidentified an award Miss Dunham received in 1979 at Carnegie Hall. It was the Albert Schweitzer Music Award, not the Albert Schweitzer Prize.

CASSON--Dr. Phillip Raynor. Died on May 29 following a recent illness. Born in Sydney, Australia, Dr. Casson graduated from the Sydney High Boys School and went on to attend the Sydney University medical School. After graduating with a BS and MB in medicine he went to Broome, Australia, to work as a surgeon in the Flying Doctor's Service, the airplane-based medical unit that made it possible for resident of the Australian Outback to receive emergency medical care. Dr. Casson then spent 12 years as a practicing surgeon in England, becoming a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons in 1958. He came to the United States in 1959 to do a Fellowship in head and neck cancer at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital. In 1963, he joined the staff at the New York University Medical Center at the urging of Dr. John Converse, who had recently founded the Institute of Reconstructive and Plastic Surgery at the hospital. There, Dr. Casson became involved in pioneering transplant research, most notably in that being conducted by Dr. Jean Dausset of Paris, France. Along with Dr. Converse and the late Dr. Felix Rapaport, Dr. Casson helped Dr. Dausset investigate the significance of tissue typing and histocompatibility in facilitating the successful transplantations of human organs, groundbreaking ideas in the medical field and for which Dr. Dausset received the 1980 Nobel Prize. Dr. Casson remained on the staff of NYU Medical Center as an Associate Professor of Plastic Surgery until his retirement in 2004. He was also an Assistant Attending Surgeon at Tisch Hospital and an Associate Attending Surgeon at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. He was a member of the American College of Surgeons, the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery and the Transplant Society. He was also a founding member of the Pawling Mountain Club in Pawling, NY. Dr. Casson will be remembered as a warm and caring husband, father and physician. A gifted surgeon who made enduring contributions to the medical community, he remained a mentor to many surgeons who trained under him over the course of his long career. He was an avid sportsman and oenophile who enjoyed the company of a wide variety of friends who shared his interests and sense of humor. He is survived by his loving wife Rosemary and daughters, Nicole, Victoria and Lindsay. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in his memory to the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 317 East 34th Street, Suite 901, New York, NY 10016. A memorial service will be held on June 1st at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, at 3 P.M. $(6$)CASSON--Phillip. To the most unique man and treasured friend I had the absolute pleasure in knowing. Your friend, Jeannie

Few New Yorkers have seen the Tardis, revered by fans of the British television show ''Doctor Who'' as the vehicle that whisks the protagonist through the centuries to save civilization from evil aliens. Yet the doctor's trusty time machine inspired the entrance to a new store that opened last week at 132 Spring Street (Greene Street) in SoHo, according to its designer. ''From the street all you see is this mountain of steel, and then whoosh, up you go,'' said Thomas Heatherwick, bottom left, a London designer. He sculptured 55 tons of sliced steel into a series of slopes you can walk up -- or climb -- to the store, La Maison Unique Longchamp, the new flagship for Longchamp Paris leather goods. (A purse display is at bottom right.)

City Councilman Joel Rivera said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to ban the sale of candy-flavored cigarettes, cigars and tobacco in New York City. The tobacco products are commonly sold in bodegas in the Bronx and northern Manhattan. Mr. Rivera, left, of the Bronx, who was joined on the steps of City Hall by students and smoking opponents, contends that the flavored cigarettes are aimed at young people to get them hooked on smoking. ''We obviously believe, just like drinking, smoking is bad for your health,'' Mr. Rivera said. Albany lawmakers are considering similar legislation. WINNIE HU (NYT)

Pope Benedict XVI issued a condemnation of anti-Semitism after harsh criticism from Jewish leaders that he failed to do so at a visit to the Auschwitz and Birkenau death camp complex in Poland. ''Humanity must not give in to the temptation of racial hatred, which is at the origin of the worst forms of anti-Semitism,'' the German-born pope said at his weekly public audience on St. Peter's Square. Jewish groups also criticized the pope's speech for blaming Nazi leaders for the Holocaust, without mention of responsibility among ordinary Germans. IAN FISHER (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''Consider the Living'' (column, May 29):

An article on Saturday about a hearing on a motion to dismiss a libel case brought against The Atlanta Constitution by Richard Jewell, a security guard who was identified as a suspect in the 1996 Olympic Park bombing and later cleared, referred incompletely to the newspaper's reasons for the motion. In addition to saying it believed the truth of what it published at the time and so lacked actual malice, the newspaper argued that its coverage was in fact accurate.

MARGOLIS--Evelyn K. Devoted mother of Nina Dobris, Barry and David Sanders. Cherished grandmother of Jason, Rachel, Rebecca, Justin and Dawnn. Great-grandmother of Andrew and Matthew. Services today 1PM at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.
To the Editor: Re ''Railroading Amtrak'' (editorial, May 28):

A former Army private was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 4 to 12 years in prison for accidentally shooting a woman in the head while firing his gun in the air during a night of drunken revelry while he was on leave in December. The former private, Danny Carpio, 23, apologized for his ''recklessness'' and expressed concern for the two young children of his victim, Selina Akther, 29, before Acting Justice Dorothy Chin-Brandt sentenced him for second-degree manslaughter. After watching a news report of the shooting, Mr. Carpio surrendered to the police and admitted killing Ms. Akther, who had gone to her fifth-floor window on 85th Road in Briarwood after hearing shots. Before the sentencing, the prosecutor, Daniel Saunders, noted Mr. Carpio's genuine remorse for Ms. Akther's death. Golam Maola, the victim's husband, was invited by the judge to speak but was too overwhelmed with emotion. MICK MEENAN (NYT)

To the Editor: In your article, bankers say consumers are unwilling to incur the inconvenience imposed by systems that would eliminate identity theft. Perhaps businesses should stop blaming consumers for identity theft.

FISH--Edith (Davis). Died May 30, 2006. Wife of the late George W. Fish. Mother of Robert, Daniel, Ruth Fishbein and Richard. A memorial service will be held June 1st at 1PM, Cobble Hill Chapel, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn.

Chinese authorities closed 201 medical clinics in northern Hebei Province and fined several hundred others because they helped detect and abort female fetuses, the New China News Agency said. The government has been trying to cut down on selective-sex abortions, which are partly responsible for a lopsided birth ratio of 117 male births to 100 female births. It has long banned medical personnel from disclosing the sex of a fetus. But the practice remains widespread because China enforces strict population controls. JOSEPH KAHN (NYT)

To the Editor: David Brooks (''The Duke Witch Hunt'') took an irrelevant and cheap shot by writing, ''For many on the tenured left, bashing people like that is all that's left of their once-great activism.''

ROSENBERG--MIRIAM be loved wife of the late Abra ham. Devoted mother of Jean Falkenstein and the late Leonard. Dear sister of Evelyn Schoen and the late Beatrice Siegel. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Eric, Kendra Falkenstein, and Andrea Smiler. Great grandmother of Joshua, Lauren Smiler, and Rachel Falkenstein. Services and interment were held on Sunday May 28th, 2006.

To the Editor: Maureen Dowd (''Live From Baghdad: More Dying,'' column, May 31) notes that President Bush ''has not attended a single funeral.'' He has missed nearly 2,500 chances to show personal respect.

The developer of Roosevelt Island's Octagon -- first a lunatic asylum, then Metropolitan Hospital, then a burned-out shell -- held a reunion for the hospital's nursing school. The last class graduated in 1958.

Ronaldinho -- better than Pelé? Our colleague at The International Herald-Tribune, Roger Cohen, wondered about that today in his World Cup blog. He was referring to the Brazilian magazine Época, which asked that very question on the cover of its May 11 issue, which you'll find on the righthand side of the page if you go to this link.
Update: Just before 4 p.m., Eliot Spitzer's statewide bus tour wrapped up in Mineola, the Nassau County seat.
After much prodding from rival candidates for attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo released tax returns dating back 14 years, when he served as Housing secretary under President Clinton.

In a city where the price of a cashmere sweater has surpassed $1,000 in some quarters and summer utility bills may do the same, finding a one-bedroom rental apartment at that price seems pretty improbable. Or so you'd think. But a survey released earlier this year by New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development found that $1,000 is the average price of a privately owned nonregulated rental apartment in the five boroughs. That included all sizes of apartments, from studios on up.

Goldman Sachs named its president Lloyd Blankfein, to succeed Henry Paulson as chairman and chief executive of the company, the world's biggest securities firm by market value. Though Mr. Blankfein was widely considered to be Mr. Paulson's heir apparent, the board's announcement threw cold water on recent speculation that the firm would split the roles of chairman and chief execuive.
The city's new top lobbyist? Kasirer Consulting, the lobbying shop run by Suri Kasirer, according to a report released today by the City Clerk's office that found she took in $2.4 million last year.

You knew it had to happen someday: live broadband webcasts of World Cup matches. The BBC has announced that it will show all 23 matches for which it has television rights live over its Web site. However, only people in the U.K. will be able to see this service. So Brits won't have to go to pubs to watch daytime matches and blow off work; now they can blow off work simply by sitting at their office desks. Presenteeism, call it.

Goldman Sachs has taken some heat in recent weeks over possible conflicts of interest, mostly centering on its dual roles as private equity investor and investment banking adviser. Just this week, Goldman withdrew as adviser to Mirant in its attempt to buy NRG Energy amid suggestions that Goldman shared confidential information about NRG. (Goldman denied sharing any such information.)

The most viewed video on YouTube today, by a landslide, is this clip of Colombia goalkeeper Luis Enrique Martinez punting the ball from his own and and scoring a goal against Poland's goalkeeper, Tomasz Kuszczak, in a friendly match earlier this week. In fact, videos of Kuszczak's gaffe, which surely will keep him on the bench when Poland starts the World Cup next week, constitute 4 of YouTube's current Top 20.
Ken in Washington D.C. writes:

Was it really Edmílson's knee, or was it his fist, that caused him to be be dropped from the Brazilian squad yesterday? That was the question being addressed this morning on The Guardian's World Cup podcast, by Fernando Duarte, who is himself blogging the event from London for the Brazilian daily O Globo. Duarte tried to scotch rumors that the influential Brazilian midfielder was in fact excluded from the team because of a training-ground fight earlier this week with his star teammate, the striker Adriano.

Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 2 column, "Insurgency Out, Anarchy In"
Our colleague Jere Longman reports today from Prague on the travails of the aging Czech Republic team, a topic that many visitors to this blog have commented on.
In a recent article about getting high-speed Internet on your cellphone (that is, EV-DO service), I mentioned that Verizon Wireless has the greatest coverage: 180 major cities.

Wall Street has already voiced its displeasure with ADC Telecommunications's plan to acquire a rival wireless company, Andrew. Shares of ADC fell 20 percent on Wednesday after the transaction, which carried an initial value of $2 billion, was announced.
When it comes to asking which cellphone company has the best coverage, the answer is all in the wording.

Stepping up the pressure on Eliot Spitzer after his big week, Tom Suozzi plans to greet the Attorney General on the County Executive's home turf when Spitzer arrives in Mineola on the LIRR this afternoon. No word yet if the Spitzer camp knows of the plans.

Lest it be lost amid other, lesser legal issues -- Enron, Frank Quattrone, stock options backdating -- The Wall Street Journal's Law Blog on Friday helpfully brings us news of this important arbitration case affecting one of Wall Street's icons: Morgan Stanley v. Meow.

The widening federal investigation into possible backdating of stock options has everyone looking under rocks for the next company to be implicated. To that end, analysts at Citigroup have screened the technology companies they cover to assess their potential exposure to the scandal, which has already resulted in more than 20 companies, many of them in the tech sector, getting subpoenas from the Justice Department.
Talk about resale value: Why Have some rare muscle cars become million-dollar babies?

The brokerage industry "has begun to look like a business in decline," The Economist writes in its latest issue. As a result, big investment banks are working to strengthen their ties to hedge funds, because for now, at least, that is where the money is.
Alternative-asset management firm GSC Partners, which says it oversees $10.7 billion in assets, on Friday announced that it named Michael R. Lynch senior managing director.

Deutsche Börse is not giving up yet. The German stock exchange, snubbed by Thursday's $10.2 billion agreement between the NYSE Group and Euronext, said in a statement Friday that it will continue to pursue a merger with Euronext. The announcement came just as top executives of Euronext and NYSE, which runs the New York Stock Exchange, were touting the virtues of their proposed combination at a press conference.

Under pressure from hedge funds, Micron Technology said Friday it is prepared to increase its offer to acquire Lexar Media, a maker of memory chips. Lexar postponed a special meeting of shareholders, which had been scheduled for that day, to consider the latest proposal.
Stuart W. Bowen Jr. has vividly shown that when it comes to assessing and improving the creaky infrastructure of Iraq, half the battle is won simply by going to construction sites.

Interest is running high for Pfizer's over-the-counter drug business, with the pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline prepared to offer more than $15 billion for the unit, according to reports. Citing unnamed sources, Reuters and The Financial Times wrote on Friday that Glaxo is set to make its $15 billion-plus bid ahead of Tuesday's deadline. Others said to be vying for the business, which owns brands such as Listerine mouthwash and Sudafed decongestant, include Reckitt Benckiser and Johnson & Johnson.
John Faso, fresh from his victory at the Republican state convention, just arrived in Flushing to speak to 20 members of the Queens Chamber of Commerce.
The number of jobs added was the lowest since hurricane-depressed October, but the unemployment rate still slipped to a five-year low of 4.6 percent.

At least one law firm is trying to put together a class-action lawsuit for disgruntled Vonage customers who invested in the Internet telephone company's disastrous I.P.O. Customers, who have watched Vonage's shares tank 32 percent since their debut last week, may have a strong legal leg to stand on, I.P.O. experts said.

A state judge has thrown out California's fraud lawsuit against the brokerage firm Edward Jones in another defeat for the attorney general, Bill Lockyer, who is trying to assert authority over mutual fund sales practices.

John F. W. Rogers, chief of staff and closest adviser to Henry M. Paulson Jr., played a crucial role in Mr. Paulson's decision about whether to leave the job he loves at Goldman Sachs for a new position of uncertain power at the Treasury.

M-Systems Flash Disk Pioneers on Thursday joined a list of companies engulfed in a widening investigation over stock options grants and postponed a stock offering, sending its shares down as much as 15 percent.

The New York State comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, the trustee of the $140 billion New York State Common Retirement Fund, has announced he will ask Judge William H. Pauley of Southern District Court to replace the indicted class action firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman as lead counsel in a shareholder suit against the German pharmaceutical giant Bayer.
Home Depot, in a bow to disgruntled shareholders, said yesterday that it would require a majority vote from shareholders for the election of board members.
Rambus said on Thursday e-mails from Micron Technology and Hynix Semiconductor support its claims that the rival memory chip makers conspired to fix prices, sending its shares up 18.5 percent.

Sony BMG Music Entertainment yesterday announced the resignations of the top two executives at its Sony Music Label Group, less than four months after the company's owners appointed a new chief executive in a bid to resolve management discord.

The private equity firm Exponent has emerged as the most likely bidder to acquire Sir Richard Branson's Trainline.com, after a 168 million pound ($314 million) offer. Exponent has been picked ahead of two rival private equity firms to enter into exclusive negotiations with Virgin Group to acquire the online train ticket retailer, The Telegraph said.

Six months after it announced plans to sell ancillary businesses, Textron said Thursday that it has agreed to sell its fastening systems unit to Los Angeles private equity firm Platinum Equity for $630 million in cash and assumed debt.
A consortium of venture capital firms is preparing a 14 billion euro bid for Portugal's biggest phone group in a further private equity assault on the telecoms market, The Times of London reported.
Canada's venture capital industry is having trouble attracting as much investment as it would like, and it wants governments to help attract money from pension funds by providing loan guarantees.

Tesla Motors, a Silicon Valley-based company seeking to develop street-legal, high-performance electric cars, has raised $40 million in third-round funding from three venture firms and several high-profile individual investors.

Ignition Partners, the Seattle-area venture capital firm run by wireless industry notables and Microsoft alumni, has expanded its $300 million third fund with an additional $80 million earmarked for helping its start-ups grow up fast through acquisitions.

Citigroup's Citigroup Venture Capital International arm is backing the U.S. expansion of Canadian ethanol producer Permolex International - the latest private equity player to seize an opportunity in the booming industry.

Luna Innovations, which develops molecular and sensing technologies, has cut the estimated price range for its pending initial public offering, reducing the deal's potential value by 27 percent to $32 million.
CTC Media priced its initial public offering near the bottom of its reduced range for its stock market debut Thursday on the Nasdaq.
Town Sports International, the third-largest fitness club operator in the United States, priced an initial public offering on Thursday worth about $99.5 million, according to an underwriter.

Australia's government scrapped plans to sell Snowy Hydro, the nation's second-biggest hydropower producer, bowing to protests led by farmers and politicians that the company may fall into foreign hands.

Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco, a Democrat, said that she would sign a near-total ban on abortion — without exceptions for rape or incest victims — that is nearing final legislative passage. The measure awaits one final approval by the Senate to changes by the House before it reaches Ms. Blanco's desk. It would allow abortion only in cases where the woman's life is in danger or when childbirth would permanently harm her health. The bill could only go into effect if the United States Supreme Court overturns its Roe v. Wade decision.

Three-wheeled all-terrain vehicles would be banned and four-wheelers intended for children would not go faster than 15 miles an hour under rules suggested by the Consumer Product Safety Commission's staff. The recommendations would also require A.T.V. manufacturers to offer free training to families when they buy the vehicles.

The Federal Election Commission has determined that Senator Bill Frist's 2000 Senate campaign violated federal campaign finance laws. The federal agency fined Frist 2000 Inc. $11,000, according to a lawyer representing the campaign of Mr. Frist, Republican of Tennessee and the majority leader, and a watchdog group. The group, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics, in Washington, filed a complaint last year against Mr. Frist's 2000 campaign committee and received the commission's findings yesterday. The commission found that Frist 2000 failed to disclose a $1.44 million loan taken out jointly by the campaign and Mr. Frist's 1994 campaign committee. The lawyer, Jason Torchinsky, said the campaign had settled the complaint.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger agreed to send the California National Guard to the Mexican border, ending a 17-day standoff with the Bush administration. The two sides had been at odds over whether California Guard troops would join the effort to bolster the Border Patrol and who would pay for it. They reached an agreement under which California will contribute about 1,000 troops and the federal government will pick up the full cost, said Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican. But in an act that was not part of the agreement with the federal government, Mr. Schwarzenegger will sign an executive order that ends the California National Guard's participation on Dec. 31, 2008, state officials said.

Two of the six remaining plaintiffs in the New London eminent-domain dispute have reached financial settlements with the city. The agreements, reached on Wednesday, involve the Dery family, which has lived in the Fort Trumbull neighborhood for five generations, and Thelma Brelesky, whose son has lived in the neighborhood for almost three decades. The settlements, for undisclosed amounts, had been negotiated by a state-appointed mediator.

A former Seton Hall University professor was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing more than $575,000 from the school's radio station, where he was the general manager and faculty adviser, the Essex County prosecutor said. The professor, Michael A. Collazo, 58, was fired from the university in 2004 after a university audit of the station, the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow, said. Prosecutors claim that Mr. Collazo took money from the station, WSOU-FM ( 89.5), and pocketed funds from unauthorized leases of the station's subfrequencies to local broadcasters. Mr. Collazo was arrested yesterday at his home in Hampton.

Calm returned to Clichy-sous-Bois and Montfermeil, two tough underprivileged suburbs northeast of Paris where youth violence broke out Monday and Tuesday night. Three cars were set ablaze and seven others damaged in Chelles, next to Montfermeil, but the national police said they had no proof that the incidents were linked to urban violence. In Montfermeil and Clichy-sous-Bois, youths had engaged in fights with the police and burned cars for two nights in a row, raising the government's worries that the unrest that gripped the country in November might be making a return.

Senegal suspended repatriation of Senegalese migrants from Spain's Canary Islands in a blow to a diplomatic offensive by Madrid to close the door on illegal immigration from West Africa that has totaled 9,000 people. Senegal said nearly 100 migrants flown to Dakar from the Canaries on Wednesday were mistreated by Spanish authorities by being handcuffed and falsely told they were bound for Spain. Spain said it would investigate the allegations. The operation had been aimed at returning more than 200 migrants.

Several thousand Palestinian security officers staged one of the largest protests yet over unpaid wages, throwing stones, smashing windows and firing their guns in the air outside the Palestinian parliament. Most belong to units considered loyal to the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, and blamed the Hamas-led government for failure to pay salaries. Because of the cutoff in international aid, the government has not paid 165,000 Authority employees since coming to power in March. Prime Minister Ismail Haniya, left, said this week that workers making less than $330 a month would be paid in the coming days. They are about a quarter of the government work force.

A land mine believed to have been planted by Communist rebels killed 12 officers from a paramilitary police force in eastern India, an official said. The officers were heading back to their base in the state of Jharkhand after defusing land mines when their jeep struck a mine near the village of Karampada, said the state's top police officer, B. C. Verma. The militants, known as Naxalites, are active in 6 of India's 28 states.

Mamoun's Falafel Restaurant, a Middle Eastern cafe, is a 60's urban college-town phenomenon. Sitting in the small, dimly lighted room decorated with rugs (on the walls), plants and stained-glass lighting fixtures, with Middle Eastern music playing, you could be in New York City, Berkeley, New Haven or Cambridge. The original Mamoun's opened on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village in 1971.

After failing a third inspection since January, the Stage Deli, home of triple-decker sandwiches of corned beef and pastrami, was closed on Tuesday for health code violations, city health officials said yesterday. Violations at the delicatessen, on Seventh Avenue near 53rd Street, included food not kept at proper temperatures, live roaches, a malfunctioning refrigerator, and inadequate garbage storage, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said. When the delicatessen passes inspection, it may reopen, officials said. The owners did not return calls seeking comment.

In a last, sharp rebuke to Army prosecutors who had charged more than a dozen soldiers with abusing prisoners at a secret military jail in Afghanistan, a military jury on Thursday acquitted a former Army interrogator of beating and sexually humiliating a terrorism suspect. The charges against the defendant, Pfc. Damien M. Corsetti, grew out of an Army investigation of the deaths of two Afghans in December 2002 at the jail, in Bagram.

MORSE--Elizabeth. Elizabeth Leah Coates Morse, 87, died on May 5, 2006 in Fort Collins, CO. Born August 3, 1918, in NYC, the daughter of John Ora Beverly Coates and Emily Pearce Coates. She married Harold G. Morse on June 23, 1943. She dearly loved music and poetry. She traced her ancestry to the Blair Clan of Perth, Scotland. She is missed by her four children, David G., M. Beverly, John B., and Robert K., and their families.

West Caicos Reserve WHAT -- Island-wide development with a hotel and residences. WHERE -- West Caicos Island, Turks and Caicos. AMENITIES -- Among others, a full-service marina, diving, horseback riding, hiking, tennis and a beach club. PRICES -- Two- and three-bedroom villa units in buildings surrounding the hotel start at $2.5 million; other residential options -- all waterfront -- include town houses and stand-alone houses, and start at $3 million. STATUS -- The marina, hotel and about 30 units are expected to be completed in early 2008; other residences will be built by mid- to late 2009. DEVELOPER -- Logwood Hotel Development Company. CONTACT -- 649-941-7480 or www.westcaicosreserve.com. DETAILS -- West Caicos, an 11-square mile island in the British West Indies at the western end of the Turks and Caicos archipelago, has been uninhabited since the late 19th century, when salt production and farming ended there. Now it is being remade as a resort and residential development. A 125-suite Ritz-Carlton hotel with restaurants and a full-service spa will be built on the northern coast, surrounded by 75 villa units, whose residents will have access to the hotel's amenities. Nearby, a full-service marina capable of accommodating mega-yachts will feature town houses and a village with shops and restaurants. Ferries from a private dock near the airport in Providenciales will provide transportation to the island. About 90 percent of West Caicos, including the 500-acre Lake Catherine, a breeding ground for pink flamingos, will be untouched. Snake River Sporting Club WHAT -- Residential community emphasizing outdoor activities. WHERE -- Jackson, Wyo. AMENITIES -- A golf course, equestrian center, fishing and skiing, among others. PRICES -- Home sites, $1.25 million to $2.5 million. STATUS -- Home sites became available last fall; the golf course opens in July. DEVELOPER DPS -- Development Company. CONTACT -- 888-434-7772 or www.snakeriversportingclub.com. DETAILS -- On 554 acres bordering Bridger-Teton National Forest, this development is aimed at active second-home owners. It stretches six and a half miles along the Snake River and offers access to fly fishing as well as rafting. A golf course designed by Tom Weiskopf will have home sites lining seven of its 18 holes, and an equestrian center and a fitness complex with tennis and squash will also be available. In colder months, the club activities include cross-country and heli-skiing. A 23,000 square-foot lodge overlooking the golf course and the river will have a lounge, a restaurant and a pro shop. And there will be a full-service spa, which will use water from natural hot springs in its various treatments. When overall construction is completed in 2008, there will be around 130 home sites. NICK KAYE Breaking Ground is a weekly look at projects, planned or under construction, that include weekend or vacation homes.

An article on May 10 about testimony from a prosecution witness in the federal trial of Shahawar Matin Siraj, a Pakistani immigrant who was eventually convicted of having plotted to bomb the Herald Square subway station in 2004, misstated the length of time that another witness, Osama Eldawoody, worked as a police informer. It was 13 months, not two years and three months. The article also referred incompletely to Mr. Eldawoody's compensation. According to later testimony, he was paid about $25,000 for the 13 months in the field and then received nearly $75,000 in relocation expenses during the 20 months he was waiting to testify at trial.

PAULSON'S SUCCESSOR Goldman Sachs's board is expected to meet today to appoint Lloyd C. Blankfein as chief executive to succeed Henry M. Paulson Jr., the nominee for Treasury secretary. People close to the board say it is also expected to debate whether or not to appoint a separate chairman. [Page C4.] WALL STREET AND WASHINGTON John F. W. Rogers's role as Henry M. Paulson Jr.'s chief of staff at Goldman Sachs highlights a growing tendency on the part of Wall Street chieftains to seek out executives with deep Washington ties to be their closest advisers. [C1.] BIG BREAK Because of a little-known provision in the tax code, Henry M. Paulson Jr. could receive a tax break of at least $48 million if confirmed as Treasury secretary. [C4.] ASIAN AUTOMAKERS GAIN SHARE Toyota, Honda and other Asian auto manufacturers claimed a record 40 percent of the American market in May. [C1.] FRENCH GO NORTH Thousands of people -- many just out of college -- are deserting France to live and work in Dublin, a city that sparkles with economic vibrancy despite a more general sense of stagnation in much of Europe. [C1.] OPEC MEETING OPEC rejected calls from its host, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, to lower production quotas at a meeting in Caracas. But that did not prevent Mr. Chávez, left, from seeking to invigorate the 11-country group by appealing to oil-rich countries in Africa and South America to become members. [C2.] NYSE-EURONEXT DEAL The NYSE Group reached a definitive agreement on a deal to buy Euronext, the pan-European stock and derivatives exchange, for $10.2 billion. [C3.] CHARGES DROPPED Frank P. Quattrone, the most prominent banker in Silicon Valley during the 1990's technology boom, won a third major legal battle as securities industry regulators dropped all charges against him. [C1.] STORES POST STRONG SALES Department stores, both high-end and mainstream, said May sales were particularly strong. Target also reported healthy sales, but its main rival in the discount store business, Wal-Mart, said sales growth slowed. [C3.] WEB RECORDS The Justice Department is asking Internet companies to keep records on the Web-surfing activities of their customers to aid law enforcement and may propose legislation to force them to do so. [A15.] HEINZ COST-CUTTING H. J. Heinz, one of the world's largest food companies, said that its quarterly profit fell 19 percent and that it would cut 2,700 jobs and exit 15 plants as part of a plan to cut costs and increase profit. The company has faced pressure from a billionaire investor, Nelson Peltz, to increase shareholder returns. [C4.] MIXED SIGNALS ON INFLATION Investors got mixed signals on inflation in new economic data, with a gauge of wage inflation posting an improved reading while a barometer of manufacturing prices posted a sharp increase. [C9.] DOW RISES Stocks rose sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 91.97 points, or 0.82 percent, to 11,260.28. [C7.] BANK OF CHINA OFFERING Shares of the Bank of China, one of China's biggest state-owned banks, soared 15 percent in their first day of trading in Hong Kong. The initial public offering raised $9.7 billion. [C3.] DISCONTENT AT HOME DEPOT Home Depot, in a bow to disgruntled shareholders, said it would now require a majority vote from shareholders for the election of board members. [C3.] JOB CUTS AT SCHERING-PLOUGH Schering-Plough said it planned to cut 1,100 jobs in New Jersey and Puerto Rico as part of an overhaul intended to make the drug maker more competitive. [C5.] TOP EXECUTIVES LEAVE SONY MUSIC Sony BMG Music Entertainment said the top two executives at its Sony Music Label Group had resigned, less than four months after the company's owners appointed a new chief executive in an effort to resolve management discord. [C5.] ENRON SETTLEMENT Enron's former law firm, Vinson & Elkins, has agreed to pay the company $30 million to settle claims of contributing to its collapse in 2001 by signing off on questionable deals. [C5.] HEART DRUG STUDY The Scios unit of Johnson & Johnson announced it would spend over $100 million to conduct a safety and effectiveness study of its heart failure drug Natrecor, intended to address safety issues that arose last year. [C3.] PAPER REVIVES CAPITAL COLUMN Kimberley A. Strassel, a member of The Wall Street Journal's editorial board, has been named the paper's new Washington columnist. She will be resuming the weekly Potomac Watch column, which has been in hiatus for the last five years. [C7.] ONLINE How Macy's Tracks Sales Revival tent fervor and hard-nosed pragmatism mix as Macy's buyers meet to discuss what's selling. A report is at nytimes.com/style. AARONS -- George ''Slim'', Photo-journalist of Katonah, NY, died Tuesday May 30. Slim is survived by his wife, Lorita Dewart Aarons of San Francisco, their daughter Mary Dewart Aarons, and her partner Robert Kent of Gloucester, MA, nine nieces and nephews and eight great nieces and nephews. Slim also leaves behind his many friends all over the world. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the Overseas Press Club of America, 40 W 45th St NY NY, 10036. To the Editor: ''The Hamptons' Most Coveted Spots,'' by Valerie Cotsalas (May 26) resonated with me. I recently purchased the nonresident parking permit for the five beaches in East Hampton Village and was quite relieved. The clerk gave me the number of permits available as well as a projection for the cutoff date, and I was in her office the next day. Ordinarily one would accept fate and find other means of getting to the beach. The beauty and quality of the beach I frequent truly deserve the rank of sixth among the 650 beaches of America's Best Beaches -- and the extra effort to be able to park there. Steven A. Ludsin East Hampton, N.Y.

Thanks to the Public Art Fund, there is almost always an interesting sculpture on the Doris C. Freedman Plaza on Central Park's southeast corner. Currently in residence is ''Corner Plot,'' above, a magical, site-specific work by Sarah Sze. From the outside you see a low pyramid constructed of brick, glass and metal, resembling the rooftop corner of an apartment building like the one diagonally across Fifth Avenue from the plaza. It looks as if a whole building had toppled and sunk into the ground as a result of some natural or supernatural disaster. Up close you can see through windows on two sides, down into one of Ms. Sze's signature, semi-Cubist, semi-Surrealist environments made of materials and objects you could purchase at Home Depot, Staples and Wal-Mart. There are multilevel shelves, abstract gridded structures, yardsticks held in place by clamps, desk lamps projecting every which way, a miniature flight of spiral stairs and a plant with round, bright green leaves. The space is also neatly stocked with household goods like toilet paper rolls, white towels, water bottles, soap bars and a fire extinguisher. It looks partly like a survival shelter created by a mad architect and partly like an unusually imaginative department store window display. The interior is not quite as wonderful as the fantastic exterior leads you to expect, but the sculpture as a whole scores a rare public-art hat trick: it appeals to the cognoscenti, intrigues random passers-by and delights children. (Doris C. Freedman Plaza, Central Park, 60th Street and Fifth Avenue, 212-980-4575, through Oct. 29.) KEN JOHNSON

For fans of Bruce Springsteen, right, who can't make it to his concerts with the Seeger Sessions Band this summer, AOL Music (aolmusic.com) will offer streaming video of songs from each night of the tour, posted the morning after the concert. Yesterday the site, which is free and available to AOL subscribers and nonsubscribers alike, posted songs from the first four nights (the tour began on Sunday in Boston), and this Sunday it will offer a song from tomorrow's concert in Glendale, Ariz. BEN SISARIO

Two of the six remaining plaintiffs in the New London eminent-domain dispute have reached financial settlements with the city. The agreements, reached on Wednesday, involve the Dery family, which has lived in the Fort Trumbull neighborhood for five generations, and Thelma Brelesky, whose son has lived in the neighborhood for almost three decades. The settlements, for undisclosed amounts, had been negotiated by a state-appointed mediator.

PaceWildenstein 545 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through June 17 In subject and style, Alex Katz's work has changed little over the years. At a fairly early point he arrived at his signature blending of figure, landscape and abstraction -- not too suave, not too rough, a little goofy, a touch melancholic -- and he has stayed with it. For this reason it might be hard to tell at a glance that the paintings in ''Alex Katz: The 60's'' were actually from the 1960's. In images of two trees in silhouette against water, a city window viewed through a door, blandly attractive people in portrait close-up, we are in a timeless Katzland.
To the Editor: Alan J. Kuperman argues that intervention does not stop genocide and seeks to portray those of us who have been organizing on Darfur as ill informed and misguided.

A picture caption in The Arts on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about new buildings in Miami by prominent architects misstated the name of the building shown, which was designed by Bernard Tschumi. It is the School of Architecture at Florida International University, not the Miami School of Architecture.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Iraqi Leaders Criticize U.S. for Civilian Deaths Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq denounced the American military for what he described as habitual attacks by troops against Iraqi civilians. Separately, senior government leaders said Iraq would conduct its own inquiry into the killings of 24 Iraqis by American marines in Haditha. A1 Deal Reached on Offer to Iran The United States, Russia, China and three leading nations of Europe announced agreement on a package of incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, shelving any action by the Security Council until Iran has time to respond. A12 Iranian officials dismissed Washington's offer to engage in direct talks on the condition that Iran first suspend all uranium enrichment, yet they said the proposal indicated that Iran's approach in its handling of the nuclear crisis had forced the United States to take it more seriously. A12 North Korea Seeks U.S. Talks North Korea invited the top American nuclear envoy to visit Pyongyang for bilateral talks, but the White House insisted that the North return to long deadlocked six-nation talks instead. A13 U.S. Nuclear Policy Is Criticized Hans Blix, the former chief United Nations weapons inspector, said American unwillingness to cooperate in international arms agreements was undermining efforts to curb nuclear weapons. A12 An Admission in Rendition Case Germany's external intelligence service said it knew about the American seizure and detention of a German citizen 16 months before the country was officially informed of his mistaken arrest. A8 Quake Death Toll Passes 6,200 The death toll from the earthquake that struck Indonesia on Saturday rose to over 6,200, as hundreds of victims continue to die each day from their injuries. A13 NATIONAL A14-19 Army Corps Faults Itself In New Orleans Disaster In a new study of the causes of the disaster in New Orleans, the Army Corps of Engineers concluded that the levees it built in the city were an incomplete and inconsistent patchwork of protection, containing flaws in design and construction and not built to handle a storm anywhere near the size of Hurricane Katrina. A1 Mentally Ill and on Death Row The next big question in death penalty law now that the Supreme Court has barred the execution of juvenile offenders and the mentally retarded: what makes someone too mentally ill to be executed? A18 U.S. Wants Internet Records The Justice Department is asking Internet companies to keep records on the Web-surfing activities of their customers to aid law enforcement and may propose legislation to force them to do so. A15 More Money Sought for Oil Spill The State of Alaska and the Justice Department said they would seek an additional $92 million from Exxon Mobil to clean up stubborn patches of oil whose most toxic elements have not dissipated in the years since the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill. A14 A Bridge Over Bottlenecks The completion of the first of two six-lane spans that will constitute the new Woodrow Wilson Bridge between Virginia and Maryland promises to unclog what highway experts describe as the worst bottleneck on the East Coast. A14 Ship Sails Despite Protests After days of protests designed to delay a large Navy cargo ship from sailing to the war in Iraq, the vessel sailed out of Olympia, Wash., on time, port officials said. A18 Bone Drug Side Effect Reported Recent reports show that a class of drugs that can prevent agonizing broken and deteriorating bones may have a new and serious side effect: death of areas of bone in the jaw. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Debate on Charter Schools Among Parents in Harlem The proliferation of publicly financed but privately run charter schools in Harlem is prompting sharp debate among parents. Some are delighted with the new choices and are turning out in large numbers for lotteries for the limited charter school seats, while others say the charter schools are unproven and take the most promising students from traditional public schools. A1 Report Faults Security Plans A report by the Department of Homeland Security, which is distributing antiterrorism money to cities nationwide, found numerous flaws in New York City's application and gave poor grades to many of its proposals, including some of the city's most highly publicized counterterrorism tactics. A1 Republicans Nominate Faso John Faso, a former New York assemblyman, beat out William F. Weld, the former Massachusetts governor, by more than 3 to 2 at the Republican State Convention to become the party's nominee for New York governor. A1 WEEKEND E1-26; E27-34 Theater is Told to Vacate The owners of the Lamb's building at 130 West 44th Street, home of the Off Broadway Lamb's Theater Company, delivered notices to all of the building's tenants, asking that they vacate the building by Sept. 30. The theater company has leased the space, except for one six-year period, since 1978. E3 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-7 'Faith Night' at the Ballpark Faith Nights, a spiritual twist on Frisbee Nights and Bat Days, are becoming popular ballpark promotions. Later this summer, the religious promotions will hit Major League Baseball. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 U.S. Carmakers' Share Falls Asian carmakers continue to win converts in the United States at the expense of American companies. The market share of American automakers has fallen to 52.9 percent. C1 Court Clears Star Banker Frank P. Quattrone, the Silicon Valley's most prominent banker during the 1990's technology boom, has won a third major legal battle. Securities regulators have dropped all charges of obstruction of justice and lifted a lifetime ban from the securities industry. C1 Wall Street and Washington Wall Street leaders frequently seek out executives with deep Washington ties to be their closest advisers. Henry M. Paulson Jr., for example, received advice from James A. Baker III, a former Treasury secretary, on whether to leave his current job for a new position at the helm of the Treasury. Friedman. Crossword E6 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E25 Weather D8

A picture credit last Friday with a sports article about Dan Wheldon, the driver who won the Indianapolis 500 in 2005, misstated the given name of the photographer in some copies. It was Tom Strattman/Associated Press, not Tim.

The Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday, about Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is expected to be the next chief executive of Goldman Sachs, referred incorrectly to his background. While he was born in the Bronx, he was raised in a housing project in Brooklyn, not the Bronx.

In a bid to stave off price controls in Europe, six mobile phone operators said they were voluntarily cutting in half the amount they charged each other to carry the phone calls of customers who cross borders, a move that would produce savings for one in three European Union residents. While welcoming the reductions by the companies, T-Mobile, Orange, Telecom Italia, Wind, TeliaSonera and Telenor, Viviane Reding, the European commissioner for information and media issues, above, still planned to press ahead and formally introduce measures to regulate so-called roaming charges on July 19 in Brussels, a spokesman for Ms. Reding said. The operators agreed to cut their wholesale roaming charges to 0.45 euro (58 cents) a minute, from 0.90 euro ($1.15) starting Oct. 1, and to cut them to 0.36 euro (46 cents) in October 2007. The Vodafone Group, the market leader with 170.6 million customers, cut its roaming charges a month ago. KEVIN J. O'BRIEN (IHT)

The National Basketball Association suspended a backup center for the Dallas Mavericks but took no action against their owner, Mark Cuban, for an incident in the stands during Tuesday night's game in Phoenix. The center, D. J. Mbenga, was suspended for six games without pay, starting with Thursday's playoff game against the Suns. Mbenga is on the inactive list and has not played during the Western Conference finals. But the suspension of the 7-foot Mbenga could hurt the Mavericks if they advance to the N.B.A. finals and have to contend with Miami's Shaquille O'Neal.

CALL it a country town with a cosmopolitan edge. The town is Lewisburg, which is tucked into the foothills of the Allegheny mountains in southern West Virginia. It's a place where you can start the day kayaking down the Greenbrier River and end it listening to a jazz concert. An afternoon spent browsing the art galleries that line the historic downtown can be capped off with fly-fishing at twilight.

The Beijing Journal article on Tuesday, about an American scholar's production of the play ''Passages of Martin Luther King Jr.'' in Beijing, included a quotation that misidentified the Alabama city where a bus boycott helped to usher in the civil rights movement. It was Montgomery, not Birmingham.
To the Editor: I agree with Thomas L. Friedman that a way has to be found to make automobiles more fuel-efficient. But a gas tax takes a larger chunk of the income of those who make the least.

Virginia Fields, a former Manhattan borough president who ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for mayor last year, said yesterday that she would not seek the State Senate seat being vacated by David A. Paterson, the Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor. In a statement, Ms. Fields suggested that it was the wrong time for the race. ''My decision is very personal,'' she said, and cited ''a very grueling mayoral campaign.'' DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)

MARROW--Jane. In Concord, MA, formerly of Scarsdale, NY May 31. Beloved wife of Gordon H. Bemis. Dear mother of Eliza Jane Marrow Bemis and Robert Sy Marrow Bemis, both of Concord. Cherished sister of Deborah Marrow of Santa Monica, CA. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, cousins and in-laws. Donations in her memory may be made to The Greeley Foundation for Peace and Justice, 33 Bedford Street, Concord, MA 01742. For obituary, directions or guestbook visit www.deefuneralhome.com

Where can you hear the jazz legend Anthony Braxton leading an orchestra of 100 tubas; Yat-Kha, a throat-singing punk band from Siberia; Amiina, above, an all-young-female string quartet from Iceland that regularly tours with the rock band Sigur Ros; a severely retuned piano; and much, much more? At the Bang on a Can Marathon on Sunday, a free daylong happening in the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center. It seems hard to believe, but Bang on a Can is approaching its 20th anniversary. The enterprise was founded in 1987 by the composers Michael Gordon, David Lang and Julia Wolfe to foster contemporary music of all types, styles and global origins, with gleeful disregard for the boundaries that separate classical music, rock, ethno and electronics. The audience is invited to come and go all day. Next to some of the more eclectic performers, like Matmos, an electronica duo from San Francisco that tours with Bjork, the more traditionally hip contemporary music groups that are also taking part, like Alarm Will Sound, Tactus, and even Evan Ziporyn's gamelan ensemble, may sound almost tame. (From 11:30 a.m. to 10 p.m., West Street, south of Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, 212-835-2789.) ANTHONY TOMMASINI

From the 1960's and 1970's The New York Public Library Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street Stokes Gallery, third floor Through June 24 The much-lived-in streets of New York City have always been a lure for photographers, and what better home for their images than the New York Public Library? This show of new additions to the library's mammoth photo collection presents the work of six professionals: Garry Winogrand, Diane Arbus, Joel Meyerowitz -- more or less pioneers of the street genre -- and lesser-known practitioners, Thomas Struth, William Gedney and Roy Colmer.
To the Editor: Re ''A Secretary for Troubling Times'' (editorial, May 31):

JUAN--Dr. Paul L., a longtime resident of Bronxville, died on Wednesday, May 31, 2006. He was born to Paul Leo Juan and Lillian St. Jean Juan on February 9, 1935 in Greenwich, CT. Paul attended Fordham University, and University of Ottawa School of Medicine. Paul did his internship and residency at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York City. Paul served in the U.S. Army as Captain from 1966 to 1968. He was a diplomate of the American Board of OB/GYN; fellow of the American College of Surgeons' served as President of the NY Gynecological Society from 1978 to 1979; and member of the NY County Medical Society. He was Director of the OB/GYN Department for 12 years at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was in private practice for over 30 years and was a professor of OB/GYN at New York Medical College. Paul was the loving husband of Lois (Murphy) Juan to whom he was married for close to 46 years. Survivors included eight children and 23 grandchildren. Visiting hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son, Inc. Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St at Kraft Ave, Bronxville, Friday June 2nd from 2 to 4 pm and from 7 to 9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, NY on Saturday, June 3rd at 10 am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, West 12th St., New York, NY 10011.

8:30 P.M. (The N) BEYOND THE BREAK -- When there's trouble brewing in Venice, Calif. -- a neglectful mother, run-ins with the law -- where's a beach baby gonna go? To Hawaii, where else? Lacey Farmer (Natalie Ramsey, above center), board in tow, has her way with the waves in this new series about young professional female surfers (including Tiffany Hines, above left, as Birdie Scott and Sonya Balmores as Kai Kealoha), filmed entirely on Oahu. 7:30 P.M. (Oxygen) BEST OF CONCERT -- You asked for them, you got them and now Oxygen is replaying them: a half-hour of highlights from the network's Custom Concerts (translation: viewers' choice) by the Goo Goo Dolls, Trisha Yearwood and John Legend. 9 P.M. (BBC America) THE THICK OF IT -- Oliver's one-night stand with a researcher from the opposition party makes him the butt of all office jokes. That'll teach him a thing or two about political loyalty. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR: WORST-DRESSED FAMILY -- It's not exactly something to aspire to, this dubious distinction. Still, there are benefits to be reaped from being the most dismally attired family in the nation, as when Stacy London and Clinton Kelly (above, with Ms. London) take the entire household back to New York for two days of shopping, hair help from Nick Arrojo and a mother-daughter makeup session with Carmindy. 10 P.M. (13) MAYOR OF THE WEST SIDE -- Though he can speak only a few works, Mark Puddington is a celebrity in his New York neighborhood, where since the age of 4 he has walked the streets, shaking hands with everyone he passes. This documentary, part of ''New York Voices,'' follows Mark and his mother, Margaret, as they prepare for his bar mitzvah -- and peers in on the conflicting and often raw emotions that surface as his family and community struggle with the realities of his adulthood. 10 P.M. (DIY) R.V. ROADTRIPS -- In this new series, Gary Bunzer (right) covers the nuts and bolts of the recreational-vehicle experience -- from dinghy towing and battery maintenance to awning care and electric-brake tuneups -- so that your family outing doesn't turn out like a bad Robin Williams movie. 11:35 P.M. (Sundance) MOTHER/COUNTRY -- In her 2003 documentary Tina Gharavi returns to Iran -- and to the mother who, in the midst of a revolution, sent her 6-year-old daughter to the West -- and tries to reconnect. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Text as Image: An Homage to Lorenzo Homar and the Reverend Pedro Pietri El Museo del Barrio 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street Through Sept. 10 As artists, Lorenzo Homar (1913-2004) and the Reverend Pedro Pietri (1944-2004) look as different as night and day. But they had essentials in common. Both were born in Puerto Rico. Both made a logocentric art of social engagement. Both are all but unknown to the art world at large, a circumstance that these two mini-surveys, lovingly assembled for El Museo del Barrio by Margarita Aguilar, should correct.

The Islanders reached out to their past yesterday, naming Bryan Trottier their executive director for player development. Trottier, 49, played 15 seasons with the Islanders and starred at center on four consecutive Stanley Cup championship teams from 1980 to 1983.

Diner's Guide presents excerpts from recent restaurant reviews. Café d'Alsace With more than 110 pilsners and lagers and bocks, along with a designated beer sommelier to explain them all, Café d'Alsace is New York's newest paradise for beer lovers. But what makes it even more special is that it could stand alone as a fetching brasserie with accomplished (although inconsistent) food, including first-rate sausages, a satisfying choucroute garnie, a warm potato salad like no other and terrific desserts. It's a sturdy restaurant, not just a gimmicky one, and won't be beer today and gone tomorrow. 1695 Second Avenue, at 88th Street; (212) 722-5133. Dinner entrees, $16.75 to $29.96. ** [Rating: Two Stars] Sascha Downstairs is a brasserie-style space that would clearly like to compete with the nearby Pastis. Upstairs is a quieter refuge with leather booths, tasseled lampshades and tablecloths. And uniting the two levels is the menu and cooking of Sascha Lyon, whose American and Continental standard-bearers seem to channel the spirit of a Midwestern hotel. It's an odd and uneventful restaurant but an often enjoyable one, with a rack of lamb (upstairs) and double burger (downstairs) that prompt no complaints. 55 Gansevoort Street, at Ninth Avenue, meatpacking district; (212) 989-1920. Lunch and dinner entrees, $15 to $42. * [Rating: One Star] Crema Taking Mexican cooking in the kind of nuanced directions that too few restaurants in New York do, Julieta Ballesteros, formerly of Mexicana Mama, lays chicken on a purée of squash blossoms, puts portobello mushroom atop it and crowns it all with goat cheese. Imaginative flourishes or intricate architecture define many of her dishes, but the kitchen's execution does not always live up to the recipes. The cheerful, orange-tinged setting and fine margaritas are definite compensation, and Ms. Ballesteros is a chef to watch. 111 West 17th Street, Manhattan; (212) 691-4477. Dinner entrees, $17 to $26. * [Rating: One Star] A Voce The chef Andrew Carmellini's solo debut, A Voce concerns itself more with sating than with wowing you, and does so with seasonal ingredients, full-flavored dishes and superior cooking. Mr. Carmellini's terrific pasta dishes include agnolotti filled with duck and covered in a foie gras sauce, and pappardelle with a lamb Bolognese shine, and he's got a talent for meatballs, alternately made of duck, pork and shrimp. The stylized, contemporary room doesn't really go with the food, but there are enormously comfortable swivel chairs as a compensation, along with a thoughtful wine list. 41 Madison Avenue, entrance on 26th Street; (212) 545-8555. Dinner pasta dishes and entrees, $19 to $55. *** [Rating: Three Stars] What the stars mean: (None) Poor to satisfactory; * Good; ** Very good; *** Excellent; **** Extraordinary.

''Rooms Under the Influence'' David Zwirner 525 West 19th Street, Chelsea Through June 17 The Swedish artist Mamma Andersson (Mamma is a nickname) represented Scandinavia in the 2003 Venice Biennale, and her paintings were highlights of the 2004 Carnegie International. Her quietly revelatory show at David Zwirner is Ms. Andersson's first solo venture in the United States. Working in muted colors and high-contrast tonalities on thin panels measuring three to eight feet across, Ms. Anderson paints rooms and landscapes in a style that updates early Modernist realism. Sometimes with a slightly Japanese inflection, she combines the sensuousness of Edouard Vuillard and the haunted moodiness of Edward Munch.

Peter Braunstein, a freelance writer accused of sexually attacking a woman in Chelsea in October, has been found to be a paranoid schizophrenic by a psychologist who examined him at the request of his lawyer. The psychologist, Barbara R. Kirwin, says in a 15-page report released yesterday by Mr. Braunstein's lawyer that Mr. Braunstein has reported suicidal thoughts and is ''plagued by self-doubts.'' The lawyer, Robert Gottlieb, said he hoped that prosecutors would ''take a fresh look'' at the case against his client, who is charged with kidnapping and assault. ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS (NYT)

Los Angeles, the 1960's Washburn Gallery 20 West 57th Street Through July 21 When he arrived in Los Angeles in 1927, the artist and teacher Lorser Feitelson, (1898-1978) born in Savannah, Ga., brought with him Modernist ideas ingested in New York and Paris. An accomplished figurative painter, he rejected the going mode of Surrealism for neo-Classical and post-Surrealist approaches and became an influential figure on the Los Angeles scene.

Turkey Hill was just another road in Westport, Conn., when Martha Stewart moved there. As her business grew from home-based catering into an empire, the road evoked a certain kind of life; it even became the name of one of Ms. Stewart's furniture collections. Now, the old farmhouse on Turkey Hill Road, and all that it entails, is for sale. The four-acre property, with its three-bedroom house built by an onion farmer in 1805, is listed at nearly $9 million. Ms. Stewart and her former husband, Andrew Stewart, bought the property for $80,750 in two parcels in the 1970's.

Mr. Gutierrez equates his relationship with ''Retrospective Exhibitionist'' -- which had its premiere at Dance Theater Workshop in November and returns on Tuesday -- to that of parent to child. ''Last year the kid was a baby, and now he/she's a toddler/preteen,'' he wrote in a recent e-mail message from Vienna, where he was teaching at Tanzquartier Wien. ''You still attend to the kid and you love the kid, but you also begin to learn how to let the kid teach you stuff.'' Mr. Gutierrez's mesmerizing solo was a handful as a newborn; one can only imagine what has transpired since then. The work, above, which probes the performer's relationship to the audience, contains nudity, but far more revealing is Mr. Gutierrez's baring of his mental and emotional landscape; a shifting, fragile terrain that seems to consist equally of bravado and vulnerability. That mix is part of what makes him such an irresistible performer, whether he's mimicking a tape of himself mouthing off at a panel discussion or following a set of unspoken rules in a section of improvisational movement. ''I won't tell you what I'm thinking because then it's no fun for me,'' his e-mail teased. Also returning to the Workshop is Mr. Gutierrez's ''Difficult Bodies,'' a dance for three women that, with ''Retrospective Exhibitionist,'' creates a performance diptych. As with his solo, Mr. Gutierrez would only hint at subtle but important changes that ''invigorate and underline the 'power' of the women in the piece.'' Powerful women or no, they also function as representations of Mr. Gutierrez, in all his dizzying forms. (Tuesday through June 10 at 7:30 p.m., 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, 212-924-0077; $12 to $25.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

The New York State Bar Association announced yesterday that it had appointed Mark H. Alcott of Larchmont as its new president. As his first official act, Mr. Alcott, a senior litigation partner with Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, sponsored the creation of a special program to encourage the members to perform at least 50 hours of free work for the poor each year.

CBS was No. 1 among total viewers on Wednesday night, but for the second night in a row a ''Deal or No Deal'' rerun on NBC was the most-watched show of the evening, with 10.21 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. That show, combined with ''Dateline'' at 8 p.m. (8.2 million) and a ''Law & Order'' repeat at 10 p.m. (8.27 million), boosted NBC into first place among adults 18 to 49. Fox was No. 2 in that age group, as its ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (8.63 million) dance-off helped push it past CBS in that demographic. CBS's new show ''Gameshow Marathon'' (8.37 million) made its debut at 8 p.m. and was followed by reruns of ''Criminal Minds'' (9.95 million) and ''CSI: New York'' (9.76 million). On ABC an original episode of the canceled ''Commander in Chief,'' once the most-watched new show of last season, drew only 5.37 million. KATE AURTHUR

The Public Theater yesterday announced its 2006-7 season, the first lineup of shows selected solely by Oskar Eustis, who took over as artistic director last year. The season covers all the bases, from Shakespeare to established modern playwrights to up-and-comers. A Shakespeare play to be named will star Kevin Kline, left, and be directed by James Lapine, and Brian Dennehy will appear in Shakespeare in the Park in summer 2007. Among the post-Shakespearean works will be ''Wrecks,'' written by Neil LaBute and starring Ed Harris; ''The Singing Forest,'' written by Craig Lucas and directed by Bartlett Sher; and Suzan-Lori Parks's ''365 Days/365 Plays,'' a series of plays written on a one-a-day basis for a year. The up-and-comers: ''Durango'' by Julia Cho; ''Passing Strange,'' a musical by the performance artist Stew in collaboration with Heidi Rodewald; and ''Emergence-SEE!'' by Daniel Beaty. The Public also announced that it would co-produce ''Yellowface,'' a new satire by David Henry Hwang, at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles in spring 2007. ''Yellowface'' will come to the Public the next fall. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

WHO -- Jim Harris, 52, president of an on-demand printing company in Nyack, N.Y. WHERE -- Callicoon Center, N.Y. WHAT -- 3-bedroom house About two years ago, I got an inkling that it was time for a change. My son and daughter were in college, and after years of being active in the community -- the P.T.A., the community board, our synagogue, you name it -- my wife and I sensed it was time to slow down.

Three people testified yesterday at the hearing of a committee considering raises for the city's elected officials for the first time since 1999. A representative of the Staten Island borough president, James P. Molinaro, said it was ''ridiculous'' that borough presidents were paid only $135,000, far less than the salary of several mayoral aides. Two civic groups, the New York Public Interest Research Group and the Citizens Union, supported modest salary increases. The commission is scheduled to deliver a report by August to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg (who refused the official salary of $195,000 and accepts a token $1). He will then present his own recommendations to the Council, whose members are paid $90,000. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)
