At 8 p.m., Arts at University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street at Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (209) 602-3216; $15.(Dunning) URBAN BUSH WOMEN (Tomorrow) The company brings its signature mix of powerful, sassy and decidedly female dance to a Brooklyn park for a performance jam inspired by a Yoruba proverb. They weave together repertory, including excerpts from ''Give Your Hands to Struggle'' and the rousing ''Batty Moves,'' with a participatory call and response. The show opens with a dance by local sixth graders. At 6 p.m., Coffey Park, Visitation Place between Dwight and Richards Streets, Red Hook, Brooklyn, (212) 625-3505 or dancinginthestreets.org; free. (Kinetz) NINA WINTHROP AND DANCERS (Thursday) Ms. Winthrop will present her multimedia ''That's Me -- I'm the One Lying Down Over There,'' set to music by Jon Gibson. She has described its inspiration as the tendency of the world to be marked by ''strange shades of joy and sharp fits of ecstasy.'' (Through June 11.) At 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, at Second Avenue, East Village (212)674-8194 or danspaceproject.org; $15; $12 for students and 65+. (Dunning) BILL YOUNG/COLLEEN THOMAS & DANCERS (Tonight) Mr. Young and Ms. Thomas have collaborated for years as dancers and choreographers. This latest program will include their new work ''A Place in France,'' whose set has transparent distorting panels, magnifying lenses, tanks of water and live close-up video. At 7:30, Tisch School of the Arts, 111 Second Avenue between Sixth at Seventh Streets, East Village, (212) 998-1982; $15; $12 for students and 65+.(Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * American Folk Art Museum: 'WHITE ON WHITE (AND A LITTLE GRAY),' through Sept. 17. The importance of neo-Classicism to early American architecture, silver and fine furniture is not exactly news. This small, beautiful show follows its spread into more personal corners of visual culture: often exquisite, strikingly dimensional white-work bedcovers; luminously grisaille, sometimes wacky marble-dust drawings; and print-work embroidery mourning pictures. 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040. (Roberta Smith) * BARD GRADUATE CENTER: 'AMERICAN STREAMLINED DESIGN: THE WORLD OF TOMORROW,' through June 11. Streamlining, a particularly American design concept born of our love of speed and admiration for industrial production, peaked in the 1930's and 40's, and is now said to be undergoing a revival. This tribute to it includes more than 180 objects, from boring but useful items like a receipt printer designed by Walter Dorwin Teague in 1946 to a plastic bicycle helmet of flowing teardrop shapes designed by John Larkin in 2000. The show is perhaps too packed with repetitive examples -- do we need to see three similar electric drills? -- but don't let that stop you. There's no shortage of wonderful things to look at here. 18 West 86th Street, (212) 501-3000. (Grace Glueck) * BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'SYMPHONIC POEM: THE ART OF AMINAH BRENDA LYNN ROBINSON,' through Aug. 13. This prodigious show, by an artist born and still living in Columbus, Ohio, celebrates her heritage in paintings, drawings, sculpture, stitchery, leather work and less classifiable forms of expression. Besides its sheer visual wizardry, using materials like leaves, twigs, bark, buttons and cast-off clothes, her art is compelling in that it ruminates on the history of black migration to, and settlement in, the United States, from early times to the present, in a garrulous, very personal way. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000. (Glueck) COOPER-HEWITT NATIONAL DESIGN MUSEUM: 'FREDERIC CHURCH, WINSLOW HOMER AND THOMAS MORAN: TOURISM AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through Oct. 22. It turns out that the Cooper-Hewitt owns thousands of rarely seen paintings, prints and sketches by Church, Homer and Moran. Studies of the countryside, mostly, they revere unspoiled nature and record tourism, a booming industry in 19th-century America. Here they're combined with antique postcards, old Baedekers, stereoscopic photographs, playing cards with pictures of Yellowstone on them and souvenir platters, all to trace the nation's transformation from primeval wilderness to Catskills resort. The show is extremely entertaining.2 East 91st Street, at Fifth Avenue, (212) 849-8400. (Michael Kimmelman) * FRICK COLLECTION: 'VERONESE'S ALLEGORIES: VIRTUE, LOVE AND EXPLORATION IN RENAISSANCE VENICE,' through July 16. Paolo Veronese (1528-88), a superb colorist and one of the most suavely sensuous of Renaissance Venetian painters, used the age-old device of allegory to make abstract concepts visual, often by means of human or mythological figures. In this five-painting show, the first to include all of his large-scale allegories from American collections, high ideals mingle with earthy and sometimes erotic physicality, as in the painting ''Venus and Mars United by Love.'' 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700. (Glueck) JEWISH MUSEUM: 'EVA HESSE: SCULPTURE,' through Sept. 17. Assembled by Elizabeth Sussman, curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art, and Fred Wasserman, a curator at the Jewish Museum, this show focuses on a pivotal Hesse exhibition, ''Chain Polymers,'' at the Fischbach Gallery -- known for promoting Minimalist painters -- in 1968. Arguably a compilation of her best work, it was her first and only solo show of sculpture during her lifetime, and most of the objects in it -- along with some earlier and later pieces -- are here. (An exhibition of her drawings is on view at the Drawing Center.) 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200. (Glueck) * METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'ANGLOMANIA: TRADITION AND TRANSGRESSION IN BRITISH FASHION,' through Sept. 4. Ranging from early-18th-century gowns to next season's evening wear, this show crowds 65 extravagantly clad mannequins into the Met's normally serene English period rooms, trying to connect the sartorial innovations of the English dandy, the aggressive tribal attire of punk and the deconstructive impulses of today's British fashion stars. (212) 535-7710. (Smith) * MET: 'GIRODET: ROMANTIC REBEL,' through Aug. 27. Hugely famous in the early 19th century, Girodet dropped down the memory chute. His ''Ossian Receiving the Ghosts of French Heroes,'' painted for Napoleon, is one of the most deranged pictures in art history. It's so unhinged that it's almost lovable, which is otherwise the last word to come to mind for an artist who, in his uptight, smarty-pants mode, could be a bore. But give the show a shot. It's sometimes brilliant, and Girodet's strangeness and fairly repellent character make him at least fascinating to contemplate and heroic in his immoderation. History is full of shifty characters, antique visionaries, cusp figures and half-crazy oddball innovators, later overlooked because they're hard to pigeonhole. Their independent cast of mind is the truest expression of how civilization advances. (See above.) (Kimmelman) * Morgan Library and Museum: 'Masterworks from the Morgan,' through Sept. 10. Almost three years after closing to build an expansion, the Morgan is back and brilliant. What's new: Renzo Piano's splendid four-story glass-and-steel court, a sort of giant solarium with see-through elevators; two good-size second-floor galleries; and a neat little strongbox of an enclosure, called the Cube, for reliquaries and altar vessels, medieval objects made with so much silver and gold that they seem to give off heat. What's not new: almost everything in this exhibition, which fills every gallery with mini-exhibitions of master drawings and musical manuscripts. 225 Madison Avenue, at East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 or themorgan.org. ( Individual show closings can be checked by telephone or through the Web site.)(Holland Cotter) Museum of Modern Art : 'AGAINST THE GRAIN: CONTEMPORARY ART FROM THE EDWARD R. BROIDA COLLECTION,' through July 10. The latest collection assembled by the Museum of Modern Art bolsters its holdings of art world mavericks like Philip Guston, Jennifer Bartlett, Ken Price and Vija Celmins and includes first-timers like Robert Grosvenor, John Lees and Susana Solano. It also illuminates parts of the untold, or forgotten, stories of the art of the 1970's and 80's: the achievements of painters and sculptors who were not at the forefront of Post-Minimalism, photo appropriation or Neo-Expressionism. Some of their efforts may disappear into storage, but quite a few will shake up the Modern's conception of the complicated course of art since 1970. The Museum of Modern Art, (212) 708-9400. (Smith) Museum of the City of New York: Sherril Schell: 'Unknown Modernist,' through June 13. Though little known today, the photographer Sherril Schell (1877-1964) was critically recognized in the 1930's for his severely formalist photographs of New York architecture. This small exhibition presents 15 examples in which closely cropped views of the Chrysler Building, the Empire State Building, the Brooklyn Bridge and other monuments of Manhattan emphasize compositional order, structure, pattern, light and shadow. Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street, (212) 534-1672. (Ken Johnson) New York Public Library: 'FRENCH BOOK ART/LIVRES D'ARTISTES: ARTISTS AND POETS IN DIALOGUE,' through Aug. 18. Organized with the Bibliothèque Littéraire Jacques Doucet in Paris, this lavish exhibition surveys some of the experimental ferment brought on by the combination of free verse, visionary publishers and the high rate of talent among French artists and poets, especially in the early years of the 20th century. New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089. (Smith) NOGUCHI MUSEUM: 'BEST OF FRIENDS: BUCKMINSTER FULLER AND ISAMU NOGUCHI,' through Oct. 15. Great, lasting friendships are rare, but friendships that enlarge the spirit through ideas, ideals and new insights are in a class by themselves. Over a stretch of more than 50 years, the sculptor Isamu Noguchi and the visionary designer R. Buckminster Fuller enjoyed such a friendship, which led to aesthetic and practical achievements that left their mark. The course of their varied collaborations is traced in this exhibition, which includes models, sculptures, drawings, photographs and films. 9-01 33rd Road, between Vernon Boulevard and 10th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 204-7088. (Glueck) * The Studio Museum In harlem: 'Energy/Experimentation: Black Artists and Abstraction, 1964-1980,' through July 2. During one of the most radical periods in 20th-century American politics, the Black Power era, a group of African-American artists was working in one of the most radical forms of 20th-century art: abstraction. This show is stylishly installed; the 15 artists are intensely individualistic and part of an important history. 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500. (Cotter) Galleries: 57th Street 'THE EAMES LOUNGE CHAIR: AN ICON OF MODERN DESIGN' Celebrating the 50th anniversary of a chair whose combination of declarative modernist structure and sheer creature comfort was both innovative and a bit alien, this exhibition is a successful design object in its own right. It pays homage with drawings, advertising ephemera, precursors, vintage television clips, a wonderful documentary and three versions of the chair itself, enshrined, exploded and useable. Museum of Arts & Design, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535, through Sept. 3. (Smith) Galleries: SoHo EVA HESSE: 'DRAWING' This show deals in depth with Ms. Hesse's works on paper, ranging from rough sketches or notes, to test pieces made from various materials that function as drawings, to finished projects that stand on their own. A zealous researcher, Ms. Hesse made all kinds of thumbnail notations and calculations to explore the properties of her malleable materials. Many of these sheets, perhaps too many, are shown, too. Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166, through July 15. (Glueck) Galleries: Chelsea * 'An Ongoing Low-Grade Mystery' Organized by the curator Bob Nickas, this excellent group show includes works in many different mediums and styles related in that they are all predominantly red. Donald Judd, Sherrie Levine, Jim Drain, Wolfgang Tillmans and Dan Walsh are among more than 30 artists included. Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105, through June 23. (Johnson) Willem de Kooning: 'Sketchbook' Twelve pages bearing spidery pencil drawings from a rare, intact sketchbook from the mid-1970's by this great Abstract Expressionist. Matthew Marks Gallery, 523 West 24th Street, (212) 243-0200, through June 17. (Johnson) BASQUIAT and DUBUFFET: 'PERSONAL MEMORIES' Nothing illuminates art like other art. And the pairing of two artists with similar appetites for drawing, collage, the grittiness of life and a bristling energy exudes a high-wattage electricity all its own. PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000, through June 17. (Smith) RICHARD SERRA: 'ROLLED AND FORGED' The centerpiece of the latest Serra spectacular, which favors mass, compression and rectangles over stretched-thin curves and spirals, is a low-lying maze in which the shifting heights and staggered placement of 16 thick, hedgelike plates create one of the most spatially complex yet straightforward works of his career. Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212) 741-1111, through Aug. 11. (Smith) Other Galleries 'The Drop' More than two dozen artists present multimedia conceptual creations about the global problem of water. In works ranging from densely informational to entertainingly visual, they address the pollution, increasing scarcity and private marketing of one of our planet's most necessary resources. Nancy Drew made 100 colorful paintings based on water bottle labels; Brandon Ballengée presents a pyramid of bottles containing preserved specimens of endangered marine life; and Christy Rupp's installation of five water coolers invites viewers to test the water of each of New York's five boroughs. Exit Art, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 966-7745, through June 10. (Johnson) Last Chance * Willem de Kooning: 'Paintings 1975-1978' Working with wide brushes, putty knives and other unidentifiable tools and methods, de Kooning improvised with abandon and to beautiful effect in these 13 paintings from the 70's. L & M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020; closes tomorrow. (Johnson) * Joe FiG With extraordinary skill and ingenuity, this young sculptor replicates in miniature the studios of well-known artists. The centerpiece of his exhibition recreates the adjoining Long Island studios of the painters and spouses Eric Fischl and April Gornik. Plus Ultra Gallery, 637 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 643-3152; closes tomorrow. (Johnson) * Rosalind Solomon: 'American Pictures from Chapalingas' This excellent exhibition of works from 1974 to 2000 surveys the career of a photographer with a keen eye for human individuality and a pitch-perfect sense of composition. Her art bears a family resemblance to that of Diane Arbus, but it is gentler and kinder. Foley, 547 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 244-9081; closes tomorrow. (Johnson)

A picture caption on Tuesday about Memorial Day observances in New York City referred imprecisely to the children surrounding Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at a parade. Although they included one Boy Scout, most were Cub Scouts.
GINSBERG--William R. Memorial service Monday, June 5, 4:30 PM, Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, NYC.

An Op-Ed on Tuesday, about internships, misstated the percentage of private-sector workers who are unionized. It is 7.8 percent, not 12.5 percent, which is the rate for private and public workers combined.

A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday about the Maytag advertising account misstated the role played by Mark Devine in some of the old Maytag commercials. He was the repairman's apprentice, not the repairman. In addition to Jesse White and Gordon Jump over the years, Hardy Rawls is the third actor to play the part of the repairman, not Mr. Devine.

DUNN--Norman S. of Pound Ridge, NY and Boston, MA on May 31, 2006. He is survived by his beloved wife Mildred, his son Jeffrey, his brother Arnold, several nieces and nephews, and his muchadored grandchildren, Lucas and Noah. Born in Woonsocket, RI on September 17, 1921, he graduated cum laude from Providence College and became a highly successful businessman in the textiles industry. He was Executive Vice-President and Treasurer of Chelsea Industries for fifty years, and involved in numerous philanthropic organizations, including serving as an overseer of the Beth Israel/ Deaconess Hospital, Boston and honorary trustee of The Rehabilitation Center for the Aged in Boston. Norman was a kind, gentle, and generous man who was admired, loved, and adored by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held Sunday, June 4 at 1pm at the Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St, Stamford, CT with interment at Pound Ridge Cemetery, Westchester Ave, Pound Ridge, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Parkinsons Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, NY NY 10018. $(6$)DUNN--Norman S. The Board of Governors and members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their longtime beloved friend and esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Charles Roden, President
To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman refers to the Hummer and S.U.V. drivers as ''gas addicts.'' Let's not lose sight of the personality types who buy these gas-guzzlers.

''I don't like to be interrupted,'' says Richard Griffiths, below, as Hector, the corpulent British teacher in the Broadway hit ''The History Boys,'' explaining why he teaches behind a locked door. Mr. Griffiths as Mr. Griffiths doesn't like to be interrupted either. So when a cellphone went off for the third time during a crucial scene at Wednesday's matinee at the Broadhurst Theater, he stopped performing and glared at the audience. ''I can't compete with these electronic devices,'' he said. ''Now you were asked nicely by the stage manager,'' he continued, referring to the preshow announcement telling audience members of the 2003 City Council ban on cellphones in theaters. ''You were told that it's against the law.'' This, he said, is ''just disrespectful.'' Then he announced that he would start the scene for the second -- and last -- time: ''I won't do it again. You've been warned.'' The audience vigorously clapped. Mr. Griffiths has previously halted performances in London for repeated cellphone interruptions, asking the transgressors to leave. At the matinee Mr. Griffiths left and re-entered to restart the scene with Clive Merrison, who plays the headmaster. This time when Mr. Griffith said, ''I hate to be interrupted,'' the audience laughed. And even Mr. Griffiths couldn't contain a smile. PATRICIA COHEN

To the Editor: I can't speak for my fellow green wristband wearers, but I wear mine not in support of the Darfur rebels, but of the principle that genocide and rape are not legitimate military tactics, whoever uses them, and of the innocent victims who have died and continue to die.

Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated his support yesterday for government financing of the underground infrastructure at ground zero, leaving the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation responsible only for meeting the $500 million budget now assigned to the memorial and museum. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to pay $100 million of the memorial's share of infrastructure costs. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

A Bronx man who tried to rob a pizza deliveryman on Tuesday was arrested after the deliveryman fought back and chased him, the police said yesterday. Investigators are trying to determine if the suspect, Charles Jones, 38, is responsible for a string of similar robberies in Manhattan last month. On Tuesday afternoon, the deliveryman arrived at 43 West 93rd Street and was met downstairs by Mr. Jones, the authorities said. The two men got on the elevator, where Mr. Jones attacked the deliveryman with a metal pipe. The man fought back, and chased Mr. Jones into Central Park, where he was arrested. KAREEM FAHIM (NYT)
MARCUS--Gertrude. Age 102, in California. Wife of the lateJulius. Burial in New York.

The National Gallery of Art presents Charles Sheeler's no-nonsense yet melancholic images of factories, mills and skyscrapers (including ''Architectural Planes,'' above), and highlights the versatility of a career that encompassed painting, drawing, photography and film. Ken Johnson's review, Page 34.

AGATSTON--Adell Paymer. On Wednesday, May 31, 2006. Wife of the late Dr. Howard Agatston; beloved mother of Ann (Philip) Glazer, Dr. Arthur (Sari) Agatston, John (Michelle) Agatston and Alice (Dennis) Corbett; sister of Sylvia Schwartz; sister-inlaw of Robert Agatston; grandmother of Jeffrey, Evan, Adam, Ben & Sammy. Graveside service will be held at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, Sunday, June 4 at 11:00 a.m. Memorial contributions may be made to Nat'l Alzheimers Foundation 11240 Waples Mill Rd, Ste 402, Fairfax, VA 22030.

Music will be everywhere at the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this fall. The 18-engagement festival -- the biggest in Next Wave's 24 years -- begins on Oct. 3 with choreography by Akram Khan and Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, left, based on the music of Steve Reich, as part of the ''Steve Reich @ 70'' celebration, also at Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall. It ends in December with ''Don Juan in Prague,'' an adaptation of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' by David Chambers that stars the Czech avant-garde singer Iva Bittova. Some of the events in between will be ''The End of Cinematics,'' the third part of Mikel Rouse's ''opera vérité'' trilogy, inspired by Susan Sontag's essays on film; a tribute to the Afro-pop legend Fela Kuti with Amadou and Mariam, Cheikh Lo, Les Nubians, Dead Prez and others; and Carl Hancock Rux's opera-oratorio ''Mycenaean.'' Other highlights include the choreographer Sarah Michelson's Brooklyn Academy debut, return engagements by Pina Bausch and the Japanese butoh troupe Sankai Juku, and the Chekhov International Theater Festival's production of ''Twelfth Night'' in Russian, with a cast of Russian film and television stars. Subscription tickets go on sale on June 19. Information: (718) 636-4100 or bam.org. BEN SISARIO

Larry Ellison, chief executive of Oracle and one of the richest men in the world, can't unload his Japanese villa in Atherton, Calif., so he's knocked down the price.

Recently we interviewed Dave Sarachan, the coach of the Chicago Fire, about various nations' tactical styles. We were pretty skeptical when he pronounced Peter Crouch, the gawky, giraffe-like replacement for Wayne Rooney in the England front line, "much better with his feet than people give him credit for." But if you were watching the England-Jamaica friendly today, which England won by 6-0 with three goals from Crouch, you'd have seen that Sarachan was right. When served skillfully by David Beckham and the other England players, Crouch, however goofy-looking he might be, is a deadly efficient striker.
Just in from Reuters, this potentially disconcerting news for the squad representing the nation of Serbia and Montenegro: Montenegro Declares Independence.
A wonderful story in today's Irish Independent puts into perspective the Michael Schumacher affair by recalling many of the famous incidents of cheating in world sporting history.

Four years ago, a guy named Clint -- Mathis -- was all the rage in the American soccer world. Cover of Sports Illustrated, pivotal goal against South Korea. But since those heady days, Mathis has been a bust, big time, in Germany and back in the U.S. of A.

Here's a sure sign that World Cup fever has taken over from avian flu as Europe's No. 1 concern: there are fears that it may jump the species barrier and spread to non-human animals. According to Süddeutsche Zeitung, a European animal rights organization called the Europäische Tier und Naturschutz (or E.T.N.) is urging fans across the continent, but particularly Dutch fans, to break with tradition this year and not paint their pets the color of their national team's uniform. As an alternative, the E.T.N. recommends that fans settle for dressing their "dogs or hamsters" in replica team jerseys.
Even as glass and steel towers reshape the city's skyline, a small group of craftsmen stand guard over New York's ever more fragile stone survivors.

In yesterday's Times, our colleague Sarah Lyall reported that British authorities have launched a quixotic campaign to discourage English fans who will be traveling to Germany for the World Cup from emulating Basil Fawlty and making frequent, gratuitous references to the Second World War. That may turn out to be far easier said than done. The tournament always inspires nationalist frenzies of varying degrees of intensity in the countries that take part. But this year, given that the first round pits Germany against Poland and the final will take place in the stadium built by the Nazis for the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, it may be quite hard for even the most impartial observer to get through the month without mentioning the war.
Compelling match-ups have been hard to come by in the early going at the world's premier clay-court tournament, but they were suddenly there on all kinds of courts.

Quarterback Shaun King, a starter at Tampa Bay when Tony Dungy was the coach there, signed a contract yesterday with the Indianapolis Colts. King, who did not play in the N.F.L. last season, joined the Detroit Lions in March and was released on Wednesday. He will try to make the Colts as Peyton Manning's backup. He has passed for 4,566 yards and 27 touchdowns.

CONSUMERS were willing to open their wallets last month, but seem reluctant to do so in the near future. Energy companies, meanwhile, are eager to spend money and are likely to spend a lot more soon. These developments have something in common: energy prices. Gasoline near $3 a gallon and the prospect of high summer air-conditioning bills are spooking many consumers but are exciting energy executives looking to use their cash hoards to buy out rivals.
Katharine Close, of Spring Lake, beat 274 of the United States' and Canada's top wordsmiths to win the 79th annual Scripps National Spelling Bee.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission must consider the risk of terrorist attack when it evaluates the environmental effect of new projects, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled. The commission had said that a nuclear reactor in California, Diablo Canyon, could build fuel storage casks without any significant environmental impact, and that the possibility of a terrorist attack was "speculative and simply too far removed from the natural or expected consequences of agency action to require a study." But the court, ruling in a suit brought by the group San Luis Obispo Mothers for Peace and others, rejected that reasoning.

A military jury at Fort Meade sentenced an Army dog handler to 90 days of hard labor but no prison time for using his animal to threaten a prisoner at Abu Ghraib in Iraq. The handler, Sgt. Santos A. Cardona, was reduced in rank to specialist, with a corresponding pay cut of nearly $480 a month, and ordered to forfeit $600 a month for one year.

Ten families were deported to Honduras under a new policy allowing federal authorities to speed the return of some illegal immigrant families, Immigration and Customs Enforcement said. Of the 120 illegal immigrants flown back to Honduras from San Antonio on Thursday, 21 were part of families sent back under the new policy, the agency said. The change lets the authorities return illegal immigrants to their home countries without a hearing.

A judge fined the state attorney general $10,000 for comments after the state won a lawsuit against former lead paint manufacturers, his second fine over statements about the case. A day after the February verdict, the attorney general, Patrick C. Lynch, was quoted in The Boston Globe as saying that the decision proved that the companies could not "duck and run" from their obligation to deal with lead paint problems. Mr. Lynch also praised jurors on a Web site. The judge, Michael Silverstein of Superior Court, had instructed lawyers not to address the jurors.

The Security Council voted to add 1,500 peacekeepers to the 7,000 already in Ivory Coast as temporary help in a political transition to elections in October. A failed coup attempt in 2002 left the government controlling the south and rebels holding the north. Secretary General Kofi Annan had asked for 3,900 new troops and police officers, but the United States, which pays 27 percent of the peacekeeping budget, protested.

A United Nations court trying the masterminds of Rwanda's 1994 genocide handed a six-year sentence to a former director of a radio station whose broadcasts were said to have encouraged the killings. The director, Joseph Serugendo, was on the board of Radio Télévision Libre des Mille Collines and the national committee of the Interahamwe militia. The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda said he had pleaded guilty to

The World Bank's new strategy for Pakistan forecasts doubling lending to the country over the next four years to as much as $6.5 billion. Up to $1 billion would help with recovery from the October 2005 earthquake. Much of the balance would finance projects in health, education, roads, railways, electricity and water. The bank praised Pakistan for policies that helped increase economic growth to 8.4 percent in 2004 and 2005, from 3.3 percent between 1997 and 2002. It said the government, bolstered by foreign aid, had exceeded targets for spending on health, education and antipoverty programs.

A suicide bomber blew his car up near a Pakistani Army convoy in Waziristan, a tribal area on the Afghan border, killing four soldiers and wounding seven, the chief army spokesman, Maj. Gen. Shaukat Sultan, said. The suicide attack, aimed at two army vehicles stopped on a road between Bannu and Miramshah in North Waziristan, represents a new tactic for the Islamic militants and foreign fighters operating in the area, who have until now mostly favored ambushes and remote-controlled explosions directed at military convoys.

Thousands of Somalis denounced the United States and called for Islamic law at a rally in the war-torn capital, Mogadishu, where Islamic militias have been battling a secular alliance. Eleven people were killed in fighting in the northern suburbs and four died in the city when a booby-trapped bicycle exploded. A Muslim leader at the rally called America an enemy of Islam and said Washington supported the secular warlords, whose battle with Islamist fighters has spawned some of Somalia's worst fighting in 15 years of anarchy. The United States is widely believed to support the secular alliance, but American officials have not commented. Somalia has had no effective government since 1991, when warlords overthrew the former dictator, then turned on each other. The Islamic militias are surging as a United Nations-backed transitional government struggles to assert control outside its base in Baidoa, 155 miles northwest of Mogadishu.

José Ramos-Horta, a Nobel peace laureate, said he would take over East Timor's top security posts. Mr. Ramos-Horta, left, already the foreign minister, shared the 1996 peace prize for bringing world attention to the plight of East Timorese under Indonesian rule. He will replace the ministers of defense and interior, who resigned Thursday, taking responsibility for failing to prevent recent violence.

An American sailor was sentenced to life in prison by the Yokohama District Court for killing a 56-year-old Japanese woman during a robbery on Jan. 3. The sailor, William O. Reese, 22, of Pittsgrove, N.J., was convicted of beating the woman to death near the United States Naval Base in Yokosuka, south of Tokyo.

A couple have been charged with trying to hire a hit man to kill their daughter-in-law, granddaughter and two step-grandchildren to prevent them from testifying at their son's rape trial.

An article in some copies on May 18 about the appointment of Kevin M. Rampe as chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the rebuilding of downtown, misspelled the name of a building damaged on 9/11. (The error was repeated in an article in some copies on May 19 about the progress on rebuilding at ground zero.) It is Fiterman Hall, not Fitterman.

A front-page article and headline yesterday about the criticism of the American military by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq in the wake of outrage over reports that American marines killed 24 civilians in the town of Haditha last year included an incorrect translation of his comments. Mr. Maliki said that violence by American troops against civilians had become a ''regular occurrence'' -- not a ''daily phenomenon.''

STAHL--Reva, age 76, passed away at home in New Rochelle on June 2, 2006. Reva, originally from Massachusetts, lived there until a recent move to New York after the passing of her husband of 57 years, Joseph. She is survived by her sister Frummie Lourie, brother Reuben Silver, her children Bernard, Jeffrey and Dina, Lewis and Helene, and Sharon and Howard Wexler. Mrs. Stahl dearly loved her grandchildren Evan, Allison, David, Jonathan and Jacob. Reva was a generous and devoted mother and grandmother. Services are being held at 11:45AM on Sunday, June 4th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish National Fund. Shiva will be held at the home of Jeffrey and Dina Stahl, 64 Jerome Ave., New Rochelle, NY.
Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission must consider the risk of terrorist attack when it evaluates the environmental effect of new projects, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled. The commission had said that a nuclear reactor in California, Diablo Canyon, could build fuel storage casks without any significant environmental impact, and that the possibility of a terrorist attack was ''speculative and simply too far removed from the natural or expected consequences of agency action to require a study.'' But the court, ruling in a suit brought by the group San Luis Obispo Mothers for Peace and others, rejected that reasoning. MATTHEW L. WALD (NYT)
PIERCE--Willa Martin, a resident of Rye, NY died Tuesday, May 30. She was 94, and was the wife of the late Marvin Pierce. Services will be private.

To the Editor: Re ''Iraqi Accuses U.S. of 'Daily' Attacks Against Civilians'' (front page, June 2):

HANRAHAN--James F., Sr. James F. Hanrahan, Sr., innovative educator and founder of St. Thomas More School in Oakdale, CT and devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend has died at the age of 82 surrounded by family. Jim leaves his beloved wife Patricia (Sweeney), 13 children, 33 grandchildren and one great grandchild. As a dad, he instilled the importance of a close knit family unit, religion and education and was happiest when with family. While teaching in the 1950's, he envisioned an all boys' school for the ''underachiever.'' In 1962 he fulfilled his dream by founding St. Thomas More School that has shaped the lives of thousands of young men. Born in Waterbury, CT in 1923, Jim attended Sacred Heart School and Crosby High. Important early influences were relatives Msgr. William Fox and Rev. Michael J. McGivney, founder of ''The Knights of Columbus.'' After studying in the seminary, he transferred to Georgetown University, graduating in 1947, earning his Masters from Fairfield University in 1952. As a teacher at Fairfield Prep, he coached men's basketball at Fairfield University, and was inducted into their sports Hall of Fame. Later, he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate by Fairfield for founding STM. A memorial service will be held 10:00 a.m. Saturday June 24th in Our Lady Chapel at St. Thomas More School. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the James F. Hanrahan Memorial Fund at STM, 45 Cottage Road, Oakdale, CT.

MARK--Stanley. 80 years old. Died June 2. Beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Nancy (Larry Honig), Carol (John Garger), and Harvey. Brother of the late Herbert Mark. Stepfather of John Gevertz (Susan), the late Bruce Gevertz (Jackie), Carrie Sheer (Paul Bourget), Andrew Sheer and William Sheer. Adoring grandfather of Emily and Charles Honig; Rebecca and Annie Gevertz; and Willie, Justin and Andrew Gevertz. He proudly served in Europe during World War II, and was a graduate of the University of North Carolina. He was a practicing accountant for over fifty years. Private graveside service.

ROBERTS--Hon. George F. The legal profession will forever miss, but always remember, the humanity, wisdom and sharp wit of a most insightful jurist and good friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and to his beloved, Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann. Herman, Sloan, Robarge & Sullivan, LLP

Sally Porter and her brother, Bill Navran, had two choices. They could either hire home care aides to live with their 79-year-old mother in her condo in Kansas City, Mo., or put her in an assisted living center. The choice could have been straightforward, but for one thing: Mrs. Porter lived in Tucson and Mr. Navran was in Hawaii. The two knew nothing about health care services in Missouri and did not know where to start looking. Luckily, their lawyer knew about Kansas City Home Care, a geriatric care management company that assesses a person's condition and puts together services to address the situation. For $170, a geriatric care manager interviewed their mother, Marjorie Siegel-Navran, for two hours and suggested a way for her to remain at home. They set up four aides, who for $18 an hour would help her bathe, dress, eat and travel.

President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Friday defied pressure from foreign leaders to accept a package of incentives in return for ending all nuclear activities, saying Iran will pursue its legal right to develop a peaceful nuclear program. ''Any pressure to deprive our people from their right will not bear any fruit,'' he was quoted as saying on state-run television.

Richards Back, Stones Roll The Rolling Stones said yesterday that Keith Richards, right, had made a complete recovery from a head injury, and that the band would resume its European tour on July 11 at the San Siro Stadium in Milan. The European leg of the Stones' world tour had been scheduled to begin last Saturday, but was postponed when Mr. Richards, 62, reportedly fell out of a palm tree in April while on vacation in Fiji, suffering a concussion. He had brain surgery last month in New Zealand. The rescheduled European tour will include 21 stadium concerts in 11 countries through Sept. 3; two German dates, in Nuremberg and Leipzig, have been canceled. In a statement Mr. Richards said: ''Excuse me, I fell off of my perch! Sorry to disrupt everyone's plans but now -- it's FULL STEAM AHEAD! Ouch!'' Jolie a Cybersavvy Mom Angelina Jolie has a head start on cybersquatters. The actress has reserved 24 Internet domain names that feature variations on the name of Shiloh Nouvel Jolie-Pitt, her daughter with Brad Pitt, Agence France-Presse reported. Internet registration files show that the Web addresses ''shilohjolie,'' ''shilohpitt,'' ''shilohjoliepitt,'' ''shilohnouveljolie,'' ''shilohnouvelpitt'' and ''shilohnouveljoliepitt'' -- with the extensions .com, .org, .net and .info -- had been reserved as of May 27, when the baby was born. Ms. Jolie has control of those Web addresses for one year. Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes were not so enterprising. Their daughter's name, Suri, was co-opted by someone else who registered the domain ''suricruise.com.'' That Web site features a countdown to Suri's 18th birthday. Starbucks Heads Straight to Video Starbucks, the coffeehouse chain that is already a big seller of CD's, will enter the video business this month with an exclusive DVD version of a 1987 documentary about Chuck Berry, above, ''Chuck Berry Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll,'' according to The Hollywood Reporter. Starbucks will begin selling a DVD-CD combo of the film and a Chuck Berry compilation album on June 27, the same day that the distributor Image Entertainment will release the standard two- and four-disc versions of the film. The Starbucks DVD includes 40 minutes of extra film selected and edited by the director Taylor Hackford and will sell for $19.95. The documentary is based on a concert for Mr. Berry's 60th birthday in 1986 featuring Keith Richards, Eric Clapton, Etta James, Linda Ronstadt and others. Dear Catherine Twenty-six letters written by Voltaire, left, to Catherine the Great of Russia were bought at auction on Tuesday on behalf of an unidentified bidder, Agence France-Presse reported. According to Reuters, Alexander Khochinsky, a dealer in Moscow, told Nezavisimaya Gazeta, a Moscow newspaper, in a report published on Thursday, that he bought the letters for $750,000 at an auction at Sotheby's in Paris. Mr. Khochinsky said the letters would be returned to Russia. He declined comment when asked if he had bought the letters at the request of a Russian state official, the paper said. The lot represents more than a quarter of Voltaire's extensive correspondence with Catherine (1729-96). ''The letters contain texts completely unknown to researchers,'' Mr. Khochinsky said. ''They have been published nowhere.'' Pop Notes New albums due in coming months include the country stars George Jones and Merle Haggard's first record together since 1982. Their album, ''Kicking Out the Footlights Again,'' is to be recorded this summer and released on Bandit Records in October. The rapper Method Man will release ''4:21,'' his fifth studio album, on July 18, Billboard reported. The album, on the Def Jam label, includes the single ''Say,'' with acoustic guitar, strings and samples of Lauryn Hill's version of Bob Marley's song ''So Much Things to Say.'' Other guests on the album include Fat Joe and Styles P. Nas's album ''Hip-Hop Is Dead,'' to be marketed jointly by Def Jam and Columbia, is set for a Sept. 19 release. The next project for Diana Krall, above, will include standards like ''From This Moment On,'' ''How Insensitive'' and ''It Could Happen to You'' in quartet and large-band settings. Her album, which does not yet have a title, is scheduled for a Sept. 12 release by Verve. The label Shout Factory will release five late albums by the blues legend John Lee Hooker next year. The albums, all from the 1980's and 90's, include ''Boom Boom'' and ''Chill Out.'' The label also plans to release an 84-track, four-disc box set by the end of 2006. Mr. Hooker died in 2001.

The Irish spend more of their income on alcoholic drinks and go binge drinking more often than any other European nationality, according to a European Union study. Irish households spend an average of almost $2,150 annually on alcohol, more than triple the figure for Denmark, home to the second-biggest spenders. One-third of Irish 15- and 16-year-olds go on drinking binges at least three times a month. Despite government efforts to combat alcohol abuse and refute Ireland's reputation for drunkenness, consumption has soared during the economic boom of the last decade. BRIAN LAVERY (NYT)

When the Internet telephone provider Vonage went public last week, it was meant to be a coming-out party for a technology that many see as the future of voice communications. It was also a chance at redemption for Jeffrey A. Citron, a brash and canny entrepreneur trying to overcome a checkered past. The company had many things to recommend it: about 1.5 million paying customers, a solid brand name and a big share of a growing market. But Vonage's public offering quickly imploded. Its shares were priced at $17 and have fallen as low as $11.64, a 32 percent decline that is one of the sharpest for a new stock in recent years. The stock rose yesterday to close at $11.98.

ALDWELL--Edward. There was no finer performer of the works of J.S. Bach than pianist Edward Aldwell. His live recitals were life-changing experiences for his listeners, leaving indelible images etched in the memory. He was one of the great treasures of our musical community, and as one of many dedicated admirers, I mourn his loss with great sorrow and send sympathy to his wife Jean Ann. Norma Hurlburt

The hair, the clothes, the moist eyes, the guest appearance by Gene Shalit: the denouement of Katie Couric's long goodbye from NBC's ''Today'' drew an average of 8.4 million viewers on Wednesday morning, according to Nielsen. It was the fourth-highest-ranked broadcast of ''Today'' since at least 1987, when Nielsen began using its current research methods. Ms. Couric, above, is to take over as the anchor of the CBS Evening News in September, but in her last full week on ''Today,'' which ended on May 26, the show drew an average of 5.8 million viewers. It was the morning show's 546th week in first place, finishing in front of ABC's ''Good Morning America'' (4.9 million) and CBS's ''Early Show'' (2.6 million). ... On FX on Tuesday the premiere of Season 3 of ''Rescue Me,'' the Denis Leary firefighter series, delivered an estimated 3.2 million viewers. On the networks on Thursday CBS won every hour in total viewers, including 8 p.m. with ''Game Show Marathon'' (8.4 million). Fox was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49. The first prime-time telecast of ''The Scripps National Spelling Bee,'' on ABC, attracted 8 million viewers, helping to put ABC in second place for the night among total viewers. KATE AURTHUR

An obituary on Thursday about Slim Aarons, the photographer of celebrities, omitted his name in the titles of two of his books of photographs. They are ''Slim Aarons: Once Upon a Time'' and ''Slim Aarons: A Place in the Sun.''

An article in Business Day on May 26 about a proposed tax-shelter settlement with the accounting firm KPMG omitted part of the response of a lead plaintiff who was offered a financial incentive to serve as a plaintiff, according to a court filing. The article noted that the plaintiff, Claude Gerald Harris, said the statements about the alleged offer, while largely true, were taken out of context. But it omitted his explanation that he and the lead plaintiff group, represented by the class-action securities law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, would be justified in getting more money than other plaintiffs because of the strength of their claims, among other reasons. He also stated that the lead plaintiffs had not been promised any portion of the lawyers' fees.

NADORF--Ben. 1919-2006. An icon of the boxing world has died. Ben Nadorf, 87, passed away on June 1, 2006, in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. A WWII veteran, Mr. Nadorf was President of Everlast Sports Manufacturing Corp. from 1957 to 2000. He made Everlast the national and international brand of boxing; boxing gloves and trunks were worn by many world champions. A loving and generous husband, brother, father and grandfather, he is survived by his devoted wife Sue, brother Louis, son and daughter-in-law Wayne Eugene Jacob and Dulce, grandson Joshua David, daughter and son-in-law Alexis Nadorf Teplitz and Paul Teplitz, and grandchildren Lita Arielle and Spencer Wayne. Services for Mr. Nadorf will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY on Monday, June 5 at 9:30am. He will be buried at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY next to his first wife Leona Yvette and son Wayne Alan. In lieu of flowers please make donations to: Rabbi Emeritus Discretionary Fund, Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY 10804. (914) 235-1800.
MERLINO--Marian June. Happy Birthday, Mother. Always remembered. Love, Marian and Lauren

To the Editor: For those of us unschooled in the subtleties of international diplomacy, it is a mighty puzzle to read David Brooks wax rhapsodic about the administration's decision to condescend to talk with Iran over the nuclear issue (''No More Excuses,'' column, June 1).

IF presiding over a growing economy with low inflation was the measure of a good Treasury secretary, then John W. Snow would be leaving his position with accolades all around, and Henry M. Paulson Jr., his chosen successor, would be said to have a tough act to follow. To assess the tenure of Treasury secretaries, the economy's performance under Mr. Snow was compared with the performance under each of the previous 10 secretaries, going back to William E. Simon, who served Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford from 1974 to 1977.

An article on Wednesday about new United Nations reports on the global AIDS epidemic referred imprecisely to the rate of H.I.V. infection in South Africa. With 5.5 million people infected, the rate is 19 percent of the nation's adult population, not its entire population.

A front-page article on April 15 about the compensation of Lee R. Raymond, the former chief executive of Exxon Mobil, included outdated information on the pay of another executive, Steven P. Jobs of Apple Computer. As the article reported, Mr. Jobs received $775 million, mostly from stock options, in 2000. But he never exercised the options because they would have cost him more than Apple shares on the open market. Instead, in 2003, he returned the options and, in exchange, Apple's board awarded him five million shares of restricted stock, valued at $74.75 million at the time. This correction was delayed by research.

With Mariano Rivera recovering from his stiff back but not yet ready to pitch, Yankees Manager Joe Torre was almost upbeat Friday night when he announced the latest ailment on his roster before his team opened a three-game series against the Orioles. ''We might not have Alex tonight,'' Torre said, casually introducing the subject of the availability of third baseman Alex Rodriguez, who is the American League's reigning most valuable player and the Yankees' leader in runs batted in with 44.

The first public preview of ''Grendel,'' the Los Angeles Opera's $2.8 million premiere by Elliot Goldenthal, went smoothly on Thursday night at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion after technical problems postponed its opening last Saturday, a delay the company said cost $300,000 in lost ticket revenue. A second preview is scheduled for tonight, with the official opening now set for Thursday. On May 23, four days before the opera was to open, computer malfunctions caused damage to a $950,000 set piece called the ''ice-earth unit,'' a 45,000-pound, 48-foot-long trapezoidal creation by the set designer George Tsypin. The piece, which stretches nearly the width of the stage and at times moves noisily, features a snowy landscape on one side and forest roots and rusted tools on the other, and rotates for each of the opera's 12 scenes. ''Grendel,'' a collaboration between Mr. Goldenthal, the librettist J. D. McClatchy and the co-librettist and director Julie Taymor, tells the story of Beowulf from the point of view of his antagonist, the man-eating monster. The first co-production by the Los Angeles Opera and the Lincoln Center Festival, ''Grendel'' is expected to open on schedule at the New York State Theater on July 11. BLAIR TINDALL

CONSUMERS were willing to open their wallets last month, but seem reluctant to do so in the near future. Energy companies, meanwhile, are eager to spend money and are likely to spend a lot more soon. These developments have something in common: energy prices. Gasoline near $3 a gallon and the prospect of high summer air-conditioning bills are spooking many consumers but are exciting energy executives looking to use their cash hoards to buy out rivals. Seeking to calm the financial markets, which were rattled by these changes and persistent signs of inflation, President Bush nominated a new Treasury secretary with ample credibility on Wall Street and Capital Hill. A NEW CAPTAIN -- With the dollar falling and the trade deficit rising, and with tax cuts bumping up against a sizable federal budget deficit, President Bush named Henry M. Paulson Jr., a Wall Street banker, to succeed John W. Snow as Treasury secretary.

APPEL--Patricia (nee Loveland), died on May 28, 2006 at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. Born May 17, 1928 in Detroit, raised in Minnesota, Patricia was a longtime resident of St. Chamas in Provence, France and of Greenwich Village. She was an accomplished photo editor and photo-journalist. Blessed with a brilliant mind, a great sense of humor, beauty and style, a joie de vivre, and a lifelong passion for books, music and travel, she embraced life fully. She is survived by her daughter Kristina Goldstein of Harrison, NY, her son Mark Appel of Manhattan, her son-in-law Jacob and granddaughter, Talia.

GEORGE--Sally. May 31, 1991 How does one replace the irreplaceable? One doesn't. Oh Sally, you are missed and thought of, every single day. You are in my thoughts and heart always. Your ever present smile, feisty spirit and love of life live on...with so much love, Catherine

An American sailor was sentenced to life in prison by the Yokohama District Court for killing a 56-year-old Japanese woman during a robbery on Jan. 3. The sailor, William O. Reese, 22, of Pittsgrove, N.J., was convicted of beating the woman to death near the United States Naval Base in Yokosuka, south of Tokyo. NORIMITSU ONISHI (NYT)

To the Editor: I guess the bar has been lowered to about six inches from the ground for the Bush administration if making two good appointments constitutes a ''display of competence.'' Bob Finger Teaneck, N.J., June 1, 2006
To the Editor: Re ''Pork 1, Antiterrorism 0'' (editorial, June 2):

An article in some copies on May 18 about the appointment of Kevin M. Rampe as chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is overseeing the rebuilding of downtown, misspelled the name of a building damaged on 9/11. (The error was repeated in an article in some copies on May 19 about the progress on rebuilding at ground zero.) It is Fiterman Hall, not Fitterman.

An obituary yesterday about Raymond Davis Jr., a chemist who won a Nobel Prize in Physics for capturing neutrinos from the sun, misspelled the given name of a survivor and referred incompletely to her hometown. She is Dr. Davis's daughter Martha Kumler of Honeoye Falls, N.Y. -- not Marha, of Honeoye.

When Commissioner Bud Selig appointed George J. Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader, to head a steroids investigation more than two months ago, the general belief was that Selig was focusing on Barry Bonds. Selig denied it, but his denials did not eliminate the notion. While Mitchell and his investigators have conducted an undisclosed number of interviews, it is unclear if they have contacted Bonds. Mitchell refused to respond to the question Thursday. When Bonds was asked last month if he had heard from Mitchell, he said, ''No, not at all.''

INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Discrepancy on Haditha Went Ignored at First Marine commanders in Iraq learned within two days of the killings in Haditha last November that Iraqi civilians had died from gunfire, not a roadside bomb as initially reported, but the officers involved saw no reason to investigate further, according to a senior Marine officer. A1 The United States military said it has cleared of any wrongdoing a commander who led a raid March 15 on a home in Ishaqi, north of Baghdad, that left as many as nine Iraqis dead and prompted the police to charge that American forces executed civilians. A6 Reviews by the office of the inspector general for the United States' reconstruction effort in Iraq provide a clear picture of a program so obscured by the fog of war that even the managers in charge often seem unclear on what has really been achieved. A6 Chinese Mobs Go Online A phenomenon in China called Internet hunting, where online throngs administer morality lessons and anonymous Web users investigate others and mete out punishment, is reminiscent of China's Cultural Revolution, when mobs of students taunted and beat their professors. A1 Iran Rejects New Nuclear Offer President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran defied pressure from foreign leaders to accept a package of incentives in return for ending all nuclear activities, saying Iran would pursue its legal right to develop a peaceful nuclear program. A7 Israeli Troops Kill 2 Egyptians Israeli soldiers shot and killed two members of the Egyptian security forces who crossed the remote desert border from Egypt to Israel, officials of both countries said. A5 Putin Fires Chief Prosecutor President Vladimir V. Putin has dismissed Russia's chief prosecutor, who only a week ago promised to disclose new ''high-profile'' cases involving government corruption, officials said. The dismissal prompted a flurry of speculation about Mr. Putin's motives. A3 Man Shot in London Terror Raid British police officers, in one of the largest counterterrorism operations in London since the bombings last July, shot, wounded and arrested a 23-year-old man in a raid on a home in East London, according to police accounts. A5 SCIENCE/HEALTH U.N. Takes Hard Line on AIDS The United Nations General Assembly adopted a strongly worded declaration aimed at pressuring the nations of the world to strengthen their battle against AIDS, the global pandemic that Secretary General Kofi Annan called ''the greatest challenge of our generation.'' A5 NATIONAL A8-11 Scientist Settles Lawsuit Over Invasion of Privacy Wen Ho Lee, an atomic scientist once suspected of espionage, settled an invasion of privacy lawsuit against the government for $1,645,000, with five news organizations paying almost half of that to avoid contempt sanctions against their reporters. A1 Push Against Same-Sex Unions President Bush is beginning a major push for a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, part of a new campaign to appease cultural conservatives who say he and his party abandoned their issues after the 2004 elections. A10 7 in Family Killed in Shooting Seven members of a family, including three children, were shot and killed in their home in what the police believe began as an attempted robbery. The police said that they had arrested one suspect and were asking for the public's help in finding a second. A9 Former Aide Denies Lying David H. Safavian, a former White House budget official, testified that he had not lied to investigators when he claimed that there was no ethical conflict in his decision to accept an invitation from the lobbyist Jack Abramoff to join a 2002 golfing trip to Scotland by private jet. 9 Religion Journal A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Mayor Criticizes Cuts To Federal Security Money After the panel that guides the distribution of federal antiterrorism money cut New York's share of funding by roughly 40 percent, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg assailed the secretive process, telling listeners of his weekly call-in radio program that he had complained to Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff and planned to fight it. A1 Two Killed in Plane Crash Two pilots were killed and three passengers were rescued after a small business jet crashed off the coast of Connecticut. B1 A Candidate's Tough Fight To the surprise of many New York Republicans, John Faso was chosen to be the party's candidate for governor at the state convention. He is hoping to become a political giant-killer by winning the Republican primary over the well-known former Massachussetts governor William F. Weld. JONAS--Seymour. Grandpa died on May 31, 2006 after a long and valiant battle with cancer. He leaves behind his wife, children, daughters-inlaw and grandchildren which he adored. Grandpa was a brilliant man with a love of gardening, fixing everything, The Times crossword puzzles and most importantly a great love of family and life. He taught his family to laugh, deal with the good and bad events of life, and to treat people with respect and kindness. He lived a 3-speed life in a 10-speed world. He will be missed greatly but remembered every minute of every day. Love, His Family & Friends

OVED-WEISS--Or, 23, beloved son of Inbal Oved and Mark and Cathy Weiss, died suddenly and tragically in Bangkok, Thailand. Or was a loving and adored son, a worshipped caring brother and an inspiration to all who knew him. He served with distinction as a Sergeant, First Class in Sayeret Duvdevan of the Israel Defense Forces where he interdicted terrorism, lead and inspired the members of his unit. A dual citizen, Or represented the best qualities of his native Israel and the United States. 'The valiant never tastes of death but once.' $(6$)OVED-WEISS--Or. On behalf of our entire organization we wish to express our profound sorrow and sincerest condolences to our esteemed partner Mark Weiss, his wife Cathy and their sons Brandon and Ryan on the tragic and untimely loss of their beloved son and brother Or OvedWeiss, son of Ibal Oved of Israel. Or was an exceptional young man. Our hearts ache for the Weiss and Oved families. May his memory be a blessing. The Principals of Newmark Knight Frank

The World Bank's new strategy for Pakistan forecasts doubling lending to the country over the next four years to as much as $6.5 billion. Up to $1 billion would help with recovery from the October 2005 earthquake. Much of the balance would finance projects in health, education, roads, railways, electricity and water. The bank praised Pakistan for policies that helped increase economic growth to 8.4 percent in 2004 and 2005, from 3.3 percent between 1997 and 2002. It said the government, bolstered by foreign aid, had exceeded targets for spending on health, education and antipoverty programs. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

7 P.M. (G4) FILTER -- This irreverent countdown series returns with a new set, new graphics, and not a little new buzz. The inaugural topic: ''21 Legendary Parties,'' from a ''skin'' party in South Miami and Carnivale decadence in Rio de Janeiro to the better-left-to-the-imagination machinations of the Donner Party. The show's host is Beth Ostrosky (above), who, as Howard Stern's girlfriend, knows a thing or two about matters of the flesh. 7 P.M. (Spike) WORLD'S MOST AMAZING VIDEOS -- Think America's funniest home videos, the TV-14 version. 7:30 (Showtime) RE: EVOLUTION OF SPORTS -- Athleticism at its most extreme, and in high definition to boot. Don't try this at home, or anywhere else for that matter. 7:30 P.M. (G4) ICONS -- This weekly biography series begins afresh with a look at ''the standard-bearers of all things cool,'' according to its people. First on: J. J. Abrams (right), who traveled from ''Felicity,'' ''Alias'' and ''Lost'' to direct the tepidly received ''Mission: Impossible III,'' a challenge that proved nearly insurmountable, even for him. Music from new indie bands backs it all up. 8 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) FRANKENSTEIN UNBOUND (1990). Time slides backwards in this Roger Corman diversion and takes Dr. Joe Buchanan (John Hurt) and his car with it. When he lands, in 1817 Switzerland, he finds Dr. Frankenstein (Raul Julia) and his contemporaries, including Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin (Bridget Fonda), Lord Byron (Jason Patric) and Percy Bysshe Shelley (Michael Hutchence), stirring up a mess. 8 P.M. (Spike) CARPOCALYPSE: CIVIL WAR -- It's all-out war when the North battles the South in Season 2 of this demolition-derby series, in which half the races are run in Buffalo and the other half in Bithlo, Fla. 9 P.M. (Discovery Channel) ANT WARS -- There is perhaps no bigger sorority on Earth, and certainly not one more sinister. This new episode looks at the African driver ant, a superorganism of 20 million sisters that devours everything in its path. Everything. 10 P.M. (Sundance) MYSTERIOUS SKIN (2004). In Gregg Araki's unexpectedly eloquent drama, adapted from Scott Heim's novel, Brady Corbet and Joseph Gordon-Levitt (left) share more than their characters' Kansas hometown. Though neither knows it, each has been molested by a Little League coach, and their violations leave welts of varying shapes: one grows up to be a teenage hustler, and the other comes to believe he was abducted by aliens. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

To the Editor: What is truly flawed in the controversy over reducing New York City's share of total antiterrorism dollars by 40 percent from $207 million to $124 million is that we are spending $200 million a day in Iraq, with costly pay for local security forces.

U.S. Job Growth Crawls, Indicating a Slowdown The nation added 75,000 jobs in May, the Labor Department said, less than half what most forecasters had expected. The news was seen as an indication that higher gas prices and interest rates were starting to crimp growth. KLEBANOW--Hy. August 14, 1915 to June 1, 2006. Gentleman, friend, mentor, a distinguished artist and founder of graphic arts company Kleb Associates, Inc., serving national accounts, he encouraged others to appreciate the joy of art and the art of seeing. Survived by a son and daughter, four grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Private service for family, followed by exhibition of paintings and reception Sunday, June 4, 12:30 P.M., 500 N. Columbus Avenue, Mt. Vernon.

Yoshiaki Murakami is Japan's answer to Carl C. Icahn, a self-proclaimed corporate raider who struck fear into the heart of corporate boardrooms and became a symbol of the nation's new breed of American-style financial entrepreneurs. Now, however, news reports here that Mr. Murakami, 46, is under investigation for suspected insider trading have raised questions about whether these younger upstarts are being punished by Japan's old guard or whether authorities are just cracking down on questionable activities in the resurgent stock market.

PEARCE -- Richard Inman. Died June 1 after a short illness. Richard is survived by his wife, Nancy Muir Pearce, his four sons, Richard, Steuart, Peter, Michael; three step-children, Katharine, Andrew, Morgan; twelve grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Born in Hewlett, L.I. on September 27, 1915, he attended St. Paul's School and Yale, where he sang in the Whiffenpoofs. While serving in the Navy in World War II, he married Patsy Pittman of NYC. They lived in Louisville, KY until 1971 when they moved to Old Lyme, CT. Patsy passed away in 1990. On October 8, 1998 he married Nancy Muir in Edgartown, MA. Dick was a gifted piano player, singer & avid sailor. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme on June 7 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Red Cross of which Dick was the Louisville Chapter Chairman for many years.

The Security Council voted to add 1,500 peacekeepers to the 7,000 already in Ivory Coast as temporary help in a political transition to elections in October. A failed coup attempt in 2002 left the government controlling the south and rebels holding the north. Secretary General Kofi Annan had asked for 3,900 new troops and police officers, but the United States, which pays 27 percent of the peacekeeping budget, protested. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

A suicide bomber blew his car up near a Pakistani Army convoy in Waziristan, a tribal area on the Afghan border, killing four soldiers and wounding seven, the chief army spokesman, Maj. Gen. Shaukat Sultan, said. The suicide attack, aimed at two army vehicles stopped on a road between Bannu and Miramshah in North Waziristan, represents a new tactic for the Islamic militants and foreign fighters operating in the area, who have until now mostly favored ambushes and remote-controlled explosions directed at military convoys. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)
ESPN severed its relationship with the ''Bonds on Bonds'' reality series yesterday. The network cited demands for editorial control by Barry Bonds's representatives for a planned final episode.
A young couple leaves a roomy apartment in Chicago for a cozier place in the heart of the Lower East Side.

So who are these "food police" we're starting to hear so much about? The term has begun showing up in media accounts of campaigns to reform school lunch or in discussions of the food industry's growing legion of critics in the media. It's the "food police" who want to get soda out of the schools and who argue that fast food outlets should disclose nutritional information about what they sell. The "food police" supposedly want to take away your constitutional right to a Big Mac - or, at the very least, your right to enjoy a Big Mac with a clear conscience.

Many thanks to everyone who wrote in response to my first column. I'm afraid that I can't answer all of the questions that were raised - apologies - but I wanted to pick up on a couple of themes.

On the front page of The New York Times today, Jere Longman looks at the problem of racism among fans, players and coaches in some European soccer leagues and reports on plans by the game's authorities to confront this intolerance head-on during the World Cup. While this news might seem to confirm all the worst stereotypes about soccer fans being ultra-violent, extreme-nationalist thugs, it is important to keep in mind that there are also signs, in the composition of several of Europe's leading national teams, that in an increasingly united Europe the old idea that nations should be made up exclusively of members of one ethnic group is gradually breaking down. Hopefully more multi-ethnic European nations will also be more tolerant ones.

You don't often associate The Daily News with coverage of the world game, but the meat-and-potatoes New York tabloid's best sports columnist, Filip Bondy, knows and loves soccer. In today's paper, he writes from Hamburg about the FIFI Wild Cup, FIFI being what the International Federation of Independent Football nations likes to call itself, rather than IFIF, which is too bad since its members are from places that are politically disputed, lack a sufficient form of self-government or are otherwise unrecognized by FIFA.

In Hanover, Germany, Nikolai Valuev of Russia kept his World Boxing Association heavyweight title, knocking out Owen Beck of Jamaica yesterday in the third round. It was the first fight for Valuev (44-0, 32 knockouts) since taking the title from John Ruiz on a controversial decision in December.

Priceline is offering international vacation packages. New destinations include Bangkok; Beijing; Hong Kong; Sydney, Australia; Cairo; Buenos Aires; and Rio de Janeiro (www.priceline.com). ... Diane Siebert and her husband did what many of us fantasize about: dropped everything and hit the open road. For 10 years, they rode motorcycles around the country, picking up work along the way when they ran out of money. Siebert has written numerous children's books about her experiences, and in TOUR AMERICA: A JOURNEY THROUGH POEMS AND ART (Chronicle, $17.95, ages 8 and up), she teams with Stephen T. Johnson, an artist and recipient of a Caldecott Honor, to highlight her favorite places. These include well-known spots like Niagara Falls and Mount Rushmore, and more obscure ones like Cadillac Ranch in Texas, an art installation of upended, graffitied cars. There's no better way to adjust to the slow pace of life at the beach than starting with one of Phoebe Atwood Taylor's classic mysteries featuring Asey Mayo.
Whitestone is now protected by severe limitations on  the building of those oversized houses unaffectionately known as McMansions.
If you want to relive the tragedy of American liberalism, take a gander toward California, where voters will decide Tuesday on Proposition 82.
Unless we get moving, over the next 14 years some 45 million additional lives may be claimed by AIDS.

MY son's bar-mitzvah-going year is almost over. There are a couple more invitations sitting in the kitchen, and then I'll be free. But not quite yet. Chauffeuring back and forth to synagogues and women's clubs/hotels/catering halls is the latest task in a long career of suburban kid-driving that includes school drop-offs, sports practices and games, class trips and birthday parties. This is more interesting than it sounds, because for some unfathomable reason, when I'm operating a motor vehicle, kids forget I'm an actual human with ears and they speak freely. The driving is dull, but it's a great opportunity to pick up some intel.

An article last Sunday about the business challenges facing the Sony Corporation misstated the timing of Sony's acquisition of the film rights to ''The Da Vinci Code.'' It occurred three years ago, not two.

To the Editor: Three things are apparent on Long Island: we love our schools, we boast about our homes and we complain about taxes. According to ''A Smart Tax,'' by Marc F. Bernstein (Op-Ed, May 21), Long Islanders must be committed to changes in the way we finance public education. That's true. One of the solutions promulgated by many is that we pay for public education through the income tax.

An article last Sunday about earmarks, the legislative practice of setting aside money in spending bills for special projects, included erroneous amounts, based on information in the Congressional Record, for the Missouri Forest Foundation and the Mystic Aquarium in Connecticut. Congress approved $750,000 for the forest foundation, not $750 million; and $400,000 for the aquarium, not $400 million.

To the Sports Editor: I would like to commend Joe Drape for his insightful, emotional, fair reporting on Barbaro's injury, Barbaro's hoped for recovery, and Barbaro's impact on the horse racing industry.
HENDLER--Marcia. We will miss you dear friend and traveling companion. Condolences to Richard and the entire Hendler family. Ina and Allen Rich

WITH one ship on the way and another one in the way, Oyster Bay Harbor is as full of conflict as it is of boats. Next Saturday, a 134-foot-long brigantine called the Corwith Cramer will arrive from Woods Hole, Mass., to offer a day of free tours, and visitors are expected to line the pier waiting their turn. But a 150-foot lighthouse ship, the Nantucket, which tied up to the pier in 2003, seems to be making no move to leave, even though it has been ordered to.

WITH one ship on the way and another one in the way, Oyster Bay Harbor is as full of conflict as it is of boats. Next Saturday, a 134-foot-long brigantine called the Corwith Cramer will arrive from Woods Hole, Mass., to offer a day of free tours, and visitors are expected to line the pier waiting their turn. But a 150-foot lighthouse ship, the Nantucket, which tied up to the pier in 2003, seems to be making no move to leave, even though it has been ordered to.

REPORTED cases of Lyme disease in the metropolitan region rose sharply in 2005, according to health officials, with increases of 34 percent in Connecticut, 23 percent in New Jersey and 9 percent in New York State. But some counties showed declines. Westchester had 458 reported cases, a decrease of 39 percent from 2004. On Long Island, Suffolk County, with 542 cases, declined 3 percent, while Nassau County, with 122 cases, had an increase of 107 percent.

To the Editor: When Henry James returned to New York City a century ago after 20 years abroad (''The Old Neighborhood,'' May 28), it was not only his old downtown neighborhood whose changes amazed him.
