INTERNATIONAL 3-24 Smuggling Scheme in Iraq The sabotage attacks that have crippled Iraq's oil pipelines and refineries for the past three years are now being used to aid a vast gasoline smuggling network that is costing the Iraqi government billions of dollars a year. 1 Gunmen ambushed five Russian embassy workers just blocks from their residence in western Baghdad, killing one and kidnapping the others in a bold attack that has become common in parts of Baghdad. In Basra a suicide attacker blew up a car bomb, killing at least 15 people. 10 Humans and Spread of Bird Flu In the wake of a cluster of avian flu cases that killed seven members of a rural Indonesian family, it appears likely that there have been many more human-to-human infections than the authorities have previously acknowledged. 14 Terrorist Arrests in Toronto Seventeen Canadian residents were arrested and charged with plotting to attack targets in southern Ontario with crude but powerful fertilizer bombs, the Canadian authorities said. American officials said the plot did not involve any targets in the United States, but warned that the full dimension of the plan was as yet unknown. 1 How Iran Strategy Changed With the threat of the coalition against Iran at risk of falling apart, and after intense debate lasting nearly two months, the Bush administration gradually grew more comfortable with offering talks to Iran, a country it considers the number one state sponsor of terrorism. 1 Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld told a gathering of defense experts that Iran was ''one of the leading terrorist nations in the world,'' and also questioned why Russia and China would allow Iran to participate the Shanghai Cooperation Organization. 12 NATIONAL 26-34 Border Patrol's Role Grows With a major expansion proposed by President Bush, the Border Patrol may soon overtake the F.B.I. as the largest federal law enforcement agency. But the stepped-up mission comes as the Border Patrol wrestles with recruitment and training problems and several agents face accusations of misconduct. 34 Town Seeks Its Own Energy A farming town in Indiana wants to secede from America's energy grid and power itself entirely with renewable sources, like its corn and pigs. 1 Early Test for Democrats In the first major Congressional race of what could be a politically volatile year, the battle to fill the seat of a jailed Republican in California is providing an early test of whether Democrats can turn Republican unrest into control of the House. 26 French Renaissance in Maine After decades of stigma for French-Americans in Maine, French is making a comeback. The state elected its first openly French-American congressman, and Gov. John E. Baldacci has steadily increased commerce with French-speaking countries. 26 Using Secrets Privilege Facing a wave of litigation challenging its eavesdropping at home and its handling of terror suspects abroad, the Bush administration is increasingly turning to a legal tactic that swiftly torpedoes most lawsuits: the state secrets privilege. 32 New Breast Cancer Drug For women with a certain type of breast cancer, the drug Herceptin has represented a major advance, but for some of those women, the drug never works. Now, an experimental drug promises to help women whose cancer continues to worsen despite taking Herceptin. 26 NEW YORK/REGION 27-29 Clinton Criticizes Terror Cut Intensifying complaints about a cut in antiterrorism money for New York City, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton challenged President Bush to take responsibility for the action. New York's share of the 2006 grants was reduced by 40 percent. 39 Chess 42 Obituaries 44 Weather 45
To the Editor: The amount of money being grabbed by Great Neck Plaza is not exaggerated (''A Village Where You Need Plenty of Coins,'' May 28).

NADORF--Ben. 1919-2006. An icon of the boxing world has died. Ben Nadorf, 87, passed away on June 1, 2006, in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. A WWII veteran, Mr. Nadorf was President of Everlast Sports Manufacturing Corp. from 1957 to 2000. He made Everlast the national and international brand of boxing; boxing gloves and trunks were worn by many world champions. A loving and generous husband, brother, father and grandfather, he is survived by his devoted wife Sue, brother Louis, son and daughter-in-law Wayne Eugene Jacob and Dulce, grandson Joshua David, daughter and son-in-law Alexis Nadorf Teplitz and Paul Teplitz, and grandchildren Lita Arielle and Spencer Wayne. Services for Mr. Nadorf will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY on Monday, June 5 at 9:30am. He will be buried at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY next to his first wife Leona Yvette and son Wayne Alan. In lieu of flowers please make donations to: Rabbi Emeritus Discretionary Fund, Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY 10804. (914) 235-1800.

ARGENTINA The Argentines have historically been loaded with talent, from Diego Maradona to their current teenage phenomenon, Lionel Messi. They beguile with their feet, their heads and, in the case of Maradona, their hands. And, of course, they win: two World Cups and two second-place finishes. So why are they so loathed? Could it be because the team has more drama queens than ''Desperate Housewives'' -- players who dive and fake injuries when someone sweats a little too close to them? Or because they often mistake an opponent's legs for the ball (they earned a tournament-high 45 yellow and 4 red cards in 18 qualifying matches)? But skill trumps chicanery, and Argentina has plenty of the former. In addition to Messi, there are the predatory goal scorers Hernán Crespo and Carlos Tevez, and the artful playmaker, Juan Román Riquelme. Those skeptics can decry Argentina all they want -- they're likely to end up with huevos on their faces. CZECH REPUBLIC The Czechs are one of the few teams that refuse to genuflect to Brazil. After all, in that other beautiful game -- supermodel supremacy -- they've long since encroached upon Brazilian dominance, and it's somehow fitting that their soccer has gotten prettier, too. Since the Velvet Divorce, which split the country into the Czech and the Slovak republics 13 years ago, the once dreary, mechanical Czechs have acquired the verve and sophistication of their stylish capital, Prague. Technically assured, the current Czech team is also long on height, from the man-mountain 6-foot-8 striker, Jan Koller, to the imposing 6-foot-5 goalkeeper, Petr Cech. But no one embodies the new Czech spirit more than Pavel Nedved, he of the silky blond locks and even silkier skills. Coaxed out of retirement from international competition, the aging (33) but charismatic Juventus midfielder still dictates the Czechs' rhythm, and he can unleash thunderbolts with either foot. Nedved is known as the Czech Cannon, and he's their best shot at dethroning Brazil. ENGLAND Only six weeks ago, England was a halfway-decent bet to win the World Cup. Many bookmakers had them as second favorites. Wayne Rooney, the team's 20-year-old savior, even went all Joe Namath on the British media. ''Of course, we're going to win the World Cup,'' he boasted, neglecting to mention his track record: reports of $1.3 million in gambling debts. Then he broke his rapier right foot, and four years after England prayed for the recovery of David Beckham's glamorous metatarsal, the country finds itself once again kneeling down to ask that a famous foot be healed. Actually, two. Rooney's strike partner Michael Owen is still recovering from a broken metatarsal. The lame attackers have forced lame-duck coach Sven-Goran Eriksson to roll the dice on the warp speed of the 17-year-old prodigy Theo Walcott, whom he has never seen play live. Yet with the formidable midfield tandem of Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard, to say nothing of Beckham's bendalicious prowess, the English should have little trouble in the first round. As for winning their first World Cup in 40 years, all bets are off. FRANCE The good news is that the French can hardly do worse than they did four years ago, when they arrived as defending champions and departed three games later -- winless, goal-less, joie-less. Then as now, they relied heavily on the talismanic presence of Zinédine Zidane, a three-time FIFA World Player of the Year and the linchpin of Real Madrid's famed galácticos. Having hobbled away from international competition in 2004, Zidane un-retired last year after all of France begged him to return as Les Bleus struggled to qualify for Germany. ''God is back,'' said Thierry Henry, a celestial talent in his own right. But the question remains: has Zidane, now 33, gone from galáctico to geriatrico? And how many of his fellow countrymen -- like Claude Makelele and Lilian Thuram, 33 and 34, respectively -- have also passed their sell-by dates? It falls to the great Henry, a sprightly 28, to ignite the French attack, but although he has been electrifying with Arsenal, his professional team, he has yet to display the same form for France. Sacré Bleus! GERMANY The only thing that's receding faster than coach Jürgen Klinsmann's hairline is the host country's faith in him. After five years of failing to beat a single world-class team, Germany turned to its former national hero and asked him to re-engineer the team's once proud soccer machine from a panzer into a BMW roadster. Instead of endurance and impregnability, he demanded adaptability and speed, off-loading battle-tested veterans in favor of untried youngsters like the fabulously named midfielder Bastian Schweinsteiger. Out went captain and goalkeeper Oliver Kahn, and in stepped rival Jens Lehmann, who recorded six consecutive shutouts for Arsenal in the Champions League (before being ejected in the final). The calm center of the team remains intact, however, bolted down by the ever dangerous Michael Ballack. Still, it seems unlikely that Klinsmann's kinder have the mettle to restore the Germans to soccer prominence, but there is one thing going for them: they get to play in their own haus. ITALY With the Italians, you don't know whether to laugh or cry. For years, the Azzurri have sung the bluesabout the injustices they've suffered at the hands of corrupt foreign referees. How ironic, then, that a match-fixing scandal has implicated their own World Cup referee, as well as all sorts of Italian suits. It's as if the soccer gods dropped a dead fish into the lap of Italy's World Cup prospects, just when those prospects looked so promising. Led by Luca Toni, who scored an astonishing 31 goals in Serie A this year, the Azzurri have successfully shed their stultifyingly defensive style in favor of a more wide-open attacking game full of flair and speed, tearing apart Germany, 4-1, in a recent World Cup tuneup. That this was accomplished without the operatic soul of the team, Francesco Totti, the Roma star known for his pretty chip shots and petty cheap shots, augured especially well for the Italians. And just as the country's rabid fans were ready to hail the return of their hero from a broken leg, the scandal has left them more hysterical than a Puccini heroine. On the other hand, because Italy is in the same group as the U.S., its woes could be buona fortuna for the Americans. THE NETHERLANDS Generally believed to be the best country never to have won the World Cup, Holland has always been one of the most colorful teams in the tournament -- literally. From their wildly entertaining Total Football of the 70's to the brilliance of their stars of the 80's and 90's -- Marco van Basten, Ruud Gullit and Frank Rijkaard -- the neon-orange-clad Dutch just can't seem to make it to the other side of the rainbow. They've lost in two World Cup finals. But in the last decade or so, Holland has earned a new reputation: as a self-defeating collection of arrogant divas who are riven by racial strife and prefer looking flashy on the field to actually winning. This year, at least, under van Basten's calm direction, the team looks once again to be a contender. He'll have plenty of world-class players to call on, including the lethal attacking trio of Ruud van Nistelrooy, Arjen Robben and Rafael van der Vaart, yet somehow you just can't help feeling that the Oranje will have their hopes crushed. SPAIN In the past half-century, Spain has yet to escape the quarterfinals, and in 1982 the team suffered the madre of all humiliations when, as host of the tournament, they crashed out in the second round. How to explain that a country boasting two of the world's most glamorous clubs -- Real Madrid and Barcelona -- has never produced a team worthy of its audacious talent? Could it be the Goalkeeper Curse? In 1998, their veteran keeper Andoni Zubizarreta sent his team packing with a spectacularly embarrassing gaffe. Four years later, Santiago Cañizares, attempting to make a save on a bottle of dropped cologne, tore a tendon and had to be replaced. This time around, sure-handed keeper Íker Casillas will no doubt go fragrance-free. But if the Spaniards, led by the teenage sensation Cesc Fábregas and their prodigious goal scorer, Raúl, need any extra incentive to finally realize their potential, they recently got it in the form of performance bonuses: if Spain wins the cup, each player will receive an estimated $700,000. That will buy a lot of Eau de Redemption.
SPERLING--Steven, 52, precious son of Edith and the late Sol. Loving brother of Elliot and the late Orin. Devoted cousin of Bea Soloway. Services Sunday at 1pm at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.
COLE--Sylvan. DearestSylvan my precious husband. After one year your last words touch me every day. I love you. I love you. I love you. And I always will, Mary.

To the Editor: It appears that the methodology used in the poll of literati was to ask each person to choose one novel as the best published since 1980. This is not a reliable statistical technique. Far more robust would be to ask each individual for a list of three top novels in order of preference (allowing for the designation of ties as well). Then give each first choice 3 points, each second choice 2 points, each third choice 1 point. If an individual judges two equal first choices, they should be given 2.5 points apiece; two equal last choices should be given 1.5 points apiece; and all three choices equal should be given 2 points apiece. This method would be far, far fairer, since many people will find it almost impossible to choose just one without feeling that very close second or third choices are neglected. The method I suggest is highly likely to result in the same conclusion if you had chosen another group of the same size of a similar composition. But if each person submits only one choice, that is not nearly so likely, rendering your poll's final ranking virtually meaningless. Daniel Asimov Philadelphia The writer is a visiting scholar in the mathematics department at the University of Pennsylvania.

To the Editor: What a disservice you have done to a truly special part of Tuscany that was yours, mine and a few other peoples' refuge from the touring hordes! (''Exploring Tuscany's Lost Corner,'' May 21.) Every time The New York Times blasts a headline in its Travel section, featuring some precious place cherished by those of us who like to truly get away, we can just say bye-bye to it. I have spent a lifetime, going from one place to another, trying to find privacy and seclusion that doesn't cost me an arm and a leg and is relatively unknown and bingo! Within a couple of years you folks have to ruin it! Thanks a lot. Diana Dehli Gould Wilmington,Vt.

An article today on Page 21 of Arts & Leisure about the film ''Superman Returns'' includes an outdated reference to the release date. After the section went to press, it was changed to June 28, from June 30.

Twenty dental students at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey were denied their diplomas at the dental school's recent commencement exercises because they are suspected of cheating. School officials believe some students received credit for clinical procedures they did not perform by obtaining presigned forms from other students. The scandal cast a shadow over what should have been a joyful graduation ceremony in Passaic County. The dental school's dean, Cecile Feldman, rightly called it a ''day of disappointment'' as well as of pride. Fully a quarter of the graduating class was absent pending an investigation.

To the Editor: I was interested in your May 28 editorial suggesting compromise on plans for Brooklyn Bridge Park. I was amused that your next editorial, ''An Authority Over Authorities,'' about making state public authorities and agencies more transparent, very neatly stated the reason that the lawsuit filed to halt development on the park became necessary.

To the Editor: In 30 years, I have never found a boss who regarded a summer intern -- paid or unpaid -- as anything but a financial loss to the company. The staff time needed for orientation, training and supervision, plus the intern's learning curve, conspire to almost assure a deficit when all factors are considered.

An article today on Page 16 of Arts & Leisure about the hand clippers used by the barber in the Broadway revival of ''Awake and Sing!'' misspelled the surname of the actor playing him. It is Ben Gazzara, not Gazarra.

GARY--Nancy E., M.D., 69, of Washington DC, died on May 31, 2006. A resident of Washington DC for 20 years, she lived for 25 years in Manhasset, NY. She is survived by her brothers, Walter Gary of Walla Walla, WA, Thomas Gary of Manhasset, NY, Peter Q. Gary of Springfield, VA and father Paul Gary of Charlotte, NC. Physician and friend, she had been Dean of the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, F. Edward Hebert School of Medicine. Visitation will be at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, 711 N Street, NW Washington, DC from 910 a.m., Monday, June 5, 2006 followed by a service at 10:00 a.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her memory to Duke University Pulmonary Hypertension Program, attention Dr. Victor Tapson, Room 351, Bell Building, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC 27710.

There may be no free Shakespeare in the park in Montauk this summer, because members of the Hamptons Shakespeare Festival have been shut out of the county-owned cabins they have stayed in for the last 10 years and are dubious about finding other affordable accommodations at the height of the summer season. The festival usually puts on a production for four weeks at Theodore Roosevelt County Park starting in mid-July and then moves to Agawam Park in Southampton for a week. Since the first festival in 1996, its actors and workers have stayed in cabins at the county park, most recently for a flat total fee of about $11,000. But this year, the cabins, which are part of what was once a cattle and dude ranch, are booked for the summer. They are being used by park officials and contractors who, in April, started a renovation of Third House, built in 1806 and used by Colonel Roosevelt and his Rough Riders after the Spanish-American War.

Since its creation 18 years ago in the wake of several municipal corruption scandals, New York City's system of public campaign financing has become an indispensable feature of local politics, and a model for campaign reformers nationwide. The system provides public matching funds to candidates in return for enhanced disclosure, a pledge to honor spending and contribution limits, and at the citywide level, participation in broadcast debates -- in all, a worthwhile investment in democracy. Much of the credit for the system's success belongs to Nicole Gordon, the program's executive director since its inception. Working with Frederick Schwarz Jr., the chairman of the five-member Campaign Finance Board, which oversees the program, and his predecessor, the Rev. Joseph O'Hare, Ms. Gordon has worked to maintain the board's non-partisan culture as well as its resolve to enforce the rules even in the heat of campaigns.

After reading Kevin Kelly's article, I felt the need to go and look at my book collection, most of which I inherited from my mother. I handled each book gently, since they are all now quite frail. My mother's books are more than personal mementos. They are a reminder that some things cannot, and should not, be replaced. I use the Internet all the time and I think it's fantastic -- for research, not for reading. I mean really reading. A book may look ''inert,'' but there's nothing inert about what happens when I shut off the PC and the TV, and begin to read. There is an intimacy to holding this special possession in my hands that I cannot experience by looking at a plastic screen inside a metal box. I applaud the dazzling advances in research that the Internet has brought and will continue to bring. And yet I will, at the end of every day, curl up with a good book, not a good computer. Clare Higgins Gloucester, Mass.

NOTHING TO WEAR? A 5-Step Cure for the Common Closet. By Jesse Garza and Joe Lupo. 192 pp., Hudson Street Press. $25.95. MY MOTHER'S WEDDING DRESS The Life & Afterlife of Clothes. By Justine Picardie 256 pp., Bloomsbury. $22.95. MUCH of the time when women shop, what they're really after is not a new outfit, it's a new self. With the exchange of a piece of plastic, they hope to achieve a look that transforms them into a captivating stranger. The fact that this doesn't quite work is why so many women's closets resemble clothing compost -- mulching heaps of different looks that don't come together in wan morning light but are too expensive to throw away and too pilled or rumpled to give to Goodwill in good conscience.

SAWYER--Norman Radack, of New York City and Sharon, CT on June 3rd. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother. He is survived by Annette his wife of 59 years and children Rachel Sawyer and James Little, son Herb, grandchildren Nina and Billy Sawyer and brother David Sawyer of Sherman, CT. A diamond broker, he was an alumnus of Cornell University Class of 1939. He served on Cornell's Secondary School Committee, was the president of The Cooper-Stuyvesant Little League and was a member of Community Board 6. Services will be held Monday June 5th at 2 PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel at Amsterdam Ave & 90th St.

LUTTINGER--Max. 88 of Lakeworth Fla. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Susan and husband Jaime, Beth, Barry. Adoring grandfather of Hayley. Companion of Shirley Goldman and daughter Ann. Dear brother and uncle. Friend of Jeff. Special friend to Elizabeth. Graveside service Sunday 2PM at MT. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale N.Y. For information ''Wien&Wien'' 800-322-0533.

SILVERMAN--Donald N. Retired Justice of the NY Supreme Court, died on Friday, June 2nd, at the age of 58, after a courageous, prolonged battle with lung cancer. Senior partner at Silverman, Bikkal & Sandberg, LLP, Judge Silverman was the founding Chair of the Westchester County Human Rights Commission and a prominent civic leader in Westchester County for over three decades. He was the beloved husband of Robin A. Bikkal, cherished father of Miranda and Douglas, loving brother of Mary Ann Siskind, Jerome and Melvin, and brother-in-law of Arthur, Nina, Sandy, Sissy, Andy, Nicky, Etsuko, Rudy, Adrien, Nita and Ron and favorite son-inlaw of Loto Bikkal. Services will be held on Sunday, June 4, 2006 at 12:30 pm, at Temple Sharaay Tefila, 89 Baldwin Road, Bedford, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lung Cancer Research Fund, c/o Mark Stoopler, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, NY, NY 10032. $(6$)SILVERMAN -- Donald. We will always cherish your love and caring. We will miss you dearly and always hold you in our thoughts. Our Love to Robin, Miranda and Douglas, Mary Ann, Arthur, Laura, Bonnie, Julie, Jim, Ken, Nicole, Noah, Emma, Avery and Kiera.

To the Editor: The choice of Toni Morrison's popular 1987 novel, ''Beloved,'' was unsurprising and well deserved. But The Times did not go far enough in drawing out the implication of Morrison's win and the receipt of the same laurel a generation ago by Ellison's ''Invisible Man.'' We now hold conclusive proof that in the 20th century we witnessed the distinctive arrival of an authentic American style, and that style is African-American. Black American culture and life are the universal metaphor for the genuine American. Since colonial times we have embraced African-Americans' indigenous experiments in speech, gesture, movement, rhythm and song. Today, we bear witness to more than 50 years of extraordinary black prowess in literature. Lawrence Jackson Atlanta The writer, an assistant professor of English at Emory University, is the author of a biography of Ralph Ellison.

While the opinions of Adam Goodheart (May 21) and his various sources offer a lively and interesting debate on the architecture of the University of Virginia, he left out an important group of experts on the subject: the students, faculty and staff -- those who eat, sleep and work in its highly disputed buildings. As a member of this diverse community, I value the functionality as well as the aesthetic beauty of the university's grounds. Keeping this in mind, I should add that (despite its visually appealing design) the ''very 21st-century culinary options'' offered at the Observatory Hill dining hall are generally limited to pizza and chicken-fried steak. Emilia Pisani University of Virginia, Class of 2007 Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

NEARLY a century ago, area leaders created the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey because they knew the region's long-term economic survival lay in cooperation, not competition between the states. Recently, we saw regional cooperation again as New Jersey and New York forged a unified agreement to rebuild the World Trade Center site. But too often in the last few years this kind of cooperation has been the exception. And that must change. Because divided, New Jersey and New York risk being crushed under the weight of their own growth. Together, however, the two states can make the landmark investments that will determine our economic success over the next century.

The Austrian accessories designer Devi Kroell got her career boost not from a powerful fashion editor but from a pop star with a reality television show, Jessica Simpson. ''I did this huge hobo bag in metallic python, and Jessica wore it nonstop on every episode of 'The Newlyweds' for six months,'' Ms. Kroell said. ''She put me on the map.'' No one-hit wonder, Ms. Kroell has just been nominated for the second time in two years for Swarovski's Perry Ellis Award for accessory design from the Council of Fashion Designers of America. The winner will be announced tomorrow evening.

To the Editor: Your May 14 editorial ''A New Day in Newark'' concerned me. I have always lived in Middlesex County, and in New Brunswick for 10 years. Now I live across the river in Highland Park, but work in New Brunswick. The changes have been good for some but not for most.

Almost a year after Elizabeth Butler, a vivacious high school senior from North Salem, was found strangled and stabbed to death in her parents' car, her former boyfriend was found guilty of the murder. The former boyfriend, Ariel Menendez, 28, of the Bronx, whom the police described as unwilling to accept the breakup of the couple's relationship, was convicted Tuesday of two counts of first-degree murder, and first-degree rape and a criminal sexual act. It took the jury two hours to reach a verdict.

To the Editor: New York City is making substantial progress in addressing nitrogen loading in Long Island Sound, a major source of water quality degradation mentioned in your May 21 editorial ''Over Troubled Water.'' In January, the city and the state reached an agreement that will sharply reduce nitrogen discharges from city-owned sewage treatment plants along the upper East River. Construction valued at more than $700 million at the city's Wards Island, Tallman Island, Hunts Point and Bowery Bay wastewater treatment plants will result in a 58.5 percent reduction in nitrogen discharges from those four plants by 2017.

To the Editor There is another factor to consider about the impact that unpaid internships have on the labor market. Last summer my daughter chose a paid internship -- near Munich. Imagine our delight at her being paid by the German government to spend the summer near Lake Starnberg working in a laboratory and polishing her German.

Golf may be wonderfully, maddeningly unpredictable, but one thing golfers can control is the stuff they carry. When you pack for a golf trip, there's the bag for clubs, balls and umbrella, and there's the bag for clothes, jackets and shoes -- in other words, what you wear instead of what you use. The first rule, when it comes to packing, is to focus on layers, including collared shirts, water-repellent shells and a sweater vest to keep you warm but your arms unencumbered. What comes next depends on the weather (and the stringency of club dress codes). Hedge your bets by working from this list. Clockwise from top: Ghurka Cavalier III bag, $1,295; Brooks Brothers Country Club sweater vest, $95; J. Lindeberg Columbia shirt (inside vest), $155; Smythson golf notebook, $70; Titleist towel, $30; Titleist Players glove, $22; Nike Golf Ignite balls, $29.99 per dozen; Polo Golf white-green-and-blue-striped polo shirt, $75; Burberry golf shoes, $495; Polo by Ralph Lauren socks, $11; Nike Golf Clima-FIT windshirt, $60; Bobby Jones Collection narrow-striped polo, $175; Bobby Jones Collection white V-neck sweater, $225; Brooks Brothers seersucker jacket, $118; a+dam by adam+eve swim shorts, $135; Nike Golf Storm-FIT light pants, $90; J. Lindeberg belt, $75; Prada Linea Rossa sunglasses, $200. Finally, don't leave home without your Tour GCX card. For $6,250, a cardholder can take three guests to play 10 rounds a year at 26 of the country's most exclusive clubs. While Tour GCX won't disclose the courses, prospective members receive the secret list, which includes two former P.G.A. Championship sites, before shelling out any money. www.tourgcx.com.

NOT long ago we had occasion to mend our fence. A break the previous week had caused our two dogs, yellow Labs, to be found wandering down the road. As my husband set himself to the task of repair, he assembled not a posthole digger, wood and nails, but electrical tape and a Wire-Nut, the plastic connector used to splice electrical wire. This is because, like many of our neighbors' fences, the one we installed around our property happens to be of the invisible variety. Its technology, known generically as a pet containment system, was invented in the early 1970's and consists of three parts: wire wrapped in a cable that is buried at the perimeter of our two-acre plot, a transmitter and a receiver.

To the Editor: All sorts of musical genres -- country, rock, folk, blues -- think they have a place on the stage, but they don't. Broadway has always represented a step up from the popular music of the day. The next great musical will be an original book with original music and lyrics. I know because I have written it. It is called ''Park Avenue,'' and it may well not see the light of day until I am dead. I can accept that. Al Keith New Hampton, N.H.

MY son's bar-mitzvah-going year is almost over. There are a couple more invitations sitting in the kitchen, and then I'll be free. But not quite yet. Chauffeuring back and forth to synagogues and women's clubs/hotels/catering halls is the latest task in a long career of suburban kid-driving that includes school drop-offs, sports practices and games, class trips and birthday parties. This is more interesting than it sounds, because for some unfathomable reason, when I'm operating a motor vehicle, kids forget I'm an actual human with ears and they speak freely. The driving is dull, but it's a great opportunity to pick up some intel.

TO anyone who has driven on Interstate 95 through Bridgeport and looked south, it is impossible to miss: a single house standing in a rocky weed-filled field, its windows boarded up or broken, its siding stripped. This is the face Bridgeport presents to the world every day. No wonder the mayor, John Fabrizi, has made it a priority to turn the 55-acre field, known as Steel Point, into a profitable development, with housing, stores and office space and a 2,200-foot promenade that will guide visitors along the shore of Long Island Sound. The developer plans to start work on the site by the end of August.

THE New York City health commissioner has proposed legal changes that would make H.I.V. testing easier and more widely available. But the New York State Legislature has yet to pass these changes. In the meantime, more than 1,100 New Yorkers every year unnecessarily progress to full-blown AIDS because their illness went undiagnosed for almost 10 years. AIDS groups should be screaming for expanded testing, and many of them are. But some are fighting any change, as though the epidemic hasn't evolved since the 1980's. In those days, there were important reasons to protect people getting tested for AIDS. There were no drugs to treat the disease. A positive test meant that you were just waiting to die. William F. Buckley was calling for tattoos to identify people with H.I.V., and others wanted to quarantine us.

You can't be a museum these days without expa-a-a-nding, and the MINNEAPOLIS INSTITUTE OF ARTS, whose neo-Classical building dates to 1915, is doing it again. Enlarged in 1974 and 1998, and now enhanced for the third time, the museum is opening a 113,000-square-foot wing, designed by Michael Graves and named for Target, the Minneapolis-based retailer that contributed more than $10 million to the building fund. With other renovations factored in, the new space amounts to an increase of 40 percent in exhibition area. What's in it for viewers? Well, the grand opening next Sunday will salute the reinstallation of much of the permanent collection of almost 100,000 works, covering more than 5,000 years of art history. It includes one of the major collections of Asian art in the United States, with 20,000 square feet devoted to the installation of Chinese art alone. And six new galleries have been added to the nine existing ones for one of the country's largest permanent installations of Japanese art. Four new shows will kick off the exhibition program. ''The Surreal Calder'' explores the Surrealist origins of the American sculptor Alexander Calder. ''From Dürer to Cassatt: Five Centuries of Master Prints From the Jones Collection'' plays up the 1916 gift from Herschel V. Jones, publisher of The Minneapolis Journal, that forms the core of the museum's print holdings. ''Highlights From the Harrison Collection of Fine Photographs (1992-2006)'' includes 100 works by major 20th-century figures. And, not to scant the present, ''The Unicorn in Captivity: New Paintings by Alexa Horochowski'' inaugurates the new Target wing, where the Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program will makes its home. 2400 Third Avenue South, Minneapolis, (888) 642-2787.

SPUT--Murray. 30 days ago our tiny group of classmatesholocaust survivors became smaller yet. Murray died on May 6, 2006. A prominent New York architect, a man of high integrity, a most reliable and trusted friend, he enjoyed his professional life as well as retirement, which permitted him to cultivate his many interests. We miss him very much. In New York, Adam Novak In Paris, Henry Klugman George Felenbok, Jo Eisenbaum In Geneva, Bronislaw Baczko

The Beauty Bar, a New York watering hole known for its retro beauty parlor interior, now has sites in Los Angeles; San Diego; San Francisco; Austin, Tex.; and Las Vegas. The chain is promoting a happy hour on Thursdays through Saturdays between 6 p.m. and 10 p.m. For $10, customers receive a full-service manicure and the salon's signature cocktail (www.beautybar.com). Priceline is offering international vacation packages. New destinations include Bangkok; Beijing; Hong Kong; Sydney, Australia; Cairo; Buenos Aires; and Rio de Janeiro (www.priceline.com). A new guidebook called ''There Is Room at the Inn, Inns and B&B's for Wheelers and Slow Walkers'' examines 117 wheelchair-accessible lodgings across the country, ranging from a Victorian inn to a dude ranch. It is available at bookstores or from Demos Medical Publishing for $21.95 (800-532-8663, www.emerginghorizons.com/inn). Butlers at St. Regis Hotels and Resorts are giving the phrase ''beck and call'' a whole new meaning. Equipped with wireless handheld devices, butlers can respond to requests sent by e-mail. After checking in at any of the St. Regis hotels or resorts, guests will be given the e-mail address of the butler on call during their stay (www.stregis.com). Avis is offering mobility scooters tor travelers with disabilities who rent cars in a new pilot program in Las Vegas and Orlando, Fla. Avis will pack a four-wheeled scooter (suitable for travelers weighing 250 pounds and less) from Scootaround in the trunk of a rental car, or it will deliver the scooter to the customer. Besides the cost of the rental car, the daily charge for the scooter will run between $40 and $50 (888-879-4273, www.scootaround.com/avis). Starting Wednesday, US Airways will offer direct flights from Philadelphia to Lisbon four days a week. Prices start at $699 roundtrip (www.usairways.com). HILARY HOWARD

The option to see all the information connected to a main idea or source might actually discourage creative thinking and might produce lazy scholars (Kevin Kelly, May 14). Those searching for information may not be inspired to draw parallels between obscure ideas or topics, and may be less inclined to make their own judgments about original material. The answers will become too available, and as a result, the educational journey of research may become obsolete. Randi Brown New York

To the Editor: Re ''Take This Internship and Shove It'' (Op-Ed, May 30): Anya Kamenetz addresses the opportunity costs of taking a position as a ''lowly intern,'' but she doesn't discuss the fierce social competitiveness among young people today that is often the motivator for seeking such experiences.

To the Editor: Anya Kamenetz insists that unpaid internships are ''not jobs, only simulations.'' As a student who just completed my freshman year at Yale, I know that many young people, including me, work long hours at unpaid internships doing the same work as paid staffers.

We are planning a trip to the Netherlands (Amsterdam and nearby towns) and Belgium (Brussels and Bruges). Should we buy rail passes and, if so, where? -- Linda Garb, San Rafael, Calif. Whether a pass is worthwhile depends on how many train rides you want to take. The distances you are traveling are fairly short compared with the distances you might be covering in, say, France or Germany. So a round-trip ticket between Brussels and Bruges can cost as little as $44 (second class) and $66 (first class); between Brussels and Antwerp, $30 (second class) and $54 (first class). But a pass is a good way to make sure you can get on any train and not worry about buying each ticket.

OFFICIALS in Westchester County have long tried to keep noise levels at the local county-run airport to a minimum. They have restricted landings and takeoffs to four every half-hour. They have capped the number of passengers allowed to travel at one time, and they have even sought to have the runways essentially closed between midnight and 6 a.m. But now the county is facing what some local officials say is the greatest threat to their efforts to reduce noise levels at the airport in years.

For every two shares of its newly traded stock that MasterCard has given to its chief executive, Robert W. Selander, it gave about three to the company's rank and file. The entire rank and file. MasterCard, which went public on May 25 with a $2.4 billion stock sale, disclosed last week that Mr. Selander received 287,341 shares of restricted stock on the day of the offering. Each of the company's 4,400 employees received 100 shares that will vest in three years -- if they are still working for MasterCard then.

AS problems go, it was a bit of a luxury matter: a gloriously sunny Memorial Day weekend, nominally free and clear. My wife, Jill, and I could theoretically go anywhere, but the most likely destination was someplace near the Atlantic Ocean within driving distance. From where we sit, which is in Montclair, that could be the Jersey Shore, or more ambitiously, the Hamptons. We decided to split the difference. When it comes to the choice between the Hamptons and the Jersey Shore, we are generally Third Way people. Minnesotans by birth, we grew up in a culture where every weekend, the question was always the same: ''Are we going Up North?'' Up North meant scattering to any one of the 10,000 lakes (more, actually) that the state is famous for.

Paul Cortese has vivid memories of watching his grandfather combine whole milk, rennet and vinegar to make delicious fresh mozzarella some 30 years ago in the Bronx. ''We would sit there with our jaws wide open,'' he said of himself and his four siblings. ''We couldn't wait to eat it.''

IN its early life, the charming old building that houses the Patio, a multifunctional restaurant on Briarcliff Manor's main shopping street, was a town hall and firehouse. That's where its wide front windows came from. In later years it became a traditional coffee shop and luncheonette. Today, all fresh paint and polish, The Patio is many things to many people, serving the public all day and most of the evening -- as a diner for breakfast and lunch; as a pleasant cafe for an evening meal or a glass of wine accompanied by succulent small dishes (tapas); and as an ice cream parlor, with handy benches on its wide sidewalk for the cone-licking crowd.
CHRISTENSEN - Angela. 1936-2005. Your birthday's come again, with you away, except in memories that will never fade. Loving thanks for the time we shared.

Nicolai Ouroussoff's article (May 21) on Bernard Khoury and Beirut's architecture of reconstruction gives a gloomy -- and misleading -- impression of one of the world's biggest reconstruction projects. Architects like Khoury are worried that the ''densely packed street life and vibrant social mix'' that Beirut is known for is ''being replaced by a generic, sanitized city,'' and that Solidere, the corporation that is rebuilding Beirut's downtown area, is ''suppress[ing] the complexities that once made Beirut teem with life.'' Huh? Instead of parroting the yearning of disappointed architects (who seem especially disappointed about their lost commissions), your writer should have given us a taste of downtown. You want teeming with life? Go there at midnight and rub shoulders with the eclectic mix of locals and internationals out with their families: Christians, Muslims and Druze all spilling out of the outdoor cafes, dancing in the second-floor clubs, footballing in the streets, critiquing the outdoor photo exhibits and strolling in one of the only pedestrian-friendly areas in Beirut. Solidere took bombed-out rubble and gave Beirutis back their city -- and a new place to party -- in less time than it takes United States cities to repave a highway. Alexandra Johnston Saab Johnston, Iowa

To the Editor: Senator John Kerry's self-defense is too little, too late. By not answering the scurrilous charges against him during the 2004 campaign, he gave them validity and allowed President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, with little or no military experience, to seem more honorable. Democratic Party strategists are to blame. They also shaped Al Gore into a candidate who appeared cold, aloof and disingenuous, a sharp contrast to the commanding, impassioned presence we see in his documentary, ''An Inconvenient Truth.''

FENIK--Inci Koner. Passed away May 22, 2006. Wife of Faruk Fenik, mother of Mehmet and Omer. A graduate of Robert College, Istanbul, Turkey, class of 1944, she was a speaker on the Turkish Voice Radio and TV programs from 1968 until 2000. She will be remembered with love and affection by her family and the entire TurkishAmerican community.

To the Editor: Property taxes in Connecticut affect everything. Local taxes are at the root of the eminent domain struggle plaguing New London and myriad controversies over development in eastern Connecticut.

ITALY THE LOCKDOWN Italy is extremely organized defensively. They're not as conservative as they used to be, but in big tournaments they still have a conservative mentality. They'll start with four defenders, four midfielders and two forwards. If they are protecting a lead, they'll drop Gennaro Gattuso, who's a terrific defensive midfielder, back into a deeper position. They'll drop one of their forwards back or replace him with another central midfielder. All this will lock out the middle. To beat a locked-in team like that, you can try to go wide to cross balls into the box or play long balls from your half and hope your forwards can get to one of them. Or you can concede territory when the ball turns over, and let them come at you. Then, when you win the ball back and they're exposed, you can counterattack and maybe catch 'em. But if you hold on to the ball too much and allow the Italians to get set, they're a very tough team to crack. They're one of the best in the world at killing off a game. BRAZIL ALL-OUT ATTACK Brazil plays a 4-2-2-2: four defenders, two rows of midfielders and two forwards. It's an interesting formation, and unique. It works because Brazil has so many tremendous players who can get forward and also get back to defend. In the midfield, Ronaldinho has the freedom to find the game wherever he wants -- not quite as much as when he plays for Barcelona, but still, he's free. He likes to drift to the left, and when he does, the midfielder Kaká will move into a more central role. On the flanks, you've got Cafu and Roberto Carlos running the entire length of the field and serving balls in toward the goal. And then you've got big, strong guys in front, like Ronaldo and Adriano, who are not only gifted with their feet but are good in the air as well. So they attack with three, four, five guys at once. Two defensive midfielders, Emerson and Zé Roberto, hold down the center while everyone is going forward. They can destroy you in a million different ways. GERMANY THE FREE KICK Taking a free kick is not rocket science, but the Germans do it as well as anyone in the world. Generally, they'll put two players over the ball, a left-footer, like Lukas Podolski, and a right-footer, like Bernd Schneider, to disguise which way the ball will come in. Usually they'll hit an in-swinger, which curves in toward the goal at high speed and is very tricky to defend against. Their other players will line up near the goal and then run toward the net. The first runner and maybe the second will be decoys, and then the third out of, say, five runners will be Michael Ballack, their best player, who scored on the United States four years ago on one of these plays. With all this movement in a confined space, it's easy for the defenders to lose a man. If the ball is hit properly, Ballack will just get to it first and head it on target. To make this kind of set piece work, you need movement, good service, guys who are good in the air and courage -- to jump into a crowd of people knowing that a goalkeeper is coming. ENGLAND MIDFIELD POWER They depend so much on Wayne Rooney. But if he stays injured, England will still probably go with the same 4-4-2 formation -- only Peter Crouch will be Michael Owen's partner up front. Crouch is very tall, very good in the air and much better with his feet than people give him credit for. So even though losing Rooney is a blow, they now have an option they might not have had before: to play longer, more direct balls from the back. Otherwise, they can still build up through the midfield, with Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard playing side by side. Since both of them like to come forward, the question there is, can one of them sit back? But in the end, England is more likely to play longer balls to the front of the opposing goal. There aren't many in the world who are better at that than David Beckham. And every one of these guys across the midfield -- Beckham, Gerrard, Lampard and Joe Cole -- can shoot very well from distance. THE NETHERLANDS WING PLAY The Dutch use real wingers -- rare in international soccer. In this 4-3-3 system, you've got these wide players who operate on the outside. Arjen Robben and Dirk Kuyt are two guys on the wing, and they love to go right at you one-on-one. Robben especially has the ability to cut inside and get shots off. Or he can beat you to the outside and serve crosses into the box in front of the net. Their target man is Ruud van Nistelrooy. He's amazing in the box, a guy who gets so many goals from within six yards of the net. And he's going to get tremendous service from his teammates on the flanks. That's the thing about the Dutch: every player -- defenders, midfielders, forwards -- has a high level of competence on the ball. There's a historical memory of Total Football here: the great Dutch system of the mid-70's that revolutionized the game, where players would change positions on the fly. I wouldn't call the setup of this team complete Total Football, but they have the personnel to come close. U.S.A. GOING WIDE The Americans like to play a 4-4-2 and go through the midfield with short passes from player to player, not over the midfield with long balls directly from the defense to the forwards. It's just a bit of the Latin style. They'll have Claudio Reyna and John O'Brien in the middle of the midfield, anchoring it, and that gives freedom to Landon Donovan and DaMarcus Beasley to go inside or outside. Then, if they want to open it up a bit, either Reyna or O'Brien will move forward a little while the other will stay back and help defend. Here, the ability for them to get around and wide is going to be important. That's where Eddie Lewis and Steve Cherundolo come in; they're both good servers of the ball. Beasley is also a very good wide player. These players will get forward and bring the ball into the corners. In the last World Cup, they made great runs wide against Portugal and Mexico to set up important goals. That'll be a characteristic this time, too. AND NOW FOR A LITTLE ONE-ON-ONE THE TURN AS THE IVORY COAST STRIKER DIDIER DROGBA RUNS, HE CHANGES THE DIRECTION OF THE BALL BY KNOCKING IT WITH THE HEEL OF HIS TRAILING LEG. THE MOVE IS A VARIATION OF ONE PIONEERED BY THE DUTCH LEGEND JOHAN CRUYFF, BUT DROGBA AND THE ARGENTINE ATTACKER LIONEL MESSI USE THIS TRICK AT A FULL SPRINT, LEAVING DEFENDERS WRONG-FOOTED. THE SCISSORS CRISTIANO RONALDO, THE PORTUGUESE DRIBBLING WIZARD, LIKES TO FEIGN KICKING THE BALL WITH THE OUTSIDE OF HIS FOOT AND INSTEAD STEPS OVER IT, THROWING THE DEFENDER OFF BALANCE. HE OFTEN REPEATS THE MOVE WITH HIS OTHER FOOT: THE DOUBLE SCISSORS. A POPULAR DRIBBLING MOVE, THE SCISSORS IS ALSO A FAVORITE OF FRANCE'S ZINÉDINE ZIDANE. THE FLICK FLACK PLAYERS LIKE RONALDINHO AND SWEDEN'S ZLATAN IBRAHIMOVIC SHOW REMARKABLE BALL CONTROL WITH THIS MOVE, ALSO KNOWN AS THE ELASTICO. AFTER PUSHING THE BALL ONE WAY WITH THE OUTSIDE OF HIS FOOT, A PLAYER IMMEDIATELY DRAGS IT BACK THE OTHER WAY WITH THE INSIDE. WHEN IT'S DONE AT FULL SPEED, THE BALL APPEARS STUCK TO HIS FOOT. *ALL LINEUPS SUBJECT TO CHANGE

GOODMAN--Barbara F. Beloved Barbara, we'll miss you so much, our hearts are broken. We have shared a lifetime together starting when you were the most adorable freshman to grace a Harvard campus. From the moment Roy met you at that ''freshman mixer'' he was smitten for life. When Larry met Dalia the twosome became a foursome. Our memories include a chronology of love, marriage, children, godparenting and grandchildren. We shared so many wonderful experiences bringing up our children and enjoying travel adventures around the world. Barbara, you possessed such grace and beauty. You were so kind, so good, so giving, so wise, so feminine, yet strong and independent. You were a loving and caring mother. Claire's, Leslie's and Randy's fine qualities and virtues do credit to your maternal devotion. Beezie, no husband has ever had a more noble and loving wife. Roy was blessed from the day he met you. Yours was the most admired and loving marriage we have ever known. Ashley and Tracy weep for you at this sad time. We mourn for Barbara and pray for God to bless Roy and give him the strength to carry on and go forth with his life. Dalia and Larry
To the Editor: I have only one question for Mr. Kozinn: Is quantity the same thing as quality? Jason Papowitz Munich, Germany

KAMPEL--Daniel S. A beloved husband and stepfather, passed away on May 31, 2006 at his home in Manhattan. His investment abilities and a wide range of philanthropic interests were an inspiration to a lot of people. He supported young artists, Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society and a research at Harvard Medical School. His passion for life will live in the hearts of all who loved him.

The big news of the week is the premiere of ALEXEI RATMANSKY's''Russian Seasons,'' commissioned by the New York City Ballet for its Diamond Project series and performed by the company on Thursday, repeated on Saturday afternoon. Mr. Ratmansky, the director of the Bolshoi Ballet, has hitherto seemed like a sunny sort of artist, to judge by his comical re-envisioning of the Soviet ballet ''The Bright Stream'' last year for the Bolshoi season in New York City, and charming pieces seen at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in 1999. But ''Russian Seasons'' mines the darker-sounding themes of the music, by the contemporary Russian composer LEONID DESYATNIKOV, and the heritage that in part inspired both the ballet and its score. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500 or www.nycballet.com; $30 to $76. Across the plaza at American Ballet Theater, three ballerinas will take on the character of Cinderella, who looks anything but a pathetic waif in DAVID BOECHLER's costumes for JAMES KUDELKA's new look at an old fairy tale. The feisty GILLIAN MURPHY will play the title role, with DAVID HALLBERG as her handsome prince, on Monday and Friday nights and Wednesday afternoon. The bouncy little XIOMARA REYES will take on the role on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday nights, performing with GUILLAUME CÔTÉ, a guest principal from the National Ballet of Canada. And the delicate, lyrical JULIE KENT takes over on Wednesday night and Saturday afternoon, with MARCELO GOMES as her prince. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000 or www.abt.org; $23 to $163. Future Cinderellas and their princes may be spotted on Monday night at the Peter Jay Sharp (formerly Juilliard) Theater, when students of the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet will perform GEORGE BALANCHINE's ''Square Dance'' and rarely seen ''Bourrée Fantasque'' and CHRISTOPHER WHEELDON's effervescent ''Scènes de Ballet,'' created for the school. Peter Jay SharpTheater, Lincoln Center, www.sab.org/workshop; $65.

STAHL--Reva, age 76, passed away at home in New Rochelle on June 2, 2006. Reva, originally from Massachusetts, lived there until a recent move to New York after the passing of her husband of 57 years, Joseph. She is survived by her sister Frummie Lourie, brother Reuben Silver, her children Bernard, Jeffrey and Dina, Lewis and Helene, and Sharon and Howard Wexler. Mrs. Stahl dearly loved her grandchildren Evan, Allison, David, Jonathan and Jacob. Reva was a generous and devoted mother and grandmother. To the Editor: When I was a senior in college, my classmates applied to banks and firms, but I searched for a job where I could make a difference. When I found that organization, I learned that entry-level positions were scarce. An internship, however, provided a chance to perform meaningful work straight out of school. I interned and waited on tables. The internship challenged my writing skills and allowed me to explore other departments and take on additional tasks. I did ''grunt'' work, but it wasn't demeaning.

When Carol Leftwich left her hometown, Dallas, to settle on Long Island, she never thought her favorite dessert would stay behind. ''We couldn't find frozen custard anywhere,'' she said. ''We were addicted to it in Texas, and we were surprised that it wasn't here in New York because custard is actually a Coney Island invention.'' To satisfy her craving, Ms. Leftwich opened her first Wolfie's Custard in Northport Village, naming it after a family friend. It was soon followed by another in Huntington. She's called herself the Queen of Custard ever since.

Road cyclists tinker. They obsess. They scrutinize every inch of their bicycles -- down to the tire caps -- to find the slightest increase in speed. But customized bikes aren't just for the pros. These days, even weekenders are tailoring off-the-rack bikes. Handlebars The Easton EC90 Equipe OS handlebars weigh just 200 grams (less than a racing helmet) and are made of carbon fiber, which absorbs vibrations for smooth rides. How so light? TaperWall technology uses less fiber and resin at the lower stress points, reducing mass. $220; www.eastonbike.com.Pedals The pioneer of the clipless pedal, Look has markedly upgraded its carbon-and-steel pedals with the ultralight, 230-gram Keo Carbon set. Spring-tension adjustment allows you to fine-tune the amount of effort required to clip in or out. $220; www.lookcyclesusa.com. Saddle No component is customized more often than a saddle. Fizik's Arione Carbon Braided seat (only 179 grams and designed for men) has more flexibility and surface area than standard models, making for a more comfortable ride. $285; www.fizik.com. The Bike Trek's Madone 5.2 has the same frame Lance Armstrong used to win the 2004 Tour de France. Made of O.C.L.V. (optimum compaction, low void) carbon, the frame is light, yet stiff and efficient. The bike can be highly customized, via Trek's Project One Web site, but also has a factory setup for those who just want to get it and go. $3,330 (without pedals); www.trekbikes.com. Wheels The latest, lightest wheels available are the ultralight (1,485 grams per pair) and ultrastiff Ksyrium ES, from Mavic. The braking surfaces are milled for smoother stopping, and the sealed-cartridge bearings can be adjusted for the weather. $1,100; www.mavic.com. Pedals The pioneer of the clipless pedal, Look has markedly upgraded its carbon-and-steel pedals with the ultralight, 230-gram Keo Carbon set. Spring-tension adjustment allows you to fine-tune the amount of effort required to clip in or out. $220; www.lookcyclesusa.com.

A marching band of 100 tubas is bound to get attention, and the annual BANG ON A CAN MARATHON should make a brassy roar with ANTHONY BRAXTON's ''Composition 19'' for that loud, low ensemble. It is scheduled to be performed on Sunday at 1 p.m. on the Oval Lawn and Plaza of the World Financial Center, near the beginning of an all-day program. Bang on a Can commissions and presents new music and started the modern chamber ensemble called the Bang on a Can All-Stars. It has moved its annual all-day extravaganza to downtown Manhattan, where it is now free as part of the River to River Festival. Bang on a Can happily knocks down category dividers, and this year's festival spans Minimalism, jazz, electronica, improvisation, Siberian throat singing, Balinese gamelan and, still, some modern chamber music. There will be music from Bang on a Can's founding composers -- JULIA WOLFE, MICHAEL GORDON and DAVID LANG -- and its All-Stars. The lineup also includes ALARM WILL SOUND, a small orchestra that has transcribed the electronic pieces of Aphex Twin for unplugged instruments; AMIINA, a string quartet from Iceland that also plays instruments like xylophone and autoharp and has toured and recorded with Sigur Ros; MATMOS, an electronic group that often manipulates found sounds, performing with the ensemble SO PERCUSSION; GLEN KOTCHE, the drummer from Wilco; JEROME COOPER, the drummer from the free-jazz Revolutionary Ensemble; YAT-KHA, a Siberian group that features throat singing; MICHAEL NYMAN, whose Minimalist compositions include the score for the Jane Campion film ''The Piano''; and DON BYRON, a clarinetist who keeps delving into odd corners of American music. The complete lineup is at www.bangonacan.org. The marathon begins with a program for children at 11:30 a.m. and runs until 10 p.m.; admission is free.

The spectacle of wayward corporate chiefs being sentenced to hard time in real prisons is not strictly an American phenomenon, despite the attention given to Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling at Enron, L. Dennis Kozlowski at Tyco, Bernard J. Ebbers at WorldCom, Martha Stewart, et al. Executives around the world have also been sent to jail -- or have been given big fines.

Peck, Jr. Devoted grandfather of Warren and Barbara Cohen, Wendy and Lawson Wilder, Eric, Tracey, Marcy, Jordan and Aaron. Adoring greatgrandfather of Charlie, Laura, Scott, Mina and Nicole. Veffer, Managing Director The Ritz Tower, Inc. $(6$)CANTOR--Sol. How does one accept the loss of a friend of 70 years? The days spent on the golf course as a twosome followed by lunch and bridge. RUSSELL--William James. Passed away On Thursday, June 1, 2006 of natural causes at the age of 90 years. William was born in Clinton, MA, in 1915. He was a graduate of Clark University where he received his bachelor's degree and Syracuse University for his master's degree. Shortly after WWII began he enlisted in the Air Force. He was a navigator on B-17's and completed two tours totaling 50 missions. Mr. Russell was discharged from the service as a first lieutenant in 1945. Upon returning home he married Virginia Nichols and began working in education. William was a teacher and ultimately a principal for Pelham High School from 1945 to 1973. He ended his career in 1976 as a principal at Port Washington High School. William J. Russell is survived by his wife of 60 years, Virginia Russell, only son, Lee Russell, and two grandchildren, Matt and Kellie Russell. He was loved dearly and will be missed by many. Services will be held today at 5pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. in Larchmont, NY.

My symptoms closely mimicked those of the patient in Lisa Sanders's May 21 Diagnosis column: lightheadedness, abnormally rapid heartbeat, a rise in blood pressure and temperature, sensitivity to light (as well as sound), terrible mental confusion and, in my case, extreme weakness. Medical tests revealed no cause, so I, too, became my own detective. The cause was not jimson weed, but an often misunderstood condition -- multiple chemical sensitivities. To those of us so afflicted, this world, with its perfumes and plethora of cleansers, becomes a toxic minefield. Maureen Gabourie Burnaby, B.C.

At 69, he is already past the usual retirement age, but Alan M. Stillman, the founder and longtime chairman and chief executive of the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, could stay on the company's payroll for another 10 years -- unless he dies, although that, too, would have a payoff. Under a new contract disclosed last week, Mr. Stillman would run the company for five more years at an annual salary of $600,000 and the prospect of a bonus. Then, if his contract is not renewed, he would receive an annual consulting fee of $150,000 for five years. The company also made him the beneficiary of one-fifth of a $5 million insurance policy it holds on his life.

Edelbrock: Made in U.S.A. By Tom Madigan Illustrated. 324 pages. Motorbooks International. $40. Enthusiasts of a certain age speak in a brand-name shorthand when describing a car's modifications. Saying an engine has a ''780 Holley'' or an ''Isky roller'' has always been enough to tip off fellow members of the greasy-pawed brotherhood that the speaker has a command of the lexicon and the mechanisms of internal combustion.

NOT long ago we had occasion to mend our fence. A break the previous week had caused our two dogs, yellow Labs, to be found wandering down the road. As my husband set himself to the task of repair, he assembled not a posthole digger, wood and nails, but electrical tape and a Wire-Nut, the plastic connector used to splice electrical wire. This is because, like many of our neighbors' fences, the one we installed around our property happens to be of the invisible variety. Its technology, known generically as a pet containment system, was invented in the early 1970's and consists of three parts: wire wrapped in a cable that is buried at the perimeter of our two-acre plot, a transmitter and a receiver.

AT first whiff, it's hard to imagine why manmade litigation is tainting the briny air of Saltaire. It smells out of place. But election fraud, misconduct and malicious prosecution are just some of the allegations filed in the past couple of years against this minuscule incorporated village by Noel Feustel, a disgruntled guy with a postmodern Robin Hood complex and an unlivable heirloom cottage whose renovation was hamstrung by the village's refusal to issue a building permit.

REPORTED cases of Lyme disease in the metropolitan region rose sharply in 2005, according to health officials, with increases of 34 percent in Connecticut, 23 percent in New Jersey and 9 percent in New York State. But some counties showed declines. Westchester had 458 reported cases, a decrease of 39 percent from 2004. On Long Island, Suffolk County, with 542 cases, declined 3 percent, while Nassau County, with 122 cases, had an increase of 107 percent.

Emergency response planners in New York City -- or anywhere, for that matter -- face the difficult challenge of persuading people to prepare now for a disaster that may not happen soon, or even at all. But the need for readiness is clear. Beyond the possibility of terrorist attacks, there are other risks -- contagious diseases, chemical accidents or severe hurricanes -- that could endanger or severely disrupt daily life. The state of preparedness among the city's emergency responders has never been better. But the same cannot be said about New Yorkers at large, many of whom could be caught off guard.

To the Editor: Regarding the headline ''Pimp My Grill'' (May 28), a pimp is a criminal who exploits women for profit. No attempt to be hip, no matter how desperate, justifies the use of the word for something that is merely extravagant. Bill Marsano New York

Ben Gazarra, ''Awake and Sing!'' If there's a moral center to Clifford Odets's ''Awake and Sing!,'' it's Jacob, the character played by Ben Gazarra. As the sage -- and Marxist -- father of Bessie Berger, the matriarch of the Depression-era family and the grandfather of her idealistic son Ralph, he provides both the play's voice of reason and its voice of agitprop. Mr. Gazarra describes how he found the essence of his character. It was, he says, ''much like Proust's Madeleine cookie that sent him back into his childhood.'' He continues, ''I was about three weeks into rehearsal, and I kept saying: 'Where is the Jew? I haven't found the Jew.' Around that time a young lady came in to teach me how to use barber tools. So among the tools was the hand clipper that brought me back, really. I hadn't seen one of those since I was a child.'' The prop instantly reminded him of the Italian neighborhood where he was the ''Sabbath goy'' for the family of Harry Ackerman, the only Jewish boy in his neighborhood.

GERSON--Ivan. Dearest Ivan, ''a unique man''. In honor of your 60th birthday, we say we love you and miss you everyday. Nothing is the same without you. May you rest in peace. Your Loving Wife and Daughter, Liana and Tara.

As head of the codes team for the Mississippi Renewal Forum, I'm pleased that Jim Lewis wrote about the Smart Code and the urban transect that guides it (May 21). New Urbanists welcome a larger conversation about zoning-code reform in this country. Under today's restrictive suburban-influenced codes, it is illegal to restore the mixed-use urban fabric of traditional cities like Biloxi or New Orleans or, for that matter, much of New York. Mississippi is seizing the ''disastrous opportunity'' Lewis wrote about, as 10 of the 11 cities planned during the forum are pursuing code reform. (The lone exception is Biloxi.) But it's important to emphasize that the codes are not just for sleepy small towns. Gulfport, a substantially larger and more diverse city than Biloxi, is embracing the Smart Code. Sandy Sorlien Philadelphia

When he nominated Henry M. Paulson Jr. to succeed John W. Snow as Treasury secretary last week, President Bush said that one of Mr. Paulson's most important responsibilities would be to promote tax relief. The president could have found no better advocate than Mr. Paulson, the chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group. Not only did he champion the president's dividend tax cut in 2003, he personally benefited from it.

To the Editor: Re ''Hidden in Brothels, Slavery by Another Name,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 1): It's time for the New York State Legislature to take a bold step and to pass legislation that will protect women and girls from the heinous crime of trafficking.

WITH one ship on the way and another one in the way, Oyster Bay Harbor is as full of conflict as it is of boats. Next Saturday, a 134-foot-long brigantine called the Corwith Cramer will arrive from Woods Hole, Mass., to offer a day of free tours, and visitors are expected to line the pier waiting their turn. But a 150-foot lighthouse ship, the Nantucket, which tied up to the pier in 2003, seems to be making no move to leave, even though it has been ordered to.

To the Editor: ''Move the Furniture, the Band Is Here'' (May 21) was a welcome reminder that live music works in many forums. The convivial atmosphere of the house concert is a great way to share that certain energy.

To the Editor: So ''Beloved'' -- the ''expected winner,'' according to A. O. Scott -- is anointed by the Book Review as the best work of American fiction published in the last quarter-century. Yet the list of 22 books that received multiple votes contains only one other novel by a woman, Marilynne Robinson's ''Housekeeping.'' Of the judges named, fewer than one in three is a woman. (We're left to guess how many women were on the original list of a ''couple of hundred prominent writers, critics, editors and other literary sages'' whose opinions were solicited.) Meanwhile, women are the authors of more than half the works of fiction reviewed in the same issue. I looked in vain in Scott's otherwise thought-provoking essay for some discussion of how gender contributes to our present-day judgments of fiction, from weekly reviews to lists of the ''best.'' Surely all American women who have published since 1980 can't be said, as Scott remarks of Ann Beattie, to have ''steadfastly'' refused to try to live up to an ''implicit criterion of importance.'' Perhaps our ideas of importance are worth revisiting. To borrow Scott's phrase regarding ''The Group'' (the only novel by a woman that he mentions as having been in contention for Book Week's 1965 list), I'll insist if no one else will. Juliette Wells White Plains The writer is assistant professor of English at Manhattanville College.

OH THE GLORY OF IT ALL, by Sean Wilsey. (Penguin, $15.) ''In the beginning we were happy,'' Wilsey writes in his childhood memoir. ''And we were always excessive. So in the beginning we were happy to excess.'' By turns heartfelt, absurd and genuinely moving, ''Oh the Glory of It All'' recalls Wilsey's parents -- his father parlayed the family butter business into a real estate empire; his mother was a glamorous society columnist -- their spectacular divorce and the miseries he endured while shuttling between households. Today, Wilsey is an editor for McSweeney's Quarterly; our reviewer, Francine Prose, said his narrative ''reflects a vivid mix of brio, self-awareness and sophistication.''

To the editor: Steven Kurutz's ''Going to Literary New York'' (May 14) reminded me that the Friends of Libraries together with the Books for Kids Foundation have dedicated several sites in New York as literary landmarks. The landmarks, like the Plaza Hotel, which inspired Kay Thompson's ''Eloise,'' and Pete's Tavern, where O. Henry is said to have written ''Gift of the Magi,'' fall into the same categories Mr. Kurutz used in his article. One can also stay at the Algonquin Hotel on West 44th Street, home of the famed literary Round Table of the 1920's, or have a drink at Chumley's (temporarily closed due to a recent fire next door) in Greenwich Village, which was frequented by John Steinbeck, Ernest Hemingway, Edna Ferber, Simone de Beauvoir and Jack Kerouac. During the day, you can stop at the Donnell Library Center (20 West 53rd Street) and visit the original stuffed-animal collection that inspired A. A. Milne's ''Winnie-the-Pooh.'' Rocco Staino Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

OVED-WEISS--Or, 23, beloved son of Inbal Oved and Mark and Cathy Weiss, died suddenly and tragically in Bangkok, Thailand. Or was a loving and adored son, a worshipped caring brother and an inspiration to all who knew him. He served with distinction as a Sergeant, First Class in Sayeret Duvdevan of the Israel Defense Forces where he interdicted terrorism, lead and inspired the members of his unit. A dual citizen, Or represented the best qualities of his native Israel and the United States. 'The valiant never tastes of death but once.' $(6$)OVED-WEISS--Or. On behalf of our entire organization we wish to express our profound sorrow and sincerest condolences to our esteemed partner Mark Weiss, his wife Cathy and their sons Brandon and Ryan on the tragic and untimely loss of their beloved son and brother Or OvedWeiss, son of Ibal Oved of Israel. Or was an exceptional young man. Our hearts ache for the Weiss and Oved families. May his memory be a blessing. The Principals of Newmark Knight Frank
PART 7

David Wilmot, ''The Lieutenant of Inishmore'' The second scene of Martin McDonagh's ''Lieutenant of Inishmore'' opens with a blood-spattered man dangling upside down and being nastily tortured by Padraic, a crazed member of a tiny Irish Republican Army splinter group. Padraic, played with sleazy gusto by David Wilmot, is taunting his victim with a razor, but it is the two revolvers he wears in a double shoulder holster that Mr. Wilmot said gave him instant access to his violent character. ''I guess I liked them because they are empowering,'' he said of the weapons. ''When you pick up the guns, they are sort of like magic wands; people in the audience shift. I guess they are scared of getting sprayed by blood.''

NERSOYAN -- Hagop (James). Died May 3, 2006, Dayton, Ohio. Beloved husband of late Marie (nee Mesrobian). Loving son of the late Fr. Nersess and Anitza (nee Sulahian) Tavoukjian. Predeceased by siblings Abp. Tiran, Mariam (Jebejian), Kevork and Tshkho. Born April 28, 1920, Aleppo, Syria. Theologian, Scholar, Philosopher, Writer. Professor Emeritus, University of Dayton. Survived by loving family, friends throughout the world. Memorial service St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 630 Second Avenue (34th St.), NYC, on Tuesday, June 6, 2006, 7:00 pm.

I must agree with Richard Tuttle: ''the whole architecture profession is ego gone wild.'' Here in Denver, Daniel Libeskind has given us a new art museum that looks, God forbid, like a collapsed skyscraper, jagged and inverted. Our football stadium has the vertigo-inducing look of an amusement-park ride, and our airport evokes a nomad's tent that can be rolled up and taken elsewhere. I believe architecture should embody two principles: a sense of place and a sense of stability, one or both of which seem to be lacking in much postmodern design. Jimi Bernath Englewood, Colo.
To the Editor: Re ''Passengers May Now Pirouette to Gate 3'' by Jesse Green [May 28]:

The annual Vehicle Satisfaction Awards from AutoPacific, an automotive consulting firm based in Tustin, Calif., measure how satisfied owners were with cars or light trucks they had recently bought. Owner satisfaction was calculated in 45 areas , including comfort, safety and the overall purchase or lease experience.
