The monumental Anselm Kiefer exhibition, at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum for the next four months, is its own museum, complete with a free bus from the Metro-North train station in Katonah and a windowless corrugated steel pavilion all to itself. When the milled steel doors are closed, you are apt to feel a little groggy as the oil paint fumes start to kick in, but that just adds to the heady atmosphere, already thick with myth. Until the ascendancy of Gerhard Richter, the talented, mystical realist painter, few German artists were as admired and collected as Mr. Kiefer.

Connecticut and I go back a long way. So long, in fact, that I could tell you the story of how ''Yankee Doodle'' got to be the state song. Connecticut was my first great political obsession, and I can still sing the words to ''The Green Hills of My Connecticut,'' which ''Yankee Doodle'' replaced in 1978. Though you really wouldn't want to encourage that. Beginning today, The Times will be publishing a separate editorial page on Connecticut issues every Sunday. We'll now have editorial pages in all five of the paper's regional weeklies, but I suspect Connecticut's is always going to have a special place in my affections. You cannot possibly spend as much time in a state capitol as I did in Hartford and not always feel the tug.

IT'S prom season and graduation is just around the corner. If there ever was a time to focus on the problem of underage drinking here in Connecticut, it's now, when teenagers are busy celebrating their final days of high school and the beginning of independence, in many cases by popping a cork or opening a bottle. Why should we focus on underage drinking? Because we have a serious problem in this state. Every year, hundreds of teenagers in Connecticut are injured in alcohol-related accidents and assaults. And what's worse is that these teenagers (and about 138,000 of their drinking peers who avoid violent injuries) are also being harmed in a less visible way by significant and documented harm to their developing brains. For a state with our per capita wealth, population talents and diverse resources, we -- parents and elected officials -- are letting our children down.

To the Editor: John Kerry seems to have forgotten the first rule of holes. It is, in case you have forgotten: To get out, you must first stop digging. This is a loser for him, but that seems appropriate. Michael Kennedy Mission Viejo, Calif., May 28, 2006

I found it surprising that nowhere in the discussion of a digitized universal library was there mention of Jorge Luis Borges's ''Library of Babel.'' In 1941, Borges posited the existence of an endless library (otherwise known as the universe) that was made up of infinite hexagonal galleries of books, containing everything ever written, including all that has ever been conceived of having been written. While Borges feared the human species might be on the verge of extinction, he did believe that ''the Library -- enlightened, solitary, infinite, perfectly unmoving, armed with precious volumes, pointless, incorruptible, and secret -- will endure.'' Robby Ameen New York
To the Editor: Re ''Gasoline Prices Got You Down? Do the Hybrid Math'' (The Count, May 20):

To the Sports Editor: I have just read ''Faith Nights Bringing Salvation to the Ballpark'' (June 2) about the proposed scheduling of religious nights at minor league baseball games. Enough is enough! Although I concede that Christians are in the majority in this country, I refuse to have their religion forced upon me. If Christians want to observe their religious tenets, let them enjoy their own services. Non-Christians should not be compelled to listen to Christian-related services at a public spectacle, especially when they pay the price of admission. Seymour Becker Brooklyn

DEL MONTE--LeRoy, 82, on May 23, 2006 in Norwalk, CT after a long illness. Survived by sister Ruth Del Monte and companion Irena Dizer. Roy was a successful private investor. He attended Syracuse University, leaving to serve in the Pacific theater in WWII. Roy was married to the late Helen Del Monte, editor at McCall's, for over 30 years. He participated in and donated generously to New York faith community feeding and homeless programs and Westport charities. Roy was a sailor and avid winter sportsman and devoted friend to Irena and Stafford. Friends and family will dearly miss him.

FISH--Edith. The Board, staff, and volunteers of the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter morn the loss of Edith Fish, mother of board member, Daniel G. Fish, Esq.We extend our heartfelt condolences to her loving family. Susan V. Kayser, Mark A Zurack, Co-Chairs. Lou-Ellen Barkan, President &CEO.

A review on May 14, about ''Strange Piece of Paradise,'' an account of an ax assault on its author, Terri Jentz, misstated the date in June 1977 that the attack took place. It was the 22nd, not the 27th. The review and a picture caption referred incorrectly to the location of the campground in Oregon where the assault occurred. It is in Cline Falls State Park, near Redmond. There is no ''Cline Falls, Ore.'' The caption also misstated the date of a picture of Jentz. It was taken in 1992, not 1977.

Sarah Jones, ''Bridge & Tunnel'' The leap to Lorraine Levine, an elderly Jewish ''creative writer'' in Sarah Jones's solo show, ''Bridge & Tunnel,'' is aided by a pair of glasses and a wool sweater. Before beginning Lorraine's humorous commentary about her life, Ms. Jones slips on the glasses. ''Those glasses are my portals into her worldview,'' said the actress, who has already received a special Tony Award this season for her show. ''I get to literally put on the eyes through which she's seeing everybody. I have several models for the character in my mind, and all of them wore some version of these. I grew up in Queens, and if you go to an optician, this is the kind they have.''

Jefferson's own suggestion (writing to James Madison from Paris) that ''the earth belongs always to the living generation'' should be our incantation. Still hot from our country's independence, his university symbolized unlimited possibilities. And since (as he also suggested to Madison) ''no society can make a perpetual constitution or even a perpetual law,'' so, too, should architecture -- especially his -- permeate all ages past, present and coming, rather than defy time. Chris Morris New York

The Cobra in the Barn Great Stories of Automotive Archaeology By Tom Cotter. Foreword by Peter Egan. Illustrated. 256 pages. Motorbooks. $24.95 Some of Tom Cotter's stories are engaging enough. The problem is that his formula is often the same: collector searches for car, collector finds car, all live happily ever after.

BOUNTIFUL plates of vibrant Italian food are the signature of Tuscan House in Southampton. The same was true of the original Tuscan House in Riverhead. This is not a coincidence. William Oster, the Southampton restaurant's chef and owner, founded the Riverhead restaurant and was its first chef. When he left, he took the name with him. (For a while, there were two Tuscan Houses -- until the one in Riverhead closed for a few months and then reopened with a new name, Il Luigino Classico.) The Southampton restaurant occupies the prominent corner location that for many years was Basilico. It is a straightforward place with sunny sponge-painted walls, carpeting, sturdy wood chairs, dramatic wall sconces, ceiling fans, framed mirrors and familiar Italian art. Arches filled with opaque glass separate the dining area from the barroom, an inviting space with high-table seating, a mirror-backed bar and a striped ceiling of blue and deep red.

Before Marlon Brando died in 2004, he spent six months working on a movie directed by a Tunisian filmmaker, Ridha Behi. The uncompleted work is now being reconfigured as part fiction and part documentary. Retitled ''Brando and Brando,'' it will be about Mr. Behi's budding friendship with the actor. Mr. Behi is the latest filmmaker who has been forced to deal with the death of a star in the middle of production. Today, thanks to digital technology, editors can insert a dead actor into almost any scene. This was the case with Brandon Lee, who was killed in an accident during filming of ''The Crow'' (1994), and with Oliver Reed, who died during ''Gladiator'' (2000).

The Connecticut judiciary appears to care little for openness, especially when it comes to information that could embarrass the politically connected, not to mention the judiciary itself. In recent years, Connecticut judges have sealed records of cases involving prominent people, refused to release routine information and, most recently, told reporters they could not take notes in an open courtroom. The public has thus been denied information, for example, about the divorce of the University of Connecticut president, Philip Austin, as well as details of civil cases involving judges and attorneys.

To the Sports Editor: William Rhoden (''An Unknown Filly Dies, And the Crowd Just Shrugs,'' May 25) and Linda Greenhouse (''Equine Evolution; Our Creation, Our Concern,'' May 28) -- and the various respondents to their columns -- seem to have chosen racehorses as their cause du jour. Their breast beating on behalf of race horses would have more credibility if they had begun their railings before Barbaro's tragic misstep. David Dax Sayreville, N.J.

IT may not have the spontaneity or intimacy of two candidates going toe-to-toe live on television. But the two major-party candidates for the United States Senate will go at each other nonetheless in a virtual debate on the Internet this summer. ''BlackBerries at 20 paces,'' Thomas V. O'Neil, a lobbyist and aide to former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, calls it.

Ian McDiarmid, ''Faith Healer'' As Teddy, the fraying theatrical manager in Brian Friel's ''Faith Healer,'' Ian McDiarmid deftly opens and pours five bottles of beer (actually cold tea) during his 35-minute monologue. The use of this particular prop is precisely choreographed in the playwright's stage directions. ''Most of what I do, Brian asked for,'' Mr. McDiarmid said. ''But the bottle and glass kind of become an extension of yourself, and of course in Teddy's case the beer is literally a prop. The beer and the ability to talk to audiences, that's what keeps him alive, that's the sustenance. I always think of George Burns and his cigar. And this is a guy who gulps beer.''

To the Editor: Vincent M. Mallozzi's column of May 28 suggests possible state slogans. I suggest our slogan include reference to what is absolutely the best thing about living in New Jersey: We don't pump gas!

PHILLIPS--Giovanna December 31, 1913 -May 27 2006 died peacefully after a short illness at her home in West Palm Beach. A native of Florence, she worked as a free-lance writer and was active in charities in New York and Palm Beach. She is survived by her sons Anthony and Guy, her daughter Beatrice Ballard, and two grandchildren. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St Juliana Church in West Palm Beach on Wednesday June 7 at 11 AM. Please send donations in her memory to the Rehabilitation Center for Children and Adults, 300 Royal Palm Way, Palm Beach FL 33480.

The New Urbanism's push to ramrod its design criteria into the redevelopment process in Biloxi reminded me of my father's disdain for those in the world of academia and business who lack the common touch. And having personally experienced that mentality in a large corporation on numerous occasions, I find that the design debacle in Biloxi provides a perfect example of degreed professionals using their credentials to exclude local input in redevelopment of the devastated city. It's obvious that the New Urbanists did not examine the issue of affordability when considering replacement housing. Lewis's article highlights the need for consensus within the community under design scrutiny. Robert P. Thibodeau Detroit

The documentary maker JAY CORCORAN has never shied away from exploring painful and politically touchy aspects of gay male sexuality from a ground-level perspective. His newest film, ''ROCK BOTTOM,'' examines the crystal meth epidemic affecting gay New Yorkers in various stages of addiction and recovery. Why, the film wonders, has this potent, destructive form of speed become such a scourge? In its thrall, users lose their health (several of those interviewed were taking H.I.V. medication), their jobs, their loved ones and sometimes even their lives. This cautionary film suggests that the crisis is rooted in the fundamental stresses of gay culture. Among men with low self-esteem, the drug temporarily blots out shame, anxiety and sexual inhibition. Peer pressure within an insulated, sex-based party culture is another cause. Most disturbing is the testimony from those interviewed about the physical experience of sex when high on crystal meth. Because it enhances and prolongs pleasure, many former users find themselves disappointed or even uninterested in sex without speed. That's why so many go back to the drug. Although psychologists and doctors have their say, the bulk of the movie focuses on present and former users, who speak about their experiences with a remarkable candor. ''Rock Bottom'' is being screened Tuesday at 8:15 p.m. and Wednesday at 3:45 p.m. at the AMC Loews 34th Street Theater as part of NEWFEST 2006, the 18th New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Lesbian and Transgender Film Festival. In a lighter vein, the festival's closing-night film, RAMON SALAZAR'S ''20 CENTIMETERS'' (next Sunday at the same theater), is a gender-bending Spanish musical-comedy fantasy. Its heroine, pursuing transgender surgery (male to female), falls asleep and awakens as the star of her own Technicolor Hollywood-style musical. 312 West 34th Street, at Eighth Avenue, Manhattan, (646) 797-9947, www.newfest.org.

An article on May 21 about the American obsession with halls of fame referred incorrectly to the membership of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, which was founded in the Bronx in 1901. It has at least three Jewish members, not one.

MAY 16 was tax grievance day in Suffolk County, a day when residents can go to their local town governments and protest the assessment of their property values. It was also a day for hours-long, soggy waits in line for hundreds of residents of the town of Southampton, many with assessments that had doubled. A townwide reassessment of 46,000 residential parcels this year was prompted in part by complaints by owners of relatively low-priced homes that they were paying more than their fair share, according to the town attorney, Garrett Swenson.

To the Editor: My daughter and I have spent two memorable vacations at the Algonquin Hotel over the past three years, and we have never paid more than $250 a night (excluding taxes). On both occasions, we stayed in spacious, attractive, quiet, nonsmoking, classic twin rooms with excellent room service and housekeeping. I have not hesitated to recommend this gracious and lovely hotel to my friends and relatives who are planning a visit to Manhattan. So, I was a little surprised to note the absence of this historic literary venue from the May 14 Travel section. What would the members of the Round Table have said about this during one of their spirited luncheons? Lucinda G. Engelund Aptos, Calif.

THE apartment where Aurelio Castaño lives in White Plains suggests a man of some means: a living room with leather couches, real oil paintings. He painted them, so you know they're real. It's hard to imagine that 12 years ago, Mr. Castaño, just arrived from Colombia, was huddled on a street corner, just another Latino laborer in worn jeans waiting for a contractor to offer him a day's work cutting a suburban family's lawn or tiling their bathroom.

Any doubt that the handbag is the engine behind current fashion was dispelled in March 2005 when the Paris house Louis Vuitton presented its fall collection. The 300 photographers and their 300-millimeter lenses, traditionally placed at the end of the runway, were suddenly moved to its sides. Within minutes arguments broke out: The photographers could not get head-to-toe shots of the models without shoving their long lenses in one another's faces. I stopped shooting the show and began documenting the mayhem. Afterward, an editor asked the executive of the house why the photographers had been moved. He replied: ''We wanted them eye level with the handbags, because that's what sells.''

To the Editor: I so enjoyed your article about the new New Jersey slogan -- though perhaps lack thereof is more accurate (''How About 'If You've Got the Time, We've Got the State'?,'' by Vincent M. Mallozzi, Jersey column, May 28). It is refreshing to see the realities of just how difficult it can be to capture the right sentiment in writing. So I propose we display our good humor and use:

The Yankees' spiral of illness and injury continued downward Saturday, when two more players were unable to perform against the Orioles in the second game of a three-game series at Camden Yards. Jason Giambi, the slugging first baseman and designated hitter, was scratched from the lineup just before the first pitch because of a stomach virus, and Darrell Rasner, a rookie reliever, was put on the 15-day disabled list with a sore right shoulder.

BOB PROUT just spent $340,000 for a solar electric system to power his family's third-generation funeral home in Verona. He also turned an old smoking room in the basement into a miniature green museum, with his solar conversion equipment encased in glass for visitors to see. This is no futuristic vanity project for Mr. Prout, 50, who drives a hybrid car and has been a member of the Hudson-Essex-Passaic Soil Conservation District since 1979. He said it was a shrewd business move.

IN Glorianne Robbi's slice of Hunterdon County, the power of pavement often prevails as one new development project after another peels away layers of what was once open space. As the chairwoman of a preservation advisory committee in tiny East Amwell Township, Ms. Robbi is responsible for recommending protection of those parcels of land with particular historical or environmental significance.

Thanks for the jimson-weed diagnosis. Since this poisonous weed is spread throughout the United States, however, it would be helpful to have given the Latin name for quicker reference: Datura stramonium. The tiny seedlings could easily be picked along with the first harvest of leaf lettuce. A scary story. Anne Krantz Amherst, N.H.

OFFICIALS in Westchester County have long tried to keep noise levels at the local county-run airport to a minimum. They have restricted landings and takeoffs to four every half-hour. They have capped the number of passengers allowed to travel at one time, and they have even sought to have the runways essentially closed between midnight and 6 a.m. But now the county is facing what some local officials say is the greatest threat to their efforts to reduce noise levels at the airport in years.

Responding to a lawsuit from Cory Booker, Newark's mayor-elect, a judge in New Jersey's Superior Court has ordered Newark's Municipal Council to stop selling off city-owned property at scandalously low prices. This fire sale is the last act of a lame-duck government seeking to reward old friends and allies one last time before Mr. Booker formally takes charge on July 1. In about two weeks, the judge will decide whether to put a permanent halt to the sales. Obviously he should. They serve absolutely no civic purpose.
WEISS--Or Oved, 23, The members of the Aspatuck Tennis Club offer our heart felt condolences to our fellow member Mark Weiss and his family on the loss of a son and a brother.

The ability to decompose and rearrange narrativetexts may be useful in ''sound-bite scholarship'' and intellectual scrapbooking. But the digital noise created by all the communal editing and footnoting may drown out any thoughtful conversation between reader and author.A library of self-contained texts, immune from indiscriminate tampering, has been, is and will continue to be our best hope for moral, ethical and intellectual evolution. Michael C. Lang New York

REPORTED cases of Lyme disease in the metropolitan region rose sharply in 2005, according to health officials, with increases of 34 percent in Connecticut, 23 percent in New Jersey and 9 percent in New York State. But some counties showed declines. Westchester had 458 reported cases, a decrease of 39 percent from 2004. On Long Island, Suffolk County, with 542 cases, declined 3 percent, while Nassau County, with 122 cases, had an increase of 107 percent.

Most years, on the Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, Marc Epstein would have been outside at a barbecue like everybody else, probably in Rochester with his wife's family. But this year, Mr. Epstein could be found in Times Square, at the far corner of a basement that housed Lazer Park, the arcade and laser tag business on West 46th Street that he owned and operated for nine years. ''We're having our wake,'' Mr. Epstein said glumly, standing behind the arcade's bar just after 3 p.m. He told a man in a work uniform who had ordered a pizza from the snack bar that it was on the house, then sat down to describe the familiar combination of rising rent and expenses that had conspired to make this Lazer Park's last day in business.

Violence in the North End of Hartford reached a particularly brutal level over the last two weeks, as 16 people were shot over a five-day period from May 24 to last Thursday morning, including a 15-year-old boy who was killed in a shooting on Clark Street on Monday night. The police believe the teenager, Kerry Foster, was ''an unintended target,'' said Nancy Mulroy, a spokeswoman for the Hartford Police Department. As of Wednesday afternoon, no arrests had been made in the shootings.

HERSHAFT--Philip. On June 3, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Loving father of Helen and the late Raymond, and father-in-law of Arthur and Nancy. Cherished grandfather of Russell, Amy, Susan and Michael. Great-grandfather of six. Funeral services today, 12:15 PM, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

To the Editor: I was annoyed by the careless sweep of A. O. Scott's statement, in ''In Search of the Best'' (May 21), that the Book Review's survey to determine the best American novel of the last 25 years ''reveals that the baby boom . . . has not produced a great novel.'' It reveals no such thing. Those surveyed -- whose credentials certainly entitle them to an opinion -- were not asked to name those novels of the last 25 years they considered ''great.'' They were asked to choose ''the single best work'' of that period. They may think 12 or 15 great novels were published in that span; they may think not one was. We have no way of telling. They were asked a different question. Scott also mentions that of the authors to receive more than two votes, only Tim O'Brien and Marilynne Robinson were born after World War II. But that still leaves some authors who (I assume) received exactly two votes: Mark Helprin was born in 1947, Denis Johnson in 1949 and Edward P. Jones in 1951, which would make them all boomers by ordinary accounting. Surely it is much too soon, in any case, to say that Jonathan Franzen, David Foster Wallace, Richard Powers or William T. Vollmann -- to say nothing of Mary Gaitskill, Ben Marcus, Paul Auster, Lorrie Moore or Charles Johnson -- have not written great fiction. Posterity always has the deciding vote in these matters. To judge from the reactions of my students, Rabbit Angstrom and Nathan Zuckerman may be in for brief runs. Scott Stanfield Lincoln, Neb. The writer is a professor of English at Nebraska Wesleyan University.

Lisa Curran eases some of the stress of swimsuit shopping with her classic tank, a one-piece suit that has become the linchpin of her collection. Originally made in black with white trim, the suit has come out this year in navy blue, wine and chocolate brown with pale stripes of honeydew green, aqua blue, pink or a python-print brown ($140 at www.lisacurran.com).

MARK--Stanley. 80 years old. Died June 2. Beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Nancy (Larry Honig), Carol (John Garger), and Harvey. Brother of the late Herbert Mark. Stepfather of John Gevertz (Susan), the late Bruce Gevertz (Jackie), Carrie Sheer (Paul Bourget), Andrew Sheer and William Sheer. Adoring grandfather of Emily and Charles Honig; Rebecca and Annie Gevertz; and Willie, Justin and Andrew Gevertz. He proudly served in Europe during World War II, and was a graduate of the University of North Carolina. He was a practicing accountant for over fifty years. Private graveside service.

NOT long ago we had occasion to mend our fence. A break the previous week had caused our two dogs, yellow Labs, to be found wandering down the road. As my husband set himself to the task of repair, he assembled not a posthole digger, wood and nails, but electrical tape and a Wire-Nut, the plastic connector used to splice electrical wire. This is because, like many of our neighbors' fences, the one we installed around our property happens to be of the invisible variety. Its technology, known generically as a pet containment system, was invented in the early 1970's and consists of three parts: wire wrapped in a cable that is buried at the perimeter of our two-acre plot, a transmitter and a receiver.

WHEN the Children First Foundation, a nonprofit organization in Yonkers that promotes adoption, decided on a message for the vanity license plates it wanted to sell in the region, it picked ''Choose life.'' It drew the attention the group wanted, and not all of it was good.

NEARLY a century ago, area leaders created the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey because they knew the region's long-term economic survival lay in cooperation, not competition between the states. Recently, we saw regional cooperation again as New Jersey and New York forged a unified agreement to rebuild the World Trade Center site. But too often in the last few years this kind of cooperation has been the exception. And that must change. Because divided, New Jersey and New York risk being crushed under the weight of their own growth. Together, however, the two states can make the landmark investments that will determine our economic success over the next century.

To the Editor: Some of us need $11,000 propane grills with hundreds of thousands of B.T.U.'s, but I agree with Chris Schlesinger, the chef who, in ''Pimp My Grill,'' says that ''two bricks and an oven rack and some wood'' are all he needs to grill a steak. In medical school, our backyard grill was an old grate and some stacked bricks from an empty lot. The fuel: wood from a pruned crape myrtle. Best steaks we ever had. J. DuPont, M.D. Phoenix
As President Bush calls to expand the Border Patrol, some question whether more agents will truly result in improved security. Page 34.

To the Editor: As you noted in ''In a Vulnerable Year for Republicans, Just How Vulnerable Is Sue Kelly?'' (May 28), Representative Sue W. Kelly has amassed more than $1 million for her house race in November, compared with just over $429,000 for the next highest raising challenger, Judy Aydelott. What you did not say is that, unlike many other Republican incumbents, Ms. Kelly still refuses to return or donate to charity the $12,000 that she has received from Armpac, the political action committee of Representative Tom DeLay.

WEST--Mary Louise Stillman, 91. Died peacefully at home June 2nd. Predeceased by daughter Sarah West and husband James W. West. Survived by daughter Susan, son - in - law Donald Ross, grandchildren Fraser, James (Sarah) and two beloved corgis. Memorial service Tuesday June 6th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Animal Medical Center, NYC.

THERE was a time many decades ago when Atlantic sturgeon were so abundant here and in other areas along the Hudson River that bartenders were known to serve caviar instead of peanuts. All along the river, with its rich spawning grounds, the giant prehistoric sturgeon was caught in such large numbers that it earned the nickname Albany beef. Now those days exist only in memories. Overfishing and pollution in the Hudson caused sturgeon stocks to plummet so rapidly -- down to several thousand, depending on whom you ask -- that by the 1990's sturgeon were on the verge of becoming endangered.
GERSON--Ivan D. ''A Unique Man.'' Happy Birthday, love and miss you. Hugs, Mom, Dad and Adrienne

Janet Guthrie A Life at Full Throttle By Janet Guthrie. Introduction by Billie Jean King. Illustrated. 398 pages. SportClassic Books. $24.95. It wasn't only her sex that set Janet Guthrie apart from her competitors, it turns out. Ms. Guthrie, the first woman to compete in the Indianapolis 500, in 1977, possesses a level of erudition rare among race drivers. And it is on full display in her autobiography, an entertaining exception to the ''as told to'' genre of sports heroes' life stories.

SERLE--Seymour, J. Beloved husband of Anita, beloved father of Janet, Alayne and Sharon, beloved father-in-law of Ira, Scott and Matthew, and beloved grandfather of Beth, Perri, Melissa, Allison and Ariana, passed away on May 20, 2006, at the age of 78, after a courageous battle with cancer.

As the season winds down, the big boys -- the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the New York City Opera -- are leaving or have already left the scene. New opportunities open up for the lesser known and less conventional, like the artists featured at the all-day BANG ON A CAN MARATHON Sunday at the World Financial Center. DANIEL RODRIGUEZ gained fame as the ''singing cop.'' He was the New York City police officer who often sang the national anthem and ''God Bless America'' at public events, most notably at a memorial service shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks. This week audiences will have the chance to hear him in an operatic role. The CHELSEA OPERA says Mr. Rodriguez, who has left the force, will make his New York opera debut in Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci.'' Performances are Wednesday through Saturday at 8 p.m., St. Peter's Church in Chelsea, 346 West 20th Street, (866) 811-4111; $75 Wednesday, $25 the other nights. The AMERICAN COMPOSERS ALLIANCE is presenting a festival of contemporary American music, divided into five programs starting Wednesday at Symphony Space. The works include 15 premieres and pieces by 30 composers. At 8 p.m., 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, with a Saturday matinee at 2 p.m., (212) 864-5400; $15. On Thursday the PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA OF THE AMERICAS, conducted by ALONDRA DE LA PARRA, plays a program that includes the premiere of a double bass concerto by the Venezuelan PAUL DESENNE. The soloist will be his compatriot EDICSON RUIZ, who at 21 is the youngest member of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. Mr. Ruiz, a product of Venezuela's vibrant youth orchestra system, was all of 17 when he won the audition. At 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $15 to $35.

James Dean From Passion for Speed to Immortality By Philippe Defechereux 132 pages. Dalton Watson Fine Books. $30 James Dean was a supremely gifted actor, but for half a century he has also been defined in terms of his violent death. As a result, he is eternally associated with a car: the silver Porsche 550 Spyder he was driving on Sept. 30, 1955, when it collided with a 1950 Ford sedan at an intersection between Bakersfield and Paso Robles, Calif. Dean was 24.

OFFICIALS in Westchester County have long tried to keep noise levels at the local county-run airport to a minimum. They have restricted landings and takeoffs to four every half-hour. They have capped the number of passengers allowed to travel at one time, and they have even sought to have the runways essentially closed between midnight and 6 a.m. But now the county is facing what some local officials say is the greatest threat to their efforts to reduce noise levels at the airport in years.

APPEL--Patricia (nee Loveland), died on May 28, 2006 at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. Born May 17, 1928 in Detroit, raised in Minnesota, Patricia was a longtime resident of St. Chamas in Provence, France and of Greenwich Village. She was an accomplished photo editor and photo-journalist. Blessed with a brilliant mind, a great sense of humor, beauty and style, a joie de vivre, and a lifelong passion for books, music and travel, she embraced life fully. She is survived by her daughter Kristina Goldstein of Harrison, NY, her son Mark Appel of Manhattan, her son-in-law Jacob and granddaughter, Talia.

Dr. Iain Moore, 31, left, a kidney specialist from Newcastle upon Tyne, England, with Dr. Alastair McKelvey, a colleague: ''I'm from Belfast, but I live in the north of England these days, so I'm used to freezing cold weather and lots of rain. It's nice to get somewhere where there isn't that sort of weather. I'd never been in catacombs before, and I expected there to be bones and so on, but the bones had all been cleared out around A.D. 500. St. Paul traveled through and slept or certainly prayed and worshipped there. And whether or not you're a believer in religion, to think that 2,000 years ago people were building these places and living in them and hiding from the authorities in them and so on -- it's just a phenomenal sense of history.'' As told to Austin Considine

I read Michael Kimmelman's article (''The Architect, His Client, Her Husband and a House Named Turbulence,'' May 21) on the dream home/nightmare house designed by Steven Holl with some interest. I lived in a small Richard Meier house in Pittsburgh for three years. The roof leaked, the walls buckled andI was visited by functional issuesthat gnawed at me almost every day. But I would not changethe experience of living in a work of art for anything. To the Tuttle-Berssenbrugge family, I would say only this: one day you will be happy for the everlasting joy of the experience. Robert F. Quinlin, M.D. Pittsburgh

Stigmatized for Decades, French Has Renaissance in Maine Once ridiculed and repressed, the French language and French-American culture are making a comeback in Maine. Above, Anna Bilodeau at an immersion school in South Freeport. PAGE 26 The World Cup, and More Play, The Times Sports Magazine, looks at the favored Brazilians and their artful star, Ronaldinho, and examines the American team's chances in the World Cup. Also: a photo essay by Andres Serrano on athletic excellence. Skyline for Sale Recent collaborations between a New York developer and star architects say volumes about the way cities are built today. ARTS & LEISURE Miami and Dallas in Finals The Miami Heat, with the veteran leader Shaquille O'Neal, will play the Dallas Mavericks in the N.B.A. finals. Dallas defeated the Phoenix Suns, 102-93, to win the West. SPORTSSUNDAY Qatar Reinvents Itself To lure visitors, days of falconry and ''dune bashing,'' then nightclubs and ultra-luxurious hotels. TRAVEL Suspect in 7 Killings In Indiana Surrenders A man suspected of gunning down seven family members in their home on Thursday in Indianapolis surrendered to the city authorities after a manhunt. The police had warned residents not to take the suspect in. ''He didn't turn himself in out of remorse,'' a deputy police chief said. ''He turned himself in because he had no place to go.'' PAGE 28 Cancer Drug Shows Promise For women with a certain type of breast cancer, the drug Herceptin has represented an advance. But for some, it never works, and it stops working in others. A new drug promises to help those whose cancer worsens despite taking Herceptin. PAGE 26 Bush Urges Gay Nuptials Ban The president called for Congress to pass a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, saying activist judges were trying to redefine ''the most enduring and important human institution.'' PAGE 30 Fight Over Needle Exchanges In New Jersey, there is a renewed effort to allow drug users to exchange used syringes for new ones in a bid to fight H.I.V. PAGE 37

New cars arrive each season, and some are always better than others. And so it is with books about cars and about the people who love them. Here are some brief reviews to help car buffs cull the crop of recent automotive books, for their own summer reading or perhaps for a Father's Day gift. CHARLES McEWEN

Mamoun's Falafel Restaurant, a Middle Eastern cafe, is a 60's urban college-town phenomenon. Sitting in the small, dimly lighted room decorated with rugs (on the walls), plants and stained-glass lighting fixtures, with Middle Eastern music playing, you could be in New York City, Berkeley, New Haven or Cambridge. The original Mamoun's opened on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village in 1971. If you like Middle Eastern food at all, it's tough not to like Mamoun's. The fare is inexpensive, reliable and delicious. Dishes are offered as sandwiches, stuffed into warm pita ($2.25 to $4.50) or as full plates, accompanied by pita and a salad ($3.95 to $12.25).

I HAVE a seat at a Bouncing Souls concert that would make even the most blasé punk kid envious: I'm in this prolific band's studio in Asbury Park where they're rehearsing their song ''So Jersey,'' off their seventh album, ''The Gold Record,'' which arrives in stores on Tuesday. Anti-Bush stickers adorn nearby sound equipment, and a frayed banner from the band's 1993 ''Drink Coffee and Destroy'' tour hangs behind the drummer, Michael McDermott. It is a piece of history itself, having survived thousands of shows during the group's career, which is now in its 18th year.
To the Editor: Re ''Dear Graduates: Money Is a Means'' (On the Contrary, May 28), which said that money, in many ways, can buy a person a better life:

EVERY Saturday before Father's Day, the good commuters of the waterfront village of Rowayton go through an annual ritual of prostrating themselves before the fickle gods that bestow precious parking spaces in train station lots. Like teenagers camping out for Madonna tickets, an assortment of millionaires, chief executives, doctors and lawyers starts lining up after midnight outside a darkened 19th-century stable and wait through the chilly, haunting hours of the night -- in folding chairs, sleeping bags, even an actual twin bed -- until the windshield parking stickers go on sale at 8 a.m. Some read by flashlight, just as they did in summer camp; some use the bushes as bathrooms, just as they did in summer camp.
To the Editor: Re ''The Day the Musical Died'' by Ben Brantley [May 21]:

Richard Griffiths, ''The History Boys'' Richard Griffiths's Hector, the intellectual and idiosyncratic professor in Alan Bennett's ''History Boys,'' doesn't have much need for props. ''The problem with the character is that none of the props amount to anything,'' Mr. Griffiths said. ''Everything is in his head.''

TO anyone who has driven on Interstate 95 through Bridgeport and looked south, it is impossible to miss: a single house standing in a rocky weed-filled field, its windows boarded up or broken, its siding stripped. This is the face Bridgeport presents to the world every day. No wonder the mayor, John Fabrizi, has made it a priority to turn the 55-acre field, known as Steel Point, into a profitable development, with housing, stores and office space and a 2,200-foot promenade that will guide visitors along the shore of Long Island Sound. The developer plans to start work on the site by the end of August.

YOU snatch a snippet from a beloved classic and blatantly incorporate it into your own work, never even thinking about paying royalties or getting permission. And you alter the pilfered material shamelessly, turning it upside down or putting a beat under it that was never in the original. You're a rap producer, right? Nah. You're a playwright, and the guy you're stealing from is in all probability William Shakespeare.

To the Editor: Anya Kamenetz (Op-Ed, May 30) sides with the paid versus the unpaid internship. For an academic, however, this is hardly the point. Good internships are not, as Ms. Kamenetz describes them, ''fake jobs.'' They are a class. And interns are not ''like illegal immigrants.'' They are students.

BENARIO--Ernest. On June 1, 2006, my beloved husband and father of our sons Peter and Jeffrey, died after a long illness at the age of 82. He will be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him. He was drafted into the United States Army at the age of 19, he graduated from Camp Richie as a CIC Agent and took part in the Invasion at Normandy with the 5th Armored Division. During the Battle of the Bulge he was awarded the Bronze Star and he stayed in Germany for one more year to work for the American Government. After returning to the United States he joined the Food Brokerage of Sayres Company Inc., which he bought in 1976 and served as the CEO until the year 1992. All his life he was determined to be successful in everything he did, and his dynamic personality will be sorely missed. Our marriage lasted 61 years, and his loss to me and my sons will be forever with us. Ernest also leaves three grandchildren, Elena, Lara and Alex, and his daughter-in-law Karen. Funeral arrangements are strictly private.

WENIG--Dolores (nee Jaffe). Beloved wife of the late Jerome Wenig. Loving mother of Debra and Howard Ross and Howard Wenig. Cherished grandmother of Leslie, Amy and Andrew Ross, and Laura and Rachel Wenig. Loving sister to Melba and David Sokol, and Lynn Froman. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

WHY GO NOW -- Five years ago, at the height of Ireland's economic boom, Dublin teetered on the brink of blandness. The city's warm fusty character and weathered shops became harder to find amid the shiny glass-paneled offices and luxury apartments. Instead of moseying to work, people wielded sharp elbows on the overcrowded sidewalks. Caffeinated sobriety replaced that famously hung-over haze.

The monumental Anselm Kiefer exhibition, at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum for the next four months, is its own museum, complete with a free bus from the Metro-North train station in Katonah and a windowless corrugated steel pavilion all to itself. When the milled steel doors are closed, you are apt to feel a little groggy as the oil paint fumes start to kick in, but that just adds to the heady atmosphere, already thick with myth. Until the ascendancy of Gerhard Richter, the talented, mystical realist painter, few German artists were as admired and collected as Mr. Kiefer.

Newark has a lot of old buildings, including the one at 40 Rector Street, which is owned by the city but is where the basketball star Shaquille O'Neal wants to build a towering, high-priced condominium complex. But Mr. O'Neal chose the wrong old building: The five-story brick structure, which is in its last year housing Science High School, is also the oldest remaining piece of the Peter Ballantine & Sons Ale Brewery and a highlight of historic tours in the area. Historic preservation officials were horrified at the proposal.
To the Editor: Apparently it's not enough to have put oneself in harm's way. The bar for patriotism and service to one's country is now measured by how much damage one sustained.
PIERCE--Willa Martin, a resident of Rye, NY died Tuesday, May 30. She was 94, and was the wife of the late Marvin Pierce. Services will be private.
GINSBERG--William R. Memorial service Monday, June 5, 4:30 PM, Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St, NYC.

MY son's bar-mitzvah-going year is almost over. There are a couple more invitations sitting in the kitchen, and then I'll be free. But not quite yet. Chauffeuring back and forth to synagogues and women's clubs/hotels/catering halls is the latest task in a long career of suburban kid-driving that includes school drop-offs, sports practices and games, class trips and birthday parties. This is more interesting than it sounds, because for some unfathomable reason, when I'm operating a motor vehicle, kids forget I'm an actual human with ears and they speak freely. The driving is dull, but it's a great opportunity to pick up some intel.

If you wanted to design the perfect retirement community, what would it look like? Most people would agree on a few things. It would be green and pretty. It would be safe but stimulating, offering better diversions than bingo, TV and staring into space. Residents could relax and reminisce, but also study and learn. There would be arts and music, lectures and books, movies and shows. And there would be lots of young people around. You could spend a ton of money and effort designing such a place. Or you could just put it on a college campus.

PALMER--Edward L. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Edward Palmer, who was elected a Trustee in 1982 and a Trustee Emeritus in 1985. Over those many years, he was a devoted supporter of the Metropolitan, lending his time and wisdom to the evolving needs of the Museum. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Margaret and to his family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

IT'S difficult to imagine, a century after the fact, the sense of excitement and new opportunity that electricity brought to modern life. But the Dada artist Man Ray, born in Philadelphia then based in Paris and later Hollywood, captured part of that moment in prints and portfolios of photographs, many of which are on display at the Heckscher Museum of Art. Beginning in Paris in the early 1920's, Man Ray (1890-1976) used electricity as an inspiration for art. He lived in one of the first electrified buildings in Montparnasse, where he invented the rayograph (named for him) by placing kitchen utensils onto light-sensitive paper and then turning on the lights. A lampshade was among his first Dada objects.

As he left the Yankees' clubhouse after a 6-5 victory against the Orioles on Saturday, Alex Rodriguez wore a pink shirt emblazoned with a movie title: ''House of the Dead.'' The humor was macabre and certainly appropriate. Rodriguez had just missed his second consecutive game with a stomach virus.

PATELL--Estrella. 78, passed away on May 31 after battling cancer and kidney disease. Cherished wife of Rusi, devoted mother of Cyrus and Shireen, loving mother-in-law of Deborah and Jimmy, adored lola of Liam and Caleb, caring sister of Noli and Angelita. Born in the Philippines, she earned 3 master's degrees from Columbia University, where she served as administrator for the Phys. Ed. Dept. at Barnard College. A true cosmopolitan, she loved New York's neighborhoods, restaurants, theater, and opera, and also loved to travel. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research appreciated. A service will be held on Monday at 12:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St.

WITH one ship on the way and another one in the way, Oyster Bay Harbor is as full of conflict as it is of boats. Next Saturday, a 134-foot-long brigantine called the Corwith Cramer will arrive from Woods Hole, Mass., to offer a day of free tours, and visitors are expected to line the pier waiting their turn. But a 150-foot lighthouse ship, the Nantucket, which tied up to the pier in 2003, seems to be making no move to leave, even though it has been ordered to.

Lightweight summer T-shirts by Under take this season's lust for lace and wrestle it into submission, with tanks and short-sleeve T's that bear the most delicate frilly edging on necklines and sleeves. In solid neutrals or pastels, the supersoft cotton shirts have an airy fit that doesn't cling at waistline or arm and doesn't need layering. They also have an infinitely comfortable price: in a world of high-end $100 T's, Under's shirts are $29 to $34.

THE New York City health commissioner has proposed legal changes that would make H.I.V. testing easier and more widely available. But the New York State Legislature has yet to pass these changes. In the meantime, more than 1,100 New Yorkers every year unnecessarily progress to full-blown AIDS because their illness went undiagnosed for almost 10 years. AIDS groups should be screaming for expanded testing, and many of them are. But some are fighting any change, as though the epidemic hasn't evolved since the 1980's. In those days, there were important reasons to protect people getting tested for AIDS. There were no drugs to treat the disease. A positive test meant that you were just waiting to die. William F. Buckley was calling for tattoos to identify people with H.I.V., and others wanted to quarantine us.

Beginning this week, this section will include news and features from the entire New York metropolitan region outside the city. Coverage of Long Island news, cultural activities and restaurants will continue. There are also two new regular columns: Generations, essays about family life; and Home Work, about gardening, chores, tools and other aspects of maintaining a home. The contents of this section, other news of the region and local opinion pages are also available on the Web at www.nytimes.com/region. Readers are welcome to comment on the changes by sending messages to regionalmail@nytimes.com.

NOT long ago we had occasion to mend our fence. A break the previous week had caused our two dogs, yellow Labs, to be found wandering down the road. As my husband set himself to the task of repair, he assembled not a posthole digger, wood and nails, but electrical tape and a Wire-Nut, the plastic connector used to splice electrical wire. This is because, like many of our neighbors' fences, the one we installed around our property happens to be of the invisible variety. Its technology, known generically as a pet containment system, was invented in the early 1970's and consists of three parts: wire wrapped in a cable that is buried at the perimeter of our two-acre plot, a transmitter and a receiver.

To banish milquetoast complexions and usher in the summer glow, True Blue Spa has come up with Hello, Sunshine! Self-tanning Face Puffs ($20 for a box of six single-use puffs at Bath & Body Works stores). The easy-to-use puffs come in individual packets. The wearer presses the packet in the center to release the self-tanner, removes the puff and swipes it quickly and evenly over the face. No orange fingertips because the puff has a sure-grip dry back and no ugly surprises because the tan develops slowly over the course of four hours.

MASON--Stephen W., Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, FL passed on May 17, 2006. Son of the late Stephen W. and Tacy (Duckworth) Mason of Hatboro, PA, grandson of the late Mrs. Adella Biddle Duckworth of Philadelphia, PA, and great-grandson of the late Pierre LeGaux, former governor of Martinique, Mr. Mason attended the University of Pennsylvania and was a graduate of Parsons School of Design in New York City. His long and successful career as a designer in the field of American Fashion spanned many continents and included his opening a design business, his employment as Senior Vice President of Design with the Leslie Fay Corporation in New York City, and as a fashion consultant in Miami, FL. Mr. Mason had resided in Fort Lauderdale for the past 25 years involving himself with charitable activities, most recently as a docent with the Bonnet House in Fort Lauderdale, where his kind, generous and sophisticated persona exquisitely complimented the capacity in which he served. A dear friend of Mr. Mason's recently shared his thoughts, which follow. For those who had the good fortune to know Stephen Mason or who had the privilege to meet him, we are saying goodbye to one of the last of a great era. ''This was a man who was at the opening nights of Chorus Line, Brigadoon, West Side Story, Pal Joey, Damn Yankees, and countless others. His friends were legends like Bob Fosse, Michael Bennett, Cheryl Hines, the Lunts, Bob Mackie, Rock Hudson, Robert Preston, and Burt Lancaster. He designed and/or built dresses for Jackie Onassis, Lauren Bacall, Marlene Dietrich, and he did once tango with Marilyn Monroe. This was a man who lived his life every second to its fullest. He could turn a phrase like no one I have ever met, and as I am sometimes stumped for words myself, I can only borrow words from a much greater writer who said, 'Good night, sweet prince, And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!''' Memorials may be made to Parsons School of Design, Fashion Department, 66 West 12th St, New York, NY 10011.

To the Editor: Kate Stone Lombardi must stop her stereotypes about the Village of Port Chester -- not town, as she states in ''An Exhibition Ends, but the Love Lingers On'' (County Lines column, May 28). We have much more than ''big-box stores and eminent domain,'' her unfortunate repetitive viewpoint of our lively village.

I loved the Ethicist's response (May 14) to Harvey Hauswirth of Provincetown, Mass., who asked if he was right to refuse the request of the 98-year-old woman who wanted to install a stairway lift in that Cape Cod cottage. ''That lift might be ugly, but some things are even uglier,'' the Ethicist wrote, and then went on to talk about the sheer human beauty of kindness, compassion and generosity of spirit. It's worth noting that the ancient Greeks made no distinction between ethics and aesthetics. In other words, if an action looks good, it probably is good, legalities be damned. Robert Blair Kaiser Phoenix

MY son's bar-mitzvah-going year is almost over. There are a couple more invitations sitting in the kitchen, and then I'll be free. But not quite yet. Chauffeuring back and forth to synagogues and women's clubs/hotels/catering halls is the latest task in a long career of suburban kid-driving that includes school drop-offs, sports practices and games, class trips and birthday parties. This is more interesting than it sounds, because for some unfathomable reason, when I'm operating a motor vehicle, kids forget I'm an actual human with ears and they speak freely. The driving is dull, but it's a great opportunity to pick up some intel.

WHEN the Children First Foundation, a nonprofit organization that promotes adoption, decided on a message for its Connecticut vanity license plates, it picked ''Choose life.'' It drew the attention the group wanted, and not all of it was good.

THE MONEY MAN The News -- President Bush nominated Henry M. Paulson Jr., chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, to become his next Treasury secretary. Behind the News -- In some ways, an odd choice. Mr. Paulson is a deficit hawk while the administration has built up historic budget deficits. But many allies of the White House had lobbied for him, convinced he could help convey the strengths in the economy and reassure voters of the president's economic competence. Mr. Paulson had to be carefully courted, a sign of the prestige the job has lost under Mr. Bush. THE NONCIVILIAN The News -- Gen. Michael V. Hayden was sworn in as director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Behind the News -- At the ceremony Wednesday, President Bush felt compelled to give agency employees a pep talk, assuring them that they remained ''vital'' to the White House. The event was for public consumption. (The general officially became director Tuesday.) The administration wanted to lift agency morale and portray a sense of calm after several turbulent years at the C.I.A. Sensitivity lingers over a military officer leading the civilian agency. THE GOLDEN ARM The News -- Roger Clemens, the future Hall of Fame pitcher, agreed to come out of retirement and rejoin the Houston Astros. Behind the News -- A break for the struggling Astros, the defending National League champions. Clemens turns 44 in August but is hardly teetering. He led the major leagues with a 1.87 earned run average last year. His time off could keep him fresh in September. Three other 43-year-old pitchers are still kicking: Terry Mulholland of Arizona, Jaimie Moyer of Seattle and David Wells of Boston. One subplot: Clemens's son Koby, an infielder in Houston's minor league system, could join his father soon. THE NEW CHILD The News -- Well, not so new a child. Prince Albert II of Monaco acknowledged that he is the father of a 14-year-old American girl, a lawyer for the prince's family, Thierry Lacoste, told Le Figaro, a French newspaper. Officials in Monaco said they would not comment on the matter. Behind the News -- Last year, Prince Albert, who is not married, acknowledged that he was the father of a 3-year-old boy. He later told The New York Times that he did not know of any other paternity claims that could be true. Mr. Lacoste told Le Figaro that legal paternity was established several weeks ago. THE LONG FAREWELL The News -- Katie Couric spent her final day as anchor of ''Today.'' Now it's on to the ''CBS Evening News'' in September. Behind the News -- For weeks, NBC built a relentless drumbeat of publicity. Then came Wednesday's lovefest packed with memories and tributes. Was it too much? It could have ''turned unbearably cloying but didn't, mainly because Ms. Couric reined in her emotions and did not exit in a puddle of tears,'' wrote Alessandra Stanley of The New York Times. But David Hinckley of The Daily News said the show was ''more like a long in-house graduation party.''

Not only did you publish an article about a building that (according to the owner) is uninhabitable half the year, does not exhibit fine workmanship and yet cost twice the budget, but you also put it on your cover.This kind of attention only goes to further the public's perception of architects as prima donnas who are insensitive to cost and program requirements. Architects are first and foremost problem solvers, and recognition should come to those architects with successful solutions. Gina G. Moffitt Los Angeles

Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told a gathering of defense experts here on Saturday that Iran was ''one of the leading terrorist nations in the world.'' Mr. Rumsfeld also questioned why Russia and China would allow Iran to participate in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, a regional organization that includes Russia, China and Central Asian nations.

ALDWELL--Edward, brilliant performing artist, master teacher, and gifted author of music textbooks, is forever etched in the memories of his many students and colleagues at Curtis over the past 35 years. He brought a performer's intensity, a scholar's intellect, and a deep humanity overflowing with humor and insight to all of his activities on stage, in the classroom, and in daily life. His recordings and his books will keep him with us in a tangible way even though his inimitable spirit, wit, and intellectual integrity may pass this way only once. The entire Curtis family sends condolences and our deepest sympathies to his wife and family. H.F. (Gerry) Lenfest, Chairman, Board of Trustees Roberto Diaz, President The Curtis Institute of Music
FELDMAN--Rose M. 105, died May 2, 2006. Mother of Stanley Feldman and Joan Kron. Memorial celebration, Monday, June 5, 5:30 pm, Regency Whist Club, 15 E. 67 St.

TWENTY years ago, Suffolk County settled a class-action lawsuit that had charged the Suffolk County Police Department with rampant discrimination against African-Americans, Hispanics and women. At that time very few women were on the force. To settle the case, the county agreed to abandon employment practices that kept women from serving as police officers. We'd like to think that problems like these have been solved. But it turns out that Suffolk's Police Department is still not so kind to the women in its ranks.

Since learning that he suffers from progressive supranuclear palsy, Charles D. Peebler Jr., chairman emeritus of the advertising company known as True North Communications, now part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has been raising money for research into the condition, a degenerative disease of the brainstem for which there is no cure. He helped to raise more than $1 million last week at a dinner at the University Club in Midtown Manhattan. At the event, the Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy honored Mr. Peebler and Dr. John C. Steele, a Canadian neurologist who has been studying the disease for more than 40 years.

10 P.M. (HBO) BIG LOVE -- Sticking to The Principle is tough, especially with those nasty brethren prophesizing right and left. In the season finale, Bill (Bill Paxton) and Joey try to lord it over Roman at a U.E.B. Priesthood Council meeting, and Nicki's life is compounded when she questions where her already dubious loyalties lie. And Barb (Jeanne Tripplehorn, above, with Mr. Paxton) seizes the spotlight at the Mother of the Year ceremony at the governor's mansion. Could it have anything to do with her parenting skills being so much more expansive than previously thought? 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) LET'S JUST PLAY: GO HEALTHY CHALLENGE -- In April, four adolescents vowed to live healthier lifestyles -- and to encourage their friends, families and communities to do the same. This special assesses their progress. 9 P.M. (TLC) WELCOME TO FATLAND -- Freedom Paradise in Mexico, a ''fat-friendly resort,'' as its people put it, welcomes those for whom the ''Go Healthy Challenge'' (see above) has not yet worked. 9 P.M. (HBO) THE SOPRANOS -- Season finale. Tony, ever the supportive spouse, gives Carmela a career boost, while A.J. receives a perk from his own place of employment. 9 P.M. (National Geographic Channel) SPACE RACE: THE UNTOLD STORY -- On their side: Sergei Korolev, a political prisoner. On ours: Wernher von Braun, a former Nazi scientist. This new series relies on recently declassified documents from the Soviet Union and the United States to chronicle the superpowers' sprint to the heavens. 10 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES -- Let the play resume. Tanya (Zoe Lucker) and Amber (Laila Rouass, near left, with Ms. Lucker), with their dueling pregnancies, battle for Conrad's love. Meanwhile, the players get worked up in Spain during a little pre-season revelry. 10 P.M. (History Channel) THE REVOLUTION -- Everyone knows the principal players: Thomas Paine, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, George Washington and Benjamin Franklin. But what about the unsung heroes -- the spies, slaves, free Africans, American Indian sympathizers, emancipated women and downright eccentric personalities -- who dared to take on the mightiest empire in the world? This new 13-part series looks at the common folk who committed treason against the British crown for the cause of independence. 10 P.M. (E!) THE SIMPLE LIFE: 'TIL DEATH DO US PART -- Make that ''The Surreal Life,'' since Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie (near right, with Ms. Hilton) aren't talking these days. With a nod to ''Wife Swap,'' this season finds the celebutantes trying to run traditional households -- individually, of course -- and lets their host families decide which one is worth keeping. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

To the Editor: Senator John Kerry's supporters believe that the charges of the Swift boat group cost him the election. The senator's Vietnam record, however, would have never been a significant issue had he not foolishly made it the centerpiece of his campaign, including the opening words of his acceptance speech for the Democratic presidential nomination: ''I'm John Kerry, and I'm reporting for duty.''

From the critical (and blogospherical) drubbing most of them received, you might think that the movie and television stars who dared to tread the New York boards this season were a colony of succubi and incubi sent to defile our sacred temple. At the very least, Hollywood types like JULIA ROBERTS, DAVID SCHWIMMER and AMANDA PEET were accused of taking jobs that belonged to properly trained stage actors. But who is ever properly trained? Drama school graduates can blither their way through performances as false as any Tinseltown nitwit's. Meanwhile Ms. Roberts wasn't the train wreck some painted her as; I hope she tries again. And several of her West Coast colleagues -- GLORIA REUBEN in ''Stuff Happens,'' JOHNNY GALECKI in ''The Little Dog Laughed,'' OLIVER PLATT in ''Shining City,'' LAUREN AMBROSE in ''Awake and Sing!'' -- were terrific. Provenance is a poor measure of actors. O.K., there was SUZANNE SOMERS. Still, the west-to-east traffic isn't slowing down. Right now in New York WENDIE MALICK (''Just Shoot Me'') and MARK MOSES (''Desperate Housewives'') are starring in DAVID WARREN's Wall Street comedy ''BURLEIGH GRIME$.'' (In previews, opens June 13, New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, 212-239-6200; $70.) And SANDRA OH (''Grey's Anatomy'') is headlining DIANA SON's ''SATELLITES,'' an intimate drama about an interracial couple. (In previews, opens June 18, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, 212-239-6200; $50.) But the bicoastal casting prize goes to NEIL LABUTE's ''SOME GIRL(S),'' whose Must-See TV ensemble includes ERIC MCCORMACK (''Will & Grace''), MAURA TIERNEY (''ER''), FRAN DRESCHER (''The Nanny''), JUDY REYES (''Scrubs'') and BROOKE SMITH (''Grey's Anatomy''). (In previews, opens Thursday, Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, Greenwich Village, 212-279-4200; $65 to $70.) Imported, yes, but at a time when plays are getting smaller, top-notch small-screen casts may be just the ticket.
