Nearly a month ago, the chairman of William Lyon Homes appeared to win his year-long struggle to take his company private. General William Lyon, a retired chief of the Air Force Reserves, proclaimed that his tender offer to shareholders had crossed the 90 percent threshold, allowing him to buy the rest of its outstanding shares for $109 apiece.
Once the dust finally settles from today's political earthquake, the candidates for governor may actually start talking more about those pressing issues facing the state.

New Venture Partners said Tuesday it closed a $275 million venture capital fund -- but none of that money is likely to go to entrepreneurs working out of their garages. Instead, the firm plans to use the new cash to finance spinoffs for big technology companies.
In California, voters go to the polls in the first major congressional race of the season.  (Producer: Emily Hager)

The "Germany Survival Bible" on Spiegel's English-language site today features an interview with Franz Ferdinand guitarist Nick McCarthy, who Spiegel explains "grew up in Bavaria and offers a few pearls of wisdom about his countrymen." His main tip for English fans traveling to Germany this month? "A good piece of advice is always to just go for a drink with a German. I think that brings people together quite easily."

Today The Sun, like several English papers, features this photograph of star stiker Wayne Rooney demonstrating his apparent return to health by executing a spectacular "scissor-kick" during a closed training session yesterday in England, before flying with the squad to the German spa town of Baden-Baden. On The Guardian's Newsdesk podcast, Ed Pilkington explains why the photograph does not grace the cover of his paper, as it does page 1 of The Sun (with the headline "THERE IS A GOD"). At press time in London last night, the asking price for non-exclusive rights to publish the photograph was 15,000 pounds.
Just three days to go, and then the party's on!

Pfizer will collect offers Tuesday afternoon -- and possibly some stragglers into the evening -- for its over-the-counter drugs business, a unit that includes such well-known brands as Listerine mouthwash and Sudafed decongestant. Notably absent from the sale process are private equity funds, who are expected to sit on their hands ahead of the bid deadline, leaving pharmaceutical and consumer-products companies (and one British retailer) to fight it out.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Serbia and Montenegro may no longer exist as a nation, but the soccer team representing the last incarnation of rump Yugoslavia is not going down without a fight -- or several fights, all among themselves. Acccording to an Associated Press report, posted on Sports Illustrated's Web site, the team didn't make it out of Austria, where it had stopped for training en route to Germany, intact. The main casualty was defender Dusan Petkovic -- Coach Ilija Petkovic's not particularly gifted son -- who decided to quit the team rather than remain the focus of the bitter complaints about nepotism back in Belgrade, as we discussed last week.
Axa SA, Europe's second-largest insurer, said it had agreed to sell its Axa Re reinsurance unit to a group of investors led by a buyout firm, Stone Point Capital.

After two years of generally disappointing results and share performance, H&R Block may be ready for a radical solution. An analyst from UBS on Tuesday suggested that breaking up the company -- a leading provider of tax advice that also has a mortgage and investment arm -- could be the best strategy.

Hewlett-Packard said on Tuesday that it would buy Silverwire Holding, a Swiss digital photo software maker with an emphasis on retail photo printing, for an undisclosed sum. Silverwire, which focuses on creating the backend software for retail photo centers, has more than 23,000 photo kiosk licenses and customers in 30 countries.
An Internet company with a kooky name, no profits and fresh from a splashy Super Bowl ad is getting ready to go public. Good luck, says TheStreet.com.
The Citic Group, a Chinese state-owned investment company, is negotiating to buy a Canadian oil company with assets in Kazakhstan, according to reports.

For two days, I had been trying to assume the life of a regular Venetian, a more authentic and potentially cheaper way to experience a city that attracts some 19 million visitors every year. I'd already failed once, a week before, having fled Venice when I mistakenly booked a hotel in a distant suburb, Lido di Jesolo. But in Bologna, I'd begun to feel the pull of the Venice, and returned by train (7.90 euros) for this, the fourth in my series of weekly round-the-world Frugal Traveler columns.

Small hedge funds in Europe are suffering from the recent market volatility -- and, in some cases, expiring, according to investors interviewed by FTadviser, a service of The Financial Times. The article does not name any specific funds that have imploded, but one person in the industry is quoted as saying "it will take a few more weeks for all the detritus to come to the surface."
A spokesman for Bill Weld confirms that Mr. Weld will drop out of the governor's race today.

When and if AT&T closes its $67 billion acquisition of BellSouth, one of the key assets it will receive is full control of the two phone companies' Cingular wireless joint venture. For all that money, though, AT&T plans to scrap the Cingular brand name in favor of AT&T Wireless, marking the victory of a decades-old acronym that includes "telegraph" over an oddly spelled word from the dot-com era.

The war on terror won't end with a signing on a battleship, as President Bush repeatedly says, so is it possible that V-T Day already happened and we missed it? John D. Judis, a senior editor at The New Republic, argues in a TNR Online article that the answer is yes. The meaning of the phrase "the war on terror" has been "exhausted," Judis writes, and the war, at least as a military operation, is over. He writes:
Bill Weld will announce his decision on the governor's race at 11:30 a.m. at his Manhattan office. Two advisers, pleading a lack of intel, say they aren't sure which way he's going.

Monday's 17 percent jump in shares of Movie Gallery added fuel to recent speculation that the video rental chain is ripe to be acquired. A larger rival, Blockbuster, and the online rental service Netflix were mentioned as potential buyers of Movie Gallery, whose market capitalization now stands at about $220 million.

By now it seems pretty clear that Bruce Arena is playing it very mysterioso to confuse the Czechs, Italians and Ghanians -- a closed-door match yesterday in which his players don't wear numbers; no comment from any American on that match, even on the official United States Web site; and a shroud of silence so complete that a panic swept through the Big Soccer bulletin board yesterday and today among United States fans afraid that Kasey Keller had been hurt and that the team was hiding the injury. Keller doesn't seem to have been injured, but the fact that there was confusion is probably fine with Arena.
There's some follow-up discussion of my sweatshop column today at the blog Economist's View.
The Russian gas monopoly Gazprom said on Tuesday it was seeking strategic partners and asset acquisitions on the British market as part of its ambitions to expand in western Europe.
A biotechnology company, Gilead Sciences, said on Teusday it had agreed to buy a Canadian unit of the German specialty chemicals company Degussa.

International Business Machines said on Tuesday it plans to invest nearly $6 billion in India over three years, underscoring the country's growing importance as a global hub for information technology expertise.
McAfee, a provider of computer security software and services, said on Tuesday that it had acquired closely held Preventsys, a developer of security software.
Publicis, the French advertising group, said on Tuesday it has acquired a majority stake in several Turkish advertising and communications companies to expand its presence in the market there.
The Onyx Software Corporation, a maker of computer hardware for businesses, said on Tuesday it had agreed to be acquired by the privately held M2M Holdings for $92 million, or $4.80 a share.

The executive board of Deutsche Borse has met its financial advisers in an attempt to establish by how much it can raise its offer for pan-European stock exchange group Euronext, The Telegraph reported.
Staff photographers for The New York Times tell how they use digital photography in their jobs.

Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Sunday, 6 June 1784: 29 6/10; 64; 66; NE; 10. Rain, rain, sun, rain, thunder. Nipped off all the rose-buds on the tree in the yard opposite the parlor window in order to make a bloom in the autumn. No bloom succeeded.

A one-time real estate mortgage broker, Howard J. Vogel, says that he and members of his family were linchpins in a long-running arrangement that helped the New York securities litigation powerhouse Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach snare lucrative lead counsel positions in a series of securities lawsuits, reaping hundreds of millions of dollars in legal fees.

Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company whose shares have fallen 28 percent since their debut, was accused in a civil lawsuit of violating securities laws and improperly selling shares to customers.

the Escala Group received a formal order of investigation from the Securities and Exchange Commission. The New York-based collectables company said it would cooperate in the investigation, which it believes is related to Escala Group's transactions with Afinsa Bienes Tangibles of Madrid.
A Delaware judge refused on Monday to dismiss a lawsuit accusing Cox Communications and Comcast of unfairly manipulating the fortunes of At Home, an Internet service provider that went bankrupt.

Bank of China, two weeks after pulling off the biggest initial share sale in six years, plans to raise a record 20 billion yuan ($2.5 billion) at home, testing confidence in the Shanghai stock market.Bank of China, the second-biggest bank in China, made an application to the regulator on Monday to sell as many as 10 billion A shares to be traded on the Shanghai exchange. The sale is expected to be completed in the third quarter, President Li Lihui said in an interview in Beijing on Tuesday.
A bankruptcy judge Monday approved $41.4 million in expenses and fees for services provided by Delta Air Lines lawyers and advisers during the first 4 1/2 months of the company's Chapter 11 case.
Yukos released details on Monday of a plan to pay nearly $30 billion in debt as the struggling oil company goes into bankruptcy hearings.

Founded with much fanfare in 2001, as the honest alternative to traditional Wall Street research, Fulcrum Global Partners has shut its books and resigned from the National Association of Securities Dealers.

Even though General Motors lost $10.6 billion last year and faces a particularly uncertain future, its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, will undoubtedly find plenty of good news to talk about at its annual shareholders' meeting in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday.

At the start of the year, Russian companies had high hopes of raising billions of dollars in stock offerings by tapping into investors' zeal for emerging markets. Twenty-five initial public offerings were planned - nearly twice the number of 2005.

Two and half years after Parmalat collapsed in one of the worst accounting scandals in corporate history, preliminary hearings opened behind closed doors Monday against 64 individuals accused of bringing the dairy giant down under 14 billion euros ($18 billion) in hidden debt.

The Bawag PSK Bank of Austria will pay at least $675 million to avoid prosecution and to settle bankruptcy claims after admitting its role in the collapse of the commodities brokerage firm Refco, American authorities announced yesterday.
Trimaran Capital Partners is looking to take a ride on another train services company after taking Freightcar America public last year.
Two buyout firms, Bruckmann Rosser Sherrill and Castle Harlan, are going out on a second date, agreeing to buy a casual Italian dining chain, Bravo Development, from its family owners.
Success in real estate, they say, depends on location, location, location. In Las Vegas, it's also timing, branding and lots of cash.

BAA, the world's biggest airport owner, accepted a sweetened 10.3 billion pound ($19 billion) bid from Spain's Grupo Ferrovial and rejected a higher proposal from a team led by the Goldman Sachs Group.

Wikia, a for-profit company founded 18 months ago by Wikipedia's founder, Jimmy Wales, hired eBay veteran Gil Penchina as its chief executive on Monday. Mr. Penchina, who worked at the online auction site for eight years, served as vice president and general manager at eBay.
Can investing in a fledgling fashion house reap profits?
Jack in the Box has no immediate plans to spin off its fast-growing Qdoba Mexican Grill chain, but the company would consider such a move in the future, the chief executive, Linda Lang, said Monday.

Merchants suing Visa International and MasterCard International in an antitrust suit may ask a federal judge in New York to undo MasterCard's $2.39 billion initial public offering last month, a lawyer said.

The banking powerhouse UBS made a last-minute bid on Monday to keep secret the trial of a former employee accused of trying to cripple the firm's computer systems and then profit from the resulting carnage.
Wedding resource firms the Knot and WeddingChannel.com said Monday that they have entered into a definitive merger agreement.
Wine and beer company Constellation Brands said on Monday it had completed its acquisition of a Canadian winemaker, Vincor International, for 1.23 billion Canadia dollars, or about $1.09 billion.
American Medical Systems Holdings said Monday it has agreed to buy rival Laserscope for $715 million to expand in the urology products market.
Disgruntled Eurotunnel bondholders have written to company chairman Jacques Gounon accusing him of selling the business by the back door, The Telegraph reported.
The Canadian mining company Inco said Monday in a filing with securities regulators in the United States that it is in talks to try to find a business partner other than hostile bidder Teck Cominco.
The financial services group Prudential is in talks to sell its private equity division, PPM Capital, to the company's management team, according to The Telegraph.

A group of Alex. Brown veterans that includes the former head of Deutsche Bank's United States equities unit, David DiPietro, are in the process of building a full-service investment-banking boutique modeled after the old Alex. Brown.
Kinder Morgan's $13.5 billion management-led buyout is being challenged by two state court lawsuits that seek to block the deal.
Travel photographers say amateurs can significantly improve their travel photos by adding a few pro-style items to a camera bag.

As regulators weigh the many elements of AT&T's proposed $89 billion acquisition of BellSouth, they are being asked to consider one more: allegations that the two phone giants turned over call records to the National Security Agency.

Serbian lawmakers proclaimed their republic a sovereign state in response to Montenegro's decision to secede from their union and dissolve the last remnant of what was once Yugoslavia. Minutes after the vote, the Serbia-Montenegro flags were removed from the Parliament building. Under the union's Constitution, Serbia inherits membership in the United Nations. Montenegro's president, Filip Vujanovic, sent a letter to Secretary General Kofi Annan asking that his new state be admitted as a United Nations member.

Liberia began recruiting women into its new postwar army. The army will initially number 2,000 troops, and roughly 400 of them will be women. Recruiting for the new army, which began in January, had previously been open only to men, and yesterday, dozens of women lined up outside a military barracks in the capital, Monrovia, to sign up. Officials say the drive to recruit women is part of the broader national goal of ensuring gender balance under President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.

A 21-year-old man pleaded guilty and will serve at least five years in prison for his role in a cluster of arson cases in 2004 at a new subdivision in southern Maryland. In a deal with prosecutors, the man, Michael M. Everhart of Waldorf, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit arson. Mr. Everhart agreed to testify against Roy T. McCann, 23, the sole remaining defendant among five young men accused of setting the fires. The blazes destroyed or heavily damaged more than two dozen unoccupied houses at the Hunters Brooke subdivision in Indian Head, about 25 miles south of Washington.

A pilot suffering a heart attack made an emergency landing on a highway on Sunday, saving his three passengers shortly before he died. The pilot, Jack Francis, 61, had taken off from Jackpot, Nev., and was headed home with his wife and another couple when he suffered a heart attack, said a spokesman for the Utah Highway Patrol. He landed the single-engine Cessna 185 on Utah 30 near Park Valley. The plane went off the highway and struck a fence before coming to a stop, but the passengers were not injured.

The Department of Justice said it would monitor primary elections today in seven counties to make sure officials adequately served voters who did not speak English. The counties are required to provide election information, ballots and voting assistance information in one or more minority languages under the 1965 federal Voting Rights Act. In San Diego County, for instance, officials settled a federal lawsuit in 2004 by agreeing to provide voting materials in Spanish, Tagalog and Vietnamese, along with poll workers who can translate in those languages.

The State Senate gave final approval to a strict abortion ban, and Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco was expected to sign the measure. The bill would ban nearly all abortions in the state, but it would take effect only if the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade, the ruling establishing a constitutional right to abortion, or if the Constitution was amended to allow states to ban abortion. Under the measure, doctors found guilty of performing abortions would face up to 10 years in prison and fines of $100,000. Originally, the bill would have allowed abortions only to save the life of the pregnant woman. The House added a provision to allow abortions in cases involving permanent harm to the woman's health.

The father of a marine killed in Iraq filed a lawsuit against a fundamentalist splinter group from Kansas that picketed his son's funeral, claiming the group defamed the family and invaded its privacy. The federal suit by Albert Snyder seeks unspecified damages. The suit lists as defendants Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka and unnamed members who picketed at the March funeral of Lance Cpl. Matthew A. Snyder, 20, in Westminster, Md. Members of Westboro, who are not affiliated with the mainstream Baptist church, assert that the military condones homosexuality and picket at military funerals across the country.

GADSDEN--Marie ''Polly.'' Of Pelham Manor, NY at home on June 1, 2006. Widow of Charles C. Survived by six children, eight grandchildren & many friends. Former director of the Pelham Public Library. Memorial service June 10, 11 AM, Christ the Redeemer Church, Pelham, NY.

To the Editor: I disagree with Maureen Dowd (''Teaching Remedial Decency,'' column, June 3): a refresher course in American ''core values'' is precisely what the American troops -- and the American people -- need at this point. Unless we demonstrate that we live by our own rules -- the values and ethics that made this country uniquely admired throughout the world and that make it possible to win moral arguments -- we are going to be defeated by the Islamic fascists, for they will have exposed us to the rest of the world as hypocrites.

MOSCHETTA--Mary Carolan on June 4, 2006 of Great Neck, NY. Beloved mother of Phil (Jeanette), Ronald (Rosemarie) & Paul (Jeanette). Loving grandma of Wendi, Ali, Kristie, Rider, Jaclynn, Isabella, Nicole and Jarrett. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass 9:45AM Wednesday at St. Aloysius RC Church, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers a donation to St. Aloysius Church would be appreciated.

To the Editor: I was bemused by Harriet Brown's ''Food Police'' essay. While she may want her children lulled into a midday food coma with an extra slice of pizza, many other parents want their children to get the mental and physical edge provided by a side of fruits or veggies. Here's hoping that other school districts have the gumption to put education into their cafeterias. Lisa Flythe Brooklyn

An obituary on May 27 about the former tennis star Ted Schroeder misstated the university affiliation of Jack Kramer, with whom he won three United States men's doubles championships. Mr. Kramer attended Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., not Stanford University.
To the Editor: ''A Hard Look at Haditha'' (editorial, June 4) was a useful insight into the horror of what took place in Haditha, Iraq, last Nov. 19. Nothing less than a full inquiry is necessary.

A picture caption on Sunday, on the front page in some copies and in the Metro section in others, about preparations for the Belmont Stakes misstated the location of Belmont Park racetrack. It is in Elmont, N.Y., not Floral Park.

BALLINGER - Iris. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. Viewing Friday June 9, 5PM to 9PM. Service Saturday at 10AM at RossRoden Funeral Service, 725 Gun Hill Road, Bronx. Interment Kensico cemetery.

WEST--Mary Louise Stillman, 91. Died peacefully at home June 2nd. Predeceased by daughter Sarah West and husband James W. West. Survived by daughter Susan, son - in - law Donald Ross, grandchildren Fraser, James (Sarah) and two beloved corgis. Memorial Mass Tuesday June 6th, 11:30am at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave at 71st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Animal Medical Center, NYC.

To the Editor: Re ''Well-Intentioned Food Police May Create Havoc With Children's Diets'' (Essay, May 30): In some ways, this society's parental approach to weight-related issues is no different from its approach to soccer games: screaming from the sidelines, barking orders, humiliating children. Thank goodness the writer, Harriet Brown, knows better. If I were an overweight child (and I was) and my school got on me about my weight (never mind all the kids who never cease to remind you every day how fat you are), I would be resentful and angry. And guess what that causes? You got it: overeating.

An article in Sunday Styles this week about plans by the singer Rufus Wainright to recreate a 1961 performance by Judy Garland next week at Carnegie Hall referred incorrectly to her death. She died on June 22, 1969, not on ''the night of the Stonewall riots.'' (A memorial was held for her on June 27, the first night of the clash, which ushered in the gay rights movement.)

DOBRER--Annette. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Mother of Marilyn Piken, Georgia Kramer, and her husband Nat. Grandmother of Lisa and Tom Piken, Cheryl and David Kramer, and his wife Jody. Great grandmother of Justin and Caroline. Sister of Bernard Hoffman. She enriched the lives of many with her warmth and love, and will be dearly missed.

To the Editor: Thank you for the wise essay on the well- intentioned ''food police.'' I retired last year after 40 wonderful years of teaching in public elementary schools. I have seen firsthand the damage done to children, especially girls, through all the obesity hype. Some sneak and hide during lunch to avoid getting caught not eating; some diet constantly. Some say their parents pay them $1 for every pound they lose. All of it is well intentioned, but dangerous.

BECKWITH--Lewis, D.O. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our longtime member, Dr. Lewis Beckwith, husband of Sue Beckwith. Condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce Block, Rabbi George Bean and Janene Edlin, Presidents

JONES--Clinton R. The entire Bard community mourns the death of Clinton R. Jones, Class of 1938, loyal alumnus, former trustee, and trustee associate. His service to and love of Bard was unwavering and unequaled. As a member of the Episcopal clergy, he was a pioneer in the promotion of tolerance and understanding on matters of race and sexual preference. We will miss this truly enlightened and supportive leader. Charles P. Stevenson, Jr. Chairman of the Board of Trustees David E. Schwab II Chair Emeritus Leon Botstein, President
MINIFIE--Frances T.J. 89, died May 31, 2006, in Newport, R.I. Wife of the late Benjamin Minifie. Her Memorial Service Saturday June 10 at 11 A.M. in Emmanuel Church, 42 Dearborn St, Newport, R.I.

To the Editor: ''Remaking the Memorial Foundation'' (editorial, June 1) claims that our building the 9/11 museum ''is an afterthought that has never been vetted publicly.'' The idea of a memorial museum emerged from public input and has been an integral component of the memorial project at ground zero since the selection of Daniel Libeskind's master plan.

A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about Suki Schorer, of the School of American Ballet, referred incorrectly to her position. She is a dance teacher and coach, not a choreographer.

To the Editor: While the column ''A Case in Point for the Maxim 'Do No Harm' '' (May 30) tells the cautionary story of one patient, it would be a disservice, and perhaps would do harm, to leave the impression that treatment harms people with borderline personality disorder. This disorder is estimated to afflict 2 percent of the American population. To counter the column's example of a woman whose illness unfolded in middle age and who seemed to worsen in treatment, I can cite many examples of adults whose lives were threatened by the self-destructiveness of this condition and who were helped by treatment to move on to fully satisfying lives.

GEIST--Helen Bowers. Died June 4, 2006 in NYC. Beloved mother of Ellen Geist Van Beuren and Bradley B. Geist, beloved grandmother of Bradley B. Geist, Jr., Tyler Geist Duer and Nicholas Van V. Geist and great-grandmother of Avery S. Duer and Nancy L. Duer. A service will be held on Wednesday, June 7, 2006 at St. James Church, 72nd & Madison Ave at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to St. James Church will be greatly appreciated by her family.

To the Editor: While Harriet Brown makes a compelling case against intrusions by the ''food police,'' she has confused the issue when it comes to banning nuts. Peanuts present a lethal threat to those people who suffer from a peanut allergy. Even a trace of the peanut allergen, whether airborne, ingested or topical, can lead to anaphylactic shock, which can be fatal to a person allergic to peanuts. Educating the public about the serious nature of peanut allergies is an enormous task that can be met with hostility when schools limit or prohibit consumption of peanut products.

The first proof of Alay Soler's command Monday night arrived early. Soler got Rafael Furcal, the Dodgers' leadoff batter, to ground out to shortstop, a simple 6-3 in the scorebook but a commendable feat for someone whose first two starts have been marred by dreadful first innings. Soler coasted through the rest of that inning, and the next, and the next, and four more after that. He departed after Furcal grounded out to shortstop again in the seventh, providing a beautiful symmetry to his first major league victory.

From the Fed Chief, Tough Talk About Inflation In his toughest comments yet about inflation, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said consumer prices were rising faster than he would like. Investors began selling stocks, and the Dow industrials and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index each fell about 1.75 percent. To the Editor: Re ''Divide and Conquer the Voters'' (editorial, June 5): President Bush's message regarding gay marriage is as tired as the rest of his administration.

To the Editor: Re '' 'A Little Sting' Can Become a Debilitating Injury'' (Cases, May 30): I read with interest the writer's account of her phlebotomy. As with much of medicine, and life, there is no free ride. We constantly weigh the benefits and risks of anything we do. Phlebotomy probably tops out on the risk-benefit ratio. Merle Myerson, M.D. Scarsdale, N.Y.

An article on Sunday about renewed interest in French language and culture in Maine misidentified the academic affiliation of Yvon Labbé, who said French-American dialect differs from the modern Parisian variety. He is affiliated with the University of Maine, not Southern Maine. Because of an editing error, the article misstated the name of the institution he heads. He is director of the Franco-American Center, not French-American Center.

To the Editor: Re ''Spelling Champion Crowned'' (news item, June 2): Watching the finale of the Scripps National Spelling Bee was deeply depressing. It was a sad spectacle to watch eager children reciting the correct spelling of words that are ridiculously arcane and utterly useless in the course of human events and often purloined from other languages far afield from English.

To the Editor: Re ''Bush to Press for U.S. Ban on Same-Sex Marriage'' (news article, June 3): The federal budget is suffering from the weight of uncontrolled spending and huge deficits; the war of choice in Iraq is a mess; the war of necessity in Afghanistan is faltering; and Congress still can't effectively police its own ethics.

To the Editor: Re ''For New Jersey 8th Grader, 'Ursprache' Means Fame'' (news article, June 3): We have come a long way in internationalizing languages. The winner of this year's national spelling bee won by correctly spelling the German word Ursprache, while the German word Weltschmerz eliminated the runner-up. Granted that these words are listed in our dictionary, as are words from many other foreign languages, but to take those words that are pronounced with the language of origin is a bit inappropriate, as it requires the contestant to identify the language and then know the nuances of its pronunciation, as was the case with Weltschmerz.

The Getty Foundation, whose spending is being investigated by the California attorney general's office, will soon expand its Web site to include much more information about the way it operates, including the salaries of top executives, officials said. Although much of the information is publicly available because the Getty is a tax-exempt nonprofit foundation, the Web site (getty.edu) will bring many of the foundation's financial documents together in one place as a way of ''increasing our transparency and openness,'' said Ron Hartwig, the foundation's spokesman. In February the foundation's president, Barry Munitz, resigned under pressure amid growing questions about his improper use of the trust's money. He was not given a severance package and was required to repay the trust $250,000 to settle questions about his expenses and travel. Mr. Hartwig said the foundation's board had decided to revamp the Web site as part of an overall plan ''to strengthen existing policies and create in some cases new policies designed to guard against issues that we've been dealing with over the past couple of years on the management side.'' RANDY KENNEDY

10 P.M. (Oxygen) THE JANICE DICKINSON MODELING AGENCY -- She was the comic relief on ''America's Next Top Model,'' the acidic chaser to Tyra Banks's gooey earnestness. That is, until her tongue got the best of her. In this new series, the officiously outspoken Ms. Dickinson (above, at a Girls Rock Fashion Show in Los Angeles last month) finds out if she can do any better as a model scout than her former employer. 9 P.M. (A&E) DOG THE BOUNTY HUNTER -- You never know who your next victim is going to be, or where you're going to find her. This week, the scary looking Dog and Beth go after Lisa, their fugitive housekeeper, in this reality series about a God-fearing father of 12 and reformed ex-convict turned bail bondsman. And then they shed a few tears 9 P.M. (Bravo) KATHY GRIFFIN: MY LIFE ON THE D-LIST -- The whining is starting to feel contrived. Still, with a rocky marriage, a dead pet, body issues and a pink slip from her red-carpet job, Ms. Griffin (right) seems to have a season's worth of grist left for her poor-pitiful-me shtick. And then maybe she -- and we -- can move on. 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) THE MOST EXTREME: GOURMETS -- No availability at Per Se? Then why not head to the wild where, according to this countdown special, the Top 10 chefs in the animal kingdom are concocting some pretty tasty meals. 9 P.M. (Food Network) TITANS OF TASTE: FAST FOOD KINGS -- No foodie delights here. Just unadulterated burgers and fries, drive-through windows and the car culture that turned them into a way of life. 10 P.M. (Style) WHOSE WEDDING IS IT ANYWAY? Talk about doing it all. A New York City woman with two children -- and a third on the way -- tries to plan her wedding while renovating her house. 10 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE -- The Fab Five hit the Las Vegas strip in three new episodes set amid the bright lights of perhaps the least tasteful of America's big cities. Among its tawdry masses: Max Clever (above, second from right, with Kyan Douglas and dancers), a fire-eating magician who wants to clean up his act for the sake of his artist wife (she makes G-strings for showgirls) and their Elvis-impersonating dog. 10 P.M. (WE) SUPERSIZE SURGERY -- For when dieting just won't cut it. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

To the Editor: Re ''House Plans to Call Gonzales to Justify Search of Office'' (news article, May 31): I am delighted that Congress has finally decided to push back against an overreaching executive branch, now that one of its own has been the subject of a court-warranted search.

A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday about the logistical problems of honoring about 70 employees of The Washington Post who have accepted buyouts misidentified one departing reporter. He is Charles R. Babcock, not Chuck Babington. (A Charles Babington works for the paper, but is not leaving.)

To the Editor: The massacre at Haditha was unconscionable, and we wonder what makes these young soldiers so impervious to their abhorrent conduct. In no way am I condoning what they did, but we have to think a bit about what makes them act like that.

Danny Almonte and Monroe High School will play George Washington in the finals of the New York City Public Schools Athletic League playoffs Friday at Shea Stadium. Monroe advanced yesterday after beating Beacon, 5-0, to win their best-of-three series, 2-0. George Washington defeated Tottenville, 3-2, to win their series, 2-0. Monroe scored five runs in the top of the 10th inning, and pitcher Dawin Rivas went the distance to record the shutout. Rivas allowed two hits and struck out six. Almonte, now a senior, attracted national attention in 2001, when, after throwing a perfect game in the Little League World Series, it was revealed that he was 14 years old, not 12, the age limit set by Little League. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT (NYT)
CANTOR--Sol W. With loving thoughts of all your Sacramento visits. Our love to Muriel and her family. Doris and Bud

To the Editor: As an immigrant and a gay woman, I have never felt so sad, angry and humiliated since George W. Bush became our president. Twenty years ago, on receiving the honor of becoming an American citizen, I pledged ''allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.''

To the Editor: I told myself at the start of this war that history could not repeat itself with such exact insanity. But it has, and I was in physical discomfort just considering the Catch-22 that leads a marine to commit crimes on the scale of Haditha.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about a judgment of civil contempt against Amy Habie, the chief financial officer of the law firm of Boies, Schiller & Flexner, in a dispute between a gardening company she owns and a rival in Palm Beach, Fla., referred incorrectly to the terms of the sanctions. While she was ordered to pay a $500,000 fine and received 90 days in jail, the judge suspended the sanctions on the condition that Ms. Habie and her company commit no future violations of the court's orders

To the Editor: Frank Rich's trenchant ''Supporting Our Troops Over a Cliff'' (column, June 4) reinforces my conviction that President Bush's war legacy can safely be predicted to be, in baseball terms, ''Three strikes and you're out!'' The wars -- against the Taliban, Al Qaeda, Iraq -- have in common premature claims of victory and the fact that, years later, they persist with mounting costs in lives, treasure and national reputation.
ROSENSTEIN Dorothea Violet, nee Cohn 7/4/24--6/6/81 25 yrs have gone by & I am still extracting lessons you left for me to learn in my memories of you. There has come a time for sensible shoes. PEACE

Mrs. Tiggy-Winkle's Diet Q. A hedgehog is lurking in the nooks and crannies in my new rock garden in the Catskills. Is it going to eat my expensive succulent plants? A. If it really is a hedgehog, probably not, but it will happily go after many of the insects that might eat your plants, as well as things like worms, slugs, millipedes and caterpillars. Hedgehogs, which belong to the insect-eating order Insectivora, have long been lured to European gardens as pest-control specialists, even though they also eat some vegetable matter. However, they are not native to North America.

For the May ratings sweeps, ABC's full daytime lineup, which includes ''The View,'' was No. 1 among women 18 to 49, the demographic advertisers try to reach during the day. And for the network's soap opera schedule -- ''All My Children,'' ''One Life to Live'' and ''General Hospital'' -- it was the sixth consecutive sweeps period that ABC won in the 18-to-49 age group. Among total viewers ABC's daytime dramas delivered an average audience of 3.38 million, which was second to CBS's 3.88 million. CBS's ''Young & the Restless'' was the top-rated soap opera among 18-to-49-year-old women, but over all, the network tied with NBC for second place in that demographic. The History Channel's Memorial Day broadcast of ''Washington the Warrior,'' an examination of George Washington as a military leader, brought in 2.47 million viewers. Yesterday Nielsen Media Research did not release its overnight ratings for Sunday because of what it said was an error in processing them. KATE AURTHUR

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a renewed effort in New Jersey to legalize needle exchanges as a way of curbing the spread of H.I.V. misstated the H.I.V. infection rate among women in some copies. Thirty-six percent of the New Jersey residents over age 13 who have the virus are women; the infection rate is not 36 percent among all women in New Jersey.

To the Editor: Tell me, John Tierney, if you were an 83-year-old widow living on your Social Security in the same apartment, now rent-controlled, for 49 years, and the apartment became decontrolled, what would you do?

As men get older, their sperm deteriorates, a new study has found, and it is likely that the damaged sperm of older men is a significant factor in certain specific birth defects and in increasing the risk of abnormal pregnancies. Birth rates since 1980 have increased by 40 percent in men 35 to 40 and decreased by 20 percent in men under 30, according to background information about the findings, published yesterday in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

FED CHAIRMAN'S WARNING -- Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he was far less worried about signs of weaker economic growth than about the danger of higher prices. [Page C1.] STOCKS RETREAT -- Share prices had their biggest loss since January after remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman. The Dow average retreated 199.15 points, or 1.8 percent, to 11,048.72. A program is to closely monitor the drug's use. Tysabri, pulled early last year after only three months on the market, is marketed by Biogen Idec of the United States and Elan of Ireland. [C1.] STOP-AND-GO DINING -- Family-style restaurants like Applebee's and Outback Steakhouse are offering curbside dining, where customers can have meals delivered to their cars as they sit idling outside the restaurant. The new offering is a hit. [C1.] A.C.L.U. ASKS FOR MERGER DELAY -- The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Federal Communications Commission to withhold approval of AT&T's acquisition of BellSouth until it reviews allegations that the companies gave customer records to the government without warrants. MEETING -- Though General Motors lost $10.6 billion last year and faces a particularly uncertain future, its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, will undoubtedly find plenty of good news to talk about at today's annual shareholders' meeting in Wilmington, Del. PRINT -- In the matchup between the print and online versions of newspapers, signs of the Internet's ascendancy are growing stronger. McWEENEY--Marjorie L. On June 5, 2006. Funeral Mass Thursday, June 8th, 8am, Church of the Resurrection, Rye, N.Y.

To the Editor: Re ''Food Police'': I am so encouraged to hear a rational voice from the fat/food wilderness. As the mother of five, two of them regulars in the husky clothing section, I have had years to contemplate the best way to guide them. When one of them reaches for a third slice of bread at dinner, I ask him what he has had for veggies. The hand retracts, and he goes in search of something with color, knowing that if after having some of each of the foods his body needs, he's welcome to more of what it wants.

An events entry in the Spare Times for Children listing of Weekend on Friday for a benefit concert for Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, featuring Dan Zanes and Brooklyn Friends, misstated the organization's Web address. It is www.dddb.net, not ddb.net.

''What is important is that when I have the diary in my hands, I feel I am holding the soul of my daughter.'' DOAN NGOC TRAM of Hanoi, on the return of her daughter's diary, decades after her death in the Vietnam War. [A8]
LIPMAN--Roberta. Missed, loved and remembered by us all. You are always in our hearts. Larry, Beth, Reed, Samara, Paige and Donna

An article on May 27 about a decision by New York City lawyers not to file criminal charges against an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who released the brake on an empty school bus, which then rolled down the street and fatally struck an 8-year-old girl, referred imprecisely to his custody arrangements. After a hearing at which the lawyers announced their decision, the boy was transferred to the custody of the Administration for Children's Services. Initially, after his arrest, he had been held by the Department of Juvenile Justice.

To the Editor: Re ''Delusions of the Rich and Rent-Controlled'' (column, June 3): I'll buy John Tierney's contention that he and Nora Ephron should be paying a lot for deluxe apartments. But where the end of rent control destroys lives is when ordinary people on ordinary salaries are suddenly forced out of apartments they have lived in for decades -- because the rent suddenly goes through the roof.

RAMOT--Bracha, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with sorrow the passing of a distinguished researcher and clinical expert in hematology and oncology, who received her early training in hematology at our institution, in the laboratory of our founding chairman of medicine, Irving M. London, M.D. At the time of her death, Dr. Ramot was Emeritus Professor of Medicine at the Sackler School of Medicine of Tel Aviv University in Israel. In 2001, she was awarded the Israel Prize in Medicine. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

To the Editor: Two articles in your May 30 edition call to mind the same issue. Although name fluency may predict an initial price increase of a stock (''What's in a Name? Researchers Suggest It's Money''), it can also decrease the credibility of poorly understood medical conditions like complex regional pain syndrome (''Doctors Struggle to Treat Mysterious and Unbearable Pain''), which are often dismissed as psychosomatic.

To the Editor: Re ''The Great Salamander Crisis'' (Side Effects, May 30): For 10 years, I have had a pet Xenopus laevis, a frog dismissed by the writer as ugly, flat and aggressive. While not as cute as the neotenous axolotl, he chirps like a spring peeper, amuses the cats and pretty much defines low maintenance.

We extend our sympathies to Donald's beloved wife, Robin; to their children, Miranda and Douglas; to Mary Ann and Arthur; & to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

An Op-Ed article on Friday, about Opus Dei, used an incorrect term in referring to the organization. In Roman Catholic nomenclature, it is a personal prelature, not an order.

To the Editor: Re ''Food Police'': Would Harriet Brown like ketchup or mustard with her lunch tray? Commenting on the decision to limit elementary school students to one slice of pizza, she writes, ''If equity is the issue, I'll eat my lunch tray.'' At our school, the decision, made at a parent-teacher meeting, was 100 percent an equity issue. It came months before the school district made its announcement.

An alcoholic drink a day can significantly reduce the risk for heart disease in men, a new study finds, but women get almost the same benefit with only one drink a week. The report, which appears online in the British medical journal BMJ, suggests that for women, alcohol intake is the primary protective factor, while for men, it is drinking frequency.

GOREN--Shelley S. A devoted and adored husband of Beatrice, on June 4th. Father of William, Roger, Irene Burg and Nance Nadel, grandfather, great-grandfather. $(6$)GOREN--Shelley. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its Honorary Chairman and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

ELEY-HANDLER--Jennifer.The Long Island Philharmonic mourns the loss of our long time friend, supporter and principal pianist. Jennifer's outstanding talent, loyalty and passion for the orchestra will be long remembered and appreciated. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband John Handler, her daughters Olivia and Emma and her sister Karen Eley. Larry Austin, Chairman David Wiley, Music Director
HANDLER--Jennifer. The Kings Point Civic Association extends profound sympathy to the Handler family. Jacques Kohanzadeh, Pres.
GOODMAN--Barbara. The New York Junior League and its Board of Managers mourn the death of Barbara Goodman, President 1968-70. Cynthia A. Cathcart, Pres. $(6$)GOODMAN--BARBARAST#

To the Editor: Re ''Food Police'': The writer is right to point out the futility of schools' policing what children eat. I commend their effort to minimize access to sugary snacks and soda, but taking such a policy to the excesses she describes makes absolutely no sense. I'd rather see schools focus on the real problem: the average child can no longer get enough exercise, whatever he or she eats, because of the professionalization of children's sports.

To the Editor: I have convinced myself that I am truly fair and impartial when I can agree with John Tierney. Rent control is the entitlement of the upper-income classes that send their children to expensive private schools from pre-K through to the Ivy Leagues. The apartments become a tax-free inheritance.

Hillary Rodham Clinton joined a chorus of critics today -- including relatives of Sept. 11 victims and Gov. George E. Pataki -- in denouncing Ann Coulter's comments about a group of activist 9/11 widows in her new book, "Godless, the Church of Liberalism."

I've spent the last two months mostly on the road, talking to audiences around the country about my book, "The Omnivore's Dilemma," and the questions it raises about how and what we eat. Most of the posts here on TimesSelect represent my thoughts in response to questions put to me by those audiences as well as readers of this site. Complicated as they may seem, many of the questions - Local or organic? Carnivore or vegetarian? - boil down to variations on the most basic question of all: What should we have for dinner?
This is the fourth in a weeklong series of columns on how genes move and change.

She wakes up at 7:30 in the morning. Her mother dresses her up and combs her hair, and then prepares her breakfast, usually a small cake and some tea and milk. She is only 6 years old so she is very much dependent on her mother. At 8:05, the bus rolls up and sounds its horn at the door; she runs to it and hops on. Her mother tells the driver to be careful because she heard that some gang kidnapped a girl the same age as her daughter only a week ago. The driver tells her that he will do his absolute best to prevent that from happening. The mother goes back into the house after waving to her daughter, praying for her safe return.

Last night, the NYSE Group announced it had added Société Générale as an adviser on its bid to buy Euronext, the pan-European stock and derivative exchange which represents the Brussels, Lisbon, Amsterdam and -- you guessed it -- French stock exchanges. "Société Générale is a major force in global financial markets, particularly in Europe," said Nelson Chai, chief financial officer and executive vice president, NYSE Group. (Société Générale will be joining Citigroup's Corporate and Investment Banking in representing NYSE Group in what the exchange was careful to label a "friendly transaction.")
Whew! The folks at AARP The Magazine listed theirfive best places for retirement and my town isn't one of them. Some nice places, though hardly any secrets.
Would you let your contractor use the bathroom? Nearly 70 percent of homeowners surveyed said sure, while 1 percent said no.

As he cleans out his desk, John Studzinski is also cleaning out his stock portfolio. Mr. Studzinski, HSBC's departing co-head of investment banking, sold shares in the bank worth 5.3 million pounds ($9.8 million), HSBC said Tuesday in a Regulatory News Statement issued by the London Stock Exchange. Mr. Studzinski, who had been in charge of deal-making and equity franchises at the global banking giant, said last month he would leave for Blackstone Group, where he will build out the buyout firm's deal advisory practice.
Yesterday, Steve Minarik succeeded in his bid to push Bill Weld out of the governor's race. (Though he failed to push another candidate out of the U.S. Senate primary this morning.)

It is still early in the game, but attorneys for power company Mirant do not seem to have impressed the court with their lawsuit against NRG Energy, the company Mirant hopes to acquire. At least, that is the impression we got from a transcript of Tuesday's conference call with the judge overseeing the case. (For excerpts from the call, keep reading.)
The Times's George Vecsey explains why the way the American team lines up matters.

Maybe Jens Lehmann should have a word with Basil Fawlty. Just when England fans seem to have gotten the message about laying off the references to former enmities with their World Cup hosts, Germany's No. 1 goalkeeper was quoted today making the observation that the Germans have a leg up on the English because with their World Cup experience they "know how to do the job better than England." Uh-oh.

Shares of L-3 Communications surged on Wednesday following the announcement of the unexpected death of the defense company's chairman and chief executive, Frank Lanza. The rationale behind Wall Street's rather ghoulish reaction: With no successor in place for Mr. Lanza, L-3 could become prey to acquisition-hungry rivals willing to pay a premium for its stock.

When Bill Weld entered the governor's race in August, he told me that his old friend Rudy Giuliani had urged him to run. Colleagues in the Reagan Justice Department, Bill and Rudy took office in the '90s as Republican mavericks cut from the same cloth -- pro-choice, pro-gay, tough-on-crime, unpredictable. After politics they did business together, with the former mayor advising an investment fund run by Mr. Weld and his former Leeds partners.

Some Americans who are just now starting to tune into the World Cup are asking where Freddy Adu went. Well, Adu, who turned 17 last week, is not on the team -- Bruce Arena deemed him not quite ready, and young Freddy might also have hurt his cause by airing his dissatisfaction with Peter Novak, his coach at Arena's old club, D.C. United.

Some former seatholders at the New York Stock Exchange are complaining that they are not able to cash in before the exchange's parent company, NYSE Group, goes through with its proposed acquisition of Euronext, according to TheStreet.com. The issue creates a difficult choice for N.Y.S.E.'s chief executive, John Thain, as he tries to gather support for the deal.

The Times's correspondent in Buenos Aires, Larry Rohter, writes in today's paper about the sense of dread among Argentina fans on the eve of the World Cup, given the albicelestes' disappointing performance in their last three appearances. This is a team that wears two world championship stars over its badge, yet expectations in Argentina are so low, as Rohter reports, that Julio Grondona, the longtime president of the Argentine Football Association, said last month: "I will be satisfied if Argentina makes it to the final eight. There is no obligation to come back champions."
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

May was rumored to be a rough month for hedge funds, and some recent figures suggest that the rumors were right -- although suggestions of a "May Meltdown" may have been overblown. The average single-manager fund posted a negative return of 0.9 percent during the month, according to early estimates from HedgeFund.net. It was the first down month in the past seven.
An ever-rising tide of sand has claimed grasslands, ponds, lakes and forests, swallowed whole villages and forced tens of thousands of people to flee China's Gansu Province.

Perhaps the most hostile of hostile takeover bids at the moment is Mirant's offer to buy its larger rival, NRG Energy. (In Sunday's DealBook column, we wrote that both power companies had "lost their marbles.")

K.T. McFarland told Republican party chairman Steve Minarik this morning that she was staying in the race for the G.O.P. nomination against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, despite Mr. Minarik's plea that she drop out.

BAE SystemsEurope's largest defense contractor, said it will force the European Aeronautic, Defence & Space Company to purchase its 20 percent stake in the planemaker Airbus after the two companies failed to agree on a price.
Here are several billion reasons why the recent string of big real-estate buyouts is probably not over.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 7 column, "A Well of Smiths and Xias"
The Times's Patrick McGeehan talks about a 17th century stone wall uncovered in Lower Manhattan. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

Unlike pop star Michael Jackson, who recently faced a financial crisis involving a hedge fund, Fortress Investments, Fortress's Michael Novogratz seems to be feeling quite flush these days. The New York Observer reports that Mr. Novogratz, who previously bought a 4,600-square-foot Tribeca triplex for $12.25 million from the actor Robert De Niro, has now acquired the unit directly beneath it for $5.3 million.
June 7 - The Department of Veterans Affairs reveals that data on nearly all active-duty military, Guard and Reserve members was on a staffer's laptop, stolen last month.

Now that he has been out of government for nearly four years, Harvey Pitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a radical idea for how to reform corporate America. In an interview with The Globe and Mail, Mr. Pitt said companies should put a big portion of executive compensation into escrow accounts, to be paid out after a scandal-free period.
From the deliciously funny Web site PatentlySilly: it's the cordless jump rope!
From the deliciously funny Web site PatentlySilly, it's the cordless jump rope!

Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that Jon Anda, who left the company in January to join a mergers boutique being formed by the veteran banker Joseph Perella, is returning to the global investment bank as vice chairman of institutional securities. Mr. Anda had been co-head of capital markets at Morgan Stanley when Mr. Perella, a prominent 1980's-era deal maker, lured him away to join his new boutique, which has not yet begun operating or announced a name.

Ace Cash Express, the largest operator of check-cashing stores in the United States, said on Wednesday it had agreed to be bought by senior management and a private equity group, JLL Partners, for about $420 million.

The media company Tribune has revealed an internal disagreement over a $2 billion share repurchase plan that is at the center of its strategy for raising its stock price. Opposition to the buyback, disclosed late Tuesday in a regulatory filing, comes from representatives of the Chandler family, which owns a 12.2 percent stake in Tribune through various trusts.

CKE Restaurants, the parent company of the Carl's Jr. and Hardee's fast-food chains, may consider selling its La Salsa Fresh Mexican Grills in the next three to five years after expanding the franchise and remodeling restaurants, its chief executive, Andrew Puzder, said Tuesday.
Tata Tea of India is scouting for more acquisitions in Europe and the United States to strengthen its position as the world's number-two branded tea firm, company officials said on Wednesday.
You would think that it would be easy to record whales on video underwater, but they have eluded underwater cinematographers for years.

The Harvard Crimson, where I spent a good chunk of my undergraduate career, did an amazing amount of work to report a profile of me. The reporter talked to a freshman roommate whom I haven't talked to for 20 years, to a former editor whom I haven't seen since high school, and to a bunch of fellow-journalists in college and at The Times. The profile is here.
A Spanish food company, Ebro Puleva, said on Wednesday it had bought the leading pasta company in North America, New World Pasta, for $362.5 million.

An investment firm seeking to push a takeover and eventual breakup of Vivendi the French telecommunications and media group, said on Wednesday it was no longer in talks with Vivendi, Reuters reported. The announcement was the first public statement by the firm, Sebastian Holdings, which holds a small stake in the company. Last month, Vivendi said it rejected Sebastian Holding's informal bid of more than 40 billion euros ($51.50 billion).

Newark Ay, FranceI had plenty of time to think Sunday night as I was in line to check in at Newark airport. The line wound on forever, and you had to traverse one maze of people and myriad velvet ropes for the privilege of having a security guard wave you into the real line that led finally to the check-in desk. Who knew Air India had such a devoted clientele for its overnight flight to Paris?
Novartis, the European drugmaker, offered to buy NeuTec Pharma for 305 million pounds ($569 million) on Wednesday to gain two experimental treatments for drug-resistant infections.
Merrill Lynch said Tuesday settlement talks have broken down in a lawsuit accusing it of discriminating against African-American brokers.

A law firm, Fox Rothschild, has just made it a bit nicer to be a lawyer starting out in the world, unless of course you work in their Atlantic City or Pittsburgh offices. The firm has increased its starting salary by $15,000 to $125,000 for the incoming class of first-year associates, an industry publication reported.

United States financial regulators on Tuesday sued a hedge fund manager for allegedly siphoning off $11.5 million of his clients' money and sending out fake statements showing that investors earned double-digit returns.
Bank of China, the nation's second-largest lender, increased the size of last month's share sale by 15 percent to $11.2 billion, making it the world's fourth-largest initial public offering.

Plans by the Ferrovial consortium to buy enough shares of BAA, the British airport operator, to stop a Goldman Sachs-led rival from breaking up its agreed 10.1 billion pound bid for BAA have been thwarted by a regulatory issue in Australia.

Digitalized files of information detailing Parmalat's relationship with its banks should clarify "the truth" of the dairy company's €14 billion ($17.9 billion) collapse, Parmalat's founder and former chief executive said outside criminal proceedings on Tuesday.

Christopher Cox, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the growing number of companies under investigation for possible manipulation of stock option grants was "of serious concern" to the agency.

The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that the Dubai Ports World row may have had an impact on investment flows to the United States from Arab countries, an increasingly important source of financing for the United States' trade deficit.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation media company, which owns almost 24 acres of South Boston Waterfront land, is dangling a choice incentive to a potential development partner: ownership of half or more of the prized location, consultants working for the firm said yesterday.

Lawmakers and a federal regulator criticized the ousted former chief executive of Fannie Mae, Franklin D. Raines, on Tuesday as a House panel aired government accusations of a six-year accounting fraud at the mortgage giant.

Shareholders of the troubled General Motors approved two proposals on Tuesday aimed at giving them more influence over the way directors are elected, the first time they have defied G.M.'s recommendations.

With the Senate expected to vote as early as Thursday on whether to repeal the estate tax permanently or to exempt more wealth and apply lower rates, certain families are watching with more than idle interest.
For two decades, as wealthy residents of both coasts have converged on Montana, buying chunks of its wide open spaces, Montanans have felt torn.
Two consumer chain auctions are keeping bankers at CIBC World Markets busy.

AirCell has won a coveted chunk of airplane-to-ground broadband Internet spectrum from the Federal Communication Commission, thanks to some last minute help from a private equity firm, Ripplewood Holdings.

Ideal Image Development secured $16 million in equity and debt financing from two nationally known investment firms. HIG, a Miami-based private equity and venture capital firm, led the financing, while Orix Venture Finance provided venture debt financing in the transaction, according to a release.
Opus Capital said Tuesday that the new firm closed its first fund, raising more than $280 million, up from an initial target of $250 million.
Canaan Partners believes its new India office, which will invest in early-stage Internet and wireless investments, may one day rival its Menlo Park, Calif., space.

Hynix Semiconductor, the world's second-largest maker of memory chips, and its creditors will sell shares and bonds valued at as much as $2.7 billion this month after the stock jumped sevenfold in the past three years.
France Telecom plans to sell part or all of its majority stake in its yellow-pages unit PagesJaunes, saying the unit is not part of its main strategy.

With talk of big bonuses for 2006 already swirling on Wall Street, investment bankers may find that a few cases of exceptional Bordeaux go well with a fat pay-check. The Berry Brothers wine-buying team has recently returned from Bordeaux and they say that there is little doubt that 2005 is one of the greatest vintages of all time: more structured than 2000, more concentrated than 1996, purer fruit than the 1990 and more classic and terroir-driven than the 1982.

Not many journalists become bankers. The two trades are too far apart, no matter how often they meet to swap gossip over lunch and drinks. But Bloomberg columnist Matthew Lynn says one reporter-cum-UBS-banker-cum-author is an exception to the rule, and a good one at that:
A bank known to high-net-worth individuals around the world, Credit Suisse is taking its brand of private client services Down Under.
Lunch, anyone?

Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecommunications equipment maker, has reached a preliminary deal to buy most of the assets of a smaller rival, Harbour Networks Holdings, according to executives at the two companies.

180solutions, which makes software commonly known as adware, has acquired Hotbar of New York for an undisclosed amount of money. As part of the announcement, 180solutions will be renamed after its consumer brand: Zango.
Yahoo is buying a 10 percent stake in Gmarket, South Korea's No.2 online retailer, giving it a foothold in one of Asia's fastest-growing e-commerce industries.
Unitab directors stand firm on a merger with Tattersall's as Tabcorp wrote to the company's shareholders urging them to accept a takeover bid of 2.1 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion).

Falconbridge has agreed to sell its Norway-based Nikkelverk refinery and other assets for $650 million, paving the way for regulators to speed up approval of its takeover by Inco, the companies said on Wednesday.

A utility operator, the Constellation Energy Group said on Tuesday it would explore selling 3,145 megawatts worth of gas-fired electrical generation plants as part of a strategy to focus on its coal and nuclear generation assets.
The pharmaceutical company Pfizer received bids worth more than $14 billion for its consumer products unit, which includes household names like Listerine and Sudafed, The New York Times reported.

UPDATE (Thur.)Midfielder Deco (PORTUGAL) has a muscle pull in his leg and is questionable for Sunday's opener against Angola.Forward Ronaldo (BRAZIL) missed the practice attended by 25,000 fans in Offenbach on Thursday with a slight fever. He is also recovering from blisters on his feet. He is regarded as probable for Tuesday's opener against Croatia.Midfielder Lionel Messi (ARGENTINA), who has missed the last three months with a thigh injury, has been declared fit for Saturday's opener against Ivory Coast.Midfielder Pavel Nedved (CZECH REPUBLIC) has a possible knee injury and is questionable for Monday's opener against the United States.Goalkeeper Andreas Isaakson (SWEDEN) has a concussion and will miss Saturday's opener against Trinidad and Tobago.Midfielder Michael Ballack (GERMANY) will miss the tournament opener on Friday with a strained calf.Striker Carlos Tenorio (ECUADOR) has recovered from his calf injury and is ready for tomorrow's opener against Poland.Defender Jacek Bak and winger Jacek Krzynowek (POLAND) declared ready for the opener against Ecuador tomorrow after recovering from illness (cold and allergies) and a thigh injury, respectively.Midfielder Steven Gerrard (ENGLAND), who has a stiff back, describes himself as "50-50" for Saturday's opener against Paraguay.Striker Johan Vonlanthen (SWITZERLAND) is out of the tournament with a torn hamstring and has been replaced by midfielder Hakan Yasin.Goalkeeper Oswaldo Sanchez (MEXICO) has returned home to be with his family following the death of his father yesterday. No word yet on when Sanchez will return.The four NETHERLANDS players fighting injury were declared fit and ready for the opener against Serbia and Montenegro on Sunday. Wesley Sneijder, Rafael van der Vaart and Giovanni van Bronckhorst, all with ankle injuries, and Philip Cocu (thigh), are back in the squad.Striker Sidney Govou of Lyon has replaced striker Djibril Cisse on the FRANCE squad. Cisse suffered a broken leg yesterday.

A Spanish property tycoon, Luis Portillo, laid the foundation Tuesday for what may be the biggest coup of his career with a deal by his Grupo Inmocaral for a 39.37 percent stake in Inmobiliaria Colonial that values the larger property group at 6.58 billion euros ($8.52 billion), including debt.
The cast and crew of "Spider-Man 3" took over the  Broadhurst Theater for a one-night-only performance.

Resolution, a British administrator of life insurance funds that are closed to new business, will pay 3.6 billion pounds ($6.7 billion) to buy the life units of Santander Central Hispano's Abbey National.

Intel is in talks with several private investment firms and rival chipmakers to sell all or part of its struggling communication-chip businesses in a single sale or series of deals that could fetch as much as $1 billion, MarketWatch said.

The struggle for control over stock exchanges took a political turn on Tuesday as President Jacques Chirac of France said that he preferred an all-European deal but backed away from the overt protectionism that has characterized French economic policy.
Walls are being dressed this season with bold patterns, often in bright colors.
Edible landscapes in the Hamptons, rooms streaked with sunshine, theatrical hotel rooms and more.
Knitting circles springing up around Manhattan and beyond are producing results that are anything but humdrum.

The famed money manager Mario Gabelli has cleared away another one of his legal challenges, but the world will have to wait until later this month to find out exactly how much the latest settlement will cost him. A few weeks after resolving a lawsuit filed by two of his earlier investors, Mr. Gabelli has settled with the Justice Department over claims that he set up sham companies to buy wireless spectrum from the government and then sell them at a profit.
Charlie Kent, golf pro, helps you drop the ball on the green with ironwood or utility clubs by Taylormade, Ben Hogan, Nickent, Cleveland and Ping.

Edward Lampert's sits on 5.8 acres with a deepwater dock. Steven Cohen's comes with a full-size indoor basketball court and an outdoor ice-skating rink. The one belonging to Paul Tudor Jones II looks like "a cross between Tara and a national monument."
Work crews and actors prepared for the Paper Mill Playhouse's production of "Hello, Dolly!"
The actress, who is nominated for a Tony Award for her role in "Rabbit Hole," answered readers' questions.
The renovation of the Museum of Natural History in Paris is the subject for this beguiling documentary by Nicolas Philibert.
Long Island wines are proving themselves worthy of respect: The best have a style of their own, leaner than the California wines with lower alcohol and higher acidity.
It is easy to think that all photo printers are the same, but now that digital cameras take really nice pictures, your shots should become nice prints, too.
The vagaries of light and positioning can turn even the most basic object shot into a shadowy mess. The Lowel Ego aims to prevent that.

HIGH-END inkjet printers have long been capable of producing photographs that match or surpass many qualities of chemically developed prints. But until now, the darkroom and its wet processing were the only way to make a popular type of print, those using glossy fiber-based photographic paper that had been air-dried.
Pressing a camera to your face and peering into its optical viewfinder is becoming quaint, if not antiquated, for a generation of photographers.
THE point of scrapbooking, besides preserving memorable objects, is to share the results with others.
Not only are memory cards less vulnerable than conventional film to exposure and other environmental pitfalls, but they also recover more easily from mishaps.
Amateurs can significantly improve their travel photos by adding a few pro-style items to a camera bag.
If every camera is essentially alike, what's left to attract buyers? The answer: specialization. Adapt or die.
Most used cameras on the market now offer all the technology most photographers need — at much lower prices than the newest models.
It's easy to think that the revolution in digital technology is over. Wrong. The revolution is taking off; it's just the boring part that's nearly over.

New Jersey State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr. captured the Republican nomination to challenge Senator Robert Menendez.

TRENTON, June 6 — When word spread that the State Legislature's two leaders had a plan for about two dozen of their colleagues to work this summer on ways to rein in the state's rising property taxes, it seemed that the state's most pressing political issue had taken center stage.

Residents of four Bronx neighborhoods who say their children developed leukemia or Hodgkin's disease from exposure to toxic chemicals in a nearby landfill have enough evidence to be allowed to sue the city, a state appellate court ruled yesterday.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine has used his broad power over the Camden Board of Education to strike down a contract for the school district superintendent, after reports raised questions about bonuses she had already received. The school board approved a three-year contract for Superintendent Annette D. Knox last week that would have paid her a salary of $193,000 for the 2006-7 school year and more than $208,000 by 2008-9. She also could have received a bonus of up to 10 percent of her base salary for meeting five performance goals. The governor rejected the contract on Monday, and the school board has scheduled a closed meeting tomorrow to discuss what to do next. Bart Leff, a spokesman for Ms. Knox, said she was unavailable for comment yesterday.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Alan J. Steinberg, a regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, announced yesterday that the city had received federal grants to study and clean up brownfields, land where contaminants are suspected or are actually impeding reuse. The announcement was made at Mariners Marsh Park, near the northwestern shore of Staten Island. A $200,000 grant will be used to clean up metals, cyanide and organic chemicals in the park, which once housed a steel mill and shipyard. (The cleanup will follow an assessment to be completed early next year through an earlier grant of $270,000.) Two other $200,000 grants will be used to investigate sites around the city that are believed to be contaminated.

The House Appropriations Committee cut Amtrak's federal financing for the next fiscal year by 31 percent, to $900 million. President Bush had requested the cut. The bill would require Amtrak to reduce spending on food, beverage and first-class services. The railroad had asked Congress for $1.6 billion.

High school criminology students working a fake crime scene stumbled across a real corpse on a field trip Monday to study forensics. The students, from St. Thomas Aquinas High School, were taken to a Fort Lauderdale park to look for clues at a mock crime scene where the instructor had planted phony evidence. The students found a man with his back against a wall.

A man was put to death by lethal injection for the 1992 ax murder of his girlfriend. The man, Timothy Titsworth, 34, was sentenced to death for killing Christine Sossaman, 26, as she slept in the bedroom of the mobile home they shared in Amarillo in 1992. Mr. Titsworth said he was high on crack cocaine when he struck Ms. Sossaman about 16 times with the ax. Mr. Titsworth was the 11th person executed in Texas this year. He was the 366th person put to death since the state resumed capital punishment in 1982, a total that leads the nation.

A gunman shot five people in a home west of Charleston before dawn, killing three people, the authorities said. The injured men managed to escape and run to a nearby house. A sixth person was also injured when he jumped through a window trying to escape. Sheriff Mike Rutherford of Kanawha County said the authorities were searching for a suspect, identified as Keith R. Jeffers, 20. The sheriff's department identified the victims as Dennis Lovejoy, 47; Amanda Ingram Walker, 31; and Gregory Childress, 46.

The White House threatened to veto legislation that would reverse the Bush administration's decision to impose contract terms on the nation's 14,500 unionized air traffic controllers. The bill, which is expected to come up for a vote in the House today, would send disputed aspects of the contract to binding arbitration. On Monday, the Federal Aviation Administration said it would impose the contract terms after 10 months of contentious bargaining, including mediation.

Chuck Yeager, left, the first pilot to fly faster than the speed of sound, has sued his four children in federal court, accusing them of diverting hundreds of thousands of dollars from his pension fund. The suit, filed Thursday, is the latest legal dispute between Mr. Yeager, 83, and his children. The fight began after Mr. Yeager became engaged to his second wife, Victoria Scott D'Angelo, said Mr. Yeager's lawyer, George A. Roberts. Mr. Yeager's finances had been managed by his oldest daughter, Susan Yeager, but Ms. D'Angelo feared he was being shut out of financial decisions, Mr. Roberts said. Mr. Yeager's children and their representatives could not be reached or declined comment.

Crews exhumed the body of the woman who was buried by the parents of a college classmate in a case of mistaken identity. A week ago, the family of the woman, Laura VanRyn, discovered that the severely injured young woman they thought was their daughter was actually her classmate Whitney Cerak. And Ms. Cerak's family learned that body they had buried in late April was actually Ms. VanRyn's, while Ms. Cerak was alive. A tractor-trailer had slammed into the university van carrying the two young women. Ms. VanRyn's body, exhumed from a cemetery in Gaylord, is to be reburied in Grand Rapids.
