The United States asked the Security Council to ease its ban on weapons sales to Liberia so that President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf could arm newly trained police and security forces as well as her own security detail. A draft resolution would exempt from the embargo all security and police officers trained since October 2003, as well as members of Liberia's Special Security Service. The Council imposed the ban in 1992.

Officials evacuated 11,000 villagers from around Mount Merapi as it shot out lava and superheated clouds of gas, the authorities said. The volcano's lava dome has swelled in recent weeks, raising fears that it could collapse and send scalding clouds of fast-moving gas and debris into populated areas. Activity has risen since a powerful earthquake struck the nearby Yogyakarta area on May 27, killing more than 5,500 people.

Two American soldiers were killed in a roadside bombing in Nangarhar Province, east of Kabul, a United States military spokeswoman said. A third soldier and an Afghan interpreter were wounded in the blast, she said. The military also said three American soldiers were wounded in a car bombing south of Kabul.

An armored car carrying a woman who had threatened to release videotapes said to show aides of the former Mexico City mayor and presidential candidate Andrés Manuel López Obrador taking bribes was fired on by gunmen, the authorities said. Three of her children were also in the car, but no one was injured. Coming on the day of the last presidential debate, the attack set off a storm of speculation about who was behind it and how it might influence the race. The woman, Celia Gurza, is the wife of Carlos Ahumada, who is in prison on charges that he paid bribes to Mexico City officials. In 2004, he released a videotape that appeared to show a close ally of Mr. López Obrador accepting a bribe. From prison this week, he said his wife would release tapes to reporters showing other bribe-taking, but after yesterday's gun attack, she canceled her news conference.

After days of intense negotiations with Parliament, President René Préval appointed a coalition cabinet that includes members of six political parties. Parliament, in which no party holds a majority, must still approve the choices.

A court in Toulouse ordered the state and the national railroad company SNCF to pay $80,000 to a Jewish family whose members were delivered to the World War II transit camp at Drancy, outside Paris, that sent Jews off to Nazi concentration camps. It was the first time that the state and the railway had been found liable for their role in the wartime deportation of thousands of French Jews. The suit was brought by two brothers in 2001. They were arrested by the Gestapo and transported to Drancy in 1944, where they remained until it was liberated by the Allies a few months later. According to the plaintiffs' lawyer, Rémi Rouquette, the court found that the state did nothing "when it had a chance to" and that the railway did not object and in fact billed the state for third-class travel although it used freight and cattle cars.

Ekene Ibekwe, a junior forward for Maryland, has withdrawn from this year's N.B.A. draft and is enrolled for summer classes, the university said yesterday. Ibekwe averaged 11.1 points a game last season and led the team with an average of 6.6 rebounds a game.

The Nets exercised the option on Coach Lawrence Frank's contract for the 2007-8 season, the team said yesterday. Frank signed a four-year, $10 million contract extension at the beginning of the 2004-5 season. This season, he led the Nets to a 49-33 record and the Atlantic Division title for the second time in three years. Under Frank, who took over midway through the 2003-4 season when Byron Scott was fired, the Nets have a 116-88 regular-season record. They are 12-14 in the playoffs, losing in this season's Eastern Conference semifinals in five games to Miami after eliminating Indiana in six games. After taking over for Scott, Frank won his first 13 games.

The Giants signed two players yesterday and officially placed wide receiver Jamaar Taylor on the reserve/retired list. The Giants signed running back Decori Birmingham and guard Kevin McAlmont and waived offensive lineman Tony Tella, who was signed last month during the team's minicamp. Taylor spent two seasons with the Giants and caught six passes for 146 yards, all in 2004.

An article in The Arts yesterday about the impact of new technology on the book industry misidentified the source of data on the decline of album and CD sales in noting fears that technology will have the same effect on books. It was Nielsen SoundScan, not Nielsen BookScan.

The ratings for the season finale of NBC's ''Deal or No Deal'' showed the remarkable strength of that game show. Its 90-minute denouement, which featured Celine Dion, delivered 18 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. By its final half-hour, an audience of 21.2 million had tuned in, 10 million of whom departed once ''The Apprentice'' finale began at 9:30 p.m. The fifth season of the Donald Trump show, which concluded with the hiring of Sean Yazbeck, brought in 11.2 million viewers. That made it the highest-rated episode of this edition, but it was the lowest-rated ''Apprentice'' finale, and in total viewers, CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' rerun (11.6 million) outdrew it. Despite the ''Apprentice'' lag, NBC easily won the night among adults 18 to 49 and total viewers. Elsewhere, the WB's critically beloved, canceled ''Everwood'' ended its four-year run with an audience of 4.1 million. KATE AURTHUR

To the Editor: As a co-founder of Generation Rescue, a national organization focused on the treatment of autism, I can provide a different perspective from Cammie McGovern's. She asserts that the hope of a cure of autism keeps parents from accepting their children's condition and implies that this may be behind the three recent deaths of autistic children at the hands of their parents.

To the Editor: ''Autism's Parent Trap,'' by Cammie McGovern (Op-Ed, June 5), will undoubtedly anger many newly minted parents of autistic children. And yet it needed to be said. In the almost 20 years since my own autistic son was born, I have never seen a ''recovered'' child. And yet what might have been a personal tragedy -- and is, for many parents -- turned out to be a treasure.

Pope Benedict XVI has elevated three New York City priests to bishop. The three -- Msgr. Guy A. Sansaricq, Msgr. Octavio Cisneros and Msgr. Frank J. Caggiano -- will serve as auxiliary bishops to Bishop Nicholas DiMarzio, left, of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, diocesan officials said yesterday. They will be officially ordained on Aug. 22. Monsignor Sansaricq, 71, who is originally from Haiti, is the pastor of St. Jerome's Church in Flatbush, which has a large Creole-speaking population. Monsignor Cisneros, 60, who emigrated from Cuba, is the diocese's secretary for priestly life and the rector of Cathedral Residence of the Immaculate Conception in Douglaston, Queens. Monsignor Caggiano, 47, a Brooklyn native, is the diocese's vicar for evangelization and pastoral life. MICHAEL LUO (NYT)

Robert De Niro has donated his vast movie archives -- 100 boxes of annotated scripts, notes and more than 3,000 costume items and props from ''Bang the Drum Slowly'' through ''Taxi Driver'' and, yes, ''Meet the Fockers'' -- to the Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The center, a treasure house of literary holdings, has already staked its claim on Broadway and Hollywood with acquisitions of the Stella Adler archives and the collections of film legends like David O. Selznick and Gloria Swanson. In a statement with the announcement of the gift, Mr. De Niro, above, a two-time Oscar winner (''The Godfather Part II'' and ''Raging Bull'') who has appeared in 67 films and directed two others, said he had chosen the Harry Ransom Center to make the materials available to students and the public. ''Ultimately that's what it's all about,'' he said. Steve Wilson, associate curator of the center's film collection, said the trove should be invaluable to scholars and actors alike. ''He thinks with a pencil,'' Mr. Wilson said of Mr. De Niro. ''Every page is covered with notes: what his motivations are, how to walk.'' And yes, he's talking to you. RALPH BLUMENTHAL

To the Editor: As the physician-parent of a person with autism, I feel a triple stress: dealing with a difficult child; feeling a professional defeat, as your own efforts at ''cure'' are failing; and feeling alienated from other parents because of the almost universal antagonism toward standard medicine by the autism parent community.

A front-page article on Monday about a lawsuit concerning the protective equipment used by workers at ground zero referred imprecisely to the contents of the breathing tanks that were supplied to firefighters. (The same error appeared in an accompanying illustration.) They contained compressed air, which includes oxygen; they did not contain oxygen alone. The illustration also mislabeled the central valve of the half-face air-filtering respirator. It was the exhalation, not inhalation, valve. A corrected version of the illustration is at nytimes.com/region.

Advertisers and agencies have started buying commercial time on the broadcast television networks for the coming season after one network, ABC, ended efforts to change which ratings would be used to set ad rates. The deals to buy spots for the 2006-7 season in the upfront market -- so known because it takes place ahead of the fall season -- are being made at a steady pace, agency and network executives said yesterday, in contrast to some recent years when demand for commercial time resulted in a frenzied seller's market.

Tomato vinegar, made from fermented tomato juice by Mutti of Italy, adds richness to salads and steamed fish and makes sliced tomatoes glow with flavor. It is $4.99 for 16.9 ounces at Gourmet Garage stores, $5.50 from chefswarehouse.com. Pesto, usually green, is ruddy red and has sweet intensity when made from sun-dried tomatoes plus Romano cheese and sesame seeds. An 8-ounce jar by Le Grand, a Canadian company, is $5.98. Le Grand also makes an earthy, slightly briny tapenade by adding sun-dried tomatoes to olives, also $5.98 for 8 ounces in mild and spicy. Both items are sold at Zabar's.

An obituary on May 1 and in late editions on April 30 about the economist and diplomat John Kenneth Galbraith referred incorrectly to his position with the United States Strategic Bombing Survey in 1945. As one of several directors of the effort, he oversaw a study of the economic effects of American bombing; he was not overall director of the survey. The error was pointed out by a reader in a letter dated May 22; the correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

To the Editor: I am the mother of a 9-year-old boy who received a diagnosis of pervasive development disorder, which is also another name for autistic spectrum. I have learned that parents can never try hard enough and must never stop their efforts slowly to chip away this tragic disability.
BUCKLEY--Neill, Of Wallingford, CT & NY, died suddenly May 27, 2006. Burial at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, June 7th. Great Poet. Fondly Remembered.

An article on Monday about the Church of St. Vincent de Paul in Chelsea, which the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has scheduled for closing, referred incorrectly to its celebrations of Mass. It is one of several city churches -- not the only one -- that offer Mass in French.

To the Editor: I am the mother of a 16-year-old young man on the autistic spectrum. Although I do not agree with Cammie McGovern's hypothesis linking parental determination to achieve a cure to the tragic events she describes, I know many parents, including myself, who have hung onto hope that a certain treatment plan or therapist or school placement will somehow result in making my son ''normal.''

An obituary on May 1 and in late editions on April 30 about the economist and diplomat John Kenneth Galbraith referred incorrectly to his position with the United States Strategic Bombing Survey in 1945. As one of several directors of the effort, he oversaw a study of the economic effects of American bombing; he was not overall director of the survey. The error was pointed out by a reader in a letter dated May 22; the correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

As I fought my way through the tourists shuffling toward Piazza San Marco the whirling gravitational center of Venice I came to two disturbing realizations: First, that I would soon have to fight my way back through the crush; and second, that whether I liked it or not, I was a tourist myself. For two days, I had been trying to assume the life of a regular Venetian, a more authentic and potentially cheaper way to experience a city that attracts some 19 million visitors every year. I'd already failed once, a week before, having fled Venice when I mistakenly booked a hotel in a distant suburb, Lido di Jesolo. But in Bologna, I'd begun to feel the pull of the Venice, and returned by train (7.90 euros) for this, the fourth in my series of weekly round-the-world Frugal Traveler columns.

It looks like a tiny Venetian carnival mask with a winsome smile, but the new stainless steel corn zipper, made by Kuhn Rikon, is an effective gadget for summer cooking. Knives can cut into the cob even when used by the steadiest hand, but the corn zipper's little teeth precisely separate the kernels from the cob so that they drop into a bowl. The corn zipper is around $11.95 at Broadway Panhandler, Gracious Home and at Art of Cooking.

The wayward Kansas City Royals chose a wayward pitcher of sorts yesterday when they selected Luke Hochevar with the first pick in Major League Baseball's first-year player draft. Hochevar, who was brilliant with the University of Tennessee in 2005, was drafted by the Los Angeles Dodgers last year and never signed.

To the Editor: I appreciate the grounding insight and message of Cammie McGovern. As the father of a 4-year-old child with autism, I have witnessed our family become consumed with the ill effects that this disorder can wreak on a family.

To the Editor: Re ''House at Stake, Midterm Election Gets Early Start'' (front page, June 6): President Bush, the G.O.P. and Christian conservatives are going to use the same-sex marriage issue as a diversion, a campaign tool and a wedge issue during midterm elections to invigorate their base.

8 P.M. (13); 9 P.M. (49) GEORGE GERSHWIN REMEMBERED -- The piano was bought by his parents for their eldest son, Ira, but it was George (right) who sat down to play it. This 20-year-old ''American Masters'' documentary heralds the talent of the younger brother whose musical impact belied his early death. 9 P.M. (Style) MY CELEBRITY HOME -- Check into a parlor suite at the Wynn Las Vegas and you'll get 1,280 square feet of opulence for about $700 per night. Shell out $3,000, like tonight's New Jersey couple did, and you can stay in a parlor suite, or something close to it, in the comfort of your own home for as long as you'd like. 9 P.M. (5) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Showgirl alert! The auditions land in Las Vegas. 9 P.M. (A&E) INKED -- It's not the sort of job you can entrust to amateurs. So Corey Hart makes a new employee clear some hurdles before he lets him pick up the needles in his Las Vegas tattoo parlor. 9 P.M. (IFC) WAKING LIFE (2001). A man (Wiley Wiggins, above) awakens in a dream he can't get out of, and everyone in it seems to have a theory about human consciousness. ''I believe reincarnation is just a poetic expression of what collective memory really is,'' says one. Another says, ''Your life is yours to create.'' Which Richard Linklater does time and again in his digitally animated ode to philosophical inquiry. 9 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES -- Chef Ramsay takes his bad attitude out on La Lanterna, a cheesy Italian hole in Letchworth, Hertfordshire, whose 28-year-old owner doesn't seem to have a clue. And what's with his car? 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) SPOOKED: GHOSTS OF WAVERLY SANATORIUM -- It's been called the scariest place on Earth, this former tuberculosis hospital on a hidden hillside in Jefferson County, Ky., where in 1928 some 65,000 people died. This supernatural exposé purports to talk to some of them. 10 P.M. (TV Land) TV LAND'S TOP 10: SPINOFFS -- Talk about family trees: ''All in the Family'' spun off ''Maude'' (about Edith's cousin) and ''Good Times'' (about Maude's former housekeeper). A one-time skit about a backwater sheriff on ''Make Room for Daddy'' led to ''The Andy Griffith Show.'' This episode celebrates some of the greatest television derivations of all time. 10 P.M. (A&E) CRISS ANGEL MINDFREAK -- He's no David Blaine. Still, there's a been-there, done-that sensibility to this new episode, in which the illusionist Mr. Angel (left) tries to walk on water. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

To the Editor: ''A Scientist's Book on Katrina Draws Fire at L.S.U.'' (Arts pages, May 30) has created the perception in some that Louisiana State University tried to limit Ivor van Heerden's access to the press and silence his voice after Katrina. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact, our media relations office still arranges many of his media opportunities.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the introduction of an online spreadsheet program by Google misstated the name of a company acquired by Google that created a Web-based word-processing program. It is Upstartle, not Upstart.

ALTHOUGH her spice-saturated food is rich in Turkish and Greek tradition, Ana Sortun, the chef at Oleana restaurant in Cambridge, Mass., does not pretend to have a sunny Mediterranean heritage. ''I grew up in Seattle,'' she said during a recent cooking session in Manhattan. ''My mother was a good, plain American cook. Most of the things I cook now, I had never heard of until I was almost 30.'' Oleana, which has become a Boston food destination since it opened in 2001, is an anomaly in the United States: a fine-dining restaurant that is influenced not by France, Italy or Asia, but rather inspired by the traditions of the Middle East.

To the Editor: While I agree with everything that Cammie McGovern writes, how many readers have noticed that almost all of the discourse on autism is confined to children of school age? Search the literature or the Internet, and it will be a rare occasion when you turn up any mention of autistic adults, their problems and their parents' problems.

ONCE a year, it seems, I go on a miniquest to find a ''new'' recipe for rhubarb. It isn't easy. There are very real limits to what you can do with a sour vegetable that doesn't really have much substance. And because there's not much in the way of either supply of or demand for it -- most stores stock a few stalks for a few weeks a year, and that's it -- the repertory doesn't seem to change much. You occasionally see rhubarb cooked with fish or stewed with sweet fruits to make a compote or, of course, made into pies, especially with strawberries, a wonderful marriage. But on a recent trip to England, where rhubarb is celebrated more than it is here, I was offered a preparation I had once loved but lost track of: rhubarb soup. This is an unexpected creation, but it makes perfect sense. When cooked with water, even for just a little while, rhubarb falls apart completely, thickening whatever liquid surrounds it.

While this photo of the wind turbine could have been shot on film, the main advantage of digital had to do with the ability to see the results immediately. I wanted an image that would pop with the brilliant late-afternoon sunlit whiteness of the structure accentuated against a deep blue sky. It was important to maintain tone in the highlights while saturating the sky.

A film review of ''District B13'' in Weekend on Friday reversed the description of two characters. Damien is the supercop; Leïto is the righteous denizen of a grungy Paris suburb. Screening information with the review referred incorrectly to its rating. It is R, not unrated.

Former Senator George S. McGovern joined the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, at City Hall yesterday to encourage more families to participate in a government program that offers free breakfasts to all New York City public school students under age 19, regardless of their family's income. Ms. Quinn, who has made fighting hunger a priority, said that fewer than 20 percent of the students had taken advantage of the free breakfasts, and of a program that provides free meals to students during the summer. Mr. McGovern is spokesman for a national ''Got breakfast?'' campaign. WINNIE HU (NYT)

Using a digital camera made it a bit easier to transmit this photo of Katrina's aftermath back to the New York office. I sent the pictures via my Wi-Fi card on my laptop. There was no electricity in the areas we worked in, and charging the batteries was done in cars and places that had a generator. Even so, I am still very much a film-and-paper darkroom person. I believe the quality is superior. But going digital has had its benefits: no mixing chemistry on a breaking story, no need for hot water or a darkroom to work in. It's just shoot, edit and transmit and on to the next part of the story until your hard drive is full. ANGEL FRANCO

The Saturday Profile, about Carlos Slim, a Mexican multibillionaire who ranked third on the Forbes list of the wealthiest people, misspelled the surname of the No. 2 person on that list. He is Warren Buffett, not Buffet.

DEVOTEES of the hobby known as scrapbooking spent an estimated $3 billion last year on patterned paper, ribbons, stamps, brads and fabrics. They also spent untold hours combining these things with family photographs to make personal albums. Claudine Jackson was one such person. But Ms. Jackson, an optometrist and mother of two in Carlisle, Pa., said she found that the hobby was taking too much time. ''When I get a half-hour, I have to move quickly,'' she said, adding, ''It would take that long just to get my materials out.''

To the Editor: Re ''On Route of the Impala, Signposts to Detroit's Decline'' (front page, June 3): When I bought my first Toyota Camry nearly 20 years ago, I had one major concern: If it broke down in an unfamiliar place, would mechanics know how to fix it?

In its efforts to crack down on secondary schools that give quick and easy grades to high-profile athletes, the N.C.A.A. has drawn up an initial list of 15 schools from which it will no longer accept transcripts. The N.C.A.A.'s plan was outlined in a document that was e-mailed to colleges across the country over the weekend. The list of so-called invalid schools will be made final by July 1. This would allow students who have attended schools under review to know if they could enroll in college this fall.

KAMPEL--Daniel. The Board of Trustees, officers and staff of HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, fondly and warmly remember Daniel Kampel for his devoted service as a Board member. Dan's passion for the HIAS mission was endearing and became a part of his core values. In addition to being extremely generous to HIAS he was also a consummate fundraiser for the HIAS scholarship program, which awards scholarships to gifted children of recent immigrants. We extend our condolences to his wife, Laura, and the Kampel family. Jerome S. Teller, Chair of the Board Gideon Aronoff, President and CEO

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Alan J. Steinberg, a regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, announced yesterday that the city had received federal grants to study and clean up brownfields, land where contaminants are suspected or are actually impeding reuse. The announcement was made at Mariners Marsh Park, near the northwestern shore of Staten Island. A $200,000 grant will be used to clean up metals, cyanide and organic chemicals in the park, which once housed a steel mill and shipyard. (The cleanup will follow an assessment to be completed early next year through an earlier grant of $270,000.) Two other $200,000 grants will be used to investigate sites around the city that are believed to be contaminated. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

ON FAITH -- The advantage of digital over film is the instant results. I can constantly check my aim and make minor adjustments. With film I can make adjustments, too, although with film I might have burned up a lot of it and still not have gotten the framing I wanted. This photograph was taken using a technique photojournalists call the Hail Mary. What I did to capture this photograph was put my camera about an inch from the ground. It was not at all close to my eye or face. A Hail Mary is usually a camera held far above one's head to take a photograph of something that cannot be seen standing at eye level. Sometimes a Hail Mary is taken around a corner you can't get your body around. OZIER MUHAMMAD

The good news for OLN was that Game 1 produced a rating more than four times above its regular-season average. The bad news was that the 0.9 rating was 23 percent lower than the 1.15 for Game 1 on ESPN in 2004. More significantly, viewership for the game fell 37 percent to 861,156. RICHARD SANDOMIR (NYT)

LAUTERSTEIN--Ronald. The Mailman School of Public Health is deeply saddened by the passing of Ronald H. Lauterstein, Class of '58, a beloved alumnus and esteemed member of the School's Board of Advisors. He died on May 8 , at his home in Toronto. An active participant in alumni activities and a major benefactor of the School, Mr. Lauterstein established the Lauterstein Scholars Program to support the development of aging policy and research. His wisdom, vigor, kindness, and compassion will be profoundly missed. On behalf of the Board, faculty, staff and alumni, we extend our sincere sympathies to Mr. Lauterstein's family and friends.

To the Editor: ''Move to Save Coral Reefs'' (editorial, June 5) correctly highlights the need to protect shallow water corals from damage by pollution, fishing boats and global warming. Most people would be surprised to know that shallow water corals encompass only 35 percent of the world's coral species. In fact, most do not need sunlight and exist in both cold and warm regions, including the North Atlantic, the Gulf of Mexico and the North Pacific.

A theater review on May 25 about a musical by Melvin Van Peebles, at T New York on West 52nd Street, misstated the title at one point. It is ''Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death,'' not ''Ain't No Time to Die a Natural Death.'' The review also misidentified the director of the original Broadway production. It was Gilbert Moses, not Mr. Van Peebles. (The error also appeared in a theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on May 19.)

Pentagon officials said Tuesday they would try to use only psychologists, not psychiatrists, to help interrogators devise strategies to get information from detainees at places like Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The new policy follows by little more than two weeks an overwhelming vote by the American Psychiatric Association discouraging its members from participating in those efforts. Stephen Behnke, director of ethics for the counterpart group for psychologists, the American Psychological Association, said psychologists knew not to participate in activities that harmed detainees. But he also said the group believed that helping military interrogators made a valuable contribution because it was part of an effort to prevent terrorism. NEIL A. LEWIS (NYT)

This is a digital image of Steve Duncan, urban explorer and historian, in the Old Croton Aqueduct in Upper Manhattan, on a ledge and board over the opening to the tunnel level. He brought his own lights because it is pitch black. For this, a digital camera was truly a miracle worker. I was able to see immediately if I had an image and especially to see if I had a sharp image. At times, in the dimly lit area, it was hard for the camera to focus. On a film camera, it would be hit or miss. It is amazing that there are images that could be taken under these circumstances. MARILYNN K. YEE

President Vladimir V. Putin spoke warmly on Tuesday of Russia's possibilities for cooperation with the United States, hailing a recent six-nation agreement on incentives aimed at defusing an impasse with Iran as a sign that the United States and Russia could still work well together. ''Although the views of Russia and the United States have not coincided on all occasions, we generally understand each other and, what counts most, are able to reach compromises,'' he said.

Calling a cheese shop Stinky Bklyn is cheeky. But Patrick Watson, above right, and Michele Pravda, who own this new store at 261 Smith Street (DeGraw Street) in Carroll Gardens, mean it with affection for the borough and the 100 or so cheeses they carry. The two, who also own Smith & Vine, a wine shop across the street, emphasize cheeses from wine regions, including California, the Loire Valley and Italy. They also sell charcuterie, chocolates and utensils: (718) 522-7425.

Senate Republicans, pushing once again to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, are split about whether to push for a full repeal that would probably fail, or seek a more cautious compromise with Democrats that could pass. Permanently repealing the estate tax, or what Republicans have branded the ''death tax,'' is a priority for President Bush and many Republican lawmakers.

In a case the authorities are seeking to connect to a retired F.B.I. supervisor, R. Lindley DeVecchio, a fisherman extradited from Florida was arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court on two counts of second-degree murder. The fisherman, Craig Sobel, 39, is accused of shooting Dominick Masseria, 17, on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights in 1989. Although Mr. DeVecchio is not accused of playing any role in Mr. Masseria's killing, prosecutors say he told a member of the Colombo organized-crime family that a man present at the killing was talking to the police. That man, Patrick Porco, was later murdered, prosecutors charge. Mr. Sobel has pleaded not guilty. MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

Not much went the Mets' way Tuesday night, the least of their problems being their 8-5 loss to the Dodgers. José Reyes did not start because of a sprained right wrist. Cliff Floyd departed in the second inning after spraining his ankle running to third base. Carlos Beltrán supplied a scare in the third inning when he lay in the Dodger Stadium grass for five minutes after making a stellar catch.

It took me five minutes to make a wild mushroom risotto using components from Really Cool Foods, 1059 Third Avenue (63rd Street). The risotto had excellent flavor, as did a seafood and andouille gumbo, thanks to the executive chef, Bill Valentine, who does most of the prep work at a commissary in Syosset, N.Y. For the six or so dishes I tried, each according to a recipe card at the store, one saucepan or skillet was all that was needed.

One major advantage of working digitally is the ability to proof as I shoot. Seeing what I'm getting as I get it allows me to make adjustments in exposure and technique based on what I'm seeing in each frame. This exposure was 19 seconds long, during which I walked around the subjects flashing them at close range about 15 times with a hand-held camera flash. TONY CENICOLA

An article on Saturday about Katharine Close, 13, the winner of the 79th annual Scripps National Spelling Bee, included incorrect information from spelling bee officials about her victory. She is the second New Jersey resident to win, not the first. (In 1971, Jonathan Knisely, then of Mullica Hill, N.J., won.) A related article in some copies misspelled the word that eliminated one finalist, Jonathan Horton of Gilbert, Ariz. It was sciolto, not cialto.

The man who managed investments for Ohio's $19 billion insurance fund for injured workers for nearly a decade will plead guilty today to federal and state charges that he traded investment contracts for bribes, his lawyer said Tuesday. The man, Terrence Gasper, will plead guilty in federal court in Akron to one count of felony racketeering, his lawyer, Terrence Grady, said.

Wynton Marsalis played the trumpet on Monday night at the Apollo Theater after a monthlong hiatus caused by a lip inflammation. The occasion was Jazz at Lincoln Center's fifth annual spring gala, which featured guest performances by Joe Cocker, Tracy Chapman, John Mayer, John Legend and Natalie Merchant. Throughout the evening Mr. Marsalis, right, the organization's artistic director, was onstage with his septet, which served as a house band. He joined his bandmates on a succession of background horn arrangements, including one for ''Unchain My Heart'' that featured Mr. Cocker. He also ventured a few brief solos, sounding less tentative as the night progressed. His most obvious exertion was on ''All Blues,'' a Miles Davis song that Mr. Mayer had chosen to perform. Last month Mr. Marsalis's injury caused the postponement of a concert with the Orion String Quartet that was to have closed Jazz at Lincoln Center's season. It has been rescheduled for Sept. 20. NATE CHINEN

More than 2,000 New York City school bus drivers voted overwhelmingly last night to authorize a strike beginning June 30 if no new contract is reached by then. The drivers, meeting at John Adams High School in Ozone Park, normally transport more than 30,000 summer school students each year. The dispute pits a coalition of two dozen bus companies against Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union. The main issues are health benefits and the union's desire to continue running its own health benefits plan. City officials say they are preparing contingency plans in the event of a walkout. The union local's three top leaders were indicted last summer, charged with cooperating with the Genovese crime family. STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT)

NEWMAN--Rosalind (Robbie). Died peacefully at home on June 3 after a brave battle with leukemia. A former Pan American airlines purser, she is survived by Fredric, her husband of 48 wonderful years; beloved children Amanda Crutcher (David) and William (Susan), and cherished grandchildren Jonathan, Jane and Nicholas.
MILLER--Leo. 85, died June 5, 2006. Beloved husband of Edna Miller and father of Lisa Beth Miller.

NEWMAN--Arnold. On June 6, 2006. Renowned photographer for 65+ years. He is survived by his wife, Augusta, sons Eric and David, grandchildren Mark, Sarah, Daniel & Emma. Services Thursday 1 PM at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue 30 W. 68th St.

LISA LEVY waited for years, her girlish hopes and dreams ever deferred, the shining prize just out of reach. ''I always, always wanted that KitchenAid mixer,'' said Ms. Levy, a pharmaceutical marketer who married in March and registered for and received a black five-and-a-half-quart model from Williams-Sonoma. ''I was afraid to buy it because on some level I believed I'd never get married if I did. That, the Cuisinart and the Dualit toaster.''

''We are ready to turn a new page with those who so desire it, and we will respond with force to those who want to pursue violence.'' NURI KAMAL AL-MALIKI, prime minister of Iraq, on releasing 2,500 detainees. [A1]

To the Editor: ''Guilt-free'' and some of the other terms Marian Burros uses in her article on fish that are safe to eat (''Holy Mackerel and Other Guilt-Free Fish,'' May 31) lead the average reader to believe the species on your list are not only safe to eat but harvested in ethically and sustainable fashions. Several of the species on your list are under tremendous fishery pressure, however, and well past what their populations can support.

TRAGER--Marlene M. 58, of East Brunswick, died on Saturday, June 3, 2006 after a long hard fought battle with cancer. Wife and best friend of Howard. Mother of Keith and Cathy Stoler, David and Samantha Stoler and David and Scott Trager. Sister of Richard & Marlene Fromme. Grandmother of Riley. Her wish was to have donations made in her memory to Beth Israel Medical Center, Attn: Head and Neck Cancer, C/O Louis Harrison, M.D., 10 Union Square East, New York, NY 10023

Joshua J. Sirefman, the Bloomberg administration official who has overseen redevelopment projects like Brooklyn Bridge Park, is now the interim president of the Economic Development Corporation, officials said yesterday. Mr. Sirefman, 38, Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff's chief of staff, was the chief operating officer of the development agency from February 2002 to November 2004. Mr. Sirefman, whose salary will increase to $178,162 from $157,500, succeeds Andrew M. Alper, who has just left the administration, while officials consider a permanent replacement. DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)

GODNICK--Martin.1928-2006. Beloved husband of 54 years, father of two and grandfather of 5, loved and adored by many, and who would eagerly give anyone driving directions, even if they didn't ask. An extraordinary man who loved life, and lived it with joy, passion and integrity. Truly one-of-akind. Funeral Services will be held on June 7th at 11am: Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills NY.

A theater review on May 25 about a musical by Melvin Van Peebles, at T New York on West 52nd Street, misstated the title at one point. It is ''Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death,'' not ''Ain't No Time to Die a Natural Death.'' The review also misidentified the director of the original Broadway production. It was Gilbert Moses, not Mr. Van Peebles. (The error also appeared in a theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on May 19.)

GADSDEN--Marie ''Polly.'' Of Pelham Manor, NY at home on June 1, 2006. Widow of Charles C. Survived by six children, eight grandchildren & many friends. Former director of the Pelham Public Library. Memorial service June 10, 11 AM, Christ the Redeemer Church, Pelham, NY.
SOKOL--Margaret McCor mack. 90, Sunday, June 4, 2006 in NYC after a short illness. Services private.

A 44-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday on charges of stabbing an Upper West Side couple in their apartment on Sunday, the police said. The man, George Borges of Prospect Avenue, was charged with attempted murder, burglary, robbery and criminal possession of a weapon. The police said he stabbed Saul Magzamere, 67, in the back and head and Claire Harnan, 61, in the arm and ribs after knocking on the door of their apartment at 120 West 97th Street and asking to borrow a pen. He robbed them of $300 and left, the police said. Mr. Borges, who has a criminal record, was identified by witnesses through a police file photo. Mr. Magzamere and Ms. Harnan were hospitalized in stable condition. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

HUNTING--Roger Bryant. Died in Richmond VA on June 3rd at the age of 85. He had previously lived in New York for 45 years where he practiced law with Greenbaum Wolff & Ernst and retired in 1992 after 8 years of service as a New York City Civil Court Judge. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and brother, he is survived by Betty Ann Grove Hunting, his wife of 35 years, daughter Barbara H. Bean, and son-inlaw Bruce W. Bean of East Lansing Michigan, and grandchildren Austin and Ashley Bean. He graduated from the University of Vermont and Columbia Law School, and served in the US army Air Corp on Guam during World War II. Former secretary of The Players. Memorial service arrangements are pending. Burial will be in New Marlborough, Mass.

Zadie Smith Novel Wins Orange Prize Zadie Smith's ''On Beauty'' (Penguin Press) has won the $56,050 (£30,000) Orange Prize for Fiction, Bloomberg News reported. The novel, the third for Ms. Smith, right, is a modern rendering of E. M. Forster's ''Howards End.'' ''This is a book which combines extraordinary characterization with skillful and seemingly effortless plotting,'' said Martha Kearney, the BBC news broadcaster who was the chairwoman of the judges' panel. ''It ranges from exposing the intimacies of family life to broader themes of aesthetics, ethics and the vagaries of academe in a literary tour de force.'' The Orange Prize, in its 11th year, is open to women whose novels are published in Britain and display ''excellence, originality and accessibility.'' Ms. Smith defeated a field that included Ali Smith (''The Accidental''), Nicole Krauss (''The History of Love''), Hilary Mantel (''Beyond Black''), Sarah Waters (''The Night Watch'') and Carrie Tiffany (''Everyman's Rules for Scientific Living''). New Free Public Library Downloads Film classics like Fellini's ''8 1/2'' and De Sica's ''Bicycle Thief,'' filmed stage productions like ''Hamlet and ''The Glass Menagerie'' and music films starring James Brown, Cher and Tupac Shakur are now available for free downloading by anyone who holds a New York Public Library card, the library is to announce today. The new service, eVideo, follows the library's establishment of other free Internet downloading services under the collective name eCollection. These include eBooks, eAudio and eMusic. The library said that since November 2004, more than 120,000 eCollection items have been borrowed. Up to 12 titles may be borrowed at a time. Items from eAudio, eBooks and eMusic may be kept for as long as three weeks; from eVideo, seven days. Information: www.nypl.org. Kimbell Museum Returns A Confiscated Turner The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth is returning a J. M. W. Turner painting to the heirs of a couple whose goods were sold at an auction of ''Jewish property'' by the Vichy regime in World War II France. The painting, ''Glaucus and Scylla'' (1841), which has been in the Kimbell's collection since 1966, will remain on view only through June 25. The museum said ''Glaucus and Scylla'' was being returned as a result of discussions with Alain Monteagle, who represents the heirs of John and Anna Jaffé, who were residents of Nice. Mr. Jaffé bequeathed the painting to his wife when he died in 1933, and when she died in 1942, she left it to a niece and three nephews, one of them the grandfather of Mr. Monteagle. The Kimbell said that the Vichy authorities had disregarded Mrs. Jaffé's bequest, seized the contents of her home in July 1943 and auctioned them in Nice, scattering more than 60 paintings and other works of art. The Turner painting did not re-emerge in any records until 1956 and was sold and resold through dealers until the Kimbell acquired it. Orchestra of St. Luke's Season Highlights The violinists Midori and Hilary Hahn, below, and the pianist Garrick Ohlsson will be among the guest stars in the 2006-7 season of the Orchestra of St. Luke's. The orchestra will play music from Henry Purcell to Arvo Part in sites including Carnegie Hall and the Brooklyn, Morgan, Chelsea and Dia:Beacon museums. During the season of about 100 orchestral and chamber concerts, the orchestra will make its debut at the Edinburgh Festival and the London Proms, in August, and its chamber music series will occupy the new Gilder Lehrman concert hall at the Morgan Library & Museum. Footnotes Sigourney Weaver will return to the stage next season, when she stars in the new A. R. Gurney play, ''Crazy Mary,'' at Playwrights Horizons. The play, about a mother (Ms. Weaver) and a son who visit a long-lost cousin at an asylum for the wealthy insane, is to begin previews in May. It will be staged by Ms. Weaver's husband, Jim Simpson, who directed her in Mr. Gurney's ''Mrs. Farnsworth'' at the Flea Theater in 2004. Cybill Shepherd will join the cast of the Showtime series ''The L Word'' when its fourth season has its premiere in January. Ms. Shepherd will appear in 11 episodes as a married woman with two grown children who begins to question her sexuality. For a third consecutive year, Brooks & Dunn will be the hosts of the Country Music Association Awards, Reuters reported. The ceremonies, to be televised by ABC, are scheduled for Nov. 6 in Nashville.

KALLENBACH--Susan Fran. Died on May 26, 2006 in New York City after a prolonged battle with cancer. Ms. Kallenbach graduated from Douglass College and received a Master's in Library Science from Drexel University. Ms. Kallenbach was a librarian and held management positions at the Van Pelt Library of the University of Pennsylvania and Bobst Library of New York University. She retired from NYU in 2000. Ms. Kallenbach is survived by her daughter Lisa and son Charles, and four grandchildren. A memorial service in her honor will be announced and held in the Fall. Memorial contributions can be made to the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, Division of Geriatrics.
An Associated Press obituary on May 20 about Lawrence Shurtliff, a longtime crew member for the Grateful Dead known as Ramrod, misspelled his wife's given name. She is Frances Whalen, not Francis.

An article on Saturday about Katharine Close, 13, the winner of the 79th annual Scripps National Spelling Bee, included incorrect information from spelling bee officials about her victory. She is the second New Jersey resident to win, not the first. (In 1971, Jonathan Knisely, then of Mullica Hill, N.J., won.) A related article in some copies misspelled the word that eliminated one finalist, Jonathan Horton of Gilbert, Ariz. It was sciolto, not cialto.

To the Editor: As Bob Herbert correctly notes (''Untapped Talent,'' column, June 5), our economy is changing in ways that put low-skilled individuals at permanent risk of financial insecurity. But in New York City as in Boston, the anticipated retirement of tens of thousands of baby boomers will create an unprecedented opportunity to move significant numbers of people into career-track jobs at family-supporting incomes.

An article in The Arts on May 30 about a legendary piano at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons referred incorrectly to the student a cappella group the Ultrasounds, an example of the school's vibrant musical life. It is coed, not all male.

Lethal Breast Cancer Likelier in Young Blacks Young black women with breast cancer are more prone than whites or older blacks to develop a type of tumor with genetic traits that make it especially deadly, a study found. The finding helps explain why black women are more likely to die when they get breast cancer. A map with an article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day last Wednesday about the commercial redevelopment of the Navy Yard in Philadelphia included outdated references to three stadiums in the area. Veterans Stadium was demolished in 2004; it has been replaced by Citizens Bank Park, used by the Philadelphia Phillies. Two indoor arenas have been renamed; the First Union Center and First Union Spectrum are now known as the Wachovia Center and Wachovia Spectrum.

One of the earliest theater buildings in New York designed especially for movies -- or ''photo plays,'' as they were called when it opened in 1914 -- was given landmark status yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Now a furniture store, the structure at Broadway and 135th Street was once the Claremont Theater and dance hall. It was designed by Gaetano Ajello and ornamented with a terra cotta movie camera on a tripod. Thomas Edison recorded Claremont patrons in 1915 in a short film that can be viewed at memory.loc.gov/mbrs/awal/4185.mpg. DAVID W. DUNLAP (NYT)

GUIDANT DOCUMENTS -- Newly released records show that Guidant was considering sending a letter to doctors disclosing problems about two of its defibrillators and saying that it had pulled back all units not yet implanted into patients. That letter, however, was never sent and more heart patients kept getting the devices. [Page C1.] ESTATE TAX STRATEGY -- Senate Republicans, pushing once again to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, are split about whether to push for a full repeal that would most likely fail or seek a more cautious compromise with Democrats that could pass. [C1.] DELL'S NEW APPROACH -- Dell said it would begin shipping an upgrade to its line of server computers in hopes of grabbing market share from Hewlett-Packard, the worldwide market leader. The upgraded systems, known as the PowerEdge series, are a new approach for Dell, which will focus on simplifying the task of installing and managing servers, not just selling them. [C3.] SHAREHOLDERS DEFY G.M. -- Shareholders of the troubled General Motors approved two proposals aimed at giving them more influence over the way directors are elected -- the first time they have defied G.M.'s recommendations. [C1.] AIRLINE CONTRACT REJECTED -- Flight attendants at Northwest Airlines rejected a contract that would have cut their pay by $195 million a year, betting that improving financial conditions for the industry will help persuade a bankruptcy judge that the airline can afford to pay more. [C3.] DEAL FOR AIRPORT OPERATOR -- BAA, the operator of some of the world's busiest airports, said that it had accepted a takeover offer from the Spanish construction group Ferrovial, ending a nearly four-month fight to remain independent. Grupo Ferrovial's bid values BAA at about £10.2 billion, or $19 billion. [C5.] TOWNSHIP BOOM IN SOUTH AFRICA -- A housing boom in South Africa has spread to an unlikely venue: townships, the ready-made slums erected by South Africa's former apartheid rulers to separate black and mixed-race citizens from whites. [A1.] CHIRAC AND STOCK EXCHANGES -- As the NYSE Group plans to acquire Euronext, a four-country exchange with origins in Paris, President Jacques Chirac of France said that he preferred an all-European deal but backed away from the overt protectionism that has characterized French economic policy. [C3.] WORLD CUP AD FRENZY -- Companies are pouring upward of $1 billion into marketing campaigns tied to the 2006 World Cup in Frankfurt. Advertising. [C1.] GAP RESUMES ADS -- As Gap prepares to introduce its fall clothing line, the brand will resume advertising on television, return celebrities to its print marketing and, for the first time, change store window displays once a month rather than once a season. [C4.] SETTLEMENT WITH GABELLI -- The Justice Department said that it had reached a settlement in a civil-fraud lawsuit with Mario J. Gabelli, the famed money manager, over accusations that he orchestrated a scheme to deceive the Federal Communications Commission in its auction of wireless spectrum licenses several years ago. [C3.] STOCKS DROP AGAIN -- The Dow fell 46.58 points, to 11,002.14. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.44 points, to 1,263.85, and the Nasdaq fell 6.84, to 2,162.78. [C8.] WATCHING INFLATION -- A Federal Reserve governor, Susan Schmidt Bies, said that central bankers were trying to keep inflation from accelerating even as economic growth slowed, and that it was unclear how many more interest rate increases were needed. [C7.] RUSSIAN GAS POLICY -- Aleksei L. Kudrin, below, Russia's finance minister, said the government was considering opening the pipelines of state-owned Gazprom to competition and would encourage greater investment in oil production. But Gazprom said it was not considering such a change. [C5.] I.B.M.'S INDIA EXPANSION -- I.B.M. announced that it would triple its investment in India to $6 billion over the next three years. [C5.] MAYTAG AND AN IOWA TOWN -- When word came from Whirlpool, which purchased Maytag, that the company would close up shop in Newton, Iowa, the community of about 15,000 was left to sort out not just what will be left of its economy, but what will become of its identity. [A16.] ONLINE BABY RUTH AND BASEBALL -- For 85 years, Babe Ruth, the slugger, and Baby Ruth, the candy bar, have lived parallel lives in which it has been widely assumed that the latter was named for the former. The confection's creator, the Curtiss Candy Company, never admitted to what looks like an obvious connection -- especially since Ruth hit 54 home runs the year before the first Baby Ruth was devoured. But these days, Major League Baseball has adopted the candy bar; a report is at nytimes.com/sports/baseball. PRIVACY AND PHONE MERGERS -- Should regulators considering the AT&T-BellSouth deal look into reports that they gave records to the National Security Agency? A report is at nytimes.com/dealbook. INVESTOR TOOLS -- Information on all United States stocks, and bonds, mutual funds, commodities and foreign stocks, as well as analysis of industry sectors and stock indexes can be found at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing An article of this development is at nytimes.com/business. S.E.C. AND OPTIONS -- Christopher Cox, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the growing number of companies under investigation for possible manipulation of stock option grants was ''of serious concern'' to the agency.

COE--Nancy. Age 75, passed away at home in Rumson, NJ on June 5, 2006. Devoted mother, grandmother and friend has died at the age of 75 surrounded by family. Nancy is survived by her brother, David Norling, her children, Jeff Coe, Chelle Coe Gourlay, Matthew Coe and Abby Coe Flanagan, and 11 grandchildren. Blessed with a brilliant mind, a strong will, beauty and style and a lifelong passion for reading, travel and gardening. She embraced life fully. Visitation on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad Street, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral on Friday, 11 A.M. at St. George's By The River Church, 7 Lincoln Avenue, Rumson, NJ.
The tears were flowing fast and free at my daughter Emilie's last-day-of-school party Wednesday morning. And it wasn't just because the kindergartners were hyped-up and over-sugared.

Yes, hard to believe. I think there has rarely been a Thursday when I have arrived at Silverstone to find a hot and sunny day. As I look outside the media center window above the straight as I write these words, I see a clear blue sky. It almost invariably rains here on Thursday.

Instead of being slowly drawn and quartered, Cendant is considering a short, sharp shock. The travel-and-hotels-and-real-estate conglomerate, which has been arranging a four-way breakup for months, said late Thursday that it may spin off two of its businesses at the same time, instead of on different dates. The double spinoff, expected in mid-July, would simultaneously liberate its real estate business, to be called Realogy, and its hospitality business, Wyndham Worldwide, as separately traded entities.
A. O. Scott reviews Robert Altman's "Prairie Home Companion," a film inspired by Garrison Keillor's long-running public radio variety show. (Produced by Emily B. Hager)
Shareholders of Mirant are not the only ones who are anxious about the power company's surprising decision to lunge at rival NRG Energy. Its bondholders have a lot to worry about as well.

"We can't know today what the success will mean," William M. Arkin writes of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death at his Early Warning blog at washingtonpost.com. But that doesn't mean we can't speculate! A sampling of the growing blogbuzz:

Anyone who watched the Czechs dominate Euro 2004 right up until the moment their freakishly-talented midfielder Pavel Nedved had to be taken off the field during the semi-final, with an injury to one of his freakishly-flexible knees, will understand why nerves are jangling in Praha today over the news that, as the BBC puts it: "Nedved hurts knee during training". Fans of the free-flowing attacking play the Czechs unleashed on the rest of Europe two years ago may recall that Nedved's knees have an unusual "patella tri-partitia" structure which, as the Czech team doctor Petr Krejci explained at the time, makes him uniquely gifted: "Most people have a single piece of bone to make their kneecap. One per cent of people have two parts, but three parts? Only Nedved." This, according to a writer for The Independent covering the Czech run through Euro 2004, "explained his running style and his ability to retain control of the ball so adeptly in many tight situations" and also led to much discussion in many European languages of Nedved's knees. Hence, the terror felt by Czech fans -- and neutrals hoping to witness beautiful play over the next few weeks -- every time one of those knees sustains what the British call "a knock". -- R.M.

It may be a hit with the Wall Street masses, but some analysts are saying that stories about an impending takeover of video rental chain Movie Gallery are hard to believe. BusinessWeek Online takes a look at the usual suspects -- Blockbuster and Netflix -- that are suggested as possible acquirers for the company and concludes that neither one would be especially interested.
One day to go! World Cup fever is everywhere -- all over the world, they're going nuts with anticipation. And we say ... get on with it already!

Here is a little-noticed side effect of the new rules requiring hedge funds to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Some managers of funds of funds -- popular investment vehicles that collect money to invest in a variety of hedge funds -- say they are getting hit with a "liquidity mismatch" when their investors want to pull money out of the pool, according to an article from Private Asset Management posted on DailyII.com.

Readers respond to David Brooks's June 8 column, "Savagery's Stranglehold"

The law firm Goodwin Procter is staffing up its private equity team in a big way. On Thursday, it announced that it hired two private equity lawyers in New York. Earlier this week, the Boston-based firm welcomed three new private equity partners in its Washington D.C., office. The New York hires, both of whom come from Chadbourne & Parke, are Thomas C. Meriam and Bruce J. Rader.

Several have written in with questions about how the newsroom goes about deciding which obituaries to write. In a message sent to us last week, a reader wondered why The Times has not yet published an obituary for an emeritus professor at Cornell. Bill McDonald, the obituary editor, responded to the reader with explanations about that specific case and how the selection process works. Their messages are below.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange is strong enough to resist weak merger offers, even in this era of consolidation madness, Craig Donahue, the exchange's chief executive, recently suggested to Reuters. The exchange can be "very selective" because it is growing faster than any other exchange, he said, adding, "we are always looking at different kinds of opportunities."

Regulators at the Federal Trade Commission have waved through Alcatel's proposed acquisition of Lucent Technologies. Lucent said Thursday that the F.T.C. had ended its consideration of the $13.4 billion deal with no action, an outcome that had been generally expected. Shareholders must still approve the transaction, which is expected to close within six to twelve months of the April 2 agreement date, Lucent said Thursday. The two telecommunications companies may need the extra time: They still haven't announced a new name.
The actor, who is nominated for a Tony Award for his performance in "The Pajama Game," answered readers' questions.

First it was Hillary Rodham Clinton's "listening tour." This summer, New Yorkers can look forward to "Kitchen Talks" with K.T. McFarland, in which the aspiring Clinton challenger will enter people's homes (we assume by invitation) and wax political "as a mother, as a national security expert and as a candidate for the United States Senate" (per the news release).

Another big corporate break-up is moving ahead. First Data has taken the next step toward separating from its Western Union unit, filing preliminary documents to transfer new shares of the money-transfer firm to its shareholders. As a parting gift, Western Union -- which sent its last telegraph earlier this year -- will get $3.6 billion in cash and debt securities from its parent, regulatory filings show. The transaction, a tax-free spinoff, is expected to happen in the fourth quarter.

Responding to a cloud of speculation that has engulfed it, media company Tribune said Thursday that it is proceeding "expeditiously" with a $2 billion share buyback program despite resistance from a leading shareholder. Its shares closed 4.2 percent higher, though they stumbled early in the trading session after Tribune made its announcement.

Injuries dominate the on-field news ahead of the World Cup opener between Germany and Costa Rica tomorrow in Munich (for all the injury news, go to this blog's earlier post, updated here.) Michael Ballack is out with a strain in what preoccupied Germans have taken to calling "the national calf," and today he lost his temper when reporters asked him whether he should have done something about the muscle strain earlier. "Such claims are an affront," he said, according to Reuters. "It's almost a slur on my reputation."
A company that monitors employee e-mail uses all of the e-mail that was gathered during the Enron trial as a free sample of its service.
Union members must decide in the next few weeks whether to accept buyouts, a decision auto worker Rick Yrlas calls "a gamble."

Many a hit is followed by lackluster imitations, which may explain the less-than-stellar stock offering that Apollo Management reportedly just completed in Europe. The private equity firm raised $1.5 billion, or about $1 billion less than it had hoped, according to Bloomberg News. The stock sale came a few weeks after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the behemoth of the buyout world, pulled in $5 billion, or more than three times its target, in its European I.P.O.
Altria's years-long spinoff of its Kraft subsidiary is contributing to some pessimism about Kraft's shares.
Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Tuesday, 8 June 1784: 29 6/10 1/2; 59; S; 17. Cloudy, gleam, dark, small shower.
Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the militant who led an insurgent campaign of suicide bombings, kidnappings and hostage beheadings, died in an air strike north of Baghdad.

Investors should buy shares of contracting and energy services giant Halliburton before "several obvious catalysts" take effect in the coming months, according to a research note from Friedman, Billings, Ramsey highlighted on Barron's Online. Chiefly, Halliburton's plan to sell about 20 percent of subsidiary Kellogg, Brown & Root in an initial public offering will add value to the stock, according to analyst Robert MacKenzie.
Parting is sometimes sweet sorrow. Returning? That's a different question.

As you probably know, Microsoft's Windows team sits at the top of an enormous economic pyramid whose base encompasses millions of people all over the world. A new version of Windows means that all those people will buy new computers to run it. Those sales provide enormous boosts to PC companies like Dell and HP. Their company stock climbs. Investors get rich.

Nomura Holdings and a private equity firm, CVC Capital Partners, said on Thursday they would lead a buyout of the restaurant chain Skylark Company for up to $2.4 billion, marking Japan's biggest management buyout to date.
It might be a good idea to keep Windows Vista, the upcoming new version of Windows, in mind when buying a new computer.

Enodis, a British maker of restaurant equipment, said on Thursday it had rejected a bid approach from the Manitowoc Company, a construction equipment maker based in the United States, that values the company at about 975 million pounds ($1.8 billion).

A Rhode Island businessman who said he was illegally tipped off to the 2000 sale of U.S. Foodservice to the Dutch retailer Ahold pleaded guilty yesterday to insider trading and charges related to an accounting scheme.
The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an informal inquiry of Maxim Integrated Products' stock-option grants and practices, company officials said Wednesday evening.

A legal wrangle in America about whether the former chairman of Deutsche Bank conspired to topple the empire of media mogul Leo Kirch will continue after an appeals court overturned an earlier ruling and said the case should be re-examined.

Although the future of Arbinet-thexchange could hinge on a proxy fight pitting management against the company's founder, Alex Mashinsky, whichever side wins faces a major task nursing the ailing electronic telecommuncations exchange back to health.
Cameras so different, they're almost mutants.
The auto parts maker Delphi has asked the United States Bankruptcy Court to extend until February its sole right to file a reorganization plan, citing the size and complexity of its restructuring.

BAE, Britain's biggest arms company, was yesterday at the center of a fresh corruption inquiry, after British police and Serious Fraud Office investigators raided the Chelsea home of one of the company's agents. Investigators are probing payments made by BAE during the government sale of two British frigates to Romania.
The Times's Jere Longman says that because expectations for its team are low, Germany just hopes to play host to a grand party this summer.

The cable operator Cablevision Systems filed a countersuit on Wednesday against several Hollywood studios and television networks that are trying to block its planned network-based digital video recorder.
Rick Kaplan, who led MSNBC to some gains in viewers but was ultimately unable to raise its standing as the third-ranked cable news network, resigned abruptly yesterday afternoon.

Oak Hill Capital Partners has acquired a controlling stake in Primus International, an aerospace parts company that had $100 million in annual sales last year, from another buyout fund, Rhone Capital.

Ace Cash Express, which operates check-cashing stores, said Wednesday that it has agreed to be purchased by a private equity firm and senior managers for $420.8 million. The Irving, Tx.-based company agreed to the buyout for $30 a share, a premium of $3.68, or 14 percent, over Tuesday's closing price of $26.32.
Cravey Green & Whalen has retained Robert W. Baird to explore a sale of TruckPro, an aftermarket distributor of truck parts, less than two years after buying the company, LBO Wire reported.
After sealing $39 million from its venture investors, HomeAway has started its new Web site, which consolidates several sites designed to help people find and book vacation rental homes.

Internet video -- from episodes of "South Park'' to videos of your friend singing karaoke to the latest Prince single -- has exploded in popularity. But it's still harder than you might think to move video around. And the huge amount of video online is straining the Internet.
Even without an exit under its belt, ATA Ventures almost hit its $200 million ceiling for its second fund, according to Managing Director Hatch Graham.

The four founders of the British gaming company PartyGaming, plus one of the group's chief technicians, cashed in some more of their chips yesterday, coming away from the table with just under 232 million pounds ($429 million).

Christopher Cox, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has urged six major options exchanges to begin quoting a limited number of options in pennies. Options are now quoted in increments of nickels and dimes.

RiverCity Motorway, the winning consortium behind Brisbane's north-south bypass tunnel, will lodge the prospectus for its A$725 million ($540 million) equity fund raising on Friday with the institutional bookbuild set to start two weeks later.

Shares of LoopNet took off Wednesday, closing 25 percent above their offering price. The San Francisco-based online marketplace for commercial real estate opened on the Nasdaq at $14.75 after pricing its 6 million shares at $12 apiece - the midpoint of its expected range - on Tuesday. Shares of the company went on to close at $15.00 for the day.

China CAMC Engineering, the first company to hold an initial public offering in the nation since a yearlong ban was lifted, attracted 213 billion yuan ($27 billion) of bids, 481 times more than the shares on offer.

Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, is a company quickly growing bigger and richer, even by the standards of an oil industry at the crest of energy prices, and it has been acquiring new fields, export terminals and exploration licenses at a dizzying pace.
Lloyds TSB has dropped ABN Amro Hoare Govett and appointed Lehman Brothers as its joint corporate broker after a fiercely contested battle to advise the British bank.
With Vonage's stock down nearly 30 percent, shareholders are boiling mad and the first of what could be a slew of class-action lawsuits against both underwriters and the company have started flying.

Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street investment bank, is to start raising billions of dollars for a new private equity fund within weeks, despite the recent furor over conflicts of interest between the bank's private equity division and its corporate clients, The Times of London reported.
The company that bought bankrupt VarTec Telecom's assets is resurrecting a familiar brand in the Dallas telecom industry.
EMC has acquired its third venture-backed start-up in as many months, snapping up an OEM partner nLayers, which provides datacenter management software.
News Corporation halved its stake in Phoenix Satellite Television, mainland China's leading private-sector broadcaster.
Business software maker Oracle on Wednesday said it extended its tender offer for all shares of Portal Software, its second extension of its bid in two weeks.

Analog Devices said it would buy Integrant Technologies, a Seoul-based company developing tuners for mobile TV reception, for $127 million in cash and possibly $33 million more depending on future performance.

The newspaper publisher McClatchy said Wednesday it would sell five more newspapers it acquired from by Knight Ridder for about $450 million. The announcement brings Knight Ridder, the second-largest U.S. newspaper company, one step closer to dissolution.

General Dynamics, which makes ships for the Navy and tanks for the Army, said on Wednesday its $2.2 billion acquisition of Anteon International, a government information technology and services company, is set to close Thursday.
A bidding battle could break out for NeuTec Pharma, which specializes in developing medicines for infectious diseases, after Novartis, the Swiss drugmaker, offered 305 million pounds for the company.
The $19 billion battle for Falconbridge heated up on Wednesday with Inco's announcement that it had reached "an important milestone" in gaining regulatory clearance to buy the nickel miner.
Dealers speculated that Vincent Bollore has once again increased his stake in Aegis as volumes in the advertising group swelled to more than four times the daily average.

Plans by Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin to fend off foreign takeovers and create a second French energy champion looked less certain Wednesday after an Italian utility, Enel, showed continuing interest in buying its French rival Suez and some French lawmakers appeared to be having second thoughts.

Italy's finance minister, Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa, said Wednesday that he favored an alliance of Euronext, Deutsche Börse and Borsa Italiana, making him the second European leader in two days to call for a regional deal since Euronext agreed to be acquired by the New York Stock Exchange.

The Tribune Company's board has been seriously considering since January a spinoff of its broadcasting group, a break-up that could lead to the eventual sale of the rest of the company, a report said on Thursday.

A banker at the heart of the defense of the London Stock Exchange has been in discussions about one of the City of London's largest inter-dealer brokers being acquired by the New York Stock Exchange, The Telegraph reported Thursday.

With a hot real estate market and a growing generation of internationally seasoned managers, Spanish corporations are shopping for companies in Europe and the United States, outmaneuvering many of their neighbors in Germany, France and Britain.
Facing increasing pressure from angry shareholders, the steel company Arcelor said Wednesday that it would talk to Mittal Steel, which has made a hostile bid for the company.

A consortium led by the investment bank Goldman Sachs said on Thursday it was no longer in takeover talks with BAA, the British airport operator, in a move that analysts said should now give Spain's Grupo Ferrovial a clear run to take control of BAA.
Many previously unseen photographs by Weegee are on display at the International Center of Photography.

After the mind-numbing complexity of the Enron trial, we were strangely comforted by the brazen simplicity of this latest, and much smaller, corporate scandal. (Plus, it has to do with pasta and not off-the-books parterships, so we can really relate.)

Here's your complete guide to national-team nicknames. In other languages, national teams are often referred to as "selections," meaning teams whose players are selected to represent the nation. Be sure to Google these nicknames -- you come across some great fan sites.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Proving that this blog is round, we return to the subject of the ball being used in the World Cup, the +Teamgeist, manufactured by Adidas. Some goalkeepers have said that it is somehow too round and perhaps too light. In today's Times, Mark Landler examines the ball and finds, among other things, that it retails for $129.99. For a soccer ball.

Southern California guard Gabe Pruitt, who averaged 16.9 points and was a first-team all-star in the Pacific-10 Conference as a sophomore last season, will be academically ineligible for the fall semester. The Trojans' other backcourt starter last season, the freshman Ryan Francis, was shot and killed May 13 in his hometown of Baton Rouge, La., apparently the unintended victim of a dispute between two men. The 6-foot-4 Pruitt will try to regain his eligibility and rejoin the Trojans in mid-December, about a third of the way through the schedule before conference play begins. Neil Smith, the architect of the Rangers' 1994 Stanley Cup championship team, is expected to be named general manager of the Islanders and Ted Nolan as their head coach.

David Zabriskie won the time trial at the Dauphiné Libéré yesterday, leading an American sweep of the top four places. Zabriskie moved to second place over all behind Belgium's Philippe Gilbert, who took the lead Tuesday. Zabriskie, riding for Team CSC, clocked 52 minutes 48.65 seconds for the 26-mile third stage that began and ended in Bourg-de-Péage, France. Floyd Landis, winner of three races this year, including the Tour de Georgia in April, placed second, 53 seconds off Zabriskie's pace. Levi Leipheimer, riding for Gerolsteiner, was third, and Discovery Channel's George Hincapie was fourth.

The Nets scheduled a workout June 17 for Jay Williams, whom the Chicago Bulls took with the second overall selection in the 2002 draft. Williams played a season with the Bulls but was severely injured in a motorcycle accident in 2003.

Darrell Kestner, who missed the cut last year, yesterday won the rain-shortened Long Island Golf Association Open championship at the Bethpage State Park Red Course. Kestner parred the final hole for a 75 and a 36-hole total of 142. Ron Faria bogeyed the last hole for a 74 and fell into a three-way tie for second at 143 with Abbie Valentine (73) and Jim Hazen (70).
A federal audit said school districts in New Jersey filed claims for thousands of speech and physical therapy treatments that they could not prove were necessary.
A North Plainfield, N.J., couple whose newborn grandson died after they put him in a toilet have been charged with aggravated manslaughter, the Somerset County prosecutor said yesterday.
