LaBranche & Company, a stock-trading firm, agreed to keep 511 jobs in Lower Manhattan for at least 10 years in a deal announced yesterday by city and state officials. After receiving $987,000 from the Job Creation and Retention Program, LaBranche, which currently has quarters on Wall Street, leased office space at 33 Whitehall Street instead of moving elsewhere in Manhattan or outside of the city, according to Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which administers the program with the city's Economic Development Corporation.

A 30-year-old woman was sexually assaulted yesterday afternoon in a beauty parlor on 52nd Street in Sunset Park, where she works, the police said. A man entered the unisex parlor, located between two apartment buildings on a quiet residential street around 1 p.m. while the owner was out and sexually attacked the woman, beat her in the head with a hammer, and fled. She was taken to Lutheran Medical Center, where she was in serious condition. There have been no arrests.

Andrew M. Cuomo, a leading Democratic candidate for state attorney general, released proposals yesterday to reduce gun violence and to hold gun manufacturers accountable for certain acts that involve their products. One proposal would require the microstamping of guns to help law enforcement agencies track illegally obtained weapons. He also called for a statewide coalition of mayors and county executives to stop the flow of illegal guns.
What remains of the Greenpoint Terminal Market is a crime scene no more.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine promised yesterday to abide by his campaign statement and create and preserve 100,000 units of housing for low- and moderate-income residents in the next 10 years. Speaking at a housing conference in Trenton, Mr. Corzine said that his administration would issue a report within the next few weeks evaluating the state's housing programs, and a blueprint later this year outlining the details. Susan Bass Levin, the commissioner for the state's Department of Community Affairs, said it was too early to put a price tag on the plan. But she did note that Mr. Corzine had proposed an increase of $15 million for a rental assistance program, and other initiatives aimed at providing housing for victims of domestic violence and veterans, among others.

Gov. George E. Pataki criticized Assembly leaders yesterday for failing to take action on his proposal to expand the state's DNA database by requiring all criminals convicted of felonies and misdemeanors, including youthful offenders convicted in criminal court, to submit their DNA. Currently, New York requires DNA only from those convicted of certain felonies and misdemeanors. The governor's plan has passed the State Senate by a vote of 60 to 1. Sisa Moyo, a spokeswoman for the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said the Assembly was working on its own database expansion proposal.

New Jersey's commissioner of human services collapsed in a bathroom at the State House Annex yesterday afternoon, moments after he left a legislative budget hearing where he had been called to testify. The commissioner, Kevin M. Ryan, left, had had pneumonia recently and missed more than a week of work while being treated. The commissioner was able to walk to an ambulance and was treated at a Hamilton hospital and released. Mr. Ryan, 39, the state's former child advocate, became human services commissioner in January.

The governing body of high school sports in New Jersey unanimously approved a plan yesterday under which all athletes in post-season competition will be subject to random steroid testing beginning in the fall. Approval of the plan by the group, the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association, makes the state the first in the nation to test high school students in all sports for performance-enhancing drugs. About 5 percent of the athletes in championship tournaments will be required to take urine tests, and students caught using the drugs will be prohibited from playing interscholastic sports for a year. As acting governor, Richard J. Codey issued an executive order last December requiring the testing.
An F.D.A. official called for a drug company to halt trials of Ketek because it could be deadly, according to memos.

The House rejected an effort to nullify a contract imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration on the nation's 14,500 unionized air traffic controllers. Supporters of the bill, which would have sent the disputed contract to binding arbitration, failed to muster the two-thirds majority needed for passage. The vote was 271 to 148. The bill sought to change rules that permit the agency to impose new wages and work rules if contract negotiations fail to produce an agreement.

Jefferson's office unconstitutional, a move that could undermine part of a lengthy bribery investigation of Mr. Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat. A high-level Security Council delegation, on a 10-day African trip, met in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, with the African Union Commission, the 53-member organization's executive body. Leaders of both groups said they had mapped out a plan for a United Nations force to take over peacekeeping in the Darfur region of Sudan and had agreed that the African troops now on the ground must be reinforced quickly. Both stressed that the government of Sudan — a union member — must approve the transfer. Sudan has been reluctant to accept a United Nations force.

At least 17 children were wounded when drug traffickers opened fire on the police near a school in Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said. Teachers had told the pupils to lie down, but some started running away in panic when the shooting started. Eight children were taken to a hospital, including five who were hit by stray bullets and had surgery. Nine more were hurt by splinters and flying debris.

To avoid a tidal wave of wine and a collapse of global wine prices because of overproduction in the European Union countries that make it, the European Commission approved plans for 79 million gallons of French wine and 69 million gallons of Italian wine to be distilled into undrinkable, industrial-grade alcohol. But Europe's agricultural commissioner, Mariann Fischer Boel, cautioned that while such stopgap action might bring temporary relief, "it does not deal with the core of the problem — that Europe is producing too much wine for which there is no market.".

The World Bank asked the government to repay $7.6 million provided for road, land, water and sanitation projects after an investigation found corruption. It also suspended parts of $72 million in loans for the projects.

After Egyptian mediation, the Hamas-led government agreed for a second time to withdraw a new paramilitary force from the streets in Gaza and redeploy it in limited, less public locations. The Egyptians are trying to get Hamas and the defeated Fatah faction, which controls most of the Palestinian Authority's security forces, to halt violent clashes in Gaza, in which nearly 20 people have died in the last month.

A construction company plans next week to blast through some bedrock to prepare column foundations for the core of the Freedom Tower.

LAUTERSTEIN--Ronald. The Mailman School of Public Health, Columbia University, is deeply saddened by the passing of Ronald H. Lauterstein, Class of '58, a beloved alumnus and esteemed member of the School's Board of Advisors. He died on May 8 in Toronto. An active participant in alumni activities and a major benefactor of the School, Mr. Lauterstein established the Lauterstein Scholars Program. His wisdom, vigor and compassion will be profoundly missed. On behalf of the Board, faculty, staff and alumni, we extend our sincere sympathies to his family and friends. James Harden, Chair Susan Patricof, Vice Chair Allan Rosenfield, MD, Dean

COLNER--Morris A. 93, of West Orange, NJ and Longboat Key, FL died June 6 in Sarasota, FL. Beloved husband of Ruth for 64 years and cherished father of Deborah Goldberg, and Martin, Alan and Leonard Colner; dear father-in-law of Jack Goldberg, Robin Colner and Simone Oppenheimer-Colner; joyful grandfather of Andrea, Dan, Phyllis, Michael, Jennifer and Ariana; and adoring great-grandfather of Seth and Eytan. He was the Senior Partner in the accounting firm of Besser, Colner, Herbst & Lustbader. He was past president of the Rotary Club of South Orange, NJ and past president of Congregation Oheb Shalom, South Orange. He was a 1935 graduate of NYU, School of Commerce, first in his class. He was a naval veteran of World War II and received the Meritorious Service Award. He was a member of Maplewood Country Club and Longboat Key Club. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Oheb Shalom, South Orange on Friday, June 9 at 2pm.

9 P.M. (MTV) THE 2006 MTV MOVIE AWARDS -- Jessica Alba (left), in a reportedly clever performance, does the honors as host of this ceremony taped on Saturday at the Sony Pictures Studio lot in Culver City, Calif. The previously announced winners -- who went home with not only a popcorn-bucket statuette but a goody bag worth $17,000 -- include Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson's ''Wedding Crashers,'' and Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal, who trumped Brangelina for best kiss. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Tim Meadows, Brande Roderick, Paige Davis, Leslie Nielsen and other celebrity types swap trivia for cash in ''Press Your Luck'' while trying to stay out of the way of those red-caped Whammys. 8 P.M. (National Geographic Channel) ANATOMY OF A TORNADO -- Using tornado simulators and debris-impact analysis, this special dissects the makeup of twisters and explores how a gust of wind can whip up a lethal frenzy. 9 P.M. (Travel Channel) DREW CAREY'S SPORTING ADVENTURES -- Mr. Carey, something of a soccer fanatic, travels to Germany to experience the 2006 World Cup and the myriad events surrounding it, starting with the match between Real Madrid and Barcelona in Spain. He's on a mission: to create a rousing fight song for the United States team. 10 P.M. (BBC America) HEX -- At last, Buffy for Anglophiles, complete with snobby girl group, fallen angel and lesbian best friend. In this dark British cult series new to American television, a teenage outcast (Christina Cole, left) at a remote boarding school discovers she is cursed with unique powers that have a terrifying link to the past. 10 P.M. (NBC) WINDFALL -- Twenty friends become instant megawinners in this new series starring, among others, Luke Perry, Jason Gedrick and Sarah Wynter, and nothing is ever the same. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Meredith Vieira, who steps into Katie Couric's shoes on ''Today'' in September, lets her hair down on the eve of her last appearance on ''The View.'' 11:35 P.M. (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Al Gore (right), who has eschewed his title of former vice president for that of environmentalist, speaks about things green. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

A headline on Friday about incentives to be offered to Iran by the United States, Russia, China and three European nations in exchange for halting its nuclear activities referred incorrectly to the possibility of sanctions. While a statement about the offer carefully avoided any mention of sanctions, Britain's foreign secretary, who read the statement, warned that ''further steps'' would be taken if Iran did not comply; she did not say the plan had ''no sanctions included.''

ROSS--Robert. Bob Ross devoted his life to the Muscular Dystrophy Association, taking it from a handful of local chapters to an internationally renowned nonprofit organization. As MDA's top executive for more than 40 years, Bob can be credited with virtually every achievement made by MDA -- the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, a summer camp program benefiting more than 4,000 kids a year, cutting-edge lifesaving research, a nationwide network of expert-led clinics, and too many other accomplishments to enumerate. With an unwavering commitment to MDA's primary mission of eradicating neuromuscular diseases, Bob pressed staff members and rallied volunteers to do their best. At the same time, he opened his compassionate heart to thousands of families he knew personally whose lives were affected by the more than 40 diseases in MDA's program. Bob Ross was MDA's president and chief executive officer, and much more. His numerous skills created success, his vision made dreams come true, and his deeply caring heart assured that the easing of suffering was always MDA's guiding priority. We extend our deepest condolences to his family, and to the countless members of his MDA family. We're honored to have been his friends. The MDA Robert Ross Memorial Fund has been established to receive contributions in his memory. Gifts can be sent to 3300 E. Sunrise Dr., Tucson, AZ 85718. Muscular Dystrophy Association Jerry Lewis National Chairman Lois R. West Chairman of the Board Gerald C. Weinberg Senior Vice President & COO Robert Bennett, Chairman of the Executive Committee Suzanne Lowden, Treasurer Joseph S. DiMartino, Chairman, Investment Committee Leon I. Charash, M.D., Chairman, Medical Advisory Committee R. Rodney Howell, M.D., Chairman, Scientific Advisory Committee $(6$)ROSS--Robert. We are deeply and painfully saddened by the loss of Bob Ross. He represented the founding and guiding force of the Muscular Dystrophy Association. On a personal level, we've lost a dear and treasured friend. Phyllis and Leon Charash

ZUCKER--Adeline. The Hamptons Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our benefactor, Tamar Ekstein. To Tamar, Jackie and to the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, Pres. Martin Berman, Chairman Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

WALLS are being dressed this season with bold patterns, often in bright colors. Small producers are hand-painting papers and experimenting with digitally manipulated photographs. Others are creating three-dimensional patterns that can be used in small pieces, more as murals than all-over wall coverings. 1. Kyra and Robertson Hartnett's hand-printed papers made with water-based inks are available in many color combinations. Designs include Peekaboo ($171 a roll), left, and Promenade ($214), right. Rolls are five yards long and 27 inches wide by Twenty2, twenty2.net or (888) 222-3036. 2. Kabloom, a hand-printed design by Flavor Paper, a company in New Orleans, is available in different color combinations, priced from $150 to $350 a roll (44 feet long and 52 inches wide); flavorleague.com or (504) 944-0447. 3. Custom wallpaper studded with tiny jigsaw puzzle pieces is handmade by a London designer, Tracy Kendall. The paper, sold in pieces that are about 20 by 84 inches, can be used to create a mural, at a cost of about $600 a square yard; from the designer, (011) 44-207-640-9071 or www.tracykendall.com. 4. A silkscreened paper, called French Dot, has a background hand-painted by its designer, Karen Combs, in North Adams, Mass. The paper is sold in sheets, 25 by 38 inches; $180 each from Nama Rococo, (413) 652-2312 or www.namarococo.com 5. Birdcage, by Timorous Beasties, a design company in Glasgow, has a hand-printed, oversize pattern that looks like damask. Birdcage comes in various colors and is 52 inches wide; $50 a yard, to the trade, at Holland & Sherry, 979 Third Avenue (59th Street), (212) 355-6241. 6. Woven Marble is made with woven strips of bark, pounded flat. It comes in sheets that go up with clear paste. The pattern, also in buckskin, cinnamon and ivory, comes in three sizes: 16 by 24 inches ($10); 24 by 32 inches ($20); and 48 by 96 inches ($160) from Barkskin in Santa Fe, N.M., barkskin.com or (505) 983-1942. 7. Photographs are manipulated to make Alula, a pattern in a debut collection by Trove, a wallpaper company in Manhattan. ''The computer is our tool box,'' said Randall Buck, one of the designers. ''We call our papers digital paintings.'' The papers are just under three feet wide; $16 a square foot from troveline.com or (212) 268-2046.

A sports article on Sunday about Alonzo Mourning of the Miami Heat, who at age 36 is trying to win his first N.B.A. title, referred incorrectly to his teammate Dwyane Wade. He would be the second player from the 2003 draft class to win a championship, not the first. (That was Darko Milicic of the Detroit Pistons, who won the title in 2004.) Another sports article in some copies on Sunday about the matchup of the Dallas Mavericks and the Heat as two first-time finalists misidentified the teams involved in the last such matchup. In 1971, the Baltimore Bullets (not Washington) lost to the Milwaukee Bucks (not the Seattle SuperSonics).

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 U.S. Officials Fault C.I.A. On Aid to Somali Warlords A covert effort by the Central Intelligence Agency to finance Somali warlords has drawn criticism from American officials who say the campaign has thwarted counterterrorism efforts inside Somalia and empowered the Islamic groups it was intended to marginalize. A1 First 500 Iraqi Detainees Freed Five hundred prisoners were released at various points across Iraq, a day after Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced plans to release 2,500 detainees in coming days in an attempt to calm tensions between Iraq's main sectarian groups. A6 Death Toll Rises in Kabul Riots Nine days after the worst riots in the Afghan capital in years, officials raised the death toll to 17, and said that 140 people remained in detention, accused of involvement in the rioting. A6 Bolton Rejects U.N. Criticism John R. Bolton, the American ambassador to the United Nations, called on Secretary General Kofi Annan to repudiate ''personally and publicly'' critical remarks his top deputy made about the United States, but Mr. Annan turned aside the challenge. A10 Doubts About a Nuclear Iran Bush administration officials said that the package of incentives offered to Iran could theoretically allow it some day to enrich uranium for peaceful purposes, but expressed severe doubts that Iran could satisfy the conditions that would allow it to do so. A14 NATIONAL A16-22 Narrow Victory for G.O.P. Signals Difficulties in Fall The victory that Republicans squeaked out in a race in San Diego to fill a Congressional vacancy left them relieved but signaled difficulties as they face Democratic challenges in much more contested districts this fall. A1 Telemedicine Rises Rurally Psychiatry, especially in rural swaths of the nation that also often have deep social problems like poverty and drug abuse, is emerging as one of the most promising expressions of telemedicine. A1 Same-Sex Marriage Ban Fails As expected, the Senate rejected a proposed constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage, rebuffing both President Bush and the social conservative movement. A19 A Rise In Illegal Workers About a quarter of the construction workers rebuilding New Orleans are illegal immigrants, who are getting lower pay, less medical care and less safety equipment than legal workers, according to a study by professors at Tulane University and the University of California, Berkeley. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH A Call to Halt a Drug Trial A Food and Drug Administration official called in May for a drug company to halt clinical trials of an antibiotic in children because the drug could be deadly, according to internal memoranda sent to other F.D.A. officials. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Homeless Men Suspected In Brooklyn Warehouse Fire Two homeless men who had been burning the insulation off copper wires they intended to sell were accused of sparking the spectacular fire that ripped through a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront last month. A1 Police Link DNA to Murders The Bridgeport police say new DNA testing has linked a man imprisoned in Georgia to the murders of four women who were among at least 15 killed during the late 1980's and early 1990's. The police are investigating whether he was involved in six more murders. B1 American Linked to Al Qaeda An American citizen who once lived in New York was indicted on charges of conspiring to send money and military gear to associates of Al Qaeda to use against United States forces in Afghanistan, federal prosecutors said. B3 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-7 Pitcher Alleges More Drug Use Jason Grimsley, a journeyman pitcher with the Arizona Diamondbacks, took only two hours to disclose what he surely hoped would remain a secret, and what other major leaguers also wanted to keep private. Two months ago, according to federal investigators, Grimsley revealed that he had used performance-enhancing substances for several years and that other players did, too. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-18 Arrest in Internet Scheme Federal authorities arrested a Miami man who they said made more than $1 million in a hacking scheme involving the resale of Internet telephone service. C1 Rejoining Morgan Stanley Morgan Stanley said that it had secured the return of a senior investment banker, a small coup for a firm that has worked hard to replenish its pool of top investment banking talent. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: A power vacuum in Iraq; one down, one to go; when drug firms pay off competitors; sniffing out fake ''prep schools.'' Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E7 Crossword E2 Obituaries A23 TV Listings E8 Weather D8

To the Editor: Michael Chertoff writes, ''I would like to clear up two other misunderstandings.''

From coast to coast, Lastings Milledge is introducing himself to the rest of baseball. His eight major league games have come on the two grandest stages of baseball, in New York and here, and Milledge is hardly intimidated. On a night when the Mets received an unexpectedly poor outing by Tom Glavine and played without their regular leadoff, cleanup and No. 6 hitters, Milledge supplied a run-scoring triple and two-run homer, sending the Mets to a 9-7 victory Wednesday night at Dodger Stadium.

An Associated Press obituary on May 20 about Lawrence Shurtliff, a longtime crew member for the Grateful Dead, misspelled his wife's given name and surname. She is Frances Whelan, not Francis Whalen. It also incorrectly rendered the name by which he was known. It was Ram Rod, not Ramrod. A correction on this page yesterday repeated the erroneous spellings of his wife's surname and his nickname.

An Associated Press obituary on May 20 about Lawrence Shurtliff, a longtime crew member for the Grateful Dead, misspelled his wife's given name and surname. She is Frances Whelan, not Francis Whalen. It also incorrectly rendered the name by which he was known. It was Ram Rod, not Ramrod. A correction on this page yesterday repeated the erroneous spellings of his wife's surname and his nickname.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a new warning on inflation from the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, misstated the time periods for his estimates of ''core'' inflation. The annualized rate was 3 percent over the last three months, not the last six months, and 2.3 percent over the last six months, not 12 months. The article also misidentified the Congressional committee at which Mr. Bernanke testified in late April. It was the Joint Economic Committee, not the Senate Banking Committee.

The Critics' Choice column on May 22, about new CD's, misstated the relationship between Johnny Cash and Carlene Carter, who wrote the song ''It Takes One to Know Me'' on the new Cash album. She is his stepdaughter, not his daughter.

Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, announced that he and a wealthy partner had bought a 49 percent share of one of Russia's prominent independent newspapers, Novaya Gazeta. The newspaper, a collective owned by its journalists and editors, has reported vigorously on politics, business and corruption, often challenging Kremlin policies. Published twice a week, it has a circulation of more than 700,000 nationwide. Mr. Gorbachev said he and his partner, Aleksandr Y. Lebedev, a billionaire who has campaigned against corruption, hoped to preserve the paper's independence and continue ''to express a wide variety of opinions,'' Interfax reported. Mr. Gorbachev's announcement came after reports that Roman A. Abramovich, the country's richest man and an ally of President Vladimir V. Putin, was negotiating to purchase another prominent newspaper, Kommersant. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)
KONIGSBERG--Natalie,You are always in our hearts. We miss you, and love you. Your loving family.

(and Stephanie) Azrieli for whom the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration is named. A retired metallurgical engineer who lived in Israel since 1947, Mr. Azrielowicz is survived by his sons, Mordecai and Aryeh, and by his five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Heartfelt condolences are extended to all the members of the Azrieli family, who we pray will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees David J. Schnall, Dean Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration

An article last Thursday about the release of federal antiterrorism grants for urban areas misspelled the given name of a spokesman for Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York. He is Jordan Barowitz, not Jordon. An article on Friday about a report by the Department of Homeland Security that criticized New York's application for aid referred erroneously to the city fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, who commented on the 40 percent cut in aid for the city. He has no middle name.

KNIT one, purl two: The most conventional instructions, murmured like an incantation at many of the knitting circles springing up around Manhattan and beyond, are producing results that are anything but humdrum. It is not uncommon in downtown Manhattan to see women, and a few men, from their 20's though their 70's, bent over the quirkiest projects -- caps with floppy spaniel ears, intricately stitched golf club covers, basket-weave-pattern dresses with hourglass curves.
To the Editor: Michael Chertoff's attempted justification for the allocation of homeland security grants is so lame as to defy description.

Immediately after ''Tryst'' closes on Sunday night, the Promenade will no longer be an Off Broadway theater. The space will be converted to another use, said Ben Sprecher, the president of the Sprecher Organization, which owns and operates the theater. He said he made the decision on Tuesday after ''Tryst'' (starring Amelia Campbell and Maxwell Caulfield, left) posted its closing notices. ''I have had an offer on the table for a very long time,'' said Mr. Sprecher, who would give no further details other than that he would still be a part-owner of the space occupied by the theater. The Promenade, at Broadway and 76th Street, opened in 1964 and closed for several years in the 1970's before Mr. Sprecher brought it back with the premiere of David Rabe's ''Hurlyburly'' in 1984. Past productions, including Edward Albee's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Three Tall Women,'' have made profits, but Mr. Sprecher said the economics of managing a 399-seat Off Broadway theater had become untenable. The Sprecher Organization still operates the Little Shubert, the 499-seat Off Broadway theater owned by the Shubert Organization. Another Sprecher-owned theater, Variety Arts, closed in 2004. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

The nation's largest manufacturing union, the United Steelworkers, and largest environmental group, the Sierra Club, are forming an alliance to promote energy independence and fight global warming and toxic pollutants. The union has long been a leader within labor in cooperating with environmentalists. The two groups said a central goal of their partnership, the Blue/Green Alliance, would be to reassure workers that measures to improve the environment need not jeopardize jobs. The union, with 850,000 members, and the Sierra Club, which has 750,000, said their partnership should help bolster the influence of unions and environmentalists. STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT)

SOKOL--Margaret. The Advisory Council of the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art, Cornell University, deeply mourns the passing of Margaret Sokol, a distinguished collector, donor, and friend. A lover of art, both Asian and western, Mrs. Sokol was a dedicated museum docent, profoundly interested in education in the arts. All her friends at the Museum will miss her keen intelligence and quiet humor.

To the Editor: In ''Protect New York, but Don't Blame Omaha'' (Op-Ed, June 6), Bob Kerrey, the former Nebraska senator and 9/11 commission member, implies that Nebraskans are as baffled by the decrease in homeland security money for New York City as they are embarrassed by Omaha's bigger slice of the antiterrorism pie.

In the battle to be the Republican candidate for governor of Alabama, Bob Riley, the incumbent, easily defeated Roy S. Moore, the former Alabama chief justice who drew national attention when he refused a federal court order to remove a Ten Commandments monument from the state judicial building's rotunda and was removed from the bench. Alabama's was among the most colorful contests on Tuesday, as voters picked candidates for governor in several primary elections.

An article in The Arts on Saturday about the author who uses the pseudonym Andrew Holleran, and his new novel, ''Grief,'' misstated the connection between a creative writing teacher he had at Harvard, Peter Taylor, and his time at the Iowa Writers' Workshop. While Mr. Taylor encouraged Mr. Holleran to go to Iowa after his senior year, Mr. Taylor did not teach there and thus Mr. Holleran did not follow him there.

Gov. George E. Pataki criticized Assembly leaders yesterday for failing to take action on his proposal to expand the state's DNA database by requiring all criminals convicted of felonies and misdemeanors, including youthful offenders convicted in criminal court, to submit their DNA. Currently, New York requires DNA only from those convicted of certain felonies and misdemeanors. The governor's plan has passed the State Senate by a vote of 60 to 1. Sisa Moyo, a spokeswoman for the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said the Assembly was working on its own database expansion proposal
To the Editor: Re ''In Praise of the Maligned Sweatshop'' (column, June 6):

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about an airlift by conservationists from Atlanta to save a population of Central American frogs referred incorrectly at one point to the disease that is threatening them. It is a waterborne form of chytrid fungus, not a virus.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the increased activity at the Mount Merapi volcano in Indonesia referred incorrectly in some copies to the distance between the volcano and the city of Yogyakarta, which is far enough away that it is unlikely to be damaged in an eruption. It is 20 miles, not 200.

What Alice Waters, the influential Berkeley, Calif., restaurateur, calls the Delicious Revolution -- a move toward organic, locally grown food -- has revolutionized the Parrish Art Museum's annual Landscape Pleasures program in Southampton, N.Y. A symposium at the museum on Saturday will feature lectures by four champions of the ''edible landscape,'' followed by tours on Sunday of private, rarely seen kitchen gardens and farms. Along with Ms. Waters, who helped create an ''edible schoolyard'' in Berkeley, speakers will include Scott Chaskey, director of Quail Hill Farm in Amagansett, N.Y.; Rosalind Creasy of San Jose, Calif., who introduced the notion of edible landscapes in the 1970's; and Brian Halweil, the editor of ''Edible East End,'' a quarterly devoted to farming in the Hamptons. Eileen Roaman-Catalano, above left, and Mark Catalano will show tourgoers their walking onions, above center, and garden, above right. The tour also includes the frontyard kitchen garden of Leslie Rose and Chuck Close in Bridgehampton; the mazelike gardens of Robert Jakob and David White in Springs; and the quarter-acre vegetable garden of Lei Shen and Andy Sabin in Amagansett, right. ''Gardening is therapy to me,'' said Mr. Sabin, who starts all his seeds under lights. Tickets are $125 for Parrish museum members, $150 for nonmembers; www.parrishart.org or (631) 283-2118, ext. 41. ANNE RAVER

ATANASIO -- Margaret T. ''Peg'' (nee McAloon), on June 6, 2006. In Breezy Point, formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn and Boca Raton, FL. Passed away peacefully at her home six days after her 90th birthday, surrounded by her loving family. Peg is survived by Joseph F. Atanasio, M.D. and her loving and much loved children, Peggy Colucci (Bill), Kathe Hanna (Tom), Joseph Atanasio, M.D. (Miriam), Paul Atanasio, Robert Atanasio (Kathy), Regina DiGiovanna, M.D. (Lawrence), Patti Griffith (Perry), Donna Andrea (Frank) and Clare Atanasio. Dear sister of Betty Zamow and the late Agnes Lynch, Rose Malone, Kitty Sacchi and Patrick McAloon. Proud grandmother of 24 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10:15 AM, at Our Lady of Angels Church. All have been touched by her life and saddened by her death. Peg was loving and caring and the life of the party, with a song on her lips and always in her heart. She lived her life with her heart soaring upwards. Her family encourages memorial donations to AHRC Foundation (Autism Program), 189 Wheatly Rd., Brookville, NY 11545.

MACKSOUD -- Carmen B. Died on June 3 at Calvary Hospital, New York City. Carmen was born on July 28, 1914 in Milford, Pennsylvania. In 1941, she joined General Motors Corporation in New York City. In 1984 when she retired from General Motors as an employee at the mandatory retirement age, she was asked to continue as a consultant which she did for four more years. During most of her 47 year term at GM, she worked for the Public Relations Department as an assistant to three successive GM Directors of Public Relations, including Anthony G. DeLorenzo, Vice President, from 1954 through his retirement in 1979. Carmen is survived by her two sisters, Alice Macksoud of New York City and Laure M. Jones of Douglaston, New York, and a sister-in-law Lisbe Macksoud of Woodstock, Vermont. She also leaves three nephews and three nieces: Kevin Jones of Marietta, Georgia, Peter Jones of Milton, Mass; and Anne Macksoud, Joyce Macksoud, Edward (Ned) Macksoud and Suzanne Macksoud Wooten all of Woodstock, Vermont. Services will be held at St. Anastasia Church in Douglaston, New York (Northern Boulevard and 245 Street, 718-631-4454) at 9:45 on Wednesday, June 14, 2006. Reception to follow. Please do not send flowers. If you wish to make a contribution in Carmen's memory, please do so to your favorite charity.
An obituary on Tuesday about Alex Toth, a comic book artist and animator, omitted his second marriage, to Guyla Avery, who died in 1985.

Neil Smith, the architect of the Rangers' 1994 Stanley Cup championship team, was expected to be named general manager of the Islanders on Thursday. ''I'm not going to confirm or deny it,'' said Smith, 51, who was here for Games 1 and 2 of the Stanley Cup finals as an analyst for the cable network OLN.

An article last Thursday about the release of federal antiterrorism grants for urban areas misspelled the given name of a spokesman for Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York. He is Jordan Barowitz, not Jordon. An article on Friday about a report by the Department of Homeland Security that criticized New York's application for aid referred erroneously to the city fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, who commented on the 40 percent cut in aid for the city. He has no middle name.

Neil LaBute's play ''Some Girl(s)'' opens tonight Off Broadway, with Eric McCormack playing a man on the brink of marriage traveling across the country to catch up with former girlfriends. ''He's trying to impress these women,'' said Neil Patel, the set designer. To convey the character's aspirational taste Mr. Patel put him in a series of boutique hotels not unlike those in the Kimpton chain. Indeed, very much like them: in an unusual promotion-collaboration, Kimpton offered Mr. Patel some of its bedding, artwork, crocodile-pattern carpets and gold-threaded wallpaper, above. ''As a designer in theater trying to recreate the look,'' Mr. Patel said, ''it would have been difficult to get that dead on.'' Audience members wanting to take home Kimpton sheets, inset, can find them at kimptonstyle.com. DEBORAH BALDWIN

A sports article on Sunday about Alonzo Mourning of the Miami Heat, who at age 36 is trying to win his first N.B.A. title, referred incorrectly to his teammate Dwyane Wade. He would be the second player from the 2003 draft class to win a championship, not the first. (That was Darko Milicic of the Detroit Pistons, who won the title in 2004.) Another sports article in some copies on Sunday about the matchup of the Dallas Mavericks and the Heat as two first-time finalists misidentified the teams involved in the last such matchup. In 1971, the Baltimore Bullets (not Washington) lost to the Milwaukee Bucks (not the Seattle SuperSonics).

Darrell Kestner, who missed the cut last year, yesterday won the rain-shortened Long Island Golf Association Open championship at the Bethpage State Park Red Course. Kestner parred the final hole for a 75 and a 36-hole total of 142. Ron Faria bogeyed the last hole for a 74 and tied for second at 143 with Abbie Valentine (73) and Jim Hazen (70). BERNIE BEGLANE (NYT)

DRISCOLL--Sean. On June 6, 2006 of Centerport, NY. Beloved son of the late Michael B. and Florence M. Driscoll. Loving brother of Gary, Brian (Elizabeth) and Dorothy Driscoll, Florence (Steve) Zeller, Dennis (Denny), Michael Driscoll and the late Kevin. Cherished uncle of Chris, Dennis, Sean, Devin, Michael and Kara and great-uncle of Ryan and Kaitlyn. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-4PM and 7-9PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, 10AM, Friday. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Send A Kid Fishing Fund, C/O The Fisherman, 14 Ramsey Road, Shirley, New York 11967, appreciated.

An Irish restaurant has opened in a bank vault near Wall Street. ''People don't want a traditional pub,'' said Jason O'Brien, the managing partner. Working with Brian McDonald, an interior designer in Dublin, Mr. O'Brien and his partners sank $1.5 million into the United States Realty Building at 115 Broadway, designed by Francis H. Kimball 102 years ago. The result, called Trinity Place, has a mahogany bar, leather banquettes and red silk lamp shades, above. Mr. McDonald raised the ceiling, put a wine cooler in an elevator shaft and locked the steel doors, nearly three feet thick, in an open position, above. The restaurant entrance is on Cedar Street, near Broadway; (212) 964-0939. ELAINE LOUIE

An article in Business Day yesterday about the proposed repeal of the inheritance tax referred incorrectly in some copies to the threshold at which the current tax would apply to the estates of single Americans and the widowed who die this year. It is $2 million, not $1.5 million.
To the Editor: A June 1 editorial criticized Senator Arlen Specter, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, for voting the marriage amendment, which he opposes, out of the committee.

You never know what you will find at Adams Unlimited, below, an antiques and used furniture warehouse in Mount Vernon, N.Y., a dealers' haunt that is open to the public. The owner, Josh Tane, says he adds new pieces daily as he buys the contents of entire houses. The inventory recently included a silk Persian-style rug, four by six feet ($175); four Mies-style wicker and steel chairs ($100 for the set) and six ball and claw foot dining chairs in mahogany from the 1930's ($400 for the set). Open Monday through Friday, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m., and weekends by appointment; (914) 668-0374 or aaadams.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

''We must find ways to live with nature in some kind of balance. The government mainly wants to control nature, which is what did all the harm in the first place.'' CHAI ERHONG, an environmentalist, on the spread of deserts in China. [A14]
To the Editor: Re ''Wi-Fi and the Cities'' (editorial, June 6):

NEWMAN--Rosalind (Robbie). Died peacefully at home on June 3 after a brave battle with leukemia. A former Pan American airlines purser, she is survived by Fredric, her husband of 48 wonderful years; beloved children Amanda Crutcher (David) and William (Susan), and cherished grandchildren Jonathan, Jane and Nicholas.

LANZA--Frank C., 74. Husband of Patricia. Father of James, Louis (Jonie), Anthony (fiance Kristina Koch). Grandfather of Matthew and Steven. Viewing will be held Thursday, June 8, 2-5 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Funeral is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Wheelchair Charities Inc. or to the Habitat for Humanity of Westchester. www.habitatwc.org.

Architects are often clueless when it comes to wallpaper, said Kari Pei, the director of design at Wolf-Gordon, a wallpaper design company in Long Island City, N.Y. To raise wallpaper's profile among future architects, she and Toshiko Mori, chairwoman of the architecture department at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, organized a wallpaper design contest for students at the school. Corinne Ulmann and Isamu Kanda beat 40 other contestants to win the $5,000 prize in the competition, called Surface Over Structure, with a design called Light, below. Ms. Ulmann said they wanted a pattern that appeared to create light playing on a wall. Wolf-Gordon carries the pattern, along with designs by three runners-up, at its New York showroom, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street), (800) 347-0550; $16.50 a roll (54 inches wide). ELAINE LOUIE

ARREST IN INTERNET PHONE CASE -- Federal authorities arrested a Miami man who they said made more than $1 million in a hacking scheme involving the resale of Internet phone service. [Page C1.] BEHIND VENEZUELA'S BOOM -- A spending spree in Venezuela, economists say, is masking the fundamental limitations of an economy that is failing to generate enough private investment to sustain longer-term growth and job creation. For many investors, increased government controls and brash moves by President Hugo Chávez, above, against the private sector are clouding the outlook. [C1.] BACK TO MORGAN -- Morgan Stanley said that it had secured the return of Jon A. Anda, a senior investment banker, a small coup for a firm that has worked hard to replenish its pool of investment banking talent. [C1.] L-3 CHIEF EXECUTIVE DIES -- Frank C. Lanza, chief executive of L-3 Communications, one of the nation's largest military contractors, died at age 74 while recovering from surgery, setting off speculation over the future of the company that he helped found nearly a decade ago. [C4.] STOCKS FALL FOR THIRD DAY -- Stocks slipped for a third day. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day down 71.24 points, at 10,930.90. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.70 points, to 1,256.15, and the Nasdaq composite index slipped 10.98 points, to 2,151.80. [C16.] ROSNEFT'S GROWTH -- While private companies in Russia are hemmed in or nearly shut down, state-owned Rosneft -- which plans an initial public offering in July -- is on a growth spurt. [C7.] ARCELOR TO MEET MITTAL -- Facing increasing pressure from angry shareholders, the steel company Arcelor said that it would talk to Mittal Steel, which has made a hostile bid for the company. [C15.] GUILTY PLEAS IN BUCA CASE -- Three former officers of Buca Inc., a chain of Italian restaurants, have agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges in connection with a scheme to create phony profits and allow executives to steal hundreds of thousands of dollars to pay for a range of expenses including the cost of an Italian villa and visits to strip clubs. [C4.] PROTEST OF AIRPORT PLAN -- A trade association for the airlines has asked airports to boycott the ''registered traveler'' program that would allow frequent fliers to bypass much of the airport security hassle. [C4.] NEW RULES BEFORE WORLD CUP -- A series of betting and match-fixing scandals, and concern over the rise of Internet gambling, has led soccer's world governing body to institute extraordinary measures to ensure the legitimacy of the World Cup, which opens Friday in Munich. [A1.] THERAPY ON THE SCREEN -- A growing number of psychiatrists are seeing their patients not in person, but via television. At least 18 states, up from only a handful a few years ago, now pay for some telemedicine care under their Medicaid programs, and at least eight specifically include psychiatry. [A1.] DRUG WARNING -- A popular class of drugs for high blood pressure may cause birth defects if taken during the first three months of pregnancy, doctors are warning. [A20.] ENERGY BILL -- The House passed a bill that its Republican sponsors said would streamline the permitting process to build the first domestic oil refineries in a generation. [A18.] GOING AFTER STARBUCKS -- Three big restaurant chains are revving up efforts to take on Starbucks. But the chains -- Dunkin' Donuts, McDonald's and Burger King -- are not going after the Starbucks coffee snob; they're going after the average Joe. They may not want the snob appeal of Starbucks, but the challengers certainly want a bigger slice of the booming $8.4 billion retail coffee market. [C1.] TRIBUNE DISSENT -- Three directors of the Tribune Company, representing the company's second-largest shareholder, have reportedly dissented from a plan to buy back stock. [C6.] QUITTING FOR VACATION -- Many young people are willing to quit their jobs rather than limit themselves to two weeks of vacation. [G1.] ONLINE INVESTOR TOOLS -- Information on all United States stocks, and on bonds, mutual funds, commodities and foreign stocks, as well as analysis of industry sectors and stock indexes. A guide is at nytimes.com/business. ADVERTISING -- With the kickoff of the World Cup just days away, even Frankfurt, the most buttoned-down of German cities, is cutting loose. A report is at nytimes.com/business. THE CLASSICS -- Previous columns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/pages/timesselect. Business Briefing An article on this development is at nytimes.com/business. A RHODE ISLAND BUSINESSMAN, Brady Schofield, 39, who said he was tipped off to the 2000 sale of U.S. Foodservice to the Dutch retailer Ahold, pleaded guilty to insider trading and charges related to an accounting scheme. Mr. Schofield owns several seafood and produce companies that supplied U.S. Foodservice. He also agreed to pay $728,232 to settle civil claims. (REUTERS)

Maybe they'll be in more of a training mode by the time their first game rolls around on Tuesday, but earlier this week those boys from Brazil sure were having a fantastic time at the World Cup. A couple of days ago Bild reported that Ronaldo, Robinho, Robert Carlos, Adriano, Emerson and Cafu left their Frankfurt hotel last Sunday night at 1:30 a.m. and celebrated Cafu's 36th birthday by dropping 680 euros at the Galerie disco. They returned to their hotel at 5:45.
It should be our goal to completely ignore the World Cup.

Achtung, Baby! as U2 might say. We've got live play-by-play coverage on this blog of three Saturday matches: England-Paraguay at 9 a.m., Sweden-Trinidad and Tobago at noon and, at 3 p.m., Argentina-Ivory Coast. Tune in for our descriptions of all the action, as it happens, at World Cup 2006.

For most of the long history of automobile racing, car designers developed new, often bizarre, technology in order to make the cars go as fast as possible. Some of that technology was not so bizarre and ended up in road cars after proving itself in the laboratory of racing.
The Times's David Barboza discusses how China's coal industry is creating an environmental and health care crisis. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

A temporary disruption in cellphone service this afternoon in Bushwick kept us from posting our photo coverage of the scene at Barzola, the fine restaurant where fans of Ecuador cheered their national side on to victory over Poland. While it didn't make it into the live commentary many of you enjoyed earlier, here, for posterity, is the pivotal moment: wild celebration of the game-clinching second goal.
Joanna Cagan and Graeme Patterson, both employees at the Bronx Zoo, share the story of their romance. (Producer: Brent McDonald)
Alison Rose, who has her own architectural design firm, Alison Rose New York, is eager to transform any space she can get her hands on.
The military has always been a great experimenter with social issues. Not all of them, but it has played around with New Urbanism, according to a story in The Times earlier this week.
This is a relief. The National Association of Realtors says the boom is over.
Floyd Norris writes his column in the New York Times today on the credibility of the consumer price index.

Nasdaq made it clear on Friday that it has no intention of giving up on the London Stock Exchange, setting the stage for a long, hot summer of speculation over how the takeover stalemate will get resolved. Nasdaq chief executive Robert Greifeld told Reuters that his company is "incredibly happy" with its 25.1 percent stake in the London exchange, which it acquired after its $4.2 billion offer for the entire company was rejected in March. "We are not contemplating being a seller," he said.

Wanting and doing are two very different things. That seems to be the important takeaway from CNN Money.com's recent article about the prospects for an initial public offering at American Media, which publishes the celebrity-drenched National Enquirer tabloid and Star magazine.
Click "more" to see the play-by-play coverage of the match that took place at the Arena Auf Schalke in Gelsenkirchen.
The projected windfall just keeps getting bigger for John Kanas, the chief executive of North Fork Bancorp, which is being bought by Capital One Financial in a $14.6 billion deal.
Readers respond to Paul Krugman's June 9 column, "The DeLay Principle"

Warner Chilcott Holdings, an Irish pharmaceuticals company that was the subject of a bitter takeover battle between private equity groups in 2004, has filed to raise as much as $1 billion in an initial public offering of stock.

With the Northeast becoming a major front in the battle for control of the House, two prominent Republican congressmen from New York -- James Walsh of the Syracuse region and John Sweeney of the Albany region -- are going up on the air with early campaign ads in their districts, where they face the prospect of strong challenges.
A. O. Scott discusses the legacy of "The Searchers," the influential 1956 collaboration between John Ford and John Wayne.

Just when American Railcar Industries has chalked up some major accomplishments this year, including a January initial public offering that raised $185.6 million, there are worries that its chairman and founder -- a certain Carl C. Icahn -- may spoil the party by unloading at least some of his 53 percent stake in the company, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported Friday.
Click "more" to see the play-by-play coverage.

Markos Moulitsas Zuniga, the proprietor of Daily Kos and the inspiration for this weekend's Yearly Kos bloggers conference (where so far, The American Prospect's Ezra Klein reports, "attendees have barely outnumbered those writing about the attendees"), has frequently professed to have no ideology other than the Democrats' winning. But in a post this week titled "The Libertarian Dem," Moulitsas explains the philosophy that connects him to the candidates he supports: "They are all Libertarian Democrats."
Television coverage of Nascar has come a long way since ABC broadcast its first race, the Greenville 200.
Opening day at the World Cup in Germany.
It looks like the battle for the world's biggest airport operator, BAA , is over, with a group led by Spain's Ferrovial outmaneuvering a consortium with Goldman Sachs up front.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's June 9 column, "Plenty of Enemies to Go"

The Economist takes a look at the emergence of timberland investment management organizations, or TIMOs, which pool private investments to buy timberland. Forest-products companies, which once owned the land themselves, buy the trees from the TIMOs and convert them into lumber or paper. This is big business: International Paper recently agreed to sell 4.2 million acres to a TIMO-led group for $5 billion in cash and notes.
A British software firm, Misys, said on Friday it had received a request from members of senior management about making a possible offer for the company, sending its shares up as much as 25 percent.

Patience seems to have paid off for Royal Group Technologies. The Canadian maker of plastic building components, which has been up for sale for more than a year, on Friday announced an agreement to be acquired for about 1.7 billion Canadian dollars ($1.54 billion), including debt. The price offered by Atlanta-based Georgia Gulf represented a whopping 43.5 percent premium over Thursday's closing price of Royal Group's shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
Over the last six years, the Federal Communications Commission has levied increasing fines on noncable television and nonsatellite radio broadcasters for “indecent” and “profane” acts.

Got a spare $100,000? If so, you might be able to plow in into Morgan Stanley's latest creation, called the Alternative Investment Partners Absolute Return Fund. The fund is the latest step in Morgan Stanley's plan to boost its offerings in alternative investments, a category that includes private equity and hedge funds. Morgan Stanley has lagged behind many of its competitors in this area, which is now extremely hot with investors, and Morgan chief executive John Mack has promised to close the gap.
Commanders at the Pentagon predict that Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death will cause an upsurge in violence in Iraq in coming days, The Times's Thom Shanker reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)
The killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi is the best news for the White House on Iraq in months or years, The Times's Jim Rutenberg reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)
The death of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq, came after intense detective work by the American military, The Times's Mark Mazzetti reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)
The excitement of the opening ceremony

Tribune's acquisition of the Times Mirror six years ago usually draws Bronx cheers these days, and Jon Fine, BusinessWeek's media writer, issues a loud one in his latest column, going so far as to compare the deal to the Time Warner-AOL debacle. The comparison is a stretch, but he connects some interesting dots all the same.

New York is joining with Euronext, and the pair is now reportedly wooing Italy. Germany is looking for -- somebody. But the consolidation fever that has gripped the world's stock exchanges has apparently not affected the Irish Stock Exchange, one of Europe's smallest. The exchange's C.E.O., Tom Healy, told Reuters on Friday that his exchange is too small to take public and under no pressure to merge.

It took three ballots, but the Stonewall Democrats, a gay political club, finally determined whom they would endorse for attorney general in a lengthy meeting last night: Sean Patrick Maloney, the former aide to President Clinton.
About 200 people on horseback rode from Nebraska to South Dakota to honor all military veterans and the revered Crazy Horse.
Wall Street can always use a dose of logic, but not this way.
A scorecard for tonight's 44th anniversary dinner of the New York Conservative Party. How many times:
There's a housing complex in Hong Kong whose 100 rooms are each ten feet square. TEN FEET.

Securities regulators are investigating whether short sellers may have played a role in the steep decline in the stock price of Internet phone carrier Vonage Holdings since its initial public offering last month, according to a published report.

It's time for General Motors and Ford Motor Company to admit to two more mistakes and sell the European carmakers each thought could stem the defection of luxury buyers from Cadillac and Lincoln, according to Bloomberg News's Doron Levin.
Cathay Pacific Airways will pay $1.58 billion to buy Hong Kong Dragon Airlines and double its stake in Air China, adding 21 routes in China. Cathay's stock gained the most in more than two years.
Houston Exploration has agreed to provide a New York hedge fund with some of the documents it demanded last week in its efforts to get the company to reconsider recent strategic investments.
New accusations of corporate stock option abuse were leveled yesterday, this time against Cyberonics, a medical device maker that is no stranger to controversy.

Ending nearly a decade of litigation, the Delaware Supreme Court upheld on Thursday a lower court decision exonerating the Walt Disney Company's board and the former chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, over the hiring and firing of the company's former president Michael Ovitz.

Take-Two Interactive Software, publisher of the video game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, has agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission accusations that it failed to disclose that animated sex scenes were hidden on the game's discs.
Cablevision Systems said yesterday that it would suspend a test of a new video recording service pending the result of a copyright infringement lawsuit filed by several entertainment companies.

The former head of Howard Stern's accounting firm skirted jail time yesterday when a federal judge sentenced him to probation for hoarding stock in Sirius, the satellite radio company the radio host moved to, days before the deal was announced.
As the star expert for the plaintiff firm Milberg Weiss, John Torkelsen became a legend for his ability to cap an all-night binge with a crack performance in a deposition the next morning.
Apple's popular iTunes music-download service is facing fresh legal attacks in Europe.
Baugur, the Icelandic group vying for control of House of Fraser, is set to start due diligence on the department stores group after its indicative 356 million pounds offer won initial approval.
South Korea's Board of Audit and Inspection is likely to refer Lone Star Funds' purchase of the Korea Exchange Bank to the prosecutors' office, according to The Financial Times.

True Religion Apparel, a publicly-traded make of designer jeans, has put itself up for sale, hoping to cash in on the new attraction of private equity firms and apparel companies to high-priced and fast-growing clothing brands. The Los Angeles-based company has hired Goldman Sachs as adviser, according to The Daily Deal.

The fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld has spun gold with his luxury designs for Chanel and Fendi, and his one-season budget collection for H&M was a retail phenomenon in 2004, with customers lining up in the streets.
Mekong Capital has announced that it has opened its second private equity fund, the fully-subscribed $50 million Mekong Enterprise Fund II.

OncoMed Pharmaceuticals, a company developing therapeutics to target cancer stem cells, has raised $3.7 million in a third tranche of its Series A financing round. OncoMed also said that it has signed a development deal with a German antibody company, MorphoSys.
GreatPoint Energy reportedly has raised $30 million in a second round of funding as it designs a process to derive clean biofuels from coal.

A Shanghai-based mobile device chipmaker, Fangtek Electronics, became the latest Chinese startup to lean heavily on United States backers, landing $12 million in a Series C investment from a coalition of Chinese and United States investors as companies in the United States continue to make record venture investments in China.

On the surface, Colombo, Sri Lanka, may seem like a strange place for Intel Capital to invest $4 million in a new Web services middleware developer, but according to Sanjiva Weerawarana, the chief executive officer of WSO2, there are few other places the investor would actually want to be.
Walden International, Asia's biggest venture capital firm, said on Thursday it is ready to invest $100 million in companies building products designed to work on compact I.B.M. computer servers.
About 200,000 Kenyans bought shares last month in the country's biggest initial public offering after the government floated a 30 percent stake in Kenya Electricity Generating, or KenGen.
The British cinema chain Cineworld Group, owned by the Blackstone Group, has postponed its planned initial public offering, citing stock-market volatility.

Vonage Holdings, the year's worst-performing initial public offering, said Thursday it plans to contest two shareholder securities fraud lawsuits against the Internet phone company, several of its officers and directors, and its underwriters.
A federal appeals court ordered yesterday that two former Merrill Lynch bankers convicted for their role in fraudulently inflating Enron's profits be released from prison.
Venture-backed TorreyPines Therapeutics has signed a reverse merger agreement with publicly traded Axonyx, the latest biopharmaceutical company to go this route in lieu of an initial public offering.

It's been a big week for Cisco Systems. The tech company said yesterday that it plans to buy back up to $5 billion of its common shares and that the chief executive, John Chambers, will also become chairman.

Sun Microsystems is ready to move off campus. In a bid to cut costs, Sun sold its Newark campus for $215 million to BioMed Realty Trust, which plans to turn it into a life sciences complex to house companies in the growing biotechnology industry.

Electronic Data Systems, the world's second-largest computer services company after I.B.M., said Thursday that it had acquired a controlling stake in Mphasis, an Indian outsourcing company, for $380 million.

Determined to expand its reach into Western Europe, Gazprom, Russia's state-owned natural gas producer, has agreed with Gasunie, the Dutch gas trading company, to exchange stakes in a move that would give Gazprom access to the British market.

Widespread global wealth creation has fueled record-setting auction seasons with jaw-dropping sales like the recent auction of Picasso's portrait of his mistress Dora Maar, which fetched $95.2 million (it was expected to sell for $50 million) and Jeff Koons's vacuum cleaners encased in a Plexiglas box, which sold for $5.3 million (estimate: $2.5 million to $5.3 million).
The president of the European Central Bank said Thursday that he would prefer to see Euronext merge with another European stock exchange operator, but added that the view was a personal one.

Televisa, the Mexican media group, is considering establishing its own United States broadcasting network if it fails to acquire Univision Communications, the largest Spanish-language television and radio group in the United States, which is being auctioned for more than $12 billion, The Financial Times reported.
One of the chief critics of Micron Technology's $741 million acquisition of Lexar Media has sold its equity holdings in the target, buoying the merger's chances of succeeding.
France Télécom surprised industry observers by joining the Washington buyout shop Carlyle Group in negotiations to buy Austrian telecom One for an estimated 1.5 billion euros ($1.9 billion).

Mittal Steel has an ally in its fight to take over Arcelor - the former United States attorney general, John Ashcroft. Mr. Ashcroft, a conservative Republican, set up the Ashcroft Group, a well-connected lobbying firm, after he left the Bush administration at the beginning of 2005.
The Tribune Company says it is sticking to a stock buyback plan, but investors yesterday reacted as if the company might be in play.
The German exchange operator Deutsche Börse wants to raise the cash component of its merger proposal with pan-European rival Euronext, a German weekly said on Friday.
German drugs and chemicals group Merck has raised its holding in a rival, Schering, to just over 10 percent, threatening a planned takeover of Schering by Bayer.

If you live in the Anglophone world, you're familiar with the concept of English spine, English bottle, the stiff upper lip or any number of other ways of expressing the idea that when the going gets rough, the English know how to tough it out. But you probably don't know about a concept that is well known in the Latin American world: Paraguayan guts, or garra guaraní. It, too, refers to the putative national trait of enduring hardship bravely, though with a slight difference.

Linda A. Rock, Riverdale, N.Y.: Far more of concern than any of the issues and questions you raised is the fact the process of voting in the U.S. is broken, perhaps irrevocably. Some partisans may be secretly satisfied by the nearly-proved-as-fact suspicion that the past two U.S. presidential elections were illegitimately conducted. Regardless, all Americans who have paid more than a little attention should be deeply troubled by the increasingly strong probability that a large plurality of their votes are neither verifiable nor correctly counted.

State Senator Thomas K. Duane, a Manhattan Democrat, introduced a bill yesterday to prohibit schools from confiscating students' cellphones. Cellphones have been banned in New York City public schools for years, but many schools quietly allowed them. The issue gained prominence two months ago, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that the police would conduct surprise scanning at city schools in a new effort to crack down on weapons. Cellphones were among the items banned. Parents, students, politicians and the city teachers' union have called for the mayor to lift the ban. Mr. Duane's bill would prohibit students from using cellphones at school.

In a setback to the city's attempt to cut down on graffiti, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit refused yesterday to stay an earlier court ruling that struck down a law intended to keep graffiti tools away from young vandals. The law, which took effect in January, prohibits the sale of spray paint and broad-tipped markers to people up to 21 years old. The appeals court ruling means that the law cannot be enforced while the earlier court ruling, issued on May 1, is appealed.

A state judge refused to grant a temporary restraining order yesterday to a consortium of hospitals, nursing homes and labor groups seeking to prevent Gov. George E. Pataki from submitting his budget without recognizing several legislative overrides of his vetoes. The overrides, passed by the Legislature, would have restored hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of health care funds, but the governor has said they are unconstitutional. Justice Louis B. York of State Supreme Court did not address the merits of the case, but said the request for a restraining order was complicated by the need to file a spending plan by June 30 to qualify for federal matching funds. Susan Waltman, a lawyer for the Greater New York Hospital Association, said,

A student who says she was raped by a fellow Coast Guard Academy cadet had consensual sex with him after the supposed rape occurred, defense lawyers said in court documents released yesterday. Lawyers for the defendant, Cadet Webster M. Smith, said they would question the woman to show that the charge was fabricated as part of an effort by several cadets to falsely accuse Mr. Smith.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed George A. Fertitta, left, a veteran advertising executive, as chief executive of the city's newly integrated tourism, marketing and event-planning operation. Mr. Fertitta, 59, was chairman and founder of Margeotes Fertitta Powell, an agency best known for creating ads for luxury goods like Godiva chocolates. Maureen Reidy, who was promoted to be the city's chief marketing officer, and Cristyne L. Nicholas, who has been chief executive of the tourism promotion bureau NYC & Company, will report to Mr. Fertitta.

Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have allowed more than 50,000 home day care providers to unionize as state employees, the administration said yesterday. The bill, supported by several public employee unions, would have classified day care providers receiving government subsidies as public employees for bargaining on wages, benefits and work conditions. The governor said the measure would inappropriately deem the workers state employees and would jeopardize $315 million in federal block grant funds for child care programs.

A former committeeman in Middletown Township was convicted yesterday of five corruption charges in Federal District Court, prosecutors said. The defendant, Raymond J. O'Grady, 56, was found guilty of accepting payments from undercover F.B.I. agents posing as vendors trying to obtain municipal contracts. He is scheduled to be sentenced in September and faces up to 71 months in federal prison.

Five months after several plastic bags of body parts were found along a road in the South Mountain Reservation, investigators using DNA testing. have determined that the body parts belonged to Viktor Alekseyeva, 35, of Brooklyn, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor's office. Several days after the bags were found in January, a friend of Mr. Alekseyeva's told the authorities that he had not heard from him in some time. Investigators relied on a saliva sample from Mr. Alekseyeva's mother to make a positive identification.

County Executive Andrew J. Spano has issued an executive order that makes Westchester the first county in the state to recognize gay marriages. Mr. Spano read the order at a meeting of gay groups on Wednesday night, and received a standing ovation. The order gives married gay couples the same county privileges as heterosexual couples, like the right to buy family passes to county parks and the right to seek emergency housing as a family. The order does not require towns and villages within the county to recognize the marriages. New York City and several other municipalities in the state already recognize gay marriages.

A 14-year-old boy pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder in the shooting death of another teenager on a Harlem street last year. The boy, Lmani Delima of Springfield Gardens, Queens, changed his plea to guilty after 10 jurors were selected for his trial in State Supreme Court. He was 13 when he killed Phoenix Garrett, 15, a student at A. Philip Randolph High School, during an argument on June 16, 2005. The judge promised Lmani, who was to be tried as an adult, a sentence of 8 years to life in prison.

A transit worker was charged yesterday with stealing $90,808 in public assistance and Medicaid benefits from the New York City Human Resources Administration, the state welfare inspector general, Paul Balukas, said. According to charges filed in Brooklyn Criminal Court, the transit worker, Ronald Woodhouse, 56, defrauded the welfare agency from April 2002 to October 2004 by claiming to be unemployed and poor while he was earning $43,000 a year as a cleaner at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The Giants signed the former New Orleans Saints tight end Boo Williams and waived tight end Matt Kranchick. Williams missed the 2005 season after tearing an anterior cruciate ligament in the preseason and was released by the Saints in February. During the four previous seasons, he caught 107 passes for 1,143 yards and 12 touchdowns.

Wedding parties and other groups hoping to commemorate their special event with a photograph at the Lincoln Memorial, Washington Monument or other popular landmarks on National Park Service land now have to pay for a permit. Under a policy that began May 15, the Park Service is requiring a payment of $50 to $250 from groups that hire commercial photographers to snap pictures at some of the 390 monuments, parks and historic sites it oversees. The cost depends on the size of the group. The fees are being charged at some of the busiest Park Service sites, including the Grand Canyon and the Statue of Liberty.

The mayor of a Chicago suburb was arrested on federal corruption charges and accused of steering local business owners to an insurance agency, Ralph Weiner & Associates, of Wheeling, that in return paid him hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes and kickbacks over 17 years. The mayor, Nicholas B. Blase, 78, who has been mayor of the village of Niles for 45 years, was charged with mail fraud. A lawyer for Mr. Blase, Harvey M. Silets, said his client denied wrongdoing.

A former state senator was convicted of extortion for taking payoffs from a fake company set up by the F.B.I. to catch corrupt lawmakers. The defendant, Roscoe Dixon, a Memphis Democrat, was the first of five lawmakers charged in the case to go to trial. Mr. Dixon was accused of taking $9,500 in bribes to help the company, E-Cycle, change state law so it could buy and recycle used government computers. After the verdict, Mr. Dixon told reporters he had been tricked by the federal government. The maximum penalty is 90 years in prison and a $1.25 million fine, but federal sentencing guidelines call for a much lighter punishment.
House and Senate Republican leaders completed agreement on a long-sought $94.5 billion bill to pay for the war in Iraq.
A Wildlife Conservation Society program is intended to help thousands of volunteer birders around the globe build a database tracking the migration patterns of all species.

A St. Peters woman angry that her new puppy had died pushed her way into a dog breeder's home and repeatedly hit the breeder on the head with the dead Chihuahua, the authorities said. The woman, 33, went to the home early Wednesday and tried to get another puppy, but the fight ensued, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported. The police said they were considering burglary and assault charges against the woman.
Braking a steep slide in global equity markets, American stocks retraced their losses Thursday, recovering to finish roughly where they began.
Germany suffered a setback when captain Michael Ballack was ruled out of the opening game against Costa Rica.  The game between Germany and Costa Rica in Munich is the first of 64 World Cup matches.

The site of the Berlin bunker where Hitler committed suicide has been marked with a sign for the first time. Berlin Underworlds, which organizes tours of World War II bomb shelters, said its sign, along with a display in German and English of the bunker's layout, had the support of city officials. In the past Berlin had resisted indicating the exact location of the so-called Führerbunker for fear that it could become a shrine for Neo-Nazis.

Haya Rashed al-Khalifa, a Bahraini lawyer who is the first woman in her country to serve as a diplomat, was elected president of the General Assembly. She is the first woman to be president of the 191-member body since 1969, when Angie Brooks of Liberia served, and she will take up her one-year position with the opening of the 61st General Assembly on Sept. 12. Ms. Khalifa, 53, who in the 1970's became one of the first women in Bahrain to practice law, has been Bahrain's ambassador to France and its permanent delegate to Unesco. She succeeds Jan Eliasson, Sweden's foreign minister.

At least 55 people have been killed and 12 are missing amid the worst flooding in parts of eastern China in three decades, the government said. At least 378,000 people had already been evacuated from the provinces of Fujian, Guangdong and Guizhou because of floods prompted by an unusually heavy seasonal monsoon.

Splinter factions of two Sudanese rebel groups that rejected the Darfur peace accord last month said they had signed a document pledging to abide by its principles. The earlier agreement was signed by the Sudanese government and the largest of the Darfur rebel groups, the Sudan Liberation Movement. A faction of that group and a smaller rebel group, the Justice and Equality Movement, had refused to sign, and officials from the Africa Union, which backed the accord, had become increasingly frustrated with the holdouts.

In the basement of a weathered grocery store on a gentrifying stretch of downtown White Plains, Feeling Mizik, a Haitian compas band, rehearses every Saturday night. Compas, Haiti's popular music, is rooted in a fusion of African rhythms, Haitian Creole culture and European ballroom dancing. And these days it is frequently updated with strains of hip-hop, funk and salsa, its Creole lyrics meshed with English and Spanish.

PAWLING, a community at the southern edge of Dutchess County with scenic horse farms and stunning vistas, is less than two hours from New York City by the Metro-North Railroad -- but weekend residents who prefer a shorter trip can travel by private helicopter. About 70 miles north of Midtown Manhattan, Pawling is a town where extravagance is embraced. ''We do a great job protecting all of our environmental features,'' said Beth Coursen, the town supervisor, mentioning the zoning restrictions that have limited development and preserved sprawling open space. ''But we are billionaire friendly. Unlike some towns south of us -- Bedford, for instance -- we allow private helipads. We have a permitting process for helipads.''
