To the Editor: Does the Bush administration honestly believe that displaying gigantic framed photographs of one bloodied, dead terrorist, while prohibiting the photographing of thousands of flag-draped coffins returning with our war dead, will confuse the American public as to the real outcome of this calamitous misstep in American policy? Charles Fowler Exeter, N.H., June 9, 2006

An article last Saturday about the official reaction by Iran to incentives offered by foreign leaders to stop all nuclear activities misidentified the nuclear fuel produced by the country's heavy-water program. It is plutonium, not enriched uranium.

Democrats are months away from elections to decide control of the House, but the prospect of grabbing the majority in November is bringing out ambition and division in the party ranks. Representative John P. Murtha, a Pennsylvanian who has become a leading Democratic voice against the Iraq war, surprised many colleagues Friday by circulating a letter announcing that he would be a candidate for majority leader should his party gain 15 or more seats to topple Republicans from power.

A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday misidentified the producer of ''Dead City,'' at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, and misstated the number of new plays the theater company 13P has produced in the last month. While the author of ''Dead City,'' Sheila Callaghan, is a member of the 13P group, the play is produced by the New Gorges company. The number of new plays 13P has produced in the last month is two, not three.

To the Editor: Barry R. Chiswick is correct in saying ''there are no low-skilled jobs that American workers would not and do not do.''

9 P.M. (BBC America) SHARPE'S COMPANY -- Sean Bean (right) is Richard Sharpe, a maverick rifleman fighting Napoleon, in the United States premiere of this British television series from the 1990's, based on Bernard Cornwell's novels. In this episode, from 1994, he must save his Spanish lover, Teresa (Assumpta Serna), who has just told him that they have a baby daughter. 7:30 P.M. (Showtime) RE: EVOLUTION OF SPORTS -- The season finale of this series looks at the paths forged by Jamie O'Brien, a rip curl pipeline masters champion; Victoria Jealouse, an extreme backcountry snowboarder; and Jay Quinlan, a freestyle snowmobiler, as they continue to push beyond the boundaries. 8 P.M. (History Channel) AMAZON ADVENTURES -- Since the 15th century, the Amazon -- a largely uncharted region some 2.7 million square miles in scope, stretching across eight South American countries -- has held the imagination of explorers who traversed its colossal river and boundless jungles for hidden riches. This special extols the exploits of adventurers who have mined the Amazon for treasures cultural and scientific as well as of a more lucrative, if mythical, nature. 8 P.M. (TLC) FLIP IT FAST -- Five of the country's most successful house flippers reveal the nuts and bolts of buying, fixing and selling property -- stat! -- to turn a quick profit. At 10, ''This House Must Go'' apportions the time, effort and investment that should go into remodeling a home. 8:30 P.M. (Sundance) JANICE BEARD 45 WPM -- (1999). Been there, done that. That's the story of Ms. Beard (Eileen Walsh), an eccentric Scot who gets a temp job in London to pay for treatment for her deeply traumatized mother -- ''postnatal, postmortem depression,'' anyone? -- but winds up an unwitting pawn of an industrial saboteur (the always amusing Rhys Ifans, above, with Ms. Walsh). 9 P.M. (Logo) WHEN OCEAN MEETS SKY -- With its heady mixture of sand, surf and social scene, Fire Island Pines has become one of the world's most celebrated gay resorts. This documentary chronicles the community's transformation from nudist colony to gay mecca, and reflects on the political, environmental and social battles fought throughout its history. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) BLACK HOLE -- An atomic research experiment goes awry in St. Louis, creating a big black hole and unleashing a creature from the beyond that feeds on the electricity pulsing beneath the city's streets. And oh, yeah -- its appetite is large enough to swallow the Midwest whole. 10 P.M. (HBO) LEWIS BLACK: RED, WHITE AND SCREWED -- Mr. Black (right), ever the wry social observer, cerebrates on topics including the war in Iraq, Hurricane Katrina and FEMA, gay marriage, the Dick Cheney shooting incident, President Bush, fossils and evolution. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
GLADSTONE--Irving. Another year today, Irving--nothing changes--I miss you all the time. Bertha

To the Editor: You rightly point out that the deaths or killings of iconic leaders alone cannot mitigate the Iraqi insurgency. But the formation of a representative and democratically elected Iraqi government is not the only ingredient missing from the recipe for a stable Iraq.

To the Editor: Re ''Block the Vote, Ohio Remix'' (editorial, June 7):

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about an agreement by International Paper to sell its coated-paper business to Apollo Management misidentified the source. It was by Bloomberg News, not by Reuters.

McCULLOUGH--John P. Of Princeton died unexpectedly in his home on Tuesday, June 6, 2006 at age of 81. He was a long-time resident of Princeton and a retired executive from Mobil Oil Corporation in Pennington. He is survived by his wife, Ann Calvert McCullough; three daughters, Sherrill M. Davis of Haverford, PA, Cathryn M. Delude of Andover, MA, and Patricia McCullough of NYC; and three grandchildren, Philip M. Delude, Patricia M. Delude, and Michael Gene Davis. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 10, 2006 at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton at 2PM, immediately followed by a reception at the main Windrows Complex. For information, Kimble Funeral Home (609924-0018). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to support research at the Alzheimer's Association.

The police in Hanover searched the Dartmouth College fraternity house that inspired the 1978 movie ''National Lampoon's Animal House'' for more than five hours on Thursday. The search was part of a nearly two-year investigation, they said. A member of the fraternity, Alpha Delta, was arrested on drug charges and released. The police said that the student, 19, was charged with marijuana possession and that a second student was expected to face a similar charge. Police Chief Nicholas J. Giaccone Jr. would not reveal the nature of the investigation, and a judge has placed the search warrant and affidavits under seal. The police removed 10 crates, 2 bags, a videotape and a computer, the Associated Press reported. ''The primary object of the search was not drugs,'' Chief Giaccone said, but would not comment further. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''After Long Hunt, U.S. Bombs Kill Al Qaeda Leader in Iraq'' (front page, June 9):

In the preliminary Nielsen estimates for Thursday's ratings, ABC scored a rare victory for the night in households and in the 18-to-49 demographic because of Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals, in which the Dallas Mavericks beat the Miami Heat. CBS, led by reruns of ''CSI'' (12.37 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (11.1 million), appeared to be No. 1 among total viewers but was dragged down by ''Game Show Marathon'' at 8 (6.84 million). CBS placed fourth for the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox was second behind ABC in that age group: a rerun of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (6.37 million) was followed by a new episode (10 million). And NBC broadcast four repeats of ''My Name Is Earl,'' along with the premiere of ''Windfall.'' That be-careful-what-you-wish-for lottery drama delivered 8.98 million viewers at 10 and beat ''Without a Trace'' in the 18-to-49 demographic. But it lost some of its audience from the first half-hour to the second, which can sometimes be a harbinger of failure. KATE AURTHUR

A sports article on Sunday about the comeback of the Edmonton Oilers misstated the given name of the team's owner in 1988, when the Oilers traded Wayne Gretzky to the Los Angeles Kings. It is Peter Pocklington, not Paul.

Polio Strikes in Namibia, Infecting Mostly Adults Officials in Namibia are dealing with a polio outbreak that has killed 7 Namibians and left 33 paralyzed. Many who fell ill, unlike their counterparts in other countries, are adults, partly because regular vaccinations for children in the country began after 1990. Is same-sex marriage on a collision course with religious liberty? It wasn't surprising that before the constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage died in the Senate this week, several senators supporting it raised that danger. But when highly respected legal experts on civil liberties, including ones favoring same-sex marriage, raise the same possibility, their concerns cannot be dismissed as partisan debating points.

Leslie Hansen Kopp, a dance and music archivist, died on May 27 in Manhattan. She was 53. The cause was breast cancer, said George Boziwick, a friend and the chief of the music division at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

An article on Tuesday about a State Department report on human trafficking, in which Germany was warned that its laws permitting prostitution could compound the problem during the World Cup, misstated the number of countries subjected to economic and security sanctions by the United States for failing to crack down on human trafficking since 2003, when the sanctions provision took effect. It is three, not two. (Besides Venezuela and Equatorial Guinea, Cambodia has been cited.)

RECNY--Christopher John. Passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family and friends on June 4, 2006, aged 52 years. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Jane, his children, Loveday, Myles and EmilyJane, his mother, brothers, sisters and many friends. Private funeral service. Friends and relatives are invited to a a memorial service Thursday 15th June at 2:30 P.M. at St. Thomas' Anglican Church, North Sydney. Please no flowers. Donations please to CAF Community Foundation--The Chris Recny Foundation. Mail to: LEK Sydney, Attn: Nina Keily; Level 36, Aurora Place; 88 Phillip St.; Sydney, NSW 2000, Australia.

A chart in Weekend on May 26 with an article about the jazz renaissance in Brooklyn erroneously included one club among those on hiatus. The Puppets Jazz Bar in Park Slope is open, offering live jazz six nights a week.

A sports article on Thursday about young soccer players to watch in the World Cup misspelled the surname of the midfielder who was replaced by Cesc Fabregas last season with the club team Arsenal in England. He is Patrick Vieira, not Viera. A chart in the sports section the same day listing the United States soccer team roster misstated the club teams for two players in some copies. Eddie Pope plays for Real Salt Lake of Major League Soccer, not Salt Lake City; and Claudio Reyna for Manchester City in England, not Manchester United.

To the Editor: Now that the legislature of the Philippines has abolished the death penalty (World Briefing item, June 8), the United States belongs to a small club that is getting even more exclusive.

A sports article in some copies yesterday about the Dallas Mavericks' 90-80 victory over the visiting Miami Heat in the opener of the N.B.A. finals referred incorrectly to the arena where Games 1 and 2 are being played. It is American Airlines Center. (American Airlines Arena is in Miami.) The article also misidentified the team that took an 82-72 lead with 7 minutes 55 seconds remaining. It was Dallas.

To the Editor: Sad to say, but Deputy Secretary General Mark Malloch Brown has it exactly right about the United States' hypocritical behavior at the United Nations (''Official of U.N. Says Americans Undermine It With Criticism,'' news article, June 7).

The United States and Chinese Olympic committees signed an agreement of cooperation yesterday, opening an exchange leading up to the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing. Each country will send delegations of athletes, coaches and administrators to the other to share information about training and research.

The drug and chemical maker Bayer said yesterday that it was buying shares of Schering on the open market in reaction to Merck of Germany's taking a 10.1 percent stake in Schering. Earlier this year, Bayer initiated a takeover bid of 16.5 billion euros ($20.9 billion) for Schering, trumping a hostile offer of 14.9 billion euros by Merck, which later pulled out. European and United States regulators have approved the deal. Schering is based in Berlin.

An article in Business Day on May 26 about plans to rescind the federal excise tax on long-distance phone calls referred imprecisely to the history of the tax. While it was first instituted 108 years ago, it has been repealed and reinstated at least twice, leaving periods of several years when it was not in force.

An article on Sunday about criticism of the United States detention center in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, by Baltasar Garzón, Spain's most prominent investigative magistrate, during an antiterrorism conference, misstated the year of the Madrid train bombing at one point. It was March 2004, not 2003.

TEITELBAUM -- Herbert I., age 80, passed away on June 8, 2006. Cherished husband of Renee (nee Landwehr), and beloved father of Gary (Nerine), and Amy Nelson (Joel). Adored grandfather to Ashleigh, Meredith, Stacy, Jonathan, Chretien and Colton. He graduated from Bronx Science H.S. and City College. Decorated veteran of World War II. He was our leader. Always the wise one. He will be missed by all. Funeral: Sinai Chapel, Fresh Meadows, New York, 12 noon, June 11.

The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday, about initial public offerings by Russian companies, referred incorrectly to the recent offering by CTC Media Inc., a network of television stations. CTC Media was the third Russian company to list on Nasdaq, not the first. (It followed Golden Telecom and Moscow Cable Communications.)

To the Editor: ''Delusions of the Rich and Rent-Controlled,'' by John Tierney (column, June 3), portrays many of the oddities and possible injustices of New York City's rent control system. But lurking behind that is a far broader, more serious issue. And that is the role of ''the market'' in the United States housing system.

The Joe Nocera column in Business Day last Saturday, ruminations on a number of topics, referred incorrectly to a $165 million donation to the Oklahoma State University athletic department by Boone Pickens, the hedge fund manager. The money will be used to build an athletic village near the university; it will not be spent to improve the university's golf team.

JOHNSON--Edna. Died on June 6, 2006 in Glendale, Queens. Surviving are her sons Fred Cushmore, Raymond Johnson and Roger Johnson and daughter Jill Nord. Grandmother of 11 and greatgrandmother of 17. Loved and deeply missed.
A report in the What's Offline column in Business Day last Saturday, about an article in Ladies' Home Journal on vacation time shares, referred incorrectly to the author. Brett Graff is a woman.

A few thousand dollars used to be a hefty fine for broadcasting a four letter word or a dirty joke. Over the last six years, the Federal Communications Commission has levied increasing fines on noncable television and nonsatellite radio broadcasters for ''indecent'' and profane'' acts.

EDELSTEIN--Ruth (Schnitzer). Age 82, on June 8, 2006, Rye, NY. Wife of the late Alfred Edelstein; mother of Richard, Charles (Tuck) and Laura Kinyon; grandmother of Asher and Miles. Ruth grew up in New Rochelle and moved to Harrison with Alfred where they raised their family. In recent years they lived together in The Osborn in Rye. Trained in commercial art, Ruth was a homemaker, volunteer, and enthusiastic participant in the worlds of dance and music, painting and ceramics. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Memorial contributions welcome to Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance and the Alzheimer's Foundation of America. Funeral services Monday, June 12, 4:00 pm at The Osborn, Rye, New York.

The Budapest Journal on Thursday, about a musical based on the story of Crown Prince Rudolf of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, gave an incorrect name for Hungary's fascist party in the Nazi era, part of a list of miseries Hungary experienced after the empire fell. It was the Arrow Cross, not the Iron Cross. The article also misspelled the name of Rudolf's mother. She was Empress Elisabeth, not Elizabeth.
The center fielder with the most home runs in baseball does not play for the Atlanta Braves. So there goes Andruw Jones. He does not play for the Toronto Blue Jays. Bye-bye, Vernon Wells.

SIMMONS--Jack L., 86, of New York, NY, passed away on June 7, 2006, in Gainesville, FL. Born in Montgomery, AL, and later moving to New York. Mr. Simmons worked for International Longevity Center. He received his Master's degree from Fordam University and also served in the U.S. Navy. Mr. Simmons volunteered and donated to New York museums, AIDS Network, and S.A.G.E. He contributed to many charities and local causes that were near and dear to his heart in the greater New York area. He was a lover and participant in theater, opera, and the arts. He is survived by six nieces, his loving family and friends. Information, Forest Meadows Funeral Home, Gainesville, FL.

I hereby declare this week to be ... Mad Scientist Week! In that spirit, I'm going experimental. Over the next five days, I will describe a few experiments I'd like to see done, and why. The first is to answer this question: Can taking the oral contraceptive pill change a woman's taste in men?

Last Thursday I was having my first final examination of the year. When I got out of the classroom, questions about soil mechanics (part of my civil engineering studies) were still bouncing around in my head. I heard someone saying something about Zarqawi. But I was not really interested. I was more interested in checking with the other students to see how well I did on the test. Then one of my friends told me that his parents phoned to tell him that Zarqawi was killed on Wednesday evening. At first that sounded more like a rumor to me. Zarqawi had been hunted down for a long time and it did not look like they would ever catch him. Then the word spread fast. More students were saying the same thing, and citing different sources.

Welcome back to the New York Times's live Web coverage of the World Cup. Click on "more" for live updates on the all the action from Cologne. As soon as it hits our TV screen, it'll hit your computer screen.

Readers following our live coverage so far may have noticed that we're huge fans of mobile or moblogging and have been posting pictures taken at bars of fans cheering on their nations from these miniature ethnic enclaves around New York City inside some of our live game coverage. We've been using a souped-up mobile phone, the Nokia N90, to post these photos to our blog from those viewing spots as the games are in progress. Now a reader, D. Rhead, has written in to alert us to his contribution to a similar though far, far more massive project going on at the photo-sharing site Flickr's wonderful "! World Cup (impressions) FIFA WM 2006 Fotos" group. This huge collection of photographs taken by and of fans around the planet -- but mainly close to the action in Germany -- is already up to 2,671 images, taken by 802 photographers, and it offers us a fascinating look at how many different ways the Cup is being followed around the world. You can scroll through the thumbnails and see larger versions of any of the photographs or just set the slide-show at 3 seconds per picture, press play and spend the next 2 hours watching the world watch.

Starting eighth, the British driver who leads the series and won the race yesterday and in Monaco, fought his way up to win. As far as Sunday's Iran-Mexico match is concerned, the English-language news media has been focusing, understandably, on Iran. On Saturday, The Times had an interesting article recapping the ways in which Iranians' obsession with soccer trumps some of the restrictions the government and cultural traditions place on individual expression. And then there's the ongoing news involving President Ahmadinejad's Holocaust denials, the appeal they hold for European ultraright groups and now, plans to stage protests against Ahmadinejad by Jewish groups and conservative and liberal German politicians in Nuremburg and other cities where Iran will play. It's gotten to the point where even soccer reporters have lost sight of the game itself and are now peppering Iran's Croatian coach with questions about Ahmadinejad's views.

Some orchestras take a safely inclusive approach to contemporary music, making sure to touch all stylistic camps in their programming. This has not been the way of the adventurous RIVERSIDE SYMPHONY, which ends its 25th-anniversary season with a concert on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall. Over the years GEORGE ROTHMAN, the music director, and ANTHONY KORF, the artistic director, have championed select contemporary composers they believe in, among them the French master Henri Dutilleux, the Danish eclectic Poul Ruders and the dynamic American Stephen Hartke. Another American, ANDREW IMBRIE, has also been a Riverside Symphony favorite. Mr. Rothman conducted the orchestra in an acclaimed 1999 Bridge Records CD, which offered gripping accounts of Mr. Imbrie's Requiem and Piano Concerto No. 3. Mr. Imbrie, who celebrates his 85th birthday this year, writes works that in their structures honor the precedents of the classical tradition, but that speak with a gnarly and arrestingly modern harmonic voice. Thursday's program presents the New York premiere of his 1970 Symphony No. 2. Mr. Rothman will also conduct two 19th-century Nordic works: the Second Symphony of the Danish composer NIELS GADE, in its American premiere, and GRIEG's ever-popular Piano Concerto, with TERRENCE WILSON as soloist. At 7:30 p.m., Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $45 and $25. The concert week kicks off today with two afternoon events. The essential FREE FOR ALL AT TOWN HALL series presents the New York debut of the emerging violinist ARABELLA STEINBACHER, born in 1981 to a German father and Japanese mother. With the pianist ROBERT KULEK, she will play works by Grieg, Schnittke, Brahms and Ravel. (Today at 5 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, freeforallattownhall.org; free, tickets distributed today starting at noon.) And LEON BOTSTEIN conducts the AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA in ''From Russia With Mozart.'' It begins with Rimsky-Korsakov's one-act opera ''Mozart and Salieri,'' which anticipates Peter Shaffer's play ''Amadeus,'' and it ends with Alexander Dargomyzhsky's opera ''The Stone Guest,'' based on Pushkin's version of the Don Juan legend. 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 247-7800; $25 to $53.

To the Editor: Mr. Kozinn writes that cities include new concert halls on their lists of ''must-have status symbols.'' This may be admirable, but the building, too often, is the focus of attention, when what happens inside is far more important. An inanimate structure neither entertains nor educates. The performances are patronized, sadly, by an exclusive minority. Mr. Kozinn is correct that it is necessary to ''grab the dorsal fin,'' but without making music education a priority, it is unlikely that the ''fin'' will be up for grabs anytime soon. Caroline Stoessinger New York City The writer is a professor of music at John Jay College of Criminal Justice.

THE sign on the Lou Gehrig baseball says ''Not for Sale,'' but that does not stop memorabilia collectors and sports fans who flock to the Hobby Shop in Aberdeen from asking Marvin Schutzer, the owner, to name his price. ''One guy walked in here and said: 'How much do you want for it? I'll pay anything, anything,' '' Mr. Schutzer, 65, recalled. ''But I told him what I tell everyone else, that the ball means too much to me to ever want to part with it and that one day it will go to my oldest son, with instructions never to sell.''

HALPERN--Dr. Seymour. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our longtime devoted member, Dr. Seymour Halpern, beloved husband of Elizabeth, father of Vivienne, Ronald, and Adrienne. The Halperns have been members of Rodeph Sholom for almost 50 years. Our deepest sympathy is extended to all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD Senior Rabbi Roger Meltzer, President $(6$)HALPERN--Seymour L., MD, FACP, FACN./d 1922-2006. Dr. Seymour L. Halpern, 83, of New York City, died on June 7th. Beloved husband of Elizabeth for 18 years, dear father of Adrienne, Vivienne and Ronald, and joyful grandfather of Alex, Sam, Ben and Anna. His first wife of 28 years, Dr. Anafred Nelson Halpern, was a pediatrician who died in 1981. He was a physician for 58 years and a leader in the medical field in understanding and promoting the importance of clinical nutrition. He served as a captain in the United States Air Force in World War II as physician in charge of a field hospital. Dr. Halpern was one of the founders of the American College of Nutrition in 1959, served as its president from 1971-1977, and remained an active participant in the organization. He served as president of The New York State Society of Internal Medicine, The New York County Society of Internal Medicine and the Food and Nutrition Council of Greater New York. He also chaired several committees of the American Society of Internal Medicine. Dr. Halpern was Vice President and Board Member of the NYU Medical School Alumni Association, president of The Beth Israel Hospital Alumni Association and was active in Columbia College alumni affairs. He served as a Board member of the West Side Chamber of Commerce and the Vacation and Community Services for the Blind. Dr. Halpern authored and edited ''Quick Reference to Clinical Nutrition: A Guide for Physicians,'' as well as authoring numerous articles, monographs and book chapters on nutrition, metabolism and cardiovascular diseases. He was an assistant clinical professor at New York Medical College. Dr. Halpern also lectured internationally in the fields of nutrition, diabetes and cardiovascular disease, and received the Purkinje Gold Medal from the Czechoslovakian Government in 1969 for his work in clinical nutrition. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York City, on Sunday, June 11th, at 11:30 am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Columbia College, c/o Paul Stoller, Seymour L. Halpern, MD Memorial Fund, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 917, NY, NY 10115, tel: 212870-2194; or to the Seymour and Elizabeth Halpern Scholarship Fund, c/o Financial Aid Office at NYU Medical School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016, tel: 212-263-5290
To the Editor: Re ''The Day the Musical Died'' by Ben Brantley [May 21]:

THE image is etched in his memory: a woman caressing the name of a soldier at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. Ned Benton, a college professor and history buff, wondered about the story behind that name, which made him think about the stories behind the names of the dozens of soldiers memorialized in the Village of Larchmont, where he lives. Eight years ago, as the village was updating its Web site, Mr. Benton and his colleagues at the Larchmont Historical Society had an idea: Why not use the Internet to tell the stories of these soldiers? The challenge was to uncover the information.

LEWIS--Norman. Joined his beloved wife Eva on June 6, 2006. Devoted father to Susan and Joan, he was a family man above all else. He cherished his home on Candlewood Lake and spent his summer days playing tennis, sailing, swimming and planting Pachysandra. An accomplished athlete, Norman captained the United States fencing team at the 1948 London Olympic Games competing in both the individual and team Epee events. He won the U.S. Foil Championships in 1939 and was the U.S. National Epee champion in 1948, 1949 & 1950. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to: The United States Fencing Association at 719866-4511.

SOKOL--Margaret McCor mack. 90, Sunday, June 4, 2006 in NYC after a short illness. Services private. $(6$)SOKOL--Margaret. A charming and discerning benefactor whose generosity was key to the development of structural DNA nanotechnology. Nadrian C. Seeman $(6$)SOKOL--Margaret. The Faculty of Arts and Science at NYU mourns the loss of our friend and benefactor, Margaret Sokol. Margaret was a spirited member of the Board of Overseers and a thoughtful patron of Arts and Science, supporting a wide range of initiatives including undergraduate scholarships, post doctoral fellowships, the Margaret and Herman Sokol Faculty Award in the Sciences and the Margaret and Herman Sokol Chair in Chemistry. We fondly remember Margaret's deep personal interest in our students and faculty and her great pride in their accomplishments. She will be missed. We offer our deep sympathies to her friends and family. Richard M. Foley, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science, NYU Peter Lennie, Dean for Science

To the Editor: Limiting eligibility based on theater capacity is indeed a flaw in the Tony Awards process. But so is having a completely original musical like ''The Drowsy Chaperone'' compete against a show with an established catalog of music, like ''Jersey Boys.'' Perhaps the Tonys should take a cue from the Oscars and split the best musical award into two categories: best original musical and best musical adaptation. Fred Cantor Westport, Conn.

Note to the new guy: Think twice before you agree to be paid in stock. That might be the best advice that James D. Carreker, the Bombay Company's former chief executive, can offer to his successor, David B. Stewart, who took over last week.

He had jolly good fun mocking struggling dot-com executives on his widely read Web site with the vulgar name, but now the shoe is on the other throat -- his. Philip J. Kaplan resigned last week as chief executive of the money-losing online advertising agency AdBrite, which he founded in 2004. While he will remain chairman and chief product officer of the agency which he says is growing rapidly, Mr. Kaplan has turned over day-to-day management to Ignacio J. Fanlo, a former investment banker with a record of building valuable Web properties.

To the Editor: I was pleased to read that the Connecticut section of The Times will begin regular publishing of editorials and Op-Ed articles (''A Letter From the Editor,'' by Gail Collins, June 4). This should make the section more relevant, with commentary on state issues and the subsequent input with letters from ''Nutmeggers'' statewide.

They are self-published, and I welcome calls at (608) 244-3359 or e-mail messages at Greenbush4 @aol.com for more information about ''A Taste of Memories From the Old 'Bush,' Volumes I and II'' (Madison, Wis.); as well as ''A Taste of Memories From Columbus Park, Volume III'' (Kenosha, Wis.); and ''Grandmothers of Greenbush.'' BURNSIDE--W. Glen. Died June 4. Loving husband and best friend to Jeanne Wigand. Sadly missed by his family and friends in Canada and NY. If desired, memorial donations to the Elija Foundation (www.elija.org). www.morrisfuneralchapel.ca

With ABC's ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Grey's Anatomy'' out of the way on Sundays, HBO can peek out from under the covers without the assistance of the Teflon ''Sopranos.'' Its ''DEADWOOD'' returns for a third and most likely final season at 9 p.m., and on ''ENTOURAGE'' at 10 p.m. the charmed Vince (ADRIAN GRENIER), the cursed Ari (JEREMY PIVEN) and Vince's acolytes anticipate the opening of ''Aquaman,'' which will determine their fates. After that are two new series: ''LUCKY LOUIE'' (10:30 p.m.), a sitcom with LOUIS C. K., and ''DANE COOK'S TOURGASM,'' an unscripted show that follows the stand-up comedian on the road. Two summer hits from basic cable also return this week. On the third season of ''THE 4400'' (USA, Sunday at 9 p.m.), the series resumes in its ''X-Files''-ish/''X-Men''-like way, as the returned abductees unleash their powers on the rest of the world. And on ''THE CLOSER'' (TNT, Monday at 9 p.m.), KYRA SEDGWICK's detective character continues to use her Southern noncharm to bug Los Angeles criminals into confessing. The dam breaks on the deluge of summer reality programming this week. ABC offers the frothy ''HOW TO GET THE GUY'' (Monday at 10 p.m.), in which four San Francisco women (the Party Girl, the Girl Next Door and so on) are coached in the ways of dating. The two coaches are engaging and practical -- they advise not getting wasted on dates -- and the women are likable (except for the New Age irritant known as the Dreamer). CBS's newest unscripted entry is ''THE TUESDAY NIGHT BOOK CLUB'' (Tuesday at 10 p.m.), which tries to be a real-life ''Desperate Housewives.'' And ''HELL'S KITCHEN,'' a success for FOX last summer, returns on Monday at 9 p.m. Chefs will try to avoid the wrath of their teacher, the screaming rage-aholic GORDON RAMSAY, and win a cooking competition.

MOST of the year, Simone Schloss of Pelham is Suburban Mom, slightly harried as she chauffeurs her three daughters and slaps together their sandwiches. But on some nights, some enchanted evenings, she is Simone Schloss, cabaret singer, chanteuse. After being primped by professionals, she slips her tall, slender figure into a sequined white gown. Then she takes the spotlight, leaning into the microphone or draping herself over a piano, and belts out standards to admirers sipping Scotch in the dark.

Visitation Sunday and Monday, 2-4 & 7-9pm, at Bay Ridge Funeral Home, 7614 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday, 9:30am, at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church.

To the Editor: After reading Amy Gunderson's ''Long Flight? You Don't Need To Go Hungry'' (Practical Traveler, May 28), it occurred to me: why shouldn't travelers go right to the source? I long ago gave up airline food, which was never palatable, in favor of purchasing local food on the way to the airport: a Cubano in Miami; fragrant chicken from the streets of Lisbon. The most memorable experience took place in Scotland and involved a mile jog to a smoked fish factory after returning our rental car. It created a vacation memory to last a lifetime. Helen Feit Villanova, Pa.
A report in the Pulse column last Sunday about lace-edged T-shirts by Under omitted the name of a store where the shirts are sold. It is Gatsbys, in Great Barrington, Mass. (413-528-9455).

To the Editor: ''More Awareness, More Cases'' (June 4) provides beneficial information regarding reasons for the yearly fluctuations in Lyme disease cases, basic information on disease transmission and patient symptoms, and successful prevention efforts in New Jersey. However, the article also perpetuates common but inaccurate myths about Lyme disease. One of these myths concerns Lyme disease testing. When used appropriately, Lyme disease testing is actually highly accurate. The estimate of 50 percent accuracy is true only when testing is inappropriately used early in the disease course during the rash phase of the illness where laboratory testing is not recommended or needed for diagnosis.

FEW people are more familiar with the layout of Winged Foot Golf Club than Tom Nieporte, 77, the club's head pro for the last 28 years. But lately, he hardly recognizes the place. The grounds have been invaded by more than 100 alien structures: huge white corporate tents along the club's demanding par 4's, television towers near its treacherous bunkers and grandstands around its famously slick greens.

ON the face of it, requiring all individuals convicted of any crime in New York State to give DNA samples for inclusion in a state database seems completely rational and unassailable. While the current law requires only the collection of DNA from those convicted of particular crimes, proponents of expanding DNA retrieval to include those convicted of any felony or misdemeanor argue that people who commit petty crimes are likely to commit more serious ones later. Moreover, their logic goes, if there are more samples in the database, then there will be more DNA matches and more criminals will be caught before they can break the law again. But there are serious implications to widespread testing that have been overlooked by its supporters in the State Senate, which has passed an expanded DNA collection bill, and in the Assembly, where a similar bill is pending. The pitfalls of adding an abundance of new DNA profiles to the state's database go far beyond legitimate concerns about the civil liberties of convicted criminals or innocent persons falsely accused.

To the Sports Editor: How callous to highlight Michelle Wie's failure to qualify for the United States Open with a huge photo on the front page of the newspaper (June 6), and hence highlight the inability of women to compete athletically with men.

MAYER--Dolf 1918 - 2006 Scarsdale NY. Beloved husband of the late Jill Russek, father of Valerie (Tony Torcia), grandfather of Anthony Tiliacos, Danielle & Adam Torcia. Born Germany, educated France, Holland & Scotland. Served in US Army, translator at liberation of Buchenwald & Nuremberg Trials. Principal in Mayer Cos. A generous gentleman who lived life on his own terms. Contributions to Scleroderma Federation, Teaneck NJ.

A review on May 28 about ''A Life Uncorked,'' a book of memoirs by the wine writer Hugh Johnson, referred incorrectly to a wine from Château Figeac discussed by Johnson at such length that he self-deprecatingly apologized to readers. Like all the wine produced there, it was a Bordeaux, not a Burgundy. (Château Figeac is in St.-Émilion, in the eastern part of the Bordeaux wine region.) The review also referred incorrectly to Château Latour, in the Bordeaux commune of Pauillac, on whose board Johnson has served. It is currently owned by François Pinault, a French industrialist; it has never been a ''Rothschild vineyard.''

3 P.M. (BBC America) QUEEN AND COUNTRY -- On June 15, Britain will celebrate the 80th birthday of Queen Elizabeth II (along with the 85th birthday of her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh). This four-hour special examines the key aspects of the reign of one of the world's most photographed personalities, who, even now, remains an enigma to her people. At 7, ''H.M. the Queen: A Remarkable Life'' looks at how the queen (above, shown arriving at Westminster Abbey on May 17) has weathered change during more than 50 years on the throne. 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 60TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS -- She may not have earned a Tony nomination, but her star turn in ''Three Days of Rain'' was a major factor in the 4.1 percent boost in ticket sales this year, according to the League of American Theaters and Producers. We're sure she'll rake in more than a few viewers in her role as a presenter at this, the least glitzy (and most scantily watched) of all major award ceremonies, broadcast live from Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan. 9 P.M. (Food Network) FOOD NETWORK CATERS YOUR VEGAS WEDDING -- It's a bride's dream-come-true when Giada de Laurentiis, Bobby Flay and other network chefs whip up a feast fit for the celebration of a lifetime. 9 P.M. (USA) THE 4400 -- Only seconds ago, Isabelle (Megalyn Echikunwoke, left) was a year-old baby. Now, in this season premiere about 4,400 humans who were abducted by aliens and then returned to Earth, she's a beautiful 20-year-old. And there are repercussions. 9 P.M. (Discovery) KRAKATOA: VOLCANO OF DESTRUCTION -- Multiply the magnitude of the 2004 tsunami by four and add the devastation of a volcanic eruption. That was the impact of the 1883 eruption of Krakatoa in Indonesia, whose explosion could be heard 3,000 miles away in Australia. This computergenerated special is almost, but thankfully not quite, like being there. 9 P.M. (HBO) DEADWOOD -- Lawlessness comes to an end with the beginning of a new season, as the town's first real election approaches. Call it strategic planning. 10 P.M. (HBO) ENTOURAGE -- Vince takes a brand-name date to his ''Aquaman'' premiere. And it's spelled M-O-M. 10:30 P.M. (HBO) LUCKY LOUIE -- Louis C.K. and Pamela Adlon (left) play Louie and Kim, typical blue-collar parents raising a child, in this new sitcom. Which is why her offer of sex for a week sounds awfully suspicious. 11 P.M. (HBO) DANE COOK'S TOURGASM -- Mr. Cook and three fellow comics tour 28 states in 30 days in a cramped bus in this new docu-comedy series. And they're still laughing. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

To the Editor: While I am delighted that you published my neighbor's letter about bar proliferation (''Liquor Licenses and Rowdy Revelers,'' May 28) in response to ''Is It Last Call for the City?,'' by David Rabin and Robert Bookman (Op-Ed, May 21), it is discouraging to see this problem reduced to a Nimby noise issue.

Terrence McNally's play ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune'' is, to put it bluntly, about losers. First produced at the Manhattan Theater Club in 1987, it is a haunting two-character piece that revolves around a one-night stand, the difficulties of dealing with either rejection or acceptance, and the sturdily built emotional defenses that get in the way. But this is not a lament, like Tom Noonan's first-date play ''What Happened Was '' or a comedy of psychological manners, like Renée Taylor and Joseph Bologna's ''Made for Each Other.'' Mr. McNally has said of his play, ''There's this sense of getting on, of making life happen.'' The uneven but rewarding new production at the Hartford Stage, directed by Jeremy B. Cohen, eventually conveys that.

THERE are always contenders for that most democratic of titles, ''the great equalizer.'' Public education, the work ethic and the lottery have all had their advocates. But anyone who drives a car knows that in the last 50 years in the United States, there has been only one truly great equalizer -- traffic. The Mercedes and the Chevy crawl to a stop with exquisitely equal kinetic certainty when the Long Island Expressway backs up. The hour's delay on northbound I-95 at Stamford is pretty much the same hour whether you are headed to Greenwich or to Norwalk.

Ordering at Ladle of Love, a tidy 400-square-foot spot in Mount Kisco, can feel like a form of therapy. Customers sit on one of the three stools and chat with Leslie Lampert and her staff as they wait for takeout or a bowl at the counter. One day last week, a regular customer proffering a big spray of mountain laurel was hugged in return. Then there is the soup. For summer, cold fruit-and-yogurt soups include blueberry, strawberry, raspberry and peach. Far East spices steeped in cream are blended into a cold cantaloupe elixir. Chilled cucumber-yogurt soup is perfumed with mint. The excellent gazpacho is drizzled with balsamic syrup. Velvety chicken dumpling soup -- voted the best lunch in town by Fox Lane High School students -- is a soup for all seasons. And it's affordable. Any soup, with a roll, costs from $5.75 to $6.25 for a small container (also available in medium and large).

Kafka Fragments Juliane Banse, soprano; Andras Keller, violinist. ECM New Series 1965; CD. ''THE Hungarian composer Gyorgy Kurtag composed his ''Kafka Fragments,'' a spare, cryptic and riveting 60-minute piece that is still little known, in a feverish rush during the summer of 1986. Though conceived as a concert piece for soprano and solo violin, it was presented at Zankel Hall early last year in a staged performance by the soprano Dawn Upshaw and the violinist Geoff Nuttall, directed by Peter Sellars, and it emerged as an arrestingly effective musical drama.

Ann Williams Campbell and Brendan John Cahill were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Gerald R. Blaszczak performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The bride and bridegroom, both 32, are senior book editors in New York, she at the Doubleday-Broadway Publishing Group of Random House and he at the Gotham Books division of the Penguin Group.

''DOLLY will never go away again'' -- or so promises the refrain from the most famous title song of all time. But in fact, since Carol Channing packed up ''Hello, Dolly!'' in 1996, after at least 5,000 performances in several Broadway runs and numerous tours around the country, no major new production has dared come near New York. It's not clear why: with songs by Jerry Herman, book by Michael Stewart and original direction and choreography by Gower Champion, the show plays well in almost any circumstances. (Please ignore the 1969 movie starring Barbra Streisand.) Perhaps something about its very solidity, and the familiarity of Ms. Channing's extreme interpretation of the meddling, matchmaking widow, has recently kept top-drawer singing actresses away. But after her success as Golda Meir in ''Golda's Balcony'' -- one of the longest-running solo shows in Broadway history -- Tovah Feldshuh, 53, felt she was ready for that other take-charge scrapper with a Jewish surname, Dolly Gallagher Levi. For the production that opened on Saturday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., and runs through July 23, Ms. Feldshuh rethought the character, researching the direct source material (Thornton Wilder's plays ''The Matchmaker'' and ''The Merchant of Yonkers'') and antecedents as diverse as 19th-century Viennese farce, Molière and commedia dell'arte.

THE sign on the Lou Gehrig baseball says ''Not for Sale,'' but that does not stop memorabilia collectors and sports fans who flock to the Hobby Shop in Aberdeen from asking Marvin Schutzer, the owner, to name his price. ''One guy walked in here and said: 'How much do you want for it? I'll pay anything, anything,' '' Mr. Schutzer, 65, recalled. ''But I told him what I tell everyone else, that the ball means too much to me to ever want to part with it and that one day it will go to my oldest son, with instructions never to sell.''

Brenda Panichi, a lawyer for Procter & Gamble in Kobe, Japan. ''I went to Korea to attend the wedding of a friend of mine. She's the one who told me about this market. To the Editor: It was somewhat heartening to read Mr. Ouroussoff's criticism of government with regard to the Atlantic Yards project. Frank Gehry is being used by Bruce Ratner as a lightning rod, to attract criticism and spare public discussion of what appears to be a classic back-room sweetheart deal, which will put hundreds of millions of the public's money into the pockets of a single developer. Tony Daniels Brooklyn

THE house on Lillian Drive in Hazlet was the kind of modest split-level that was the chief crop on much of New Jersey's farmland in the mid-1960's -- chicken coops still standing at one end of the street, a bus stop to New York at the other, three bedrooms and a throw rug of a yard that, to the McDermott clan of Hell's Kitchen via Brooklyn, looked like all the space a family would ever need. And the summers -- oh, the summers -- when the six McDermott kids would pile into the car with their mother and head around the corner to the sprawling, shimmering pool complex that their town had built for them and the hordes of other families who had made the same trek south from cramped city neighborhoods in search of the same sweet pleasures.

The arrival of a remarkable collection of American paintings at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton would no doubt have been considered a ghastly mistake by the museum's founder, Samuel Longstreth Parrish, the Europhile Italian renaissance art collector (1849-1932). But it should please the public, for this is the first time these distinguished works of art have traveled en masse from their home at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington. As a frequent visitor to museums in the nation's capital, I know many of the paintings in this delightful exhibition well. Some of them are old friends, for I have been looking at them on and off for years, either in real life or as reproductions in art history books. The exhibition does not contain the entire collection, but a selection of 74 of the best pictures from the Corcoran Gallery's permanent collection. While the rooms that house the collection are being refurbished, some of their most famous tenants were sent on the road, stopping first in Houston before heading to Southampton.

To the Editor: Lyme disease cases may be down over all in Suffolk County, but Shelter Island should've been shown in the darkest shade on your map. It's a hotbed of Lyme disease. Maybe we didn't ''qualify'' for this article because our population is small. But almost every other person I know here has had a bout with Lyme disease. You can check it out. Call our medical center. Melanie Coronetz Shelter Island

RICHARD EMANUEL has been getting calls for advice from other lawyers ever since he filed a motion in New Haven Superior Court in 2005, challenging the arrest and conviction of his client, Van McKenzie-Adams, a teacher at Hill Regional Career High School in New Haven. Mr. McKenzie-Adams was convicted in 2003 of sexual assault for having sex with two of his students, but Mr. Emanuel won his release from prison after filing a novel, but controversial, appeal that at least one other law firm has already copied. Mr. Emanuel is not denying or admitting that his client had sex with the students, ages 16 and 17, but is claiming that Mr. McKenzie-Adams's constitutional right to privacy was violated. In Connecticut, it is not illegal, of course, for two consenting adults to have a relationship, and people over the age of 16 are considered to have reached the age of consent.

The portrayal of my interview with Deborah Solomon (May 14) was misleading, callous and hurtful. I spoke with Deborah Solomon for more than one hour for what she described as a Mother's Day feature. We spent much of that time talking about my mom. I told her how my mom insisted her four kids sit at the kitchen table doing our homework while she prepared supper. We couldn't trade our pencil for a fork until she had corrected our work. Her lessons of discipline, accountability and preparation were invaluable training for my job as a journalist. I told her of Mom's joy at hearing our parish priest say, ''The hand that rocks the cradle rules the world'' because it affirmed the reality in our family -- that I was truly blessed to have a strong mother and strong father. I told her how my mom would wake me with a soft ''Tim, Tim.'' To me this proved you could be heard without yelling, something I hope is reflected each Sunday on ''Meet the Press.'' I told Solomon the details of my mom's final hours last August when she died from cancer. All four children were at her bedside. I told Solomon that my mom was a beautiful person, inside and out. Solomon chose to ignore all this, and instead the interview was selectively edited -- an interview entitled ''All About My Father,'' implying I chose to talk about my dad rather than my mom on Mother's Day. She also combined questions in her piece, suggesting I did not offer separate and distinct responses to each of her questions, which, of course, I did. My mom was a central figure in my life. This was my first Mother's Day without her. Your writer's deliberate mischaracterization of our conversation and her feeble attempt at humor made it a particularly painful day. Tim Russert Washington

AS summer arrives with its peak electricity demands, the best of all possible worlds apparently prevails in our deregulated electricity market in New York State. A report released in early March by the Department of Public Service in Albany concludes that the wholesale electricity markets in New York ''are among the most advanced in the nation and that wholesale competition has led to significant efficiencies.'' The primary evidence is that the average prices paid by customers, adjusted for inflation, fell by roughly 16 percent from 1996 to 2004. This drop is indeed good news, and many have seized on it as evidence of the deregulated market's health. Unfortunately, this conclusion is incorrect. Deregulated markets have failed to prompt the investments needed to ensure a reliable future supply, particularly in New York City, Long Island and the greater metropolitan area. Furthermore, New York State still has the highest average price of electricity in the continental United States. In spite of our major hydroelectric plants at Niagara and Messina, the average retail price in New York State in 2004 (12.5 cents per kilowatt hour) was 50 percent higher than the price in Pennsylvania (8 cents per kilowatt hour).

GOOD afternoon, this is security; you have a floral delivery,'' said Robert Vigliotti into the phone, and then laughed a bit sheepishly at the response as he realized his call had ruined a surprise. ''Oh well,'' he said, before waving a bouquet-bearing delivery car through the guard gate at Somerset Run. That would be the down side of full-time security-guard vigilance at the gate of a housing complex for adults age 55 and over like this one -- the occasional muffed gesture. But that's very rare, insisted Mr. Vigliotti.

FISCHBARG--Zulema, MD. On June 4th in Buenos Aires, of acute leukemia. Her husband Jorge, sons Gabriel and Victor, daughter-in-law Jill, grandson David, relatives, friends and colleagues will cherish the memory of who was in life an inexhaustible source of humor, inspiration, energy and solidarity.

To the Editor: I would like to applaud the collaboration between developers and architects cited in ''Skyline for Sale.'' It's a relief to see this kind of experimentation outside the rarefied culture sector, where the threat of cost overruns due to architectural extravagance can be devastating to an institution.

One of the photographs in your article shows the widow of Sergeant Morgain at his grave site. I read, with outrage, the designation on the plaque, ''Operation Iraqi Freedom.'' It is bad enough that the administration has inflicted this euphemism on us in its speeches and pronouncements. To place it on the grave of a serviceperson, where it will be linked with him or her for centuries, is an obscenity. I am thankful that when such a plaque goes on my grave, mine will truthfully and bluntly read, ''Vietnam War.'' Harold Cheney Martinsville, Ill.

THERE are always contenders for that most democratic of titles, ''the great equalizer.'' Public education, the work ethic and the lottery have all had their advocates. But anyone who drives a car knows that in the last 50 years in the United States, there has been only one truly great equalizer -- traffic. The Mercedes and the Chevy crawl to a stop with exquisitely equal kinetic certainty when the Long Island Expressway backs up. The hour's delay on northbound I-95 at Stamford is pretty much the same hour whether you are headed to Greenwich or to Norwalk.

The eminent domain battle in New London moved closer to resolution when the City Council voted last Monday to begin the eviction process for the remaining residents of the Fort Trumbull neighborhood. All but two of the seven remaining homeowners have agreed to settle with the city, and when asked before the vote what she would do if the councilors pushed ahead, Susette Kelo, one of the two holdouts, said she might have to ''get some boxes.'' New London condemned the homes in 2000, but a legal battle that reached the United States Supreme Court caused delays. The court backed the city in the case, allowing the city to take the properties and turn them over to a private developer to build a hotel, offices and homes. But the ruling spurred a national outcry against eminent domain and spurred some states to forbid taking homes to make way for private redevelopment.

Because of an editing error, the Journeys column on May 28 about rock music festivals in Europe misstated the location of Rock am Ring, a festival in Germany at the Nürburgring race track. It is at Nürburg, not Nuremberg.

ON the face of it, requiring all individuals convicted of any crime in New York State to give DNA samples for inclusion in a state database seems completely rational and unassailable. While the current law requires only the collection of DNA from those convicted of particular crimes, proponents of expanding DNA retrieval to include those convicted of any felony or misdemeanor argue that people who commit petty crimes are likely to commit more serious ones later. Moreover, their logic goes, if there are more samples in the database, then there will be more DNA matches and more criminals will be caught before they can break the law again. But there are serious implications to widespread testing that have been overlooked by its supporters in the State Senate, which has passed an expanded DNA collection bill, and in the Assembly, where a similar bill is pending. The pitfalls of adding an abundance of new DNA profiles to the state's database go far beyond legitimate concerns about the civil liberties of convicted criminals or innocent persons falsely accused.

THE 7:47 a.m. Long Island Rail Road train from Ronkonkoma to Jamaica pulled into the Deer Park station, and Sandra Krebelj-Douglas eyed her fellow passengers carefully. As one of eight official ''note takers'' for the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, a volunteer group that acts as the voice of the railroad's passengers, she was preparing to monitor riders' behavior in a two-month program to establish the nature and extent of antisocial behavior. Results from the note takers, who ride different lines from different stations, will be used in a report sent to railroad management later in the year.

STEVEN--James R. Passed away on June 9, 2006 at the age of 87. A retired CCNY Professor of Civil Engineering and veteran of WWII, Jim is survived by his wife, two children, three step-children and nine grandchildren. Memorial service at Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville on Tuesday from 2-4pm.

The picture of Paul Statzer in Anderson's article speaks volumes of the true casualties of the Iraq war -- in addition to those killed. It irritates the hell out of me that, in general, the news media and the government make little public mention of some 18,000 or so soldiers who have been wounded, many of them so maimed and mutilated that their lives are forever changed. That is the true cost of this ill-conceived war. David O'Neal (former marine) San Francisco

To the Editor: It is surprising that it has taken so long for the Democratic Party leaders to realize the need to organize their operations across the United States. A key strategy should be to strive to capture the votes of individuals who are disillusioned with President Bush's leadership and his administration. People are frustrated by Republicans who have neglected social and economic issues.

President Bush will begin a strategy session on Iraq tomorrow that one official called a ''last, best chance to get this right.'' Page 22.

To the Sports Editor: Since there is no widely available and reliable urine test for human growth hormone, it would seem prudent to collect and store urine samples until a test is available. At the least, the possibility of future exposure may have some deterrent effect as well as eventually make the hindsight interpretation of baseball statistics more realistic. Fairfid M. Caudle Staten Island
To the Editor: Re ''The Ends Justify the Mean'' (editorial, June 4):

POT AU PHO is a soup and noodle shop housed in a tiny storefront on Whitney Avenue in New Haven. The bulk of the seating is down a short flight of stairs to a low-ceilinged room decorated minimally and tastefully with Asian art. But I prefer to sit upstairs, where there are few tables, and the chef often emerges from the small semi-open kitchen at the back to deliver the food. This organic connection between kitchen and dining room, and the quiet attention of the chef, imbues the place with the easy rhythm of a well-loved neighborhood cafe. And the food is just terrific.

The Cries of London Theater of Voices; Fretwork. Harmonia Mundi France HMU 907214; CD. THE recent howls of anguish over the prospect of live advertising in the theater might be softened a little if enough people hear the new CD ''The Cries of London'' from Harmonia Mundi France. Sales pitches captured on the streets of early- to mid-17th-century England were organized into musical form by eminences like Orlando Gibbons and Thomas Weelkes as well as the slightly lesser lights William Cobbold and especially Richard Dering, who to my ears is the star of the show.

BALMER--John Wrennel. 82, of Monmouth Beach, died April 19, 2006, at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, NJ. Born in Atlantic Highlands, he grew up and lived in Asbury Park where he graduated from Asbury Park High School in 1943. For the past several years, John lived in Monmouth Beach. As a teenager in the early 40's he started work as an usher for the Walter Reade Organization. After graduation from high school, John joined the armed forces, serving his country in the latter years of World War II. After the war, he returned to Asbury Park and took up where he left off in the theater. His career spanned 50 years from usher to Executive Vice President in charge of Walter Reade Theaters throughout the United States. He was involved in the decor and design of many of the art cinemas including the Ziegfield Theater in New York, the Charles Theater in Boston, the King Theater in Seattle and the Esquire Theater in Chicago. John was also an artist and spent his time away from the theaters painting, enjoying his home on the ocean and traveling. Surviving are a cousin, Muriel Thoener of Yonkers, NY, second cousins, Carol Randall and David Thoener, and third cousins, Scott Harris and Austin Thoener, as well as many good friends and colleagues. There will be a memorial service at Posten's Funeral Home, Atlantic Highlands, NJ Friday, June 16, 2006 at 11 am.

To the Editor: After reading this article, I am left feeling that Bruce Ratner, taking a huge gamble, is proceeding in a smart, businesslike way. The risks are enormous and Mr. Ouroussoff pays no heed at all. Perhaps he ought to start a fund to develop any mad, beautiful, outrageous or significant work of architecture of his own and put his money where his mouth is. Michael Salzberg Bethesda, Md.

Senator John W. Warner and his wife were at the White House for a Memorial Day photo session with veterans when they received an unexpected invitation from President Bush. ''Come on,'' the president said suddenly. ''Let's go back to the Oval Office.'' What followed, said Mr. Warner, a Virginia Republican and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, was a rare 15 minutes alone with the president, no aides or staff in sight.

To the Editor: Re ''How to Grow a Democratic Majority,'' by Daniel Galvin (Op-Ed, June 3): As a disillusioned Democrat, I am not surprised that my party's leaders are arguing over ''party strategy.'' They are debating party strategy because they lack the courage and creativity to begin a discussion of the substantial issues confronting our nation today.

FEW people are more familiar with the layout of Winged Foot Golf Club than Tom Nieporte, 77, the club's head pro for the last 28 years. But lately, he hardly recognizes the place. The grounds have been invaded by more than 100 alien structures: huge white corporate tents along the club's demanding par 4's, television towers near its treacherous bunkers and grandstands around its famously slick greens.

FOR those who have already spun and sipped their way through Bordeaux, Alsace and Napa, there are a growing number of bike tours in other wine regions. Some touring companies offer fully guided and supported multiday excursions arranging everything from upscale hotels to luggage transport to private tastings at wineries and host hotels. You can also hire local cycling guides to provide intimate glimpses of their home turfs, or in most areas, follow winery maps for a straightforward do-it-yourself exploration. Here are five less-pedaled wine regions to please the palates of cyclists and oenophiles of all levels. Prices are per person. Oregon: Willamette Valley Oregon pinot noir was put on the map at the 1979 ''Wine Olympics'' in Paris, when a 1975 Eyrie Vineyards Reserve pinot noir, from the Willamette Valley, took third place among the 600 entries, beating out pricier French Burgundies. The region has since taken off and also makes notable pinot gris, riesling and chardonnay.

MICHEL NISCHAN says we should know where our food comes from. At the Westport restaurant he plans to open with Paul Newman in August, the food will come from cows and vegetables raised without relying on hormones or pesticides. The menu will also feature several kinds of fish, preferably caught within miles of the restaurant and preferably served within hours of being caught. Mr. Nischan, who is active in the organic food movement, is teaming with Mr. Newman to create a restaurant called the Dressing Room next to the Westport Country Playhouse that will serve traditional American foods and rely on produce, cheese and meat from state farmers.

deSIMONE--Jack A. Aged 88, on May 31, 2006 while in the paradise island of KohSamui,Thailand. Distinguished associate to many in the performing arts and politics in New York City. Predeceased by his joyful wife, Adele and son Paul, survived by his daughter Diane, brother Anthony and sister Frances.

He was a loving brother to Irving, Morris, Sylvia and Lillian, father-in-law to Seymour, Susan and Sally, and grandfather to Noah, Rebekah, Isabel and Jack. Following the lead of places like Los Angeles, New York and even London and Dublin, the Canadian provinces of Quebec and Ontario are the latest governments to ban smoking in public places. On May 31, it became illegal to smoke in bars, restaurants, private clubs and virtually any other public place in those two provinces.

THE image is etched in his memory: a woman caressing the name of a soldier at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. Ned Benton, a college professor and history buff, wondered about the story behind that name, which made him think about the stories behind the names of the dozens of soldiers memorialized in the Village of Larchmont, where he lives. Eight years ago, as the village was updating its Web site, Mr. Benton and his colleagues at the Larchmont Historical Society had an idea: Why not use the Internet to tell the stories of these soldiers? The challenge was to uncover the information.

GERSHON--Louis. 81, Silver Spring, MD, formerly of West Orange, NJ, died June 2, 2006. Beloved husband of Beverly Rubin. Cherished father of Robert and Julie Glass. Loving grandfather of four grandsons. A partner in the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche and formed private firm of Gershon, Pierce & Co. in Morristown in 1983. Donations: Michael J. Fox Foundation, Grand Central Station, POB 4777, NY, NY 10163

To the Editor: Daniel Galvin endorses the recipe for the growth of the Democratic Party proposed by Howard Dean, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, but doesn't factor in one ingredient essential for success. No political organization can succeed without a coherent, broad-based program that allows people with differences, even on hot-button subjects like abortion and gay marriage, to keep their differences and vote the Democratic line on other social, economic and foreign policy issues.

STEIN--Samuel J. , M.D. On June 8, 2003. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Rosanne and David. Adoring grandfather of Ilene, Andrew, Heather and Rainbow. Great grandfather of Daniel. Selfless physician for over 70 years. Honored World War II veteran and amateur artist. Admired by everyone who knew him. Service Sunday 2 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. $(6$)STEIN--Samuel J., M.D. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished and longtime member, Dr. Samuel J. Stein. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort for those who mourn his passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y

THERE is a bakery here with a twist -- and not just in the rolls and challah it bakes. The Rockland Bakery, in a nondescript building in an industrial part of Nanuet, about 30 miles north of mid-Manhattan, is many things to many people.

SIMON--John L. Died peacefully at his home on June 8 following a courageous effort to overcome leukemia. Cherished father of Julie and brother of Richard (Maxine) Simon and Barbra and (Bruce) London. He is further survived by his beloved Lori and her daughters, his niece and nephews and close friend Marylu. John made enduring commitments and contributions to his community serving as president of The American Jewish Committee, Central New Jersey chapter and esteemed member of its International Relations Commission. He was an innovator and visionary in his diversified and highly regarded work in the healthcare industry. John was a man of rare openness and insight with the sort of warmth that put people at ease and made them lifelong friends. He made an impact on all of us who had the privilege of knowing him and he will be profoundly missed. Memorial services will be held at The Grounds for Sculpture in Hamilton, New Jersey on June 12 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in John's name to The American Jewish Committee, 225 Millburn Avenue, Suite 301, Millburn, NJ 07041.

To the Editor: Re ''Deadly Quackery,'' by John Moore and Nicoli Nattrass (Op-Ed, June 4): The South African government's comprehensive H.I.V. and AIDS program has three principal objectives. One, prevent the transmission of H.I.V. Two, when transmission occurs, delay for as long as possible the onset of AIDS-defining illness. Three, care for patients whose infections have progressed to AIDS-defining illness.

To the Editor: For more decades than I will enumerate I have hugely enjoyed the layout and approach of the Book Review. I like to scan the table of contents and then read the reviews whose titles and reviewers attract me, both fiction and nonfiction categories. I liked the fact that each issue contained an interesting combination of fiction and nonfiction reviews as well as other interesting features. My mind was stretched by the diverse reviews in each issue. Now to my dismay I pick up the May 21 issue and it is devoted entirely to fiction. I feel robbed. Then comes the May 28 issue devoted exclusively to food. I throw it in the wastebasket. Though I occasionally am attracted to a food book review, an entire issue devoted to that subject turns me off. No mind stretching here. Perhaps the next issue will be devoted to crime books. That, too, will go in the wastebasket, though an occasional crime book review attracts me. How I yearn for the Book Review of old that did not try to push particular books or categories of books on me but always stimulated me with a careful selection of reviews of outstanding and important books on a wide variety of subjects, along with eye-catchingbook ads. Perusing The New York Times Book Review is a habit difficult to break. Please, no more special-interest issues other than the year-end best books of the year. I do not enjoy throwing copies in the wastebasket before reading. Henry Halsted Racine, Wis.

''Psycho'' is famous for a shocking syncopation: ALFRED HITCHCOCK silences his heroine in the middle of her song. (And where else but in the shower?) To play the audience like an organ demands a killer sense of timing -- or, to switch metaphors, suspense is the art of killing time itself. With its razor-sharp montage and suffocating tensions, ''Psycho'' inflicts a sustained and subtle assault on the normal rhythms of life. As such, it screams to be slowed down, picked apart and scrutinized frame by frame. Two of the most fascinating responses to the movie proceed in just this manner. In his posthumously published study ''A LONG HARD LOOK AT PSYCHO,'' the critic RAYMOND DURGNAT crawls through every square inch of the movie, ingeniously analyzing its ''tissue of implication and suggestion.'' The artist DOUGLAS GORDON has taken a simpler but more drastic approach, enabling everyone to look as hard as Durgnat. ''24 HOUR PSYCHO'' is just that: Hitchcock's 109-minute masterpiece projected at two frames per second rather than the standard 24, with a consequent run time of one full day. Like Andy Warhol's eight-hour portrait of the Empire State Building, or the artist Paul Pfeiffer's extraordinary three-month study of a wasp nest, Mr. Gordon's 1993 video sounds like a flippant stunt until you set eyes on its gripping creep of light and shadow. Equal parts homage, invention and metacritical commentary, ''24 Hour Psycho'' is as hypnotic, in its slow-drip way, as the source material. The video is habitually situated in the center of a room and projected on a translucent screen, encouraging reflection on both sides of the image, and of ''Psycho'' itself as a piece of sculpture. Thus does it greet visitors to ''DOUGLAS GORDON: TIMELINE,'' an elegantly installed retrospective of the artist's videos opening today at the Museum of Modern Art. What Mr. Gordon has done to ''The Exorcist,'' Otto Preminger's ''Whirlpool'' and the spectacle of an enormous female elephant padding around the Gagosian Gallery (in his 2003 knockout ''Play Dead; Real Time'') can be investigated on the second and sixth floors of the Museum of Modern Art through Sept. 4. 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400.

A picture caption last Sunday with the continuation of a cover article about the developer Bruce Ratner's projects misstated the site of his Atlantic Yards development. It is on rail yards and other land in Prospect Heights and on a block in Park Slope. It is not in Downtown Brooklyn, although it is near that neighborhood. In addition, three credits were omitted. A picture of the New York Times building was by Angel Franco/The New York Times. A picture of Mr. Ratner with Frank Gehry was by John Marshall Mantel/Associated Press. And a picture of a scale model of the development was by Robert Stolarik for The New York Times.

COLNER--Morris. The Board and staff of the JCC of MidWestchester mourns the passing of Morris Colner, father of our esteemed VicePresident Alan Colner. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Alan, Robin and the entire Colner family.

As a student of social movements and an occasional political blogger, I had hoped that the Web offered a more democratic space for a wide variety of voices, and in theory, that was what blogs were supposed to offer (Matt Bai, May 28). The reality has been that those who run the blog sites create an elitism that simply mirrors the traditional political arena, where those with the most connections get the most airplay. As Bai suggests, these new avenues will not change the current political configuration but will simply meld into it. Tina Gentzkow Portland, Ore.

In 2003, Tovah Feldshuh secured wide critical praise and a long Broadway run by reincarnating a ghost. Now, starring in ''Hello, Dolly!'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, she is trying hard to keep a couple of ghosts off the stage. Ms. Feldshuh's Broadway success -- she was nominated for a Tony Award -- was the one-woman show ''Golda's Balcony,'' in which night after night, with the help of makeup artists, she transformed herself into a convincing Golda Meir. Now, on the Paper Mill stage, she is Dolly Gallagher Levi. But she is decisively not Carol Channing or Barbra Streisand.

To the Editor: Re ''The Drug Benefit: A Report Card'' (editorial, June 5): It's worth questioning the validity of a position that an array of drug plans for people with Medicare makes it ''possible to choose coverage that provides the right blend of benefits and costs for each individual.''

When they write the history of New York State politics, 2006 will undoubtedly be labeled a particularly strange year. This is the year that control over the state budget has moved solidly into the governor's office. The Legislature's role, steadily diminishing over the last few years, has been whittled down to that of official supplicant. Gov. George Pataki has essentially taken on the role of state parent, and New York's 212 legislators can do nothing more than whine, plead, denounce and delay.
