Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest AMERICAN MOVIE CRITICS: An Anthology From the Silents Until Now, edited by Phillip Lopate. (Library of America, $40.) A century of film through the eyes of the country's best critics. THE BIG BAM: The Life and Times of Babe Ruth, by Leigh Montville. (Doubleday, $26.95.) Ruth's on-field genius and outsize personality set baseball on the path to its prime-time glory. SPALDING'S WORLD TOUR, by Mark Lamster. (PublicAffairs, $26.) Lamster rollickingly recreates the exhibition baseball tour that Albert Goodwill Spalding led around the globe in 1888-89. L'AMERICA, by Martha McPhee. (Harcourt, $25.) An Italian boy and an American girl, in love with each other and with each other's countries. DOING NOTHING: A History of Loafers, Loungers, Slackers, and Bums in America, by Tom Lutz. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.) A study of our attitudes about working and slacking. BLACK MAESTRO, by Joe Drape. (Morrow/ HarperCollins, $24.95.) A galloping biography of the cosmopolitan black jockey Jimmy Winkfield, who won the Kentucky Derby in 1901 and 1902. MOONLIGHT HOTEL, by Scott Anderson. (Doubleday, $24.95.) In a fictional third-world country, an American villain stirs up a war bearing traces of several recent real-world conflicts. THE HERETIC, by Miguel Delibes. (Overlook, $25.95.) This absorbing novel of the Inquisition delights in the details of 16th-century Spanish life. ROUGH CROSSINGS: Britain, the Slaves and the American Revolution, by Simon Schama. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $29.95.) An account of the thousands of runaway slaves who served the British crown in hopes of securing their freedom. LA PERDIDA, by Jessica Abel (Pantheon, $19.95.). The heroine of this graphic narrative seeks intuitive kinship with Mexican culture, but grim reality intrudes on her folkloric illusions. LATE BLOOMER, by C. Tyler (Fantagraphics, $28.95.) A collection of graphic work amounting to a wise autobiographical sketch of the cartoonist as she struggles with life and motherhood. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Anthony and Federico Terzano -- first-generation Italian-Americans, brothers and partners in the storefront restaurant Babbone -- are big, personable guys who, in the great Italian tradition, want to feed you to make you happy. On a recent night, Freddy, who works up front, came to our table with both an apology (''We're a little jammed up in the kitchen'') and a plate of boccie-size meatballs to tide us over. His brother, Tony, cooks with as much muscle as finesse, with little regard for calories, which is not to say that his hearty, Abruzzese-style cuisine is not delicious. In her classic book ''Italian Regional Cooking,'' Ada Boni describes the Abruzzo's ''historical tradition of gigantic meals,'' manifest in the panarda, a colossal feast dating to antiquity. Mr. Terzano's plus-size portions do nothing if not honor his ancestry.

It's been five years since La Sorpresa Bakery opened on a street off the Post Road in Norwalk (near the Darien line). This tiny bakery is next to and part of a Colombian restaurant of the same name. Once you find the right street, you can't miss the free-standing brick building, set back from the road, with Colombian and United States flags above the door and, on the roof, a delightful folk sculpture of a crowded bus piled high with passengers and luggage. The best time to visit La Sorpresa, which is open from 6:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily, is midmorning, when the breads, sweet rolls and other baked goods come piping hot from the kitchen. It is possible to order coffee and take your sweet roll through the adjoining door to a stool at the bar of the restaurant, which is quiet at that time of day.

TEITELBAUM -- Herbert I., age 80, passed away on June 8, 2006. Cherished husband of Renee (nee Landwehr), and beloved father of Gary (Nerine), and Amy Nelson (Joel). Adored grandfather to Ashleigh, Meredith, Stacy, Jonathan, Chretien and Colton. He graduated from Bronx Science H.S. and City College. Decorated veteran of World War II. He was our leader. Always the wise one. He will be missed by all. Funeral: Sinai Chapel, Fresh Meadows, New York, 12 noon, June 11.

It may sound bourgeois, but sometimes souvenir shopping is the best part of traveling. So why not cut out the distractions -- oh, like a visit to the Louvre or the Vatican -- and go on a vacation designed for shopaholics? That's the selling point behind a new service offered by Artisans of Leisure (800-214-8144, www.artisansofleisure.com), a high-end tour operator based in Manhattan that promises to steer clients to the best bargains and the best-kept shopping secrets. The shopping advice can be requested with any of the company's tours for no extra cost.

FEW people are more familiar with the layout of Winged Foot Golf Club than Tom Nieporte, 77, the club's head pro for the last 28 years. But lately, he hardly recognizes the place. The grounds have been invaded by more than 100 alien structures: huge white corporate tents along the club's demanding par 4's, television towers near its treacherous bunkers and grandstands around its famously slick greens.

The Initial Quality Study by J. D. Power & Associates measures problems that arise in the first 90 days of ownership. Many consumers find longer-term studies more useful; one assessment is Consumer Reports' predicted reliability ratings, based on surveys of readers for the three most recent model years (or two in cases of recently redesigned vehicles).

LAZARUS--The Honorable Eli, 87 years old, died on June 7, 2006. Retired Judge of The Criminal Court of The City of New York. Retired Deputy Chief Inspector of The New York City Police Department. President of The Captains Endowment Association for eight years. He earned four university degrees including a BA from CCNY in 1938 and was elected Phi Beta Kappa, a Master's Degree in Education in French, an LLB from Brooklyn Law School in 1947 and a JSD from Brooklyn Law School in 1949. He also served in the Army Air Corps in Hawaii during World War II. He is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Bernice (nee Shapiro). He was the devoted father of George and Shelly Lazarus and Robert and Jill Lazarus and a cherished grandfather of Theodore, Sa mantha, Benjamin, Anna and Eli. Services Friday 1PM at ''Riverside - Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Society of Honorary Police Surgeons Scholarship Fund, 133 East 73 Street New York, NY 10021.

Michelangelo ''saw the angel in the marble'' and carved until he set him free. Agostino Malatesta, a sculptor in Trenton, saw his painful past and frightening future and carved to set himself free. Played to perfection by Dan Lauria (of the television series ''The Wonder Years''), Agostino -- the central character in William Mastrosimone's play, ''A Stone Carver'' -- is a bereaved Italian widower whose unkempt but beloved house is under threat of demolition for a highway ramp. His son, Raff (Jim Iorio), returns to his childhood home with his proper fiancée, Janice (Elizabeth Rossa). Having eschewed his own past as a stoneworker, Raff is now an upstart politician who hopes to have his father sign the necessary papers for the bulldozing to continue.

AS summer arrives with its peak electricity demands, the best of all possible worlds apparently prevails in our deregulated electricity market in New York State. A report released in early March by the Department of Public Service in Albany concludes that the wholesale electricity markets in New York ''are among the most advanced in the nation and that wholesale competition has led to significant efficiencies.'' The primary evidence is that the average prices paid by customers, adjusted for inflation, fell by roughly 16 percent from 1996 to 2004. This drop is indeed good news, and many have seized on it as evidence of the deregulated market's health. Unfortunately, this conclusion is incorrect. Deregulated markets have failed to prompt the investments needed to ensure a reliable future supply, particularly in New York City, Long Island and the greater metropolitan area. Furthermore, New York State still has the highest average price of electricity in the continental United States. In spite of our major hydroelectric plants at Niagara and Messina, the average retail price in New York State in 2004 (12.5 cents per kilowatt hour) was 50 percent higher than the price in Pennsylvania (8 cents per kilowatt hour).

To the Editor: Re ''Long Scorned in Maine, French Has Renaissance'' (news article, June 4): French was very much alive in Lewiston, Me., during my younger days in the 1940's and 1950's. When I was in downtown Lewiston, it was French that I heard most often.

STIEFEL--Werner K., 85, died June 8, 2006 at VNA Hospice House near his home in Vero Beach. Born on March 10, 1921 in Brooklyn, NY, he grew up in Montclair, NJ and Preston Hollow, Albany County, NY and later resided for many years in Oak Hill, Greene County, NY. After his graduation from Yale University in 1942 with a B.S. degree in chemical engineering, he founded the Stiefel Medicinal Soap Company which laterbecame Stiefel Laboratories, Inc. He remained President and CEO until his retirement in 2001. Under his leadership, Stiefel Laboratories became, and remains, the largest privately owned dermatological (skin product) company in the world with over 2,500 employees and offices in over 100 countries worldwide. Mr. Stiefel was a scientist and inventor who was granted nine United States patents. He was a retired member of the Board of Directors of Norstar Bank of Albany, NY, the Pioneer Insurance Company of Greenville, NY, and president of the Board of Education of the Durham Central School, where he was instrumental in bringing about its merger with Cairo Central School to create the Cairo-Durham School District in Greene County, NY. He was a member of the Rotary Club of Greenville, NY, and a long time Scoutmaster of Boy Scout Troop 101, East Durham, NY. He was a licensed ham radio operator under call letters W2HSK. Mr Stiefel was an Honorary Life Member of the North American Clinical Dermatological Society, and also belonged to the prestigious Annenberg Circle of the Dermatology Foundation, which annually hosts the Werner K. Stiefel lectureship delivered by a world-renowned dermatologist. Mr. Stiefel is survived by his wife Marie (Caruso) Stiefel and six children: John (Joyce) of Wethersfield, CT, Edward (Deborah) of Naples, FL, Charles (Daneen) of So Miami, FL, Joan Stiefel Rodriguez (Ignacio) of Rockville, MD, Stephanie Stiefel Williams (Luke) of Guilford, CT, and Lili Stiefel of Washington, DC. He is also survived by twelve grandchildren: John David Stiefel, Kristen Stiefel Levithan (Josh), William Stiefel, Lisa Stiefel, Jeffrey Stiefel, Todd Stiefel (Diana), Brent Stiefel (Courtney), Melanie Rodriguez, Andrew Rodriguez, Marilyn Rodriguez, Valerie Williams and Richard Williams and three great - grandchildren: Cole, Amber and Sienna Stiefel. He was predeceased by a son, Richard, and his first wife, Catherine (Pierson) Stiefel. Interment will be at the Oak Hill Cemetery, Oak Hill, NY, with a private service following. The date of a public memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Werner K. Stiefel Scholarship Fund (for a Yale University engineering student), 331 Main St., Catskill, NY 12414.

To the Editor: It is hard to argue that the general trend of activism among high school students is not wonderful; it is always good to see that more people are actively volunteering to help better the world. But are these students ''volunteering''? Volunteer work should give the volunteer an altruistic sense of satisfaction that he or she is helping without personal gain. Students cannot possibly understand the true value of volunteer work if their motivations are based, at least partly, on societal pressures to gain and not on genuine concern. BENJAMIN SACKS Barrington, R.I.

ESCHER--Margaret, Arm strong Brockie. A life long resident of Englewood, NJ, died peacefully on June 3rd 2006, in Jacksonville, FL. Born on Aug. 1st, 1918, in Englewood, she graduated from Dwight School for Girl's , and attended Smith College, as a member of the Class of 1940. With her beloved Husband, David A. Escher, a decorated WWII Marine Corp Aviator, who died in 1982. She happily devoted her life to her family. That selfless dedication combined with her natural warmth and easy sense of humor, earned her the unfailing love and admiration of her children, and grandchildren. Her personal interests included membership in the Garden Club of Englewood, where she enjoyed judging and competing in flower arrangement with great success. She was a member of the Englewood field club, cofounded by her Father, Edward S. Brockie, and the Order of Colonial Lords of Manors. Survivors include Mrs. Escher's children, Caroline and Alberto Simian, of Santiago, Chile, David and Lynn Escher, of South Hampton, MA, and Dorothy and Gilbert Kerr of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, a brother, Arthur H. Brockie III, of West Melbourne, FL. 6 grandchildren, and 1 great grandaughter. A memorial service will be held in Englewood, at a date to be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Davis Johnson Memorial Park and Gardens, C/O Tenafly Dept. of Public Works, 107 Grove St, Tenalfy NJ 07670. Phone: 201-569-7275 or Planned Parenthood of Greater Northern NJ Inc., 196 Speedwell Ave., Morristown NJ 07960. Phone: 973-539-9580

The South Korean artist ATTA KIM's best-known body of work is a series called ''The Museum Project'' (1995-2002), for which he photographed his human subjects -- families, nude couples, maimed war veterans -- locked inside plexiglass exhibition cases like specimens on display. The series eventually took a religious turn with models posing as Buddhist deities. The pictures in his first major American solo show, at the INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY, continue in this spiritual trajectory. Filmed using long exposure times, figures, landscapes and religious icons have been turned into apparitions. People, art and museums may last for a while, Mr. Kim seems to say, but all things eventually melt away. Through Aug. 27, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 857-0000. Photography has been an existential mirror and also a social tool for the American artist LORNA SIMPSON, who has a midcareer survey at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. Ms. Simpson, born in 1960, uses combinations of image and text to examine gender, race and history from an oblique, conceptualist perspective. Her serial pictures of figures standing with their backs to the camera or with their faces obscured have implied narratives. But it is the viewer who fills in the story line. Through July 10, 250 South Grand Avenue, Los Angeles, (213) 626-6222. If you miss the Simpson show in Los Angeles, you can catch it at the Whitney Museum of American Art next year and elsewhere. But that is not the case with ''CASAS GRANDES AND THE CERAMIC ART OF THE ANCIENT SOUTHWEST,'' at the ART INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO, which will not travel. The ceramic art produced by Indian communities in northwest Mexico and the American Southwest between 1200 and 1400 is among the most beautiful anywhere. The Mimbres vessels from what is now New Mexico, with their fantastic painted figures and animals, may be familiar. But this border-dissolving exhibition expands the story of a great ceramic tradition into Mexico itself. Through Aug. 13, 111 South Michigan Avenue, Chicago, (312) 443-3600.

THERE are four large cardboard packing boxes sitting in my front hall that irritate me every time I walk by them, which is many times a day. These packages arrived at my doorstep via U.P.S. several weeks ago, predating my daughter's arrival home from college by a day or two. They sit, a glaring reminder of how difficult it can be to reabsorb the college student back into the household. The boxes are packed to the brim with dirty laundry, blankets and pillows, sweaters and scarves, a couple of stretched canvases, framed photos and much more -- I have only skimmed the top layers. (My daughter ships what she doesn't store on campus, since her college is far enough away that she travels there by plane.) The key point, however, is that both she and the boxes have been home since May and still, they remain unpacked.

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Elana Jeanne Cox and Bruce Lawrence Levinson misstated the age of the bridegroom. He is 35, not 31. The report also misidentified the occupation of Patricia Levinson, the bridegroom's mother. She is a cognition therapist who helps people with learning disabilities, not a psychotherapist.

The number of people around the world suffering from diabetes has skyrocketed in the last two decades, from 30 million to 230 million, claiming millions of lives and severely taxing the ability of health care systems to deal with the epidemic, according to data released Saturday by the International Diabetes Federation. While the growing problem of diabetes in the United States has been well documented, the federation's data show that 7 of the 10 countries with the highest number of diabetics are in the developing world.

The spring sprint for the Tony Awards generally means that Off Broadway slumbers through the weeks leading up to the big night. But once the red carpet has been rolled up at Radio City, as it will be Monday morning after Sunday night's awards, it's open season for the smaller fry. The week is thick with theater openings away from the Great White Way. First up is ''BURLEIGH GRIME$,'' a comedy by ROGER KIRBY about a neophyte Wall Street trader and his mentor. The astringent WENDIE MALICK, a regular on the snarky sitcom ''Just Shoot Me,'' stars alongside MARK MOSES, the killer widower on ''Desperate Housewives.'' The show also features music by the ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'' composer DAVID YAZBEK, who seems to like writing for bad guys. DAVID WARREN directs. Opens Tuesday at New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, (212) 239-6200; $70. In ''THE WATER'S EDGE,'' the new play by THERESA REBECK at the Second Stage Theater, drama begins to boil when a woman and her two adult children receive a visit from her ex-husband, long estranged. KATE BURTON and TONY GOLDWYN play the former spouses. The play is set at a lakeside house, the kind of place where unexpected, possibly disturbing things are wont to occur. Opens Wednesday, 307 West 43rd Street, (212) 246-4422; $58 to $65. The Atlantic Theater Company makes its first foray into new musicals with ''SPRING AWAKENING,'' which boasts a score by DUNCAN SHEIK, best known as a pop-rock performer and composer. Mr. Sheik has evinced some disaffection from the old-school musical in interviews, and certainly the source material, Frank Wedekind's once-scandalous 1891 play about sexual exploration among teenagers, suggests that this will not be your run-of-the-mill singalong show. STEVEN SATER wrote the book and lyrics, and MICHAEL MAYER directs. Opens Thursday, 336 West 20th Street, (212) 239-6200; $60.

The Ahold scandal just will not go away. Brady M. Schofield, a produce and seafood merchant, agreed last week to pay more than $700,000 to settle a civil lawsuit in which the Securities and Exchange Commission accused him of profiting from inside information about Ahold's plan to buy a food distribution company, U.S. Foodservice, in 2000. It also accused him of later submitting false paperwork that helped U.S. Foodservice to inflate Ahold's profit for three years.

THE image is etched in his memory: a woman caressing the name of a soldier at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. Ned Benton, a college professor and history buff, wondered about the story behind that name, which made him think about the stories behind the names of the dozens of soldiers memorialized in the Village of Larchmont, where he lives. Eight years ago, as the village was updating its Web site, Mr. Benton and his colleagues at the Larchmont Historical Society had an idea: Why not use the Internet to tell the stories of these soldiers? The challenge was to uncover the information.

HomeI was profoundly moved by Scott Anderson's article (May 28). I'm against the war in Iraq, and his article only strengthened my resolve in this. However, the profiles of the men who served (the psychologically and physically wounded and those who died) reminded me that they are not the enemy and that they deserve my support and compassion,despite my feelingsabout the war itself. This article made the cost for the soldiers and their families painfully real. I appreciate their willingness to share these difficult experienceswith readers like me, and I thank Scott Anderson for listening so well and writing it all down. Douglas Hein Salem, Mass.

An article last Sunday about the regional theater Tony Award misstated the given name of the artistic director of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. It is Libby Appel, not Linda. The article also misstated the name of the group that recommends the award winner. It is the American Theater Critics Association, not the American Drama Critics Association.

IN the war's first year, American commanders made so much of his role in the worsening insurgency that they developed their own wry, self-mocking way of referring to him. He was ''the Z word,'' the villain-for-all-occasions, the default to turn to whenever American commanders looked for causes and patterns in a conflict that, at the time, they had only begun to figure their way through. He was the devil's pimpernel -- now in Falluja, now in Baghdad, now in Mosul. He moved undetected across a map that was an obstacle course of checkpoints and curfews and roadside explosions and traffic back-ups behind American military convoys -- enough to make a nervous wreck of the most placid traveler, let alone a man sharing with Osama bin Laden the grim distinction of a $25-million American bounty on his head.

MICHEL NISCHAN says we should know where our food comes from. At the Westport restaurant he plans to open with Paul Newman in August, the food will come from cows and vegetables raised without relying on hormones or pesticides. The menu will also feature several kinds of fish, preferably caught within miles of the restaurant and preferably served within hours of being caught. Mr. Nischan, who is active in the organic food movement, is teaming with Mr. Newman to create a restaurant called the Dressing Room next to the Westport Country Playhouse that will serve traditional American foods and rely on produce, cheese and meat from state farmers.

CHEMLA--Fernand Joseph (Pino). Died peacefully on Thursday, June 8, 2006, at the age of 92. He was greatly loved by his wife Edmee, his children Franck, Alexandre, Muriel and Daniele, his children-in-law Claude, Lori and Claude as well as his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the Cimetiere du Montparnasse on June 13 at 3 PM. Please no flowers.

WHERE'S the beef with broccoli, the steak kew, the moo shu pork? Nanking, a recently opened restaurant in New Hyde Park, named for a former capital of China and proclaiming on its marquee that it is Thai and Chinese, does not specialize in the familiar. Patrons who expect complimentary crispy noodles, pots of hot tea, rice with their entrees and fortune cookies at the end of the meal may be taken aback. Most of the surprises, though, are pleasant ones, for the décor and the food are appealing. This is a beautiful restaurant with hammered copper tabletops, red plush chairs and banquette seating. The centerpiece chandelier with a dozen tasseled red lanterns is dramatic, and walls are covered in sumptuous red and gold silk. A stand of dark brown bamboo separates the main dining room from the bar. An attractive party room is dominated by a giant gold Buddha.

TWO months ago, John P. Ginty was just a regular guy living in Ridgewood and working as a financial-data analyst for a publishing company in Manhattan. And while he had dabbled in local Republican politics, the most ink he had received was when he wrote to local newspapers calling for, among other causes, the impeachment of Bill Clinton. Funny how 40,000 or so votes can thrust you into the center of New Jersey politics.

After a series of contentious public hearings and the City Council's failed attempts to reach a budget compromise, property taxes in Long Beach will go up 25 percent on July 1, for an average increase of $500 a year for owners of one- and two-family homes. Two months ago, the city manager, John J. Laffey, first proposed a $72.4 million budget that included a 25 percent tax increase. City Council members offered alternatives to reduce the increase, but partisan wrangling divided the five-member council. Under the City Charter, because there was no consensus on an alternative, Mr. Laffey's original budget went into effect on June 1.

In a nuclear plant like Westchester's Indian Point, the radioactive decay of fuel rods boils water into steam, which causes turbines to spin at high speeds, generating electricity. A similar process also occurs in the high-pressure rhetorical atmosphere surrounding that much-hated plant on the Hudson. Its aging reactors are a steady source of political heat, which sets the pool of public opinion to bubbling and generates large amounts of spin.
An article on May 28 on John Lloyd Young, who plays Frankie Valli in the Broadway musical ''Jersey Boys,'' misstated the name of Mr. Young's singing instructor. It is Katie Agresta, not Kim Agresta.
LESTER--Iva M. 78, former employee of the United Nations, NY, died Thursday, June 1, 2006 in Ft. Myers, FL.

I have heard horror stories of passengers with a confirmed reservation who have been bumped from overbooked flights when they arrive at the airport in good time. How likely is this to happen, and what can one do if it does? -- Jeremy Woolfe, Brussels It's down to the law of averages catching up with you. Bumping, or ''involuntary denied boarding,'' happens because airlines typically oversell flights by up to 50 percent to compensate for people who fail to turn up. For instance, Judith Goldberg of Tel Aviv writes: ''I flew Austrian Airlines from Tel Aviv to Delhi, via Vienna. When I arrived at the transfer desk, two and a half hours before the Delhi flight, I was told I had no seat reservation, the flight was overbooked, and I would be wait-listed -- no matter that I had paid months in advance and was joining a tour. Austrian did give me a hotel for the night and paid for a night at my hotel in Delhi.''

Frances Bingham Bolton, a daughter of Julia Sayers Bolton and Charles P. Bolton of Mentor, Ohio, was married yesterday to Patrick Storm Wilmerding, a son of Elsie Storm Wilmerding and Patrick R. Wilmerding of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Daniel H. Schoonmaker performed the ceremony at St. Hubert's Episcopal Church in Mentor. Mrs. Wilmerding, 28, is studying for a master's degree in law and diplomacy at the Fletcher School at Tufts University. She was from 2000 to 2004 a special assistant to John R. Bolton, then the under secretary of state for arms control and international security. (They are not related.) The bride graduated from Georgetown.

CALLAN--Irving on June 9, 2006. Formerly of River Edge, NJ. Survived by his wife Beatrice (Jacobs), daughters and sons in law Ilene and David Siscovick of Seattle WA and Loren and James Rosenzweig of Brookline MA, grandchildren Benjamin, Johnathan and Miriam Siscovick and Anne David and Racheal Rosenzweig, and Sister Betty Baum. Donations may be made to: Jewish War Veterans 1811 R St NW, Washington DC, 20009. Graveside services at Beth David, Elmont on Sunday June 11 at 1pm.

The big news in jazz for the week is that the JVC and Vision festivals are in town. But there are also worthy small-club gigs, and two are Monday night. A young jazz singer trained in the verities of Ella Fitzgerald and Sarah Vaughan, SASHA DOBSON is starting to make music that's more about her own time; her album ''Modern Romance,'' to be released in August, includes covers of songs by the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Duke Ellington, as well as her own pieces. The band, on the record and for her current live gigs, includes several colleagues of Norah Jones -- JESSE HARRIS, RICHARD JULIAN and TONY SCHERR -- as well as the percussionist MAURO REFOSCO. She will be playing every Monday in June at Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side. At 9 p.m., 196 Allen Street, between Houston and Stanton, (212) 477-4155; no cover. And then there is the saxophonist CHRIS POTTER, who started playing in New York around 1990, an obvious talent in Red Rodney's group and the Mingus Big Band. Over the years, working his way up, he has played in some of the best jazz groups of the day, like Dave Holland's quintet and Paul Motian's Electric Bebop Band; these are groups marked by careful, defined sound, which he has been able to enhance, as the gestures in his playing became bigger and more authoritative. He avoids playing licks, using an imaginative, almost Wayne Shorter-like approach to improvisation. In this small gig he will have plenty of room, with only the bassist SCOTT COLLEY and the drummer JEFF BALLARD. At 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 929-9883; $10.
To the Editor: Re ''Skyline for Sale'' [June 4]:

Reports that People magazine shelled out $4.1 million for pictures of Shiloh, the Angelina Jolie-Brad Pitt newborn, brought cagey denials from People's editor. But the two stars do say they are selling photo rights to benefit charities, undoubtedly for amounts that could otherwise pay for some very fine art. What to buy with a budget like that? Works by old masters, or snapshots of a two-week-old?
''The situation is really in the last four years the most unstable and insecure I have seen.'' TALATBEK MASADYKOV, a U.N. official in Afghanistan, on the Taliban's resurgence. [1]

An article last Sunday about finding an apartment to rent in New York City for about $1,000 misstated the name of a condominium on Staten Island that offered a unit for rent for $1,100. It is Foxwood Square, not simply Foxwood. The article also misidentified the neighborhood. It is New Springville, not Heartland Village. The errors were repeated in a picture caption.

THERE are always contenders for that most democratic of titles, ''the great equalizer.'' Public education, the work ethic and the lottery have all had their advocates. But anyone who drives a car knows that in the last 50 years in the United States, there has been only one truly great equalizer -- traffic. The Mercedes and the Chevy crawl to a stop with exquisitely equal kinetic certainty when the Long Island Expressway backs up. The hour's delay on northbound I-95 at Stamford is pretty much the same hour whether you are headed to Greenwich or to Norwalk.

MY spring planting never occurs in spring. I have to use the phrase ''spring planting'' loosely to accommodate the fact that it always happens in summer. I start dreaming in March, but by June only delusions have sprouted. I buy seeds, imagining I will have time to cultivate them in little pots or trays. In reality, my tote bag and kitchen cabinets hold packets of seed pods long past their expiration dates. I yearn with a fever bred by generations. Everybody in my family was a closet gardener in a city apartment, producing pale lunar indoor stalks on the shadowy shelf above the winter coats.

To the Editor: Allan Kozinn is dreaming. His article, while filled with statistics and facts, remains an exercise in happy talk. The line that brings the biggest smile is the reference to John Adams's ''rock-star popularity.'' Ha! Being the music teacher for 380 of Chicago's brightest and most affluent children, I can report that the only John Adams they, or their parents, or the rest of the universe, have the slightest awareness of is still the former president. Jesse Roe Chicago

To the Editor: Sharon Seitz, in ''Off Track'' (Op-Ed, May 28), is right on track in her defense of Floyd Bennett Field against those who think it is just an abandoned Brooklyn airfield with empty runways made for racing. The Park Service police are now hard put to enforce the park's 25-m.p.h. speed limit. What they don't need is Paul Newman and the North American Motorsport Events people creating a 3.5-mile race course there and sending the message to all speed enthusiasts: ''Speeding is O.K. in Floyd Bennett Field.''
SILKE--Thomas. Of NYC, died June 8, age 81. 40 year employee with Rudin Management. Beloved by Rita, Stephanie and ''Harry.'' Mass June 12, 9:45 A.M., Holy Trinity, 213 West 82 Street.

THE 7:47 a.m. Long Island Rail Road train from Ronkonkoma to Jamaica pulled into the Deer Park station, and Sandra Krebelj-Douglas eyed her fellow passengers carefully. As one of eight official ''note takers'' for the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, a volunteer group that acts as the voice of the railroad's passengers, she was preparing to monitor riders' behavior in a two-month program to establish the nature and extent of antisocial behavior. Results from the note takers, who ride different lines from different stations, will be used in a report sent to railroad management later in the year.

''Shep.''/m Fourteen years have not faded the beautiful memories we shared. You will be remembered forever with love

LORY--Jonathan Michael. Born December 19, 1948, died on June 5, 2006. Loving son and grandson of the late Jack and Winifred Lory, Agnes Henry Feeley, and Isaac and Allegra Levy. He is survived by his beloved wife Carla, uncles Gerard Feeley and Edward Lory, and an extended family of devoted aunts, cousins, and longstanding friends. Many of those friends met Jonathan during his 30-year career as an audio engineer at the American Broadcasting Company, which earned him eight Emmy Awards. He worked on daytime dramas, national conventions and presidential debates, covered town meetings in Israel and South Africa, traveled to Sarajevo and Lake Placid for Olympics, and to stadiums across the country for Monday night Baseball and Football. He leaves us who knew him best with memories to cherish of a warm and gentle man with a keen respect for detail and workmanship, an encyclopedic memory, vast interests, tremendous style, extraordinary humor and quick wit, all of which he shared with remarkable generosity and kindness. He was a joy in our lives and he will be deeply missed.

To the Editor: Your policy of assigning reviews to unbiased third parties has been violated by your assignment of ''A G-Man's Life: The FBI, Being 'Deep Throat,' and the Struggle for Honor in Washington,'' by Mark Felt and me, to John Dean (May 7). It would be hard to imagine a reviewer more biased than Dean. He was convicted of a crime and disbarred as a result of both Felt's investigation of Watergate and his role as ''Deep Throat.'' Additionally, the book assigned for review deals sneeringly with Dean's lack of integrity. Dean himself has written two books assessing the identity and motives of Deep Throat, both of which were proven embarrassingly wrong in light of the recent revelation of Felt's role. Dean's bias has resulted in palpably false assertions in the review, the heart of which, ironically, is that Felt has supposedly made factual errors in this book. Dean claims, for example, that, contrary to Felt's assertion in our book, John ''Ehrlichman and I were out of the White House at the time'' of L. Patrick Gray's resignation. In fact, Gray resigned and was replaced on April 27, 1973, while Dean and Ehrlichman were employed in the White House until April 30. Dean also states unequivocally that Felt was wrong in writing that the ''White House'' was ''following'' the Watergate investigation ''through L. Patrick Gray.'' In fact, Dean himself, as White House counsel, received multiple F.B.I. investigative reports from Gray, as any informed observer knows. Finally, Dean's claim that it is ''absurd'' to say Daniel Ellsberg had been ''briefed'' rests upon deliberate misreading. Felt claimed only that Ellsberg had been briefed ''on the subject,'' which is the Kissinger wiretaps generally, revealed in Time magazine three months earlier, about which his lawyers had since been inquiring; and not that Ellsberg knew that he had actually been overheard. The oleaginous Dean's attempt to alchemize these provably false charges into mere technicalities engenders yet more falsity. Ehrlichman was influential with, and praised by, Nixon through the end. In fact, Dean devoured a foot-high stack of F.B.I. summaries, ''302'' and ''airtel'' investigative reports, which he often kept on his desk, admitting in ''Blind Ambition'' that ''on a park bench, I told Gray I needed the materials to keep track of the investigation's progress.'' In any case, Felt's work is proven not to be ''riddled with errors''; someone else's, though, is. Because Dean's accusations of inaccuracy are at the core of his criticism of the book, they cannot be dismissed as inconsequential. Accordingly, Dean's obvious bias has sullied, actually and substantially, the integrity of the review process. John D. O'Connor San Francisco John Dean replies: John O'Connor claims I am biased against Mark Felt, so I wrote a review falsely claiming his book with Felt has errors. I do confess a bias -- toward honest history, but I have none toward Mark Felt. In fact, when it was revealed that he was Deep Throat, I made highly favorable comments publicly, at a time when my former Nixon White House colleagues were busy trashing him. (I publicly congratulated O'Connor as well, but I stand by my Deep Throat sleuthing, for Mark Felt does not fit all the clues found in ''All the President's Men.'') As for Felt's sneering, since he does it to everyone in the Nixon White House, and he is deeply confused about the facts, I did not take it personally. O'Connor asserts that Felt's investigation of Watergate and his role as ''Deep Throat'' are reason for my bias, but he could not be more wrong. The historical record (testimony and Nixon tapes) show that after trying to persuade my colleagues to end the Watergate coverup -- which was not being investigated by the F.B.I. at the time, for only the Senate Watergate Committee was exploring it as a potential matter of misconduct -- I went to the United States Attorney's office on my own initiative to end the coverup. Felt had nothing whatsoever to do with my decision. As for Deep Throat, according to ''All the President's Men,'' he never mentioned my name until April 16, 1973 (after I had been dealing with the prosecutors for several weeks), and then he gave Woodward totally false information about me, like claiming I had talked with Senator Howard Baker, who was ''in the bag'' -- which was untrue -- and that Nixon personally threatened to send me to jail if I told the prosecutors about ''national security matters'' -- which was also untrue. The distortions in O'Connor's letter, in which he misstates what I wrote in my review and uses his misstatements to assert I have falsely accused the book of being in error, necessarily require a bit of explanation. In my review I wrote: ''Felt, who was passed over for the director's job, claims that in the period after Gray's departure from the F.B.I., he 'knew that as long as John Dean and John Ehrlichman were in the White House,' he 'would have less chance of receiving the appointment than the man in the moon.' But Ehrlichman and I were out of the White House at that time.'' Note, however, how O'Connor has twisted my words, writing: ''Dean claims . . . that, contrary to Felt's assertion in our book, 'Ehrlichman and I were out of the White House at the time' of L. Patrick Gray's resignation.'' (Emphasis added because I did not mention Gray's resignation.) Here are the facts. Pat Gray resigned on April 27, 1973, and President Nixon selected William Ruckelshaus, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, to serve as acting director that same day. Felt/O'Connor write that Felt understood that Ruckelshaus ''would barely warm the director's chair'' (for Ruckelshaus had said he did not want the job of F.B.I. director). They then explain that on April 30, 1973 (according to The New York Times, for the date is not in the book), when Felt presented Ruckelshaus with a copy of a telegram from senior F.B.I. officials to the president urging Nixon to appoint someone from within the F.B.I. to be director, that Felt did not have himself in mind. The reason, Felt/ O'Connor write, was that Ehrlichman and I were in the White House. But that is not true. O'Connor's acknowledgment that he knew Ehrlichman and I had left the White House the very day that Felt decides he has no chance of becoming director because we are in the White House makes absolutely no sense. In my review I wrote that ''Felt seems unaware that the White House followed the F.B.I.'s Watergate investigation through Henry Petersen, chief of the criminal division, not through the acting director, L. Patrick Gray.'' Note again how O'Connor has twisted my statement, writing that ''Dean also states unequivocally that Felt was wrong in writing that the 'White House' was following the Watergate investigation 'through L. Patrick Gray.' (Emphasis added because that is not what I wrote.) Yet he makes his claim that I am wrong based on a statement I did not make, nor do I dispute: ''In fact, Dean himself, as White House counsel, received multiple F.B.I. investigative reports from Gray, as any informed observer knows.'' Any informed observer would also know that I testified on repeated occasions that there was nothing in the F.B.I. material I received from Gray that was particularly useful to the White House and that I followed the Watergate investigation through Henry Petersen. This is the historical record I alluded to, which O'Connor simply ignores. Lastly, I wrote Felt/ O'Connor claim ''that Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the Pentagon Papers, 'had certainly been briefed' on the fact that he had been wiretapped at the White House's behest, an absurd assertion.'' The assertion is absurd for several reasons. To set up this claim that Ellsberg had been briefed about White House wiretaps, Felt/O'Connor write that ''during the closing days'' of Ellsberg's trial, ''The Washington Post alleged that the White House Plumbers had placed wiretaps on Ellsberg's phone.'' Felt/O'Connor have mislabeled the so-called Kissinger national security wiretaps (from 1969-70), one of which was placed on former Kissinger aide Morton Halperin, for this tap picked up some 15 conversations with Ellsberg -- a fact the government lied about, including, apparently, Mark Felt. The Plumbers (who operated in 1971) did not wiretap Ellsberg. Ellsberg's memoir, ''Secrets: A Memoir of Vietnam,'' and the Pentagon Papers report that his attorneys made repeated inquiries to the government about whether Ellsberg had been wiretapped but were always given ''formal denials''; nowhere in his memoir is there a hint that Ellsberg had been briefed on the White House wiretaps. (Ellsberg confirmed to me that, in fact, he had not been briefed, and he too found Felt's contention ''absurd.'') Notwithstanding O'Connor's letter, I repeat what I stated in the review: ''A G-Man's Life'' is riddled with errors. I had only mentioned a few of them because I had no desire to embarrass Felt or O'Connor. I will resist characterizing O'Connor's letter because it speaks for itself. The editor replies: Although John Dean's review of ''A G-Man's Life'' disclosed that he is mentioned in the book, the Book Review should have encouraged him to be more explicit about his dealings with Mark Felt during the Watergate controversy.

Bruce and Christiane Schneider are selling their Roanoke Point Vineyard and popular Potato Barn label but will continue to make small quantities of cabernet franc and syrah wine under their Schneider Vineyards brand. Mr. Schneider said last week that he intended to devote more time to his wine-marketing consulting practice at RF/Binder Partners in New York City, where he is involved with Wines of Germany and Wines of Chile, both clients.

AS summer arrives with its peak electricity demands, the best of all possible worlds apparently prevails in our deregulated electricity market in New York State. A report released in early March by the Department of Public Service in Albany concludes that the wholesale electricity markets in New York ''are among the most advanced in the nation and that wholesale competition has led to significant efficiencies.'' The primary evidence is that the average prices paid by customers, adjusted for inflation, fell by roughly 16 percent from 1996 to 2004. This drop is indeed good news, and many have seized on it as evidence of the deregulated market's health. Unfortunately, this conclusion is incorrect. Deregulated markets have failed to prompt the investments needed to ensure a reliable future supply, particularly in New York City, Long Island and the greater metropolitan area. Furthermore, New York State still has the highest average price of electricity in the continental United States. In spite of our major hydroelectric plants at Niagara and Messina, the average retail price in New York State in 2004 (12.5 cents per kilowatt hour) was 50 percent higher than the price in Pennsylvania (8 cents per kilowatt hour).

Tania Vanessa Ralli and Claude Franklin Goldsmith III were married yesterday at the Fortnightly of Chicago, a women's club. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert W. Bowen, a Presbyterian minister, officiated. Ms. Ralli, 30, is keeping her name. She works in Boston as a producer of ''On Point,'' a public radio news and culture program, which originates at WBUR. She graduated from Bates College. The bride received a master's degree in art history from Oxford University in England and a diploma from the French Culinary Institute in New York. She is the daughter of Heide and Hugo Ralli of Chicago.

Dr. Benjamin Thomas Davis and George Johnston Bradish were married yesterday at the First Parish Church of Newbury, Mass., by the Rev. Nancy Haverington, a minister of the United Church of Christ. Dr. Davis (left), 42, is an assistant professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School, specializing in infectious diseases and the care of H.I.V. and AIDS patients. He graduated summa cum laude from Yale and received a medical degree from Harvard-M.I.T. Division of Health Sciences and Technology.

To the Editor: Re ''The Lost Summer'' (June 4): Reading your article, I was filled with frustration and outrage. Yet another article on the workaholic youngsters of today and their vicariously overachieving parents? I wonder how many parents of ninth and 10th graders will see this article and push their children ever harder, worrying that they are falling behind in the race to get the ''gold medal'' of an acceptance into Harvard.

MY spring planting never occurs in spring. I have to use the phrase ''spring planting'' loosely to accommodate the fact that it always happens in summer. I start dreaming in March, but by June only delusions have sprouted. I buy seeds, imagining I will have time to cultivate them in little pots or trays. In reality, my tote bag and kitchen cabinets hold packets of seed pods long past their expiration dates. I yearn with a fever bred by generations. Everybody in my family was a closet gardener in a city apartment, producing pale lunar indoor stalks on the shadowy shelf above the winter coats.

J. C. Penney may be a discount retailer, but its new chief operating officer, Catherine G. West, did not come cheap. Ms. West, who had been running Capital One Financial's domestic credit card business, received a pay package worth more than $20 million for joining Penney last week, according to a contract that was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MARK D. BOUGHTON, the mayor of Danbury who won a national reputation for talking tough to illegal immigrants, is a descendant of immigrants. Only his French-British ancestors arrived in this country a few decades after the Mayflower. It is understandable that one could forget after all this time that coming to a new land is an awkward business, and that the natives may not be happy with the newcomers' outlandish ways. Let's remember that despite the initial good will that we romanticize on Thanksgiving, the Indians grew quite upset with the Pilgrim interlopers and killed more than a few.

To the Editor: Congratulations to Alice Elliott Dark for managing to trot out just about every negative stereotype that exists about bar or bat mitzvahs (''For an Information-Hungry Mom, 13 Is a Lucky Number,'' June 4).

GOODMAN - Barbara. We will never forget your important role in the creation of The Hechinger Institute at Teachers College Columbia University 10 years ago. As the Chairman of our Advisory Board you were a fine prescence, offering wise and caring guidance. We will always be grateful. Grace, Paul and John Hechinger

THE sign on the Lou Gehrig baseball says ''Not for Sale,'' but that does not stop memorabilia collectors and sports fans who flock to the Hobby Shop in Aberdeen from asking Marvin Schutzer, the owner, to name his price. ''One guy walked in here and said: 'How much do you want for it? I'll pay anything, anything,' '' Mr. Schutzer, 65, recalled. ''But I told him what I tell everyone else, that the ball means too much to me to ever want to part with it and that one day it will go to my oldest son, with instructions never to sell.''

At its best, all dance taps into a sense of ritual communion with something larger than the self. The Korean dancer MYUNG SOO KIM makes this explicit in ''MODERN ECHOES OF THE ANCIENT,'' an evening of solos that call upon the traditional shaman dances of her homeland. Between the solos, Ms. Kim will sing ''Arirang,'' peasant songs of resistance that document the woes of Korea's troubled history, and change her elaborate costumes onstage. She offers a kind of primer on traditional Korean dance, filtered through both personal history and contemporary sensibility, that sounds fascinating. Wednesday through Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m., the Duke on 42nd Street, 229 West 42nd Street, second floor, (212) 239-6200 or www.telecharge.com; $35, $25 for students and 65+. During American Ballet Theater's recent Metropolitan Opera House season, audiences had just one chance to see the glorious Kirov Ballet star DIANA VISHNEVA perform the title role in ''Giselle.'' This week she will give two performances as the village maiden betrayed by her noble lover and transformed into a Wili, one of a band of haunted spirits condemned to destroy the men who deceived them. In this ballet, Ms. Vishneva's technical command and exquisitely articulated upper body are merely at the service of her dramatic powers. Wednesday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000; $23 to $100. There has been a lot of buzz about the Finnish-born choreographer JORMA ELO recently. He began to make a name for himself after joining the Nederlands Dans Theater in 1990 and put himself on the map in this country when he made the critically applauded ''Sharp Side of Dark'' for the Boston Ballet in 2002. Last year he was appointed the resident choreographer of that company, and this week the New York City Ballet will perform the premiere of his as-yet-unnamed Diamond Project commission, to music by Vivaldi and Biber. Good ballet choreographers are in short supply these days, so here's hoping. Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570; $30 to $86.
To the Editor: Re ''TV Screen, Not Couch, Is Required for This Session'' (front page, June 8):
YES, WE TRAFFIC IN DEBT. BUT AS WITH EVERY OTHER COIN OF THE REALM, THERE ARE FLIP SIDES TO CONSIDER. SOME DEBTS CAN BE OPPORTUNITIES; OTHERS ARE MORE BURDENSOME.

Heather Michelle Morr, a daughter of Karen and Thomas G. Morr of Vienna, Va., was married yesterday to Gilbert Hild Klemann, the son of Patricia and Gilbert L. Klemann II of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Peter G. James, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Georgetown Presbyterian Church in Washington, with the Rev. Liam Quinlan, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part. The bride and bridegroom met at Princeton, from which she graduated summa cum laude and he cum laude.

Jay Leno As you know, President Bush is calling for a constitutional amendment against gay marriage. He says he is out to put both Al Qaeda and Ikea out of business. Senator Hillary Clinton is calling for a return of the 55 mile-an-hour speed limit. When people in Los Angeles heard about that they went, ''Cars can go that fast?''

It hardly feels like summer without a trip to the beach. But if you are not a resident of one of the 26 Connecticut towns with a shoreline on Long Island Sound, chances are you will face high ticket prices for parking or admission before you dig your toes in the sand. The situation is a state embarrassment. Now Stamford has made a more neighborly move to lower nonresident beach parking fees, and it is something other towns should emulate.

FISHER--Richard. Died suddenly in Vienna, Austria on June 6. He is survived by his companion of thirty years, Kevin Poulis, brother Barry Fisher, nephew Steven Fisher & niece Sharon Socherman. He was a world traveler and died doing what he loved the most. We will sincerely miss him. Tina Simner, Rosalind Glaser, Alan Fisher

I have been a New Yorker for decades now, but I call Butler County my home. Your article captured the spirit and heart of this often overlooked corner of western Pennsylvania. I grew up in its rolling hills and, in a different generation, watched high-school friends go off to Vietnam and listened as my dad and his friends quietly discussed their experiences in World War II, though only if prodded. My view then, as it is now, is that returning veterans of all generations do not receive the proper medical and social help that they need to reintegrate within their communities. Veterans Affairs hospitals in Butler and elsewhere are simply not provided the resources to do the job. This article was a fitting tribute to the founding fathers of Butler County who served the military, through the ensuing generations who continued to serve. Perhaps it will also serve to stimulate dialogue on the assistance that returning veterans have earned from their service. Such support knows no political boundaries. Cindy Morgan-Olson New York

MICHEL NISCHAN says we should know where our food comes from. At the Westport restaurant he plans to open with Paul Newman in August, the food will come from cows and vegetables raised without relying on hormones or pesticides. The menu will also feature several kinds of fish, preferably caught within miles of the restaurant and preferably served within hours of being caught. Mr. Nischan, who is active in the organic food movement, is teaming with Mr. Newman to create a restaurant called the Dressing Room next to the Westport Country Playhouse that will serve traditional American foods and rely on produce, cheese and meat from state farmers.

Megan Wolfe Benett and David Martyn Ratzan were married yesterday afternoon at Bourne Farm in West Falmouth, Mass. The ceremony was led by Judith S. Kaye, the chief judge of New York State, who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate. The bride, 34, is a law clerk to Judge Kaye. In 2001 and 2002 she was a staff lawyer for the Claims Resolution Tribunal in Zurich, which processes claims for dormant Swiss bank accounts from the Nazi era. She graduated from Stanford and received her law degree cum laude from the University of Michigan.

Ending Truce, Hamas Fires Rockets Into Israel Hamas fired at least 15 rockets from Gaza into Israel, formally ending a truce after eight Palestinians, including four children, were killed on a crowded Gaza beach by what appeared to be an errant Israeli shell. To the Editor: As a high school junior, I commiserated with the teenagers featured in ''The Lost Summer.'' Our generation has a remarkably new criterion by which we can be rejected from our top-choice universities. We must worry not only about our SAT scores and G.P.A.'s, but also about how we spend our free time. If one applicant worked with a research lab on debilitating diseases and another reinforced a church in sub-Saharan Africa, is there room for the bright, well-rounded applicant from our parents' generations? Somewhere between doing summer course work for Advanced Placement classes, volunteering as an emergency medical technician and working two jobs, I forgot to make room in my schedule to work in an orphanage. RYAN CROWLEY Morristown, N.J.
A pawnshop full of go-for-broke accessories with plenty of collateral interest.

If ''To be, or not to be'' conjures images of a wan and slender Prince of Denmark prowling the gloomy turrets of Elsinore Castle as he ponders his own mortality, well, think again. Picture an overweight, bleary-eyed hulk of a man dressed in his underwear, slumped in an armchair, whisky flask in hand, glass poised at his lips. And listen as a magnificent actor named Morlan Higgins declaims Shakespeare's immortal text in a voice tinged with enough personal regret and heartbreak to move one to tears. ''Exits and Entrances'' is the South African playwright Athol Fugard's latest work, and the role of Andre Huguenet, a legendary Afrikaan actor for whom the writer served as ''dresser'' in the early stages of his own aborted acting career, is any performer's dream part. Where else, in a 90-minute outing, would one have the chance to tear into Hamlet's melancholy soliloquy, stumble bloody-faced and eyeless through Oedipus's howling monologue, pour forth the tormented ramblings of Cardinal Mindszenty in Bridget Boland's ''Prisoner''?

High school athletes will soon be living the legacy of Coach Codey. Details are in place for random drug testing in championship events, as Richard J. Codey, then the governor, directed in an executive order in December. Testing will start this fall. Under the plan adopted by the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association last week, New Jersey will become the first state to require random steroid screening of scholastic athletes. Five percent of about 10,000 players in state tournaments will have to take urine tests after championship games.

The Food section is the first one I look at in the magazine, and sitting in our Putnam County home, thousands of miles from my country of birth, I was pleasantly surprised (and nostalgic) to see R. W. Apple Jr.'s recollection of Leon's Russian Grill in Tehran (May 28). That is where my future husband took me for dinner on our first date. Thank you, Mr. Apple, for mentioning that special restaurant, a very good one. My favorite was karsky, the lamb dish, a rack of chops grilled to perfection. Karina Lima Patterson, N.Y.

JUSTIN G. SCHILLER, who collects and sells art and old and rare books, is shopping for a Manhattan apartment. But he has no intention of plunking down a single penny for one. Rather, he plans to do something fittingly old-fashioned: barter. In a time when half a million dollars barely buys a studio in New York, Mr. Schiller is hoping to trade a watercolor drawing by his longtime friend Maurice Sendak, perhaps best known for his children's book ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' for an apartment.

THERE are four large cardboard packing boxes sitting in my front hall that irritate me every time I walk by them, which is many times a day. These packages arrived at my doorstep via U.P.S. several weeks ago, predating my daughter's arrival home from college by a day or two. They sit, a glaring reminder of how difficult it can be to reabsorb the college student back into the household. The boxes are packed to the brim with dirty laundry, blankets and pillows, sweaters and scarves, a couple of stretched canvases, framed photos and much more -- I have only skimmed the top layers. (My daughter ships what she doesn't store on campus, since her college is far enough away that she travels there by plane.) The key point, however, is that both she and the boxes have been home since May and still, they remain unpacked.

MICHEL NISCHAN says we should know where our food comes from. At the Westport restaurant he plans to open with Paul Newman in August, the food will come from cows and vegetables raised without relying on hormones or pesticides. The menu will also feature several kinds of fish, preferably caught within miles of the restaurant and preferably served within hours of being caught. Mr. Nischan, who is active in the organic food movement, is teaming with Mr. Newman to create a restaurant called the Dressing Room next to the Westport Country Playhouse that will serve traditional American foods and rely on produce, cheese and meat from state farmers.

Samantha Jones Brodlieb, a daughter of Nancy and Richard A. Brodlieb of Huntington, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Stetter Platner, a son of Gertrude and Robert B. Platner of Parlin, N.J. The Rev. Carlye J. Hughes performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. Mrs. Platner, 30, is the public relations and marketing manager of Angel Sanchez, a designer of evening wear and bridal gowns in New York. She graduated from Sweet Briar College. Her father works in Paterson, N.J., as the sales and marketing director of Sunset International, an import division of Istikbal, a Turkish furniture maker. Her mother prepares floral arrangements for events like weddings and corporate parties.

To the Editor: During the 19th century my great-great-great grandfather, James Sinclair, was at the head of the oldest stoneworking business in New York City, which was named after him and founded in 1820. He furnished the stonework for the city's bank buildings, the Stock Exchange Building, the Astor Library Building, St. Luke's Hospital, the old Times Building in 1857 and the residences of many prominent figures. He saw Wall Street built over twice and took down stone he had laid for buildings now outdated, giving way to new structures which he also built.

THE sign on the Lou Gehrig baseball says ''Not for Sale,'' but that does not stop memorabilia collectors and sports fans who flock to the Hobby Shop in Aberdeen from asking Marvin Schutzer, the owner, to name his price. ''One guy walked in here and said: 'How much do you want for it? I'll pay anything, anything,' '' Mr. Schutzer, 65, recalled. ''But I told him what I tell everyone else, that the ball means too much to me to ever want to part with it and that one day it will go to my oldest son, with instructions never to sell.''

To the Editor: Congratulations to Alice Elliott Dark for managing to trot out just about every negative stereotype that exists about bar or bat mitzvahs (''For an Information-Hungry Mom, 13 Is a Lucky Number,'' June 4).

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Marion Jones Adds New York Event to Comeback Trail'' (June 3): As a track and field official, and a former competitor, I am frustrated by your limited coverage of track and field. We get an occasional item about a top athlete's performance in a popular event (usually the 100 or the mile) and an overabundance of articles about Marion Jones, who has not done much recently.

TOWARD the end of the ''I Love Lucy'' television series, which ran from 1951 to 1957, the Ricardo family moved from New York City to ''the country'' -- Westport, to be exact -- and Lucy started raising chickens. From then on, all of America saw Connecticut as ''the country.'' Oddly enough, that moment marked the beginning of the mass exodus of upwardly mobile New Yorkers to the suburbs of the metropolitan region -- and the beginning of the end of animal agriculture in this state.
To the Editor: Congratulations for your enlightening and indispensable tribute to New York's unsung and largely uncelebrated stoneworkers and their legacy (''Written in Stone,'' June 4).

MY spring planting never occurs in spring. I have to use the phrase ''spring planting'' loosely to accommodate the fact that it always happens in summer. I start dreaming in March, but by June only delusions have sprouted. I buy seeds, imagining I will have time to cultivate them in little pots or trays. In reality, my tote bag and kitchen cabinets hold packets of seed pods long past their expiration dates. I yearn with a fever bred by generations. Everybody in my family was a closet gardener in a city apartment, producing pale lunar indoor stalks on the shadowy shelf above the winter coats.

THE showcase promoted a number of underground Asian bands, but most of the audience at the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa on this Sunday night had come out to see a three-man rap group, the Notorious MSG, whose account of an unusual trajectory from the kitchens of Chinatown restaurants to the local stage was the big draw. By 9 p.m., with fists and camcorders raised, the crowd cheered as the group bounded onto the stage. They were outfitted in matching black Adidas tracksuits, sunglasses, and three distinct hairstyles: Jheri-curled mullet, frizzy dreadlocks and bowl cut.

To the Editor: I am a psychologist and a life member of the American Psychological Association. The opinion expressed by Stephen Behnke, director of ethics of the association, that participation of psychologists in the interrogation of prisoners at Guantánamo and such places (''Psychologists Preferred for Detainees,'' National Briefing item, June 7) is acceptable and ''a valuable contribution'' certainly does not reflect my view nor, necessarily, that of the membership as a whole.

The new government of Iraq has decided to postpone any demand for negotiations to establish a more formal legal basis for the presence of American and other foreign troops on its soil, Iraqi and American officials said this week. Instead, these officials said, Iraq will allow the current United Nations mandate to remain in effect beyond a deadline next Thursday for a review of Security Council Resolution 1637, which authorizes the American-led military coalition to continue combat operations.

Has your grande/half-skim-half-soy/mocha/no-foam latte lost its luster? At Café Beethoven in Chatham, you'll find specialty drinks reminiscent of a Viennese cafe. The Fur Elise ($3.25), which combines cocoa, coffee, steamed milk and orange wedge, goes well with one of the cafe's pastries (petits fours, napoleons, croissants) or muffins and sweet breads (a morning favorite is banana-blueberry bread, at $1.25 a slice).

To the Sports Editor: Gary Sheffield and Hideki Matsui are great players, no doubt. Their replacements in the batting order provide a level of intensity, scrappiness and hunger to prove themselves that the Yankees have lacked in their starting lineup since the championship years. Strange as it seems, the Yankees are a better team without an All-Star at every position. Steve Hermanos San Francisco

THE image is etched in his memory: a woman caressing the name of a soldier at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. Ned Benton, a college professor and history buff, wondered about the story behind that name, which made him think about the stories behind the names of the dozens of soldiers memorialized in the Village of Larchmont, where he lives. Eight years ago, as the village was updating its Web site, Mr. Benton and his colleagues at the Larchmont Historical Society had an idea: Why not use the Internet to tell the stories of these soldiers? The challenge was to uncover the information.

Rebecca May Seamans and Carlos Egea were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Carleton P. Jones performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. The bride, 30, is an architect at Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates in New York. She graduated from Wesleyan University and received a master's degree in architecture from the University of Pennsylvania.

THE killing of Iraq's most wanted terrorist leader, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, won't end the country's civil strife. There may be as many as 100 insurgent groups waging war against United States forces, and often, each other. They are not fully understood, in part because their relationships seem to evolve from month to month. Already this year, several new groups have emerged.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Surge in Racist Mood Raises Concerns on Eve of World Cup'' (June 4): When Jim Crow laws existed in parts of this country and black citizens were set upon by racist hooligans, pickets often greeted officials from those regions when they traveled.

West Village Co-op $1,100,000 MANHATTAN: 260 West 10th Street (at Greenwich Street) A one-bedroom, two-bath co-op. Jayme Gordis, the Corcoran Group (718) 832-4197; www.corcoran.com MAINTENANCE: $1,340 a month PROS: A former carriage house, this co-op has a private entrance with tall, wide doors and a small gated stoop. The living space has 13-foot ceilings, exposed brick, a wood-burning fireplace and a sunken dining area. Parking is available on the property for $130 a month. CONS: Although the bedroom has a window, it still has a basement feel as it is below street level. In addition, it is reached by a spiral staircase best left to the sure-footed. Boerum Hill Condo $695,000 BROOKLYN: 497 Pacific Street (at Third Street), #2A A 1,200-square-foot, one-bedroom, two-bath condo in an old sail-making factory building, converted about 20 years ago. Sue Wolfe, Nancy McKiernan Realty (718) 858-3822, ext. 100; www.brooklynbrownstones.com. Open house Sunday, 1-2 p.m. COMMON CHARGE: $503 a month; taxes, $123 a month PROS: The apartment has a classic loft layout and feel, and is flooded with light through seven huge windows. A 120-square-foot storage space on the same floor is included and could become a home office, and another small bedroom could be carved out of the apartment itself. CONS: The bedroom at the very end of the loft gets very little light and is not currently screened off from the rest of the apartment. Upper East Side Condo $1,750,000 MANHATTAN: 715 Park Avenue (between 69th and 70th Streets), #11E A one-bedroom, one-bath condo. Elie Khen, Bellmarc Realty (212) 517-9100, ext. 213; www.bellmarc.com COMMON CHARGE: $1,000 a month, plus $570 in taxes PROS: This Park Avenue apartment has a modern vibe thanks to its white palette, dark oak floors and open streamlined kitchen. It is also wired for surround sound. There are south- and east-facing windows, as well as a terrace off the living room with enough room for lounging. The limestone bathroom has nice features like an oversize shower head and towel warmers. The building has laundry facilities and allows pets. CONS: There is not a lot of closet space. Castle on a Hill $2,795,000 NEW JERSEY: 83 Chestnut Street South, Livingston A 6,000-square-foot English colonial, with gables and a turret, built in 1995. The house has five bedrooms, five and a half baths, 12-foot ceilings, a finished basement with exercise room, an office and a great room. There is also a free-form outdoor pool with a spa, two staircases, a gourmet kitchen and two fireplaces. Kathy Gering, Gail Lowenstein Realtors (973) 994-4323; www.gaillowenstein.com TAXES: $36,397 a year PROS: The rooms are abundantly spacious, but not cavernous, and flow beautifully. The backyard pool area, including the spa and waterfall, is private and resortlike. CONS: This is deep suburbia; it may take a few extra minutes of driving time to get to a cup of coffee. Condo Conversion $1,779,240 CONNECTICUT: 25 Forest Street, Stamford A 2,400-square-foot condo with three bedrooms, three baths, an office, a new kitchen and a terrace. It is the first completed unit in the conversion of the Classic. Common charges cover many amenities. Jessica Rohm, the Classic Condominiums (203) 967-9500; www.theclassiccondos.com COMMON CHARGE: $1,164 a month; taxes, $18,405 a year PROS: The living areas in this penthouse are focused around views of the Stamford skyline. Smaller units in the building start as low as $376,000. CONS: This project is not for buyers in a hurry -- the remaining tenants had until June 10 to decide whether to buy, which means many conversions are only just beginning.

A listing in the Summer Arts Calendar on May 21, about Shakespeare on the Sound in Pinkney Park in Rowayton, misstated the admission policy and the address. Performances are free, but contributions are accepted; tickets do not cost $10 to $20. The park is at 177 Rowayton Avenue, not 176.

An article on May 21 about the soprano Birgit Nilsson included an outdated reference to a forthcoming English translation of her autobiography. The book is to be published by the University Press of New England, not Baskerville Publishers.

It's all been said before, at one university or another. And so, in trying to come up with something new, many commencement speakers do considerable research on what to say -- and what it is permissible to say -- before they address graduating students. This year, Judith Resnik, a legal scholar, could win the exhaustive-preparation prize. For her speech at Bryn Mawr, Dr. Resnik reviewed over 100 years of commencement addresses.

The National Academy of Sciences released a report on alternatives to the Indian Point nuclear reactors in Buchanan on Tuesday that pleased critics and supporters of the plant. The report, commissioned three years ago in a bill sponsored by Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Westchester Democrat, found that New York could replace the energy generated by Indian Point if the reactors were shut down, but that other options would be costlier, create more pollution, and leave New Yorkers more vulnerable to natural gas shortages.

When Bettina S. Simon quit on June 1 as the chief legal officer at Mannatech, a vitamins and nutritional supplements manufacturer in Coppell, Tex., she departed with some pretty sizable, not to mention unusual, parting gifts. According to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ms. Simon, 57, received her ''executive desk, executive chair and two side chairs.'' That is in addition to her company car and a monthly consulting contract that will pay her $10,000 a month for a year -- two far more common items handed out to departing corporate executives.

IT is daunting enough to mount a direct challenge to the likes of Toyota and Honda, but Hyundai's quest to join the top ranks of global automakers has been complicated by the legal troubles of its chairman in Korea and by turbulence in the top ranks of its American operations. No longer a late-night punch line, the Hyundai-Kia Automotive Group now ranks No. 6 in worldwide sales, according to Automotive News, a trade publication. And Hyundai was already one of the world's fastest-growing major automakers when it opened an assembly plant -- its first American factory -- in Montgomery, Ala., in 2005. Cars from Hyundai and its Kia subsidiary, which not long ago were cellar dwellers in the quality and reliability ratings of J. D. Power & Associates and other survey firms, have shown steady improvement. Some have even achieved best-in-class status.

To the Editor: In ''Shameless in the Senate'' (column, June 5), Paul Krugman writes about the estate tax repeal and ''moderate Republicans like Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island who consistently cave in to the party's right wing.'' This statement is puzzling. Anyone familiar with my voting record would never use the phrase ''cave in.'' In his Feb. 10 column, Mr. Krugman wrote about the tax cut debate of 2001 that ''even some Republican senators were skeptical'' of the $1.6 trillion tax cut and were responsible for scaling it back to $1.35 trillion. This, as Mr. Krugman said, led to the ''sunsets'' and the expiration of the estate tax in 2010. The skeptical Republican senators were actually only three, myself being one.

Works of religious art are generally found in churches or in the permanent-collection rooms of major museums. It is rare to see them in a contemporary art museum. But for the next nine months, at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill, ''Reverence'' invites viewers to lift their eyes to spiritual heights, and depths. As an agnostic who has spent a great deal of time at churches and temples looking at religious art, I approached this exhibition with a measure of skepticism; how, I wondered, could contemporary artists compete with the great masters of religious art?

To the Sports Editor: I was on the sideline of a soccer game in New Jersey watching my 14-year-old son in a tournament when a player on the opposing team directed an ethnic slur at one of my son's teammates. This is not an infrequent occurrence in youth soccer. The league has a no-tolerance policy for such behavior, but it is rarely enforced.

RASKIN--Harold 6/12/96. 10 year anniversary. Missed, loved, & remem bered everyday. Always in the hearts of your children & grandchildren. Love, Donald, Mara, Jason, Erica, Cindy, Lou, Matthew, Benjamin Daniel, Susan, Alan Brandon, Keith & Jonathan

Call it a case of revising taxation with uneven representation. First, the taxation: Last week, New Jersey's top two lawmakers announced that they were launching a series of summer committee hearings on strategies to beat back the frequent increases in what are already the nation's highest property taxes.

In the basement of a weathered grocery store on a gentrifying stretch of downtown White Plains, Feeling Mizik, a Haitian compas band, rehearses every Saturday night. Compas, Haiti's popular music, is rooted in a fusion of African rhythms, Haitian Creole culture and European ballroom dancing. And these days it is frequently updated with strains of hip-hop, funk and salsa, its Creole lyrics meshed with English and Spanish. Ever-changing compas -- also spelled kompa, as it is pronounced, or konpa -- provides Haitian-Americans from Miami to Brooklyn and points in Westchester with a vital link to their past. The members of Feeling Mizik, which may be the only compas band based in Westchester, have been living in White Plains for as long as 35 years and as little as two months. Most of them didn't play compas until they arrived in the United States.

To the Editor: The assumption underlying ''Why It's Right to Test,'' by Peter Staley (Op-Ed, June 4), is that more people are not testing for H.I.V. because written consent, which is currently required by New York State law, is a barrier. Written consent is not a barrier to patients testing for H.I.V.
