To the Editor: Congratulations to Hunterdon County, N.J., for its public information campaign credited in reducing by half the annual new cases of Lyme disease. By comparison, in Suffolk County, where millions are spent in fighting the much-hyped mosquito-transmitted West Nile Virus (which over the past several years averaged only a few new cases), our public officials scarcely make any reference to the presence of Lyme, despite the number of new cases being in the hundreds annually. They've tried ignoring it. It didn't go away!

THE 7:47 a.m. Long Island Rail Road train from Ronkonkoma to Jamaica pulled into the Deer Park station, and Sandra Krebelj-Douglas eyed her fellow passengers carefully. As one of eight official ''note takers'' for the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council, a volunteer group that acts as the voice of the railroad's passengers, she was preparing to monitor riders' behavior in a two-month program to establish the nature and extent of antisocial behavior. Results from the note takers, who ride different lines from different stations, will be used in a report sent to railroad management later in the year.
KURZ--Israel Beloved husband, dearest father, grandfather, and great grandfather. Always there for all of us. A pillar for his community and his people.
MENOWITZ--Sophie. Died June 11, 1979, twentyseven long years ago. Loving wife, mother, grandmother. We shall always remember your devotion to your family. Your loving family

VILLENCY--Ruth, on June 10, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Devoted mother of Roy and Linda Neuberger and Bob and Rowann Villency. Dear grandmother of Juliet and Osher Jungreis, Susan and Shlomo Lancry, Aharon and Ariel Neuberger, Miriam and Alvin Hess, Nechama and Yaakov Slatus, Cara and Joshna Sacks, Eric and Kimberly Villency. Also survived by 20 great-grandchildren. Past President of Palm Beach Chapter of Friends of Akim. Secretary-Treasurer of Maurice Villency, Inc. She was always first to help people who needed her. Service Sunday 11:45 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

IF ''shabby'' can be mistaken for ''blighted,'' then yes, the brick apartments at 150 Secatogue Avenue, where the ''No'' on the ''No Vacancy'' sign is intentionally obscured by dirty white paper, qualify. These may be garden apartments, but this is no garden spot. Unlike the landscaping at two brick complexes around the corner on busy Conklin Avenue, where signs advertise luxury apartments and condominiums, the grounds here suffer from terminal neglect. Odd, considering that some of the tenants are the same Latino day laborers hired to manicure the properties of Long Island homeowners who can afford to pay someone else to keep their lawns green and pools pristine.

ROTHMAN--Lester D., in New York City on June 6 at the age of 94. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Dr. Rothman graduated from NYU School of Medicine and practiced Internal Medicine in New York for over 60 years. He was also a veteran of World War II, serving as a Flight Surgeon in the Army Air Forces in the Asiatic-Pacific Theatre. Survivors include his loving wife, Judith Sadoski, son Dr. Peter M. Rothman of Fort Wayne, Indiana, grandson Wilson J. Rothman of Fort Lee, New Jersey, granddaughter Caroline Rothman Victory of Sarasota, Florida, and many nieces and nephews. Dr. Rothman was predeceased by his first wife, Rosemarie Brancato Rothman, and his two sisters, Jean Rothenberg and Sylvia Palant. In accordance with his wishes, no memorial service is planned. Acknowledgements of his passing may be sent to the American Heart Association.

The sinuous lines of the fin de siècle textile patterns and Art Nouveau movement have injected a new spirit into the current rigid style of fashion. The most stunning example, large photo at right, worn last month by the New Yorker Ingrid Yonke, was hand-painted to duplicate the cut-velvet 1900 Worth gown next to it, now on view in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's British fashion exhibition. Spring clothes are echoing the flourishes of gates, like the one above, one of the beauties at Old Westbury Gardens, on Long Island. Exotic flowers like the black iris, bottom left, called ''Hello Darkness,'' and the vines of scarlet nasturtiums were just a couple of nature's influences on textiles of the Art Nouveau period.

To the Editor: It is certainly true that Democrats have failed woefully to build effective organizations at the state and local levels, Ohio being perhaps the most glaring example. But I think that Daniel Galvin (Op-Ed, June 3) misses the most important reason that Democrats are impatient and anxious with Howard Dean's strategy to focus on the long term, rather than on the coming fall elections.

Sallie L. Krawcheck, the chief financial officer of Citigroup, is widely regarded as one of the most powerful women in business, but she has never been a director of a public corporation. That is about to change because Dell Inc., whose annual meeting will be on July 21, has nominated her to its board. Ms. Krawcheck, who turned 41 in late November, will be more than a decade younger than nine of her fellow Dell directors. But she won't be the youngest.

To the Editor: The Democratic Party's vision has deteriorated into anti-Republicanism after the failure of its vision of the welfare state as an ideal. If the Democrats don't wake up and realize that more government can evolve only into totalitarianism, all the strategy and tactics for getting elected will be for naught.

I chuckled as I read the letters (May 28) criticizing Kevin Kelly's article (May 14) on the coming revolution in distributing book content online. The critics are clearly bedfellows in print: writers, publishers a museum curator. The same kind of entrenched folks no doubt resisted the digital transformation of library card catalogs a few years ago. And long before that, blacksmiths and wagonmakers were similarly disposed against the railroaders. All disruptive technologies have their momentary detractors. What an exciting time we readers live in. Sheldon Peck Waban, Mass.

To the Editor: In ''A World-Class Party'' (May 28), Jeff Z. Klein describes all of the merriment and excitement that will surround the soccer competition in Germany. Of all the venues in Germany, Mr. Klein selects Cologne as his choice because of its ''smart hotels'' and ''culturally sophisticated attractions.'' He singles out one of those attractions, Pascha, described as a ''10-story bordello'' where soccer fans from all over the world are already being welcomed. To add a bit of humor, Mr. Klein mentions that this brothel is ''on the aptly named Hornstrasse.'' I suppose we are all meant to chuckle and wink at this point. It's too bad it's not victimless fun. Many groups fighting human trafficking have been bringing attention to the plight of young women and girls who will inevitably be brought into Germany to ''service'' the merry soccer fans during this monthlong competition.

AN agreeable cloud of mystery hovers over Sri Thai in Montclair, one that was not dispelled by two visits and several phone calls over the past couple of months. In a sense, the restaurant is Déjà Vu all over again: that's the name of the establishment it replaced about six months ago. If you examine Sri Thai's takeout menu, with its intriguing amalgam of Thai and French dishes, you'll see that the restaurant's name has been carefully taped over Déjà Vu's. So have the prices, which (as on the sit-down menu) average about $2 lower.

Suzanne Elizabeth Kerrigan was married last evening to Adam Grey Ciongoli. Associate Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. of the Supreme Court, for whom the bridegroom is a clerk in Washington, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Mrs. Ciongoli, 36, is the general counsel and the chief operating officer of Spencer Capital Management, investment advisers in New York. She graduated from Columbia and received her law degree magna cum laude from Cornell. She is the daughter of Lisa Kirkland of Brattleboro, Vt., and James M. Kerrigan of Ithaca, N.Y. Her father is a lawyer in Ithaca. Her mother teaches special education students at the Green Street School in Brattleboro.

ZISKIN--Philip F., Passed away on June 8th, 2006. He is now playing Black Jack, drinking scotch, and gone fishing with his buddy Herb. Great husband, father, grandfather, friend, and WWII vet. Your Loving Ziskin Family.

THEY MADE AMERICA: From the Steam Engine to the Search Engine -- Two Centuries of Innovators, by Harold Evans with Gail Buckland and David Lefer. (Back Bay/ Little, Brown, $18.95.) Sir Harold, the historian, publisher and journalist, follows up ''The American Century'' (1998) with absorbing profiles of Americans from the Wright brothers to Bill Gates, whose inventiveness changed the way we live. The author sees innovation as ''a distinguishing characteristic of the United States'' -- both a product of and a contributor to American society. Originally published as an illustrated large-format volume, ''They Made America'' was the basis of a four-part television series for PBS in 2004. ''This is a rich, wide-ranging work,'' Neil Genzlinger wrote in the Book Review.

When they write the history of New York State politics, 2006 will undoubtedly be labeled a particularly strange year. This is the year that control over the state budget has moved solidly into the governor's office. The Legislature's role, steadily diminishing over the last few years, has been whittled down to that of official supplicant. Gov. George Pataki has essentially taken on the role of state parent, and New York's 212 legislators can do nothing more than whine, plead, denounce and delay.

SEASON OPENER The News -- The 2006 Congressional campaign season got under way early, with a special election for a House seat in San Diego. Behind the News -- Republicans held on to the seat, which was left vacant when Randy Cunningham resigned after pleading guilty in a corruption scandal. But the thin victory margin of the winner, Brian P. Bilbray, was a sign that the party may be in for difficult times in more competitive districts. Campaigns were already in full swing in some of those districts, long before the traditional Labor Day start of the election season. CYBER-RIVALRY The News -- Google unveiled a new online spreadsheet program, the latest volley in its attacks against its rival Microsoft. Behind the News -- The free program, Google Spreadsheets, is designed to allow multiple users to work on a spreadsheet simultaneously. But more important, perhaps, is that it can read files created in Microsoft's popular program Excel. So it's another step in Google's efforts to make inroads on Microsoft's core business, desktop programs. Microsoft has countered in recent years by expanding its Web offerings. BOOMTOWN The News -- Construction contractors for the Freedom Tower announced they would begin work on the foundation by blasting away bedrock. Behind the News -- While the thought of more explosions at the World Trade Center site might be chilling to residents and workers in Lower Manhattan, those in charge of the project said that the detonations, to be carried out over two months, would hardly be noticeable. Blasting, they added, would produce far less dust and din than the constant pounding of an alternative method, hydraulic rams attached to backhoes. M-M-MEMORIES The News -- Barbra Streisand announced she would perform in 20 cities this fall, her first concert tour in a dozen years. Behind the News -- Since Ms. Streisand, 64, never really retired, it's not a comeback tour. A more accurate description might be ''marathon fund-raising event.'' The singer, who has long used her concerts to raise money for political causes, said she would donate proceeds this time to educational, environmental and women's health groups. PLAYTIME The News -- The 32-team World Cup soccer tournament got under way in Germany with the opening match in Munich. Behind the News -- Concerns about how the monthlong event might be affected by racist fans, bribable referees, an influx of prostitutes and even the shape of the ball dominated much of the discussion in the weeks leading up to it. Most of the worries melted away as play began, although German and English fans had to be separated by police officers in Frankfut. In the opener, Germany defeated Costa Rica, 4-2.

President Bush's two-day strategy session starting Monday at Camp David is intended to revive highly tangible efforts to shore up Iraq's new government, from getting the electricity back on in Baghdad to purging the security forces of revenge-seeking militias, White House officials said. Three years of efforts to accomplish those goals have largely failed. Billions of dollars have been spent on both electricity and security, yet residents of Baghdad get only five to eight hours of power a day, and the American ambassador acknowledged on Friday that the city is ''more insecure now than it was a few months ago.''

INTERNATIONAL 3-20 Taliban Surges in Afghanistan A large springtime offensive by the Taliban has turned into their strongest show of force since American forces chased them from power in late 2001, and Afghan and foreign officials and local villagers blamed a scarcity of United States-led coalition forces for the resurgence. 1 Hamas Rockets Hit Israel Hamas fired at least 15 Qassam rockets from Gaza into Israel, ending a 16-month truce with Israel, a day after eight Palestinians, including four children, were killed on a Gaza beach, apparently by an errant Israeli shell. 8 Iran to Present Counteroffer Iran's foreign minister said that the government would issue a counteroffer to an proposal by Europe, China and the United States to get Iran give up enriching uranium in the short term. troops on its soil, Iraqi and American officials said. 20 Concern Over China's Coal Use China uses more coal than the United States, the European Union and Japan combined, and the increase in global-warming gases from China's coal use will probably exceed that for all industrialized countries combined over the next 25 years, surpassing by five times the reduction in such emissions that the Kyoto Protocol seeks. 1 Progress in Hariri Inquiry The head of the United Nations inquiry into the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister, said he was making ''considerable progress'' and had established the case was probably a suicide bombing, but he revealed nothing new about who was behind the killing. 27 Zarqawi Planned Expansion At the time of his death, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi was still trying to transform his organization into a global operation capable of striking far beyond Iraq's borders, recruiting terrorists both in Iraq and abroad, intelligence experts agree. 1 Venezuela Forges New Force President Hugo Chávez is attempting to create Latin America's largest civilian reserve force as part of Venezuela's rising military profile, in preparation for what Mr. Chavez insists is the threat of invasion by the United States. 3 NATIONAL 28-37 Suicides at Guantánamo Three detainees being held at the United States military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, apparently committed suicide, the first deaths of detainees to be reported at the military prison since it opened in early 2002, American military officials said. 1 Medicare Problems Continue Bush administration officials say Medicare's new prescription drug program is humming along smoothly, but many patients still say they have difficulty getting the drugs they need. 32 Democrats Courting Bloggers If there is an emerging consensus among much of the Democratic Party establishment, it is that blogs are an important emerging power in American politics. What is less clear is how mainstream politicians grapple with an audience that has defined itself in part by its dissatisfaction with mainstream politicians. 37 Recruiters Look to MySpace Many companies that recruit on college campuses have been using search engines to conduct background checks on seniors looking for their first job. But now, college career counselors and other experts say, some recruiters are also looking up applicants on social networking sites like Facebook and MySpace. 1 OBITUARIES 45 Charles F. Connecticut's eight-year experiment with electric deregulation has not delivered on its promise of lower prices and customer choice. Instead, prices have soared, competition never materialized and the only people who are happy are owners and shareholders of electric generators, many of which are making record profits. In response, the General Assembly held hearings in mid-May and last Monday to consider solutions, among them a bill that's a good first step toward fixing what is broken. The state cannot afford to wait until next year. The General Assembly should pass the proposed bill in special session, before campaign season starts in earnest, to provide long-term relief for residents and businesses burdened by the cost of power.

Attorney General Eliot Spitzer hit back at his rivals today, who have tried to paint him as a tax-and-spend Democrat. Following a speech this morning to the New York State Conference of Mayors, he unveiled his own plan to cut property taxes by $6 billion over three years, targeted at the middle class and seniors.

The sunny -- and lightly regulated -- Cayman Islands are a favorite choice of hedge funds seeking to domicile themselves offshore. But Dublin, which has an active industry for servicing hedge funds, is working to lure more of them, according to an article in Hedgeweek, an Irish publication.

Texas Regional Bancshares said Monday that it had agreed to be acquired by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria for $38.90 a share, or about $2.18 billion. The announcement confirmed reports from earlier in the day that Spain's BBVA was in talks to buy the McAllen, Tex.-based bank, which had about $6.6 billion in assets as of March 31.

The honeymoon period that followed eBay's purchase of Skype is clearly over, and many investors want to know what is in it for them. The moment of truth is likely to come this week as eBay, the heavyweight of online auctions, is expected to explain how it will integrate Skype's Internet phone service into its United States operations.

Two private equity investors in the United States may buy a stake in the German state bank HSH Nordbank in a move that could signal Germany's petrified bank ownership structure is starting to crumble.

Thomas C. Mazzucco has joined UBS as its global head of Internet investment banking, the securities firm said Monday. Mr. Mazzucco, who had previously been head of Internet banking at Lehman Brothers, will be located in UBS' San Francisco office, the firm said in a press release.

Cowen Group, a New York-based investment bank that is a unit of French bank Societe Generale, set the parameters of its initial public offering on Monday, saying it would seek to raise as much as $235 million.

The United Kingdom's financial regulator said Monday that United States regulations would not automatically apply to British companies in the event that a U.S. exchange bought the London Stock Exchange. This news is of vital importance to the Nasdaq Stock Market, which is still considering a second bid for the London exchange. Many observers have been worried that such a deal might end up bringing the stringent provisions of the U.S.'s Sarbanes-Oxley Act across the Atlantic.

Gilbert White's Selborne Journal: Saturday, 12 June 1784: 29 4/10 1/2; 59 1/2; W, SW. Sun & clouds with strong gale. Men wash their sheep. Some wood-strawberries eatable. Finished tacking the vines. Hoed carrots, parsneps, &c. Received 5 gallons & a quart of French brandy from Mr. Edmd. Woods.

Lehman Brothers on Monday reported a 47 percent rise in net income for the fiscal second quarter, kicking off earnings season for the major investment banks on a strong note. Net income increased to $1 billion in the three months ended May 31 from $683 million a year earlier, Lehman said in a statement. Lehman's trading and merger advisory businesses were strong performers.

Plains All American Pipeline said on Monday it had agreed to buy Pacific Energy Partners for $2.4 billion in cash and stock, including the assumption of debt, marking another deal in the sought-after pipeline sector.
The Mirant Corporation, the Atlanta-based power company, said on Monday it had withdrawn its unsolicited $8 billion bid for NRG Energy, saying NRG was unwilling to discuss the offer.

Signet Group, the world's largest specialty-jewelry retailer, said it has held talks about a takeover of its main U.S. competitor, Zale. Shares in the U.K. company, which also owns H. Samuel and Kay Jewelers, had their biggest gain in more than three years.

The Bank of New York Company said on Monday it had acquired TD Banknorth's bond administration business for an undisclosed sum, increasing its trust and agency operations. Through the takeover, Bank of New York acquired about 350 bond trusteeships and agency appointments, representing $5.2 billion in debt outstanding.

A wireless equipment maker in California, Powerwave Technologies, said on Monday it was buying the majority of the wireless infrastructure business from a British rival, Filtronic, in a deal worth $336 million.

CapVest and Blackstone Group, the private equity firms, are the favorites to acquire Unilever's frozen food businesses for an estimated 1 billion pounds ($1.8 billion) in an auction that could be a prelude to the sale of the Anglo-Dutch group's home-cleaning business.

A venture-backed Waltham, Mass. company that's quietly amassed more than 650,000 Internet domain names is stepping out of stealth mode today and unveiling its plans to build a substantial Boston-area Web 2.0 business around the emerging field of "direct navigation."

Renowned corporate blogger Robert Scoble, credited with helping to break down a siege mentality at his employer, Microsoft, confirmed Sunday that he is leaving to join a Silicon Valley video blogging start-up.
Having built a portfolio that's reached the $2 billion mark in just two years since its founding, Morgan Creek Capital is looking to overseas markets for new opportunities.
With help from Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, One True Media has added its name to the growing list of start-ups making tools to edit and share video and photographs online.

Poste Italiane's CEO Massimo Sarmi told Fortune that the post office will be ready for privatization by year-end, estimating the company could be worth $13 billion. It's a goal Italy's newly elected government seems set to embrace, spurred by the Netherlands and Germany, where selling the national postal service has not only brought in revenue but also improved performance.
Standard Life, Europe's largest mutual insurer, is to become the latest victim of turbulent stock markets and is expected to lower the price range for its planned flotation by as much as 10 percent.

A crop of ethanol producers is fetching premium I.P.O. valuations, but their growth is predicated on unsustainable ethanol prices, according to Breakingviews. As Alan Greenspan noted this week, the economics of the business aren't there and Breakingviews warns that investors may be in for some nasty surprises.

Although not initially favored to pull it off, David Wormsley, the head of U.K. investment banking at Citigroup (he is widely known as "The Worm"), has emerged triumphant from the extraordinary 10.1 billion pound ($18.6 billion) battle for U.K. airports operator BAA. In the face of the fiercest competition, he and his colleague Philip Robert-Tissot have delivered BAA into the hands of his client, Ferrovial, the Spanish construction group.
Reuters Group has bought risk management software firm Application Networks for $41 million cash to expand the services it can offer customers, the news and financial data company said on Sunday.
Cisco Systems, one of the more frequent shoppers of venture-backed companies, has snapped up two communications software start-ups, Metreos and Audium, for a combined $47.8 million.

Kushner, whose jailed founder was a key link between former New Jersey Gov. James McGreevey and his lover, Golan Cipal, is considering offers to sell a piece of its real estate empire for about $2 billion, The New York Post reported.

Banco Bilbao Vizcay Argentaria, a large Spanish bank, is considering buying Texas Regional Bancshares, in its latest bid for a small regional bank. The two sides are in preliminary talks, according to The New York Times, but it remains possible that the negotiations could break down.
A consortium including Goldman Sachs may agree to a 2.5 billion pound ($4.6 billion) deal to acquire Associated British Ports as soon as this week, according to press reports.
Arcelor, the world's second-largest steelmaker, said it rejected a revised offer by hostile suitor Mittal Steel and will meet Mittal again to discuss the prospect of a higher bid.

Several people wrote in during our live play-by-play of the England-Paraguay game to complain about the late-afternoon shadows cast at the Waldstadion in Frankfurt by some kind of gigantic cubelike thing suspended from the roof of the stadium. The contrast between harsh sunlight and deep shadow made the match very hard to follow on TV. Here's the culprit: there's a huge scoreboard and videotron dangling from up in the stadium rafters, as if were some kind of hockey rink on steroids.

Everyone loves the Soca Warriors today, and why not? They've done their nation proud and lifted the spirits of underdogs everywhere. And, of course, Trinbagonians know how to have a good time. So remembering the great soca anthems from 1989, when Trinidad and Tobago came oh so close to reaching Italia '90, and intrigued by Austin Kelley's reference to the current soca hit "Keepah" during his commentary of the T & T-Sweden match on Saturday, we've found the motherlode of World Cup-themed tunes from Scarborough to Guayaguayare to John John, and it's right here at Warrior Nation, the site of the Soca Warriors Supporters Club. You can hear "Keepah," by Madix, "Time fuh Germany," by Nigel Fabian, or "Sweet Soca Music," featuring T & T defenders Brent Sancho, Dennis Lawrence and Cyd Gray and midfielder Carlos Edwards. But our favorite is "Soca Warriors Anthem," by Gino McKoy, in part because it references the chorus of "Road to Italy," the No. 1 soca hit from the heady days of the '89 Strike Squad team, written and sung by SuperBlue. That chorus: "T ahnd T, we want ah goal!"

Leading Democrats in the State Senate proposed a broad package of legislation yesterday aimed at increasing the supply and quality of moderately priced housing in New York. The package included items long on the agenda of New York City housing advocates, like repealing a state law that forbids the city from making its own rent laws, as well as new proposals, like the creation of a housing council to coordinate the various state agencies involved in housing and community development. The Democrats accused Gov. George E. Pataki of failing to take the lead on the issue, and said they wanted to make housing a key issue in the statewide elections this fall.

The state police searched yesterday for an escaped prison inmate in connection with the shooting of a state trooper, Sean Brown, during a traffic stop on Saturday. Trooper Brown was in fair condition yesterday with a single gunshot wound to the abdomen. The suspect, Ralph Phillips, 43, who was serving time for a parole violation, used a can opener to escape from the Erie County Correctional Facility in Alden in April, the state police said. The Press & Sun-Bulletin in Binghamton reported yesterday that the state police were seeking a stolen white pickup truck with tinted windows and large rust spots on the hood. The newspaper quoted Trooper Mark O'Donnell, a state police spokesman, as saying that several checkpoints had been set up in the area.

A man was arrested on Saturday afternoon after the police said he stabbed another man who had tried to steal his jewelry in Central Park. The suspect, Thomas Norflett, 44, of Central Park West, was charged with weapons possession. The police said the stabbing victim, Melvin Grady, 32, of the Bronx, tried to take Mr. Norflett's chain about 4:20 p.m. inside the park near 110th Street and Central Park West. The two struggled, the police said, and Mr. Norflett stabbed Mr. Grady in the chest. Mr. Grady, who was in stable condition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center yesterday, was charged with robbery, the police said.

The son of a prominent advocate in the Hispanic community was fatally shot outside a convenience store in East Camden about 9:45 p.m. on Friday night. The man, Andres Camacho III, 26, of Camden, was the son of Andres Camacho, a board member of the Puerto Rican Culture and Arts Center and a staff member of the Camden County Office of Hispanic Affairs, The Courier-Post of Cherry Hill reported yesterday. He is also the nephew of Assemblywoman Nilsa Cruz-Perez, the newspaper reported. The police said they had no motive for the slaying, but are looking for a man caught on videotape by a store surveillance camera.

A woman was charged yesterday afternoon with the fatal stabbing of a man with whom she shared a house on East Booker Avenue, the Suffolk County police said. The woman, Micki Pryor, 29, was charged with first degree manslaughter, the police said. According to the police, Ms. Pryor argued with the victim, Bennie Lenord, 46, about noon yesterday at the home they shared. During the argument, the police said, she picked up a kitchen knife and stabbed him in the chest.

Four teenagers were seriously injured when they were struck by a car while trying to cross Richmond Avenue early yesterday, the police said. The four, two 16-year-old girls, a 16-year-old boy and a 14-year-old girl, were struck about 12:20 a.m. while crossing Richmond Avenue near Amsterdam Place in the New Springville section, the police said. They were crossing in the middle of the block, the police said. The driver of a 1991 Honda spotted the group and tried to stop, but skidded into them, the police said. One of the 16-year-old girls and the 14-year-old girl suffered head injuries and were in critical condition yesterday, and the other two were in stable condition. The driver was not ticketed, the police said. Neither the driver nor the pedestrians were identified by the police.

Ernie Banks, who had a Hall of Fame career with the Chicago Cubs from 1953 to 1971, last month told The Tribune Company's chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, that he would like to be part of a group that could buy the team, Crain's Chicago Business reported on its Web site.

Harvard won the 141st Harvard-Yale Regatta for the seventh year in a row yesterday on the Thames River in New London, Conn. The Crimson finished the four-mile men's heavyweight crew race in 23 minutes 22.6 seconds. Yale finished two boat lengths behind in 23:30.4. Harvard has won 20 of the last 22 regattas, extending its dominance in the nation's oldest intercollegiate athletic competition. The Crimson leads the series, 88-53.
Fernando Alonso led yesterday's British Grand Prix in Silverstone from the pole to the finish for his 13th career victory, his third in a row and his fifth this season.

Daniele Contini of Italy won the 165-kilometer (102.5-mile) second stage of the Tour of Switzerland yesterday after a long solo attack. Contini, a 31-year-old rider for LPR, broke away after 50 kilometers and finished just over five minutes ahead of his compatriot Daniele Bennati and Erik Zabel of Germany.

Levi Leipheimer of the United States, preparing for the Tour de France, won the Dauphiné Libéré yesterday. Christophe Moreau of France was second in the event, a warm-up for the Tour, 1 minute 48 seconds back, and Bernard Kohl of Germany was third.

The Harmon brothers, Butch, Bill and Craig (a fourth brother, Dick, died this year), have spent a lifetime connected to Winged Foot Golf Club through their father, Claude, the club's longtime head golf professional.

Phil Mickelson's changes in his practice regimen have put him on an equal footing with Tiger Woods entering the United States Open at Winged Foot Golf Club. With a look at the challenges of Winged Foot and its rich Open history. Section F.
BREGER--Anita (nee Blankfein). Of Aventura, FL. Beloved daughter and sister. Loving and devoted mother of Bruce and Kenneth. True to herself always. There will never ever be another you.

COLE--Bernard Michael, 84, of Boca Raton, passed June 11, 2006. He is survived by his beloved wife Rita, by two loving children, Dr. Alan (Harriet) Cole, Stephanie (John) Eason, and by his wonderful grandchildren Dr. Lisa (Jonathan) Cole Olin, and Rebecca (Adam) Cole Lurie. He was president of The Alan Braid Co., Stribbons Ltd., Weaving Corp. of America and Georgia Narrow Fabrics, Inc., which was ultimately sold to the Blackstone Group. Peers considered him a legend in his industry. He spent the majority of his life in New York, then retired to Boca Raton, Florida, where he enjoyed life at St. Andrews Country Club. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to your favorite charities. Funeral services will be Monday, June 12th, at 2pm at The Gardens Mausoleum, Boca Raton, Florida. Shiva will be at the residence on Monday and Tuesday evening and at the home of Alan and Harriet Cole in Natick, MA, for the remainder of the shiva week. Contact Sinai Memorial Chapels, Delray Beach, Florida, 561-865-1747.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Talks With Russians On Investment Freedom Russian, American, European and Japanese officials are negotiating over whether Russia should be allowed greater latitude to invest in utilities, pipelines, natural gas facilities and other infrastructure in the United States and Europe. A1 U.S. Rejects Witness Account The top American commander in Iraq rejected as ''baloney'' an account by an Iraqi eyewitness who said a dying man resembling Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the terrorist leader, had been beaten by American troops after warplanes demolished Mr. Zarqawi's safe house with two bombs. A10 Iran Refuses Preconditions Iran has begun a public campaign apparently aimed at nudging the six nations that have offered a package of incentives into negotiations over its nuclear program without first freezing its efforts to make nuclear fuel. Ali Larijani, Iran's chief negotiator, told reporters that Iran would support negotiations but without prior conditions. A11 China Fires Olympics Official A senior Beijing official responsible for overseeing the huge construction projects planned for the 2008 Olympics was dismissed from his post for corruption, the state news media reported. A11 Shift in Mexico's Election Law Courts in Mexico recently interpreted electoral law to give the Federal Election Institute, created by congress to eliminate campaign fraud, broad authority to ban any speech that besmirches a candidate's reputation or is false. The agency's rulings in this year's campaign have raised free-speech issues. A3 Hamas to Fight Referendum The militant faction Hamas announced its intent to block a July 26 referendum called for by Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, after failing to reach an agreement in talks with him. A8 NATIONAL A12-15 Prisoners' Ruse Is a Focus Of Guantánamo Inquiry Three detainees at the United States military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, tried to conceal themselves in their cells to prevent guards from seeing them commit suicide, a senior military official said. Military officials said one focus of an investigation into the suicides would be the need for procedural changes. A1 Auto Union Expects Hard Times The president of the United Automobile Workers union, Ron Gettelfinger, left , told his members in a strikingly blunt report that they cannot ride out the automobile industry crisis and should be prepared to make tradition-breaking decisions to help rescue the industry. A1 Elderly Women Held in Fraud Two women in their 70's, posing as aunts, fiancées or cousins, took out numerous life insurance policies on two homeless men, prosecutors say, collecting over $2.2 million after the men died in hit-and-run traffic cases. The women pleaded not guilty to federal charges of mail fraud and submitting false insurance applications. A12 Questions on Duke Rape Case The case against the three Duke lacrosse players accused of rape appears to some to be falling apart. Three players have been indicted, but evidence that has surfaced has thrown the accusuer's account into doubt. The prosecutor has refused to speak publicly about the case since the beginning of April. A13 Study of Arab-Americans In a study financed by the Justice Department, Arab-Americans reported suspicion of government and law enforcement, and concerns about their civil liberties. The study also concluded that local police officers and federal agents were straining under the pressure to fight terrorism and that new federal policies in this effort were poorly defined and inconsistently applied. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Black and Hispanic Leaders Meet to Block Candidate A group of black and Hispanic elected officials from Brooklyn plan to devise strategies to keep a white city councilman from winning the Congressional seat held for the last two decades by Major R. Owens, who is black. B1 Ring Tone Only for Young High school students in the New York area have begun using a high-pitched cell phone ring tone, inaudible to older people, to surreptitiously communicate in classrooms and places where phone use is prohibited. A1 Mentally Ill With Diabetes Roughly one in five mentally ill people develop diabetes, and as more of the mentally ill population die from the disease and related complications than from suicide, mental health professionals have begun to debate the customary limits of psychiatric practice. A1 ARTS E1-10 Tonys Are Awarded ''Jersey Boys,'' the surprise hit about the Four Seasons as told through their songs, won the big prize -- best musical -- at the Tony Awards, as well as three more, including best actor for John Lloyd Young The show's main competitor, ''The Drowsy Chaperone,'' picked up five awards, including best book, best score and best featured actress. E1 Ensler Organizes Arts Festival Eve Ensler, the author of the ''Vagina Monologues,'' has organized an arts festival in New York focused on violence against women. The festival, set to begin today, expands the V-Day franchise, the global movement that Ms. Ensler ignited in 1998 with benefit performances of her play. E1 OBITUARIES B7 Flora Gill Jacobs An internationally recognized authority on dollhouses, she was 87. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Investors Reducing Risk As stock markets from India to Brazil to the United States skidded last week, there was little doubt that investors were dumping risk from their portfolios. The question for the coming week is whether investors feel comfortable with the risk they have left. C1 Product Placement in Books Procter & Gamble has signed an unusual marketing partnership to showcase its Cover Girl makeup products in a novel for young adults. C1 Credit Suisse May Sell Unit AXA, the French insurance company, is in exclusive talks with Credit Suisse to buy its Winterthur insurance division in a deal worth more than $8 billion, according to a person with direct knowledge of the transaction. C2 Leaking Exclusive Pictures The first pictures of Shiloh Nouvel Jolie-Pitt were leaked to several gossip blogs before they appeared in People Magazine, which paid millions for the exclusive right to publish them. An article on May 26 about a commencement speech by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, in which he urged an end to the political manipulation of science, referred incorrectly to Terri Schiavo, the Florida woman at the center of a politically charged debate over the right to die. Ms. Schiavo was brain-damaged at the time of her death in March 2005; she had not been brain-dead.

A report by the Associated Press in the National Briefing column on Thursday about a lawsuit against the Vatican involving sexual abuse accusations against a priest, the Rev. Andrew Ronan, misstated the year of his death. It was 1992, not 1970.

Busta Rhymes ''The Big Bang'' (Aftermath/Interscope) Busta Rhymes wants to make a classic hip-hop CD. He wants to be the king of New York. And so, for his seventh album, ''The Big Bang,'' he became serious. He joined forces with Dr. Dre, hip-hop's bluest-chip producer. He recruited respected guests like Q-Tip and, more impressive, Stevie Wonder. He recorded earnest songs about his tough childhood and the state of hip-hop.

A sports article on Thursday about tennis players who have perfected the slide on clay courts like those at the French Open misstated the nationality of Martin Jaite, who played on the men's tour in the 1980's and early 1990's. He is Argentine, not Chilean.

Safeway, Pleasanton, Calif., is placing its $250 million television advertising account in review after working for more than five years with Dailey & Associates, West Hollywood, Calif., which will not take part in the review. The assignments handled by Dailey, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, included creative duties, promotions and media planning and buying. Safeway hired Pile & Company, Boston, to help manage the review. Hewlett-Packard, Palo Alto, Calif., is expanding its relationship with Enterprise IG, part of the WPP Group, by naming the agency to handle its worldwide brand identity and strategy duties, which had been handled by Stone Yamashita Partners, San Francisco. Spending has not been determined. The Enterprise IG New York office will lead the account, working with offices in cities including London and San Francisco.

NEWMAN--David. Died June 9, 2006 in NYC at 75. Survived by a wife, two brothers, two daughters and one grandson. He served in the Korean War. He owned and manufactured ladies sportswear. Contributions to Hospice Care, Visiting Nurse Service of NY.

To the Editor: Autism does not have to be a life sentence. Who am I to make such a statement? I am the author of ''Son-Rise,'' one of the ''bibles of hope'' referred to by Cammie McGovern in ''Autism's Parent Trap'' (Op-Ed, June 5). I am also the co-founder, with my wife, Samahria, of the Autism Treatment Center of America.

Winged Foot Golf Club is located in Mamaroneck, N.Y., 27 miles north of New York City. Getting There by Car Spectator parking will be provided at lots located north and south of the course, with free transportation to and from the course. There is no general spectator parking available in the immediate vicinity of the course. All other parking is by permit only. General spectator parking will provide parking for the disabled, and specially equipped vans will be available to shuttle disabled spectators who are confined to wheelchairs or who require supplemental oxygen to the course. It is recommended spectators purchase round-trip rail tickets before boarding the train to go to the tournament. The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.87 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.06 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.76 percent.

Regina Spektor ''Begin to Hope'' (Sire) Regina Spektor is the queen of the quizzical. She has a sweetly good-humored voice, some classical piano training from her childhood in Russia and a gift for sounding far more naïve than she is. On her new album, ''Begin to Hope,'' she asks pointed questions like, ''If I kiss you where it's sore/Will you feel better, better, better/Will you feel anything at all?'' She makes observations like ''Summer in the city means cleavage.'' And she can unfurl a poetic illogic that can be romantic or hard-nosed.

Leading Democrats in the State Senate proposed a broad package of legislation yesterday aimed at increasing the supply and quality of moderately priced housing in New York. The package included items long on the agenda of New York City housing advocates, like repealing a state law that forbids the city from making its own rent laws, as well as new proposals, like the creation of a housing council to coordinate the various state agencies involved in housing and community development. The Democrats accused Gov. George E. Pataki of failing to take the lead on the issue, and said they wanted to make housing a key issue in the statewide elections this fall. ''It's not just poor families and it's not just New York City,'' said Senator Liz Krueger, a Manhattan Democrat and ranking member of the Senate's committee for housing, construction and community development. ''It's a statewide issue.'' NICHOLAS CONFESSORE (NYT)

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a competition to design a working-class apartment development in the South Bronx incorrectly stated the date the competition would be announced. It is today, not yesterday.

The problem with reality television is not that it traffics in humiliation. The problem is that it's not humiliating enough. There is no excuse for a series about spoiled suburban housewives that focuses on their inner lives. Yet ''The Tuesday Night Book Club,'' which begins tomorrow on CBS, showcases soul-searching and empowerment. Despite leering promos that promise bosomy, botoxed heroines drinking, dancing and plotting adultery (a Sisterhood of the Traveling Hot Pants), the series is a teary feel-bad/grow-stronger pageant along the lines of the daytime life-coaching series ''Starting Over.''

To the Editor: Paul Krugman writes (''The DeLay Principle,'' column, June 9) of ''a peculiar obligation to men of great wealth'' that politicians today owe to their financial benefactors such that they would cut their taxes in time of war.

To the Editor: As the sponsor of legislation introduced this week in the Senate that would ban imports of sweatshop products, I read Nicholas D. Kristof's June 6 column, ''In Praise of the Maligned Sweatshop,'' with dismay.

INVESTORS SHUN RISK -- The terms differ slightly -- a nervous sell-off, a correction, the beginnings of a bear market. But as markets from India to Brazil to the United States skidded last week, there was little doubt that investors were dumping risk from their portfolios. The question is whether investors feel comfortable with the risk they have left. [C1.] BIG DOUBLE BILL -- The Nasdaq Tower, left, and the Reuters sign in Times Square are two of the most valuable advertising spaces in the world. Now, with a deal to be announced today, advertisers can rent both spaces at once -- and create a virtual roadblock on the south side of the square. It is a partnership that the two companies hope will leverage both ad spaces to stand out in a sea of advertising. [C10.] BEATING PEOPLE TO THE PUNCH -- After People magazine won the very expensive rights to the first photographs of Shiloh Nouvel Jolie-Pitt and before they were published, they appeared on gossip blogs and other Web sites. [C1.] FOX'S MOVIE STRATEGY -- For the year to date, Fox is No. 1 in move theater market share. At the same time, it has fostered a corporate culture that its parent company, the News Corporation, seeks in all its television, news and mobile entertainment divisions: eyes fixed on the bottom line while remaining fearless about creative risks. [C1.] BOOKS AND PRODUCT PLACEMENT -- Procter & Gamble has made a deal to help market a novel for teenagers called ''Cathy's Book.'' [C1.] SUPPORT FOR LAW FIRM -- The embattled securities class-action law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman is receiving some political backing with the release of a statement signed by four Democrats from the House of Representatives condemning last month's indictment of the law firm on criminal charges. [C10.] IRE OVER E-MAIL TAX -- A French member of the European Parliament, Alain Lamassoure, recently uttered the dreaded T-word -- taxes -- in connection with e-mail and mobile-phone text messages, and in so doing earned the wrath of the Internet generation. [C9.] NOT CHOCOLATE, BUT CAMERAS -- With the installation of new souped-up automated kiosks in three shopping malls this week, Sony hopes to make the purchase of many of its electronics products as easy as buying a piece of chocolate. [C9.] INTERNET AND OLDER SHOPPERS -- Older consumers, who generally sat out the Internet's first big commercial push, are helping to feed the surging Web economy. And because this group has far more disposable cash than any other, executives who have not already begun tweaking their strategies to reach them will probably do so soon, online analysts and executives say. Philip Charles-Pierre, above, a Travelocity executive, said a program aimed at AARP Passport members has helped the company tap into an increasingly affluent market. [C8.] DIGITAL REGRETS -- So many years into the digital revolution, even those with presumably the highest levels of computer expertise seem to get caught up and embarrassed by their ''digital trail'' -- that wide wake we tend to leave as we transact an electronically mediated life. Tom Zeller Jr.: Link by Link. [C5.] ONLINE WIRELESS LIVING -- Communities around the country getting into the telecommunications business, wireless gambling, simple fixes for Wi-Fi woes, Internet calling without a laptop and more. A special report is at nytimes.com/technology. THE CLASSICS -- Previous columns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/pages/timesselect. YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with ''Your Money,'' a free weekly newsletter. It can be found at nytimes.com/yourmoney. THE WALK-THROUGH BLOG -- Writers for The New York Times look at residential real estate news, trends and tidbits at nytimes.com/walkthrough.

During the first week of June TNT and ESPN's ratings continued to benefit from their N.B.A. broadcasts. As the conference finals reached their climaxes, two Miami Heat-Detroit Pistons matchups on ESPN were the most-watched cable shows in the week that ended on June 4. One drew 6.6 million viewers; the other brought in 6.46 million. Three Dallas Mavericks-Phoenix Suns games on TNT also made the Top 10 list of the week, putting that channel atop the primetime rankings in Nielsen's estimates. The week's most-watched entertainment show was Comedy Central's special ''Blue Collar Comedy Tour: One for the Road,'' which delivered an audience of 5.31 million. The June 4 movie, starring Jeff Foxworthy, above, Larry the Cable Guy and other members of the Blue Collar troupe, was the eighth most popular show ever telecast on Comedy Central. KATE AURTHUR

Sonic Youth ''Rather Ripped'' (Geffen) Sonic Youth is 25, and its 20th album appears tomorrow. You may forget that math, or you may fixate on it. What was Sonic Youth's past, in larger terms, anyway? What did the band stand for, except unorthodox guitar tunings, overtones, conceptual art, popular culture (inasmuch as it could be related to conceptual art), inside jokes, fanzines and -- somewhat skeptically -- rock 'n' roll?

The top audiobooks are almost evenly split between tales of hard-boiled mystery and self-help books, which probably reflects as many purchases by people gearing up for summer road trips as by those commuting to the office. Readers seeking moral guidance or inspiration might look to the top 10 classics at BarnesandNoble.com, among them John Steinbeck's ''Of Mice & Men'' (above), Homer's ''Odyssey,'' Mark Twain's ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' and Tzu Sun's ''Art of War.'' SHELLY FREIERMAN

To the Editor: As a financial adviser, I spend much of my time helping clients decide how to handle their estate tax liability.
To the Editor: An examination of the financing behind the anti-estate tax movement provides one of the best reasons for keeping this tax.

Jones Is On When It Counts THE WORLD'S BEST golfer was Bobby Jones, a 27-year-old amateur (and lawyer) from Atlanta. The next year, he won the Grand Slam of that day: United States Open, United States Amateur, British Open and British Amateur. This time at Winged Foot, he was erratic one day, sensational the next. In the final round, he led by six strokes with six holes to play, then crumbled until his curling 12-foot putt on the 72nd hole gave him a 79 and a first-place tie with Al Espinosa, at 294. The next day, in a 36-hole playoff, Jones shot 72-69 and won by 23 strokes. As the leading pro, Espinosa won $1,000. Jones, an amateur, left with only a trophy. Casper by a Stroke FOR THE FIRST TIME in the tournament's history, the final round was postponed a day. In the cold and wind of the last day, many had an opportunity to win. Ben Hogan, seeking his fifth Open title, needed only a par 70, but his putter betrayed him and he shot a 76. He tied for eighth place with Sam Snead, who had a 75. Mike Souchak, who knew the Winged Foot course well because he was once an assistant pro there, left his chip shot short on the 72nd hole. Bob Rosburg recorded sensational birdies, holing a 50-foot explosion from a trap on the 11th hole and a 50-foot putt on the 12th. He needed a 30-foot putt on the 18th and missed. Billy Casper, 27, finished at 282 and won by a stroke over Rosburg. Casper played 72 holes with few gambles and near-faultless putting (114 putts over 72 holes). Hale Irwin's Magic 2-Iron IT WAS HALE IRWIN against the legends, and the legends lost. In the first round, Jack Nicklaus's 25-foot birdie putt on the first hole caught the ridge and ended up 28 feet from the hole. Johnny Miller, the defending champion, had three consecutive bunker shots roll back to his feet on the par-3 seventh hole and took a 7. In the second round, Gary Player took a triple-bogey 7 on the fourth hole and a double-bogey 6 on the 14th, where his shanked bunker shot almost hit Arnold Palmer. Lee Trevino missed the cut. Tom Watson entered the final round leading by a stroke, only to finish with nine bogeys and a 79. Irwin, with six bogeys, struggled in the last round, too. But he managed to put a 2-iron on the 72nd green and twoputted to defeat Forrest Fezler by two strokes with a 287, seven over par. Fuzzy Zoeller and the White Towel TRAFFIC, PARKING and crowd-control problems were so bad that Jim Hand, the president of the United States Golf Association, said, ''This is an absolute zoo.'' The tournament ended in a wild way, too. On the 72nd hole, Greg Norman made a sliding 45-foot putt for par and tied Fuzzy Zoeller for the lead. Zoeller, standing in the fairway, thought Norman had made birdie for the lead and waved a white towel in mock surrender. Zoeller made par for 276, forcing an 18-hole playoff the next day. On the second hole of the playoff, Zoeller rolled in a 68-foot downhill putt, Norman three-putted from 18 feet, and a runaway began. Zoeller won with a 67 to Norman's 75. Walking to the final green, Norman, beaten but still with a sense of humor, waved his own white towel. FRANK LITSKY (NYT)

The ''Campaign for Real Beauty'' for Dove, sold by Unilever, won two major awards. The advertising part of the campaign, created by the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, won the Grand Effie at the 38th annual Effie Awards, sponsored by the New York American Marketing Association. The public relations part of the campaign, by Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc., won the 2006 Best of Silver Anvil Award from the Public Relations Society of America. A radio commercial for the National Thoroughbred Racing Association by DeVito/Verdi, New York, won the $100,000 grand prize in the 15th annual Radio-Mercury Awards, administered by the Radio Creative Fund.

MEISEL--Irving. Irving S. Meisel, 84, of Scarborough, NY died late in the afternoon on Saturday, June 10 from complications of brain cancer. A marketing and advertising executive for the Browne Vintners Company of the Seagram Corporation and, later on, of the the Schiefflin Company, Mr. Meisel was among the pioneers of consumer-friendly sales promotion, marketing, and advertising techniques from the late 1950s through the 1980s. He also created equally consumer - friendly techniques for innovative packaging in the early days of the bubble pack period as president of MAMM Industries. He is survived by his son, Perry Meisel of Manhattan. Funeral services will be held at Sharon Gardens, Kensico Cemetery, in Valhalla, NY on Monday June 12 at 1PM.

SAFON--David M. Age 43, suddenly, on June 10, 2006. A partner in the New York office of Ford & Harrison, he was a widely respected labor and employment lawyer, admired for his personal integrity and character, as well as his knowledge and skills. Unassuming and forever giving, he was a former president of his synagogue, Congregation Ohav Sholom, and a source of wise and compassionate counsel to his family, friends, colleagues, and clients. He will be dearly missed by everyone his life touched. In addition to his beloved wife, Lisa, he is survived by his children, Jenny, Keith and Noah. Funeral services are scheduled for Monday, June 12, 2006, at 11 o'clock A.M. at Congregation Ohav Sholom, 145 South Merrick Avenue, Merrick, NY. For directions, see www.ohav.org. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Chai Life Line or Congregation Ohav Sholom. $(6$)SAFON--David. Congregation Ohav Sholom deeply mournsthe sudden and untimely loss of our beloved and respected past president, Board of Education Chair and friend. We will profoundly miss his warmth, gentle humor, and devotion to the synagogue. Heartfelt sympathy to beloved wife Lisa, cherished children, Jenny, Keith and Noah and all his dear family. Funeral Monday, June 12, 11 AM, at Ohav Sholom, 145 South Merrick Avenue, Merrick, NY. Jeremiah Wohlberg, Rabbi Peter Tannenbaum, Pres.

9 P.M. (VH1) THE DRUG YEARS -- Sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll. Is anything more all-American? This four-part documentary chronicles the drug craze (including reefer madness, above) in the last half of the 20th century through interviews with former smugglers, government agents, journalists, musicians, actors and policy advocates. Among those offering hazy confessions are Peter Coyote, Jackson Browne, Ice-T, Liz Phair, Juliette Lewis, Tommy Chong, Richard Belzer, Richard Lewis, John Mellencamp, Henry Rollins and Russell Simmons. 8 P.M. (Fox) HELL'S KITCHEN -- Fire in the hole! The deliciously hot-headed Gordon Ramsay, a professional soccer player-turned-Michelin star chef, plays drill sergeant to 12 fledgling restaurateurs hoping to win the title of executive chef at the Red Rock Casino Resort and Spa in Las Vegas. 8 P.M. (A&E) LOOK, UP IN THE SKY! THE AMAZING STORY OF SUPERMAN -- Everyone thinks he's got a grip on the Man of Steel, but what's really going on beneath that tough exterior? This documentary begins with his emergence in 1938 -- an immigrant who leaves his home to reinvent himself in the land of opportunity -- and traces the trajectory of his superhero-ness, which has acted as a sort of pop-culture barometer of the American ideal. Kevin Spacey, who plays Lex Luthor in the upcoming ''Superman Returns,'' narrates. 9 P.M. (BBC America) FRANCES TUESDAY -- A gangster's moll (Tamzin Outhwaite) changes her identity in order to save her life, and that of her daughter, after her ex-boyfriend is released from prison in this made-for-television thriller. But will she get recognized when she infiltrates his inner circle? 9 P.M. (TNT) THE CLOSER -- Deputy Chief Brenda Johnson (the sweet-tart Kyra Sedgwick, left), who heads the Priority Homicide Division of the L.A.P.D., is back with the doughnuts and the bad disposition in the season premiere of last summer's breakout hit. First up: the murders of a fellow officer and the drug dealer he was investigating. 10 P.M. (A&E) ROCK PAPER SCISSORS CHAMPIONSHIP -- There's nothing childish about the $50,000 grand prize in this first-time event, held, after months of regional tournaments, in April at the House of Blues in Las Vegas. The squabbling lawyers who were recently ordered by a district court judge to use the game to resolve a dispute might want to watch and get pointers. 10 P.M. (ABC) HOW TO GET THE GUY -- Four attractive and available women (from near right, Michelle, Alissa, Anne and Kris) determinedly scour the streets of San Francisco for Mr. Right in this new reality series that purports to take the guesswork out of the opposite sex. Lesson No. 1: how to attract him in the first place. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
KLEIN--Bernard L. 6/12/02. Gone these four years, you are missed and loved everyday. Helpful to many, generous to all. Alice Klein and Family

LANG--Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Sid. Devoted mother of Barbara, Susan and Nancy and mother-in-law of Rob Feldman and Jerry Passaro. Cherished grandmother of Steven and Lauren. Loving sister of Dora, Annie, Millie and Jeannie. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. You will live forever in our hearts.

ENG--Suzanne nee Reardon, passed away peacefully on June 9, 2006 at age 59 after a 30 year valiant struggle with multiple sclerosis. Her husband Jimmy Eng and two children Jimmy Jr. and Michele sustained her in the long illness with a love and care rarely seen and they serve as an inspiration to all who loved her. She is survived by brothers James, Gerard, Dennis and Michael and sisters Betty Reardon and Kathleen DiPersio (Richard) as well as 22 nieces and nephews. For information Stutzmann Funeral Home 718-465-3210. Donations may be made to The National Multiple Sclerosis Foundation.

To the Editor: ''Industry's Role in Hypertension'' (editorial, May 30) and ''Unease on Industry's Role in Hypertension Debate'' (front page, May 20) portray the American Society of Hypertension as seeking to increase the number of patients who are candidates for blood pressure medications at the behest of pharmaceutical companies seeking greater profits. We strongly disagree with this portrayal.
To the Editor: Only the richest 1 percent of the population now pay the estate tax. What kind of hold must they have on those senators who voted to repeal it?

Because of an editing error, the Drilling Down report in Business Day last Monday about an increase in revenue from college textbooks because of rising prices referred incorrectly to a sales figure. The $1.7 billion in used textbooks sold last year was from sales only in college bookstores; it did not include other sources, like online sales.

A Critic's Notebook article on May 30 about ''Operation Atropos,'' a video by the artist Coco Fusco about a training course in military interrogation, misstated the background of Team Delta, the private organization that provided the training. Its members were formerly intelligence interrogators in the United States military, not in the United States Intelligence Agency.

GREER--Linda. Beloved wife of Leonard. Loving father of Nicole and Leigh. Dear sister of Mark. Beloved grandmother of Jake and Zachary. Services Tuesday, 11 am, Central Synagogue, 55th Street and Lexington Avenue.

MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL American League BOSTON RED SOX--Recalled LHP Jon Lester from Pawtucket of the IL. Optioned RHP Craig Hansen to Pawtucket. CLEVELAND INDIANS--Recalled INF Ramon Vazquez from Buffalo of the IL. Optioned INF Lou Merloni to Buffalo. KANSAS CITY ROYALS--Acquired RHP Brandon Duckworth from Pittsburgh for cash considerations. Designated RHP Kyle Snyder for assignment. Optioned RHP Leo Nunez to Omaha of the PCL. Added RHP Todd Wellemeyer to the 25-man roster. YANKEES--Activated RHP Shawn Chacon from the 15-day DL. Designated RHP Scott Erickson for assignment. OAKLAND ATHLETICS--Agreed to terms with RHP Chad Lee, OF Jermaine Mitchell, OF Toddric Johnson, LHP Branden Dewing, INF Mike Affronti, 1B Greg Dowling, C Jacob Smith, RHP Patrick Currin and RHP Josh Morgan. National League COLORADO ROCKIES--Agreed to terms with OF David Christensen, RHP Craig Baker, OF Kevin Clark, C Michael McKenry, RHP Brandon Hynick, RHP William Harris, RHP David Arnold, C Austin Rauch, RF Victor Ferrante, CF Anthony Jackson, RHP Michael Gibbs, RHP Andrew Graham, LHP Devin Collis, SS Matthew Repec, RHP Drew Shetrone, and 1B Joshua Banda. MILWAUKEE BREWERS--Recalled RHP Carlos Villanueva from Huntsville of the Southern League. PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES--Placed C Mike Lieberthal on the 15-day DL, retroactive to June 6. Recalled RHP Brian Sanches from Scranton/Wilkes-Barre of the IL. Announced Scranton/Wilkes-Barre of the IL will move to Allentown for the 2008 season. WASHINGTON NATIONALS--Activated RF Jose Guillen from the 15-day DL. Optioned OF Mike Vento to New Orleans of the PCL.
''Uncontrolled diabetes can ruin a person's life as much as uncontrolled schizophrenia.'' DR. JOHN NEWCOMER,a professor of psychiatry at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis. [A1]

An article in Business Day on June 1 about an economic battle over efforts to recover oil from the Orinoco Belt region in eastern Venezuela misstated the estimated size of the area being developed. It is about 4,500 square miles, not 54 square miles.

A sports article on Friday about the authorities' revelations regarding the use of performance-enhancing substances by pitcher Jason Grimsley, and their effect on the Arizona Diamondbacks, who granted his request to be released, gave an outdated name for the team's home stadium in Phoenix. It is Chase Field, not Bank One Ballpark.

''The History Boys,'' Alan Bennett's story of the students and dueling educational philosophies at a British secondary school, had an outstanding showing at the 60th annual Tony Awards last night, picking up six prizes, including best play, best direction, best actor and best featured actress in a play. ''The History Boys'' beat out two other British imports, Martin McDonagh's ''Lieutenant of Inishmore'' and Conor McPherson's ''Shining City,'' as well as the one American nominee, David Lindsay-Abaire's ''Rabbit Hole.''

BOBMAN--Hana. June 10, 2006, of Rego Park, NY. Beloved sister of Marilyn (Howard) Spencer and the late Martin Bobman. Survived by nieces and nephews, great nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday, 2 pm, Locustwood Memorial Park, Cherry Hill. Contributions to City of Hope. Info: Platt, 856-428-9442.

To the Editor: Walter Isaacson writes (''Go Southeast, Young Man,'' Op-Ed, June 8), ''President Bush said that if he were young and looking to make his mark or some money, he would move to New Orleans.''

For now, at least, the Yankees do not believe that starters Dontrelle Willis of Florida or Barry Zito of Oakland are available in trades. The Yankees have made it a priority to bolster their staff before the July 31 trading deadline, but the return of one starter did not help much yesterday. Pitching for the first time since May 16, Shawn Chacon was uneven. The Athletics moved at least one runner to third base in every inning he pitched, and he was lifted before the first out of the sixth inning.

As we reach the midpoint of Mad Scientist Week, I want to get into some madder, badder territory. Today's question is: does the egg matter? That is, genes aside, how much does the other stuff in an egg affect what sort of animal you get? If, for instance, you remove the genes from a pigeon egg and put in chicken genes instead, what would you get? A pigeon? A chicken? A weird mix? Nothing at all?

William F. Weld's aides had promised that the former candidate for governor would deliver "Secrets of My Campaign" at the annual awards dinner tonight of the Brownstone Republican Club. But anyone expecting a tell-all by Mr. Weld would have been disappointed.

"Isn't that Khalid?" my cousin asked, pointing across the street to a lithe figure in a fading track suit, slowly creeping along the sidewalk with his back to the wall. He carried a Russian-made PKC machine gun, with an ammunition belt wrapped around his shoulders. A black ski mask covered his face.

We were listening to "The Brian Lehrer Show" this morning on WNYC, the National Public Radio station in New York City wnyc.org, when the discussion turned to the World Cup and its newfound appeal to the front-running members of the American literati.

A mortgage lender, Greenlight Financial Services, announces its Green Living Essay Contest. People are invited to write up to 500 words about the benefits of eco-friendliness at home. The prizewinner gets $2,500, presumably to be used toward conservation-minded home improvements. Deadline is July 20. -- JOYCE COHEN

Forbes.com is running a series of videos on the most expensive homes in America. To make it easier to digest, the homes are broken down by region. Start with the South and go from there. -- DAMON DARLIN
When does the real estate market really get bad? When those adjustable rates reset upwards and mortgage payers can't make the higher payments.
Is Tom Suozzi a superhero?
Anybody who cares about the developing world can't help wondering about the injustices one sees. Why do small children always get malaria and die? And why is Allan Rosenfield dying of ALS?
Credit Agricole just announced that it was gobbling up Greek lender Emporiki for 3.1 billion euro ($3.9 billion). And it may not be full yet.

To the list of London's many charms, add one more: distressed debt. The Times of London reports that United States-based hedge funds and investment banks are sending staff there in droves as they seek to invest in the credit of Europe's troubled companies.

Thomas R. Suozzi might be trailing in the polls, but he was the only one of the three gubernatorial candidates to receive a standing ovation from the New York State Conference of Mayors at their meeting in Saratoga Springs.
Hillary Clinton got a decidedly mixed reception today when she appeared before a liberal gathering and discussed her position on Iraq.

Late last week, there were reports that Grupo Televisa might form its own broadcasting network in the United States if it failed to win the auction for Univision Communications. If true, the reports could be seen as a big negative for Univision, which counts on Televisa for a large chunk of its programming, including its popular Spanish-language soap operas known as telenovelas.
Who were the big winners in the Iran-Mexico match? Perhaps Germany.
George Vecsey and Roger Cohen assess the surprises and disappointments of the tournament so far. Plus, they pick the team they can't wait to  see in action again.
Why do the Brazilians get the soccer world in such a tizzy?
The Times's George Vecsey is disappointed in the performance of the Americans who play for European club teams.
The Spitzer camp is engaging.

The list of very, very lucky executives -- those whose stock-option grants came at just the right moment to maximize profits -- keeps getting longer. No one is sure how the scandal over options backdating will end, but Tuesday brought two suggestions of what the collateral damage might be.
Remember the idea that the real estate market is not a bubble, but a balloon? Check out this billboard that has appeared around California, where home sales are not soaring. -- DAMON DARLIN
The answer to that question is never easy, but one answer might be found on this mortgage broker's solicitation that Southern California Real Estate Bubble Blog found on Craigslist. I copy it here.

The NYSE Group's regulation subsidiary said on Tuesday it had fined three banks a total of $1.35 million for proxy vote violations, such as submitting more votes than they were entitled to in various proxy matters.

You know those rah-rah, taxpayer-funded TV ads that George Pataki loves to narrate? If Eliot Spitzer wins in November, he won't be doing them. Then again, his spokesman did once say that Eliot's "not a parade kind of guy."

Just a few weeks ago, buyout firms were stampeding toward the public markets. Now it seems they are running in the opposite direction. Several reports suggest that choppy markets and a poor showing from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts' recent offering are causing private equity firms to rethink plans to sell stock to the public.

A fiscal quarter may consist of three entire months, but as Goldman Sachs reported its latest quarterly earnings on Tuesday, Wall Street analysts seemed to obsess about the last two weeks in May. That is when the world's equity markets began their recent tumble, leaving some to wonder if the boom times for the financial services industry were in danger of ending.
President Bush made an unexpected appearance in Baghdad to talk with Iraq's Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. (June 13, 2006)

June 11: It's a clear, sunny Sunday afternoon. Mexico City is full of tricolor emblems - green, white, and red like the flag - and the sound of horns and all kinds of noisemakers delivering a triple blast: ME-XI-CO. The ceremonial sites of Mexican history (the Angel of Independence in the middle of Paseo de la Reforma; the central square called the Zócalo, which is still the heart of the country just as it was in pre-Hispanic times) are full of euphoric people celebrating the Mexican selection's 3-1 victory against Iran. It's an innocent celebration that unites Mexicans regardless of their differences.
The meltdown that led to a loss in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals was uncharacteristic, but not unprecedented for the Dallas Mavericks
Bank of America said Tuesday it had hired Lewis Warren Jr. from its rival, Citigroup, as deputy head of global investment banking.

While the Anthony Pellicano investigation has turned up alleged sex, lies and audiotape involving some of Hollywood's biggest movers, the four-year eavesdropping saga hasn't really fallen within DealBook's purview. Until now.

A claims management provider, Sedgwick CMS Holdings, said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy the Security Capital Corporation, a provider of workplace health and safety services, for about $191.5 million.
That's the title of Bill Weld's speech at Pete's in Brooklyn tonight, his first public remarks since dropping out of the race for governor.
Live play-by-play here.
At the New York Buddhist Church, the Rev. T. Kenjitsu Nakagaki has been leading meditation classes and incorporating the practice into his Sunday services for years.

A new investigative Web site, Sharesleuth.com, is getting all its financing from Mark Cuban, the technology entrepreneur, independent media mogul and owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball franchise, according to PaidContent.org.

Barclays Capital, the investment banking arm of Barclays Group, said Monday it is considering making a bid with a buyout firm, Permira, for a British housebuilder, McCarthy & Stone. A takeover would be the biggest ever in Britain's 19 billion pound ($35 billion) homebuilding industry, Bloomberg News reported.

The private equity powerhouse Carlyle Group announced Tuesday that it would buy a party supply company, the Oriental Trading Company from a fellow buyout shop, Brentwood Associates. According to an earlier report in The Wall Street Journal, the deal is valued at about $1 billion, including $300 million to $400 million in equity.

Here's where high commodity prices go from hazy economic concept to hard reality: Thanks in part to rising prices for aluminum, the biggest ladder company in the United States has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

I'm a huge raving iMovie nut. In fact, I consider it one of the best features of the Macintosh. You plug in your camcorder, dump in the footage, and use this super-easy, super-powerful program to edit it, add music and credits, apply special effects, fix up old and faded footage, and finally burn the whole thing to DVD (or export it, or e-mail it, or send it to your iPod, or play it back out to tape). I use iMovie every week for my Times videos.

After yesterday's debacle against the Czech Republic, how should the United States restructure its system of government to promote a winning World Cup team? New Republic editor Franklin Foer, the nation's premier soccer pointyhead, asks the pertinent question: "If we were to take up arms for this reason, what kind of government would we want to install?"
I’m a huge raving iMovie nut, but a recent video project took me to the program's limits.
How many candidates for President can a single state have?

The investment bank Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that profit in its second quarter surged to $2.31 billion, or $4.78 a share, more than double the $865 million, or $1.71 a share, it reported a year earlier. Setting aside special items, Goldman said it earned $4.97 a share in the period, which ended May 26, topping the average estimate among analysts.
