A firm conclusion with a surprise twist works enough to make Kari Floren's comedy considerably more credible than it initially appears.
Sloppy can be good. Or sloppy can be bad. Example: "Elvis and Juliet," a clodhopper of a comedy.
This is a play of real ideas, posing questions about moral relativism, the limits of vigilance and human decency.
The Hain Celestial Group said on Tuesday it had acquired the Linda McCartney brand frozen meat-free food business from the H.J. Heinz Company, expanding its line of natural and organic products.

Affiliated Computer Services, a student loan processor that earlier this year held unsuccessful buyout talks with private equity firms, said Monday it had authorized up to $1 billion for a share repurchase program. The plan represents about 18 percent of the company's total outstanding shares.
A federal judge in Massachusetts has rejected a request for an injunction preventing Google from distributing its popular 3D Earth-mapping and visualization program.

Monster Worldwide, parent of the job search site Monster.com, was subpoenaed yesterday by the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York over the timing of stock option grants to executives.
Lawyers for a recently convicted former executive for Enron's Internet division want a new trial after jurors complained other panel members pressured them into voting guilty.
Coller Capital's 4th Global Private Equity Barometer reports that investor bullishness on private equity is unchanged despite blockbuster fundraising in 2005.

NM Rothschild has teamed up with Merchant Equity Partners, the private equity firm set up by a former Deutsche Bank managing director, Henry Jackson, to bid for the struggling retail arm of MFI Furniture, The Times of London reported.

Marsh Supermarkets, which agreed to be acquired by an affiliate of Sun Capital Partners, said on Monday it opposed a richer takeover offer from a group led by Cardinal Paragon because of uncertainty surrounding the bid.

A start-up dubbed Baynote is set to begin operating on Tuesday with on-demand software so Web site publishers can make it easier for visitors to find what they are looking for. Baynote, which received $4.6 million in venture capital funding last year, offers software that monitors the behavior of visitors to Web sites.
The buyout firm Blackstone Group raised $5.25 billion to acquire hotels, offices and shops, more than doubling the size of its previous real estate investment fund.

Adept Technology agreed Monday to sell $10 million worth of its common stock to Crosslink Capital. Livermore-based Adept will sell the shares at $13.6752 each. The deal represents about 11 percent of the company's outstanding shares before the financing.

Palamida said that it had secured a second round of $8 million in funding from the venture arm of the Japanese conglomerate Mitsui. The company and its rival Black Duck Software have developed software that automatically scans code to reduce intellectual property risks from third-party software, notably open-source products.
Amy Harmon of The New York Times answered readers' questions.
NanoNexus, a maker of advanced contractor and interconnect test products for electronic manufacturers, said Monday it had secured $32 million in an oversubscribed preferred first-series financing.

TetraLogic Pharmaceuticals, a Malvern, Penn. biotechnology company developing drugs to restore the body's natural ability to kill cancer cells, said Monday it had raised $36 million from private-equity investors in Philadelphia and as far away as San Francisco.

Gmarket looks set to become only the second Korean company after Lotte Shopping to sell shares to international investors through an initial public offering this year. It is expected to ignore the sharp decline in global equity markets over the past month and kick off a formal road show later this week.

The security- and storage-software maker Symantec said on Monday it would offer $2 billion in convertible senior notes and use proceeds to buy back about $1.5 billion worth of its own stock. Symantec's plans elicited upbeat comment on Wall Street and sent its stock higher. Shares gained 23 cents, or 1.5 percent, to close at $15.63.

The buzz surrounding ethanol producers is growing as the first of three companies gets set to go public, but analysts say retail investors should beware of the risks associated with getting in on the ethanol game.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a Wachovia Securities broker with insider trading relating to Blue Rhino's 2004 merger with Ferrellgas Partners.
A Philadelphia conglomerate Day & Zimmermann said on Monday that it had acquired Atlantic Services, a Virginia power-plant-maintenance firm, in an effort to broaden its reach further south.

Lockheed Martin reached a definitive agreement to acquire ISX of Camarillo, Calif. Terms were not disclosed, but Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., said ISX makes military decision systems and other information technology solutions for government customers.
Displaced New Orleans residents return to this seafood joint in far eastern New Orleans for a taste of their old lives. Susan Saulny reports. (Producer: Brent McDonald)
A Connecticut company established to acquire technology businesses has agreed to buy Aviel Systems and create a new company based in Northern Virginia.
Nasdaq Stock Market said on Monday it had agreed to buy PrimeZone Media Network, a privately held publisher of corporate press releases, for an undisclosed price.
A Brazilian judge approved an offer by a Varig employee group to buy the debt-ridden carrier, which was once Latin America's largest airline.

Shares of BriteSmile soared as much as 53 percent Monday after it rejected an unsolicited bid from privately-held Futuredontics, offering $4 a share in cash and stock for all outstanding stock of BriteSmile, a California-based teeth-whitening technology company.
Alcan's chief executive, Richard Evans, downplayed speculation on Monday that the company, the world's second-largest aluminum producer, is a takeover target.
The Times's George Vecsey is disappointed in the performance of the Americans who play for European club teams.

The dogfight for BAA has been the best takeover battle yet of the current M&A boom, writes John Waples in The Times of London. It had it all - big numbers (BAA went for north of 10 billion pounds, or $18.4 billion), big politics (the prickly question of handing over Britain's biggest airports to foreign owners), big personalities (wily Spanish entrepreneur Rafael Del Pino versus City grandee Marcus Agius) and big drama.
Credit Agricole, which said last month it was mulling a bid for Britain's Alliance and Leicester, has made a 3.1 billion euro ($3.9 billion) offer to take over Emporiki, the Greek lender.

The New York Post speculated that a dramatic fall in New York Stock Exchange shares over the past two weeks may undermine its plans to merge with Euronext, a deal that has been hammered by a host of politicians across the Atlantic.
Mirant withdrew its proposal to acquire its rival, NRG Energy, on Monday. But apparently that was not enough for one disgruntled hedge fund.

Tenaris, the world's biggest supplier of seamless steel pipes for the petroleum industry, agreed to buy Maverick Tube for $3.19 billion, including debt, to expand its oil and natural gas well business in North America.

The lobbying for control of the European steelmaker Arcelor accelerated on Tuesday as Mittal Steel said it expects core earnings to rise by more than $4 billion in the next three years and revealed a business plan previously seen only by Arcelor management.

It's really not over until it's over. That old adage seems especially true in the case of the bidding war for Schering. In April, the Berlin contraceptives maker agreed to a 16.4 billion euro ($20.7 billion) takeover offer from Bayer, but 11th-hour rearguard action from the German chemicals group Merck, who lost out to Bayer, threatens to derail the deal.
As even the most casual follower of world football knows, there is nothing more nerve-wracking than watching your team sit back and protect a 1-0 lead for long stretches of time in big games.
A federal judge has awarded the book publishing and movie rights to some of John Steinbeck's major works to his son Thomas and granddaughter Blake Smyle.
Monday's slide in United States' stock markets was blamed on many factors -- inflation, energy prices, geopolitics -- but why not chalk it up to Americans' sad showing in the World Cup?
Jeffrey Rosen answered readers' questions about his article on affirmative action.
Kaka delighted the Brazilian fans who have sambaed their way to Germany, scoring in the 44th minute, and the defending champions won a record eighth straight World Cup game.

The U.S. national team didn't look too animated on Monday, but that doesn't mean there's no room for animation in soccer. In fact, these animated re-enactments of goals from the current tournament, appearing on the Czech site aktualny.cz, are fun to look at. There's one goal from every game, including, from Monday, Tim Cahill's 89th-minute screamer off the left post that beat Japan for Australia, Tomas Rosicky's breakaway tally that made it 3-0 for the Czechs over the Americans and Andrea Pirlo's seeing-eye drive through a maze of players that put Italy 1-0 up against Ghana. Czech it out.

Good news for the Czech Republic: it looks as if Jan Koller's hamstring injury is not nearly as serious as it first seemed. According to this article on the Czech-Moravian Football Federation site, the MRI showed that the big guy has suffered only a muscle pull. "On Saturday against Ghana," the article says, "the Czech cannoneer clearly will not play, but otherwise his injury isn't so bad as was intially feared."

Do Americans know soccer? An edifying study in this issue is under way at AOL, of all places. The Web giant put up a poll on its U.S. site Monday after the Americans' cataclysmic loss to the Czech Republic. The question: "Who deserves the most blame for the U.S.'s opening loss?" The choices given: Bruce Arena, DaMarcus Beasley, Landon Donovan, Eddie Lewis, Oguchi Onyewu, Eddie Pope and "other."
An advocacy group sued KFC today to get it to stop using a key ingredient of its fried chicken.
he condition of quarterback Ben Roethlisberger of the Steelers, injured in a motorcycle accident Monday while not wearing a helmet, was upgraded today from serious to fair condition.

In the aftermath of being decimated by the Dallas Mavericks in the first two games of the N.B.A. finals, a huge question hangs in the humid air: Will the real Shaquille O'Neal show up tonight in Miami?
Leaders of one of the oldest and most established Buddhist movements in the country are trying to incorporate meditation into their services to serve new audiences.
A statement announced that a man named Abu Hamza al-Muhajir would replace Abu Musab al-Zarqawi as the head of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

Providing hints that a reduction in coastal sea ice may make life difficult for polar bears, government biologists from Canada and the United States say they observed three instances of cannibalism among polar bears in a three-month stretch in 2004 along Alaskan and Yukon coasts. In the journal Polar Biology, the researchers said that no previous examples had been observed in the region in at least 24 years. Computer simulations project that the Arctic Ocean could become largely free of sea ice later in the century in summers if global warming intensifies.
A hurricane warning was issued on Monday and evacuations were ordered for parts of the Florida Gulf Coast.

In the latest crackdown on corruption in Suffolk County, a judge on Monday sentenced the former chief building inspector of Brookhaven to prison for two and a half years to seven and a half years and ordered him to forfeit $150,000 for improperly enriching himself, mostly through his government position.
The beleaguered Jason Grimsley, who will probably never pitch in the majors again, was nonetheless suspended for violating Major League Baseball's Joint Drug Prevention and Treatment Program.

Some of Brooklyn's most prominent black officials said yesterday that they wanted to enlist party leaders at the national level to prevent a white politician from winning a Congressional seat long held by black politicians.
Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks lower, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit.
RENO, Nev., June 12 — A family court judge standing at a third floor window of his downtown court building here was shot in the chest shortly before noon on Monday.
Mr. Hundley was first a leader in the Eisenhower and Kennedy administrations' fight against organized crime and then a sought-after defense lawyer for powerful people.
With the city's force recovering from Hurricane Katrina, memories of its incompetent, brutal past have returned.
The breakfast hour at Winged Foot Golf Club passed without the presence of Tiger Woods, who extended his nine-week break from the PGA Tour by one morning.
The Mirant Corporation, a power generator, withdrew its bid under pressure from Mirant shareholders, who said they could make more money if Mirant sold itself instead.

Joan Baron was certain that her husband, a surgeon who suffered a debilitating stroke in February 2004, never ordered a telephone-directory advertisement from Verizon. When she received a bill for such a service, she disputed it.
The investigation of Anthony Pellicano, a Hollywood private eye, has turned up only a single recording in which people were wiretapped, prosecutors said.
In the preliminary report, issued by the F.B.I., the biggest increases in murder came in medium-size cities and in the Midwest.

The sister of a slain New York City graduate student, Imette St. Guillen, traveled to the Capitol yesterday to press for two laws aimed at increasing security at taverns. Assemblyman Felix W. Ortiz, a Brooklyn Democrat, is sponsoring

Some of New Jersey's state-financed preschools have failed to conduct required background checks on teachers and other employees, according to a published report. The Record of Bergen County found that the required checks, intended to prevent criminals and child abusers from working with children, are frequently incomplete or nonexistent. In 2005, proof that every required check had been completed was missing at 24 out of the 31 school districts in which the state is required to provide free preschool, the newspaper reported.

The former leader of a Long Island Boy Scout troop was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison for sexually abusing two 13-year-old Scouts, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The former scoutmaster, Ronald E. Occhipinti, 46, of Bayside, pleaded guilty in May to abuse charges and was sentenced in State Supreme Court by Acting Justice Pauline A. Mullings. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Occhipinti, the leader of Troop 183 in Great Neck, abused the boys at his home and at a church in Little Neck where the troop held its weekly meetings.

A serial sex offender who raped the actress Kelly McGillis in 1982 was convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court of raping and robbing two other women in their Manhattan home in 1996. The defendant, Leroy Johnson, 39, faces up to 25 years in prison on each of the two rape counts when he is sentenced this month. After his conviction, Mr. Johnson issued a statement through his lawyer denying guilt, and placing blame on news coverage of his past victimization of Ms. McGillis. Ms. McGillis has discussed the attack publicly but has never identified her attacker. In the Manhattan case, Mr. Johnson was convicted of raping the two women at knifepoint in their Greenwich Village apartment.

Democratic lawmakers are considering a proposal to decrease the sales tax but expand it to services not currently taxed, like those offered by lawyers and accountants. Senator Wayne Bryant, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, estimated that an expanded tax could generate about $2 billion in revenues. Gov. Jon S. Corzine has proposed increasing the sales tax from 6 percent to 7 percent to raise $1.1 billion. Yesterday, a spokesman for the governor declined to say if he would support the expansion plan. Associations representing lawyers and accountants criticized the plan. Ralph Thomas, executive director of the New Jersey Society of Certified Public Accountants, said a sales tax on accountants would send people elsewhere to seek accounting services.

A Copiague man was arrested on Sunday night after he and another man raced their cars along the Sunrise Highway, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The man, Darryl Cruz, was charged with reckless driving and engaging in a speed contest, the police said. About 10:15 p.m. an officer spotted a black Toyota and a gray Honda weaving through traffic at over 100 miles per hour, the police said. The officer stopped the Toyota and arrested Mr. Cruz.

A 19-year-old man was fatally stabbed near the Journal Square PATH station on Sunday night by a man he knew and had argued with, the authorities said yesterday. Investigators say that just after 8 p.m., Manuel Reyes, 20, stabbed Nicholas M. Perhacs once in the chest, then fled. Mr. Perhacs was taken to Jersey City Medical Center, where he died, said Edward J. De Fazio, the Hudson County prosecutor. Mr. Reyes had not been caught by last evening.

An ancient offering vessel expected to sell for as much as $30,000 at auction this week has been withdrawn from the sale over concerns about its removal from Egypt, the Christie's auction house said yesterday. Christie's said it had contacted federal authorities and was trying to help return the vessel as quickly as possible. The alabaster vessel is in two halves and is carved in the shape of a bird. Experts say it is more than 4,000 years old.

Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for attorney general, was endorsed yesterday by Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, which represents 60,000 doormen, janitors, security guards and other building service workers in the city. The endorsement, the largest so far for Mr. Green, offered him bragging rights in a campaign that has been dominated by Andrew M. Cuomo, who won the State Democratic Party's backing last month. Mr. Green said the union could be helpful in gathering petition signatures for a spot on the primary ballot.

Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to raise $500,000 this evening at a Midtown reception for his political action committee, Solutions America, his advisers say. Mr. Giuliani, who is considering a presidential run in 2008, has not held a fund-raiser for his committee since January 2005, preferring instead to headline events for Republican candidates. A senior adviser to Mr. Giuliani, Anthony V. Carbonetti, said the gathering of donors on Mr. Giuliani's behalf was not a sign that he was any closer to a decision on a White House run. There will be Republican star power on hand: Ken Mehlman, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, is to pay tribute to Mr. Giuliani. The political action committee had $224,000 in its coffers in late April. Mr. Carbonetti said the new money would be used to support House and Senate candidates, and could not be used to advance Mr. Giuliani's campaign.
Basra is being pulled apart by Shiite  parties that want to control Iraq's south and its biggest prize, oil.
Tim Cahill scored the country's first World Cup goal in the 84th minute, then goals came in a flurry as the Aussies rallied for a victory over Japan.
A daily dose of Cialis, the No. 2 impotence drug, would be aimed at allowing more spontaneity in the user's sex life.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an appraisal of the automobile industry by Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, referred incorrectly in some copies to his comments on the economic state of the industry. It was workers' health care benefits that he said had become
As expected, the chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency faulted Iran for failing to provide information crucial to understanding its nuclear program.
A lawyer for the government asked a judge to dismiss an A.C.L.U. challenge to a domestic eavesdropping program, under the state secrets privilege.
Italy distanced itself from a corruption scandal back home with a 2-0 victory over Ghana in Hanover, Germany.
Defense lawyers say their clients have been beaten by guards, threatened by other inmates and held in isolation.
A migration of young adults from upstate New York is turning many communities grayer.
Derek Jeter got his 2,000th hit last month, and when Bernie Williams plays his next game, he will have 2,000 career appearances.
The Central Intelligence Agency has refused to confirm or deny the existence of documents authorizing it to detain and interrogate terrorism suspects overseas.

The Bloomberg administration wanted to spend $111 million in the coming year to install a sprawling security camera system in the Wall Street area. To be modeled on London's so-called Ring of Steel, the plan involved placing video cameras at half of the 535 intersections south of Canal Street and installing surveillance equipment capable of zeroing in on details as small as a license plate.
The huge trade gains could create new pressures on Beijing to allow its currency to appreciate against other world currencies.
With Cory Booker's resounding victory in the mayoral election last month, voters in Newark signaled a demand for fresh leadership after five terms of Mayor Sharpe James.
A large number of sport utility vehicles and pickups have been redesigned to reduce the threat they pose in collisions with smaller cars.
The handiwork of a small office in the U.S. Army has had an outsized influence on the public face of the military and government.

After reports that a two-month run of explosions at ground zero would begin yesterday to clear bedrock for the Freedom Tower's foundation, some downtown workers expected they might feel the ground shake. But by day's end, many said they had hardly noticed.
FIFA's media representative would not make a deal with the Defense Department's American Forces Network, so AFN will not carry any World Cup matches.
Security personnel of the Fatah faction went on a rampage after Hamas gunmen attacked the headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces.
Security Council members told the country's political leaders to tone down their election rhetoric and avoid inflaming ethnic tensions.

Relatives of a taxicab driver whose vehicle smashed into a concrete median in Greenwich Village early Sunday morning, leading to the death of one passenger and injuring three others, said he had suffered a seizure in the past. They suggested that he might have had another seizure Sunday at the wheel.
A five-day general strike turned violent and soldiers opened fire on protests by high school students over the suspension of year-end exams because teachers had joined the strike.
Tajikistan complained that landmines planted along its border by Uzbekistan have killed 68 people since 1999, reopening a point of contention between the countries.
Two brothers decided to pay their grandfather a surprise visit and drove 60 miles along a busy highway before they were pulled over, the police said.
The government cut electricity to the American diplomatic mission in Havana a week ago, and requests for power to be restored have gone unanswered, officials said.
The legislature agreed to hold a special session to debate a possible referendum to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
Nigeria agreed to withdraw its troops from Bakassi, a potentially oil-rich, 400-square-mile peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea it has long claimed, within 60 days.
The Emirates has sent 1,075 boys smuggled in from Bangladesh, Pakistan, Eritrea, Mauritania and Sudan to race camels home to their countries, government officials said.
A new technology applies the brakes to individual wheels or cuts back the engine power when sensors detect the vehicle is beginning to spin or skid.
On Monday, Senate colleagues of Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia honored the Democrat as the longest serving senator.
The European Union pushed forward with enlargement plans, conducting a first round of membership negotiations.

General Mills will let its two principal agencies, Campbell Mithun and Saatchi & Saatchi, determine the media in which ads run and which agencies will create them.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 12 — With his rivals in the campaign for governor trying to paint him as a tax-and-spend Democrat, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer unveiled a plan on Monday to cut property taxes by $6 billion over three years, aimed at the middle class and the elderly.
As he prepares to play in the United States Open, his first tournament since the death of his father last month, Tiger Woods is paying tribute to him in a new Nike commercial.

WASHINGTON, June 12 — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that new evidence about a long-ago murder in rural Tennessee, including DNA evidence, raised sufficient doubt about who committed the crime to merit a new hearing in federal court for a man who has spent 20 years on the state's death row.

In a temporary truce until June 30, flight attendants agreed not to strike and the airline agreed not to set aside their contract.
The European steel giant formally rejected a 25.8 billion euro hostile takeover bid by Mittal Steel. But for the first time, Arcelor said it might be willing to negotiate.

Dirk Kempthorne's chief task as the new secretary of the interior is to resurrect his department's long tradition of responsible stewardship of the public lands.

A measure that would have restricted illegal immigrants' access to nonemergency services was denied a chance to be on the November ballot when the State Supreme Court ruled that it dealt with more than one subject, which is not allowed by the State Constitution. The initiative would have allowed illegal immigrants to receive only federally mandated services like emergency medical care while denying most other services including welfare. Because the deadline for November has passed, the measure is not likely to be reintroduced until 2008.

The special prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak investigation said he did not expect the White House to try to block Vice President Dick Cheney's former top aide from using classified intelligence material to defend himself against perjury charges. Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the special counsel, said in Federal District Court that the White House had designated certain documents that it was concerned about being made public. If the aide, I. Lewis Libby Jr., wants those documents to prepare his defense, Mr. Fitzgerald said, he and Mr. Libby's lawyers will work out solutions with the judge in secret under a law intended to deal with defendants' access to classified information. Mr. Libby was charged in October with lying to the F.B.I. and a federal grand jury about how he learned about Valerie Wilson, a Central Intelligence Agency officer, and when he told three reporters about her.

A judge struck down a voter-approved proposition that would have limited handgun possession within the San Francisco city limits to the police and other security personnel. The ruling, by Judge James Warren of San Francisco Superior Court, found that the handgun law was in violation of state laws. The proposition also banned the manufacture, sale or distribution of firearms and ammunition.
Pak Darto, a mystic in an Indonesian village, is entrusted to sound the alarm in the event of danger from Mount Merapi.

A publisher who disappeared on Saturday while sailing the Chesapeake Bay was presumed dead after a search of 100 square miles of water over two days turned up nothing. Search crews continued to look for the man, Philip Merrill, 72, but rescuers said it was unlikely he was still alive. His sailboat was found on Saturday more than a dozen miles south of his planned sailing route. Mr. Merrill, the publisher of Washingtonian magazine and six Maryland newspapers, was sailing alone.
To understand the history of life we have to understand the relation between evolution and the events that have altered its direction.
Education Secretary Margaret Spellings announced that $24 million in federal aid had been awarded to Louisiana for the development of charter schools.

The welcome recent announcement that the U.S. is willing to join face-to-face talks with Iran rekindled memories of my own experiences as chief negotiator in the Iranian hostage crisis.

To learn from what happened in Haditha, Iraq, is to learn to notice not just the alleged massacres but the civilian deaths that for too much of this war have remained invisible.

Ms. Feldshuh places her own stamp on one of the musical theater's most celebrated female roles. As they say in old Eire, you go, girl!

Americans swept the top three places in the Mixed Pairs Championship yesterday at the World Bridge Championships in Verona, Italy, with the title going to Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H., and Matt Granovetter of Cincinnati.
In a mere six months of operation, TMZ.com has ridden a wave of enthusiasm for online video, attracting links from other gossip sites with its run-and-gun sequences of stars acting stupid.
For innovation in commemorating this year's Mozart anniversary, Leon Botstein's program with the American Symphony Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall is going to be hard to top.

NEW JETBLUE SHUTTLE JetBlue Airways is starting a shuttle service, with six daily nonstops between Kennedy International Airport and Washington Dulles International Airport. Introductory one-way fares, available through June 30, are $39, with a 14-day advance purchase requirement, for flights between Aug. 17 and Sept. 30. Regular one-way fares will range from $50 to $145. JetBlue described the introductory fare as 40 percent lower than any in the New York area. But the main shuttle carriers, Delta and US Airways, fly between La Guardia and Reagan National Airport, which many business travelers consider a far more convenient route than Kennedy-Dulles.
On Sunday afternoon Yuri Temirkanov concluded his tenure as music director at the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra with a stirring performance of the "Resurrection" Symphony.
New novels by Andrew Trees and Eliot Schrefer are about private schools and the moneyed teenagers who attend them.

"Cemetery Man," a ceaselessly surprising zombie comedy-thriller-romantic fantasy, has finally surfaced on DVD. Also, "Valley of the Dolls" and Father's Day specials.

McGRAW--Donald C., Jr, 81. Of Gulf Stream, Florida, passed away on June 11, 2006 after a long illness with heart disease and complications due to a stroke. He was married to Dorothea McGraw and is survived by three sons, Donald III ''Josh'', of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., Robert L.W., of Sheffield, MA, David W. of Osterville, MA., and thirteen grandchildren. Don was predeceased by a son, Peter S., of San Rafael, CA., and a wife of fifty years, Anne Williams McGraw of Osterville, MA. He was a WW II Navy veteran and was with McGraw-Hill Inc. for many years. Mr. McGraw started Nautical Quarterly and owned Soundings Publications. Funeral services are private and in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mystic Seaport, The Museum of America and the Sea, 75 Greenmanville. Avenue, Mystic, CT. 06355

RAYSMAN--Victor. Born in Lodz, Poland, September 15, 1914, died in Valley Stream, New York June 11, 2006. As a young engineering graduate, Victor fled Poland to escape Nazi persecution via Lithuania, Russia, Japan and Canada, arriving in New York City in 1944, where he married and established a jewelry business that continued for many years. He is survived by his wife of sixty years, Irene Davies Raysman, his son Richard and wife Georgia, his daughter Dorothy and husband Robert Dorman, his grandchildren Joshua Raysman and wife Jennifer, Sarah Raysman Fahy and husband John, Julia Natalie Raysman and Peter Urbano Raysman, and his great-grandchildren Oscar Burr Raysman and Abigail Rose Raysman. Services Tuesday at 11am, Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 11557 (tel. 516-295-3100).

To the Editor: What is the consequence of music in the operating room for our patients? Anesthesiologists (I am one) have recently been asked to seek ways to reduce the rare occurrence of awareness under anesthesia. The most commonly reported recall that patients report is auditory.

Then he defied the Supreme Court's 2004 repudiation of his position and announced that he would insist on yet another ruling of the court before providing elementary fairness.

A report in the World Briefing column on Friday about a sign being erected to mark the Berlin bunker where Hitler committed suicide misspelled the surname of the reporter. He is Victor Homola, not Homolo. (The same error was made in a World Briefing report on April 14 about a so-called honor killing that shocked Germans.)

During the regular season ABC wins the ratings race on Sunday nights because of the interpersonal games that take place on ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Grey's Anatomy.'' But the network won this Sunday because of games of a different sort: the N.B.A. Finals. Nielsen's estimates for the live broadcast were preliminary, but its overnight ratings showed that ABC was ahead among total viewers and adults 18 to 49, and that this year's game No. 2 delivered a larger audience than last year's. CBS and its Tony Awards placed second among viewers, but fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox, in turn, was No. 2 among 18-to-49 year-olds, and fourth among viewers. Its most-watched show of the night was a rerun of ''Family Guy'' at 9 p.m., with 5.93 million viewers. It led into the comedy ''It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia'' by FX, Fox's cable sibling; it drew a series-high 3.75 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

SLANETZ--Charles A. Jr. MD. Of Locust Valley, NY, June 12, 2006. Age 73. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and physician. Visitation at Dodge - Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, L.I. Service Christ Church, Oyster Bay, Thursday, 10:30 A.M.

MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL-Suspended Arizona RHP Jason Grimsley 50 games for violating the joint drug prevention and treatment program, to begin upon his placement on a 40-man major league roster. American League BOSTON RED SOX-Optioned RHP David Pauley to Pawtucket of the IL. LOS ANGELES ANGELS-Activated OF Darin Erstad from the 15-day DL. Optioned OF Tommy Murphy to Salt Lake of the PCL. TORONTO BLUE JAYS-Activated INF John McDonald from the 15-day DL. Recalled INF Russ Adams from Syracuse of the IL. Gave INF Edgardo Alfonzo his unconditional release. Assigned 2B Luis Figueroa outright to Syracuse. National League METS-Activated RHP John Maine from the 15-day DL and optioned him to Norfolk of the IL. Agreed to terms with RHP John Holdzkom, RHP Stephen Holmes, OF Daniel Stegall, RHP Nathan Hedrick, INF Daniel Murphy, LHP Duane Privett, RHP Tobi Stoner, C Stephen Puhl, RHP Nicholas Waechter, INF Valentin Ramos, RHP Steven Cheney, OF Will Bashelor, INF Jacob Eigsti, OF Jeremy Hambrice, INF Jeffery Voyles, OF Donald Green and RHP Kyle Johnson. Assigned Privett, Cheney and Hambrice to Kingsport of the Appalachian League; Holmes, Murphy, Stoner, Puhl, Waechter, Bashelor and Eigsti to Brooklyn of the New York-Penn League; and Holdzkom, Stegall, Hedrick, Ramos, Voyles, Green and Johnson to the Gulf Coast Mets. To the Editor: You report that Dr. Norman E. Shumway, a heart-transplant pioneer, who died in February, ''had often played Édith Piaf during surgery.''

An article by Bloomberg News on June 1 about regulatory approval for a growth hormone, Omnitrope, from Novartis, included an erroneous reference to another drug, Nutropin, by Genentech. In the approval process with the Food and Drug Administration, Omnitrope was compared analytically with Genotropin by Pfizer; it is not also based on a version of Nutropin. The headline also referred incorrectly to Omnitrope. It is a name-brand prescription drug, not a generic drug.

To the Editor: Re ''Hamas Declares It Will Resume Attacking Israel'' (front page, June 10): It is genuinely unfortunate that eight Palestinians at a beach picnic in Gaza were killed, apparently by an errant Israeli shell targeted at a launching site for rockets fired by Palestinians into Israeli towns, an error for which Israeli military officials expressed regret.

In the Senate, Robert C. Byrd is famous for reciting poetry, reading from an encyclopedia and lecturing on the lessons of history. On Monday, as his colleagues honored him as the longest serving senator, they had a chance to show off their knowledge of his history. They noted his number of days served (17,327), the number of senators he has outlasted (1,885), the percent of votes he won in his last race (78) and the number of terms he will have been elected to if he wins again this fall (9, another record).

SAFON--David. Our dear friend and wise counsel, we will miss you. Your warmth, caring, professionalism and ethics were unparalleled. The world has lost one of the truly special ones. Our deepest sympathies to Lisa, Jenny, Keith and Noah--you were the twinkle in his eye. Richard, Lila, Leslie & Adam Holland

To the Editor: Re ''Mourning in America,'' by John Tierney (column, June 10): My brother was murdered, along with almost 3,000 other innocent victims, on Sept. 11, 2001. While this does not make me or my family ''experts'' on terrorism, it does make us experts on grief.

FEEN--Rosalie D., on June 10, 2006. Cherished wife of Eugene and beloved mother of Susan and David. Grandmother of Allyson and sister of Marion. She will live with us forever. Funeral service at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 1 PM, Wednesday, June 14.

An article in The Arts on June 3 about the author who uses the pseudonym Andrew Holleran and his new novel, ''Grief,'' in which the narrator discovers letters and journals by Mary Todd Lincoln, included a quotation that referred incorrectly to her as the subject of an opera. Although Mr. Holleran said he did not know why no one had written an opera about her, one has in fact been written, ''The Trial of Mary Lincoln,'' by Thomas Pasatieri, with a libretto by A. H. Bailey, which had its premiere in 1972.

To the Editor: Re ''Do Your Skin a Favor: Protect It in Summer'' (Personal Health, June 6): Skin cancer, like many other illnesses, is a class-sensitive disease. The wealthy -- those who golf and play tennis, those who can afford to lie on the beach -- buy and use sunscreen. Bravo. But then there are those of us who work outdoors.

The meeting came as Republicans began an effort to turn recent events in Iraq to their political advantage. To the Editor: The essay ''Well-Intentioned Food Police May Create Havoc With Children's Diets'' (May 30) patronizingly dismisses legislation meant to improve the nutritional quality of foods available during the school day. But haven't things gotten a tad out of hand when children are taught good nutrition in the classroom, but then presented with banks of candy, soda and snack machines in hallways and more junk foods in cafeterias?

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Palestinian Factions Clash In an Eruption of Violence Hundreds of security personnel loyal to the Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas and his Fatah organization went on a rampage in Ramallah, firing bullets at the buildings of the Hamas-dominated Parliament and cabinet and setting them on fire. The attacks came after Hamas gunmen attacked the Gaza headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces with rockets and grenades. The statement announced that a man named Abu Hamza al-Muhajir would replace Mr. Zarqawi. A14 President Bush gathered top aides at Camp David to determine the best way forward in Iraq during what the administration described as a critical juncture, following the death of Mr. Zarqawi and the final formation of a unity government. A10 Terror Suspects Charge Abuse Defense lawyers representing several of the men held on terrorism charges in an Ontario maximum security jail claim their clients have been beaten by guards, threatened by other inmates and held in isolation. The lawyers made the accusations as preliminary bail hearings were about to get under way for the 17 suspects arrested on June 3. A6 Round 1 of Turkey Negotiation The European Union pushed forward with enlargement plans, conducting a first round of membership negotiations with Turkey and Croatia and signing a pre-membership agreement with Albania. A5 Kosovo Independence Closer Members of the United Nations Security Council appear to be leaning toward permitting Kosovo to go its own way. C13 NATIONAL A16-21 Lethal Injection Challenges Allowed by Justices The Supreme Court opened the door for death-row inmates to challenge the way most states carry out executions by lethal injection. In its unanimous opinion, the court expressed no view on the constitutionality of lethal injection in general. The migration is turning many communities grayer, threatening the long-term viability of already ailing cities and raising concerns about the state's future tax base. An international group of scientists is building a new kind of telescope at the bottom of the Mediterranean Sea, near the coast of France. To be completed in 2007, it will detect light generated by neutrinos, the high-energy cosmic particles that pass directly through the Earth. Because neutrinos pass through most matter (including the seafloor), scientists can use them to peer into active galactic nuclei. Why underwater? To help shield the telescope from cosmic radiation coming from above. FRANK O'CONNELL AN UNDERWATER ARRAY Twelve vertical lines, each made up of 75 optical modules. Diagram (schematic, not to scale) highlights the following: 3 OPTICAL MODULES SEA FLOOR ANCHOR BUOY LIGHT FROM SOURCE TO DETECTION 1. Some neutrinos are thought to be created and ejected into space from black holes. 2. Neutrinos encountering the Earth pass right through, emerging on the other side. 3. Interacting with the Earth's crust or the water of the ocean, the neutrinos produce muons. 4. As they rise up from the ocean floor, the muons emit a faint bluish light, called Cherenkov light. 5. Photo detectors sense this light and relay the data to shore. PARTICLE TRAJECTORY As the muons pass through the telescope, individual sensors pick up the emitted light. Tracing the path backward through the array, scientists can determine the particles' trajectory. OPTICAL MODULES Pressure-resistant glass spheres encase photo sensors. The modules are angled down 45 degrees to better detect the muons as they move upward. (Diagram) Antares observes space by looking down through the Earth rather than up through the atmosphere. CHERENKOV LIGHT Generated when charged particles travel through a medium faster than light, which slows down in water. Diagrams highlight the following: MUON ANTARES NEUTRINO PHOTOMULTIPLIER TUBE ACTIVATED SENSOR OPTICAL MODULE (Source by Antares Collaboration)

Q. When I photograph a person using a flash, I often get ''red eye,'' but when I photograph my dog, I get ''blue eye.'' What difference in their eyes accounts for this? A. The difference lies in the layers of cells at the back of the eyeball, where the flash of light strikes. When people are photographed in dim light, their pupils are wide open to let in enough light to see. As the flash hits the retina, which is richly supplied with blood vessels that are close to the surface, a red reflection may result.

NBC named a new management team for its all-news channel MSNBC yesterday, elevating one of its program hosts, Dan Abrams, to the position of general manager, and handing overall oversight of the channel to Phil Griffin, currently senior NBC News vice president with responsibility for the management of NBC's ''Today'' program. The two will succeed Rick Kaplan, who resigned last week as the network's president. Steve Capus, the president of NBC News, acknowledged that the selection of Mr. Abrams, below, who has been the host of the network's 4 p.m. show, ''The Abrams Report,'' since 2001, was unusual. Mr. Abrams had not previously been part of the management of NBC News. ''It's an unconventional move for an unconventional time,'' Mr. Capus said. ''All of the old models in the news business are being thrown out every day.'' Another unusual part of the change is that Mr. Abrams, who is a graduate of Columbia's law school, will remain the chief legal correspondent for NBC News. Mr. Griffin, who previously worked at MSNBC as vice president of prime-time programming and as the executive producer of its signature program, ''Hardball With Chris Matthews,'' will assume the title of executive in charge of MSNBC. He has the same title at ''Today.'' BILL CARTER

10 P.M. (CBS) TUESDAY NIGHT BOOK CLUB -- The ladies of Wisteria Lane have nothing on this bunch. In this new reality series, seven women (above, from left, Tina, Sara, Cris, Jamie, Lynn, Kirin and Jennifer) from Scottsdale, Ariz., dish the dirt on rearing children, running households and handling their husbands (and the occasional fling) and prove that reality can be stranger -- and more provocative -- than fiction. But how much reading are they actually getting done? 8 P.M. (NBC) FEAR FACTOR -- Apparently 15 minutes wasn't long enough. In this new ''reality stars'' episode, contestants who were barely noticed in situ -- including Tana Goertz of ''The Apprentice,'' Anthony Federov of ''American Idol'' and Mike Mizanin of ''The Real World'' -- get closer to their idea of fame as they compete in reputation-building tasks like hunting for skulls in a swamp. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING -- The comedians pull out their best shtick for a chance to compete in the finals. But with Kathy Griffin as a celebrity judge, will the contestants feel the inclination to whine? 9 P.M. (VH1) THE DRUG YEARS -- In Part 2 of this four-episode documentary special, the counter-culture's drug experimentation seeps into the established media, and the deaths of Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin (left) call attention to addiction's darker side. 10 P.M. (Biography) DEAD FAMOUS: GHOSTLY ENCOUNTERS -- Ghost hunters scour Austin, Tex., for the spirit of Janis Joplin, whose drug years (see above) got the best of her. 10 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE -- His family wants an Orthodox wedding for hundreds; hers prefers something glamorous and secular. What are Asher and Tsiliana, New Yorkers who met online and are marrying after a three-month courtship, to do? Elope to Las Vegas, what else? In this new episode, the Fab Five give them a celebration neither they nor their officiant (Carson Kressley, doing double duty) will soon forget. 10 P.M. (Oxygen) THE JANICE DICKINSON MODELING AGENCY -- Viewers are clucking that Ms. Dickinson's wannabe models aren't exactly runway material. (And to think she had the nerve to criticize Tyra Banks's babes for not having the right stuff.) But no one is surprised when the tart-tongued Ms. Dickinson clashes with her new business partner. 11:15 P.M. (Flix) IN COLD BLOOD -- (1967). Thirty-eight years before ''Capote,'' Philip Seymour Hoffman's tour de force, there was this gem of a thriller, starring Scott Wilson and the formidable Robert Blake (far left, with Mr. Wilson), about the men who brought murder to a trusting Kansas town and the people who forever after locked their doors. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an appraisal of the automobile industry by Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, referred incorrectly in some copies to his comments on the economic state of the industry. It was workers' health care benefits that he said had become ''unsustainable'' -- not that the domestic automobile industry had become economically unsustainable because of generous health care benefits. The article also referred incorrectly in some copies to the year that the union's membership peaked at 1.5 million. It was 1979, not 1970.

Illness Scraps Korn Tour The hard-rock band Korn, which recently turned itself into an investment vehicle by selling a stake in its box-office, album and other revenues, announced that it had been forced to cancel the remaining dates on its European tour because its lead singer, Jonathan Davis, right, had become ill. He was admitted to a British hospital, the announcement said, and the band's performance at the Download Festival in London on Saturday night was shortened and used guest vocalists. On the korn.com Web site, Mr. Davis said an allergic reaction to some medication had reduced his blood platelet count to a point where ''if I continued to headbang onstage, I could have had a brain hemorrhage and dropped dead on the spot.'' The band is still expected to headline an American tour to begin on July 27 in Virginia Beach, Va. Footnote Barbra Streisand's concert tour, beginning on Oct. 4 in Philadelphia, is scheduled to bring her to Madison Square Garden on Oct. 9. Among other dates are Oct. 13 in Washington, Oct. 22 in Boston, Nov. 7 in Chicago and Nov. 20 in Los Angeles.

A Los Angeles judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by a producer of the Oscar-winning film ''Crash'' against the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the Producers Guild of America. The plaintiff, Bob Yari, left, who had raised money for ''Crash'' but was denied a formal producing credit by the two organizations, and therefore an Oscar statue, sued them both, contending that he had been denied due process. The judge rejected his claim. George Hedges, a lawyer for the Producers Guild, said, ''We've always said there's simply no legal basis to bring this claim, and the court has agreed with that.'' William Immerman, a senior executive at the Yari Film Group, said he would file an amended complaint in the next few days.. SHARON WAXMAN

To the Editor: Elizabeth Bennett of the Wildlife Conservation Society (''A Global Advocate for the Meal That Cannot Speak for Itself,'' June 6) implies that animal hunting and trading in Africa and Southeast Asia differ from the more civil forms of slaughter and marketing that go on in North America. Thus she inconsistently accepts deer hunting in New Jersey, where she says the animals are overabundant, but opposes hunting in Malaysia.

To the Editor: It didn't concern me in the least whether or not my surgeons were listening to music during my aortic valve replacement procedure. My nervous energy before the operation was channeled into the creation of my own iPod playlist, ''Chamber Music: Music for Open Heart Surgery.'' The first movement was full of calm, reassuring music, as I slipped into unconsciousness.

Warning: Public health officials have determined that not breast-feeding may be hazardous to your baby's health. There is no black-box label like that affixed to cans of infant formula or tucked into the corner of magazine advertisements, at least not yet. But that is the unambiguous message of a controversial government public health campaign encouraging new mothers to breast-feed for six months to protect their babies from colds, flu, ear infections, diarrhea and even obesity. In April, the World Health Organization, setting new international bench marks for children's growth, for the first time referred to breast-feeding as the biological norm.

JONES--Dr. Robert E., 77. Died peacefully on Saturday, June 3, 2006 at the Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston. Raised in New York, he was a long-time resident of Boston's Back Bay and Professor Emeritus, Foreign Languages and Literatures at MIT. He also taught at the University of Pennsylvania and was the author of several books, including The Alienated Hero in Modern French Drama, Gerard de Nerval and Botticelli's Face. Educated at Columbia College and University, as well as the Sorbonne, he was an avid art collector and learned aficionado of all the arts, especially opera. He was a lifetime member of the St. Botolph Club in Boston. He will be deeply missed by his spouse James W. Ryan of Boston, his brother Thomas Jones of Nashville, TN, and his many loving friends. He was the devoted son of the late Robert Emmet and Lois Kathryn (UpdeGrove) Jones. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 24, 2006 at 4:00PM at the MIT Chapel on the MIT campus. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 350 S. Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA. 02130.

AUTO WORKERS CONVENTION -- The United Automobile Workers convention opened in Las Vegas with leaders and members in a familiar fighting mood, but with a new battle plan aimed at protecting what they have rather than gaining new ground. [Page C1.] S.U.V. REDESIGN -- A large number of sport utility vehicles and pickups that have been redesigned to reduce the threat they pose in collisions with smaller cars are now reaching the road. A recent study showed that the modifications sharply reduced deaths of people in cars struck by these vehicles. [C1.] ANTI-CRASH TECHNOLOGY -- As many as 10,000 fatal highway crashes could be prevented each year if all vehicles were equipped with technology that helps drivers maintain control at high speeds and on slippery roads, a new study shows. [C4.] FADING STAR -- After more than half a decade as Hollywood's savior, the DVD is looking a little tired -- and the movie studios, for once, are having trouble in coming up with a sequel. [C1.] ONCE-A-DAY CIALIS -- Icos Corporation, which with Eli Lilly markets Cialis, the No. 2 impotence drug, says it plans later this year to ask the Food and Drug Administration for approval of a once-daily version. Icos and Lilly plan to market the new version to men in their 40's and 50's who take impotence drugs frequently. [C1.] STOCKS FALL SHARPLY -- Fears about higher interest rates, rising inflation and a slowing economy sent stocks sharply and broadly lower, with emerging markets taking the biggest hit. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.3 percent, erasing all of its gains for the year so far. The Nasdaq composite index fell more than 2 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average fell almost 1 percent. [C1.] HOLLYWOOD CASE -- The federal investigation of Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private eye accused of masterminding a sprawling eavesdropping operation, has turned up only a single recording in which two people were unknowingly wiretapped, prosecutors said. Defense lawyers are questioning whether even that wiretap is really what it is said to be. [C3.] ARCELOR MIGHT BE WILLING TO TALK -- Arcelor formally rejected a 25.8 billion euro ($33 billion) hostile takeover bid by Mittal Steel, but for the first time it said it might be willing to negotiate a deal. If a deal is reached, it will leave the Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov, above, who had agreed to a separate deal with Arcelor, in the cold. [C8.] EXPANDING EUROPEAN UNION -- The European Union pushed forward with enlargement plans, conducting a first round of membership negotiations with Turkey and Croatia and signing a premembership agreement with Albania. [A5.] TRUCE AT NORTHWEST -- Northwest Airlines and its 8,700 active flight attendants agreed to a temporary truce -- meaning no strike by the flight attendants and no effort by the company to set aside their contract -- until June 30. They said negotiations would resume tomorrow. [C3.] WORKING RELATIONSHIP -- General Mills is seeking to transform the way it works with its advertising agencies. In one big change, it is adopting performance-based compensation: payments that are based on marketplace results. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C3.] CHINA'S TRADE SURPLUS GROWS -- China said that its trade surplus reached a record $13 billion in May, raising the prospect of renewed trade friction with the United States and Europe. [C8.] TAKEOVER BID DROPPED -- The Mirant Corporation, a power generator, withdrew its $8 billion unsolicited bid for NRG Energy under pressure from Mirant shareholders, who said they could make more money if Mirant sold itself instead. [C6.] ONLINE DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY -- Digital scrapbooking, watching whales in high-def, tips from the pros and more. A special report is at nytimes.com/technology. President Bush took a break from a meeting on his Iraq policy with his war cabinet at Camp David to call the United States team three hours before its game against the Czech Republic yesterday. Speaking via speaker phone, Bush told the team, ''the whole country is pulling for you,'' according to a spokeswoman for the president, Dana Perino. ''He urged them to play hard and keep their heads up,'' Perino said, quoting the president as saying, '' 'We can't wait to see you win.' '' JIM RUTENBERG (NYT)

An article on Thursday about Kyle Kevorkian McCann, a piano teacher who was beaten and sexually assaulted 10 years ago in Central Park, misstated the title of her album of children's songs. It is ''While We're Young,'' not ''When We're Young.''

WALLACE--Marcia (neeToporek). June 11, 2006, beloved wife of Justin, mother of Erika Kors and Nina Wallace; and grandmother of Samantha, Brian, Samuel and Emma. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. The family respectfully requests that contributions in her memory be made to The National Parkinson Fdn., 1501 NW 9th Ave., Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL 33136--1494.Joseph Levine and Son www.levinefuneral.com

A report in the World Briefing column on Friday about a sign being erected to mark the Berlin bunker where Hitler committed suicide misspelled the surname of the reporter. He is Victor Homola, not Homolo. (The same error was made in a World Briefing report on April 14 about a so-called honor killing that shocked Germans.)

To the Editor: You point out the inhumanity of Rear Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr.'s response to the Guantánamo suicides (''The Deaths at Gitmo,'' editorial, June 12). When I first read the admiral's remark -- ''this was not an act of desperation, but an act of asymmetrical warfare waged against us'' -- my body went numb. When I read your editorial, I began to sob.

Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for attorney general, was endorsed yesterday by Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, which represents 60,000 doormen, janitors, security guards and other building service workers in the city. The endorsement, the largest so far for Mr. Green, offered him bragging rights in a campaign that has been dominated by Andrew M. Cuomo, who won the State Democratic Party's backing last month. Mr. Green said the union could be helpful in gathering petition signatures for a spot on the primary ballot. JONATHAN P. HICKS (NYT)

O'BRIEN --VERITY VOIGHT, 78. eloved wife of the late William Jourdan O'Brien. Born June 3, 1928 in Montclair, NJ. Died peacefully at home on Quiogue, NY on Sunday, June 11th. Loving sister of Markell Calvillo, Walter Gorham Voight and the late Delvert Gallett Voight. Survived by devoted children and their spouses Bim Webb and Pat Dowd, Peter and Ann Webb, David and Beth Webb, Betsy and David Rowe, 11 grandchildren and many relatives and friends.

Tajikistan complained that landmines planted along its border by Uzbekistan have killed 68 people since 1999, including 20 children, reopening a point of contention between the countries, which have quarreled since the breakup of the Soviet Union. Sections of the Tajik-Uzbek border have been mined by Uzbekistan since militants from Tajikistan carried out raids into Uzbek territory in 1999 and 2000. Uzbekistan has said they were necessary to deter the militants. Tajikistan, whose land is also littered with mines from its civil war in the mid-1990's, contends that the mines were not necessary, especially because most of the militants, who allied with the Taliban, were routed in the war in Afghanistan in 2001. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

SCHWEITZER--Meyer (Mac). Died peacefully June 10, 2006 at the age of 94 at New York Hospital. Mac left with the wish for peace on earth. World War II Sergeant, USAAC, world-class art dealer and founder of The Schweitzer Gallery. Survived by his beloved wife Frederika, son David, sister Francis, stepdaughter Dr. Adele Mackintosh, her son Gregory and sadly missed by his family in Arizona and friends from around the world.

To the Editor: Although the exact reason that three detainees at Guantánamo committed suicide is not known, it is clear that our government failed in its responsibility to safeguard prisoners under our custody.

To the Editor: Re ''In a Crisis, They Offered Something, Anything'' (Cases, June 6): Dr. Elissa Ely describes a patient who experienced a severe depressive and hysterical reaction, along with suicidal thoughts, and felt better after eating. She may have had a dipping of her blood glucose levels, depriving her brain of its only source of fuel. That she responded rapidly to the food may suggest that she suffered from a severe bout of hypoglycemia.

Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has questioned the role of the secretary of the Smithsonian in selecting a new inspector general at the institution, citing concerns over a possible conflict of interest. Mr. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said that the head of the Smithsonian, Lawrence M. Small, should defer to the institution's board of regents to choose the inspector general, and that the inspector general should report directly to the board. The inspector general's office, established in 1989 to conduct independent investigations of Smithsonian operations, issues a semiannual report to Congress, the board and the secretary. The office is currently examining executive compensation, including Mr. Small's, and accounting standards at the Smithsonian. A spokeswoman for the Smithsonian said that the board would be involved in the decision in any event. The institution announced an acting inspector general last week. JOHN FILES

To the Editor: Re ''Three Prisoners Commit Suicide at Guantánamo'' (front page, June 11): Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and the United Nations have all denounced the conditions of the United States military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and even Prime Minister Tony Blair, the Bush administration's single major ally in the war on terror, has called for its closing.

The legislature agreed to hold a special session from today until the end of the month to debate a possible referendum to recall President Chen Shui-bian, left. The opposition Nationalist Party sought the recall after corruption allegations involving the president's family, but the legislature is not expected to approve a referendum. Approval would require a two-thirds majority, and parties supporting the president hold almost half the seats in the legislature -- although a few lawmakers usually on the president's side have lately voiced misgivings about him. The session will also take up the budget, direct flights to mainland China and other issues. KEITH BRADSHER (NYT)

Lincoln Center announced two finalists yesterday for the design of the Harmony Atrium, an indoor public space on the ground floor of the Harmony Condo building, between 62nd and 63rd Streets; the atrium extends from Broadway to Columbus Avenue. The architects are Morphosis of Santa Monica, Calif., led by Thom Mayne, and Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects of New York. Lincoln Center plans to lease the 6,900-square-foot atrium space and use it for free Juilliard concerts, discount ticket sales on performance days and as a gathering place for audiences. Morphosis's projects include the Caltrans headquarters building in Los Angeles and a new academic building for Cooper Union in New York; Mr. Mayne, above, was awarded the 2005 Pritzker Architecture Prize. Recent projects by Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects include the American Folk Art Museum in New York. An architect will be selected this summer, and work is expected to be completed by fall 2008. ROBIN POGREBIN

A report in the What's Online column in Business Day on Saturday about Farecast, an online guide to buying airline tickets, misstated the Web address of John Battelle's Searchblog, which commented on the service. It is battellemedia.com, not battellemedia.org.

BAILEY--Robert J. Noted photographer and writer, and producer/host of the cable TV show, Poetry Live, passed away June 11, 2006 at age 64 after a struggle with cancer. He was the son of the late Edna Wheeler and Richard Bailey. Survived by Julie Hindra, his beloved wife, his brother Rick Bailey & sisters Becky, Edna and Gail, and numerous nieces & nephews. He will be missed by many. Visitation will be held at the John Krtil Funeral Home on June 14, 2-4 and 7-9.

Yesterday, I went whacky, and entertained experiments beyond the cusp of knowledge. In today's installment for Mad Scientist Week, I propose an experiment to look at an intriguing claim. Namely, that the sex practices of Orthodox Jews - which are strictly prescribed by Jewish law - dramatically increase the chances of having a son.

An injury sustained during training on Monday in Billerbeck, by Nemanja Vidic, who defends for Manchester United during the season, has reduced the already short-handed squad from Serbia Minus Montenegro to 21, according to this report from UEFA. His coach, Ilija Petkovic, responded to the MRI on Vidic's knee, which showed ligament damage, with the more philosophical comment: "That's football, that's life."

Daniel Loeb, the famously outspoken hedge-fund manager, will soon have something new to brag about. The New York Observer reports that Mr. Loeb is gearing up to move to a $45 million penthouse he is buying on New York's Central Park West. When the deal closes, it will rank as the highest-priced sale of a single residence in the city, eclipsing Rupert Murdoch's record-setting $44 million purchase on Fifth Avenue in 2004.

Japan's SUMCO said on Wednesday it would buy rival Komatsu Electronic Metals for about $320 million in a deal that puts it in the running to be the world's top producer of silicon wafers.
Michaels Stores filed its delayed quarterly report late Tuesday and confirmed that there may be accounting discrepancies in its financials related to stock options granted before 2001.
The Xerox Corporation said on Wednesday it would buy the privately held Amici LLC, which helps customers manage and search through legal and other documents, for $174 million.

The publisher of The National Enquirer and Star magazine said Wednesday that it would consider selling five magazines that do not fit its core business of celebrity and "active lifestyle" publications. American Media, which is owned by private equity firms Thomas H. Lee Partners and Evercore, has hired J.P. Morgan Chase and Bear Stearns to shop the magazines, which are Muscle & Fitness, Flex, Muscle & Fitness Hers, Country Weekly, and Mira!

Private equity players Blackstone Group and Carlyle Group have reportedly postponed plans to launch listed buyout funds. In the current market conditions, it's not surprising. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts already mopped up most of the demand.

Shareholders in the media buyer Aegis voted down two board nominees put forward by the French financier Vincent Bollore on Wednesday, but Mr. Bollore vowed to continue his quest for representation by calling an emergency meeting in the autumn.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation could auction off the MySpace search business to one of the larger search providers like Google, Yahoo or Microsoft's MSN, a senior News Corp. executive said Tuesday.

J. Crew will offer 18.8 million shares at a per-share price between $15 and $17 in its upcoming initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing on Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission

Gemstar-TV Guide International on Tuesday said its former chief financial officer, who was fired in 2003 over a scheme to defraud investors, agreed to drop a claim against the company for $8.4 million.
Adobe Systems "has made no determination" to take legal action against Microsoft, after Microsoft said it would offer a free download to let users create PDF files in the next version of Office.

Phillips-Van Heusen may be exceeding its quarterly financial projections, but it remains hot on the acquisitions hunt to maintain the momentum. And one company that Women's Wear Daily said PVH has its eyes on is Warnaco.

Plaintiffs' attorneys in the Enron shareholder lawsuit filed papers Tuesday saying Houston law firm Vinson & Elkins helped executives at the company conduct a massive accounting fraud that led to that firm's December 2001 bankruptcy and billions of dollars in investor losses.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is inviting public comment on the cost of mutual fund governance rules set aside by a federal court in April, a move that leaves open the possibility of reviving or revising them.

Executives guilty of manipulating their stock option grants should be prosecuted to the fullest extent possible, Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said yesterday.

The private equity firm HMD Partners, based here, has sold its controlling stake in fashion house Escada to the Swiss finance group Finartis for an undisclosed sum - and has moved on to the next acquisition.

Nordic Capital, an investment firm, said Tuesday that it would buy Dangaard Telecom, a Danish company that is one of the world's largest distributors of mobile phones and mobile phone accessories, for an undisclosed sum.

The buyout firm Nautic Partners is near closing a deal to sell Contec, which repairs cable TV set-top boxes, to a fellow buyout firm, LBO Wire reported. The transaction, which was cleared of antitrust concerns by the Federal Trade Commission, is expected to close in a few weeks, LBO said.
RedSeal Systems has dug up more than $14 million in Series A financing and plans to reveal its security risk management software for the first time later this week.

Morgan Stanley has been awarded the role of sole bookrunner for the bond component of PSA International's acquisition financing for Hutchison Port Holdings. The $4.4 billion acquisition financing is to be funded through a combination of a $3.42 billion term loan and bond offering estimated to be worth around $1 billion.
The French insurer AXA has agreed to buy the Swiss-based Winterthur unit from Credit Suisse for 12.3 billion Swiss francs ($10 billion), the companies said Wednesday.

The public face-off between Mittal Steel and Arcelor, the rival steel giants, may soften a bit as a result of a meeting on Tuesday evening in Brussels in which they were expected to discuss a potential merger.

Commodities have become big business for Wall Street banks, and revenues from the area could grow 15 percent to 20 percent a year for the next several years, even with recent pullbacks in the oil and metals markets, analysts and business heads said.

An industrial testing and inspection business, Moody International, has been put up for a potential $250 million-$300 million sale by its private equity owner, Close Brothers Private Equity, The Telegraph reported.

With buyout funds reaching increasingly astronomic proportions, it was only a matter of time before the venture capital community followed suit. Oak Investment Partners said it put the finishing touches on the largest venture capital fund ever, as its 12th vehicle closed with $2.56 billion.

The N.H.L. is trying to fool the public with a flawed anti-doping program, Dick Pound, the chairman of the World Anti-Doping agency, said yesterday. Lt. Gen. James T. Conway has been nominated by President Bush to serve as commandant of the Marine Corps.

When Ben Roethlisberger, Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback, chose to ride his motorcycle, he did not breach his football contract or break the law.   His biggest offense might have been breaking his contract with fans.
Lottery Numbers.
Alan B. Mollohan, Democrat of West Virginia, faces an investigation into possible links between real estate investments and nonprofit groups he supported with earmarks.
At the Bellevue Hospital Center, a garden that some use with their therapy may become part of an expanded parking lot.
The arcane trade issue has returned as British publishers complain about what they see as a new threat on their home turf.
"I was overcome and almost appalled with disappointment in terms of the breadth and depth of corruption in your administration," a judge told William C. Campbell.
