By taking on Big Oil, which has developed other offshore fields in Newfoundland and Labrador, premier Danny Williams is taking quite a gamble.
EBay said that sellers would be able to add a link to their listings allowing potential buyers to reach them through Skype, the Internet phone service.
Best Buy said the gain was driven by an increase in the average size of each transaction.
Goldman Sachs reported that its earnings more than doubled from a year earlier, but the company failed to impress Wall Street and its stock fell.
In the United States, stocks drifted in and out of positive territory early in the day but closed down for the third consecutive trading day.
Most minor league teams have promotions — from Thunderstix Night to Food Fling — but the Rox, an independent franchise, seem to have a knack for devising stunts that resonate nationally.
Quebec offers universal day care, an audacious idea that recognizes the revolution in women's work over the last 30 years.
Secretary General Kofi Annan warned that a new mission would need at least six more months to set up.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 13 — Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, might be trailing in the polls, but he was the only one of the three candidates for governor to receive a standing ovation at a two-day gathering of mayors from across the state here.

The Conservative national government invoked special powers to invalidate a local law that was to be the first in Australia giving legal recognition to same-sex partnerships. The law was passed last month by the Australian Capital Territory, which includes the national capital, Canberra, and was to go into effect this week. Federal marriage laws were amended in 2004 to define marriage as a union between a man and a woman, and opponents of the local law to allow civil unions said it effectively legalized gay marriage.
The police in Toronto charged eight people said to be gang members in connection with the shooting death of a 15-year-old girl on Dec. 26.
The Security Council eased its ban to enable President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf to arm newly trained police and security forces.
Some one million high school students returned to classes after a three-week strike that wrested new education money from the government.

Scientists lowered the alert status at Mount Merapi, saying the risk of a major eruption had decreased. The volcano remains at the second-highest alert level, meaning it is still dangerous, but the decision means that thousands of people who left their homes can return, said Yousana Siagian, the country's chief volcanologist.

A survey of more than 1,000 law enforcement actions on the subway system in Moscow found that people who appeared non-Slavic were 20 times more likely to be stopped by the police than those who looked like Slavs. The results were announced by the Open Society Justice Initiative and Jurix, a private organization, and they denounced what they called an institutionalized practice of racial profiling. The report, which also identified profiling practices but to a much lesser degree in the United States and Britain, followed a series of brutal beatings and killings in Russia of minorities from Central Asia, the Caucasus and Africa. Moscow "simply cannot afford to have police wasting time and resources by stopping anyone who looks different," said James A. Goldston, the director of the justice initiative.

An American military tow truck pulling another truck hit a motorbike in Kabul and killed its driver before plowing into a house, two weeks after another crash in the city involving United States forces set off riots that killed 20 people. There was no immediate sign of unrest after the accident, which occurred when the truck's driver seemingly lost control going down a hill, said Mohammed Zaman, a police officer. No one in the house was hurt.
The Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro had the cast changed on his broken right hind leg and the plates and screws that were inserted three weeks ago appear to be working.
Also, Israel rejected responsibility for eight deaths on Friday that Palestinians blamed on an errant shell.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton moved to shift the debate over abortion rights to the subject of access to family planning services.

TRENTON, June 13 — With many Democrats wary of Gov. Jon S. Corzine's plan to increase New Jersey's sales tax in an effort to balance the state's $31 billion budget, the governor met on Tuesday with two top Republican legislators who delivered the same message — to drop it.
The bombings killed more than two dozen Iraqis in morning rush-hour attacks that were aimed at top police officials and security patrols.
Among the thousands of families displaced by the Chernobyl nuclear meltdown was that of Andriy Shevchenko, the captain of the Ukrainian team and one of the most menacing forwards at this World Cup.

When Madalitso Muthiya stands on the first tee at 9:01 a.m. Thursday at the United States Open, Zambia will rejoice and a father's dream will have been realized at one of golf's most revered tournaments.
Three of New York's most elite high schools improperly charged poor students a total of $180,000 over several years to take Advanced Placement exams, investigators said.

The City Council toughened its internal sexual harassment policy yesterday to require a person who complains of being harassed to follow up with an official complaint and a council member who hears of inappropriate behavior to report it.
At age 31 in his 11th season, Jerry Stackhouse has never been closer to an N.B.A. championship. He has subverted his ego and embraced his sixth-man role.
The wife of a man being sought in the wounding of a family court judge was found stabbed to death, the police said.

ALBANY, June 13 — A powerful state teachers' union agreed Tuesday to pay $100,000 as part of a settlement with Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's office, following an investigation of its dealings with the Dutch financial services giant that bought exclusive access to sell investments to teachers.
Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said a greater reliance on nuclear power and ethanol-based fuels was more realistic than President Bush's plan of reducing dependence on foreign energy sources.
The United States Committee for Refugees and Immigrants counted 644,500 Iraqi refugees in Syria and Jordan in 2005.

United States military personnel, who were resigned to missing the World Cup on bases and ships around the world, will apparently be able to watch the games after all through the intervention of the media magnate Rupert Murdoch.
Some protesters had chained themselves to trees and picnic tables in defiance of an eviction order at the 14-acre site.

HARTFORD, June 13 — James Galante named his hockey team the Danbury Trashers to reflect his empire, one built on garbage collection. But federal agents say Mr. Galante committed fraud by putting some players as well as some players' wives and others on the payrolls of his companies.
Bayer filed suit in a federal court Tuesday to stop a German rival, Merck, from voting its recently acquired stake in Schering.
On the whole, the new more participatory politics that the Internet is ushering in is clearly a good thing for democracy.
The road back to prosperity will be a long and hard one for American automakers.

Brazil, five times champions and firm favorites to take home a sixth trophy, entered a charged World Cup arena in the German capital's Olympiastadion and defeated a determined Croatia, 1-0.
After too many photo-ops, Americans hunger more than ever for a realistic game plan for Iraq and some real progress.
A bill that provides $94.5 billion for Iraq, Afghanistan and Gulf Coast recovery is expected to pass the Senate.
Lawyers for former parishioners and the Archdiocese of New York clashed before an appellate court yesterday over whether church officials can demolish one of the oldest churches in Manhattan.
As much as $1.4 billion in government disaster aid to victims of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita went to bogus or undeserving victims, an investigation found.

Laura Bush arrived in Lakewood, N.J., for a fund-raiser for State Senator Thomas H. Kean's candidacy for the United States Senate, everything appeared to run smoothly.

A Riverhead man is accused of capturing a neighbor's cat and taking it to an animal shelter to be put to death.
Law enforcement agencies in Russia are not only taking sides in commercial disputes, but also precipitating them to enrich corrupted officials.

A teenage girl walking along an elevated stretch of Route 1 fell to her death last night after she dropped her cellphone and tried to retrieve it, the girl's boyfriend told the authorities. It was just after 8 p.m. when the unidentified girl, believed to be between 14 and 18, fell about 110 feet down a rocky slope, said Sgt. Edgar Martinez, a spokesman for the Jersey City Police Department. She was pronounced dead at the scene, and traffic and several freight rail lines in the area were suspended for several hours. Sgt. Martinez said that the boyfriend was the only witness and that officers interviewed him at the scene before handing the case over to the Hudson County homicide squad.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed three bills yesterday that tighten regulation of city lobbyists, including a ban on gifts from lobbyists to city officials. The mayor noted that revenues to city lobbyists had more than doubled since 2000. The mayor also signed a bill to increase the number of taxicab medallions reserved for vehicles that are wheelchair-accessible or run on alternative fuels.

Demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street will not begin this month, as had been anticipated, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday. On Monday, the federal Environmental Protection Agency raised questions about the proposed handling of waste materials containing polychlorinated biphenyls and cadmium in the heavily contaminated 41-story tower opposite ground zero. The corporation hopes to begin demolition later this summer, a spokesman said.

The cost of settling lawsuits against New York City grew to $575.6 million in 2004 from $265.1 million in 1995, according to a report that the city's Independent Budget Office released yesterday. The cost grew at an average annual rate of 9 percent, nearly twice the rate of all other city spending. The mayor's most recent budget projections anticipate that the cost will increase to nearly $800 million by 2010. Four categories of cases — medical malpractice, sidewalk trips and falls, motor vehicle accidents and police actions — accounted for most of the expenses.

The wife and sons of Charles Kushner, the New Jersey real estate mogul who went to jail for two years for witness tampering and illegal campaign contributions, have put a block of the Kushner Companies' properties on the market in a deal that some say could net them $2 billion. Clive Cummis, vice chairman of the company, said the family had put some 17,500 apartments in 90 developments in New Jersey and Pennsylvania up for sale in the past few months because of the strength of the rental housing market.

A 12-year-old pitcher whose heart was stopped by a line drive during a baseball game in Wayne on June 6 is slowly being brought out of a medically induced coma, his family said yesterday. Doctors at St. Joseph's Regional Medical Center in Paterson performed an M.R.I. scan of the pitcher, Steven Domalewski, on Monday, said the boy's aunt, Marie Fullerton. Steven suffered some brain damage, but the extent will not be known until he is fully alert, Ms. Fullerton said. He opened his eyes yesterday and gripped the hands of his parents, Joseph and Nancy Domalewski.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has funneled another enormous set of grants — more than $30 million — to hundreds of New York City arts and social services groups through a gift to the Carnegie Corporation. The donation announced yesterday is the largest that the mayor has made, ostensibly anonymously, through the corporation thus far. The grants, generally ranging from $25,000 to $100,000, are to benefit 518 organizations in all five boroughs, Carnegie officials said, varying from the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club to the Ghetto Film School in the South Bronx.

Two people were shot, one fatally, about 9 p.m. yesterday on a residential street in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, the police said. A 34-year-old man was declared dead at the scene after he was shot in the head and chest in front of 520 East 21st Street. The other victim, a 36-year-old woman whom neighbors identified as Nichelle Edwards, was shot in the hand and taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where she remained in stable condition last night. Witnesses said the gunman fled in an orange-colored car. There were no arrests last night.
Women still make up a small fraction of the university's tenured professors, a year after a major effort to make the faculty more diverse.

The number of smokers in New York City rose slightly last year, but remains historically low, the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday. A survey commissioned by the city found that 18.9 percent of adults in the city smoked last year. That was up from 18.4 percent in 2004, but still well below the 21.6 percent found in 2002, and higher rates in earlier surveys. Combined city and state tobacco taxes jumped in 2002 to $3 per pack of cigarettes from $1.19, contributing to the decline. The next year, new laws banned smoking in nearly all restaurants and bars.

New York State's highest court yesterday upheld the removal of a controversial State Supreme Court justice who prevented a detective from arresting a robbery suspect in her courtroom two years ago by allowing him to exit through a back entrance. The justice, Laura D. Blackburne, left, of State Supreme Court in Queens, had argued that she should not be removed for a single error of judgment, but a majority of the State Court of Appeals disagreed. The court's 5-2 decision upholds a ruling last November by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, which found that Justice Blackburne had
Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, a Rhode Island Democrat, was sentenced to court-ordered drug treatment, a year of probation and a $350 fine.
Thierry Henry and his teammates were unable to play their natural fast-moving game because the grounds crew neglected to water the grass.
The energy giant is in talks with several universities as possible sites for the research center but says it has not yet picked a partner.
J. J. Redick, a star guard for Duke the past four years, was arrested early Tuesday on charges of drunken driving.
The amendment to the union's constitution allows the international leadership to spend up to $60 million from the strike fund.

House lawmakers accepted a $3,300 raise that will increase their salaries to $168,500. Lawmakers easily squelched a bid by Representative Jim Matheson, Democrat of Utah, to vote on the cost-of-living raise, which is automatically awarded unless lawmakers vote to block it. Last year, the Senate voted 92 to 6 to deny the raise but quietly surrendered the position in negotiations with the House. As part of an ethics bill in 1989, Congress gave up its ability to accept pay for speeches and made annual cost-of-living pay increases automatic unless blocked.

A judge on Monday sentenced a woman to prison for telling her 6-year-old daughter to steal a volunteer fire company's fund-raising jar, a crime that netted $1.85. The woman, Judith Weidner, 42, told the police she needed the change for gasoline, but in court she blamed a heroin addiction. Judge David W. Addy sentenced her to one to three years in prison for the January 2005 theft.

A federal judge sentenced a former city clerk in Chicago to two years in prison for taking thousands of dollars in bribes over six years. The former clerk, James J. Laski, 52, was the highest-ranking official to be charged in a federal investigation into corruption in the city's disbanded truck contracting program. Mr. Laski pleaded guilty in March and admitted to taking $48,000 in bribes from two friends in exchange for city trucking work. A total of 44 people have been charged and 37 convicted in the investigation.
A university committee voted 6 to 3 to recommend that Ward Churchill, a controversial professor of ethnic studies at the University of Colorado, be dismissed.

A federal jury in the first trial in the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal was sent home four hours after beginning deliberations so the judge could consider whether to dismiss a juror for misconduct. David Safavian, a former Bush administration official, is charged with concealing from ethics officials and investigators that he assisted Mr. Abramoff's efforts to obtain two government properties. Prosecutors argued that the juror should be dismissed because she disregarded the judge's instructions on several occasions and told other jurors she had discussed the costs of a golf trip to Scotland with her father. Mr. Safavian's expenses for such a trip in 2002 have been an issue in trial testimony.

Republicans scrapped a vote on President Bush's choice to head the agency in charge of mine safety after it became clear that he did not have enough support to win Senate approval. Democrats opposed the nominee, Richard Stickler, saying he had spent too many years as a coal mining executive and had failed to demonstrate that safety was his top priority. In his confirmation hearing earlier this year, Mr. Stickler declined to endorse several proposed changes to mine safety laws but said the enforcement of existing laws could be improved. Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, used a procedure known as a legislative hold to block the nomination.

It has become standard practice for developers to negotiate with neighborhood and other groups to forge so-called community benefits agreements.

Representative John P. Murtha, left, a candidate for majority leader if Democrats take control of the House from Republicans in November, said he would not actively campaign for that post until after the elections.
Philip Merrill was an Annapolis publisher and former diplomat who has been missing since he set out for a solitary sail on Saturday afternoon.
A top official cast new doubt on whether the signature skyscraper's steel frame would ever rise above street level.

An article on Saturday about statements from the United States and Iran on possible negotiations over Iran's nuclear program misidentified the Iranian official who said his country was ready to hold talks with the United States. He was Muhammad Javad Larijani, chief of international affairs for the country's judiciary; it was not his brother Ali Larijani, Iran's chief nuclear negotiator.
Airbus said that it would produce only nine of its giant new A380 jets next year because of numerous design changes.
Queen Afua believes "there is a healer within each of us and we must establish a relationship with him/her."

Mike Quarry was a leading light-heavyweight boxer of the 1970's and a younger brother of the heavyweight contender Jerry Quarry.
Ingo Preminger was a Hollywood agent and producer who represented several blacklisted screenwriters during the anti-Communist fervor of the postwar years.
Zhao Yan, who is accused of disclosing state secrets and fraud, has been in custody for 22 months without appearing in court.
Charles J. Haughey was a three-time Irish prime minister who helped pave the way for Ireland's economic boom of the 1990's.
Half of the $3 billion, far more than originally estimated, will be needed for new houses, according to the new findings.
A first-year teacher of immigrant high school students thought what better way to give them confidence than to have them perform "The Wizard of Oz."

Colm Toibin wins a big prize, Michigan Senate favors "truth in music," Getty book deal reported and more culture news.

With more single-flower honeys on store shelves and farmers' market tables, chefs have been dispatching their wildly different flavors to dishes the way sommeliers pair wine with food.
The Texas troupe's latest work, a rock opera of songs by musician and artist Daniel Johnston, has won over critics and audience members alike.
Michael Sullivan's Brouwers of Stone Street opens on Friday, a slice of Provence comes to Carroll Gardens and Sadie Mae's plates up comfort food for the stroller set.

It's time for baseball — from owners to players to trainers — to look in the mirror and examine its soul.
Some of the United States players did not know their roles during Monday's 3-0 defeat to the Czech Republic at the World Cup, midfielder Bobby Convey said today.

Because of a day off on Monday, the Yankees gave Randy Johnson the option of pushing his start back a day to get his mechanics straightened out. Johnson will pitch as scheduled tonight against the Indians, but Manager Joe Torre said the decision was not made final until yesterday.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Bush, in Baghdad, Urges Iraqis to Pull Together President Bush used a surprise visit to Baghdad to say that the time had come for Iraqis to pull together to save the faltering American-sponsored democracy there. A1 Insurgents unleashed a volley of bombings across the northern oil city of Kirkuk, killing more than two dozen Iraqis. A15 In one of the first tallies of Iraqis fleeing Iraq since the American-led invasion, the United States Committee for Refugees and Immigrants counted 644,500 Iraqi refugees in Syria and Jordan in 2005. A15 Israeli Strike Kills More Civilians Eight Palestinian civilians were killed and more than 40 wounded by an Israeli missile strike on Islamic militants. Israel's defense minister said an investigation into the earlier death of a family showed that Israel was not to blame. A1 Global Views on U.S. Are Dim The global image of America has slipped further, even among people in some countries closely allied with the United States, according to a survey done in 15 nations this spring by the Pew Research Center. A8 Indonesia to Release Cleric A radical Islamic cleric, whom the Bush administration has portrayed as an important operative for Al Qaeda in Southeast Asia, was scheduled to walk out of prison after serving just over a year for criminal conspiracy, his lawyers and Indonesian officials said. A10 Costly Indonesian Earthquake The Indonesian government said more than $3 billion would be needed for reconstruction because of the May 27 earthquake, far more than originally estimated. A9 Muslim Shot Without Warning A 23-year-old Muslim man who was shot and wounded in London during what the police have described as a counterterrorism operation said the officers had not identified themselves and had given no warning before opening fire at close range. A10 NATIONAL A16-21 No Charges Against Rove In the C.I.A. Leak Case The decision by a special prosecutor not to bring charges against Karl Rove in the C.I.A. leak case followed months of intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering between the prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, and Mr. Rove's lawyer, according to lawyers in the case. A1 Many Still in FEMA Trailers Tens of thousands of people continue to live crammed in FEMA trailers, greeting this year's hurricane season the same way they said goodbye to the last one. A1 The House of Representatives approved a $94.5 billion emergency spending bill to provide more money for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan and to finance the recovery of Gulf Coast states battered by hurricanes last year. A21 Baptists Have New President The nation's 16 million Southern Baptists have a new president, Dr. Frank S. Page, elected in an upset victory that he said marked a turning point for a church that has grown increasingly conservative. A18 Storm Posed No Serious Threat Tropical Storm Alberto weakened before hitting the Florida Gulf Coast with heavy rain and high winds, but it did not pose the threat forecasters had feared. A20 KFC Sued by Nutrition Group A nutrition advocacy group sued KFC to get it to stop using partially hydrogenated oils, a key ingredient of its fried chicken. The oils contain trans fats, which scientists consider the most unhealthful of all fats. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Prozac Ineffective for Anorexia A widely used treatment for anorexia nervosa, the antidepressant Prozac, works no better than dummy pills in preventing recurrence of the eating disorder in young women who have recovered from it, researchers are reporting. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Texas Tourist Stabbed By Stranger on the Subway A man sitting in a subway car on the Upper West Side suddenly stood up, crossed the aisle and repeatedly thrust a knife into the chest of a 21-year-old tourist from Texas riding with a female friend, critically wounding him, the police said. A1 Giuliani Faults Energy Policy Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, challenging fellow Republicans in Washington, said that the Bush administration lacked an energy policy and that greater reliance on nuclear power, ethanol-based fuels and hybrid vehicles was more realistic than President Bush's goal of independence from foreign energy sources. B1 Tower May Hinge on Leases A top official of the Port Authority cast new doubt on whether the Freedom Tower's steel frame would ever rise above street level at ground zero. The 1,776-foot tower would have to be reconsidered if state officials fail to obtain leases for 1 million square feet from federal agencies by September, the official said. B3 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-7 Heat Takes Game 3 Miami's Dwyane Wade scored 42 points and lead the Heat to a 98-96 come-from-behind victory over the Dallas Mavericks in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals. Miami trails 2-1 in the best-of-seven series. D1 ARTS E1-10 PBS Looks to a Digital Future Staking its future in the digital media world, the Public Broadcasting Service has created a new post of chief content officer and named a public broadcasting executive with extensive digital experience to fill the job. John Boland, 57, is currently the executive vice president and chief content officer at KQED Public Broadcasting in San Francisco. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Digital Giants Square Off The land around the Columbia River along the Oregon-Washington border, at the intersection of cheap electricity and accessible data networking, is the backdrop for a billion-dollar face-off among Google, Microsoft and Yahoo that will determine Internet dominance for years to come. A1 Global Stocks Tumble Around the world, waves of selling sent stocks and commodities tumbling. C1 Goldman Profits Soar Goldman Sachs said it more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago. However, the firm's stock suffered from concerns that recent market weakness would continue and form a seasonal summer slowdown in brokerage activity. C1 Tribune Trusts Disagree Two towering figures in 20th century newspaper publishing created distinctive trusts to safeguard the papers they built and the causes they championed. Now the two trusts -- both shareholders in the Tribune Company -- differ on a plan to revive the company's slumping shares. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Too soon to cheer in Baghdad; worse than nothing; wrenching changes on the line; Adam Cohen on whether a 15-year-old with a laptop could be the new campaign media guru. FEEN--Rosalie D., on June 10, 2006. Cherished wife of Eugene and beloved mother of Susan and David. Grandmother of Allyson and sister of Marion. She will live with us forever. Funeral service today, 1 PM at Schwartz Bros Chapel, Forest Hills, NY.

ANA SORTUN, the chef at Oleana restaurant in Cambridge, Mass., finished culinary school in Paris in 1988. But the education of her palate wasn't complete, she said, until she apprenticed herself to the Tunisian chef Moncef Meddeb in Boston, then began traveling to Turkey and Greece in the 1990's. In those countries she first encountered the seasonings that are used liberally by cooks in the Eastern Mediterranean, but sparingly in the European repertory she'd been schooled in: many kinds of chilies; dried herbs like mint and thyme; warm spices like turmeric, cumin, and cinnamon; sesame and poppy seeds; intensely sweet-tart pomegranate molasses.

The police in Toronto charged eight people said to be gang members in connection with the shooting death of a 15-year-old girl on Dec. 26. The girl died after being caught in cross-fire outside a downtown mall, and the audacity of the gunfight -- in broad daylight on Canada's busiest shopping day of the year -- shocked the city, which had already experienced a rash of gang shootings. The killing had an influence on the national election the next month that was won by the Conservatives, whose leader, Stephen Harper, blamed the policies of the Liberal government of Prime Minister Paul Martin for an increase in violence. CHRISTOPHER MASON (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''Those Pesky Voters'' (column, June 12): Bob Herbert is correct in saying that although it can't be proved that the 2004 presidential election in Ohio was rigged, in light of the irregularities observed in the process itself, it is overwhelmingly probable that it was.

The finest chocolate, as we know it, dates from 1879. That was when Rudolph Lindt, a Swiss chocolatier, invented the conching machine, which made it easier to knead a mass of warm chocolate to a satin-smooth texture. The longer the chocolate is conched, the finer the texture. Chocolate that is worked by hand will never achieve that finesse. But a bite of a bar of Don Puglisi chocolate proves that there is merit in old-fashioned chocolate that is dull, not shiny, and has a pleasingly crunchy texture. This artisanal chocolate from Modica, a baroque hill town in southeast Sicily, is made from the finest criollo beans and is worked without heating, on a machine that is similar to a metate, a Mexican-style mortar, so that the sugar crystals retain their integrity.

Five years ago, if you were searching the globe for the next international party hot spot, you might easily have overlooked the island of Hvar, off Croatia's Dalmatian coast. The wars that engulfed the region following the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991 had only just ended, and Hvar itself was nothing but a hilly rock in the unpolluted Adriatic Sea, dotted with picturesque villages and cursed with fresh seafood, near-eternal sunshine and a currency cheapened by years of conflict. In other words, Hvar was ripe for a comeback, as was the entire country. In the not-so-amazing race by travel insiders to find the new "it" spot, Croatia has been billed as "the next Italy." And for frugal travelers everywhere, "emerging" and "undiscovered" are not only code words for tourist-free and unspoiled but often synonymous with affordable.

India's factories will double annual exports to $100 billion and create 25 million jobs by 2010, according to a new study. The country's low-cost labor and engineering expertise will draw increased investment in the country's manufacturing, according to the study by the trade group Assocham, or the Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India. India has so far become known globally as a services hub. Assocham, based in New Delhi, said the biggest growth would be in engineering, textiles, drugs and auto parts. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

To the Editor: To solve the widening reading gap between boys and girls, David Brooks says educators should offer them different reading materials. He's right in one sense. The easiest thing in the world is for elementary school and even middle school teachers to offer kids choices about what to read. But please, let's not make that old mistake of assuming that what's appealing to one sex is not appealing to the other.

To the Editor: Bob Herbert's column should turn the stomach of every American who has been led to believe that our democracy is fair and equitable. Election reform must happen at many levels, but first and foremost, laws must be passed to ensure that top election officials in states are barred from serving in any capacity with a campaign.

Wayne Harley Brachman knows what it's like to pack two children off to school with filled lunchboxes, so his advice in ''See Dad Cook'' (Clarkson Potter, $16.95 paper) rings true. Mr. Brachman is an experienced chef, but his friendly book, which might be just right for a Father's Day gift, assumes little familiarity with the kitchen. It covers tools, shopping, shortcuts and, perhaps best of all, how kids can be enlisted to help out at mealtime. The recipes are basic: pasta primavera, for example, pot roast, even popcorn. The blueberry muffin recipe is excellent. The esthetics of Japanese food, so evident on the plate, start with often hand-crafted kitchen implements. Cooks everywhere have discovered the santoku knife, but in ''Cool Tools: Cooking Utensils from the Japanese Kitchen'' (Kodansha International, $28), Kate Klippensteen discusses many more utensils, like slender chopsticks used in cooking, ceramic pots, special graters and graceful bamboo colanders. A list of sources is given.

To the Editor: David Brooks addresses a crucial point, that our boys and young men in school are often turned off as young readers because the books assigned them to read are not engaging them and turning them into readers. But his solution -- assigning more ''Hemingway, Tolstoy, Homer and Twain'' -- is not the answer, especially for our country's struggling readers.

To the Editor: Warm thanks to Bob Herbert, whose June 12 column recommending Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s important exposé in Rolling Stone deserves the highest praise from every patriotic American citizen. The integrity of our elections is certainly not a partisan concern or a left-right issue, but a civic matter of immeasurable importance. If we aren't free to vote our representatives and leaders in and out of office, we really aren't free at all, whether we declare ourselves as Democrats, Republicans or independents.

GOOGLE'S BIG PLANS -- On the banks of the windswept Columbia River in Oregon, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing: a computing center as big as two football fields. [Page A1.] GOLDMAN PROFIT LEAPS -- Goldman Sachs said it more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, with strong results in each of its divisions. The bank reported net income for the second quarter of $2.31 billion, or $4.78 a share. Market Place. [C1.] MARKETS STRUCK BY SELLING -- Waves of selling, described by some analysts as panicked, sent stocks and commodities tumbling around the world. The worst declines were in Asia. [C1.] WHOLESALE PRICES -- Higher prices at the manufacturing level helped push overall prices of wholesale goods higher in May, the Labor Department reported. At the same time, the government said that retail sales were essentially flat. [C3.] DUELING LEGACIES -- Two trusts representing the legacies of Harry Chandler and Col. Robert R. McCormick have taken starkly different views of the plan by the Tribune Company's management to revive the media giant's slumping shares [C1.] SHOWDOWN OVER OIL -Danny Williams, premier of Newfoundland and Labrador, is a multimillionaire and a member of the Conservative Party of Canada. But in his fight with Big Oil over a field's development, he is being compared to Venezuela's president, Hugo Chávez. [C1.] EBAY-SKYPE LINK -- EBay said that sellers on its auction site will soon be able to add a link to their listings that will let potential buyers reach them through Skype, the Internet phone service that eBay bought last year. The announcement comes nine months after eBay raised eyebrows by spending $2.6 billion for Skype, a European start-up that at the time had just $60 million in sales. [C5.] U.A.W. FINANCES RECRUITMENT -- The United Automobile Workers union has voted to use part of its $914 million strike fund to pay for recruitment of new members. [C3.] SUIT TAKES AIM AT FAT -- A nutrition advocacy group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, has sued KFC to stop its use of a key ingredient of its fried chicken -- partly hydrogenated oils containing trans fat, which scientists consider the most unhealthy fat. [A16.] BP TO FINANCE BIOFUELS PROGRAM -- BP is planning to spend $500 million over the next 10 years to finance major work on biofuels. The energy giant is in talks with several universities in the United States and Britain as possible sites for the research center. BP's chief executive, Lord Browne, above, is expected to formally announce the program in London today. [C9.] ENRON SETTLEMENT -- Two small utilities are set to pay more than $50 million to Enron for electricity that they agreed to buy but that Enron will never deliver, under a settlement that raises larger issues. [C3.] PROZAC FOR ANOREXIA -- One of the most widely used treatments for anorexia nervosa, the antidepressant Prozac, works no better than dummy pills in preventing recurrence of the disorder in young women who have recovered from it, researchers are reporting. [A21.] PBS NAMES CONTENT CHIEF -- Staking its future in digital media, the Public Broadcasting Service has created a new post of chief content officer and named a public broadcasting executive with extensive digital experience to fill the job. [E1.] DELAY IN JET DELIVERIES -- Airbus said it would produce only 9 of its giant new A380 jets next year, not the 25 planned, because of numerous design changes. [C3.] FACE TO FACE -- The public face-off between Mittal Steel and Arcelor, rival steel giants, may soften a bit as a result of a meeting in Brussels. There, they were expected to discuss a potential merger. [C9.] DRUG MAKER'S SUIT -- The German drug and chemicals company Bayer filed suit in a New York court to stop a German rival, Merck, from voting its recently acquired stake in Schering. Bayer has bid 16.5 billion euros, or $20.8 billion, for Schering. [C9.] TEACHERS' UNION SETTLES -- A powerful teachers' union agreed to pay $100,000 as part of a settlement with the office of the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. The union, the New York State United Teachers, was paid $3 million a year by the Dutch financial services firm ING, and in return it endorsed ING's retirement products to its more than 500,000 members. To the Editor: David Brooks says schools are turning boys into ''high school and college dropouts who hate reading'' by forcing boys to read ''new-wave young adult problem'' novels. Unfortunately, by the time that boys are old enough to read young adult novels, they have long been conditioned to choose video games over books. Mr. Brooks writes that ''the percentage of young men who read has plummeted over the past 14 years.'' This shouldn't be surprising given the popularity of video games, which are played mostly by boys.

To the Editor: ''The Stranger,'' ''Catcher in the Rye'' and ''Slaughterhouse-Five'': I find it difficult to imagine that these titles are any less in touch with the human experience than ''Pride and Prejudice'' and other works that David Brooks describes as being favored by women and ''better.'' Men, women and teenagers could all pick up some of the wrenching humanity in the works of Albert Camus, J. D. Salinger and Kurt Vonnegut.

An article on April 30 about the demolition of a building in Asbury Park, N.J., that had become a symbol of failed efforts to revive the city, referred erroneously to one observer, Kevin Feehan. He is a former manager of the Wonder Bar in Asbury Park, not an owner. This correction was delayed by a reporting lapse.

TED DENNARD, founder of the Savannah Bee Company, says 2004 produced the best orange blossom honey the South has seen in decades. But you never know. ''Last year was an awful year for basswood,'' said Zeke Freeman, owner of Bee Raw Honey, blaming an early summer drought in New York.

deSIMONE--Jack. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Jack deSimone. Jack played a distinguished role in the history of Carnegie Hall. A tireless advocate on the Committee to Save Carnegie Hall, he joined the Board of Trustees of the newly formed Carnegie Hall Society in 1960, and became an Honorary Trustee in 1988. All of us at Carnegie Hall are grateful to Jack for his vision, his leadership and his love for this institution. We send our heartfelt condolences to his daughter, Diane; his brother, Anthony; his sister, Frances; and to his many friends. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman of the Board Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director

An obituary on Sunday about Charles F. Brush III, an archaeologist and former president of the Explorers Club, incorrectly listed his third wife, Ellen Sperry Brush, as a survivor. She died in 1999. The obituary also misstated his grandfather's given name in some copies. He was Charles Francis Brush, not George Francis.

An article on Saturday about statements from the United States and Iran on possible negotiations over Iran's nuclear program misidentified the Iranian official who said his country was ready to hold talks with the United States. He was Muhammad Javad Larijani, chief of international affairs for the country's judiciary; it was not his brother Ali Larijani, Iran's chief nuclear negotiator.

The second season of Fox's ''Hell's Kitchen'' made its debut on Monday, and Gordon Ramsay, the screaming chef, divided the teams by sex, made them crawl around in garbage and got rid of three competitors. (Two were eliminated; one left because of too much stress.) The cooking contest won the night for Fox among adults 18 to 49 and delivered 6.7 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. It built steadily from its first half-hour at 8 p.m. (5.5 million viewers) to its last at 9:30 p.m. (7.9 million). CBS's night of repeats placed first among viewers, and second in the 18-to-49 demographic. Its ''CSI: Miami'' rerun at 10 p.m. was the night's most-watched show, with 13.4 million viewers. That trampled the series premiere of ABC's ''How to Get the Guy,'' a dating reality show, which drew a mere 4.3 million. KATE AURTHUR

A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday included incorrect references to the theater company 13P. It produced two plays last month, not three; ''Dead City,'' playing at the 3LD & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, was not one of them. A correction on this page on Saturday misspelled the name of the company that did produce ''Dead City.'' It is New Georges, not Gorges.

The Top 20 finalists try to remember that it takes two to tango, krump, paso doble and salsa as they dance as couples before the phone lines are opened to voters for the first time this season. 8 P.M. (13) BILL IRWIN: CLOWN PRINCE -- Robin Williams calls him ''Fred Astaire on mojitos,'' which is a pretty apt description for someone whose pliable physicality put the limp in Noodle (as in Mr., his ''Sesame Street'' character). This 2004 ''Great Performances'' special traverses 25 years in the life of Mr. Irwin -- actor, playwright, director, choreographer, clown and national treasure -- as he sets about proving that sometimes a simple gesture is just as effective in getting your point across as a script's worth of words. 9 P.M. (13, 49) COLE PORTER: YOU'RE THE TOP -- His marriage was a mostly happy sham, and some of his bestknown love songs were inspired by men. Still, no one could craft a lighthearted ode to human emotion better than Porter (above), whose life, as shown in this 1990 ''American Masters'' special, was as complicated as they come. Bobby Short, the definitive Porter interpreter, narrates. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) COUNTDOWN TO DOOMSDAY -- Has the state of the world got you down? This special, with Matt Lauer as host, not only lists 10 potential scenarios under which earth's next mass extinction might occur, but also -- for the optimists out there -- 10 equally plausible approaches for averting disaster. 10 P.M. (ABC) COMMANDER IN CHIEF -- Talk about a lame duck. Mackenzie Allen (Geena Davis, right), the country's first female leader, says goodbye to the Oval Office, Air Force One and her other presidential perks in this series finale -- but not before trying to get the Equal Rights Amendment passed. 10:30 P.M. (Comedy Central) DOG BITES MAN -- Kevin Beekin (Matt Walsh) goes undercover as a gay man to expose prejudice in America in this improv series about a fictional news team in Spokane, Wash. Turns out it's a lot harder than it sounds. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
An obituary yesterday about the composer Gyorgy Ligeti misstated the date of his composition the Horn Trio. It is from 1982, not 1980.

An article on Sunday about efforts by Senator Daniel K. Akaka, Democrat of Hawaii, to win federal recognition for his state's native people misstated the given name of his spokeswoman. She is Donalyn Dela Cruz, not Donna.

When the lease for Sundaes & Cones, Royce Chan's store in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, expired after 15 years, he packed up and moved to 95 East 10th Street in the East Village. An array of homemade ice creams in flavors as diverse as green tea, strawberry, tiramisù and chocolate sorbet are served in this industrial-looking shop. I loved the chunks of ginger in the ginger ice cream, but the litchi flavor, while properly creamy and perfumed, proved to me that this fruit does better as sorbet.

A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday included incorrect references to the theater company 13P. It produced two plays last month, not three; ''Dead City,'' playing at the 3LD & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, was not one of them. A correction on this page on Saturday misspelled the name of the company that did produce ''Dead City.'' It is New Georges, not Gorges.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed three bills yesterday that tighten regulation of city lobbyists, including a ban on gifts from lobbyists to city officials. The mayor noted that revenues to city lobbyists had more than doubled since 2000. The mayor also signed a bill to increase the number of taxicab medallions reserved for vehicles that are wheelchair-accessible or run on alternative fuels. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

To the Editor: David Brooks (''The Gender Gap at School,'' column, June 11) says that boys read less than girls for two reasons: They could be ''insensitive dolts,'' or their brain chemistry is different. There is a third reason: We raise them differently.

Gaining Some World Cup Respect Togo arrived at the World Cup amid low expectations and the chaos of having its coach quit (and return). The Togolese, waiting for the exchange of jerseys, battled South Korea but lost, 2-1. To the Editor: I suppose I shouldn't be surprised to read about grown-ups making long registry lists with the zeal of 10-year-olds writing letters to Santa (''Just Registered,'' June 7). The idea of ordering up a perfect gift list is a harmless enough daydream. Though etiquette mavens may cringe at the very idea, and many of us have at least one experience with a friend's out-of-control registry, it is time itself, not the opinions of others, that proves us fools.

The House of Representatives approved a $94.5 billion emergency spending bill on Tuesday to provide more money for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan and to finance the recovery of Gulf Coast states battered by hurricanes last year. The Senate is expected to approve the measure in the next few days, clearing the legislation for President Bush to sign.

Because of a day off on Monday, the Yankees gave Randy Johnson the option of pushing his start back a day to get his mechanics straightened out. Johnson will pitch as scheduled tonight against the Indians, but Manager Joe Torre said the decision was not made final until yesterday. After working out before the game, Johnson privately expressed doubts about making the start, which probably would have pushed Aaron Small into duty. But before leaving Yankee Stadium last night, Johnson insisted he would pitch, without elaborating on what he had been working on.

To the Editor: David Brooks blames an alleged feminist takeover of the high school curriculum in the 1970's for boys' difficulty in school. But boys have performed poorly relative to girls for as long as educational data have been collected. The 1870 United States Census shows that boys had greater access to schooling than girls but lower literacy rates; by 1924, boys were 11 percent less likely to enroll in high school and 24 percent less likely to graduate.

ARUGULA is an assertive green, and balancing its intense flavor can be tricky: it can overwhelm many foods you might combine it with. Mixing it with other greens rarely makes sense, because it makes a mockery of most of them; teaming it with tame meat or fish is almost equally futile. That's all fine with me. Using arugula as the basis for a main-course salad gives you a reason to put together plenty of really strong flavors, all playing nicely off the others. Here I assemble salt cod, capers, a lot of parsley -- which has a definite affinity for arugula -- a sharp lemony dressing and, for bulk, contrast and texture, some cooked white beans.

Great-grandmother of Stephanie, Arthur and Alex Entratter and Daniel Plain. Memorials in her memory to The American Heart Association, 208 S. LaSalle, Chicago, IL, 60604, would be appreciated. At the moment that the White House is again trying to cast them as weak on national security, Democrats are debating their stance on the war in Iraq with new intensity, with some of the party's leading figures -- including potential 2008 presidential candidates -- sharply divided over whether the United States should set a deadline for bringing troops home. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, faced boos and shouts of ''bring them home'' from an audience of liberal Democrats here on Tuesday as she argued against setting a deadline, wading into what she called a ''difficult conversation.'' Thirty minutes later, the same crowd applauded wildly as Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, the party's 2004 presidential candidate, implored the Senate to back his call for a six-month deadline for withdrawal, and said he regretted his initial support for the war.

A man who calls himself Ken Griffin’s former “friend and mentor” is suing the billionaire money manager, alleging that Mr. Griffin defrauded him and breached their partnership agreement before going on to found hedge fund giant Citadel Investment Group.

I was wondering if there was anything original to say about grown-up mean girls and good female friendship, when another local mom, seeing me reach for Wiseman's book, stepped up to recommend I read "Stressed-Out Girls," by Roni Cohen-Sandler.

In my last post. I talked about the big houses of Champagne and how for the most part they do as much as they can to exalt the fact that they are brand names and play down the idea that they are wines. But there is another side of Champagne, a side not of polished, image-conscious corporations but of grower-producers who, as in Burgundy, try to make wines - sparkling wines - that best express the characteristics of their little piece of Champagne.

The global head of equity research at HSBC is not happy. Many of the notes written by the bank's analysts amount to "worthless flashnotes," and the analysts who produce them, along with their managers, "do not deserve to be paid this year," he raged in an internal e-mail to senior managers earlier this month.

Sebastian Holdings, a fund that has been agitating for a revamp at Vivendi, said Thursday it opposed the company's plan to buy France Telecom's PagesJaunes telephone directories. The fund, which holds a small Vivendi stake whose exact size is unclear, said in a statement that such an acquisition would harm Vivendi's value.

Does the new generation of soccer intellectuals have an ethnic slant? Lizzy Ratner, writing in The New York Observer, presents an anthropological analysis of "the Soccer Jew, that intellectual, kvetchy, Granta-reading guy who also happens to possess an encyclopedic knowledge of Ronaldinho's every kick. With one foot planted firmly in the nerd camp and at least a few toes dangling in the jock sphere, he is the strange, hybrid Creature of the Moment." She adds, "Perhaps the Soccer Jew's most abiding characteristic is that he never roots for Germany."

If only the government would let them speak, hedge fund managers could convince the public that their business is not a nest of secrecy and fraud, several fund executives suggested at a Securities Industry Association conference on Wednesday, according to Reuters. Click more for Austin Kelley's live commentary on the Group A match in Hamburg.Final Thoughts When the tournament started, Ecuador wasn't given much of a chance. People said they could only win at the ridiculous altitudes of Quito, but they have impressed in their first two games, winning them by a total of 5-0. At times they resemble Argentina. They're not pushing forward all the time, but they're calm on the ball. And suddenly, they pounce. Brilliant skill from Augustin Delgado, who must be a national hero right now. The defense also played well, shutting down the lethal Wanchope.

Inter-Tel's founder and largest shareholder, Steven Mihaylo, said Thursday he has offered to buy out the company at $22.50 a share cash. Mr. Mihaylo said Vector Capital is a partner in the offer. He also said purchase price holds a 14 percent premium above the closing price of Inter-Tel's shares on March 3, and 12 percent above the June 14 closing price at $20.03.

Bear Stearns said its profits rose 81 percent in the second quarter as revenue hit a record high. The securities firm reported net income of $539 million in the three months ended May 31, up from $298 million in the same quarter of 2005. Net revenue came to $2.5 billion, up 33 percent, lifted by strong gains from its institutional equities and fixed-income business.

The Carlyle Group announced Wednesday that it had closed Carlyle Asia Growth Partners III (CAGP). The $668 million fund will continue to invest in growth capital companies across China, India, Japan and Korea.

In one of the largest research grants by an oil company, BP is planning to spend $500 million over the next 10 years to finance major work on biofuels to find "longer-term commercial alternatives to oil and gas."

Small companies going public are facing more and more obstacles in the United States, prompting venture capitalists to look to London. Some 40 companies in the United States have listed on the London Stock Exchange's Alternative Investment Market since it opened more than a decade ago, and more companies from outside Britain are listing there every year.
Shui On Land, a Chinese real estate developer, said it scrapped an initial public offering of 7.96 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1 billion) after a slump in global stock markets.

After suspending its merger plans with FPL Group due to disputes with Maryland lawmakers, the power company Constellation Energy Group said on Wednesday it would sell part of a natural gas exploration and production business in an initial public offering in an attempt to take advantage of high gas prices.

Another play about skullduggery on Wall Street, "Burleigh Grimes," has flopped, leaving some wondering why Broadway has such a hard time getting laughs out of the financial sector. Four Long Island teenagers claiming to be federal agents beat and robbed two Mexican immigrants fishing off a jetty Monday night after demanding to see their green cards, the authorities said yesterday. The assault, which the police said took place on a beach in Rocky Point, was the latest in a series of attacks on Latino immigrants in Suffolk County.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation completed a deal yesterday that would let the American Forces Network carry the remaining United States team's games in the World Cup and the event's semifinals and final.
Moazzam Begg, a former Guantánamo detainee, has emerged over the last few months as a minor celebrity.

A boardroom feud at the Tribune Company escalated as the Chandler family, Tribune's second-largest investor, called for a breakup of the company.

New York Red Bulls midfielder Peter Canero had surgery yesterday to repair a tear of the medial meniscus in his left knee. Canero is expected to be sidelined up to a month, the team said. Canero, 25, has played in seven games, starting one.

From the passenger seat of a black sports utility vehicle, Larry Brown put both arms out the window and waved them in a crisscross pattern, like a hostage signaling for help. The car never slowed, and Brown quickly disappeared — a prisoner still to his own lucrative contract, and to a Knicks franchise that does not want him.

Casey Mears was hired yesterday to drive for Hendrick Motorsports, earning a seat with one of Nascar's superteams. The move had been widely expected since last week, when Mears informed the car owner Chip Ganassi that he would not be returning in 2007 on the same day Brian Vickers asked to be released from his Hendrick contract.
The Minnesota Wild have hired a 24-year-old sportswriter as their director of hockey operations.

Steve Morabito of Switzerland won the fifth stage of the Tour de Suisse yesterday, and Ángel Vicioso of Spain took the overall lead. Morabito finished the 130.5-mile stage from La Chaux de Fondsin to Leukerbad in 5 hours, 37 minutes and 48 seconds. Jurgen van Goolen of Belgium was runner-up, 14 seconds back. Vicioso, two seconds farther back in third, took the overall lead from Nick Nuyens of Belgium.

About a third of those arrested were in California.

An Irvington woman was sentenced yesterday in State Superior Court to 40 years in prison for cutting the throats of her two young stepchildren to get back at their father. The woman, Sultana Haque, 33, left, a native of Bangladesh, pleaded guilty in April to killing Alstan Haque, 8, and his sister, Aisha, 5, while they were at an Irvington apartment complex on March 29, 2003, visiting their father. She fled to Toronto, where she was arrested.

A minivan rolled off a cliff in Bear Mountain State Park yesterday, killing a 35-year-old Staten Island woman and injuring her two daughters, the police said. The woman, Hegin Han, and her husband, Victor Han, had stopped their 2003 Honda Odyssey at a scenic point off Perkins Memorial Drive shortly after 6 p.m., the police said. While Mr. Han stepped out to take a photograph, the minivan went over the cliff, plunging 300 feet into the trees and rocks below. Hikers who heard the crash led the police to the accident. Mrs. Han, who was not wearing a seat belt, was declared dead at the scene, according to David Harrick of the New York State Park Police. The daughters, ages 3 and 5, were wearing seat belts. They were in stable condition at Nyack Hospital in Nyack.

After nearly 24 hours, the Coast Guard suspended its search yesterday afternoon for a man who fell into the water when a boat capsized off Breezy Point on Tuesday, Coast Guard officials said. The man, Jeremiah Swinton, 36, was one of four people on the boat, which capsized about 5:30 p.m. near Rockaway Inlet. The other three were rescued and treated for minor injuries, the Coast Guard said. The police said Mr. Swinton was not wearing a life jacket and did not know how to swim.

A federal appeals court has upheld a penalty against New York City for violating the Clean Water Act by adding silt to an upstate trout stream that carries part of the city's water supply. Ruling on Tuesday in a lawsuit filed by environmentalists six years ago, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit sent the case back to the trial judge to recalculate the original $5.7 million penalty, which lawyers said could be trimmed by about $500,000 after a correction in its calculation. The appeals court said that the City Department of Environmental Protection needed a special pollution permit because it added so much silt to the Esopus Creek at the eastern edge of the Catskills. Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the department, said the agency believed that it was inappropriate to apply Clean Water Act rules intended to regulate sewage and industrial waste water to the conveyance of untreated, natural drinking water.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg kicked off a three-day tour for advisers evaluating New York's bid to play host to the 2008 Democratic National Convention with a dinner reception at his home last night. Whoopi Goldberg was to join him in the effort, but the mayor said the essence of his message would be about the Republican Party, which held its 2004 convention in Manhattan.

The authorities yesterday identified a 17-year-old girl who fell to her death on Tuesday evening after she dropped her cellphone, reached for it and tumbled off a cliff. The girl, Danielle VenHorst, a junior at Secaucus High School, was sitting with her boyfriend drinking beer on a rocky slope near State Highway 139 and Bevan Street around 8 p.m. when her phone rang, said the Hudson County prosecutor, Edward J. De Fazio. Ms. VenHorst dropped the phone, and when she tried to retrieve it, she slipped and fell nearly five stories onto train tracks below. Mr. De Fazio said the cause of death was trauma consistent with a fall.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has named Paul J. Cosgrave commissioner of information technology to succeed Gino P. Menchini, who resigned in March to join a software company. A deputy commissioner, Ronald M. Bergmann, has run the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications in the interim. Mr. Cosgrave, 56, was executive vice president at Crown Consulting in Washington, where he worked on a federal program to develop a new system for tracking and managing air traffic. From 1998 to 2001, he was chief information officer at the Internal Revenue Service, and before that, he was head of the Claremont Technology Group.

A former official of Connecticut's Department of Public Works pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to two counts of making false statements to federal agents investigating whether state business was awarded fairly in the nine years that John G. Rowland was governor. The defendant, Richard F. Piotrowski, faces 4 to 10 months in prison for having misled agents three years ago about conversations he had as a member of the panel that chose Tomasso Brothers in April 1999 as the construction manager for a $57 million juvenile center in Middletown.

A former employee of the Midtown `restaurant Sparks Steak House accused it in a federal lawsuit filed yesterday of unlawfully creating a tipping pool and failing to pay its waiters the minimum wage. The former employee, Gerald Duchene, a Sparks waiter for 14 years, claims that the restaurant, on East 46th Street, deprived its waiters of more than $5 million in income over the past six years. The suit, filed in Federal District Court, said that Sparks operated a tipping pool for employees who did not serve customers, like appetizer expediters, banquet and kitchen managers, dessert station chefs and wine cellar masters. According to state and federal labor law, only those employees connected with the actual serving of the food and beverages are eligible for participation in a tip pool. A spokesman for the steakhouse said it denied all allegations.
Four rare Revolutionary War battle flags, which had been captured from Continental troops and taken to England, were sold on American soil in a Flag Day auction for $17.3 million.

A federal judge dismissed a juror in the trial of David H. Safavian, a former White House aide accused of lying about his relationship to the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, and then sent the case to the revised jury. The jury is weighing charges against Mr. Safavian, who is accused of lying to government investigators about the circumstances a 2002 golf trip to Scotland. The trial is the first to result from the influence-peddling scandal centered on Mr. Abramoff, who has pleaded guilty to conspiring to corrupt public officials.
One in three fatal asthma attacks worldwide involves a child with a mild form of the disease, and nearly half of all parents are unaware of the risk, according to a report presented in Vienna.

An explosion and fire at Universal Form Clamp, near Chicago, injured one person and sent two firefighters and four others to hospitals. The cause was unknown.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. will invest $700 million of pension-fund money in housing and real estate projects along the Gulf Coast in the next seven years, union officials said.
The Pentagon ordered three reporters at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to leave, officials and the reporters said.
It remains to be seen whether Iraq's new government will be capable of restoring security, particularly in the capital, where some areas are close to anarchy.

More than 40 African nations met in Nigeria and agreed to lift all cross-border taxes and tariffs on fertilizers needed to replenish the continent's severely degraded soils. Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, committed $10 million to a fund to finance wider use of fertilizers. Three-quarters of Africa's farmland is severely depleted of basic nutrients needed to grow crops.

The prosecution of Jennifer Williams, 54, of Bloomington for practicing medicine and midwifery without a license ended in a plea bargain. Indiana and nine other states prohibit midwifery by people other than doctors and nurses. A baby Ms. Williams delivered died last year, but Ms. Williams was not charged in the death. She pleaded guilty to a felony count of unlicensed midwifery and will receive a year's probation.

Mahlon Hector, 22, pleaded guilty to sending a live tarantula in a box to a female co-worker at a Marks & Spencer store in Leicester. At the same time, he handed his bosses there his resignation. Neither the intended recipient nor the spider was hurt. Mr. Hector, 22, is to be sentenced later on a charge of sending a threat. He did not reveal his motive in court. When workers at the store discovered the Mexican red-kneed tarantula — considered venomous but docile and commonly used in films because of its scary appearance — they alerted the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which took it away.

José Bové, the farmer who has attracted worldwide attention for his protests against globalization, said he would run in the presidential election next year, pledging to pull left-wing votes from the Socialists, the main opposition party.

A day after scientists reduced the alert level for Mount Merapi, it erupted and spewed wide trails of lava and huge clouds of searing hot gas through the night. The gas clouds, which can exceed temperatures of 540 degrees Fahrenheit, traveled more than four miles from Merapi's peak, well past the closest villages. Lava edged to within 700 feet of Kaliadem, one of the closest villages to the thundering crater. Scientists reinstated the alert to its highest level in the afternoon, just before sirens began blaring across the mountain, setting off the instant evacuation of thousands of villagers in trucks and cars and on motorbikes. Many of them had just returned home after spending weeks in nearby refugee camps. But Mbah Marijan, a 79-year-old local spiritual leader who lives just below the lava dome and who makes offerings to appease the volcano, remained at home, where lava crept to within several hundred feet of his front door.
The House voted 406 to 22 to cut the Amtrak federal subsidy by 18 percent, to $1.1 billion. The subsidy is $214 million more than President Bush requested and a House panel approved last week.
The French insurer AXA has agreed to buy the insurer Winterthur for 12.3 billion Swiss francs ($10 billion).

The government of Bosnia and Herzegovina has confirmed to the Council of Europe, the continent's main human rights watchdog, that it allowed American forces to seize six Algerian-born men in January 2002 for transfer out of the country, the council reported. The men have been detained at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, since then as enemy combatants. While the seizure and transport of the men has long been known, Bosnia is the only one of the council's 46 members to acknowledge it had breached the European Convention on Human Rights by participating in an extrajudicial seizure of individuals by United States authorities.

While some people turned their backs on her and a protest banner was unfurled during her appearance, the scene inside Alumni Stadium where she spoke did not turn tumultous, nor was she heckled while speaking.

Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for attorney general, unleashed a surprisingly early attack yesterday on Andrew M. Cuomo, the designated Democratic candidate, saying that most New Yorkers would find him unqualified to be the state's top law enforcement officer.

WINTRUB--Warren G. Formerly of Stamford, CT died at his home in Boca Raton, FL on June 13th 2006 after a valiant battle with brain cancer. He was born on December 9, 1933 in Canton OH, son of the late Hy and Mollie Wintrub. He graduated from Ohio State University and Harvard Law School, becoming an Executive Partner at Coopers and Lybrand (now Price Waterhouse Coopers) and, after his retirement, served on eight corporate boards. He also served as treasurer of Stamford's Temple Sinai, Trustee of Low Heywood School, and on the Board of Rockrimmon Country Club. In Boca Raton, he was treasurer of Bocaire Country Club. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, the former Toby Buchhalter; his children: Marcy Wintrub and Duane Barton of Franklin, MA; Charles Wintrub and Tammy Davis of Stamford, CT; and Mark Wintrub of Clearwater, FL; four grandchildren: Jay and Samuel Wintrub and Arianne and Niall Barton; his sister: Nancy Gerstman of Kirkland, WA and his sister-in-law: Barbara Schmider of Albuquerque, NM. Services will be held at Temple Beth El of Boca Raton, 333 SW 4TH Ave, Boca Raton, FL at 11:00 AM on Friday June 16th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to: Hospice By The Sea 1531 West Palmetto Park Road Boca Raton, FL 33486 (561) 395-5031 Ext 5180 Or 800-633-2577 Or Bethesda Memorial Hospital Radiation Oncology Department 2815 South Seacrest Blvd Boynton Beach, FL (561) 391-8900 Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel 800-992-9262 $(6$)WINTRUB -- Warren. The Board of Directors and members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Warren Wintrub, on Tuesday June 13, 2006. We extend condolences to all of his family. Service will be held on Friday, June 16 at 11 A.M. at Temple Beth El, 333 SW 4th Avenue, Boca Raton, FL.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about eBay's plan to add a new calling feature that would allow buyers to contact sellers through Skype, its Internet phone service, misstated an eBay sales projection in some copies. The company said that it expected Skype to generate $200 million in overall sales this year, not that the new feature by itself would bring in that amount.

An article in The Arts on Tuesday about an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society that opens tomorrow, ''Legacies: Contemporary Artists Reflect on Slavery,'' omitted a given name of an artist in the show. He is Kerry James Marshall, not James Marshall.

GOLDSTEIN--Patti. Author of the book Creature Comforts, a biography of the chief of night emergency at the Animal Medical Center in New York, publicist for CBS and NBC, and writer for numerous national publications, died Friday night, June 9, 2006 at her home in Bridgehampton, NY. She was 75. The cause was cancer, said her long time companion Sandra Powers. Patti Goldstein began her career as a publicist first for CBS television and later for NBC television where she was Manager of Magazine Publicity. In 1962, she became a partner in her own public relations agency, Addison, Goldstein & Walsh. She has written articles for New York Magazine, Esquire, Vogue, Ms. Magazine, TV Guide and Rolling Stone. She is the author of several screenplays, a novel, and in 1975 with master chef James Beard created ''The CookAlong Cassettes''. In 1986, she wrote the musical fable ''The Cat that Saved the Kingdom'' with score by the late Joe Raposo. The fable was performed at Lincoln Center with full symphony orchestra and six cats and reviewed by the New York Times. Ms. Goldstein also worked in television production. She wrote and produced a public service announcement with Gene Wilder after Gilda Radner's death in 1989 to inform the public about the warning signs of ovarian cancer. Ms. Goldstein was born in New York City on December 5, 1930. She earned her Bachelor of Arts degree from Hunter College. She is survived by Sandra Powers; her sister, Wini Arouty; two nieces, Lisa Lester and Meredith MacPhail; a nephew, Stefan Arouty; four grand-nieces and two grand-nephews. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall. Donations can be made to the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, PO Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975.

An article on Saturday about the sentencing of a Brooklyn man who tried to avoid jail by assuming the identity of a dead man with the same name misspelled the surname of the sentencing judge. He is John Gleeson, not Gleason.

The government of Bosnia and Herzegovina has confirmed to the Council of Europe, the continent's main human rights watchdog, that it allowed American forces to seize six Algerian-born men in January 2002 for transfer out of the country, the council reported. The men have been detained at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, since then as enemy combatants. While the seizure and transport of the men has long been known, Bosnia is the only one of the council's 46 members to acknowledge it had breached the European Convention on Human Rights by participating in an extrajudicial seizure of individuals by United States authorities. CRAIG S. SMITH (NYT)

MORRIS--Craig. It is with profound sadness that the Trustees, President, curators and entire staff of the American Museum of Natural History mourn the unexpected death of Dr. Craig Morris, Curator in the Division of Anthropology and longtime Dean of Science at the Museum. The loss to the Museum, to the scientific community, and to so many of his colleagues is indescribable. Dr. Morris was a world-renowned scholar of the highest order whose contributions in anthropology and archaeology earned him membership in the National Academy of Sciences. He was an extraordinary leader of the Museum and an exceptionally wise colleague-a pillar of the Museum community. A brilliant scholar, always a gentleman, and a dear friend to many of us. He will be sorely missed. The funeral will be held at the JH Churchill Funeral Home in Dr. Morris' hometown, Murray, Kentucky, and a Memorial will be held at the Museum at a future date. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

Credits were reversed for two pictures in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about an experiment that produced nearly round salt crystals. The picture of normal salt crystals, which are cube-shaped, was by Dr. Jeremy Burgess, via Photo Researchers Inc. The picture of experimental crystals came from the Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute in India, via the American Chemical Society.

The On Education column yesterday, about immigrant students in Brooklyn who put on a production of ''The Wizard of Oz,'' misidentified a Hollywood actress when noting that a student who did not want to sing her solo in rehearsal appeared as if she just wanted to be alone. The comparison was to Greta Garbo, not Marlene Dietrich.

ABRAMS--Morris H. age 88, June 14, 2006. Beloved husband of Lillian, father of Naomi Rosenberg and Daniel Abrams, grandfather of Joshua Rosenberg. Services 1 PM, June 15, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Burial at Cedar Park Cemetery.

The old stereotype that British people, if they see a line forming, will immediately stand in it, has been getting some fresh reinforcement at the British Museum here where a blockbuster exhibition has been created around some relatively small works. The hubbub should be no surprise given that the artworks in question, however diminutive in scale, are by Michelangelo (1475-1564), an artist whose last solo engagement at this museum was some 30 years ago. Since "Michelangelo Drawings: Closer to the Master" opened in March, such has been the public enthusiasm that the British Museum has announced that it will keep the galleries open until 10 every night in the show's final week, June 18 through 25. Taking things another step or rather two hours further, on Saturday nights this month the exhibition remains open until midnight, taking the august institution into the city's lively nightlife realm for the first time.
HANLEY--Katherine M. June 15, 1994. Mom, the depth of our loss is matched only by the depth of our love. Ed, Kathy, Charlie, and Tim

An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 25 about advances in sound quality for music players and home stereos incorrectly described the recording technique for compact discs. CD's offer lesser sound quality than DVD's because CD's are recorded at a lower bit rate, not because the data is compressed.

Katsuya, a Japanese restaurant, will open on June 26 in the Brentwood area of Los Angeles, a project of the designer Philippe Starck, above on left, and the SBE Restaurant Group. It will be the first in a series of restaurants and hotels the restaurant group plans to build with Mr. Starck, said the restaurant group's chief executive, Sam Nazarian, above on right. Named for its chef, Katsuya Uechi, the restaurant has hemlock walls and ceilings and a shape suggesting a bento box.

Urbanites can trade in their ho-hum hibachis for a small European import that uses canned fuel. The Alain Delon barbecue, by a Finnish designer, Klaus Aalto (no relation to Alvar), measures a city-friendly 7 inches wide, 7 inches long and just 8.5 inches tall. It is powder-coated steel with a stainless grill rack and wood handle. A dial adjusts the flame. Mr. Aalto keeps one in his car, so he can pull over to make stovetop espresso; $360 at the Future Perfect, 115 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn; (718) 599-6278.

Your patio chaise can now feel more like your favorite armchair. Simply cover it with a waterproof acrylic from the Great Outdoors line by Holly Hunt. The fabrics have a soft hand (no more sticky vinyl weaves) and come in subtle earthy colors and in textures like chenille, making them appropriate for indoor use as well. Sun and sand patterns include Big Sur, Coastline and Portofino. The fabrics resist fading and mildew; $54 to $62 a yard (54 inches wide) at Holly Hunt, 150 East 58th Street, (212) 891-2500.
