AUGERI--Joseph. A legend in the cosmetics industry, Joe passed away peacefully on the morning of Sunday, June 11. Credited with turning Lancome into a household name, Joe was well respected not only for his business acumen, but also for his sociable disposition. The son of Italian immigrant parents, Joe grew up in Brooklyn with his sister, Anne. During World War II, Joe served in the Army. When the war drew to a close, Joe decided to attend Rollins College and graduated in 1953. Armed with a degree, it took Joe a mere one week to get a job at Revlon as a sales trainee, and over the course of the next 17 years Joe worked his way up to become Vice President of Sales. Later, Joe would join L'Oreal USA. Joe assumed control of a little known division named Lancome and, within 10 years, Joe turned Lancome into a well-known brand. On the heels of such a turnaround, L'Oreal was anxious to see what else Augeri could accomplish. By 1984, Joe had become a Senior Vice President, overseeing Lancome, Ralph Lauren, Biotherm, and Cosmair's European fragrance division. In his later years at L'Oreal he worked with the international divisions to further develop their business. For his enduring contributions to the industry, Augeri was presented with the coveted Beauty Fashion Medal of Honor Award in 1990. Having achieved a great deal of success in his career, Joe retired to Palm Beach, Florida in 1993. Joe married his longtime love, Ann Fox, on May 3, 1996. They were seldom without friends and family. Joe's joie de vivre warmed the hearts of those around him. With a mischievous glint in his eye, Joe lived and loved life to the fullest. He is survived by his wife Ann, sister Anne Detroyer, and many nieces and nephews. The funeral service for Joe will be held Friday at 12:30 PM the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 306 East Ridgewood Avenue, Ridgewood, New Jersey. (www.vanemburgh.com). Donations to Hospice of Palm Beach, 5200 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL., 33407, would be appreciated.

An article in Science Times on June 6 on a conversation with Elizabeth Bennett, a zoologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society who campaigns against hunting endangered and threatened animals for human consumption, misstated the name of the organization that gave her the Leila Hadley Luce Award for Courage. It is Wings WorldQuest, not Wingsquest.

There will soon be one more reason to visit the outlet stores in Secaucus, N.J. On Tuesday Design Within Reach will open its first outlet there, the DWR Annex, a 22,000-square-foot warehouse filled with its modern furniture. Overstocked items in perfect condition will be 10 percent off; pieces with minor damage will be 20 percent off; deep surface dings will bring a 40-percent discount; and anything with structural damage will be 60 percent off. A Mirra task chair in perfect condition, above left, would be $674, down from $749, and a Globus side chair, above right, would be $196, down from $218. The selection will vary. For directions to the DWR Annex, 55 Hartz Way: (201) 325-8411. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

TRIBUNE SHOWDOWN A boardroom feud at the Tribune Company escalated as the Chandler family -- the billionaire former owners of the Los Angeles Times and now large Tribune investors -- called for a breakup of the company. [Page C1.] AIRBUS DELAY HURTS STOCK Shares in European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent company of Airbus, fell sharply after another delay in the delivery of the new double-decker A380 airplane. In the short term, the latest fumble casts a cloud over the future of Noël Forgeard, above, a co-chief executive of EADS. Over the longer term, analysts said Airbus's troubles would probably give a lift to its rival Boeing. [C3.] QUESTIONS FOR GRASSO Richard A. Grasso, the former chief of the New York Stock Exchange, faced questions from federal regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the American International Group's share price while he was head of the exchange and its regulatory unit, government documents revealed. [C1.] HURDLES TO EURONEXT DEAL A trans-Atlantic deal that looked like a strategic coup for the newly public NYSE Group -- its proposed acquisition of the pan-European stock exchange Euronext -- appears to be running into a quagmire. [C1.] NEW INFLATION ATTITUDE When the government reported that a measure of consumer prices edged up 0.3 percent in May and was up 2.4 percent from 12 months earlier, analysts greeted the numbers as uniformly bad. That is a far cry from how such data would have been viewed 25 years ago. [A1.] FED REPORTS SLOWER GROWTH Economic growth in the last month and a half was generally strong across the country but showed ''some signs of deceleration,'' the Federal Reserve said in a report. At the same time, prices in most regions rose, according to the report, known as the Beige Book. [C3.] STOCKS REBOUND The Dow Jones industrial average rose 110.78 points, or 1.03 percent, to 10,816.92. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.35 points, to 1,230.04, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 13.53 points, to 2,086. [C6.] JAPAN AND TRADING SCANDAL Revelations that the Japanese central bank governor invested in a fund implicated in an insider-trading scandal has led to criticism of the bank and of one of the country's most respected economic leaders. [C5.] BAYER TO ACQUIRE SCHERING The health care giant Bayer clinched its bid for Schering as a rival bidder, Merck of Germany, backed off, agreeing to sell its stake to Bayer in return for a possible joint venture with the combined company. [C5.] DELL STRATEGY Kevin B. Rollins, the chief executive of Dell, is pushing his company, which is growing more slowly than the rest of the PC industry, to act quickly and aggressively to fix its problems lest they grow bigger. [C1.] NEW HEWLETT SERVERS Hewlett-Packard announced a line of servers that it said would play a major role in its vision of next-generation data centers that operate with less energy and almost no people. [C4.] AOL CHANGE AOL is turning Netscape.com into a collection of links to news articles submitted by users and expanded upon by a staff of bloggers. AOL, owned by Time Warner, has been moving away from its rapidly declining Internet access business by building a series of advertising-supported Web sites. [C3.] U.A.W. LEADER RE-ELECTED Members of the United Automobile Workers union elected Ron Gettelfinger to a second term as president. [C13.] COSMETIC RISK VS. REWARD More people are having liposuction to remove fat from their ankles, knees, chins, necks, backs and upper arms, raising questions about the increasing risks cosmetic doctors and patients are willing to take in the name of perfection. [G1.] AEGIS REJECTS PROPOSAL Shareholder of the London-based advertising company Aegis overwhelmingly rejected a proposal by Vincent Bolloré, who owns a 29 percent stake in the company, to name two representatives to its board. [C4.] ONLINE ONLINE JOB SEARCH The online persona of some jobseekers has undermined their résumé. Companies are looking up job applicants on social networking sites like MySpace. A report is at nytimes.com/business. SLIDE SHOW A look at five properties for sale in the New York region can be found at nytimes.com/realestate. STOLEN LIVES The ranks of identity theft victims are large. Just how large may depend on the definition. A special report is at nytimes.com/national/nationalspecial2. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. AMERICAN MEDIA, publisher of the Star gossip magazine, said it would explore the sale of five publications. The Axe Table reflects a role reversal, said the designer, Michael Andrulewich. It is ''constructed from the harvesting tool rather than the material sought,'' he wrote in an e-mail message. Hickory ax legs attached to a birch plywood frame with a thin stainless steel top form the lightweight piece, which measures 47 inches long by 30 inches wide and 29 inches tall. Mr. Andrulewich wrote that the table is ''a bittersweet reminder that a luxurious solid wood piece of furniture was once beautiful in nature.'' He said he plans to make a side table and a low bench using hatchet handles. The table is $1,900; www.anthracite.cc or (646) 591-1167.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Bush Making Push at Home And Abroad for Iraq Efforts Seeking political momentum from his surprise trip to Baghdad, President Bush warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counterterrorism efforts, and promised to send American diplomats to press countries to make good on $13 billion in pledges toward rebuilding Iraq. A1 On the first day of the new government's security regime in Baghdad, soldiers and police officers took up positions, while Iraqis went about their business, wondering what, if anything, would be different. A13 Afghans' Release Sought An Afghan government delegation to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, said about half of the 94 Afghans being held there were not guilty of serious crimes and should be released. A12 After the three suicides at Guantánamo, the respectful reception for a former detainee, Moazzam Begg -- whom the Pentagon still portrays as a terrorist -- is one of many markers of the waning credibility of Washington's detention policies. A1 Palestinians Protest Back Pay Palestinian civil servants stormed the parliament building in the West Bank demanding back pay, in the second violent protest this week at parliament, underscoring growing pressure on the Hamas government on several fronts. A10 Offer to Iran Omitted Penalties When a formal incentives package by the six powers to encourage Iran to curb its nuclear program was presented in writing in Tehran, it omitted a long list of potential punishments should Iran reject it, according to senior officials familiar with the package. A3 NATIONAL A14-21 Officials Seeking Source Of Lethal Heroin Mixture Police and health authorities are struggling to track down the source of a doctored, intensely powerful heroin that has killed many in and around Chicago and Detroit and sent hundreds more to hospitals in cities from St. Louis to Philadelphia. A14 Wealthier to Displace the Poor Federal housing officials said over 5,000 public housing apartments for the poor are to be demolished in New Orleans and replaced by developments for residents with a wider range of incomes. A16 Rove Decision Relieves Bush President Bush said he ''took a sigh of relief'' when federal prosecutors decided this week not to indict Karl Rove, his top political adviser, in the C.I.A. leak case. Mr. Bush voiced full support for Mr. Rove, but otherwise declined to go into the details of the investigation. A19 SCIENCE/HEALTH Genetics to Explain Behavior Studies that suggest a connection between DNA makeup and certain behaviors are causing many people to blame genetics for their shortcomings. Genes seem to influence whether a person is fat, for example, has a gift for dance or may become addicted to cigarettes. A1 Bush Plans National Monument President Bush will create the world's largest protected marine area, designating as a national monument a 1,200-mile chain of small Hawaiian islands and surrounding waters and reefs that are home to a spectacular array of sea life, senior administration officials said last night. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Rampage Followed Attack In Subway, Police Say A man suspected of stabbing a tourist from Texas on a downtown C train then went on a 13-hour rampage through Manhattan, the police said, plunging a knife into three more people and terrorizing workers at a late-night grocery store. He was arrested after a doorman and cabbies who had seen one of the attacks called 911 on their cellphones as they followed him. A1 Ruling on 9/11 Detentions A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that the government has wide latitude under immigration law to detain noncitizens on the basis of religion, race or national origin, and to hold them indefinitely without explanation. But the judge allowed the class-action lawsuit that prompted the ruling -- filed by Muslim immigrants detained after 9/11 -- to continue on other claims. B1 Crime Rises, but Not in City Violent crime rose last year in cities and even in some quiet suburbs in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut region, according to preliminary statistics released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The increases were such that New York City, which saw decreases in violent crime and murders, appeared to be an oasis of relative calm. B1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-8 1st Woman Joins Bowling Tour Kelly Kulick, a 29-year-old from Union, N.J., who works part time in her father's auto body shop in neighboring Elizabeth, became the first woman to qualify for a season-long exemption on the Professional Bowlers Association Tour, a 20-event circuit that begins in October. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-15 Inflation Worries Analysts When the government reported that the core measure of consumer prices edged up 0.3 percent in May and was up 2.4 percent from 12 months earlier, analysts greeted the numbers as uniformly bad -- a far cry from how such news would have been viewed in decades past. A1 Tribune Breakup Urged A boardroom feud at the Tribune Company escalated as the Chandler family, one of the largest shareholders, called for a breakup of the company, the latest sign of the growing pressure on newspapers. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: A leap of faith, off a cliff; running Hoover's railroad; the journalist as scapegoat; Donald Hall, poet laureate. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E6 Crossword E2 Obituaries C16 TV Listings E12 Weather A20

The Minnesota Wild have hired a 24-year-old sportswriter as their director of hockey operations. Chris Snow, who covered the Wild for one season for The Minneapolis Star Tribune and currently covers the Red Sox for The Boston Globe, will join the team near the end of the summer. The Globe is owned by The New York Times Company. According to the Wild, Snow's duties will include contract and arbitration research, statistical analyses of amateur and pro players, and monitoring other N.H.L. rosters. He will not make personnel decisions. Other than occasional pickup games on a frozen lake, Snow -- a native of Melrose, Mass., and a Syracuse University graduate -- never played hockey. His father, Bob, had Boston Bruins season tickets, and Snow's love of the game grew from rooting for players like Cam Neely. PAT BORZI (NYT)

WYNKOOP--Nancy. February 24, 1925, died June 7, 2006 in Woodstock, VT. She was born Nancy Helen Marie Leeds in New York City on February 24, 1925, the daughter of William Batemen Leeds, Jr. and Princess Xenia Georgievna of Russia. Through her mother, she was a member of the Romanov dynasty and direct descendent of Catherine the Great. Nancy's maternal grandfather, Grand Duke George Mikhailovitch, was shot by the Bolsheviks in St. Petersburg in the Russian Revolution. Nancy was proud and dutiful of this heritage, but relished also the roughand-tumble adventures of her American ancestors, who included the senior William B. Leeds, the Tin Plate King. She was raised on Long Island, where she attended the Green Vale School. She was a graduate of the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT and Sarah Lawrence College. In December 1945 she married Edward Judson Wynkoop, Jr., of Syracuse, NY. The Wynkoops lived for 21 years in Darien, CT before moving to Woodstock in 1969, where Nancy belonged to the New Century Club and was president of the Vermont chapter of the Colonial Dames of America. She is survived by her husband, Edward J. Wynkoop of Woodstock, and their daughter, Alexandra, of South Burlington, Vermont. Most of the Wynkoop-Romanov collection, including rare objects of Faberge, was endowed to Middlebury College toward the end of Nancys life. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock on Saturday, June 24, at 1:00 pm. Memorial donations may be made to the Lucy MacKenzie Humane Society, PO Box 343, Woodstock, VT 05091.

A day after scientists reduced the alert level for Mount Merapi, it erupted and spewed wide trails of lava and huge clouds of searing hot gas through the night. The gas clouds, which can exceed temperatures of 540 degrees Fahrenheit, traveled more than four miles from Merapi's peak, well past the closest villages. Lava edged to within 700 feet of Kaliadem, one of the closest villages to the thundering crater. Scientists reinstated the alert to its highest level in the afternoon, just before sirens began blaring across the mountain, setting off the instant evacuation of thousands of villagers in trucks and cars and on motorbikes. Many of them had just returned home after spending weeks in nearby refugee camps. But Mbah Marijan, a 79-year-old local spiritual leader who lives just below the lava dome and who makes offerings to appease the volcano, remained at home, where lava crept to within several hundred feet of his front door. PETER GELLING (NYT)

A French court on Wednesday sentenced 25 people convicted of plotting terrorist attacks on the French capital in 2002 to prison terms ranging from 6 months to 10 years. Prosecutors had charged them with planning attacks on several sites, including the Eiffel Tower. One of the convicts, Menad Benchellali, 32, was accused of trying to concoct chemical or biological weapons at his mother's apartment in a suburb of Lyon.

An article on Sunday about commencement speeches around the country referred imprecisely to audience reaction to a speech by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice at Boston College. While some people turned their backs on her and a protest banner was unfurled during her appearance, the scene inside Alumni Stadium where she spoke did not turn tumultuous, nor was she heckled while speaking.

GOTTLIEB--Lester, on June 7, 2006 at the age of 92. Loving husband of Ruth, patient father of Pamela, Michael, and Gabrielle. Grandfather of Audrey, Joshua, and Alexandra. Great grandfather of Kaitlynn and Josh. He was a bringer of light, music, and humor to the world. He sang with a clear, ringing, joyful, tenor voice until the end of his life. He will be terribly missed by all who knew him.

More than 40 African nations met in Nigeria and agreed to lift all cross-border taxes and tariffs on fertilizers needed to replenish the continent's severely degraded soils. Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, committed $10 million to a fund to finance wider use of fertilizers. Three-quarters of Africa's farmland is severely depleted of basic nutrients needed to grow crops. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has named Paul J. Cosgrave commissioner of information technology to succeed Gino P. Menchini, who resigned in March to join a software company. A deputy commissioner, Ronald M. Bergmann, has run the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications in the interim. Mr. Cosgrave, 56, was executive vice president at Crown Consulting in Washington, where he worked on a federal program to develop a new system for tracking and managing air traffic. From 1998 to 2001, he was chief information officer at the Internal Revenue Service, and before that, he was head of the Claremont Technology Group. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg kicked off a three-day tour for advisers evaluating New York's bid to play host to the 2008 Democratic National Convention with a dinner reception at his home last night. Whoopi Goldberg was to join him in the effort, but the mayor said the essence of his message would be about the Republican Party, which held its 2004 convention in Manhattan. ''I think everybody agrees that the convention that the Republicans had in New York gave them an enormous lift, and it was good for their candidate, and that's my main message to the Democrats,'' he said. DIANE CARDWELL (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''Too Soon to Cheer in Baghdad'' (editorial, June 14):

WEISSMAN--Blanche (Nee Talansky). Died Thursday June 8th, 2006. Beloved wife of Robert for 581/2 years. She leaves two children: Linda and Mark. Grandsons: Dov, Elaad and Jeremy, Corey. Donations to Hospice Care Network. Information: Sinai Chapels 718-445-0300.

(Nancy), Timmi Vesci (Jim), and the late Maureen J. and Susan H. Grandfather of Jim (Julie), Kevin, Tim, and Monica Vesci, and Mickey Sala, Greatgrandfather of Olivia and Aidan Vesci. ''When you get four and a half million people a day into the system, every once in a while a really bizarre thing can happen.'' RAYMOND W. KELLY, New York City's police commissioner, on stabbing attacks in the subway. [B6]

The goths narrowly surged past the country girls on this week's Billboard album chart. The band AFI, whose music lies somewhere between goth-rock, emo and punk, reached No. 1 for the first time, with sales of 182,000 copies of ''Decemberunderground'' (Interscope), according to Nielsen SoundScan. It pushed the Dixie Chicks' ''Taking the Long Way'' (Columbia), with 175,000, to No. 2 after a two-week reign at the top. The Atlanta rapper Yung Joc reached No. 3 with ''New Joc City'' (Bad Boy/Atlantic), and Ice Cube's new ''Laugh Now, Cry Later,'' on his own Lench Mob Records, opened at No. 4. The soundtrack to the new animated movie ''Cars'' (Walt Disney), with songs by Rascal Flatts, John Mayer and Sheryl Crow, opened at No. 7. BEN SISARIO
To the Editor: Re ''Bush Makes Surprise Visit to Iraq to Press Leadership'' (front page, June 14):

LESSER--Saal D. (1924 - 2006). Died at peace of Alzheimer 's Disease on June 13, 2006. He was ever the adoring husband of Deborah (Silverman), doting father of Marc and Elizabeth Lesser, Robin and Chris Cordima, and Nina and Todd Insler and proud grandfather of Danielle, Madeleine, Matthew, Gabriel and Ethan. He served as Director of the Encampment for Citizenship, District Director of the Office of Economic Opportunity under Sargent Shriver and as the Executive Director the N.Y. State Division of Human Rights. Through his consulting firms , Saal Lesser Associates and EEO Compliance Services, he was a respected advisor and tireless champion of equal rights. He served as President of the YM-YWHA of Southern Westchester and as Civil Service Commissioner of the City of Mount Vernon. He was an honored athlete and a true friend. Contributions in his memory would be appreciated by The Southern Poverty Law Center or by Jansen Hospice, Tuckahoe, N.Y. His family and friends will gather to remember him on Sunday, June 18, 2006 at noon at Riverside Chapel 21W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, N. Y.

8 P.M. (13) LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER: ''THE LIGHT IN THE PIAZZA -- '' Live from the Vivian Beaumont Theater comes this winner of six 2005 Tony awards, with a book by Craig Lucas and music and lyrics by Adam Guettel. The production, running since April 18, 2005, is scheduled to close on July 2, so better catch it now. Is fate or coincidence at play when a gust of wind takes a young woman's hat, which lands at the feet of a handsome Florentine stranger? Katie Clarke and Aaron Lazar, (above)are the lovers. 9 P.M. (BBC America) WATERLOO ROAD -- This new series from the makers of ''Footballers Wive$'' is about the surprisingly tumultuous lives of teachers. The staff of a failing inner-city school is under pressure to improve but must leap some professional and personal hurdles. Some argue ideology, while the English teacher (David Crellin) falls for his fiancé's best friend, who is, appropriately, the drama teacher. 9 P.M. (MTV) MAKING THE BAND 3 -- Sean Combs previously chose the five women to make up his hot new pop group and this season kicks off with Aubrey, Aundrea, Wanita, Dawn and Shannon getting ready to record their first album and go on tour. Like any reality show worth it's salt, this one also makes them live together while we watch them try to get along. 9 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC -- Britney Spears answers her critics. With one baby at home and another on the way, she wants to clear up your misconceptions about her maternal skills and her marriage. Matt Lauer, (right, with Ms. Spears) interviewed his subject at her home, where she appeals to the paparazzi to back off and describes married life with Kevin Federline as ''awesome.'' Despite what you may have heard, the hubby is apparently not living in the basement. 10 P.M. (NBC) WINDFALL -- The second episode of this new drama continues to prove all is not fun and games when you suddenly come into a huge pile of cash. Beth (Sarah Wynter) and Nina (Lana Parrilla) fly to Paris for a weekend shopping spree that is sure to be a bit tense, considering Nina still carries a torch for Beth's hubby. Meanwhile Zoe (Sarah Jane Morris) is smitten and growing closer to Sean (DJ Cotorona) despite his creepy past. 10 P.M. (MTV) PIMP MY RIDE -- The rapper and car lover Xzibit, (left) is back for another season of making over some of the worst eyesores on the road. STEVEN McELROY

Friends may call Wednesday, 7-9 and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. The Sunshine Group mourns the loss of a dearly loved and highly respected member of our family, Judith A. Banham. An esteemed colleague, she will be remembered for her optimism, wit, intelligence and kindness. She touched each of us, as our mentor, friend, and trusted advisor. The return of ''The Closer,'' with Kyra Sedgwick, below, as a Southern-fried detective, set a ratings record for advertiser-supported cable. Monday's premiere of Season 2 brought TNT 8.3 million viewers, the largest cable audience for a scripted series. An audience of 5.1 million stuck around to watch the series debut of ''Saved.'' Elsewhere on cable, the beginning of Season 3 of USA Network's ''4400'' drew 4.2 million viewers on Sunday. The Miami Heat's comeback win against the Dallas Mavericks delivered a ratings victory for ABC on Tuesday. Nielsen's estimates for the live broadcast were preliminary, but they indicated that ABC was No. 1 among total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic. NBC placed second in both categories. At 9 p.m., ''Last Comic Standing,'' in which the final group of comics was picked to live together, drew 9 million viewers and was the top entertainment program of the night among adults 18 to 49. A ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' repeat followed the comedy show, bringing in 9.7 million viewers. Between ''Law & Order'' on NBC and the N.B.A. on ABC, CBS's debut of ''Tuesday Night Book Club'' was practically invisible. The reality soap attracted an audience of 5.1 million. KATE AURTHUR

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Kenneth R. Thomson, the Canadian publishing magnate, referred incorrectly to one of his surviving children. Taylor is his daughter, not a son.

Challenging Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for her seat is apparently not enough for John Spencer: He is going to war against his fellow Republicans, too. Mr. Spencer, a Vietnam combat veteran who relishes tough talk, plans to begin broadcasting a radio advertisement today that accuses unidentified ''national Republicans'' of not helping him and urges voters to donate to him instead of other Republican causes.

YORK--Rose E., 92, of New York, on June 14, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Manny and mother of Alen, Judd and Jesse. Loving grandmother of Kevin, Gregory, Jay, Barri and Elizabeth. Known and admired throughout the home fashions industry as an innovator and pioneer. She was one of the industry's first top female executives. Her companies, Countess York and Rose York Associates, popularized the use of comforters and introduced fully coordinated bedroom fashions. She served as the first woman president of the Feather and Down Association and served on Governor Rockefeller's Upholstery and Bedding Advisory Board. She was a board member of the Hebrew Institute of Long Island. She was named a Legend of the Industry by the National Bed, Bath and Linens Association, and a Dean of the Industry by the Home Fashions Products Association. Her love, warmth and energy will be missed. Services at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY on Friday June 16 at 12:30pm.
To the Editor: The Sept. 11 attacks left our nation shocked, confused, angry and hurt. But for those who lost family that day, the pain was far greater.

NOW that kitchens are showrooms for entertaining friends, family and cable-TV-fed fantasies of personal fulfillment, high-style product choices are proliferating. Cabinets are being made of polyester, resin and bamboo. Countertops can be cut from jewel-tone acrylic, and the once-ordinary backsplash is a canvas for color and texture. The latest designs may eventually trickle down to big box stores, but for those who are obsessed with being first -- and who can afford to indulge that obsession -- here are new ways to accessorize restaurant-grade appliances. It's Not a Sink, It's a Statement IN a survey done for Electrolux, nearly a fifth of respondents said they spent at least five hours a day in the kitchen. No small amount of that time is spent at the sink, so it makes sense that designers are treating this once taken-for-granted component seriously.
To the Editor: ''When Drug Firms Pay Off Competitors'' (editorial, June 8) hits the nail squarely on the head.

Because of an editing error, a Political Memo article on Sunday, about failed political efforts to improve upstate New York's economy, referred incorrectly to an accomplishment by a Democrat, the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, that helped his two Democratic successors make inroads with upstate voters, including Republicans. He was able to convince them that New York City and its suburbs were already sending more money to Albany than they received, not that the city and its suburbs should start doing so.

McKINLEY--Selma Anderson. 15 June 1982. Dearest Momma, you are always with me
To the Editor: I read ''A Ring Tone Meant to Fall on Deaf Ears'' (front page, June 12) with my 38-year-old eyes.

Committee Votes to Cut Public Broadcasting Funds The House Appropriations Committee voted to reduce funds for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and refused to allocate any money to it for 2009, Reuters reported. The committee is giving $400 million to the corporation for fiscal 2007, but also voted on Tuesday to eliminate spending for its conversion to digital television and for Ready to Learn grants, which contribute to some children's shows. The corporation said the public broadcasting budget had been reduced by 17.4 percent by the committee vote. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting is at the center of debates about perceived liberal bias and conservative efforts to influence its activities. The question of financing will go next to the House floor and then to the Senate, which is traditionally more hospitable. A Beach Boys Reunion? A hint of a possible reunion of the Beach Boys, above, emerged in Hollywood on Tuesday when the three surviving founders of the band made their first public appearance together in 10 years, Reuters reported. Asked about the possibility of performing again, Brian Wilson said, ''There's a chance of that.'' He, Mike Love and Al Jardine were on the top of the Capitol Records office tower for the presentation of double-platinum plaques commemorating United States sales of more than two million copies of the band's 2003 collection, ''Sounds of Summer: The Very Best of the Beach Boys.'' With them were Bruce Johnston, who joined the touring lineup in 1965, and David Marks, who filled in for Mr. Jardine briefly in the early 1960's. Ringtones Go Gold And Platinum The Recording Industry Association of America expanded its gold and platinum designations yesterday to include sales of ringtones. In an announcement, the organization said it was ushering in the Master Ringtone Sales Award, an update of its 47-year-old gold and platinum program, ''to recognize the growing popularity of enjoying music through cellular phones.'' The association defines an eligible ringtone as an original recording, rather than a synthesized instrumental version, of a hit song. Tracks will be certified gold (500,000 downloads), platinum (one million downloads) and multiplatinum (starting at two million and following in increments of one million). The first awards, plaques decorated with a cellphone motif, consisted of 84 gold, 40 platinum and 4 multiplatinum certifications. The multiplatinum winners were T-Pain's ''I'm N Luv (Wit a Stripper)'' (Jive), D4L's ''Laffy Taffy'' (Atlantic), Black Eyed Peas' ''My Humps'' (A & M) and Chamillionaire's ''Ridin' '' (Universal). Among winning artists in other categories were Beyoncé, Mary J. Blige, 50 Cent, Kanye West, Green Day, the Beastie Boys and Eminem. Footnotes Neil Simon, below, was named to receive the annual Kennedy Center Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. In a statement, the center said, ''For more than four decades, his plays have invigorated the stage with poignant stories and zany characters,'' adding, ''Perhaps his greatest contribution has been his extraordinary ability to create humor from the good things and bad in the lives of everyday people.'' The Royal Shakespeare Company announced plans yesterday to transform its home in Stratford-on-Avon, England. The centerpiece of the $185 million project is a new main stage to replace its 1932 auditorium, ''which owes more to cinema than theater design and separates the audience from the actors,'' an announcement said. Scheduled for completion in 2010, the new theater, ''a modern take on the courtyard theaters of Shakespeare's day,'' will seat slightly more than 1,000 people and reduce the distance between audience and actors to 15 yards from 30 yards. Catherine Deneuve is to be chairwoman of the jury at this year's Venice International Film Festival, Reuters reported. The festival will run from Aug. 30 through Sept. 9. Jerry Lewis had a heart attack on Sunday and ''is under hospital care and is expected to make a full recovery,'' said Candi Cazau, a spokeswoman for the Orleans Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas. She called the heart attack mild and said Mr. Lewis, 80, was also suffering from pneumonia and had been forced to cancel a July engagement, The Associated Press reported. Jazz at Lincoln Center's resident big band, the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra With Wynton Marsalis, has a new name. Henceforth it will be the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra With Wynton Marsalis.

The police in northern England said they had arrested a 21-year-old man and a 16-year-old on charges of conspiracy to murder and of conspiring to ''cause a public nuisance by use of poisons and or explosives.'' Both are to appear in court today. The arrests took place last week at Manchester Airport and in Dewsbury, Yorkshire. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

Cory Booker finally has what he wants. He will take over for Mayor Sharpe James on July 1 with a landslide victory behind him and -- thanks to Tuesday's runoff -- unanimous support on the Municipal Council. Now comes the hard part: fulfilling his promise to make Newark a national model of urban reform without alienating residents who may resist change.

AMBITION comes in all sorts of guises. But they are rarely more quirky or varied than among those aspiring to a modeling or acting career. Portfolios in hand, dozens of hopefuls clustered last week outside a Champs Sports store in Harlem, at a casting call for ''Yo Momma,'' with Wilmer Valderrama, on MTV. Over the weekend, hundreds of others lined up to try their luck at an open call by the International Talent Conference, a convention of agents and scouts held at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Flashing head shots and showy accessories, the aspiring actors/models/whatevers seemed to think that getting attention is largely a matter of packaging. ''I'm here to pursue my dream of becoming a hip-hop artist, or maybe I'd like to be a model like Tyson,'' said Lee Wilson, 21 (at right in photo above), who arrived at Champs in a scarlet tracksuit with a Kangol hat to match.

''My name is Peter Parker, and I've been Spider-Man since I was 15 years old.'' This is just part of the speech the web-spinning superhero delivers in the second issue of Civil War, a mini-series from Marvel Comics. Normally, nothing comes between a superhero and his secret identity. But in this case, Spider-Man, right, wants to make a point: that he will support the government's Superhuman Registration Act in the hope of once again gaining public trust for heroes. The act was passed after the reckless behavior of a group of glory-seeking young heroes caused hundreds of civilian casualties. Spider-Man's revelation is ''not a dream sequence,'' said Joe Quesada, Marvel's editor in chief. He described ''Civil War'' as a ''story-driven event'' that would affect the heroes for years to come. The immediate follow-up to Spider-Man's revealing his identity will come in Amazing Spider-Man No. 533 and Civil War: Front Line No. 2, both on sale June 28. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

CUNNINGHAM--Robert Joseph. Family friends , and his beloved team-mates mourn Bob's passing, June 13, at Memorial Hospital in Savannh, GA. A resident of Hilton Head Island, SC, Bob leaves his wife June, son Rob, daughters Margaret and Ellen, and six grandchildren. A graduate of All Hallows HS, Bronx, NY, he was recently inducted into their Hall of Fame. His athletic prowess at All Hallows led to a scholarship to the University of NC, under the guidance of well known Basketball coach, Frank McGuire. Bob Cunningham was a key member of the 1957 NCAA Basketball Championship Team that became known as the ''Subway Five''. The 1957 UNC team was undefeated with a 32-0 record that included a triple overtime victory against Michigan State, in the semifinals. Followed the next night by a triple overtime win, over Kansas University, then led by future ''Hall of Famer'' Wilt Chamberlain. Many sports journalists view that game as among the most exciting ever played. Bob remained close to his team-mates over the years, and enjoyed their company at annual gatherings. His many achievements in the business community include positions at IBM, Sensormatic, and his own trucking business. He leaves behind a legion of friends who share his memory. Services Saturday, 11 AM, Holy Family Catholic Church, 24 Pope Ave., Hilton Head, SC.

From the passenger seat of a black sport utility vehicle, Larry Brown put both arms out the window and waved them in a crisscross pattern, like a hostage signaling for help. The car never slowed, and Brown quickly disappeared -- a prisoner still to his own lucrative contract, and to a Knicks franchise that does not want him. ''Can't talk. Can't talk. Sorry,'' Brown said yesterday morning as the car, driven by an assistant coach, Dave Hanners, passed a group of reporters near the Knicks' training center in Greenburgh, N.Y. ''Hope the family is all right.''

Available in August for $60; (800) 289-0944 or www.salterhousewares.com. 2. The Casual Home Kitchen Cart's top is half wood, half stainless steel. The cotton T-Towel, with a drawing of a stylized sink, is from a series of patterned towels, including one with kitchen implements, another with dishes; $15 each at the MoMA Design Stores (not at the Web site) at 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street), (646) 613-1367, or 44 West 53rd Street, (212) 767-1050. 7. This cotton bag keeps washed lettuce fresh when closed; $16 at Williams-Sonoma stores; locations, williams-sonoma.com or (877) 812-6235. 8. Reston Lloyd enameled colanders come in many colors and in three sizes: 1.5-quart ($15.99), 3-quart ($17.99) and 5-quart; $21.99 each from Club Wedd at target.com or (800) 800-8800. 9. A new rechargeable hand vacuum, called Kone by Dirt Devil, comes in white with a lighted base (shown), $49.99, and it will be available starting next month. Kone vacuums in colors including purple and pink will be available beginning in September; from dirtdevil.com or (800) 321-1134. 10. A set of three Elegan Store and Show bowls with lids, by Rubbermaid, comes in three sizes: 6-, 10- and 18-cup. The set is $19.99 from Club Wedd at target.com.

The A.F.L.-C.I.O. will invest $700 million of pension-fund money in housing and real estate projects along the Gulf Coast in the next seven years, union officials announced in New Orleans. The program is also designed to create jobs for union members and will finance home mortgages for union members and municipal employees. LESLIE EATON (NYT)

SKIRTS aren't just for tennis players anymore. In the last year, skirts specially designed for runners have hit the market. No longer do women need to ''imitate men down to the last thread,'' said Nicole DeBoom, a triathlete whose company, Skirt Sports, sells three skirts and a marathon dress. ''Now, as you bounce past a guy in a skirt and he grunts, 'I'm getting beat by a skirt,' you can smile to yourself,'' she said. Most running skirts are made from moisture-wicking polyester-spandex blends and feature fitted shorts underneath to prevent chafing (and overexposure).
STECKLER--Frederick Gordon. On June 12 in Hannibal, MO. He was the son of the late Samuel and Stella Steckler, and brother of the late Roy Steckler. Service Thursday 10 A.M. at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

To the Editor: According to ''No Rove Charges Over Testimony in C.I.A. Leak Case'' (front page, June 14), the decision not to bring charges against Karl Rove in the C.I.A leak brought a ''surprise ending'' to the matter. In reality, however, no one should be too surprised by this ending.

HAAS--George Charles, Jr., 85 George Charles Haas Jr. of Lake Worth, Florida, died Monday, June 12, 2006, in West Palm Beach, FL. He was 85 years old. George C. Haas Jr. is survived by Susan Orthwein of Stamford, CT; Judith Eshelman of Putney, VT; and Sally Colbert of Weston, CT. Services will be held at St. David's-in-the-Pines Episcopal Church in Wellington, FL on Tuesday, June 20th, at 11am.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Argentina's 2-1 soccer victory against Ivory Coast in the World Cup referred incorrectly to the number of World Cup titles that Diego Maradona helped win for Argentina. It is one (in 1986), not two.
VILLENCY--Ruth. Friends of Akim mourn the loss of a ''Woman of Valor''. Past president of Akim Palm Beach. Heartfelt sympathy to her family. Elayne Flamm, Nat'l Chair; Jim Knee, Exec. Dir.

MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES--Placed OF Jay Gibbons on the 15-day DL. Recalled OF Ed Rogers from Ottawa of the IL. CLEVELAND INDIANS--Released LHP Scott Sauerbeck. TAMPA BAY DEVIL RAYS--Placed RHP Tyler Walker on the 15-day DL. Purchased the contract of RHP Tim Corcoran from Durham of the IL. Transferred RHP Dan Miceli from the 15-to the 60-day DL. National League LOS ANGELES DODGERS--Purchased the contract of RHP Chad Billingsley, from Las Vegas of the PCL. Optioned INF/OF Joel Guzman to Las Vegas. PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES--Recalled RHP Scott Mathieson from Reading of the Eastern League.

Iraqis have been congratulating each other ever since the news of Abu Musab Al-Zarqawi's death was announced (Mohammed Fadhil, of the blog Iraq the Model, wrote about this in Tuesday's Wall Street Journal). My mother spoke with her two brothers in Baghdad right after a friend called her with the news. A couple of days later, I called another uncle in Baghdad to congratulate him. He was happy, and said that people were celebrating even more than when Saddam was captured. The reason for that, explained Huda, a cousin's wife in Cleveland, was Zarqawi's overt appeals to Sunnis to kill Shias. My take on that is that through Zarqawi's open incitement to kill Shias and the bid for a civil war, Iraqis had to look their racism in the eye - and what they've seen, they haven't liked. The bearer of that message, had to be destroyed.
Matrix and Bubble Meter take note of the latest trend in real estate: the collapse of bubble blogs. -- DAMON DARLIN
It's no surprise that the real-estate market is being affected by the gigantic computerplex being built by Google in The Dalles, Ore.

Zip Realty has its latest report on price reductions in a number of markets across the country. It can't catch all of them, but the list gives you a good idea of how sellers are tempering their expectations.

A word to all not reading this on a Mac. Here's an excellent reason to feel good about working on a John Hodgman rather than a Guy From "Dodgeball": the FIFA World Cup site is offering free video highlights of all the games, and they look beautiful, I'm told, if you did not just shell out two grand for a brand new iMac. For some reason, the FIFA site uses a kind of Yahoo video which only plays on PCs -- forcing those of you on Macs to either take frequent two-hour-long breaks for breakfast, lunch and late lunch, or just rely on us to describe things in such intensity that you'll feel like you've already seen the highlights anyway when your friends who work on PCs describe them to you later. The same clips are also available on Univision's Web site, but again, if you use a Mac all you get there is a blank screen with the message: "Lo sentimos pero tu sistema operativo no es compatible."

A really aggressive real estate agent, especially in a seller's market, will march right up to the door of homes and ask if they are for sale. Some will have an offer ready from a client who loves the house and the neighborhhood.

Vancouver has been held out as one of the great examples of urban rejuvenation. Tall apartment towners concentrated downtown have created a density that in turn has created a lively street life. Residents shop and eat near their homes in the towers.
It's called Dance Festival in most of the city and it has been around, it seems, for as long as the public school system. The Times's David M. Herszenhorn reports. (Producer: Craig Duff)
Roger Cohen says that Holland's dreams are sure to be frustrated. What else is new?
Raser Technologies, a technology licensing company, said on Friday that Amp Resources, which Raser had agreed to buy, had delivered a termination notice of the acquisition agreement to Raser.
Vince Vaughn's acting career is going strong these days, but his mother's role as a high-end money manager seems to have flopped, big time.

Brookfield Asset Management, the biggest non-government owner of power plants in North America, agreed to buy a controlling stake in Transelec Chile SA for $1.55 billion from Hydro-Quebec, adding transmission lines to its South American energy assets.
Ze Frank talks with Warren St. John about the methods behind his madness as he prepares to perform a script written by a network of his online fans and critics. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

This year's Le Mans 24-Hour race, tomorrow and Sunday, will be worth watching for several reasons. Naturally the first reason is because it is Le Mans, one of the three greatest races in history, along with the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500. Secondly, it will be interesting also to see if Audi can win yet again, but this time with a diesel engine. They have already set a new record as the first team to set pole position with a diesel engine.
Click "more" for play-by-play commentary of the match, as it happened at the Niedersachsenstadion in Hanover. Jeff Z. Klein describes the action.

Moving to quell fears that securities laws might jump the ocean like bird flu, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday published what it called a "fact sheet" on cross-border exchange mergers. Though the NYSE Group was not mentioned, the S.E.C.'s statement was clearly geared toward recent concerns about that company's proposed $10.2 billion acquisition of Euronext -- specifically, concerns that such a deal might cause the more-stringent rules of the United States to apply to Euronext-listed companies.

Gov. George E. Pataki's own staff in Iowa isn't ready to endorse him for president -- quite a boost as he makes the rounds at the Iowa G.O.P. convention this weekend. (Props to Ben Smith for eyeballing.)

If you think the stock market has been grim in recent weeks, check out shares of the major exchanges, NYSE Group and the Nasdaq Stock Market. They are down 41 percent and 43 percent, respectively, from their 52-week highs. But TheStreet.com points out that shares of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange -- the largest publicly traded exchange in the United States by market capitalization -- have largely avoided the downdraft. They have fallen just 11 percent from their 52-week high and are up 2 percent in the past month.

"I still hate the FIFA World Cup," says Graciela Daleo. Her hatred lingers from the 1978 championship, when Argentina, the host team, won its first FIFA title. Daleo, a political militant, suffered through that World Cup from her clandestine prison cell in the Naval Mechanics School (ESMA), which housed the most infamous of the concentration camps put in place by the savage junta that governed Argentina from 1976-83, headed by General Jorge Videla. The ESMA, where approximately 5,000 people were illegally processed and detained, is located a scant 700 meters away from the River Plate Stadium, where Argentina beat Holland 3-1 in the final match of the 1978 cup.

Brooklyn City Councilman Bill de Blasio, a seasoned political operative, may be smarting today. He made an appearance before a local Democratic organization in his Brooklyn district on Thursday night to urge members to endorse his old boss, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Mr. de Blasio managed Mrs. Clinton's 2000 Senate campaign before running for a Council seat.)
A former executive with Goldman Sachs and J. P. Morgan Chase paid $5.8 million this month for two adjoining apartments at 1 Main Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn.
Everything seemed to be on track for German drug maker Bayer's $20.8 billion takeover of Schering until Merck started buying Schering stock last week.
Live play by play of Holland - Ivory Coast, described by Victor Mather.

An independent investment bank, GMP Capital Trust, entered the private-equity market on Friday, purchasing EdgeStone Capital Partners for about 157.7 million Canadian dollars ($140.8 million) in cash and units.
Tiger Woods is out and Steve Stricker is leading the pack.
Quarterback Rob Johnson experienced little pain at minicamp in his return from elbow surgery.
Is it better to be feared or ignored?
What today's traveling chef needs to make it on the road.

As Verizon Communications prepares to announce whether it will sell or spin off its directories business, a research analyst is calling the planned separation a "mixed bag" for the telephone giant's investors. Morgan Stanley analyst Simon Flannery said in a research note this week that Verizon's cash flow would take a hit and earnings would be "modestly" diluted by 8 percent if the yellow pages business, called Verizon Information Services, is split off. The unit is expected to produce $1.65 billion in Ebitda this year.

Energy Partners Ltd. said Friday it made a formal offer to buy Stone Energy for $51 per share, giving the oil and gas producer until Sunday to choose between its offer and a previous one from Plains Exploration and Production. Friday's bid valued Stone's equity at $1.4 billion, Energy Partners said.

Mirant, the Atlanta-based power company that recently withdrew an $8 billion hostile bid for it srival, NRG Energy, said Friday that it would hold a series of meetings with shareholders next week to discuss its future. It also suggested that it was not considering other acquisitions in the wake of the messy about-face on NRG.
Click on "more" to follow our live coverage of the match between Argentina and Serbia+/-Montenegro this morning in Gelsenkirchen, described by Rob Mackey.

Veolia Environnement sought to ease investors' fears of a costly bid battle for Vinci on Friday, saying it would not make a hostile bid for the company. Reaffirming that it wanted to merge with Vinci, Veolia said such a deal would create value through faster revenue growth and synergies that could add as much as 700 million euros ($882.5 million) annually to core earnings. A Vinci deal would be Veolia's largest since it was spun off in late 2002 from media group Vivendi.
Telenor has told some institutional shareholders in Vimpelcom that it might consider buying more stock in the Russian mobile operator, it said in a filing to market regulators in the United States.

BCE is holding talks with a private equity group that includes the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan to sell its Telesat satellite unit for 3 billion Canadian dollars ($2.7 billion), Canada's Globe and Mail newspaper reported on Friday.

The volume of private-equity backed mergers and acquisitions in the United States so far this year has reached record levels, according to research firm Dealogic. Through June 14, more than 500 deals worth $157.4 billion and backed by private equity have been announced. That's almost double the volume during the same period of 2005.
Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said Thursday that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years.

Lexar Media investors will find out late Friday whether the latest takeover bid from Micron Technology is enough to win over several large shareholders who complained an earlier offer was insufficient.

The co-chief executive of EADS, Noel Forgeard said on Friday he first knew in April of potential production problems on the Airbus A380 but there was no reason at the time to think the planemaker could not resolve them.
First came the branding, now come the lawsuits.
Two former New York Stock Exchange specialists broke the N.Y.S.E.'s "golden rule" by putting themselves ahead of their customers, a prosecutor said in opening arguments at their criminal trial.

It will take years for Fannie Mae, the mortgage giant, to change its practices and recover from an $11 billion accounting scandal, the top government official overseeing the company told the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday.
A federal judge ordered a unit of the bankrupt commodities broker Refco to honor a British court judgment to pay $124 million to Sberbank, Russia's largest bank, court documents show.

Boston Scientific said Thursday that a federal judge in Delaware had upheld last summer's jury verdict that the Cordis subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson infringed its patented design for coating coronary stents with drugs.
The H. J. Heinz Company said it was planning a vigorous campaign against attempts by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz to get the company to raise profit.

The landmark fraud and conspiracy case against the law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman has run into unexpected delays because five federal judges in Los Angeles who had been assigned to it recused themselves from hearing the matter.

The EMI Group, the music giant, agreed yesterday to pay $3.75 million to resolve accusations of paying radio programmers to play specific songs, becoming the last of four major companies to reach a settlement as part of an investigation by the New York attorney general.
Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives, The New York Times writes.
For eight years, curators, conservators, lighting experts and stonemasons have been making small but significant improvements to the five medieval cloisters that were fashioned into a museum in 1938.
The China Construction Bank said on Friday it had sold a portfolio of repossessed mortgage assets with a face value of 960 million yuan ($120 million) to a foreign consortium.
The painter Doug Auld uses art to attempt to destigmatize those whom disfiguring burns have reshaped into aesthetic outcasts.

Hoping to cash in on the billions of dollars spent on advertising, ClickShift has emerged from stealth with $6 million in new funding to build a business around its marketing analytics software, VentureWire has learned.

VLST, a tiny Seattle biotechnology company that was formed by two former Amgen researchers, has scored $55 million in venture capital that it will use to develop experimental treatments for diseases such as lupus, psoriasis and multiple sclerosis.

MicroNets and Eyespot are wading into a rapidly growing thicket of do-it-yourself Internet video editing start-ups. But armed with fresh funding and a focus on cellphones, the pair hope to distinguish themselves in a particularly hot tech segment.
The tech billionaire Mark Cuban, the high-profile owner of the NBA's Dallas Mavericks, may be out of bounds with his plan for a new Web site aimed at ferreting out corporate fraud, says BusinessWeek.

Two more Asian property sector I.P.O.s were overcome by the volatile market environment yesterday, with China-based Yanlord Land Group forced to cut the number of shares on offer by 29 percent and Cambridge Industrial Trust, based in Singapore, pulling its deal altogether. Both listing candidates had already completed their bookbuilding.

Golfsmith International, a seller of golf and tennis gear, priced an initial public offering of 6 million shares at $11.50 each, but investors apparently felt that was a bit on the high side. Golfsmith's stock was down 19 cents at $11.31 in morning trading.

When shares of Volcano and Synchronoss Technologies both priced below their expected range on Wednesday it looked as though the venture-backed companies were set up for a poor reception on the Nasdaq.

Shares of Aeroports de Paris, Europe's second-largest airport operator, rose as much as 6 percent Friday after its 1.4 billion-euro ($1.8 billion) initial public offering, the second-largest privatization this year behind the Bank of China.

Perella Weinberg Partners, the start-up investment firm launched yesterday by Joseph Perella, the veteran Wall Street banker, will not set up a private equity fund because of fears over potential conflicts of interest.

A Bear Stearns-backed hedge fund is shutting its doors under a mysterious cloud after regulators discovered an unusual, potentially improper pay deal in which one of the Wall Street giant's brokers was caught matching super-rich investors with secretive investment pools.

The race for control of Canada's nickel titans moved closer to the finish line as competition authorities in Europe, the United States and Canada signaled various levels of approval for competing bids for Falconbridge and Inco.
Suez, a French utility company, and the state-controlled Gaz de France reiterated Thursday their plan to merge, shrugging off doubts expressed by lawmakers of France's governing party.

A Venezuelan media investor, Gustavo Cisneros, said on Thursday his company, Venevision Investments joined a group of bidders exploring an offer for a Spanish language broadcaster in the United States, Univision Communications.

The independent directors of the Tribune Company threw their support yesterday behind the embattled chief executive, dismissing a call by the second-largest shareholder, the Chandler family trusts, to break up the company and questioning the shareholder's motives.

A federal jury has found that a policy requiring female Suffolk County police officers to go on patrol while pregnant or use sick or vacation time is discriminatory. In its verdict on Wednesday in a civil lawsuit, a jury in Federal District Court awarded damages ranging from $5,000 to $13,000 to six female officers represented by the American Civil Liberties Union. A Suffolk police spokesman said that the policy was changed last year to offer 90 days' limited duty to any officer who could not fit into a safety vest.
A 16-year-old Brooklyn girl was found fatally stabbed and her stepfather was found hanged yesterday afternoon in what appeared to be a murder-suicide in their East New York home, the police said.

A leading architectural and design association called yesterday for significant changes to the proposed Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, saying that the current plan would overwhelm the surrounding neighborhoods and burden the area with more traffic.

NEWARK, June 15 — St. Barnabas Health Care System, the state's largest private hospital network, has agreed to reimburse Medicare $265 million to settle charges that it overbilled the federal program over an eight-year period.

Five days before New York authorities say Kenny Alexis stabbed four people in a wandering 13-hour spree through Manhattan, a judge in East Boston released him on his own recognizance, an official in Massachusetts said yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., June 15 — Lurking behind the Wisteria Lane facade of suburban prosperity, many middle-class Long Islanders are barely hanging on and others are suffering in pockets of poverty, disease and dysfunction, a new report says.

An ice cream salesman was sentenced in State Supreme Court on Wednesday to 10 years in prison for assaulting two competitors in an attempt to take over their truck route. The businessman, Fernando Esparza, pleaded guilty last month to attacking Juana and Luis Marrero on March 27, 2004, as they and their granddaughter returned to a Bronx truck depot. The attack, in which Mr. Esparza used a wrench, left Juana Marrero hospitalized for more than a month.

Two former top managers at a Toms River water company were indicted yesterday by a state grand jury on charges that they manipulated tests to hide high levels of radium in the drinking water in Toms River, where environmental officials have linked contaminated water to childhood cancer. The defendants, George Flegal, 56, the former general manager for United Water Toms River, and Richard Ottens Jr., 52, the former operations manager, were accused of shutting down one of the water-supply wells during a test for radioactive materials. An internal inquiry uncovered problems with the test. The amount of radium did not pose an immediate health risk, the company said, and it informed its customers by letter of the elevated amount. New equipment has been installed to reduce radium levels, said Rich Henning, a United Water spokesman.

The city's jobless rate dropped to 5 percent in May, its lowest level in almost 18 years, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday. The number of city residents employed exceeded 3.6 million for the first time and the number of unemployed residents dropped to 189,000, the fewest since November 1988, according to the report. The unemployment rate, which fell from 5.4 percent in April, has not been lower than 5.2 percent since July 1988, when it was 4.9 percent. The state rate, which matches the national unemployment rate, dropped to 4.6 percent in May, its lowest in five years.

Zulima V. Farber, the New Jersey attorney general, said yesterday that she opposed legislation that would require jail time and revocation of retirement benefits for public officials convicted of corruption. Ms. Farber told the Senate Judiciary Committee that judges should have leeway to decide prison terms and whether pensions should be forfeited.

The federal Environmental Protection Agency has approved a revised plan by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to inspect the rooftop of the former Deutsche Bank building, which was struck by the collapsing 2 World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001. Hundreds of tiny bone fragments have been found in the gravel ballast, which is being cleaned before demolition of the bank building begins. The development corporation, which suspended rooftop work on April 20, said the remaining ballast, air intakes and mechanical equipment would be searched under the observation of the city's office of the chief medical examiner, the Fire Department and an archaeologist working for TRC, the environmental consultants on the project.

Two tractor-trailers collided between Exit 8A and Exit 12 on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday, killing one of the drivers and setting a large brush fire, the police said. The collision happened after 9 p.m. and shut down part of the New Jersey Turnpike for several hours.

Leszek Kuczera, the homeless man accused of setting the 10-alarm fire that destroyed a historic waterfront warehouse complex in Brooklyn last month, was indicted yesterday, prosecutors said. Mr. Kuczera, 59, could be sentenced to up to 15 years in prison if convicted of the charges: second- and third-degree burglary, fourth-degree arson, first- and second-degree reckless endangerment, petty larceny and criminal mischief, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney said. The warehouse blaze was the city's biggest fire in a decade, excluding the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Kuczera told the police that he lit the fire to burn the insulation off copper wire, which he planned to sell.

The New York City Housing Development Corporation announced yesterday the approval of $179 million in financing to build or preserve 5,300 low- and medium-priced apartments in the Bronx, Upper Manhattan and Queens. The financing includes $36 million to help keep 18 apartment houses in the state's Mitchell-Lama subsidized housing program, and $142.7 million to build or restore 22 buildings in the city. Emily A. Youssouf, the corporation's president, said:

A Manhattan jeweler lauded by hip-hoppers for his showy diamond creations was among 16 people arrested yesterday on federal drug and money-laundering charges. Federal authorities said the jeweler, Yakov Arabov, 41, known throughout the hip-hop world as Jacob the Jeweler, laundered money by taking cash from drug sales and failing to file the tax forms necessary for cash business transactions over $10,000. Mr. Arabov's jewelry business, Jacob & Company, has headquarters on East 57th Street. Federal authorities said that cash came from a gang called the Black Mafia Family, which dealt cocaine in Detroit beginning in the early 1990's. Stephen J. Murphy, the United States attorney in Detroit, said the group had conspired to distribute more than 476 kilograms of cocaine and had laundered about $270 million.

After more than two years as director of the Newark Police Department, Anthony F. Ambrose III, left, announced yesterday that he would retire on June 30. Mr. Ambrose's retirement coincides with Mayor Sharpe James's last day in office. Mr. Ambrose, who joined the force in 1986, has led the 1,800-member department since April 2004. Sakina Cole, a spokeswoman for Mayor-elect Cory A. Booker, said that Mr. Booker would probably announce a successor by July 1, when he is sworn into office.

Michael Jordan, who had been trying to own an N.B.A. team since he retired, settled for a co-ownership position with the Charlotte Bobcats, joining the majority owner Robert L. Johnson.

Parliament enacted a law requiring the government and employers to combat the soaring suicide rate, which is among the highest in the world. The law mandates that central and local governments come up with policies to prevent suicides, requires the government to report annually on its progress and asks employers to take better care of workers' mental health. Two men who had sought shelter in an underground bunker during an eruption on Mount Merapi were found dead from burns, officials said. The men fled to the shelter on Wednesday while helping to evacuate villagers during a burst of volcanic activity, and the steel bunker was later covered with up to six feet of fiery debris. Rescue workers found the two bodies after opening the shelter early in the morning, said Widi Sutikno, head of volcano relief operations. "We found the bodies were burned because of the hot temperatures in the bunker," Mr. Sutikno said.

Bombs exploded almost simultaneously at 41 government offices in the three provinces of the mainly Muslim south, killing a security officer and a local official and wounding 16 other people, including police officers and marines, the police said. Muslim insurgents believed to favor independence for the provinces were suspected. One bomb went off at a government office minutes before Deputy Prime Minister Chitchai Wannasathit was scheduled to visit the area. Mr. Chitchai is in charge of overseeing security in Thailand's south.

India nominated Shashi Tharoor, the United Nations under secretary general for communications and public information, to become secretary general when Kofi Annan's term ends on Dec. 31. Mr. Tharoor, 50, has been with the United Nations since 1978 and becomes the fourth announced candidate in a race in which the organization is expected to choose an Asian. Other candidacies are expected before the Security Council decides whom to recommend to the General Assembly this fall for ratification. Already in the race are Ban Ki Moon, the foreign minister of South Korea; Surakiart Sathirathai, Thailand's deputy prime minister; and Jayantha Dhanapala of Sri Lanka, a former under secretary general for disarmament.

Months before arresting 17 suspects in an alleged terrorism plot this month, agents of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service warned some of the suspects' parents that their sons were adopting "extremist ideology," The Globe and Mail reported. The accused, mostly in their late teens and early 20's, face charges of participating in a plot to attack Canadian landmarks and behead the prime minister. The approach taken by the agents to speak to the suspects' parents was in line with a strategy to scare off the accused by not hiding the fact that they were being monitored. "C.S.I.S. officers had approached some parents to let them know that C.S.I.S. suspected their children were becoming adherents to an extremist ideology," a spokeswoman for the service, Barb Campion, told the newspaper.

A NEW exhibition at the Sterling Memorial Library at Yale University details the life of Anne Morrow Lindbergh, the aviator, author and wife of Charles A. Lindbergh, in letters, photographs and books. The show, which opened last week, marks the first time Yale's collection of Mrs. Lindbergh's papers has been displayed. The exhibition also marks another milestone: If she were still alive, Mrs. Lindbergh, who died in 2001, would have turned 100 on June 22.

STERN--Richard Hoffman, age 94. On June 14, 2006. Beloved husband of Marion for 68 years. Loving father of Judy and Bob Snyder and the late Robert Hoffman Stern. Grandfather of Jill and Robert Granader, Andrew and Molly Snyder; great grandfather of Joshua, Jessica, Natalie, Sara and Samuel; member of the American Stock Exchange, Founding Member of Stern, Hoffman and Company, members New York Stock Exchange. Private service. Contributions to Visiting Nurse Service of N.Y. Hospice Care, POB 6445, NY, NY 10277.

WINTRUB--Warren G. Formerly of Stamford, CT died at his home in Boca Raton, FL on June 13th 2006 after a valiant battle with brain cancer. He was born on December 9, 1933 in Canton OH, son of the late Hy and Mollie Wintrub. He graduated from Ohio State University and Harvard Law School, becoming an Executive Partner at Coopers and Lybrand (now Price Waterhouse Coopers) and, after his retirement, served on eight corporate boards. He also served as treasurer of Stamford's Temple Sinai, Trustee of Low Heywood School, and on the Board of Rockrimmon Country Club. In Boca Raton, he was treasurer of Bocaire Country Club. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, the former Toby Buchhalter; his children: Marcy Wintrub and Duane Barton of Franklin, MA; Charles Wintrub and Tammy Davis of Stamford, CT; and Mark Wintrub of Clearwater, FL; four grandchildren: Jay and Samuel Wintrub and Arianne and Niall Barton; his sister: Nancy Gerstman of Kirkland, WA and his sister-in-law: Barbara Schmider of Albuquerque, NM. Services will be held at Temple Beth El of Boca Raton, 333 SW 4TH Ave, Boca Raton, FL at 11:00 AM on Friday June 16th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to: Hospice By The Sea 1531 West Palmetto Park Road Boca Raton, FL 33486 (561) 395-5031 Ext 5180 Or 800-633-2577 Or Bethesda Memorial Hospital Radiation Oncology Department 2815 South Seacrest Blvd Boynton Beach, FL (561) 391-8900 Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel 800-992-9262

An article in Business Day on Saturday about an agreement between Delphi Corporation, the auto parts supplier, and the United Auto Workers to extend a buyout program referred imprecisely to the role of General Motors. (The error was repeated in a front-page article on Monday.) While G.M. will pay the full cost of the first 13,000 buyouts that were offered, it will split the cost with Delphi for an additional 10,000 buyouts.

6 P.M. (AMC) VIVA BOND -- There's no need to leave the house on the final night of this weeklong series of back-to-back Bond. Since Sir Sean Connery (right, in ''Thunderball'') last week won the annual lifetime achievement award from the American Film Institute, it seems a good time to revisit some of his excursions as the super-suave superspy Agent 007. First, in ''Goldfinger'' (1964), he fights a scheme to rob Fort Knox. Then, at 8 p.m., he battles SPECTRE's evil Ernst Blofeld (Max Von Sydow), who tries to steal a couple of nuclear missiles in ''Never Say Never Again'' (1983). And if you're up for a late night, you can catch ''Thunderball'' (1965) at 11 p.m. This time, the whole world is held for ransom. 8 P.M. No, it's not a reality show. 8:30 P.M. NOW (13, 49) Rethinking summer travel plans because gas prices are so high? This episode might send you over the edge. In ''Crude Awakening,'' the host, David Brancaccio, asks big questions about big oil and why some companies' profits are still so, well, big. 9 P.M. (CMT) GREATEST MOMENTS: WILLIE NELSON -- This hourlong biography of the septuagenarian Texan features 20 significant moments from his career as a singer-songwriter, actor and author. An article yesterday about President Bush's plan to designate a 1,200-mile-long chain of largely uninhabited small Hawaiian islands as a national monument referred incorrectly to Gov. Linda Lingle. She is the second Republican to be elected governor of Hawaii. (The first was William F. Quinn, in 1959.) The article also misspelled the given name of the executive director of the Western Pacific Fishery Management Council, which opposes a complete ban on fishing in the area. She is Kitty M. Simonds, not Kittie.

SUN--Alexander S., he was a beloved father and scientist who dedicated his life to saving the lives of others. Born in 1939 in Hunan, China, Alexander Shikuan Sun survived the invasion of China during WWII. Alexander completed his college education in Taiwan and moved to the U.S. to receive his Ph.D. at the University of California at Berkeley. With the mentorship of Nobel Laureate, Dr. Melvin Calvin, Alexander excelled in the field of photosynthesis and later as a postdoc under the guidance of Nobel Laureate Christian de Duv. Alexander was a pioneer in the study of aging for more than 15 years as a faculty member at Mount Sinai Hospital and continued his research at Yale University School of Medicine. When his mother was diagnosed with inoperable Stage IV lung cancer and given 6 months to live, Alexander invented his Selected Vegetable Herbal Soup that allowed his mother to live an additional 17 years. Through the advancement and development of his company, Sun Farm Corporation, Alexander has aided cancer patients around the world. His dream of achieving approval from the FDA for his product was almost realized before his passing. Today, his dream of fully developing the first nontoxic treatment for cancer continues. He is survived by his brother and sister, nephew, niece, wife, and two sons who are determined to sustain what they hope to be his enduring legacy. A funeral will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street at 1pm on Friday, June 16. There will be a Memorial Service at the Sun home at 500 Anderson Ave., Milford, CT at 1pm on Saturday, June 17th. Donations can be made to the American Heart Association.

BANHAM--Judith A. The Sunshine Group mourns the loss of a dearly loved and highly respected member of our family, Judith A. Banham. A founding member of The Sunshine Group, Judy's leadership, wisdom and creativity, over 16 years, inspired and guided the development of properties that re-shaped the New York City skyline. An esteemed colleague, she will be remembered for her optimism, wit, intelligence and kindness. She touched each of us, as our mentor, friend, and trusted advisor. Judy will be deeply missed and remain in our hearts forever. The Sunshine Group $(6$)BANHAM--Judith. Our heartfelt condolences to the family, friends and colleagues at The Sunshine Group on the loss of Judy Banham. We were honored to know Judy professionally and personally. Our memories of Judy's dedication, professionalism, creativity and keen sense of humor will remain with us forever. She will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege to know her. May she rest in peace. From her friends at The Related Companies.

YORK--Rose. Rosie, mydearest, sweetest friend, godmother to my Caron, you'll be in my heart forever. Gale YORK--Rose E., 92, of New York, on June 14, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Manny and mother of Alen, Judd and Jesse. Loving grandmother of Kevin, Gregory, Jay, Barri and Elizabeth. Known and admired throughout the home fashions industry as an innovator and pioneer. She was one of the industry's first top female executives. Her companies, Countess York and Rose York Associates, popularized the use of comforters and introduced fully coordinated bedroom fashions. She served as the first woman president of the Feather and Down Association and served on Governor Rockefeller's Upholstery and Bedding Advisory Board. She was a board member of the Hebrew Institute of Long Island. She was named a Legend of the Industry by the National Bed, Bath and Linens Association, and a Dean of the Industry by the Home Fashions Products Association. Her love, warmth and energy will be missed. Services at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY on Friday June 16 at 12:30pm.

A front-page article last Friday about the federal government's approval of a vaccine against cervical cancer referred incorrectly to the disease's toll. Worldwide, it is a leading cause of cancer death in women, with 239,000 deaths in 2002, according to the World Health Organization; it is not the second leading cause of overall deaths among women. Cardiovascular diseases caused 8.6 million women's deaths in 2002; infectious and parasitic diseases, including AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, caused 5.1 million.

A group of Brooklyn College graduate art students whose thesis exhibition was shut down last month have filed a federal suit against New York City, the Parks Department and the college, claiming that their free-speech rights were violated and that their work was damaged when it was removed. On May 4, a day after the exhibition opened, the Brooklyn parks commissioner, Julius Spiegel, ordered it closed and changed the locks on the exhibition space, a World War II memorial hall near the Brooklyn Bridge. He said that some of the artworks -- featuring, among other things, a live rat and a sculpture of a hand holding a penis -- were not appropriate for families, violating an oral agreement he said his department reached six years ago with Brooklyn College on the use of the space. The suit, filed in district court in Brooklyn by Norman Siegel, the former executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, asks the court to send ''a clear message'' that ''government is not the appropriate body to judge the value of art.'' After the closing, the students accepted an offer by the college to relocate the show at an empty retail space at 70 Washington Street in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn. That exhibition closes today. RANDY KENNEDY
